column2:
'Experimental']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Sacred Bones']|2013-02-19 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 17:01:30.557911|"

""I found out I never knew where it was going/ And it might take a while
column3: Psychic Ills sing on One Track Mind. For the psych-dabblers (who celebrate their tenth birthday this year)
column4: this could have been the mantra all along. Following on from their debut Dins
column5: they spent the next decade playing with different sounds and approaches
column6: all loosely based around a fairly cosmic aesthetic. Where that album was new age-y with great pop impulses
column7: follow-up Early Violence was a left turn into murky
column8: minimalist post-punk. The all-improv Mirror Eye was a messy
column9: often intolerable stretch of raga drones. 2011's aptly titled Hazed Dream
column10: their first for New York imprint Sacred Bones
column11: toyed with bluesy Eastern psychedelia. They've never really had a compass
column12: and while the same school of thought has sometimes benefitted bands of their ilk in very exciting ways
column13: it's often left Psychic Ills' catalogue looking lopsided.

column1: Their latest effort
column2: One Track Mind
column3: is yet another diversion
column4: and one that couldn't have been predicted. Though most closely resembling Hazed Dream
column5: One Track Mind is the most straightforward album Psychic Ills have ever made
column6: offering 10 tracks that sound like they were all found along the same stretch of desert highway. Some of this is likely down to the presence of Neil Hagerty (of the Howling Hex
column7: and formerly Royal Trux and Pussy Galore)
column8: who contributes backing vocals and produced a couple songs. While One Track Mind is unlikely to be mistaken for the work of a different band (though it's uncannily like Black Rebel Motorcycle Club in parts)
column9: its unexpected clarity of vision and execution makes it arguably their best album since Early Violence
column10: though the rewards aren't great.

column1: Psychic Ills have always been more concerned with establishing feel and atmosphere over general songcraft
column2: and here they just about manage to bridge the gap. Almost every track features similar components-- rippling
column3: melty guitars
column4: country jangle
column5: hints of desert mirage psychedelia-- alternating between tempos that are either morphine drip-slow or a more sinister boogie. The songs with more step are the most memorable
column6: like ""Depot""
column7: its grislier tone coming off genuinely
column8: potently sexy. ""FBI"" and (more successfully) ""Western Metaphor"" stand out thanks to the added funk
column9: both blistered and blazed.

column1: Psychic Ills' Achilles' heel is still in plain view
column2: as much of One Track Mind is simply quite dull. It's a pretty repetitive listen thanks to the unvarnished structure of these songs
column3: but what really drags things down is a lack of necessary drama. A howling guitar on ""See You There"" brings some welcome fire and brimstone
column4: but mostly emphasizes the dynamic void elsewhere. The shout-along chorus of ""Might Take a While"" should feel like a sinner's testimony
column5: but comes across limp. The same can be said for Tres Warren's weightless vocals throughout.

column1: Considering the band's taste for zoning out to infinity
column2: One Track Mind really needed a harsher edit. With some tightening and pruning
column3: it could have burst into bloom. A decade in
column4: much of that spent in the shadow of peers like Black Dice and Gang Gang Dance
column5: it's heartening that Psychic Ills are still exploring new avenues
column6:
though they rarely punch above their weight.

"|17661.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/17661-psychic-ills-one-track-mind/|6.0|Zach Kelly

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/18809/homepage_large.6a90d786.jpg|Vol. 5|30993.0|Dur-Dur Band|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Awesome Tapes From Africa']|2013-02-19 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 17:01:31.082018|"

One of the greatest gifts recorded music gives us is a little piece of life from places we may never otherwise know. There was a time when Mogadishu
column2: the capital of Somalia
column3: was often referred to as the ""pearl of the Indian Ocean."" Before dictator Mohamed Siad Barre was ousted in 1991 and the country plunged into civil war
column4: it was a beautiful
column5: cosmopolitan city with the nightlife and bands to soundtrack it. Today
column6: it's a scarred place under persistent threat from the country's still-powerful religious militias and al-Shabaab suicide bombers.

column1: In the 1980s
column2: Mogadishu swung in spite of the country's oppressive leadership
column3: and one of its best-known acts was the Dur-Dur Band. Awesome Tapes From Africa has reissued some of their other albums before this
column4: but this release of Dur-Dur's Volume 5 is true to the label's name-- it's directly mastered from a cassette copy of the album
column5: one of about 10 that the band recorded. As you might imagine
column6: the preservation of master tapes has been low on the priorities list in Mogadishu for the last 20-odd years
column7: so this is a case of making the best of what's available. For the most part
column8: the sound is excellent. What hiss there is can easily be chalked up as part of the experience-- this music has never existed in a state of digital clarity.

column1: Like many of the great African dance bands
column2: Dur-Dur was a big
column3: versatile group
column4: with three horn players
column5: four lead singers
column6: three backing singers
column7: two guitarists
column8: a keyboardist
column9: a drummer
column10: two percussionists
column11: and a bass player. The vocalists trade off from song to song
column12: singing what the liner notes reveal to be mostly songs about relationship trouble (the novelty for Western listeners will be that a few deal with competition between wives in polygamist households)
column13: but unless you speak Somali
column14: you'll be following the melody and not the story-- and the melodies are excellent.

column1: The band's sound is funky throughout
column2: with apparent influences from American funk and soul and possibly even West African music-- the static harmony of their heavy vamps is well matched to the modal
column3: more traditional Somali vocal melodies. The group's one female singer
column4: Sahra Abukar Dawo
column5: also may have watched a handful of Bollywood films-- the edge on her held notes and the way she makes sudden leaps from legato to staccato phrasing is reminiscent of Asha Bhosle.

column1: The songs on the tape were clearly not recorded at the same session
column2: as the instrumentation and audio quality vary a fair amount. I wonder whether the musicians may have been updating their gear around the time they recorded this music-- some tracks feature meaty
column3: old-school organ
column4: while others feature tinny synth and what's either a drum machine or a very convincing approximation of one; the Caribbean-styled ""Dholey"" is replete with bendy synth lines and accent percussion that would sound at home on Phil Collins' No Jacket Required.

column1: In the early 90s
column2: unable to continue playing in their city
column3: Dur-Dur Band broke up and scattered abroad. Their competition did too
column4: and the cinemas
column5: studios
column6: hotels and theaters that once played host to their music closed
column7: or were forced to. In 2006
column8: Mogadishu was briefly dominated by Islamic extremists who attempted to outlaw music. The place where this music was made is still listed on the map as though nothing changed
column9:
but it's not the same city today as it was in 1987. This record is a superb glimpse of what was and what's been lost.

"|17612.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/17612-dur-dur-band-vol-5/|7.7|Joe Tangari

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/18821/homepage_large.4ff472e8.jpg|You're Nothing|29540.0|Iceage|['Rock']|1.0|0.0|0.0|['Matador']|2013-02-18 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 17:01:31.718373|"

When Iceage released their excellent 2011 debut
column2: New Brigade
column3: a large part of the discussion was dedicated to the nihilistic but crush-worthy Danish punk group's ages (at the time
column4: ranging from 18 to 19)
column5: and the fact that they sounded much older than that. You also got stories about their bloody live shows and
column6: later
column7: online handwringing about them baiting controversy Joy Division-style by apparently flirting with fascist gestures at one of those shows. In the beginning
column8: though
column9: people were most interested in the part about four young dudes exploding out of ""nowhere"" (the Copenhagen DIY scene) fully formed and going on to release one of the best punk collections in recent memory. Their shows during that time were powerful in a very messy
column10: very punk way. Two years later
column11: they're a different band
column12: one capable of more than shambling atmospherics and stage dives. Iceage write brilliant songs; on You're Nothing
column13: they've found a way to clarify these compositional skills without stripping away their power.

column1: Iceage's self-produced second album is even better than their debut. It's the quartet's first offering for the larger label Matador (the album's still being released by Escho in Denmark) and they come off even wilder and more chaotic than they did in 2011
column2: but also more experienced and nuanced. They've honed the uncanny sense of classic punk songwriting-- the guitar sound's huge
column3: the hooks more present
column4: the charisma of dead-eyed
column5: out-of-breath vocalist Elias Bender Rønnenfelt even greater. When you listen to the two records in tandem
column6: you realize how brittle New Brigade was: ""brittle"" in an excellently fuzzed
column7: rancid way
column8: but You're Nothing is a heftier experience.

column1: Unlike some groups who sign to a bigger label and beef up their sound in the wrong ways
column2: Iceage used the new resources to hone what they already did well without abandoning what made them interesting in the first place. You can hear the shift on the industrial/ambient instrumental ""Interlude""
column3: which helps to make Nothing darker and danker
column4: and on ""Morals""
column5: a mid-tempo piano-flecked track based on the 1960s Italian singer Mina's ""L'Ultima Occasione"". The odd reference fits here
column6: building into a frenzy that finds Rønnenfelt hoarsely screaming ""Where's your morals?"" over militaristic rhythms. And
column7: even with these slight tweaks
column8: they don't fuck around: New Brigade offered 12 songs in 24 minutes
column9: You're Nothing 12 songs in 28-and-a-half.

column1: On the more typical Iceage songs
column2: you get their mix of dirty punk and pulsing hardcore wrapped in an ink-black atmosphere
column3: and Rønnenfelt's existential musings come in more powerful doses. The brilliant opener ""Ecstasy""
column4: which sounds like a punk anthem mid-melt
column5: strings together furious tempo changes
column6: with
column7: Rønnenfelt howling ""I can't take this pressure"" in the final implosion. ""Coalition"" is a classic rager
column8: but you've never heard them doing doubled Sonic Youth guitar hooks like this. From ""In Haze""'s clipped and twangy d-beat to the heavy bass of ""Everything Drifts"" to the spiraling anthemics of the title track
column9: there are no weak spots. They chiseled things down for a reason: Great punk comes in spurts.

column1: Rønnenfelt has said You're Nothing was inspired in part by his readings of Bataille
column2: Genet
column3: and the like. On these off-kilter anthems
column4: you also imagine them reading Rimbaud
column5: and get the sense that the group has taken Richard Hell and the Voidoids' ""Blank Generation"" to heart with lines like the title track's ""Thats right
column6: you're nothing/ Feel the void grow"" and ""Ecstasy""'s ""But bliss is momentary anyhow/ Yet worth living for
column7: along with the romantic surrealism of lines like ""If I could/ Leave my body then I would/ Bleed into a lake/ Dashing away/ Disappear"" from from ""Morals"". These are the sentiments of early 70s NYC punk made by kids who can look back on hardcore and post-punk to add fuel to it.

column1: There was a moment at last year's Pitchfork Festival in Chicago that crystallized part of what makes Iceage fascinating: During their set
column2: a bass head blew
column3: then another
column4: and then another. This is something that would usually cause a group to apologize
column5: or blush
column6: or throw a tantrum. But Iceage kept playing
column7: didn't seem to sweat it
column8: and calmly did their thing until someone else fixed the problem. Bassist Jakob Tvilling Pless looked around and shrugged it off. Rønnenfelt also kept going. In a way
column9: it hardly registered. (Blank Generation
column10: indeed.) It was my favorite moment of the weekend
column11: and the most real: Iceage are a band who do these things honestly
column12: and without thinking too much about it
column13:
and that's a big part of their power. That they back the attitude up with songs of this quality is what makes them unstoppable on You're Nothing.

"|17623.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/17623-iceage-youre-nothing/|8.6|Brandon Stosuy

column1: 0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/18819/homepage_large.9e4f1e09.jpg|Clash the Truth|27968.0|Beach Fossils|['Rock'
column2:
'Experimental']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Captured Tracks']|2013-02-18 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 17:01:32.299335|"

Dustin Payseur sounds confused on Clash the Truth and rightfully so-- the Beach Fossils frontman is dealing with some tricky stuff. The time that's passed since Beach Fossils' solid
column3: well-received eponymous debut has given its name an unintended resonance; when we all pass from this mortal coil
column4: songs like ""Daydream"" and ""Vacation"" will be artifacts frozen in time
column5: informing our descendents of what happened in 2010 when the attitudinal tenets of chillwave were leeching into fuzzy
column6: soft-focus indie pop. There's the big picture stuff too: how to let one's ambition manifest
column7: what really endures in a world where so much is fleeting
column8: the challenges of squaring artistic expression with financial temptation. These are all relatable even if you're not in a band
column9: and they've proven fine inspiration for musicians who confidently use their art as a means of making sense of it all. On the other hand
column10: you sometimes get a passive-aggressive album like Clash the Truth
column11: which just sounds kind of confused.

column1: That's really the bigger concern. Their first album peers Wild Nothing
column2: Real Estate
column3: and Cloud Nothings have already proven themselves with assured
column4: expansive sophomore LPs
column5: and in even quicker succession
column6: former guitarist Zachary Cole Smith's Dive went from ""Beach Fossils side project"" to DIIV
column7: a band that surpassed them while operating in the same lane. There's a lack of conviction on Clash the Truth that finds numerous ways to infiltrate otherwise fine songs; the opening title-track makes an unexpected shift into a post-punk monotone which only stresses the utter lack of urgency in Payseur's vocals. By introducing a darker
column8: more socially aware edge
column9: it makes a song on the opposite end of the spectrum like ""Taking Off"" (""I'm taking off again/ It feels like it's so soon/ Am I excited or am I just so confused"") sound like a sheepish retreat to their previous work.

column1: Elsewhere
column2: Beach Fossils' indecisiveness arises more subtly. Some wondered if the relative cleanliness of their 2011 What a Pleasure EP detracted too much from the scrappy charm of Beach Fossils; it isn't the production methods that defined them so much as a kind of instrumental formalism where all the moving parts work in an almost militaristic lockstep. Without that rigidity
column3: you get amiable
column4: mid-fi college rock jangle along the lines of ""Careless"" and ""Crashed Out""
column5: or drowsy
column6: rainy-day window-watchers like ""Sleep Apnea"" that are perfectly tuneful in the moment and do little to impress on one's mind in any way
column7: let alone establish themselves as the work of Beach Fossils and no one else. You also get the sense of a bigger
column8: conceptual gambit that they couldn't quite grasp. The inclusion of several short guitar pieces isn't a bad move in theory; their riffs are often tasked with handling the expression when Payseur's flat
column9: affectless voice cannot. But while their titles suggest some sort of attempt at unifying the disparate sounds of Clash the Truth
column10: they manage no sequential effect and unlike DIIV
column11: the difference between their instrumentals and vocal pieces is too wide to hear them as anything other than filler.

column1: The wishy-washy attitude may be slightly bothersome for most of Clash the Truth
column2: but it's frankly inexcusable on ""Generational Synthetic""
column3: a song about the intersection of commerce and art whose title makes its point abundantly clear. Whether or not you think Beach Fossils have earned the right to make a song like this is a moot point. Two years ago
column4: you wouldn't have thought Cloud Nothings would've had much to say about it either
column5: but by making their sound a philosophy
column6: Attack on Memory was a kickass rock album and potent criticism. With its ringing guitars and brisk drum rolls
column7: ""Generational Synthetic"" is not too different than any other Beach Fossils song. If they admitted to their own ambivalence
column8: they'd come off as sympathetic. Instead
column9: Beach Fossils come from a place of judgment and open themselves up to criticism.

column1: As such
column2: ""Generational Synthetic"" doesn't stand up to the slightest bit of scrutiny-- when Payseur leans on sarcastic
column3: passive-aggressive commentary (""Oh your words are so poetic/ Generation apathetic"")
column4: he comes off as both preachy and phony in the context of music that sounds like part of the problem rather than the solution. And considering the troubling financial realities of even the most successful indie bands are common knowledge
column5: by sneering ""trade your fortune for a song
column6: he just sounds naïve.

column1: Beach Fossils aren't hypocritical for making ""Generational Synthetic""
column2: as criticizing a system you fully participate in is pretty much democracy in action. But a guy like Craig Schuftan
column3: author of the alt-rock dissertation Entertain Us!
column4: has thought longer and harder about the clash of indie rock and major money and calmly
column5: unintentionally ethers their message with one sentence: ""It's not so much about whether playing in front of a logo makes a mockery of your principles
column6: it's more about making sure your principles are good in the first place
column7: that they're strong enough to survive a process like that."" Or
column8: as Iceage put it
column9: ""Where are your morals?"" On ""Generational Synthetic""
column10: Beach Fossils get on a soapbox without taking a stand
column11: and it's the most damning example of the mixed messages that pervade Clash the Truth-- as the cliché goes
column12:
be the change you want to see in the world.

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/18954/homepage_large.8960a2ae.jpg|Moon B|31088.0|Moon B|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Peoples Potential Unlimited']|2013-02-18 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 17:01:32.767896|"

Dig if you will a picture: one producer armed with a few pieces of analog hardware
column2: trying to fashion funky beats with his makeshift home studio. In the wake of the lo-fi house movement
column3: particularly the clutch of artists operating in New York on labels like L.I.E.S.
column4: this is now a familiar scenario. But Moon B is a little different. For one
column5: he operates out of Atlanta
column6: where he has relatively few peers. His first album comes not via a hip underground dance label but through Peoples Potential Unlimited
column7: a D.C.-based imprint that specializes in reissuing old funk obscurities.

column1: Now
column2: Moon B is not a funk obscurity; or
column3: at least
column4: not an old one. This particular slab of eponymous vinyl is a reissue
column5: however: he self-released an album last year
column6: originally on cassette. It’s the first release on PPU’s Test Pressing series
column7: which focuses on contemporary music. But Gray’s work fits surprisingly well with its motley crew on PPU
column8: even if it’s not wholly retro. Its backward-looking qualities don’t indulge in nostalgia; instead of hypnagogic undercurrents
column9: Moon B coasts on a distinct feeling of ease.

column1: At its most bubbly
column2: like the opening track
column3: Moon B has the same cruising-along feel of the brightest of Detroit techno-- say Model 500 or Rhythim Is Rhythim-- but without the futurist impulses. Gray is reportedly a seasoned crate digger: mixed in with the usual touchstones of Detroit techno and meaty Chicago house is dreamy incidental music and dusty library records
column4: all packed together so neatly you can’t tell where one thread ends and the next begins. They have the improvised quality that comes from an artist who knows his equipment inside out: one who has listened to so many different kinds of records that he just feels where his melodies should snake and spiral out towards.

column1: Gray’s range extends from Dirty Mind-style 1980s minimal funk to the gummy groove of “B Side TRK 2”
column2: where the 4/4 beat feels like it’s held together with viscous jelly rather than house’s typical taut wireframes. Other tracks brim with the whimsy of imaginary after-school specials
column3: and the rest are gasping slabs of brittle soul that shake and shimmy with the homegrown twist of a real set of hands at the controls. Throughout
column4: Moon B stands out from the reams of music defined by lo-fi aesthetics; Gray seamlessly blends trends in electronic music without ever sounding trendy
column5:
proving that you don't have to have state of the art equipment or a heavy-handed concept to make distinctive and engaging dance music.

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/18862/homepage_large.5c3d6307.jpg|Long Island|19355.0|Endless Boogie|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['No Quarter']|2013-02-18 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 17:01:33.470455|"

If nothing else
column2: New York's Endless Boogie will go down in the annals of rock history for laying claim to one of the most appropriate band names of all time. Frontman Paul Major (aka Top Dollar) have a few things they do very well
column3: so fans will be happily unsurprised to hear that Long Island
column4: their third proper release for No Quarter
column5: is very much an Endless Boogie record. Which is to say that it's another scummy
column6: riff-stacked
column7: delightfully boneheaded affair.

column1: Endless Boogie tend to go where the spirit moves them-- they're known for unpredictable gigging
column2: marathon sets
column3: and hard to find 12""s-- and they've earned the right to be comfortably stubborn as Major approaches his 60th year. ""Ain't no guest list
column4: no free drinks
column5: he snarls on the Radio Birdman-like wailer ""General Admission"". ""No free rides
column6: I hope to see you outside."" Long Island operates strictly on Endless Boogie's terms
column7: though at 80 minutes
column8: listener fatigue is a real danger. By the time you're through with the incredibly fun ""Taking Out the Trash""
column9: the realization that you have a whole hour left to go sets in pretty hard.

column1: But Long Island knows its audience. The repetitive
column2: fairly simple templates give Major and guitarist Jesper Eklow room to play around
column3: and they do in a fashion as elegant as it is sloppy. Even if you find yourself nodding in and out of these infinite
column4: often fluid stretches of psychedelia
column5: garage
column6: and scorched
column7: Southern-fried stoner rock
column8: there are frequent enough bursts of extra gnarly guitar work
column9: or some especially tasty groove
column10: to snap you out of a haze.

column1: There are also some real tunes here. Opener ""The Savagist"" is the sound of your favorite local go-nowhere bar band getting to the bottom of a bottle of absinthe
column2: with Major growling all over it like Screamin' Jay Hawkins at his most pig-snort feverish. It's the best of three songs that go well over the 10-minute mark
column3: and while it may seem blasphemous to suggest as much of a band like this
column4: the shorter
column5: tighter tracks suit them best. The squalling ""Imprecations"" plays like the soundtrack to Easy Rider if it starred your drunk
column6: unemployed uncle
column7: and the parched
column8: gritty ""Occult Banker"" screams like a man in the deepest ethers of a Guatemalan Insanity Pepper trip.

column1: The production is appropriately seedy
column2: showcasing equipment that sounds like it's been on its last legs for a few decades
column3: and when the band cooks
column4: they really cook. Long Island probably isn't going to win any new fans for Endless Boogie
column5:
but their strengths are on display regardless.

column1: 0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/18910/homepage_large.c97293e0.jpg|Miracle Mile|26974.0|STRFKR|['Rock'
column2:
'Pop/R&B']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Polyvinyl']|2013-02-18 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 17:01:34.234815|"

Give this to Josh Hodges: He seems like a guy who would do reasonably well during any period of indie rock history. If it was the 1980s
column3: he probably would have fronted a band that sounded like the Replacements. If it was the 90s
column4: he'd be penning decent approximations of Pavement songs. If it was the early 00s
column5: he'd be part of the post-Strokes ""return of rock"" wave of Vines and Jet wannabes. But Hodges came up in the late 00s
column6: so he founded STRFKR (or Starfucker
column7: or Pyramid or Pyrmamiddd when they briefly lost their nerve) and emulated the MGMT/Passion Pit model of synthy indie pop. No matter what
column8: Hodges has what it takes to survive
column9: if not exactly thrive.

column1: Miracle Mile is STRFKR's fourth record
column2: which seems like a lot for a perennial second-tier band on the dorm-party circuit. This is a testament to Hodges' skill as a craftsman: He can turn out reasonably engaging amalgams of lightly funky disco rhythms and mildly trippy psych rock ambiance without breaking a sweat. His records-- now made in collaboration with a band that includes bassist Shawn Glassford
column3: drummer Keil Corcoran
column4: and guitarist Patrick Morris-- are always immaculate and thoroughly professional enterprises. But
column5: like a machine designed to endlessly churn out identical pots
column6: STRFKR apparently never wondered if the world needed another record like Miracle Mile. This band can capably turn out listenable
column7: inoffensive music that conforms to the demands of the marketplace
column8: but that doesn't mean Miracle Mile has any discernible personality or artistic character. It's just another well-made pot on a shelf with nothing inside.

column1: It's a shame
column2: because Hodges obviously wants STRFKR to stand out and mean something. There's that band name
column3: of course. There's STRFKR's theatrical live show
column4: which is like the kids' table alternative to of Montreal. And there's Hodges' academic streak
column5: which manifests itself in references to college syllabus-approved philosophers
column6: like Alan Watts on 2011's Reptilians and Khalil Gibran on Miracle Mile. It would be stretch to call Miracle Mile a concept record
column7: but there are thematic links between the songs. The album-opening ""While I'm Alive"" sets the tone: While the music is sugary and blandly hooky
column8: Hodges grasps for the profound in the lyrics
column9: singing about the underlying fear of death that's the opposite of YOLO hedonism: ""Just keep telling myself/ To live my life alive/ Like everything else/ Just keep on breathing and live."" If only Hodges didn't write about going through the motions like a man going through the motions.

column1: Hodges repeatedly refers to restless nights
column2: romantic tragedy
column3: and emotional crisis on <i>Miracle Mile
column4: even as it remains set on a sleepy default pop rock setting. If anything is truly at stake here
column5: Hodges is unable to convey it musically. Instead
column6: STRFKR falls back on the band's dubious gifts for indie pastiche. ""Sazed"" shoplifts at least a couple of elements from Washed Out's already plundered ""Feel it All Around"". ""Malmo"" references Bon Iver's ""Holocene"" and utilizes the lamest of recent indie trends
column7: the ""catchy"" whistle. ""Leave it All Behind"" and ""Last Words"" are typical of the same-y
column8: mid-tempo laptop pop songs that dominate the interminable second half of Miracle Mile.

column1: At 15 tracks
column2: it's at least twice as long as it should be. It's possible that the cumulative deadening effect of Miracle Mile is intentional
column3: or that the contrast between the vacuous music and the spiritual ennui of the lyrics is supposed to be ironic. But Miracle Mile doesn't seem smart enough
column4: musically or lyrically
column5:

Push the Sky Away is the 15th official album by Nick Cave and the Bad Seeds
column3: but it could almost be their first. After 30 years together
column4: the band has effectively come full circle
column5: having completed its evolution from untamed beast to rock dignitary and
column6: via the fearsome alter-ego offshoot Grinderman
column7: back again. Factor in the recent resignation of Mick Harvey (Cave's right hand man since their Boys Next Door days in the late 1970s)
column8: and the sudden deep-sixing of Grinderman (as a recording entity
column9: at least)
column10: and the Bad Seeds' reliably black essence now more closely resembles a blank canvas.

column1: Push the Sky Away scans as the Bad Seeds' post-Grinderman comedown album
column2: to be filed alongside statelier turns like 1997's The Boatman's Call and 2001's No More Shall We Part. But where the Bad Seeds' mellow records usually find Cave in pensive
column3: piano-man mode
column4: Push the Sky Away presents an uncharacteristically weightless
column5: eerily atmospheric sound; in lieu of crossover ballads like ""Into My Arms"" and ""People Ain't No Good""
column6: we have foggy reveries built upon ominously rumbling bass lines
column7: twitchy rhythmic tics
column8: and hushed-voice intimations. It may not erupt with same force as the Bad Seeds' stormiest gestures
column9: but the underlying menace fuelling it remains.

column1: The approach bears the influence of Grinderman as much as the Bad Seeds' decidedly more raucous 2008 release
column2: Dig!!! Lazarus Dig!!!. Though Grinderman was often seen as the Bad Seeds' wild child offspring
column3: it was also a vehicle through which Cave and his increasingly prominent foil
column4: Warren Ellis
column5: could experiment with textures and loops (to the point of spawning a remix album). These production intricacies form the bedrock of Push the Sky Away
column6: which is less a showcase for Bad Seeds' powerhouse prowess than a reconstructed fever-dream memory of it
column7: transmuting the familiar into something foreign. There's a sense of the Bad Seeds expanding their sound and unlearning it at the same time. (Drummer Jim Sclavunos wins the Take One for the Team Award here
column8: tempering his usual thunderous thrust for stragetically timed snare-rim taps and brushed-skin driftiness.)

column1: The freer
column2: more exploratory bent extends to Cave's lyric sheet. True to the album's desolate
column3: dead-of-night air
column4: his songs are less narratively focussed
column5: more stream-of-consciousness haze
column6: countering Dig!!! Lazarus Dig!!!'s gritty urban milieu with impressionistic images of mermaids and the sea that reinforce the sense of a mind floating away. Tellingly
column7: Cave has said his writing for the album was inspired by ""Googling curiosities
column8: and his lyrical logic follows the same circuitous path as an extended
column9: after-hours web-surfing session
column10: bouncing between subjects profound and frivolous
column11: indulging life-long obsessions and newfound
column12: fleeting fascinations. Bad Seeds albums used to inspire you to reacquaint yourself with folk tales and the Old Testament; this one will have you brushing up on quantum physics
column13: astronomy
column14: and ""Hannah Montana"".

column1: That last bit shouldn't come as a surprise: Over the past decade
column2: Cave has shown a greater eagerness to interact with contemporary pop culture
column3: from the Oprah shout-out on Grinderman's ""Kitchenette"" to the comically perverse Avril Lavigne fixation that formed a subplot in his 2009 novel
column4: The Death of Bunny Munro. But where these namedrops have felt like humourous incongruities in Cave's fire-and-brimstone universe
column5: Push the Sky Away straight-facedly acknowledges how modern phenomena like Wikipedia and Miley Cyrus hold as much sway over the populace as the Bible and Robert Johnson once did
column6: while translating brooding ballads into text-speak and slang (""We No Who U R""). And where more recent Bad Seeds standouts like Abattoir Blues' ""There She Goes
column7: My Beautiful World"" and Lazarus' ""We Call Upon the Author"" saw Cave writing songs about writing songs
column8: Push the Sky Away goes one meta: The album's most elaborate track
column9: ""Jubilee Street""
column10: is answered by ""Finishing Jubilee Street""
column11: a spartan
column12: spoken-word account of a dream Cave had just after he completed work on the former.

column1: For all the album's wandering spirit
column2: the first eight tracks on Push the Sky Away are neatly structured into two complementary
column3: four-song halves that mirror one another: each comes outfitted with an ominous opening salvo (""We No Who U R""
column4: ""Mermaids"")
column5: an icy glare that thaws into an open-hearted address (""Wide Lovely Eyes""
column6: ""We Real Cool"")
column7: and a scenery-chewing set piece (""Water's Edge""
column8: ""Finishing Jubilee Street"") that hearkens back to early Bad Seeds storytelling turns like ""The Carny"". (Fittingly
column9: original bassist Barry Adamson rejoined the band following the album's recording.) The simmering tension of each side is eventually unleashed through a slow-boiling
column10: show-stopping epic. The aforementioned ""Jubilee Street"" is built upon a repeated ""Hey Joe""-like chord progression that
column11: thanks to Ellis' mesmerizing violin lines
column12: grows more grandiose with each passing cycle
column13: reaching such dizzying heights that you almost forget you're listening to a song about a murdered prostitute. But even that pales in comparison to side two's colossal ""Higgs Boson Blues""
column14: which begins as a solitary 3 a.m. strum in the vein of Neil Young's ""On the Beach"" but
column15: over seven writhing minutes
column16: ends up traversing the entirety of modern history
column17: from ""the missionary with his small pox and flu"" to the birth of the Devil's music to the anticipated death of a certain teen-pop starlet who ""floats in a swimming pool.""

column1: ""Higgs Boson Blues"" is named for the elementary particle whose discovery last year was hailed as the most significant breakthrough in contemporary physics
column2: one that essentially provides the missing piece in explaining the structure of our entire universe. But its discovery after 50 years of intense research has also led to something of an existential crisis among physicists
column3: who are now left with no theory to prove
column4: and asking themselves
column5: ""What now?"" One can imagine Nick Cave asking himself the same question as he entered his fourth decade fronting a deviant rock band that had seemingly mined every last shade of noir. But in this album's quietly defiant title-track denouement
column6: he finds a renewed mission statement: ""If you got everything and you don't want no more/ You've got to just keep on pushing
column7: keep on pushing/ Push the sky away."" Because when you can't see the sky
column8:
you can't see your limits.

Screaming Females compensate for one half of its moniker not being entirely accurate-- two-thirds of the New Jersey trio is male
column2: after all-- by redoubling its efforts on the other half. Last year's Steve Albini-produced Ugly was a ferocious post-punk
column3: post-90s
column4: post-patience for your sorry ass guitar-rock record. It sprawled like a double gatefold classic rock LP
column5: but the tone was intensely
column6: if not narrowly
column7: aggressive. The group's sole Screaming Female
column8: singer/guitarist Marissa Paternoster
column9: tore through a series of loose songs spotlighting her unpredictable vocal and six-string contortions. Any bruises left in her wake were intentional.

column1: The new Chalk Tape EP is half as long as Ugly
column2: but twice as musically diverse. The record's short
column3: economical songs expand on the psychedelic influences broached on Ugly
column4: and take them into more sophisticated emotional terrain. Chalk Tape even subs in an acoustic guitar every now and then
column5: and changes up the band's grunge/sludge template with Middle Eastern grooves and new wavey basslines. These subtle yet unmistakable musical flourishes accompany some of the hookiest
column6: most melodic songs Screaming Females have ever recorded.

column1: In a way
column2: Chalk Tape feels like an act of reconnaissance
column3: a cautious feeling-out to gauge whether fans will appreciate a relatively poppy follow-up to Ugly. Chalk Tape is composed of songs recorded throughout 2012 in a manner that deviated from the band's usual ""jam it out in the studio"" approach. These tracks started out as concepts written on a chalk board; the band then translated these ideas into songs
column4: and laid them down quickly without further revisions. For the standout ""Bad Men""
column5: the original concept could have been ""Tusk-era Stevie Nicks ballad with a doom-folk twist""; that's what it ended up sounding like
column6: anyway
column7: thanks to Paternoster's surprisingly tender vocal and a demented
column8: druggy coda that takes romantic desolation to a disquieting place. On the opposite end of Chalk Tape's spectrum is the brilliant ""Crushing the Kingdom""
column9: a Dio-esque metal epic in 63 shred-filled seconds. In the middle is ""Sick Bed""; a rubbery bassline gives the song an extra dose of sinister psych rock evilness
column10: but it's Paternoster who nails you to the floor
column11: double-tracking her voice on the verse and turning it into a duet between ghostly
column12: undead witches.

column1: Chalk Tape isn't completely removed from its predecessor; ""Green Vapors"" and the hellacious blast of white noise that is ""Wrecking Ball"" offer plenty of sudden
column2: violent interruptions and skin-crawling rants. But now more than ever
column3: Screaming Females can grab you with songs
column4: rather than just an overpowering instrumental attack. ""Poison Arrow"" might be their best song yet-- Paternoster hangs back for the first part
column5: letting the swinging rhythm section of Jarrett Dougherty and King Mike do most of the heavy lifting until slashing out some space for a choked
column6: inverted guitar solo that stops just short of exploding. This is an exciting new direction for a very exciting rock band. Chalk Tape could wind up as an important transitional milestone on the way to a future breakthrough but for now
column7:
it's a very engaging record on its own.

column2:
'Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Bureau B']|2013-02-15 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 17:01:36.243079|"

The term ""Krautrock"" was coined in the UK press to describe the experimental German rock bands of the late-60s. It stuck to German experimental musicians thereafter
column3: even though many of them embraced electronics as convenient solid-state synthesizers replaced unwieldy modular ones. It includes bands as organic and free as Faust or Amon Düül II
column4: bands as mechanical and stiff as Kraftwerk or Can
column5: and bands as wholly mystic as Popol Vuh. And yet for all its evident disjointedness
column6: so-called Krautrock has a few broadly consistent traits. One is a shared drive to escape from blues-based rock
column7: either by traveling back in time to pilfer from classical
column8: jazz
column9: and world music or forward to embrace the newfangled analog synthesizer. Another is a high quotient of improvisation and open forms. A third
column10: quite simply
column11: is Hans-Joachim Roedelius.

column1: Born in Berlin between the world wars
column2: Roedelius is an elder statesman who epitomizes everything we associate with German experimental music over the last four decades. In 1967
column3: he co-founded the influential experimental music venue Zodiak Free Arts Lab with early Tangerine Dream member Conrad Schnitzler
column4: where the pair met Dieter Moebius. They formed the trio Kluster
column5: becoming Cluster after Schnitzler's brief tenure ended. Meanwhile
column6: Moebius and Roedelius created another seminal band
column7: Harmonia
column8: with future Kraftwerk and Neu! guitarist Michael Rother. Cluster played progressive rock
column9: abstract experimental music
column10: new age
column11: and more
column12: but made their most lasting impression as ambient keyboard caressers
column13: infusing minimalist patterns and inert drones with playful jazz and spacey themes.

column1: When Moebius left Cluster and the name was retired in 2010
column2: Roedelius almost immediately formed Qluster with Onnen Bock
column3: a relative youngblood at something like 40
column4: and began to issue low-key yet gratifying albums at a furious pace. 2011 saw the release of a trilogy
column5: some of it recorded live and all of it focused on improvised interplay for keyboard or piano. Though Antworten reputedly closed the trilogy
column6: fourth record Lauschen picks up where it left off. Recorded live in Berlin with guest Armin Metz
column7: it's the sonic document of three men standing very still in front of intimidating electronic boxes. But these three are good enough to make that more exciting than it sounds. While the title (Listen in English) makes clear that this is head music
column8: the body is not neglected. It becomes a sensitive head-to-toe antenna as different feelings radiate from the same harmonies depending on the palpable shapes and lengths of the waves.

column1: Lauschen frequently takes on a sinister edge but flows through plenty of tender and contemplative states as well. The musicians push at common objectives rather than one another
column2: sliding into the grooves around each other's staked-out timbres and frequency ranges. The record is divided into nine movements
column3: each named for a different classical muse
column4: and while they roll continuously one into the next
column5: they are also admirably self-contained. The ominous but controlled threnody of ""Kalliope"" runs right  into ""Urania"" before rumbling filter snaps begin a seamless transformation. The pitches are limited but their oscillation rates and periodic durations are constantly
column6: calmly
column7: and decisively nudged around. Held notes can be so intricately gated and filtered that their pitch and timbre contours verge on miniature compositions unto themselves. In the music's mostly slow movement
column8: you can track individuals having and implementing ideas
column9: each putting a meaningful twist in the whole.

column1: Any jam involves throwing some spaghetti at the wall
column2: but Qluster flick their pasta with sniper-precision. The highlights for me are the silkily pooling tonality of ""Euterpe""
column3: the flutey Mesoamerican dream turned subterranean nightmare of ""Terpsichore""
column4: and especially ""Melpomene""
column5: which starts as a music-box ballet before majestic slopes of bass in the distance widen out the sense of scale. The invention only flags near the end
column6: where ""Thalis"" reprises the a theme from ""Erato"" without putting much of a new spin on it. But if anyone has earned some placid victory laps after a lifetime of tireless exploration
column7: it's Roedelius. None of these Qluster albums are apt to become cornerstones of your kosmische discography. But all of them
column8: including Lauschen
column9: offer the pleasure of hearing a deep musical mind still paddling the stars
column10:
at consummate ease now in his weathered craft.  

"|17719.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/17719-qluster-lauschen/|6.5|Brian Howe

Companion is the project of the singer/songwriter Pepi Ginsberg

column4: however

column6: magic-hour production
column7: booming drums
column8: and her trembling
column9: emotive voice

column12: she has said

column14: and somehow emerged with a project that resembles Kate Bush singing Gloria Estefan. Go figure.

column1: Whatever her influences
column2: they moved Ginsberg to some of the most charged
column3: vivid songwriting of her career
column4: starting with the ripe opener ""20th Century Crime"". Set to a watery
column5: oscillating synth part that evokes a blue John Hughes skyline
column6: she sings in a delicate puff of head voice on the verses before opening up into the glorious
column7: stretched-out melisma of the chorus. She has a fluttery
column8: decentered approach to singing-- somewhere between R&B theatrics and Natasha Khan doing vocal warm-ups-- that is intriguingly wayward

column1: ""No Kid/Blast""
column2: for example
column3: starts as a slow-burning lover's lament (""You
column4: you
column5: you/ You treat me like an arrow/ You shoot me into places/ I don't wanna go"")
column6: Ginsberg bending notes soulfully on the chorus. The guitar smears its tone into a Grizzly Bear-ish blot
column7: Ginsberg stacks her voice in layers of harmony
column8: and then itchy drums and post-punkish guitars break out
column9: starting a panicky dance party that settles back down just as it gets going. Every song comes with at least one cheap-seats hook
column10: but the album's tone is unsettled

column12: and it makes Companion a genuinely unpredictable listen.

column1: Some of these songs digress so often that they end up banging their heads away in corners; ""Homegirl"" interrupts itself repeatedly in its three minutes without making a point. Companion feels like a band hashing out its identity
column2: and there are portions (the drifting instrumental coda to""Swimming/Wave"") where the listener feels like taking a bathroom break to leave them to it. The quirks that make Ginsberg's vision personal and unusual detract from the record's streamlined nature; pared down
column3: it would almost certainly hit harder. As it is
column4: Companion is a dramatic
column5: ambitious record that falls a few inches short of its target. Ginsberg and co. aren't quite ""there"" yet; they sound like a band opening up for the band they ultimately want to become. But you can hear nervy exhilaration in Companion's best moments: ""Welcome the new age
column6: Ginsberg exults on ""New Age/Real Change"". Hopefully with a few more anthemic warm-up stretches
column7:
they'll get there.

column13: and headband; dance moves from the ""How to Ace Your Wes Anderson Audition"" guidebook.

column1: Smith comes across similarly disenchanted and tempted by the prospect on Songs for Imaginative People

column3: he laments how we waste our lives as collateral for empty material satisfaction in a lolling drawl that comes off like a bad James Murphy impersonation (which is doubly unfortunate since LCD Soundsystem lampooned vacuity with greater elegance). On the subsequent ""You Can't Be My Girl""

column6: and completely shunning his naturally artless expression isn't the way to get there.

column1: ""Have you ever seen a wrecking ball as small as her?/ She smashes up my glasses when she passes but it doesn't hurt/ I can't see straight now with this crush/ But I have all of this love to give

When the Das Racist narrative began to take shape
column2: the trio was almost always presented as a New York rap act. That handy descriptor overlooked the fact that Kool A.D.
column3: the rapper born Victor Vazquez
column4: is Bay-blooded. His recent solo incarnation acknowledges his roots more explicitly-- last spring's 51 and now
column5: the sprawling mixtapes 19 and 63
column6: are titled after Bay-Area bus routes. They're filled with local producers and the sort of minimal twitch-fizz beats aligned with San Francisco's hyphy sound
column7: and he's often found snarling a solid E-40 impersonation. ""I feel like while I still can
column8: I should wild out the West coast a little before I completely grow up
column9: he said in an unusually earnest interview a few weeks ago
column10: and explained that he's spending prolonged stretches back home. ""I'm guess I'm getting all my little nostalgia things out of the way.""

column1: But it would mean selling Vazquez short to say he's leaning on tradition or simply indulging Bay-heyday nostalgia on his new solo material. If there's a particular San Francisco artist he shares the most DNA with here
column2: it's Lil B
column3: the wildly unorthodox and prolific rapper whose Wifi signal strength has always been far more important than his actual coordinates. 19 and 63 are pegged as ""outtakes and collaborations""
column4: and they share the same freewheeling (based?) sensibilities as many pages in Lil B's catalogue
column5: clocking in at two hours and showcasing a scattershot couple dozen producers and guest rappers. As much as Kool A.D. pays tribute to his hometown with Mac Dre references and song titles like ""Bay Shit""
column6: he deliberately strays from heritage formulas. He randomly shouts names like ""Bieber"" and ""Madonna"" throughout the tapes
column7: and the single ""Eroika"" knowingly evokes raps in the mold of Lil B's ""Ellen Degeneres"". The wacky fusion of traditional Bay-Area themes and contemporary Web 2.0isms makes for some of the most delightfully unwieldy and entertaining mixtapes to arrive this year.

column1: To call these tracks ""outtakes"" implies there was more than one take
column2: but many of them sound like they were rapped off-the-cuff in a single go
column3: which is generally for the best. Kool A.D. sometimes cuts the tracks off arbitrarily
column4: loops the tape backwards
column5: samples spoken word
column6: or adjusts his vocal track to cartoonish speeds. He repeats lines we've heard before
column7: as though he's folding a set of crude origami animals out of the same piece of paper. On 19
column8: the thorny and psychedelic foil to the gentler 63
column9: he defiantly chooses to name one of his catchiest-ever songs ""Beautiful Naked Psychedelic Gherkin Exploding Tomato Sauce All Over Ur Face
column10: Flame Grilled Painting"". You might say he just doesn't give a fuck if there weren't some kind of base-level motivation required to sit down and record 38 rap songs. But for a couple of tapes so big and discombobulated
column11: there are hardly any spots that feel too slack or sluggish. You can either pick out a standard album length's worth of songs to replay or listen to the whole shebang front to back
column12: waiting for esoteric stoned gems and bits of spoken-word trivia to dislodge themselves and worm their way into your brain.

column1: 19 and 63 are organically avant-garde
column2: and they assert Kool A.D.'s militant refusal to take himself seriously. Occasionally he'll break from his loopy gags and grow stone-faced
column3: only to make a show of yanking himself back up into the clouds. ""Shit
column4: my dreams were probably made up in the Philippines/ By a little kid who would kill to live as ill as me
column5: he raps with an unusually sharp-tongued political urgency on ""Moneyball"" before conceding
column6: ""Or some shit/ Man I'm dumb
column7: I don't read enough."" The raps are quickly cut short
column8: and he heaves
column9: ""I'm an idiottttttttttttt."" So many of these songs prove that he's both highly capable of and entirely unwilling to tuck his shirt in and rap a lyrically upright verse-- some of the sharpest stuff comes out of his mouth when he's slack-jawed and intentionally limp-tongued
column10: as though he wants to distract us from how skilled he is by flubbing his words. He only succeeds in sounding savvier as a result
column11:
and it's often a deeply enjoyable contrast. Kool A.D. keeps proving that extremely talented underachievers are always the most fun to be around.

column5: the sprawling mixtapes 19 and 63
column6: are titled after Bay-Area bus routes. They're filled with local producers and the sort of minimal twitch-fizz beats aligned with San Francisco's hyphy sound
column7: and he's often found snarling a solid E-40 impersonation. ""I feel like while I still can
column8: I should wild out the West coast a little before I completely grow up
column9: he said in an unusually earnest interview a few weeks ago
column10: and explained that he's spending prolonged stretches back home. ""I'm guess I'm getting all my little nostalgia things out of the way.""

column1: But it would mean selling Vazquez short to say he's leaning on tradition or simply indulging Bay-heyday nostalgia on his new solo material. If there's a particular San Francisco artist he shares the most DNA with here
column2: it's Lil B
column3: the wildly unorthodox and prolific rapper whose Wifi signal strength has always been far more important than his actual coordinates. 19 and 63 are pegged as ""outtakes and collaborations""
column4: and they share the same freewheeling (based?) sensibilities as many pages in Lil B's catalogue
column5: clocking in at two hours and showcasing a scattershot couple dozen producers and guest rappers. As much as Kool A.D. pays tribute to his hometown with Mac Dre references and song titles like ""Bay Shit""
column6: he deliberately strays from heritage formulas. He randomly shouts names like ""Bieber"" and ""Madonna"" throughout the tapes
column7: and the single ""Eroika"" knowingly evokes raps in the mold of Lil B's ""Ellen Degeneres"". The wacky fusion of traditional Bay-Area themes and contemporary Web 2.0isms makes for some of the most delightfully unwieldy and entertaining mixtapes to arrive this year.

column1: To call these tracks ""outtakes"" implies there was more than one take
column2: but many of them sound like they were rapped off-the-cuff in a single go
column3: which is generally for the best. Kool A.D. sometimes cuts the tracks off arbitrarily
column4: loops the tape backwards
column5: samples spoken word
column6: or adjusts his vocal track to cartoonish speeds. He repeats lines we've heard before
column7: as though he's folding a set of crude origami animals out of the same piece of paper. On 19
column8: the thorny and psychedelic foil to the gentler 63
column9: he defiantly chooses to name one of his catchiest-ever songs ""Beautiful Naked Psychedelic Gherkin Exploding Tomato Sauce All Over Ur Face
column10: Flame Grilled Painting"". You might say he just doesn't give a fuck if there weren't some kind of base-level motivation required to sit down and record 38 rap songs. But for a couple of tapes so big and discombobulated
column11: there are hardly any spots that feel too slack or sluggish. You can either pick out a standard album length's worth of songs to replay or listen to the whole shebang front to back
column12: waiting for esoteric stoned gems and bits of spoken-word trivia to dislodge themselves and worm their way into your brain.

column1: 19 and 63 are organically avant-garde
column2: and they assert Kool A.D.'s militant refusal to take himself seriously. Occasionally he'll break from his loopy gags and grow stone-faced
column3: only to make a show of yanking himself back up into the clouds. ""Shit
column4: my dreams were probably made up in the Philippines/ By a little kid who would kill to live as ill as me
column5: he raps with an unusually sharp-tongued political urgency on ""Moneyball"" before conceding
column6: ""Or some shit/ Man I'm dumb
column7: I don't read enough."" The raps are quickly cut short
column8: and he heaves
column9: ""I'm an idiottttttttttttt."" So many of these songs prove that he's both highly capable of and entirely unwilling to tuck his shirt in and rap a lyrically upright verse-- some of the sharpest stuff comes out of his mouth when he's slack-jawed and intentionally limp-tongued
column10: as though he wants to distract us from how skilled he is by flubbing his words. He only succeeds in sounding savvier as a result
column11:
and it's often a deeply enjoyable contrast. Kool A.D. keeps proving that extremely talented underachievers are always the most fun to be around.

This review began with me typing the words ""Paul Banks"" into the Datpiff search bar. If I got nothing else out of Everybody on My Dick Like They Supposed to Be
column2: a rap mixtape from the lead singer of Interpol
column3: I will always have that moment. Scrolling to the comments out of sheer curiosity
column4: I came across one user’s eloquent plea: ""stop gentrifying datpiff
column5: white ppl."" I sat with that a minute. Then I downloaded Paul Banks' mixtape anyway.

column1: As I listened
column2: the weariness of this tiny protest stuck with me; from its rib-jab of a title on down
column3: Everybody on My Dick Like They Supposed to Be feels intended to spark a quick instance of internet incredulity: a ripple of WTFs in your timeline
column4: a few dumb jokes in comments sections (a favorite being ""Obstacle 1: Deez Nutz""). Whenever rock artists start fucking around with rap music
column5: eyebrows raise
column6: with good reason
column7: and the prospect of Paul Banks rapping
column8: with his dour
column9: stentorian moan and deathlessly quotable lyrics
column10: struck me as especially comical. Despite myself
column11: I was nagged by faint curiosities: Would he dare to actually rap? If so
column12: would his lyrics be as clumsy and clueless as this tape’s title? Would he drop mad science? And would any of this be remotely salvageable?

column1: The answers to my low-stakes queries were all variations on ""no."" No
column2: Banks doesn't sing or rap
column3: and no
column4: none of this is remotely salvageable. Everybody on My Dick mainly consists of Banks’ own beats and instrumentals
column5: which are indistinguishable from most of the ones you hear on YouTube made by well-meaning college sophomores. They're littered with the canned synth pads and stock drum sounds of someone who hasn't spent much time or money on equipment
column6: and the vocal samples strewn throughout lack imagination
column7: to put it gently. ""Iron Mike"" samples the same old Tyson snippet (""I'm Alexander! He's no Alexander!"") that's been used in more than one million rap songs to date (rough estimate). Clips from Miller's Crossing and Robocop float past
column8: signifying zero. They aren't appealingly rudimentary
column9: like Zaytoven or Young Chop; they're just rudimentary. Nowhere on this tape do you sense that Paul Banks actually has a feel for rap instrumentals
column10: let alone a sense of how to make a good one.

column1: And still
column2: he managed to corral co-signs from two legit collaborators. Talib Kweli wanders in on ""What's in the Box"" (the title is
column3: I'm guessing
column4: a Se7en reference) and drops a hot line where no one is guaranteed to find it: ""Fuck the opinion of these celebrities
column5: including me/ They ain't doing me like Jane Fonda in the 70s."" El-P also shows up on ""Quite Enough"" with a vivid
column6: allusive
column7: poorly recorded verse. To Banks’ credit
column8: ""Trace""
column9: with High Prizm
column10: has a catchy
column11: stabbing piano line
column12: and there’s one pretty little synth sketch (""Show You My Footage"") that doesn't sound like a rap song at all and which could almost be something. But there is no effort
column13: vision
column14:
or craft in this music. The title and artwork were more than enough; the mp3s don’t even need to exist.

column3: Paul Salva's Complex Housing emerged as the work of a producer with seemingly every stylistic option at his disposal. From house to grime to bass
column4: he'd find a way to make anything knock on his own terms
column5: no matter what kind of dancefloor you pointed him toward. What those terms were
column6: though
column7: seemed a bit up in the air-- with the unpredictability of his versatile approach came a sense that he was still synthesizing a great wide open host of influences. Things cohered a bit for Salva last year
column8: though: after teaming with bass music cohort RL Grime to do a trapped-up remix of Kanye's ""Mercy"" and coming away with internet-going-nuts buzz
column9: he was vaulted to the top of the next-hype pile and tapped for tastemaking DJ sets.

column1: If the timing of Odd Furniture feels a little perilous-- right at the crest of a growing anti-trap rave backlash-- the music itself should still endure whatever gets thrown at it before things settle back down. That's because the DNA of 808 hip-hop was in Salva's music for years
column2: following him from Chicago to the Bay Area to L.A.
column3: it's just given a bit more volume and upfront homage here. While the five tracks on this EP highlight a more trimmed-down take on his long-gestating style
column4: it does so with enough nods to a wider range of influences that there's some subtle but welcome variety. And it's hard not to imagine some of these tracks absolutely bulldozing over a crowd at the peak of a DJ set
column5: small club
column6: and huge festival alike.

column1: Take opener ""Get a Life""
column2: for instance-- a hyena-laughing bass anthem that hammers home a hook sourced from YG's ""I'm Good"" (""you at the club every weekend/ bitch
column3: get a life"") and turns it into something of a self-effacing motto that highlights his DJ grind. Muscle past all the contemporary Southern bounce trappings and there's a keen integration of ghetto house
column4: Miami bass
column5: and trans-Atlantic techno that blurs the line between of-the-moment trends and their decades-old heritage. ""Drop That B"" feints at some of the more obvious trap rave tropes-- a down-pitched ""drop that bitch"" refrain and a hard clap rhythm that splits the difference between gunshot and snare drum-- it springs off its simple template to get successively twitchier and more sinuous with each ensuing buildup and breakdown until it sounds like a throwdown in the middle of a hydraulics factory. ""Hard Drive"" toys with the offspring of juke and g-funk (replete with ""Little Ghetto Boy"" spark-up SFX)
column6: ""Rest in 3-Piece"" refits icy tech house instrumentation into a fusion of dancehall and circa '92 jungle that straddles generations
column7: and ""BBQ"" is a hopped-up take on baile funk that filters the favela sound through the streets of Chicago.

column1: Of course
column2: this music wouldn't hit as hard if Salva didn't put together some bracingly complex drum tracks. What separates him from the bandwagoners is his delirious sense of rhythm
column3: streamlined from years of cross-pollinated listening and setlist creation into an almost improvisational rapport between snares
column4: kicks
column5: and bass. There's hardly an eight-bar stretch on this EP that doesn't elaborate on the foundational rhythm of a track
column6: jostling the one and pouring in rolls and fills that rewind waists and scuff the soles of All-Stars and Jordans. The bass thumps
column7: but the beats tumble and scatter
column8:
betraying a sneaky virtuosity and restlessness that toys with momentum like few of his peers.

Out on a stroll in the council block housing near his home in Southampton
column2: Luke Donovan happened on a box of beat-up records. Intrigued
column3: he brought his findings home
column4: slapped one down on the turntable
column5: and started strumming. The result of this past-and-present fusion is Spectral Park
column6: the self-titled debut from Donovan's phonographically enhanced one-man band. But if the Spectral Park project got its start on a leisurely afternoon constitutional
column7: the album itself winds up feeling a lot more like one of psychonaut hero Aldous Huxley's wild rides. The push-and-pull between Donovan's high-spirited
column8: straight-outta-1966 psych-pop and the snatches of exotica he applies liberally to Spectral Park's surfaces leaves the album constantly teetering on the edge of chaos. How fitting
column9: then
column10: that Donovan himself
column11: driven almost mad by a romance gone sour
column12: spends Spectral Park sounding every bit as turned-around and twisted as the funhouse mirrors that make up his music.

column1: Well before the needle hits the wax
column2: Donovan throws just about everything you can think of at his songs. His compositions would be plenty wriggly without the salvaged sounds-- waves of tropicalia
column3: drum machine dribble
column4: organs aplenty-- slathered over top. All this
column5: Donovan presents at a pace several clicks above manic; could be Donovan's trying to throw sample snitchers off his trail by playing through his discard pile at an advance speed
column6: but whatever the reason
column7: Spectral Park doesn't leave much time to pause and reflect. Donovan's songs run the gamut from proto-punk to synth-pop
column8: but between its frenetic gait
column9: its thick carpet of harmonies
column10: and its ebullient
column11: every-which-way hooks
column12: Spectral Park winds up feeling closest in spirit to that idyllic moment in the mid-60s when psychedelics had permeated the culture but the hippies could still handle their speed. On the surface
column13: Spectral Park is all smiles: every hook's a gusher
column14: every little noise that floats by another chance at a blown mind. But there's an unease running under Spectral Park's madcap multivalence
column15: a bitter pill only made swallowable by Donovan's candied choruses.

column1: Donovan's the romantic type
column2: but here
column3: he sounds like he's at the end of his rope. Spectral Park begins with a series of pleas-- ""Are you tired? Tired of me? Like I'm tired of you? Like I'm tired of this?""-- and goes from there
column4: with Donovan switching off between a kind of doomed idealism and a resignation that whatever this is
column5: it just isn't working. ""We've done this all wrong
column6: we talked for too long
column7: betrothed ourselves to eager bad advice
column8: Donovan admits on Spectral Park highlight ""Nausea""
column9: holding back the bile as best he can. His desperate words and this frantic music make for a kind of technicolored romantic frenzy not unlike of Montreal's Fantasia of self-consciousness circa Hissing Fauna. Donovan's lovelorn streak provides a much-needed dose of reality amidst Spectral Park's gumdrop wonderland
column10: an orientation point in the center of the psychedelic swirl.

column1: When you can make it out
column2: that is. Spectral Park's a wild ride
column3: but all the stuff zipping past your head makes for a lot of motion blur. You might not even notice Donovan's sadsack streak your first few times through Spectral Park
column4: as you'll be too distracted by all the pretty colors
column5: the endlessly transmogrifying hooks
column6: the way every song seems to stumble headlong into the next. Between the spring-loaded choruses
column7: the far-flung samples
column8: and Donovan's chest-clutching lyrics
column9: Spectral Park's got a lot going for it; at times
column10: maybe a little too much. Donovan occasionally seems to be competing with himself for space in the mix
column11: occasionally drowning out his own voice in a sea of crackling samples and peripheral swirl. Halfway through the organ-soaked ""Cut""
column12: he silences half of his pocket symphony
column13: letting the hook-- not coincidentally
column14: the album's best-- shine through. It's one of just a few moments on Spectral Park where he doesn't seem compelled to dredge up every musical notion he's ever had all at once. But for Donovan
column15: mired in romantic disorder throughout the topsy-turvy Spectral Park
column16: clarity seems a far-off goal. He'll get there eventually; first
column17:
he's gotta work through all this chaos.

The young Dutch electronic producer Pascal Terstappen has numerous assets
column2: any one of which would be enough to build a strong aesthetic. He has a keen ear for melody
column3: a terse
column4: supple way with rhythm programming
column5: and a sensitive dowsing rod for strange gems and ores hidden under timbral crust. His humid webs of synthetic tones and bass
column6: drums
column7: and treated voices are full of graceful curves and slants. Each intonation of a motif is unique as a piece of hand-blown glass. Best of all is his knack for startling
column8: bafflingly perfect changes in tack
column9: which is in fine form on Dreaming in Key
column10: his new record as Applescal. His music's slippery momentum and Frankensteinian melodies seem designed to delight rather than unsettle. Among fellow deconstructive electronic musicians
column11: he makes for a uniquely genial as well as interesting companion.

column1: Loops are naturally
column2: stubbornly additive
column3: but Applescal's are so pliant that the music feels conscious
column4: especially at points of transition-- prone to pausing and gathering itself before swirling into a new form. At the top of a long
column5: warming rise
column6: you're as likely to find a frosty plateau or a side-winding shift as a sheer drop. He's not interested in forward motion; instead
column7: he develops overlapping concentric circles of melody and rhythm
column8: like rain dappling water. With shades of Boards of Canada and Four Tet in its spacey melody and Morse code percussion
column9: ""Onetasker"" teases at catharsis before finally unleashing one huge
column10: woozily droning chord. The percolating beginning of ""Vintage Clown / Shadow Hunters"" abruptly slumps into a post-R&B vocal fantasy
column11: which is gradually split open by geysers of molten synths. The stellar ""On the Way"" starts at an oozy lope but ends in a glorious pile of marbled
column12: backmasked melody
column13: making the old technique feel fresh.

column1: Applescal is profligate but consistent with genre: He likes to combine springy tech house arpeggios
column2: intrepid harmonic explorations
column3: and tilted minimalist percussion with hefty ambient stuffing and a sparkly veneer of 90s IDM. It's mind/body music in the lineage of James Holden's Border Community label output
column4: seeping fluidly between kinetic ecstasy and moody solitude. Applescal's versatility and vision caused his prior records to meander sometimes
column5: bogged down by surplus ability and eagerness. That's what makes this more sharply focused third LP a great entry point-- though it wouldn't be Applescal without a certain amount of meandering. He vamps well
column6: working filters and oscillators the way a jazz keyboardist works a modal scale. But his music is most compelling at its most structured
column7: when he carefully draws different elements into uncanny wholes. The best example is still 2010's ""Dialeague""
column8: where the warmest
column9: most thickly rolling drones and the coldest
column10: thinnest swirl of notes breathe in unison
column11: though it's now rivaled by ""On the Way"".

column1: As an opener
column2: ""Boys"" is intriguing but limited in scope
column3: with exhalations and hisses atomized over exfoliating arpeggios and locomotive drums. The live version of ""El Diablo"" is a little too like Ratatat for comfort
column4: and closer ""Keep on Dreaming"" feels like an afterthought. But everything else on Dreaming in Key is rich
column5: vivid
column6: and full of surprises. The dreamy ""Lonely People"" draws songful metallic pulses into an almost fugue-like structure
column7: while the visceral ""Spring and Life"" has a bassy carved-out menace recalling Booka Shade's ""Darko"". Standout ""Wise Noise on Time"" channels Pantha du Prince with its tinkling
column8: starry variations
column9: but not before a ghostly melodic line suddenly leaps up to a squeal and hangs there
column10: forming a yawning chasm around a steely bass. Among heavy competition
column11: it's one of my favorite ""Applescal moments"" so far
column12:
the kind where a solid form seems to be pulled out of thin air.

0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/18766/homepage_large.32686a6c.jpg|Night Slugs: Allstars Volume 2|0.0|Various Artists|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Night Slugs']|2013-02-13 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 17:01:41.466594|"

If you want a sense of where things are headed in bass music through the near future
column2: it's always a good idea to keep tabs on the Night Slugs label-- not because it adheres to or forecasts any specific scenes and movements
column3: but because it doesn't. Its identity in a post-Soundcloud world hinges on extending the UK bass diaspora far outside the confines of Bok Bok and L-Vis 1990's London-- all the way to Los Angeles (Kingdom)
column4: Toronto (Egyptrixx)
column5: even Savannah
column6: Georgia (Helix)
column7: and Lawrence
column8: Kansas (MORRI$). And the Night Slugs sound
column9: such as it is
column10: isn't merely compatible with but hotly anticipates so many potential directions for underground and aboveground club music
column11: all while revealing a deep and adventurous postmodern enthusiasm for its decades of heritage. Run though their three-year catalogue and you'll hear adventurous integrations of boogie funk and electro
column12: deep house
column13: Second Summer of Love rave
column14: first-gen two-step
column15: pirate-radio grime
column16: and white-label dubstep. The label's sonic commonalities mostly extend to a garage-inflected sensibility
column17: a thing for feverishly intricate yet danceable drum tracks
column18: and an intangible mood of refined hyperactivity-- enough to make for a trustworthy imprint
column19: while still keeping its style fairly unconstricted.

column1: Like the first volume of the Night Slugs Allstars series
column2: Night Slugs Allstars Volume 2 ties together highlights from the roster's most visible and pivotal members. Its label-sampler format draws off a lot of previously released material
column3: though there are just as many potentially overlooked deep cuts as there are top-tier favorites. It's practically a given that this is a collection for people who've already checked out Volume 1
column4: whether it was their introduction to the label or a culmination of everything they'd already grown to appreciate about it. But it also reveals subtler pleasures at work under the label's purview. There's nothing on here with the instant gravitational pull of Volume 1's appearance by Girl Unit's go-berserk ""Wut""
column5: the breakthrough single that cranked up the label's early buzz 2 1/2 years ago. But Volume 2 does a lot to show just how much ground one label can really cover.

column1: The handful of new and/or unheard tracks are enough to bolster the ranks and give the diehards something to look forward to
column2: but they're not the kinds of afterthoughts that come across as fans-only barrel-scrapings. L-Vis 1990 delivers ""Not Mad""
column3: a twitchy stomp of a cut that pits an off-kilter shuffle-beat bassline against nervous chuckles
column4: xylophone rolls
column5: and 85 pop-funk synthesizers. Girl Unit's ""Double Take Part II"" reconfigures the last minute or so of the Club Rez original so that the shivery slow-jam R&B coda stands alone as its own song-- becoming his most accessibly moving track to date. The East Coast contingent turns in a couple gems
column6: too. The all-tension/no-release drift of Kingdom's ""Bank Head"" is the most provocative track on the compilation
column7: constructing a whole track off the kind of anticipatory clap-drummed
column8: sweeping chord build that usually prefigures some kind of big sonic epiphany that never actually arrives. (It should work wonders as a DJ set opener.) Egyptrixx's ""Adult"" is a bit more intense-- there's something to it that feels like the austere future-noir drum and bass of late 90s Photek wrapped around a post-dubstep chassis-- but its ebb and flow pumps laser-cut chords and all-caps bass over an efficiently propulsive rhythm track that lets a lot of air in between the beats.

column1: The rest of the collection is filled out by singles
column2: b-sides
column3: remixes
column4: and deep EP tracks that point towards a more crossover-friendly direction for the label-- one that's trimmed away some of the over-the-top bombast while still prioritizing a sense of rhythmic intricacy. It's a smartly selected cross section that covers a lot of bases: Kingdom's tense horror-flick homage ""Stalker Ha""
column5: the glowing
column6: prismatic techno of Jam City's ""How We Relate to the Body""
column7: the luxuriant longing of L-Vis 1990's Javeon McCarthy deep house feature ""Lost in Love (Night Slugs Street Mix)""
column8: and Helix's frenetic
column9: understatedly titled kick/snare apocalypse ""Drum Track"". Novel without being gimmicky
column10: body-moving without being overbearing
column11: these are all selections that point towards a rewarding future for one of the most exciting labels in bass music. <span style=""color: #222222;"">Whether or not they're pointing the way for some scene or another
column12:
the artists of Night Slugs definitely know where they want to go themselves.
