Throughout the 1990s
column2: Indiana songwriter Lisa Germano released a string of brilliant
column3: incisive
column4: criminally underheard records whose best lines landed like jokes told in airless rooms. ""You wish you were pretty
column5: but you're not/ Ha-ha-ha
column6: she sang at the beginning of an excellent record with the cruelly ironic title Happiness. Like her plaintive-voiced contemporary Liz Phair
column7: Germano's music is at once a critique and a celebration of femininity. (Happiness first came out a month after Exile in Guyville
column8: and she had a minor alt-rock hit with an uncharacteristically sunny song called ""The Dresses Song"".) But Germano also tread into much darker corners of the psyche than Phair and most of her contemporaries
column9: tackling themes of depression
column10: abuse
column11: body image and occasionally
column12: just enough to keep things from getting unrealistically bleak
column13: being happily in love. No matter the topic or mood
column14: Germano's lyrics feel like secret
column15: intercepted thoughts
column16: frighteningly articulate accounts of the things people rarely admit to thinking about themselves. She often sounds like the devil on her own shoulder
column17: singing to herself as she stitches the angel's mouth shut.

column1: No Elephants is her ninth record
column2: and the fourth she's made since declaring
column4: that she was quitting the music business forever. The music she's made since she (thankfully) reneged on that promise has been a bit more subdued sonically
column5: centered around her piano and violin rather than the evocative
column6: adventurous guitar tones that characterized her 90s work
column7: but her songwriting has been as cutting and uncompromising as ever. 2003's Lullaby for Liquid Pig and 2006's In the Maybe World were cosmically dark enough to find a fan in Michael Gira
column8: who released them on his own Young God label.

column1: On a cursory listen
column2: the somewhat restricted sonic palette she pulls from on No Elephants might scan as ""pretty"": composed mostly of delicately plinking piano and Germano's snowy puff of a falsetto
column3: which shape these fragile melodies with a featherlight touch. But lean in a little closer and it's classic Germano-- her lyrics perhaps even more jarring
column4: rough-hewn
column5: and anguished than ever. The opener ""Ruminants"" begins sounding like something you'd hear coming out of an ice cream truck circling a Lynchian cul de sac
column6: and only grows eerier as Germano conjures surreal imagery: vomit
column7: viscera
column8: and bulldozers. ""Throw up
column9: start over
column10: she sings. ""I need four stomachs to deal."" This one's probably right up Gira's alley too.

column1: No Elephants is a meditation on two themes that seem very different but become entwined as the record goes on. The first is animal cruelty (""There is a natural order to this world that the human race has completely messed up. Especially in how we treat animals
column2: she says in explanation of some of the record's lyrics. ""It's almost forgotten that there is an exchange between us."")
column3: and the other is the difficulty of ""real
column4: direct communication in a technology-crazed world. Germano tries to unite these two ideas through samples and found sounds
column5: which she's used inventively throughout her career. (Perhaps the most piercing song she's ever recorded
column6: ""A Psychopath""
column7: features the frantic audio of a woman calling 911 after an intruder has entered her home.)

column1: The sparse piano ballads on No Elephants are scattered with artful interruptions from farm animals
column2: dial tones
column3: and random electronic buzzes. Her unconventional use of samples on the otherwise mostly acoustic album calls to mind the way Fiona Apple scattered them throughout The Idler Wheel
column4: aiming for a natural vibe as though somebody left the window open while the song was being recorded. Save for the instrumental ""Dance of the Bees"" (a sound collage of cell phone interference that sounds a lot like a buzzing hive)
column5: it doesn't quite come together. The samples and some of the lyrics feel a little too controlled
column6: on-message
column7: and conceptual
column8: which is unusual since her songs often tease out the dark emotion in mundane
column9: everyday moments. As a result
column10: No Elephants often feels hermetic and occasionally impenetrably austere.

column1: That's not to say the record is without moments of striking beauty: the piano ballad ""And So On"" is one of the most simply affecting songs she's written (""And when you break a heart
column2: it's always after you/ Haunted"")
column3: moving with the wistful grace of a more forlorn
column4: modern day take on ""Somewhere Over the Rainbow"". The closing track ""Strange Bird"" is also a standout
column5: centered around a poetic yet economical lyric that captures simultaneous feelings of alienation and interconnectedness (""All alone as we are
column6: birds flying all around""). But overall
column7: No Elephants feels inert in a way that Germano's records usually aren't. She has a gift for distinguishing between melancholy's infinite shades of grey
column8: but the most of the songs here feel uncharacteristically monochromatic.

column1: Germano ""retired"" in 1998 because even during alternative rock's anything-goes mainstream moment
column2: her unflinchingly personal records had trouble connecting to mass audiences and finding a home at major labels. (She was on Capitol briefly
column3: and released some of her best albums on 4AD when they were distributed in the U.S. by Warner Brothers.) Though she has a small
column4: devoted fanbase
column5: it's tempting to imagine what her career might have looked like if she hadn't had to do battle with the majors-- especially right now
column6: in a moment when 90s artists like Apple are taking advantage of their crumbling dominance
column7: connecting more directly with fans
column8: and rerouting their careers on their own uncompromising terms. Which is why it's a shame that No Elephants is an uncharacteristic weak spot in her discography; if ever there were a time Germano could have slipped through the cracks and had a sleeper underground hit
column9: now is as likely a time as any. On the bright side
column10: though
column11: it's now easier than ever for new converts to discover her best records. Technology might sometimes feel as pesky as a buzzing bee
column12: but if it allows for even a few people to stumble upon Lisa Germano's deep back catalog
column13:
it can't be all that bad.

One of the less frequently discussed aspects of the Chicago drill scene is that female artists played an active part in it from the beginning
column2: back when barely anyone outside of an enthusiastic audience of South Side high-schoolers even knew that it existed. Fortunately
column3: when the scene became the controversial subject of media attention last year
column4: Sasha Go Hard and Katie Got Bandz received just as much of it as Lil Reese
column5: Fredo Santana
column6: and the rest of the rappers drafting off of Chief Keef's obsessibility.

column1: At the time
column2: the main difference between Sasha and Katie and their male equivalents was that instead of rapping about being a ""hitta""-- the local term for an ass-kicker-- they rapped about being in love with hittas. Otherwise
column3: they rode the same kind of icily sociopathic beats from the same producers as any other drill rappers
column4: and came across equally as tough.

column1: But while Chief Keef and his Glory Boyz crew are attempting to ride the drill craze towards a mainstream audience
column2: Sasha and Katie have both recently made some interesting left turns. Back in November
column3: Katie appeared on ""Kat!e""
column4: a single by Fool's Gold artist Carnage that combined the signature drill sound with squawking moombahton synthesizers and seemed aimed more towards edgy EDM kids than listeners of mixtape rap. Now Sasha's released her third solo full-length
column5: Round Three
column6: which finds her heading in a far less grim
column7: more pleasurable direction.

column1: That Round Three is a different animal from Sasha's past mixtapes is apparent even before you download it
column2: thanks to the Diplo production credit sitting proudly beside the opening track. ""Damn"" opens with a few seconds of pleasantly blippy synthesizer arpeggios before turning itself inside out and morphing into a straight-up EDM track with a propulsive
column3: handclap-heavy beat and the kind of enjoyably annoying synth sounds that have become Diplo's trademark. ""Pretty Fly""
column4: produced by Absolut-P
column5: follows suit with an electro streak that's far more suggestive of rooms full of sweaty
column6: neon-clad young people than the blighted streets of the South Side.

column1: But Sasha hasn't gone full-on hip-house revivalist
column2: as interesting as that might be to imagine. Most of Round Three offers the same kind of pleasures as her past mixtapes
column3: just with a broader range of sounds. The Absolute-P beat behind ""Bringing Heat"" uses burbling synthesizers and cinematic strings to evoke the kind of ominous mood that Chicago rap has come to be known for
column4: albeit in a warmer
column5: more organic way that lacks the jittery edge of
column6: say
column7: a Young Chop production. Block on Da Trakk's ""Kill Bill"" beat is straight Chicago drill
column8: with the requisite gunshots
column9: tolling bells
column10: and hi-hat spasms
column11: but certain flourishes-- like the backwards kick drum that sounds like a heartbeat-- add a subtle flavor to the usual bombastic overload.

column1: Sasha's flow is still miles away from that kind of subtlety
column2: though. Like the rest of her class of young Chicago MCs
column3: her writing is light on metaphor and heavy on unadorned real talk. What she does have is a surfeit of charisma; enough to sell a line like ""I think that I am Kill Bill"" that doesn't make any kind of apparent sense on paper
column4: and enough to outshine Kreayshawn
column5: whose verse on ""Kill Bill"" seems like she actually put some effort into it.

column1: She's also got a smartly adventurous side that's developing in an interesting way. Writing a female-centric anti-hater anthem like ""To the Girls"" isn't a wildly outside-the-box idea
column2: but inviting the avant-garde rapper Le1f-- who happens to be a gay man-- to contribute a shade-throwing verse is conceptually crafty
column3: not to mention immensely satisfying to hear. Sasha's drill-scene connections have brought her a long way
column4:
but the company she's keeping now is a lot more interesting.

As Lady Lazarus
column3: California dreamer Melissa Ann Sweat crafts intimate miniatures
column4: mostly for solo voice and electric piano
column5: and then slowly drowns them in oceans of reverb. As short patterns of chords or intervals revolve hypnotically
column6: overlapping layers of echo and decay well up around them until only the tips of the keyed notes glint out. The music lands somewhere between Grouper and Erik Satie
column7: though Sweat's singing has a decidedly folksy cast. This balance of cool circumspection and human warmth is just one of the deep contrasts churning her music's simple surface. It's impossible to decide whether the music is constantly changing or totally still
column8: a strangely placid kind of tension that never fails to draw me in.

column1: I fell hard for Lady Lazarus' first full-length album
column2: Mantic
column3: which I still love. But in hindsight
column4: I let myself overlook the meandering stretches
column5: which are scarcer on new LP All My Love in Half Light
column6: recorded in San Francisco with Papercuts' Jason Quever. It will sound instantly familiar to fans of Mantic-- at least once you get past the brassy ""Lapsarian""-- but its proportions are sturdier and its vocal melodies more sharply honed. Instead of slipping off into the distance
column7: Sweat strongly projects from the center of the frame
column8: though her romantic lyrics are still strewn about in coded fragments. There are new production touches that enhance the sound without diluting its essential simplicity: Faint harmonies ring the vocal of ""Eventide"" and a cello discreetly flickers through ""Constant Apples"". The means are still strictly limited
column9: but more versatile than they sound.

column1: There are essentially four different types of Lady Lazarus songs here
column2: all of which have analogues on Mantic. Sweat helpfully fills the four opening slots with an example of each
column3: setting the parameters for the rest of the record. There's the type that ditches piano in favor of accordion
column4: tucked away near the end of Mantic as ""Pearl"" but audaciously beginning All My Love as ""Lapsarian""
column5: where Sweat belts like a Sacred Harp singer over the noisy instrument. There's the type built around a tone-packed pulse
column6: such as the gorgeously tolling ""Goudanov""
column7: and the type built around a silence-packed theme
column8: such as ""Wonder
column9: Inc"". And of course
column10: there's the type built on pearly scalar columns: ""Eventide"" is this record's answer to Mantic standout ""The Eye in the Eye of the Storm""
column11: speeding up when she sings and dragging when she stops
column12: as if the piano were feeding directly off her voice.

column1: While the beauty doesn't flag in the second half
column2: the forms do start to repeat
column3: with ""Edge"" recapturing the wistful blur of ""Wonder
column4: Inc""; ""Constant Apples"" the regressing mirrors of ""Goudanov"". Even so
column5: Sweat manages to glimpse some striking new vistas from within her familiar straits. With its bobbing major chords and images of ships on the Atlantic
column6: ""Argosy"" is as sun-bathed and spacious as her usual songs are misty and occluded. A blizzard of trills descends on the low
column7: craggy ""Gleam""
column8: closing the album with an unusually bracing chill. Lady Lazarus' music is so drowsy and rapt
column9: so vast and alone
column10:
that I always wondered if clearer recording and bolder singing might ruin it. It's a relief to discover on All My Love in Half Light that that's definitely not the case.

column7: which was markedly less accessible. However
column8: last year's hyperkinetic Shy Pursuit was a more balanced affair; you didn't have to follow the literal meaning of the blithely careening ""Keep Them Alive"" or crunching new-wave anthem ""Take It"" to enjoy the chase. With its color wheel-spinning palette
column9: sticky
column10: curlicued melodies
column11: and poignant lyrical reflections
column12: Cool Cocoon is an occasionally breathtaking highwire walk between craft and genuine feeling that builds confidently on its predecessor.

column1: For a start
column2: they've left the tunes more room to breathe: See the strummy
column3: piano-based ""What I Love""
column4: where intricate strings and percussion leave enough room for a sense of floating-on-air giddiness that usually goes hand-in-hand with new romance. The clappy ""She Don't Want Me"" conjures a more lucid Animal Collective

column1: Almost 17 years after they originally formed
column2: the Spinto Band seem to be examining their relationship with music

column4: on Cool Cocoon. ""Amy + Jen"" is a thoughtful if pointed response to a newfound duo prepping their first cassette; the Badfinger-saluting opener ""Shake it Off""
column5: where the narrator is ""unhappy with dreaming
column6: could as easily be about giving up on a band as a lover. Thankfully
column7: Cool Cocoon stops short of getting lost in its own head: Another standout
column8: the practically-power ballad ""Memo""
column9: directly criticizes how we ""over-intellectualize
column10: with the chorus' subtle shift from ""you don't feel any better"" to ""you don't feel"" hammering the point home.

column1: The Spinto Band can sound like Paul McCartney disciple Emitt Rhodes one second
column2: pop-polymath newcomers Foxygen the next. Their perpetual underdog
column3: self-releasing ways bring to mind lo-fi godhead R. Stevie Moore

column6: and they're edging ever closer to deserving a place within it-- even if they don't necessarily believe it themselves. On the clanging
column7: penultimate track ""Na Na Na""

column10: ""Believe me

column13:
but Cool Cocoon reveals a band convincingly growing into what it had longed to be all along.

column3: ""Inhaler"" does not sound like the triumphant return of one of Britain's most successful modern bands. In fact
column4: it sounds claustrophobic-- hookless
column5: even. During what feels like the chorus
column6: Yannis Philippakis can't quite get hold of a melody that sounds like it might never resolve. All the while
column7: he's being cramped by increasing amounts of reverb. But then
column8: at about the 1:45 mark
column9: he yells
column10: ""and I can't get enough... SPACE!"" and then Foals break the song wide open with a riff that's startlingly low-slung and grunge-y for technically proficient guys who otherwise proudly wield their guitars pecs-high. You can easily hear a throng of festival-goers absolutely losing its shit during this extremely self-reflexive moment
column11: and there's more like it on Holy Fire
column12: which is a good thing. On 2010's Total Life Forever

column14: inscrutable songs like ""Mathletics"" made a shift to expansive and emotive rock in a way that was both surprising and completely logical. With Holy Fire

column10: making the hooks feel like bigger payoffs by gracefully ascending towards them. A similar refinement happens on the maddeningly catchy ""My Number""
column11: which reshapes the cyclical chants of ""Total Life Forever"" into a song that's 85% hook; deceptively chipper funk-rock surrounding a bitter declaration of romantic independence where the latter sought eternal companionship. At least in contemporary terms
column12: it's easy to hear them as the muscular
column13: brooding complement to Wild Beasts' limber

column16: circa Wish.

column2: you'd be forgiven for thinking Holy Fire's title and imperious cover art indicated that they were continuing down that spacious
column3: grandiose path while using U2 as their proverbial North Star. The weakest patches of Holy Fire come when Foals try to repeat ""Spanish Sahara"". Though Flood and Alan Moulder's production is worth every penny and does everything in its power to make Holy Fire spacious and sparkling
column4: ""atmospheric"" Foals tends to obscure melody every bit as much as Antidotes' acrobatics. Likewise
column5: while Philipakkis' voice is becoming more versatile and expressive
column6: his lyrics depersonalize what appear to be very personal songs with stock metaphors: ""I'm the last cowboy in this town
column7: ""Every time I see you
column8: I wanna sail away

column10: ""I know I cannot be true/ I'm an animal just like you.""

column1: Though a dead heat in terms of overall quality

column3: Holy Fire is better proportioned than the top-heavy Total Life Forever. Prior to the nearly beatless and occasionally stirring final 10 minutes
column4: ""Milk and Black Spiders"" slowly builds from a bed of pinprick harmonics to a stirring chorus in Holy Fire's most effective use of the slow build

column1: Holy Fire is undoubtedly a very good
column2: ambitious record
column3: one that operates on an artistic economy of scale

The rest has the easy task of proving the Oxford band to be more emotionally substantial and idiosyncratic than any of their mainstream peers. Like <i>Total Life Forever
column5: Holy Fire threatens greatness
column6:
and whatever disappointment comes from missing the mark is mitigated by its scope: A bomb needs to be operational more than it needs to be accurate.

The Brainfeeder-affiliated Brooklyn rap duo the Underachievers are part of New York City's loose knit Beast Coast collective
column2: which counts Joey Bada$$ and his Pro Era crew along with Flatbush Zombies among its membership
column3: and the A$AP Mob as friends. But the Underachievers are a singular presence within the new New York scene. They're not retro-leaning traditionalists like Bada$$
column4: whose 1999 mixtape studiously replicated the vibe of classic 90s New York rap. They're not as aggressively weird as the Flatbush Zombies
column5: and their seriousness of purpose sets them apart from the A$AP Mob's faded party rap. And while many of their contemporaries subscribe to a school of rap that extols the joys of drug use
column6: gleefully cataloguing chemicals consumed
column7: the Underachievers' Issa Dash and Ak treat mind-altering substances like sacraments
column8: like battering rams at the doors of perception. Their debut mixtape
column9: Indigoism
column10: is druggy
column11: but aesthetically so; beneath the surface lies a work of art-damaged mysticism and pyrotechnic wordplay.

column1: Indigoism derives many of its psychedelic properties from its production team
column2: the Entreproducers
column3: whose broad palette supplies Issa and Ak with bountiful and bizarre sounds. ""Herb Shuttles"" and ""T.A.D.E.D"" affix spectral keys to the skittering hi-hats and 808s of modern Southern rap. ""So Devilish"" and ""New New York"" are built around menacing psych rock grooves. ""Revelations"" seamlessly marries elements of blues and reggae to trap. Indigoism covers a lot of ground
column4: and there is as much movement within songs as there is between them. ""Leopard Shepard"" chops a muted horn sample no less than three different ways
column5: and songs like ""Gold Soul Theory"" and opener ""Philanthropist"" modulate between divergent verse and chorus sections like a live band would. Even meat-and-potatoes boom bap numbers ""6th Sense"" and ""The Madhi"" sneakily shift melodic elements in and out of the mix as they progress. Indigoism's one relative constant on the production front is a tendency toward a low BPM.

column1: Slower beats are the perfect launchpad for the breakneck doubletime raps and stop-on-a-dime flow shifts that are the Underachievers' calling card. Indigoism's dizzying flurry of internal rhymes matches California rap luminaries Kendrick Lamar and Ab-Soul at their most switched on
column2: but where the Black Hippy crew likes to slow things down periodically to air out the rhyme schemes
column3: the Underachievers rarely let up. It's as if they have too much to say without the time to get it all out. The fury of their lyricism also calls back to unsung technicians of 90s rap like Freestyle Fellowship and Organized Konfusion
column4: acts possessed of an almost intimidatingly masterful command of words. This isn't to say that Underachievers' ability to rap very well is a liability
column5: but Issa and Ak's battery of lyrical speed trials occasionally feels one-note when spread over 16 songs. Indigoism clocks in at under an hour
column6: but it feels longer than it is
column7: and is probably most effectively ingested in smaller doses.

column1: After more than a year of sporadic live shows and piecemeal track releases
column2: this full reveal of Underachievers' vision shows a group that's thick with promise. Issa Dash and Ak are intriguing thinkers with formidable mic skills and a team of producers challenging them with moving
column3: breathing soundscapes. In an era rife with aesthetes playing dress up with rap and auteurs who treasure texture and feel over good old-fashioned musicality
column4:
the Underachievers are a monument to the complex lyricism and drug-friendly experimentation of Souls of Mischief and the offbeat spirituality of the mystics in the Dungeon Family. But Indigoism isn't really about showing off a good record collection; it's about digesting influences and turning out something vaguely familiar but somehow brand new.

Struggling to pin down Veronica Falls' sound
column4: an interviewer recently told frontwoman Roxanne Clifford

column13: down-to-earth emotions.

column3: Clifford sings on ""Everybody's Changing""
column4: a side B highlight with a chiming melody that sounds like a long lost Teenage Fanclub tune. Whether slyly intentional or not
column5: its title lyric beats the haters to the punch: Veronica Falls haven't changed much in the year-and-a-half since their debut. If you were expecting a bounding artistic leap forward on Waiting
column6: or standalone tracks as immediate and memorable as ""Bad Feeling"" and ""Graveyard""
column7: you might be slightly disappointed that their second record doesn't stray much from their established blueprint. But taken apart from the high expectations set by their debut
column8: Waiting is another strong collection of guitar pop gems from a band quickly proving itself to be a better
column9:
more elusive quantity than any easy genre tag might suggest.

0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/18881/homepage_large.fc05521f.jpg|The Sundown Song|935.0|Clogs|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Brassland']|2013-02-12 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 17:01:47.549610|"

Three weeks after Clogs released The Creatures in the Garden of Lady Walton in March 2010
column2: the woman for whom it was named died. Lady Susana Walton had been married to the composer Sir William Walton. She created their home
column3: the tropical garden La Mortella
column4: on the Italian island of Ischia
column5: where they lived when the once well regarded musician's star had started to wane. Creatures was a celebration of life and presence
column6: both qualities brought home by its predominant guest star
column7: My Brightest Diamond's Shara Worden. Its florid
column8: baroque approach was wound down on the partnering Veil Waltz EP
column9: and hushed to a whisper on the Last Song EP
column10: both released later that year as developments and conclusions to the project.

column1: Two-and-a-half years later
column2: we now have The Sundown Song EP
column3: a three-song collection intended as a coda to Creatures
column4: and to mark ""an ending of what Clogs once were as well as a reaffirmation of what they continue to be."" Unlike the other parts of the Creatures world
column5: Padma Newsome is the only member of Clogs to appear on Sundown; Rachael Elliott
column6: Thomas Kozumplik
column7: and the National's Bryce Dessner are absent
column8: though their label Brassland assures that it's not a permanent change despite the grave accompanying statement. The predominant lyrical theme here is mortality and life cycles-- perhaps in reference to Lady Walton
column9: or transitions within the band-- and the domestic roses on the EP's cover aren't meant to represent La Mortella
column10: but Newsome's own garden at home in Mallacoota
column11: a gorgeous
column12: isolated coastal town in Victoria
column13: Australia.

column1: The intimacy and simplicity of approach is startling: Each of these three songs is based around baritone ukulele (not the clanky kind used by their Brassland labelmates Buke and Gase) and Newsome's earnest
column2: moving voice. It would sound folky if it weren't so formal. When I interviewed Newsome about Creatures for The Quietus in 2010
column3: he used complex musical terminology-- isorhythms
column4: mirror canons
column5: double chases-- and if those processes are present on The Sundown Song EP
column6: they're not as obvious. The low uke skitter on ""A Hobson's Choice"" ebbs around Newsome's tight
column7: whipped vocal intonation
column8: as he sings a perfectly plain song of conversations with friends on the porch
column9: observing small
column10: lolloping marsupials-- but highly strung
column11: as if he had pulled all the threads tight in a piece of cloth. The topic of conversation turns to war and rifle fire and wives that weren't there on the soldiers' return
column12: and suddenly the porch gathering is full of ghosts. A light enveloping of strings coaxes the tension out of the song
column13: but as the ghosts slip away and Newsome's character confides in a friend about his ""plans for the great great plans
column14: it's as if he's mocking the point of making any.

column1: The Sundown Song EP is the first Clogs release that feels as though it could be performed spontaneously
column2: without the need for microphones or seated applause. The gently ululating ""The World Loves Me"" could be a wry comment on the way humans act as if the world and its myriad beasts should serve them
column3: or it might just be Newsome wandering about his garden
column4: looking out to Mallacoota's crystalline bay and marveling at life on the edge of the earth. The notes he sings always ascend or descend in opposition to the direction of the ukulele
column5: making for a slight uneasiness sharpened by his eerie whistle.

column1: The title track is a welcome balm to that relative standoffishness. It features the Mallacoota Community Choir
column2: and the depth of their voices balance out Newsome's warmly lilting ukulele for a stirring effect that feels like being able to see the ocean floor clearly. Although the lyrics throughout the EP are quite simple descriptions of time's progression
column3: the prevailing lyrical air of acceptance and of Newsome not wanting to change anything or dress his work up in fancy structures and conceits is unusually moving. ""The people come and the people go/ But I'd rather stay here with you
column4: he sings in the final lines of ""The Sundown Song"". It works for the Waltons' relationship
column5: and for Clogs' welcome imperviousness; 12 years of producing precisely what they want
column6:
not what they think people want.

0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/18884/homepage_large.c988096b.jpg|Confrontations|29264.0|Umberto|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Not Not Fun']|2013-02-12 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 17:01:48.183994|"

Kansas City musician Matt Hill
column2: who returns to Not Not Fun for the release of this fourth album under his Umberto alias
column3: is still searching for a suitably blood-soaked visual counterpart to his glossy electronic work. Hill's music takes the form of imaginary soundtracks to films that only exist in his mind
column4: primarily inspired by lurid 1970s horror features of wildly varying quality. Last time we heard from him was on the 2012 Rock Action release Night Has a Thousand Screams
column5: an album inspired by a slice n' dice flick from 1982 titled Pieces. Screams felt like an endgame for Hill's obsession with the macabre work of Italian composers such as Claudio Simonetti and Fabio Frizzi
column6: ultimately putting him in a position where
column7: three albums into his career
column8: he needed to take those influences and find a musical place of his own to dwell. Confrontations doesn't exactly leave his giallocore tendencies behind
column9: but it does subtly amp up the Italo disco influence that has crept into the Umberto frame
column10: giving it a brilliant sheen that resembles a shift from fleapit to arthouse.

column1: Of course
column2: his prior work as Umberto was all about recreating the feel of slumping down in one of those fleapits
column3: watching a million dismembered limbs fly across the screen through scratchily projected celluloid. Here
column4: the production values are heightened
column5: making it feel like Hill's cinematic diet has expanded. The palpitating groove of ""Night Fantasy"" bears similarities to Giorgio Moroder's ""Chase""
column6: from Midnight Express: Both tracks are riddled with a dual sense of urgency and abandon
column7: although Umberto's is ultimately more enamored with the kind of 3am cool practiced by Chromatics and most of the Italians Do it Better stable. Clearly
column8: there are still traceable lines to be drawn between this music and the work sourced by Hill
column9: but he's bringing in a wider spectrum of influence this time. The light electronics and flattened drum samples of ""Final Revelation"" even edge into the kind of soundtrack territory Harold Faltermeyer was working in during the 80s
column10: albeit with some ghostly vocal chants to anchor it in Umberto's world.

column1: Similar ties proliferate throughout
column2: making Confrontations a baby step forward rather than a thorough overhaul of Hill's sound. When ""Initial Revelation"" enters into a strident synth passage
column3: it becomes his most confident statement yet
column4: playing out like a main title theme begging to be played over scrolling credits. But Hill is wise to keep such moments to a minimum; soundtrack albums often tell their own story
column5: spread out over shifts in mood and space. Confrontations works that way
column6: too. ""Dead Silent Morning"" allows oscillating electronics to coil around one another
column7: imposing a strong sense of trepidation as the intensity is slowly heightened. It's a formula that Hill sticks with throughout the album
column8: starting tracks slow
column9: building up layers
column10: then delivering a payoff that typically involves screaming analog synths. When it works
column11: it can be gloomily affecting. In particular
column12: ""The Invasion"" shows Hill's mastery of restraint
column13: creating a faintly agonizing feeling of anticipation and alarm.

column1: Such tracks are certainly a progression on what came before
column2: but there's still a sense that Hill is a little too enthralled by the work that inspires him. It's possible that he's happy down here-- the forthcoming Umberto tour schedule includes a show at a John Carpenter tribute concert in Geneva
column3: suggesting Hill is at peace with his tendency toward replication. But Confrontations triggers a nagging feeling that he's capable of so much more
column4: particularly when he's mashing up styles on standout tracks like ""Night Fantasy"" and ""Initial Revelation"". Broadcast's Berberian Sound Studio showed that there are plenty of fresh ways of looking at the source material from which this record borrows
column5: but after four albums as Umberto it's starting to feel less likely that Hill can find a similar strain of inspiration. Often he feels like a genre director hired for his reliability rather than excelling in his field. Still
column6: there are advances here
column7: a sense that Hill's VHS collection may have expanded beyond the horror section
column8:
a step up from pan-and-scan into something approaching widescreen.

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/18775/homepage_large.a149e651.jpg|Honeys|5308.0|Pissed Jeans|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Sub Pop']|2013-02-11 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 17:01:49.016593|"

If you're into Pissed Jeans' music because you relate to it
column2: well
column3: Matt Korvette is sorry it's come to this. Call it Commiseration Rock: Over the past decade
column4: the Philly-via-Allentown band has occupied a very specific niche
column5: making violent
column6: shout-along sludge punk about situations that find men at their wimpiest and most impotent. In Pissed Jeans' songs
column7: men (typically Korvette himself) go bald
column8: can no longer shop happily at Whole Foods
column9: take solace in ice cream
column10: are beleaguered at work
column11: and baffled by women.

column1: Those are very real concerns that nonetheless foster a dangerous perspective from which to create art: It's basically responsible for the rash of deplorable ""manxiety"" sitcoms
column2: which take the defensive and view any deviance from a false ideal of ""father knows best"" society as a threat to God's natural order. Typically
column3: you'd say there's a ""delicate balance"" to be struck with this kind of stuff. On Honeys
column4: Pissed Jeans' fourth and best album
column5: they wisely make no such distinction
column6: trusting the power of honesty in Korvette's lyrics while dropping the musical defense mechanisms that kept listeners at a distance-- it's headbanging music that allows you to nod feverishly in agreement.

column1: So
column2: no more seven-minute dirges about car troubles
column3: no spoken word odes to scrapbooking. That's not to say Pissed Jeans have gone soft on us. You'll get your fill of terror by the second track
column4: as ""Chain Worker"" is three minutes of free-time
column5: squalling feedback surrounding Korvette's screams about a tortured office drone drinking until he cries blood. Otherwise
column6: it's 10 songs (and a brief interlude) that take after the delirious opener ""Bathroom Laughter"" in concision and purpose. Nearly everything could pass for ""the single""-- edge-of-sanity tantrums that make for great singalongs because the chorus is either an exasperated yell or just the song title. Without sacrificing visceral force
column7: Pissed Jeans allow themselves enough versatility to keep Honeys intense and interesting throughout
column8: fashioning a loser's history of alt.rock that honors some of the most abrasive bands to get a deal post-Nevermind; the cruel swing of Jawbox (""You're Different (In Person)"")
column9: the Melvins' mammoth plod (""Male Gaze"")
column10: Nirvana themselves going very ape (""Vain in Costume"")
column11: and of course
column12: plenty of the Jesus Lizard's warped machismo.

column1: The spirit of the music alone positions them as top-flight  AmRep revivalists
column2: though the relatively clean production makes them sound a little less faithful than labelmates METZ. But this is a necessary decision
column3: as Korvette is a frontman who is trying to communicate with the listener
column4: not just be a part of the abrasive din. Honeys is the most concentrated and consistent display of what Korvette does best. He's reliably quotable largely because his deadpan literalism allows him to be funny without aspiring to cleverness
column5: and lets the ridiculousness of his actions and those of others speak for themselves: a chemically processed
column6: preservative-laden frozen meal calls itself ""Healthy Choice
column7: a stick figure family decal on a car proudly boasts one's humility
column8: the friendly ""ding"" accompanying an incoming email reveals the death of a coworker
column9: a lazy boyfriend who thinks his girl should appreciate the effort it takes for him to say ""let's do it.""

column1: In the past
column2: it was easy enough to applaud Pissed Jeans simply for being so overtly topical in a genre that rarely has much to say-- to think
column3: ""Oh
column4: a doom metal song about getting a massage
column5: good one."" While it's clear what each song is specifically about on Honeys
column6: whether that's online dating or cat allergies
column7: they're all essentially dealing with the same thing in a larger sense; the guilt of recognizing the frivolity of your problems and the compounded guilt of recognizing how powerless you are over these stupid things.

column1: ""Cafeteria Food"" is closest to the perfect Pissed Jeans song in terms of aligning those two threads. The hollowed-out thud of the kick drum and guitar mirrors how
column2: on the wrong day
column3: a walk down the hallway at work can feel like a death march. It contains the album's best one-liners; upon finding out a shithead project manager has died
column4: Korvette feels ""like I've won the Super Bowl
column5: ""like Jesus Christ
column6: our savior
column7: and in a line inspired by guitarist Brad Fry's viewing of Maury
column8: ""like I'm not the father."" If it were just an Office Space­-style revenge fantasy
column9: I doubt it would hold up to many listens. There's something more devious at play; notice that Korvette doesn't screw his enemy's wife on his desk
column10: he doesn't take a baseball bat to his fax machine
column11: he doesn't tell him and his fantasy team to fuck off. This is a subtler
column12: dark humor-- here's a guy whose hatred has rendered him so feeble
column13: he's resorted to the futility of begging for divine intervention
column14: resigned to the fact that he'll probably have to make small talk with the same guy in the lunchroom today
column15: tomorrow
column16: and the day after that: ""Go ahead
column17: you can use the microwave/ It's an excellent kitchen tool.""

column1: Honeys hits hard and it also stings as it fully explores how lives are driven by fear and the sad little power plays we make to clutch any bit of control. The last two songs are on seemingly different planes: On ""Health Plan""
column2: Korvette refuses to take shit or (any helpful medical advice) from doctors
column3: and later disappears into his DVD collection on ""Teenage Adult"". But they're both unflinching looks at how people frame their willingness to endanger their wellbeing as principles rather than serious denial. This is even more pronounced on the ""relationship"" songs; far from an Al Bundy homage
column4: the laughs of ""Romanticize Me"" are uncomfortably triggered by the acknowledged
column5: pathetic co-dependency where one person refuses to change
column6: the other refuses to leave
column7: and you sit at dinner with the couple wondering how they ever found each other attractive. ""You're Different (In Person)"" is similar in that it doesn't deconstruct social media so much as let it speak for its own devolutionary power; from the excitement of setting up that perfect profile to the realization that the internet allows shut-ins an even higher level of deceit
column8: manipulation
column9: and stunted emotions than ""real life."" When Korvette yells
column10: ""I thought this was meant to be fun!"" he outlines the sad truth that most people aren't different in person.

column1: The cartoonish brutality of the music is fun as hell
column2: and since Korvette is most often mocking himself during <i>Honeys
column3: it doesn't come off as hectoring. This is extremely important on ""Male Gaze"". Most often
column4: songs by men decrying misogyny try to speak on behalf of all men (or all women
column5: really)
column6: and turn into condescension. It might help that ""Male Gaze"" takes the most caricatured
column7: simian path musically
column8: but Korvette simply acknowledges the unintended consequences of his actions (""It's when a smile becomes a stare/ And it starts to burn"") and apologizes. He doesn't ask for or assume forgiveness
column9: he doesn't place himself on a pedestal and he doesn't indict his entire gender so you might think more highly of him. Korvette artlessly mutters
column10: ""I know I'm no angel/ But I'm trying to kill it
column11: admitting to progress in a way that's more powerful than feigning perfection.

column1: Pissed Jeans can often be mistaken for a misanthropic band
column2: especially since Hope for Men and King of Jeans came equipped with enough self-sabotage to keep their underdog status intact. But when I call it ""Commiseration Rock""
column3: it's because Honeys focuses on dealing with other people to an extent that's extremely rare. Not ""how to deal with people""-- Honeys is thankfully not a treatise
column4: not a moral code
column5: not a series of op-ed pieces trying to convert you to Korvette's point of view
column6: and it acknowledges that the zero-sum games of ""fuck the man"" punk idealism don't work for most people who have real jobs and bills. It's just a kickass rock record that presents Korvette in a way most of us can relate to
column7: a guy trying to blow off steam after another exhausting
column8:
barely successful attempt to not be an asshole one day at a time.

column2:
'Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Domino']|2013-02-11 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 17:01:49.651876|"

Ulrich Schnauss has never been a risky producer. He has released volumes of material as a solo artist and with Engineers
column3: much of it tied to the ambient pop drift of early 1990s shoegaze. Schnauss deserves some credit for forecasting the heady
column4: frosting-thick synthesizer music of bands like M83
column5: but there's no getting away from the fact that little of his work bears revisiting. It's been six years since a review here said Schnauss' music ""begs for a riskier approach""
column6: so it's doubly difficult to announce that while A Long Way to Fall meaningfully alters Schnauss' approach for the first time
column7: he still comes up empty handed.

column1: Schnauss admitted in an interview last year that this change of direction was intentional: ""My music taste changes every eight to ten years I think
column2: and I was getting a bit bored with [that synthesized shoegaze sound]."" Fall finds Schnauss ditching the limp vocals and siccing his impressive gear collection on slowly unfurling ribbons of melody
column3: which he fits against beaming pads and gentlemanly rhythms. The thrust of his music hasn't changed. Schnauss makes inviting
column4: optimistic music; ""pretty"" is still the noble but limited goal. There is a newfound clarity and separation to the mix
column5: though
column6: clear demarcations between his celestial yellows and terracotta oranges.

column1: A Long Way to Fall wants to undo some of the persistent criticisms of Schnauss' music: that it is indefinite
column2: without substance. Instead
column3: it confirms them
column4: condemning Schnauss as an eager tinkerer with great taste but terrible instincts. Fall is an ill-at-ease collection of midtempo electronic cheese. It is weightless
column5: light music
column6: like Schnauss skimmed the foam off the top of the ocean
column7: leaving the roar
column8: agitation
column9: and murk behind. Even armed with an encyclopedia of genre names and a phone book of similar artists
column10: you would have trouble explaining what Fall is. It touches base with Boards of Canada and Air France
column11: but Fall cares little for nostalgia or youth. It doesn't fade into the background or throttle you; it sits leaden in the middle of the room.

column1: Fall's worst moments are queasy and charmless. Offenders include the title track and the comically turbulent ""The Weight of Darkening Skies"". Every ability
column2: every emotion
column3: must be wrangled and displayed; no one can be offended. This is Fall's lot: breadth without purpose
column4: clarity without detail. That Schnauss flounders this way after his first artistic shift in a decade is discouraging. He has always seemed thoughtful and passionate-- a recent podcast for XLR8R explores drum & bass
column5: and is a lot of fun. Now
column6: as in the past
column7: though
column8:
Schnauss' devotion and care outpace the quality of his output.

0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/18885/homepage_large.0c6cae29.jpg|No Beginning No End|28662.0|José James|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Blue Note']|2013-02-11 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 17:01:50.427697|"

New York-via-Minneapolis singer José James was once comfortable being the oddball talent of the contemporary jazz scene
column2: an unknown quantity in a world with plenty of known ones; “When it's all said and done
column3: jazz with a capital J is where I'm coming from
column4: ” he told Billboard in 2010. “Dexter Gordon
column5: Billie Holiday
column6: Miles Davis
column7: Charlie Parker
column8: Thelonious Monk-- that's what I really studied when I was a teenager and what really fueled my passion.” While that loyalty manifested itself in releases like 2008’s The Dreamer and 2010’s Blackmagic-- two albums that showcased James’ penchant for genre-stretching while sprinkling in more straightforward covers-- his sound has always been hard to peg.

column1: For his new record No Beginning No End
column2: he’s staying true to that wanderlust
column3: enlisting musicians like bassist Pino Palladino (who famously helped construct neosoul gems like D’Angelo’s Voodoo as well as Erykah Badu’s Mama’s Gun) and contemporary jazz star Robert Glasper as well as Franco-Moroccan singer Hindi Zahra. While he’s always been one to try stuff out-- he successfully collaborated with Flying Lotus on Blackmagic--on No Beginning No End he finds a way to make an eclectic approach feel unified and whole.

column1: James sings with a steely grace that does in fact recall D’Angelo
column2: a quality only reinforced by Palladino’s fingerprint on songs like the grooving opener “It’s All Over Your Body” and the back half’s soul clap “Make It Right”. But James’ more detached voice isn’t the weapon that D’Angelo’s proves to be
column3: if you’re looking at No Beginning No End as a spiritual cousin of Voodoo or Mama’s Gun. While James’ record prizes overarching vibe over song-to-song substance
column4: it’s more subdued and
column5: in a sense
column6: more unpredictable: the opener cedes to the hand drum cool-out “Sword + Gun”
column7: which builds to the straightforward pop reach on the record
column8: the taut “Trouble”
column9: which in turn slides into Robert Glasper and James’ capital J jazz tribute “Vanguard”
column10: a tribute to the Greenwich Village institution where the song was devised.

column1: Though that sounds like a lot of hopping around-- the poppy
column2: percussive midalbum standout “Come to My Door” is another good example-- No Beginning No End works smoothly as a suite
column3: which is a testament to James shape-shifting nature as well as the session musicians' willingness to stay in a support role. While one could see the temptation to push further into a pop crossover sweet-spot
column4: No Beginning No End contains few heavy brush strokes. Though James’ meandering gets the best of him on the slow shuffle “Bird of Space” and the never-quite-gets-there “Untitled” echo “Do You Feel”
column5: even when he misses his low-key restraint retains its charm.

column1: Though No Beginning No End succeeds in its laid-back approach
column2: make no mistake that James is seeking to bust out of the NPR Jazz world and into the ears of new audiences. In March
column3: he'll play Music Hall of Williamsburg
column4: Bowery Presents' Brooklyn hype thermometer (also playing that month: Sky Ferreira
column5: How to Dress Well
column6: Savages
column7: Django Django)
column8: just a 20-minute train ride from the Village Vanguard but a world away. With previous releases
column9: he's earned his heroic acclaim in the tough
column10: tried-and-trusted lanes of contemporary jazz. With No Beginning No End
column11:
he's built his own road out.

column1: 0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/18858/homepage_large.0501dc9c.jpg|II|28962.0|K-X-P|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Melodic'
column3: the way that frontman Timo Kaukolampi talks about his band K-X-P's sophomore LP II might make you a little concerned about your own mental health. And for good reason
column4: as K-X-P are band not to be trusted
column5: perhaps even feared. Take the Finnish group's regrettably overlooked but excellent self-titled 2010 debut
column6: which orbited a smorgasbord of maximalist pop fragments around lockstep motorik rhythms
column7: ultimately leaving brains pleasantly gooped like a sous-vide egg. But it's with II that the self-proclaimed ""anti-band"" has taken things to a new level
column8: as Kaukolampi has attested to infusing their sound with ""free jazz
column9: drone
column10: noise
column11: pop
column12: rock
column13: with an overall emphasis on trying to tap into something ""more punk."" He's even adopted a sort of alter ego
column14: combining the personalities of ""a lunatic occult reverend
column15: a yoga teacher
column16: John Lydon
column17: Freddie Mercury and Rob Halford."" Because why not? For a band that should've gotten your attention the first time around

column1: K-X-P aren't bullshitting you; II is both more ambitious and vaster in scope than its predecessor
column2: a record that pushes their most far-out tendencies to their respective limits. It is
column3: however
column4: less extreme than Kaukolampi's screeds would have you believe

column6: as arpeggiations chatter back and forth in ways that will likely remind you of the last Cut Copy full-length. Once the rhythm section locks in place (this is a band that features two drummers
column7: after all)
column8: majestic synths build

column11: beholden to no specific guiding principles. It's this sense of freedom that makes II an engaging
column12: at times very exciting listen
column13: but it also doesn't lead to much cohesion. K-X-P spend most of their time with their heads barely above water
column14: but instead of merely treading
column15: it feels as if they're betting alongside you as to whether or not they'll eventually go under. Needless to say

column1: As a record peppered with tiny little interludes (a snatch of opera runs backwards
column2: synths plink like drops of water
column3: etc.) that stitch things together loosely
column4: it's clear that this recording is intended to be approached as a kind of journey. To paraphrase Robert Downey Jr.
column5: you never go full prog
column6: but K-X-P's could-give-a-fuck-ness often trumps the pitfalls of similarly minded efforts. A good portion of these songs do sound like miniature campaigns
column7: chugging forward at various intervals
column8: often as sprawling as K-X-P was tightly coiled. But the heartbeat at the core of II is a human one

column1: Much of II exists in a sort of quasi-mythical realm
column2: where medieval chants and regal

In the solemn and self-serious realm of post-metal
column2: no band serves as a working template quite as much as Neurosis. For the last quarter century
column3: the California group has blended massive atmospherics with steely-eyed ferocity
column4: resulting in albums of grand arches and
column5: at best
column6: total immersion. Part of the delight
column7: though
column8: is tracing the band's stepwise development during their era; antithetical to the pervasive indie culture quip of ""I liked their earlier stuff better
column9: seldom few Neurosis fans would argue that the band arrived fully formed. Rather
column10: their most foundational records appeared in their second decade as a unit (see
column11: debatably
column12: the Relapse era
column13: from 1996 until 2001). And when I interviewed the band last year about their very good 10th album
column14: Honor Found in Decay
column15: Steve Von Till said that Neurosis was still working to develop and explore new techniques. ""Rather than get set in our ways or find anything too comfortable
column16: we find these new places to exist
column17: he said
column18: explaining that some of his favorite parts on the latest record stemmed not from the typical loud guitars but instead from keyboard player Noah Landis. For Von Till
column19: Neurosis' emphasis on long-run evolution rather than short-term aberrations was a clear point of pride
column20: a practical ideal to suit their musical aesthetic.

column1: One clear heir to both Neurosis' sprawling post-metal cycles and their persistent development as an ensemble is Sweden's Cult of Luna. Like their transoceanic predecessors
column2: Cult of Luna is as much a posse as a band
column3: with seven members integrated into the fold over the last 14 years. And like Neurosis
column4: they started simply as a viscous
column5: belligerent metal band (see the great ""Sleep""
column6: from their 2001 debut); with ambition and gusto
column7: they have slowly augmented their sounds and approaches
column8: not only incorporating electronics but also warping expectations of structure and form. That process
column9: as one might imagine
column10: hasn't been without its missteps. The Beyond
column11: from 2003
column12: had its moments
column13: but the band's attempts to infuse electronics were sometimes coltish and awkward
column14: like a nü metal band trying to transgress into a more sophisticated mold.

column1: But their sixth album
column2: this year's Vertikal
column3: serves as proof positive that
column4: even after more than a decade
column5: Cult of Luna remains a promising and dynamic enterprise. Recorded in sessions that stretched for more than a year
column6: Vertikal hinges upon Cult of Luna's ability to have the band's machine and men play nice. At its best
column7: it finds a surprising middle ground between Deftones and Neurosis
column8: and that seems to have been part of the point. As co-founder Johannes Persson told Britain’s ATTN: magazine
column9: electronics served as a vital piece of the writing process for the first time on Vertikal
column10: not a tacked-on and late textural addition. ""On Eternal Kingdom
column11: he said
column12: referencing the band's 2008 album
column13: ""we tried to have the electronics in mind when we wrote
column14: but we couldn't do that in the same sense. ...We put the layer electronics on top
column15: but this time we had the electronics while we were writing. It made a huge impact.""

column1: Indeed
column2: Vertikal's moments of synthesis unveil remarkably progressive doom
column3: putting the surly form in uncomfortable positions and often finding a payload. ""I: The Weapon"" is an aggressive march
column4: with a sharp and long riff that’s treated like an epic voyage. At one point near its midsection
column5: Cult of Luna swaps the strings for a rubbery dubstep backbone. That might read terribly
column6: but it’s as exhilarating as it is unexpected. In the coda
column7: distorted guitars linger over and wrap around crackling keyboards. ""The Sweep""
column8: the album's shortest non-instrumental track
column9: is a brutal burst of industrial pop
column10: with the warped pulses and sinews of noise waging war against the mutilated vocals. Cult of Luna's metal pedigree provides texture and depth; their interest in corroding their limits provides the inspiration. And on the beautiful
column11: patient closer ""Passing Through""
column12: the twinkles of glockenspiel and the sheets of digitally tweaked crooning float above sinister guitars set on an infinite loop. Previously
column13: Cult of Luna's sideshow forays detracted from their bulkhead of heaviness; here
column14: they serve as reinforcement.

column1: Vertikal is an interesting and accomplished hybrid
column2: but it isn't perfect. In fact
column3: it works best on a track-by track basis
column4: though the record clearly aims to be its own holistic
column5: all-encompassing universe. Persson says Fritz Lang's early sci-fi horror Metropolis served as a stylistic inspiration for an album ""that was going to sound like a 'factory.'"" After a dozen trips through
column6: though
column7: the sequencing and transitions still feel ineffective. The prelude ""The One"" doesn't funnel into what would have been the more daring gambit
column8: ""I: The Weapon"". And the end of ""Mute Departure"" and the beginning of ""In Awe Of"" have nothing to do with the interlude that divides them
column9: a 45-second synthesizer piece that seems to summon the legacy of Laurie Spiegel only as a perfunctory demonstration of erudition.

column1: Brevity isn’t a thing that Cult of Luna knows well
column2: either. These 65 minutes are a median length for a band that’s consistently guilty of conflating quantity with quality. The distended build that opens the 19-minute ""Vicarious Redemption"" demands an edit that it doesn’t get; as is
column3: some of the heaviest and best moments on the record
column4: when the septet works in perfectly combustible unity
column5: get diluted by the deep slog that surrounds them. But that's the risk of unrest
column6: isn't it? Had Cult of Luna attempted to make the same record six times during the last decade
column7: maybe they would have condensed it into a tight 30 minutes by now. That would be neither captivating nor interesting
column8: though
column9:
and Vertikal is quite often both.

Fleetwood Mac's Rumours would never be just an album. Upon its release in 1977
column3: it became the fastest-selling LP of all time
column4: moving 800
column5: 000 copies per week at its height
column6: and its success made Fleetwood Mac a cultural phenomenon. The million-dollar record that took a year and untold grams to complete became a totem of 1970s excess
column7: rock'n'roll at its most gloriously indulgent. It was also a bellwether of glimmering Californian possibility
column8: the permissiveness and entitlement of the 70s done up in heavy harmonies. By the time it was made
column9: the personal freedoms endowed by the social upheaval of the 60s had unspooled into unfettered hedonism. As such
column10: it plays like a reaping: a finely polished post-hippie fallout
column11: unaware that the twilight hour of the free love era was fixing and there would be no going back. In 1976
column12: there was no knowledge of AIDS
column13: Reagan had just left the governor's manse
column14: and people still thought of cocaine as non-addictive and strictly recreational. Rumours is a product of that moment and it serves as a yardstick by which we measure just how 70s the 70s were.

column1: And then there's the album's influence. Though it was seen as punk's very inverse
column2: Rumours has enjoyed a long trickle-down of influence starting from the alt-rock-era embrace via Billy Corgan and Courtney Love to the harmonies and choogling of Bonnie ""Prince"" Billy and the earthier end of Beach House. Rumours set a template for pop with a gleaming surface that has something complicated
column3: desperate
column4: and dark resonating underneath.

column1: Setting aside the weight of history
column2: listening to Rumours is an easy pleasure. Records with singles that never go away tend to evoke nostalgia for the time when the music soundtracked your life; in this case
column3: you could've never owned a copy of it and still know almost every song. When you make an album this big
column4: your craft is
column5: by default
column6: accessibility. But this wasn't generic pabulum. It was personal. Anyone could find a piece of themselves within these songs of love and loss.

column1: Two years prior to recording Rumours
column2: though
column3: Fleetwood Mac was approximately nowhere. In order to re-establish the group's flagging stateside reputation
column4: in early 1974 Fleetwood Mac's drummer and band patriarch
column5: Mick Fleetwood
column6: keyboardist/singer Christine McVie
column7: and her husband
column8: bassist John McVie
column9: moved from England to Los Angeles. The quartet was then helmed by their fifth and least-dazzling guitarist
column10: the American Bob Welch. Not long after the band's British faction had relocated
column11: Welch quit the band. Around the same time Mick Fleetwood was introduced to the work of local duo
column12: Buckingham Nicks
column13: who'd just been dropped by Polydor. The drummer was enchanted by Lindsey Buckingham's guitar work and Nicks' complete package
column14: and when Welch quit
column15: he offered them a spot in the band outright.

column1: The group
column2: essentially a new band under an old name
column3: quickly cut 1975's self-titled Fleetwood Mac
column4: an assemblage of Christine McVie's songs and tracks Buckingham and Nicks had intended for their second album
column5: including the eventual smash ""Rhiannon"". It was a huge seller in its own right and they were now a priority act given considerable resources. But by the time they booked two months at Record Plant in Sausalito to record the follow-up
column6: the band's personal bonds were frayed
column7: there was serious resentment and constant drama. Nicks had just broken up with Buckingham after six years of domestic and creative partnership. Fleetwood's wife was divorcing him
column8: and the McVies were separated and no longer speaking.

column1: While Fleetwood Mac was a bit of a mash-up of existing work
column2: Lindsey Buckingham effectively commandeered the band for Rumours
column3: giving their sound a radio-ready facelift. He redirected John McVie and Fleetwood's playing from blues past towards the pop now. Fleetwood Mac wanted hits and gave the wheel to Buckingham
column4: a deft craftsman with a vision for what the album had to become.

column1: He opens the record with the libidinous ""Second Hand News""
column2: inspired by the redemption Buckingham was finding in new women
column3: post-Stevie. It was the album's first single and also perhaps the most euphoric ode to rebound chicks ever written. Buckingham's ""bow-bow-bow-doot-doo-diddley-doot"" is corny
column4: but it works along with the percussion track (Buckingham played the seat of an office chair after Fleetwood was unable to properly replicate a beat a la the Bee Gees' ""Jive Talkin'""). Like ""Second Hand News""
column5: Buckingham's ""Go Your Own Way"" is upbeat but totally fuck-you. He croons ""shackin' up is all you wanna do
column6: -- accusing an ex-lover of being a wanton slut on a song where his ex-lover harmonizes on the hook. Save for ""Never Going Back Again
column7: (a vintage Buckingham Nicks composition brought in to replace Stevie's too-long ""Silver Springs"") Buckingham's songs are turnabout as fairplay with lithe guitar glissando on top.

column1: ""Second Hand News"" is followed by a twist-of-the-knife Stevie-showpiece
column2: ""Dreams""
column3: a gauzy ballad about what she'd had and what she'd lost with Buckingham. It was written during one of the days where Nicks wasn't needed for tracking. She wrote the song in a few minutes
column4: recorded it onto a cassette
column5: and returned to the studio and demanded the band listen to it. It was a simple ballad that would be finessed into the album's jewel; the quiet vamp laced with laconic Leslie-speaker vibrato and spooky warmth allow Nicks to draw an exquisite sketch of loneliness. ""Dreams"" would become Fleetwood Mac's only #1 hit.

column1: Though Fleetwood Mac was always the sum of its parts
column2: Nicks was something special both in terms of the band and in rock history. She helped establish a feminine vernacular that was (still) in league with the cock rock of the 70s but didn't present as a diametric vulnerability; it was not innocent. While Janis Joplin and Grace Slick had been rock's most iconic heroines at the tail-end of the 60s
column3: they were very much trying to keep up with boys in their world; Nicks was creating a new space. And Fleetwood Mac was still very much an anomaly
column4: unique in being a rock band fronted by two women who were writing their own material
column5: with Nicks presenting as the girliest bad girl rock'n'roll had seen since Ronnie Spector. She took the stage baring a tambourine festooned with lengths of lavender ribbon; people said she was a witch.

column1: Like her male rock'n'roll peers
column2: Nicks sang songs about the intractable power of a woman (her first hit
column3: ""Rhiannon"") and used women as a metaphor (""Gold Dust Woman"")
column4: but her approach was different. At the time of Rumours' release
column5: she maintained that the latter song was about groupies who would scowl at her and Christine but light up when the guys appeared. She later confessed that it was about cocaine getting the best of her. In 1976
column6: coke was the mise of the scene-- to admit you were growing weary would have been gauche. Nicks' husky voice made it sound like she'd lived and her lyrics-- of pathos
column7: independence
column8: and getting played-- certainly backed it up. She seemed like a real woman-- easy to identify with
column9: but with mystery and a natural glamour worth aspiring to.

column1: It's almost easy to miss Christine McVie for all of Nicks' mystique. McVie had been in the band for years
column2: but never at the helm. Her songs ""You Make Lovin' Fun"" and ""Don't Stop"" are pure pep. ""Songbird"" starts as a plaintive ode of fealty and how total her devotion-- until the sad tell of ""And I wish you all the love in the world/ But most of all I wish it from myself
column3: (an especially heart-wrenching line given that McVie's not quite ex-husband was dragging a rebound model chick to the sessions and Christine was sneaking around with a member of the crew). She didn't hate her husband
column4: she adored him
column5: she wished it could work but after years of being in the Mac together
column6: she knew better. Throughout
column7: McVie's songwriting is pure and direct
column8: irrepressibly sweet. ""Oh Daddy""
column9: a song she wrote about Mick Fleetwood's pending divorce is melancholy but ultimately maintains its dignity. McVie
column10: with typical British reserve
column11: confessed she preferred to leave the bleakness and poesy to her dear friend Stevie.

column1: As much feminine energy as Rumours wields
column2: the album's magic is in its balance: male and female
column3: British blues versus American rock'n'roll
column4: lightness and dark
column5: love and disgust
column6: sorrow and elation
column7: ballads and anthems
column8: McVie's sweetness against Nicks' grit. They were a democratic band where each player raised the stakes of the whole. The addition of Buckingham and Nicks and McVie's new prominence kicked John McVie's bass playing loose from its blues mooring and forced him towards simpler
column9: more buoyant pop. Fleetwood's playing itself is just godhead
column10: with effortless little fills
column11: light but thunderous
column12: and his placement impeccable throughout. The ominous
column13: insistent kick on the first half on ""The Chain""
column14: for example
column15: colors the song as much as the quiver of disgust in Buckingham's voice when he spits ""never.""

column1: In the liner notes to the deluxe Rumours 4xCD/DVD/LP box set
column2: Buckingham describes the album-making process as ""organic."" Rumours is anything but
column3: and that is part of its genius-- it's so flawless it feels far from nature. It is more like a peak human feat of Olympic-level studio craft. It was made better by its myopia and brutal circumstances: the wounded pride of a recently dumped Buckingham
column4: the new hit of ""Rhiannon""
column5: goading Nicks to fight for inclusion of her own songs
column6: Christine McVie attempting to salve her heart with ""Songbird."" That Fleetwood Mac had become the biggest record Warner Bros. had ever released while the band was making Rumours allowed for an impossibly long tether for them to dick around and correct the next album until it was immaculate.

column1: Given the standalone nature of Rumours
column2: it's difficult to argue that any other part of the box set is necessary. The live recordings of the Rumours tour are fine
column3: lively even (perhaps owing to Fleetwood rationing a Heineken cap of coke to each band member to power performances). Only a handful of tracks on the two discs of the sessions outtakes lend any greater understanding of the process behind it. One is ""Dreams (Take 2)""
column4: which is just Nicks voice
column5: some burbling organ
column6: and rough rhythm guitar gives an appreciation of her fundamental talent as well as Buckingham's ability to transform it; it makes the case for how much they needed each other. Another is ""Second Hand News (Early Take)""
column7: which features Buckingham mumbling lyrics so as not to incense Nicks. The alternate mixes and takes (more phaser! Less Dobro! Take 22!)
column8: by the time you make it to disc four
column9: just underscore the fact that Rumours did not hatch as a pristine whole. One does not need three variously funky articulations of Christine's burning ""Keep Me There"" to comprehend this.

column1: Nevertheless
column2: it is difficult not to buy into the mythology of Rumours both as an album and pop culture artifact: a flawless record pulled from the wreckage of real lives. As one of classic rock's foundational albums
column3: it holds up better than any other commercial smash of that ilk (Hotel California
column4: certainly). We can now use it as a kind of nostalgic benchmark-- that they don't make groups like that anymore
column5: that there is no rock band so palatable that it could be the best-selling album in the U.S. for 31 weeks. Things work differently now. Examined from that angle
column6: Rumours was not exactly a game changer
column7:
it was merely perfect.

Say what you like about Darkstar's shapeshift from forward-facing production crew to pillowy dreampop dudes
column2: but it's probably not a move they made for cred points. After all
column3: back when they were featured players on Kode9's Hyperdub label

The subsequent addition of vocalist James Buttery appeared to position Darkstar at the forefront of a generation of dance acts looking to marry vocals and textured dance sounds in a novel and original way. The ensuing ""Aidy's Girl is a Computer"" seemed like a bellwether-- for a good six months

column1: But a funny thing happened on the way to that moment; Darkstar got soft. Not soft soppy-- although this album's detractors might argue that
column2: too-- but soft sonically. Even with Buttery in the fold

News From Nowhere is so unbothered by rhythmic invention that it might as well be from a different band. The keening falsettos

column1: It's fun to think about Darkstar's raw materials and what they might do with them one day
column2: but nobody's going to come away from News From Nowhere feeling like they've successfully cultivated their own unique universe. Perhaps in the grand scheme of things
column3: this might end up being thought of as a necessary transition album that bridges some new future territory for them. But even as a functional exercise in sensitive songs and electronic pastels

Le1f's 2012 mixtape Dark York established him as one of the more idiosyncratic rappers in a year defined in large part by a vast number of debuts by folks who don't fit the popular conception of what people expect from an MC. Most of the record is given over to edgy dance-rap hybrids and edgier electronic psychedelia
column3: but in the moments that his vision snaps into focus-- including but not limited to the addictively skronky
column4: twerk-worthy single ""Wut""-- he turns into a pop star waiting to happen. On Fly Zone
column5: his full-length follow-up to Dark York that comes on the heels of a collaborative EP with his producer Boody
column6: he seems determined to make that transition.

column1: Even just a couple of years ago the idea of a rapper with such a strongly avant-garde sensibility-- not to mention one that's openly gay-- bent on crossing over with a mainstream audience would have seemed like a cruel joke. But the hip-hop mainstream has been steadily catching up with its artsy leading edge
column2: so that someone like Clams Casino can go from being an obscure producer with a sui generis aesthetic and a SoundCloud page to prominent placement on marquee major label albums in what seemed like no time.

column1: Le1f’s forthright about his ambitions. He dedicates the album’s third track
column2: ""Cloud So Loud""
column3: to college kids
column4: suburbs
column5: the projects
column6: and clubs ""with no basic bitches at the function

column8: produced by the evocatively named DJ Blood Everywhere
column9: is frenetic
column10: booming
column11: and probably sounds amazing being played too loud over a club P.A.
column12: so the idea of Le1f attracting that kind of audience is far from unfeasible. In that context
column13: its use of a snippet of the same vocal sample from Super Beagle's ""Dust a Soundboy"" that Kanye and Lifted based the beat to last summer’s megasmash ""Mercy"" around is both aspirational and hella cheeky.

column1: ""Cloud So Loud"" isn't the only overtly ambitious moment on Fly Zone
column2: but unlike most goal-oriented mixtape rappers
column3: Le1f wisely prefers to show his crossover potential rather than to rap about it. On Dark York his vocal performances tended to be about as spacey as the beats behind them
column4: but since then his flow has developed a heft and muscularity that it lacked before
column5: as if he's only just now figuring out what his limber vocal chords are capable of
column6: which includes everything from deep
column7: unexpectedly Tupac-like growls to a girlish squeal that he sometimes deploys during punchlines. His lyrics are stronger too. ""Airbending"" boasts the line
column8: ""I am whatever you say I am/ Stop worrying about how gay I am
column9: where the fact that it's a flip of an Eminem lyric is followed quickly by the realization that a rapper quoted one of pop's most virulent homophobes to reaffirm his gayness
column10: which is a brilliant demonstration of conceptual judo.

column1: Fly Zone's production is similarly more coherent than Dark York's. There's still enough weirdness to satisfy Le1f's more psychedelically inclined fans (including ""Psy Lock""
column2: which is one of the trippiest odes to cybersex ever recorded)
column3: but he seems more inclined now to borrow ideas from mainstream rap music
column4: even if he ends up turning them inside out. Standout track ""Spa Day"" sounds like the result of an MDMA-fueled encounter between dubstep and trap rap. (The hook where Le1f wishes us ""mazel tov"" is prone to looping endlessly in the brain long after the song is over.) ""The Whip""
column5: featuring Haleek Maul
column6: is even more traditional
column7: with a beat that delivers an almost eerily accurate reproduction of early-90s g-funk.

column1: All in all
column2: Fly Zone is an epically audacious record
column3: boiling down to essentially a 13-track demand from Le1f to be allowed access to a mainstream audience without sacrificing a shred of the identity that sets him apart from nearly every rapper a mainstream audience has been drawn to. Will Le1f be able to have his cake and eat it
column4:
too? I have a feeling we'll find out by his next installment.
