column14: here we are
column15: talking about his latest effort
column16: Us Alone.

column1: This is his seventh album in 17 years
column2: which is something. More importantly
column3: it's his first release through the Canadian label Arts & Crafts
column4: home to Broken Social Scene and all of its many offshoots. Such a signing could prompt some pop history revisionism
column5: casting Hayden alongside some of his new labelmates as foundational to Toronto's indie rock scene. Sure
column6: his music bears some superficial similarities to Feist
column7: who also started out in the 90s. But he lacks her subdued spryness and-- more crucially-- her sense of melody; the relative quiet of her music conceals unruly emotions and provides a setting for her sonic experiments. Hayden is nowhere near as idiosyncratic. In fact
column8: his closest contemporary analog might just be the likewise drowsy-voiced M. Ward
column9: except without his throwback sensibilities and-- more crucially-- his sense of melody.

column1: Despite the new label
column2: Hayden hasn't beefed up his sound on Us Alone. Instead
column3: he's pared down even more. He recorded these songs almost entirely by himself in his home studio
column4: playing all of the instruments and emphasizing a live
column5: textured sound that he says he hopes will be easier to replicate onstage. Even with fewer hands playing fewer instruments
column6: the songs nevertheless sound leaden
column7: ponderous
column8: drowsy. Still
column9: there are some inspired flourishes
column10: like the hesitating guitar riff on ""Rainy Saturday"" or the church organ on ""Oh Memory"" or the vocals by Lou Canon on ""Blurry Nights"". She's a lively presence on the song
column11: and her breathily expressive delivery makes her a good foil for the deadpan Hayden.

column1: Opener ""Motel"" actually starts strong as Hayden describes a tryst between conflicted lovers
column2: with synths bouncing around a simple drumbeat and a piano providing some languid drama. But there's no build
column3: no direction. Even when he breaks the fourth wall on the last verse and speaks directly to the listener
column4: the music doesn't react. Instead
column5: it merely maintains
column6: minding its own business and almost pointedly ignoring his lyrical gambit. If that song sets a melancholy tone for Us Alone
column7: it also hints at its shortcomings. Too often the music just hangs there
column8: possibly by design or more likely because Hayden is a limited instrumentalist (his drumming in particular is fairly rudimentary). As a result
column9: these songs are heavy on atmosphere but low on dynamics
column10: which completely deflates the meandering closer ""Instructions"".

column1: About that last verse on ""Motel"": Perhaps Hayden intends that aside to the audience to be self-deprecating. ""I can't go on pretending this song is about young lovers
column2: born to run
column3: he sings
column4: ""when it's clearly about you and me."" Especially with that shoehorned shout-out to the Boss
column5: it comes across as self-satisfied
column6: almost smug in its cleverness-- a wink rather than a tear. Hayden treads a fine line here
column7: writing explicitly as a musician managing romantic disappointments
column8: but more often than not it gets away from him: ""I don't want the bright lights
column9: I don’t need more invites
column10: he muses on ""Old Dreams"". ""I don't need more reviews
column11: not unless they're from you.""

column1: On the other hand
column2: ""Almost Everything""
column3: even with its nod to the title of his debut
column4: is a clear-eyed origin story that recalls 1994 in all its promise: touring in a red Toyota Tercel
column5: playing to crowds of seated fans
column6: meeting a few of his heroes
column7: allowing himself to believe he belongs in that world. It's a bittersweet reminiscence made all the more affecting by the mere fact that Hayden is still around to remember those days: ""I'll admit that now and then
column8: some nights when I'm strumming
column9: or maybe just strumming
column10: music's still everything."" Then he thinks about his kid asleep upstairs and corrects himself: ""Well
column11: almost everything."" Us Alone may not be the triumphant comeback he intended
column12:
but such candid confessions reveal why we're still talking about Hayden so many years later: He still (almost) believes.

column6: the story goes

column13: Hutchison sings

Bryan Ferry works steadily

column1: All told

column3: though Ferry acts as co-producer and general driving force rather than performer. In fact
column4: for the first time since Let's Stick Together
column5: Ferry's own material is the subject of reworking: all selections are his work ranging from Roxy's debut single ""Virginia Plain"" to ""Reason or Rhyme""

column7: The Jazz Age's roots lie in 1999's As Time Goes By
column8: where Ferry recorded jazz and pop songs predominantly from the 1930s. Five out of The Jazz Age's eight performers reappear from the earlier work along with others such as regular Ferry collaborator
column9: trumpeter Enrico Tomasso. But The Jazz Age

column11: is more self-consciously 1920s
column12: openly meant to evoke Louis Armstrong
column13: early Count Basie
column14: and the initial mass popularization of jazz.

column1: If there's an inescapable element of perverseness about The Jazz Age

column5: a clipped mood piece like ""Love is the Drug"" or ""Don't Stop the Dance""
column6: or contemplative songs like ""Avalon"". The resultant energetic but never too disruptive presentation turns everything into something which sounds like it could be coming out of the Victrola at a party at ""Downton Abbey"" by the time the show hits season five. The album is hard to immediately see as anything but a studied curio by a famous name deliberately out of sync with nearly everything around it
column7: unless one wants to talk about Hugh Laurie's tribute to New Orleans and the blues.

column1: The internal trick of The Jazz Age is that Ferry's orchestra also deftly avoids simply sounding one-note despite the uniform presentation and ambience. At points the arrangements are almost specific responses to the originals. ""The Bogus Man"" here shrinks from 10 to two minutes long
column2: hinting at second line comedy before the funeral's actually been completed

column5: stately number from 2002's Frantic

column7: surprises turn up one by one

column9: the crystalline theatricality of ""Reason or Rhyme"" mutates into a one-room-over and slightly boozy speakeasy swing

column1: Meanwhile

column1: The end result is actually the most atypical Ferry album of them all. It's something that seemed-- only after it was announced-- obvious that he would do but never actually did. column4:
The Jazz Age is Ferry's most radical work yet.

The blend of pottymouthed humor and a Biz Markie-an performance is by no means subtle

column4: as if to prove the implied point

In an industrial area 40 minutes north of Amsterdam lives a 24-year-old multi-instrumentalist with a Brian Jones haircut. Jacco Gardner's home is called the Shadow Shoppe Studio
column2: and there
column3: he creates music that hearkens back to the studio wizards of the 1960s: Brian Wilson
column4: Van Dyke Parks
column5: Syd Barrett
column6: Curt Boettcher
column7: Love
column8: and so on. There's no sense of industry
column9: or really
column10: the 21st century in Gardner's baroque pop

column12: sometimes jaunty Lewis Carroll quality to it. Unsurprisingly
column13: he told The Guardian that he found inspiration in records ""where the songwriter or artist also took over the role of producer and could really start experimenting and work out everything they could think of themselves."" With his head stuck in classic albums and with very few collaborators
column14: he spent a couple years creating the universe you hear on his debut solo album
column15: Cabinet of Curiosities.

column1: It's not just hard to hear a hint of the modern world in Gardner's music; it's hard to hear a hint of Gardner in Gardner's music. Though he's said in interviews that he wrote some of his songs from a personal place
column2: his lyrics don't read like personal folk tales or journal fodder. Instead
column3: they're littered with psychedelic romance and costume drama-- ""Open up the window to your mind/ So I can look inside and lend a hand
column4: he sings in ""The One Eyed King"". ""Sleep when stars are bright
column5: he coos in ""Lullaby"". The title track features harpsichords and laughing babies. Thematically speaking
column6: Cabinet of Curiosities is all facade-- these are quaint stories approached with the tools of 1960s psychedelia. In order to pull off this sort of thing in 2013
column7: it's on Gardner to create a soundscape strong enough to support his own airily fey material. And that's exactly what he does.

column1: In the Shadow Shoppe
column2: he created arrangements that are diverse and lush
column3: where the most atmospheric elements on the record sound full instead of brittle. Opener ""Clear the Air"" can pull off harpsichords and featherlight synths because they're complemented by huge
column4: echoing drums. In the chorus
column5: beneath Gardner's vocal
column6: you can hear voices lending haunting ""ahhs"" from each corner of the mix. And right when a song starts to get stale
column7: he also knows exactly when to inject a bold new element. ""Summer's Game"" starts off pretty spare
column8: but right when it begins to overstay its welcome around the midpoint
column9: the percussive backbone kicks in and carries the song to the finish. It also helps that Gardner has an ear for melody-- his singsong sensibility makes the sweet
column10: sad album closer ""The Ballad of Little Jane"" an easy highlight.

column1: Sometimes
column2: though
column3: Gardner plays it a bit too straight. ""Cabinet of Curiosities""
column4: for example
column5: is a repetitive instrumental that doesn't do much to add to its already well-established facade. And sometimes the ""Mad Hatter universe"" feeling turns more into ""oppressive carousel music
column6: as is the case with ""The Riddle"". But the biggest danger for Gardner is in the album's diversity (or lack thereof). On an individual level
column7: these songs can thrive due to their masterful arrangements. But it's hard to shake an overwhelming feeling of stagnation in the run from ""Watching the Moon"" to ""The Riddle""
column8: which all feature the exact same sort of keyboard work.

column1: Ultimately
column2: it's an album that's a bit on the long side
column3: and for a record that has such firm roots in the 1960s
column4: that's a tough obstacle to overcome. Overlong albums are one thing
column5: but overlong and sonically derivative albums are usually near unlistenable. But it's the individual songs that make Cabinet worth the time. ""Puppets Dangling"" obviously has more of Gardner's whimsical imagery in its lyrics and title
column6: but it also has some incredible moments. As he transitions into the song's refrain
column7: he doesn't ramp up the percussion; he lets loose a barrage of gorgeous
column8: densely packed strings and synths. It's a beautiful section of one song
column9: and Cabinet of Curiosities has several just like it. The album might exist in the wrong era
column10: but throughout
column11:
those moments highlight Gardner's biggest strength-- he's a studio wizard.

On a recent episode of Portlandia

column1: As Little Wings

column1: There's a sepia flatness to the songs on LAST. Heavy moments are portrayed at exactly the same tempo and lyrical level. Field might be singing about death
column2: life
column3: or sitting around his house

column5: Field positions himself as an observer of nature and of himself. When he sings ""there goes my light feeling
column6: on ""Light Feeling"" his voice cracks and strains against his own constraints. He doesn't sound sad to lose happiness
column7: instead he sings from outside himself
column8: like it's maybe a bummer worth noting later. It's a neat effect

column1: Not too long ago
column2: British author Zadie Smith spoke at the New York Public Library. As an aside
column3: she half-joked that if a book involves a character staring out an ocean
column4: it's probably not very good. Her point being that everyone is in awe of an ocean and everyone is in awe of nature
column5: so staring out at a vast expanse of water and not being able to see a horizon is now emotional shorthand for poignancy. Maybe it's worth finding other ways to be deep. There are
column6: of course
column7: always exceptions to this rule. Field is able to transform the mundane into a quietly shared experience-- it works as a sort of Introspective Depressives Anonymous. His songs are for people fiending for the next transcendent moment to jumpstart their lives. He knows these moments can exist
column8: but is never sure where he'll next find them. On ""Wide Daylight"" he wonders if he can ""manage to turn the corner again."" The implication being that the song itself could be that corner for at least a few listeners somewhere.

column1: By the time ""You Know Who"" starts
column2: it feels like a turning point. A break from Field's shaky-voiced uncertainty comes in the form of murky keys that give way to an unexpectedly strong moment
column3: when Field sings ""barely old enough to fade now
column4: and young enough to be strong
column5: he's illustrating a particular kind of purgatory-- the space between full blown responsible adulthood and the last remnants of youthful brashness. With over a decade's worth of music under his belt
column6:
he seems content to stay there forever.

""When can we hear some new material?
column3: someone asked Kevin Shields in an AOL chat interview published by the San Francisco zine Cool Beans!. ""Definitely sometime this year or I'm dead..."" he answered
column4: later driving the point home with
column5: ""I really am dead if I don't get my record out this year. Nobody's threatening me
column6: BTW I just have to.""

column1: That chat took place exactly 16 years ago tomorrow and Kevin Shields is still alive. And now
column2: almost 22 years after My Bloody Valentine's last album
column3: Loveless
column4: we finally have that record. For those of us whose relationship to music and maybe even the act of hearing has been changed by Loveless
column5: it's hard to believe. I'd grown comfortable with the idea that there would never be another My Bloody Valentine album. Even as recently as two months ago
column6: I figured it would never happen. ""But he said it was mastered
column7: people said to me. The last time a master of an MBV album was completed it took four years for it to come out. And that was music that had already been released. An alleged master of a new release? Plenty of time to pull the plug. But no
column8: it happened
column9: by surprise
column10: last Saturday night. And many 403 errors later
column11: we finally have this thing on our hard drives. mbv. 2013. This Is Our Bloody Valentine.

column1: Like a few people I know
column2: I was initially afraid to listen
column3: but there was no need to be. My Bloody Valentine have taken the precise toolkit of Loveless-- layered Fender Jaguar guitars made woozy through pedals and tremolo
column4: hushed androgynous vocals way down in the mix-- and made another album with it
column5: one that is stranger and darker and even harder to pin down. Where Loveless felt effortless
column6: mbv strains
column7: pushing at its boundaries with a sense of pensive gloom. If the guy spending all those years in the studio felt trapped by the experience
column8: like the walls might be closing in and that he was dead if he didn't finish
column9: the music here reflects it. mbv is an album of density with very little air or light. But it doesn't forgo the human touches that have made this band so special.

column1: The nine-song mbv can be divided into thirds and the first three-song section
column2: consisting of ""She Found Now""
column3: ""Only Tomorrow""
column4: and ""Who Sees You""
column5: finds Shields exploring the untapped textural possibilities of the guitar. The last several years have been bad ones for the instrument. In independent music circles
column6: the guitar has become synonymous with regression
column7: a symbol used to evoke something from the past. And that might seem at first equally true here
column8: since the tone of Shields' guitar is so clearly connected to the sounds he pioneered two decades ago. But no one believes more deeply than Kevin Shields in the expressive power of the processed guitar
column9: and the music here turns out to be more about feeling than style.

column1: ""She Found Now"" is an opener of daring subtlety
column2: a ballad in the vein of ""Sometimes"" that consists mostly of deep strumming and Shields' singing in a tone near a whisper. There's a bit of percussion
column3: a few more layers of distortion
column4: but no announcement of anything earth-shattering or even particularly different. It's My Bloody Valentine making the kind of noises they invented and perfected. As the chords cycle through in the following ""Only Tomorrow""
column5: Shields sets up a situation where the repetition and familiarity lulls you into a kind of trance and small gestures hit with great force. On ""Only Tomorrow"" that spine-tingling moment is a dead simple screeching high-end refrain that repeats toward the end
column6: while on the following ""Who Sees You""
column7: it's a section halfway through where a rush of trebly chords coats the entire song in another layer of textured fuzz. When it comes to Shields and guitars
column8: the small details do a tremendous amount of work.

column1: The second trio of songs feature the lead vocals of My Bloody Valentine singer/guitarist Bilinda Butcher. The push and pull of her singing next to Shields' is
column2: along with the wavy ""glide guitar"" effect
column3: My Bloody Valentine's other defining characteristic. Their voices are the essence of the the band's strangely androgynous and non-specific sensuality. ""Is This and Yes"" is just Butcher's voice and an unusual organ pattern that hangs in space at the end of the progression and never resolves itself; ""New You"" is the only track on the record that sounds even remotely like a single
column4: and it shows that Shields' melodic impulses have not left him.

column1: In another sense
column2: ""New You"" points out how much has changed since MBV last released a full-length. In 1991
column3: they were still a pop band
column4: the kind that made videos and appeared on magazine covers and were on a fashionable record label. As such
column5: there was at least some pressure for them to fit in
column6: for their music to have context in the popular music landscape. So they released singles and probably hoped they'd become hits. Even if ""Soon"" had
column7: as Brian Eno stated at the time
column8: set a ""new standard
column9: that didn't change that fact that it was in fact still pop. But those days are gone. My Bloody Valentine fit in exactly nowhere and the commercial expectations of a release like mbv are minimal. Whatever the cause
column10: mbv is the weirdest album My Bloody Valentine have made by some margin. Some of the record's otherworldly quality is up to frequency range. There's very little on this album in the treble range but there's endless detail in the bass and mid
column11: which makes the record feel more closed in and insular. But some of it is in the arc of the record.

column1: Through the 1990s Kevin Shields often talked about jungle
column2: what it meant to him
column3: and how some of the ideas behind it were making their way into a new My Bloody Valentine album. He was not alone in this
column4: but mixing drum'n'bass' whooshing walls of percussion with oceanic shoegaze seemed a natural pairing (it was so natural
column5: in fact
column6: that artists like Third Eye Foundation beat Shields to the punch). Whether or not the final three songs on mbv are related to Shields' experiments of that time
column7: on mbv
column8: where Shields presumably had time to make the drum parts he wanted
column9: it's clear that he doesn't really hear percussion the way most of us do. Drums are mostly distant
column10: often muddy
column11: serving as an underpinning or textural contrast to the guitar instead of driving the rhythm on their own. In this sense they mirror the 8-bit snatches of sound caught by crude samplers in the 90s. But since Isn't Anything
column12: drums have been down on the list of concerns for MBV
column13: which is one way the final third is so surprising and ultimately powerful.

column1: ""In Another Way""
column2: another Butcher lead
column3: begins to tilt the balance between noise and melodic beauty as the tempo increases
column4: and by the following instrumental ""Nothing Is"" the mood has changed considerably. A track of heavy bass drums and pounding guitar
column5: it feels militaristic and even a touch grim
column6: with just faint glimmers of beauty inside the barrage. And then by the final ""Wonder 2"" the album has become something else. This is MBV's version of an album-closing ""L.A. Blues""-like Stooges freak-out
column7: where they stop worrying about structure and fill every inch of tape with noise. The heavy flanging evokes choppers buzzing overhead
column8: and somehow
column9: through it all
column10: there are wispy voices
column11: buried and being shoved around by the din. It's a disquieting end. Where Loveless
column12: despite its complexity
column13: sounded as natural as breathing
column14: mbv sounds like the product of great effort
column15: of meticulous work to get every sound in place. And that exertion is especially apparent in the final third
column16: as Shields tries and ultimately succeeds in taking the project somewhere it's never gone. All this work gives mbv its own quality
column17: simultaneously intimate and detached.

column1: Like its predecessor
column2: mbv feels like an album in part about love
column3: but it approaches the grandest of human emotions from an unusual angle. Kurt Cobain
column4: another iconic songwriter of the 1990s who never got a chance to grow old and figure out how to maintain his creativity in the wake of game-changing masterpieces
column5: had a song called ""Aneurysm"" and it had a refrain that went
column6: ""Love you so much
column7: makes me sick."" That's how My Bloody Valentine's deeply destabilizing queasiness
column8: amplified here to a frightening degree
column9: has always struck me: There's a rush of feeling inside their music so intense it creates a kind of paralysis. Music swirls and moves in and out of phase
column10: voices float by
column11: half memory and half anticipation
column12: and you're never quite sure how all the parts fit together. You get lost in it
column13: and if you're wired a certain way that mixture of desire and confusion is easy to map on to the wider world. For 22 years
column14: the only way to get there was through Loveless and its associated EPs; now there's another path
column15:
one many of us never expected to find. That it's this successful in spite of it all is something we never had a right to expect.

Brainfeeder beat wizard Matthewdavid and his partner
column3: the visual artist Jesselisa Moretti
column4: founded the cassette label Leaving Records in 2009. Since then
column5: they've released everything from freak folk to instrumental hip-hop to free-jazz and psychedelic funk. The pair recently partnered with Stones Throw to release the Dual Form compilation
column6: a set of 19 new tracks that highlights that eclectic Leaving Records vision and also serves as an announcement of an ongoing distribution agreement between the two labels.

column1: While the collection is the perfect primer for Matthewdavid's and Moretti's taste
column2: it's almost impossible to pin down what that taste reveals about the two artists
column3: one of whom is already on a shortlist of the strangest musicians currently working. The Leaving Records vision forms a large umbrella
column4: and most of the music the label releases is abstruse
column5: and difficult to classify.  But the tracks on Dual Form do tend to have some comfortable points of comparison to help listeners get their bearings.

column1: For one thing
column2: most of them contain a loose thread of focus
column3: a core which is surrounded by distracting noise. That noise comes in the form of loose dialogue
column4: in arrhythmic interruptions
column5: anything that your yoga teacher might refer to as ""the distractions of your day."" ""Windy Windy"" by Dntel (aka Jimmy Tamborello
column6: of the Postal Service)
column7: is a perfect example. The track builds off a pleasant little loop
column8: and then totally submerges that loop in a waterfall of ambient noise
column9: before the pattern finally emerges unscathed at the end of the song. Even the most straightforward song on the collection
column10: a kind of gateway drug in the form of Julia Holter covering Arthur Russell
column11: has snippets of dialogue floating through the performance
column12: as if it were a bootleg recording that turned up in somebody's basement
column13: a long-forgotten remnant of some LA newbie's obsessive recording of his first week in the city of angels.

column1: Most of the songs are unsettled
column2: surreal
column3: and distorted
column4: never ugly but never particularly easy to get a solid grasp on
column5: especially given how quickly they flow into one another. Pleasant
column6: off-kilter bass from Liverpool producer the Cyclist on ""Visions"" melts into loose verses from Serengeti whose abstract
column7: hollowed out voice makes perfect sense for a loopy beat from Matthewdavid himself (the duo are identified as Davis
column8: the name of an EP they released together in 2011). From there
column9: we tumble into the minute-long ""Lion's Dream""
column10: another simple loop
column11: this one dwarfed by domino shuffles and replete with rattles and fuzz. Thankfully
column12: there's an internal logic governing these transitions that helps to cushion the shock of diving into a new sound experiment every couple of minutes.

column1: When interviewed Matthewdavid
column2: born Matthew McQueen
column3: tends to couch his preference for offbeat music in spiritual terms. And while sneerers are going to sneer
column4: it's impossible to deny that there is some spirituality to Dual Form. That's partly because the collection jolts you out of everyday listening patterns so effectively; expectations are useless in the midst of an album full of left turns
column5: and the experience puts the willing listener in the most open mindset possible. And it's partly due to the unique beauty of the collection. Anticon co-founder Odd Nodsam's contribution
column6: the stunning ""Sisters""
column7: is all gleaming tones and angelic voices. And ""Peace""
column8: from Muscovite producer Lapti
column9: is aptly named with exceptionally pretty rainbow chords and a friendly shuffling pace.

column1: That open mindset we talked about is necessary for the most outré tracks here. ""Labelle Gross""
column2: provided by the field recording hip-hop instrumentalist Oscar McClure is as disjointed as you might expect those two genres to be when combined and nearly impossible to get your head around. Some of the interruptions on Dem Hunger's ""Glue Suit"" are unpleasantly jarring
column3: similar to the static expulsions on Lou Reed's ""Kicks"" without that calming heroin croon. But in contrast there's a straightforwardness to contributions from Philly beatmaker Knx (formerly Knxledge
column4: whom Dilla heads should be familiar with) and Belgian loopmaster Ssaliva
column5: who somehow manages to effectively deploy bird calls in the midst of an electronic mélange. Perhaps the most enjoyably simple track of all is ""Cooked Love
column6: Lady Bomb""
column7: a slice of sun-ripened funk from the one-man Floridian band
column8: Dream Love.

column1: So what can we tell about Matthewdavid and Moretti from this collection? They are definitely outsiders and they favor their fellows. They are likely both inheritors of the ""freak"" mantle that Hunter S. Thompson assigned to himself and his ilk. And they are probably two of the most open-minded artists you’re going to hear from. Dual Form
column2: might be just too plain weird for many listeners. But for others it should be a worthy exploration
column3: a journey into the curatorial whims of two artists whose tastes
column4: as obscure as they might be
column5: have an undeniable
column6: if indefinable
column7:
cohesion.

""Well

column1: That said
column2: Yellen is kind of the real deal. His past couple of years have been itinerant
column3: dropping out college
column4: having been relieved of both jobs and girlfriends
column5: traveling across the country and eventually writing Country Sleep in a Nashville house once owned by none other than Johnny Cash himself. Dude had to take out some loans to get it done
column6: but I swear
column7: labels should be giving out scholarships for this sort of thing if you've got a voice like Yellen's. The guy is blessed with jump-out-of-the-gym vocal athleticism and throughout Country Sleep
column8: it's unclear whether he's a showoff or if he's still trying to figure out how to corral it. Though there’s a fair share of C&W formalism and cask-aged drawl
column9: Yellen's more of a Buckley or even a Banhart in terms of his ability to work without strcuture. A diva

column1: It's all very disarming and Country Sleep talks a good game and looks the part like the beautiful

column3: rollicking acoustic strums

column9: is the guy singing this song real? I dunno

column11: she sure is pretty.

column1: So yeah

column4: but he's much better playing the softie. While ""Lost Springs"" and ""Was I For You?"" are certainly breakup balm

column6: towards the end of the former

column9: you're probably already inspired to make your next crush playlist

column11: be-quiet-and-drive song at its core

column13: after an untethered falsetto introduces ""Wanted You In August""

column12:
you were sad.

column12: somewhat awkwardly

but Wraetlic is too satisfied with its own dissatisfaction to serve as anything more than comfort food for those predisposed to melancholia.

The anonymity trick may have helped Unknown Mortal Orchestra gain notoriety at the outset
column2: but it soon became the least interesting thing about them. Their self-titled debut was a wonderful record that lived up to the promise of early singles ""Ffunny Ffriends"" and ""How Can U Luv Me"". And the more we got to know Ruban Nielson

column4: opinionated frontman

column6: even rarer in the indie rock realm

Would Nielson devote more attention to his guitar heroism than his songwriting? While there's no need for those two qualities to be in conflict
column8: II eschews the greatness within its grasp whenever it pits them against one another.  The result is a record that's equally remarkable and frustrating
column9: split between incredible pop songs and turgid guitar noodling with very little middle ground.

column1: Let's start with the good stuff
column2: since that's what II does. Within the first four songs
column3: Nielson reiterates what helped Unknown Mortal Orchestra transcend simple time-stamped pastiche: his handsomely scuffed vocals and inventive melodies
column4: and a rhythmic vocabulary that draws equally and naturally from psych rock
column5: hard funk
column6: and soul. It's the work of an assured craftsman with a preferred set of sonic parameters

column8: loose fashion. UMO's lo-fi sizzle and compression gave it the feel of an artifact
column9: a lost treasure transmitted through decades of overdubbed tapes. II isn't a big budget affair
column10: and Nielson still handles everything except the drums. The result is a surprisingly minor but welcome upgrade in fidelity that makes II sound more lived-in than pre-damaged
column11: like a worn pair of jeans or an unmade bed.

column3: Nielson sings on the former
column4: and the latter's chorus serves a suicide metaphor that takes as many odd turns as its backing melody. Even the soulful simmer of ""So Good at Being in Trouble"" doesn't come off as bravado-- not when the attendant lyric is ""so bad at being in love.""

column1: It's an impressive start that heralds a curious bit of sequencing; starting with ""The Opposite of Afternoon""
column2: II places its three longest tracks consecutively in the middle

column4: walking riffs

column8: they constitute the last hook we hear for some time. ""No Need for a Leader"" goes for a brisk
column9: head-down six-minute jog
column10: which at least is preparation for ""Monki""

column1: It's a tough patch to endure

column6: II might come off more scattershot than it really is. In a way

column11: a subtle advance that puts Unknown Mortal Orchestra right back where they started: something of a mystery
column12:
but one that will certainly be interesting going forward.

I never met an Actress track I didn't immediately love until the first time I heard ""Voodoo Posse Chronic Illusion"". Londoner Darren Cunningham has been on an astounding run since his debut
column3: 2008 LP Hazyville

column5: yet somehow retains its transparency by revealing layers upon layers of sound hidden in the crushed frequencies. You have to look for it at first
column6: but even with his most difficult music
column7: somehow you know there's genius lurking underneath. With the Silver Cloud EP
column8: however

column10: digital dust was missing.

column1: Of course
column2: I was wrong. Which I figured out after about 10 listens. But there is something that feels different about the Silver Cloud EP
column3: his first new music since 2012's R.I.P.. That record had a strangely homemade and organic feel to it
column4: like finger-painting with pixels. While Silver Cloud uses the same palette of rainy-day greyscale crackle
column5: the three-track EP sees a return of sorts to beat-oriented material
column6: following R.I.P.'s pastoral landscapes. It also marks a homecoming to Cunningham's own Werk Discs label
column7: having spend time over at Honest Jon's.

column1: The EP starts off with ""Voodoo Posse Chronic Illusion""
column2: one of Actress' longest tracks to date. Its palette is plaintive
column3: but the way it methodically
column4: mindlessly repeats forever with little variation is almost aggressive-- like a particularly hostile staring contest. This dimension feels less friendly than usual
column5: maybe even lazy. But lay on the lapping ebb and you'll be pulled into deep relaxation with every mangled guitar strum; it's lo-fi new age music. You'll hardly even notice the brittle percussion come in and nudge everything along so beautifully and fluidly.

column1: The flipside is even stranger. Much of the talk surrounding the EP-- which was pressed as a sneaky white label before its proper digital release-- was flustered frustration about whether the vinyl rips floating around online were at the correct speed. It's easy to understand the confusion: these two tracks are syrupy slow
column2: mining the same dungeon house territory as Andy Stott's recent work
column3: all demonic vocal samples and engine room churn.

column1: Both tracks are cut from the same cloth
column2: but different in mission. ""Silver Cloud Dream Come True"" is illusory
column3: industrial techno beat thin like malleable metal
column4: marking each bar with a portentous chime. ""Floating in Ecstasy""
column5: meanwhile
column6: is unlike much else in the Cunningham catalog: It's drenched in tape hiss
column7: and the synth noises have more in common with Wolf Eyes than anything else. Here he's taking a rare cue from someone else
column8: the lo-fi house of collectives like L.I.E.S.. It's a move that already suits Cunningham's distinctly decayed
column9: sawn-off palette. Like all three tracks on Silver Cloud
column10: it's unusual and a little more impenetrable than usual. But like Cunningham's entire oeuvre
column11:
each track unwinds into a tapestry of intense sonic detail if you just give it a little time to recline.

When British indie rock revivalists Yuck released their self-titled debut in 2011

column1: Out of View

column4: and appropriates the signature fuzzed-out rock sound of indie rock's golden years in much the same way as bands such as Best Coast and Real Estate recontextualized 60s guitar pop: as a vehicle for yearning for what they perceive to be simpler times. Only those who didn't live through the years documented in Our Band Could be Your Life would mistake them for a sepia-tinged period of innocence and carefree romance

column6: they've become expert at turning out prime indie rock ear candy: Catchy riffs come fast and furiously
column7: and ""Mallory"" is probably the finest example. In just over four minutes
column8: it delivers crunchy
column9: swaggering guitar melodies
column10: big
column11: fat drums that cut through the fog of sugar-coated noise
column12: and Minn's gooey ""oh-oh-oh""s. ""I Want More"" supplements the formula with a swath of drones
column13: ""Long Way to Go"" turns the volume down a fraction

column1: It should probably go without saying that Out of View isn't a terribly deep or meaningful record. Whether the History of Apple Pie retains its charm over the long haul very much remains to be seen. But taken for what it is—a fluffy
column2:

There's no more cliched declaration of vaguely anti-mainstream
column2: middlebrow tastes than someone saying that they listen to ""everything but country."" But the relationship between counterculture and country music used to be quite cozy. Thanks to his influence on the Rolling Stones
column3: Gram Parsons helped turn psychedelic rock fans on to the contemporary country sounds of the time
column4: and country musicians returned the favor by introducing a stoner-friendly grooviness to their sound and image. (Check out Light in the Attic's fantastic compilation
column5: Country Funk 1969-1975
column6: to see how groovy things got.)

column1: Chris Darrow is a product of that union. He was a fixture of the L.A. music scene for years
column2: best known as the co-founder of the psych rock outfit Kaleidoscope
column3: and as an in-demand sideman who played alongside Leonard Cohen
column4: Linda Ronstadt
column5: the Nitty Gritty Dirt Band
column6: and James Taylor. His 1972 solo debut
column7: Artist Proof
column8: is close to the platonic ideal of the California country rock that was being produced at the time.

column1: One of the reasons why is that over its dozen songs (and five bonus demo versions) you can hear pretty much every one of the sound's major touchstones at some point. Gram Parsons' influence looms large
column2: as it did over every commingling of rock and country at the time. Darrow has the same laid back demeanor and enthusiasm for the kind of unabashedly twangy Bakersville country that was more often associated with shitkicking rednecks than longhairs. There's also some of Neil Young's effortlessly beautiful way with a melody
column3: Townes Van Zandt's moodiness
column4: and a funky hippy streak that seems equally indebted to to the Grateful Dead and the Band.

column1: Artist Proof has all of the distinguishing characteristics of a low-key release by a veteran working musician who's outgrown his own dreams of stardom: a backing band made up of other players from the session circuit
column2: efficient and unflashy production
column3: and a tiny initial pressing that seemed to guarantee its future obscurity. But like many such records
column4: the few copies that were pressed were enough to grow a small but devoted cult around them. Luckily the cult has some influence at Drag City
column5: which has earned itself a decent reputation for rescuing private press albums from absolute obscurity.

column1: The difference between Darrow and past acts reissued by the label is that the others have mostly been obscure for justifiable reasons. The world was obviously not ready for a black protopunk band like Death
column2: or an eccentric New Wave performance artist like J.T. IV
column3: and for the most part it still isn't yet. But Artist Proof sounds like it could have been huge. Part of that is the fact that the Eagles used an eerily similar combination of country twang
column4: soft rock
column5: urban counterculture cred
column6: and peaceful
column7: easy feelings to produce one of the highest-selling albums in the history of recorded music. (Their first record came out the same year as Artist Proof.) It also just feels somehow classic.

column1: Darrow's voice was maybe not cut out to sell tens of millions of albums
column2: but his songwriting talents should have elevated him much higher in the music business than he ended up. Listening through Artist Proof
column3: it's hard not to play matchmaker between the songs and the more established and ambitious country artists from the 70s who could (and maybe should) have recorded them. ""Shawnee Moon""
column4: with its juxtaposition of mellow midtempo funkiness and bittersweet melody and lyrics
column5: would have fit in nicely on Emmylou Harris's Quarter Moon in a Ten Cent Town
column6: next to the contributions of era-defining songwriters like Rodney Crowell and Guy and Susanna Clark. The fact that Linda Ronstadt never recorded the gorgeously sad ""Move on Down the Line"" is in itself heartbreaking.

column1: But if the consolation prize is just finally having Darrow's album to listen to
column2: that's perfectly fine. The phrase ""lost classic"" gets attached to inessential reissues with such regularity that it hardly means anything anymore
column3: but Artist Proof genuinely deserves the title. It's deeply satisfying
column4: constantly rewarding
column5:
and I'm not entirely sure what I was doing before it came into my life.

With the third volume of Sonny Smith's 100 Records project
column3: he's once again ditched the Sunsets and inhabited a universe of fictional musicians. He's back as Hank Champion

column3: and I don't play reggae music or whatever

his final 100 Records collection is much stronger than it has any right to be.

For a guy defined by his band's take on ""roots"" music

column6: and throughout

column8: in her words
column9: ""I wanted to try to be a real live person
column10: rather than just singing songs about them."" So she settled in San Francisco. She didn't write much
column11: and instead did some deep thinking about her life's direction. She made an effort to be a part of her community
column12: spending time working with an organization that advocates for prisoners' rights. Then

column1: But on We the Common

column11: she sings later

column1: We the Common's best songs are its most dynamic. ""City"" is driving
column2: percussive
column3: and dotted with distorted guitar riffs that touch down unexpectedly
column4: like lightning bolts. The chaotic and kinetic ""Move"" seems to pick up a few tricks from Nguyen's pal Merrill Garbus of tUnE-yArDs-- lurching at a midtempo stagger that suddenly explodes into one of the record's most satisfying moments
column5: when Nguyen shakes off her composure and screams
column6: ""Oh

column1: And speaking of indie marquee names

she sings in the powerful last seconds of ""City"". ""Start a new year whenever you need.""

column3: always the same. This phrase was used by the late John Peel to describe his favorite band

The instrumental interludes aren't necessarily much to listen to on their own (and Harris' personal stamp on them is not as strong)

an uncanny mixture of wonder and dread that nobody does better.

column1: 0181 as a whole serves as a reminder of the cyclic nature of this kind of instrumental production. Creating the electronic music of the future involves sifting through the past to re-discover sounds. 0181 bring to mind this sort of time-shift not because the sounds within are regressive

The first thing about Amateur Best that hits is his voice; it's down
column2: but not beaten. It's the kind of voice that popstars used to have in the days before AutoTune
column3: perma-grins
column4: and mandatory teeth whitening. Warmly scratchy
column5: it tickles the subconscious as he searches for words
column6: and frays charmingly as he reaches for the big notes. It's a voice that wears its heart on its sleeve; emotions etched in sky-high letters with every breath. While he can't hide the heavy sense of disillusionment that imbues his every note
column7: equally present is an almost child-like stubbornness; a playfully shirty refusal to be engulfed by misery.

column1: London's Joe Flory
column2: the man behind Amateur Best
column3: has been here before. He played the popstar game at major label level as previous incarnation
column4: Primary 1
column5: where his messy
column6: heartfelt songs were shoehorned into pastel-colored pop videos desperate to be hits. The hunger didn't suit his aesthetic or temperament
column7: and he killed off the project almost as soon as he had released his debut album
column8: Other People. I'd interviewed him for Dummy in summer 2009
column9: a few months before its release
column10: and even then reluctance streamed out of his every pore.

column1: A couple of years on
column2: reborn as Amateur Best
column3: Flory has found a home with indie label Double Denim [run by Pitchfork contributor
column4: Hari Ashurst]-- where
column5: one imagines
column6: the pressure and control are flipped to more agreeable levels-- and has made an album that marries hooks and heart to soul-satisfying ends. No Thrills is pop is of the homemade kind
column7: as flagged by the comic
column8: 3D world he painstakingly made and photographed for his album artwork
column9: but it's in no way lo-fi. It's boldly rendered
column10: and somehow crafts a very human world from cartoon sonics. Squeezed synths
column11: squeaky brass
column12: sliding whistles
column13: and pre-set keyboard melodies are all deployed at various points
column14: yet in Flory's hands they assume a peculiar beauty. The forced sunniness of Primary 1 has been shooed away
column15: leaving an acutely refined understanding of the importance of subtlety; how the biggest hooks are not necessarily the loudest
column16: but the ones that keep you waiting.

column1: Opener ""Ready for the Good Life""
column2: featuring Chilly Gonzales on piano
column3: is a perfect case in point. In your memory
column4: it sounds huge
column5: but the reality is much quieter. Flory isn't one to overplay
column6: and it's what he holds back that gives his performance its power and poignancy. The good life
column7: however
column8: is not really any concern of No Thrills. Instead it gently unpicks the delusional idea that a constant state of happiness is possible. Allusions to depression stalk his songs
column9: lurking under the melodies. Over the title track's bubbling percussion he sweetly strains to sing: ""No thrills
column10: no high/ But I was right the first time/ It spills
column11: it chimes/ Brain pain in the family line."" Yet every sour word is wrapped in a sweet note
column12: and every painful revelation coiled in a soaring chorus. No Thrills never wallows but instead finds a joyful rhythm with an everyday battle.

column1: Happy-sad is pop's holy grail: the hooks that lift and the lyrics that burn. In No Thrills' finest moments-- ""Too Much"" with its tortured sax and guitar work that evokes the Cure
column2: the soul-searching ""Be Happy"" and its sad rumba rhythm
column3: the sighing soul of ""Walk In Three""-- No Thrills reaches that grail
column4: triumphantly. While not exactly damp squibs
column5: ""Pleased"" and ""In Time"" don't quite have the force that the rest of the album possesses. Maybe because their self-consciously offbeat bounce could have sat comfortably on Other People
column6:
though part of the lasting pleasure of No Thrills is that Flory has delivered on his early promise. He no longer sounds reluctant at all.

La Big Vic is a New York City trio comprising producer Toshio Masuda
column2: composer and synth-tinkerer Peter Pearson
column3: and singer and violinist (and former Pitchfork contributor) Emilie Friedlander. Their spaced-out 2011 debut
column4: Actually
column5: reliably translated leftfield influences-- new age
column6: dub
column7: early electronic experimentation-- into a more approachable experience. The result was testament to the group's good taste and unconventional leanings (they released an all-dub remix version of it the same year)
column8: if not a little shaky getting on its feet-- groove-friendly
column9: sure
column10: but lacking in quantifiable oomph. But with Cold War La Big Vic make a crucial leap
column11: tightening up what made them unique to offer one of the best outsider pop records of the young year.

column1: You could almost run Actually right into Cold War without batting an eyelash
column2: if it weren't for the fact that they've blown everything widescreen. ""Cold War"" is an affirming opening
column3: and for all its familiar synthetic percolations and winsome
column4: melodic loftiness
column5: there's a serious rhythmic backbone that places its feet firmly on the ground
column6: sounding like something the Chemical Brothers of the late 1990s would kick themselves for not thinking of first. This reinvigorated focus on beats-- trip-hoppy at times
column7: chugging and mechanical at others-- now frames the komische flourishes and prog flirtations in a context that's almost radio-friendly. La Big Vic's third eye still remains firmly intact
column8: but instead of making music built for headphones
column9: Cold War is a record meant to be played out in the open; music that can fill a room and move with the fickle ebb and flow of the people in it
column10: proving delightfully distracting for snatches of time.

column1: This might lead you to believe that La Big Vic are merely jukebox junkies
column2: but these songs are anything but convoluted or over-stuffed. At no point does it feel as if you're listening to the product of messy curation or some soupy free-for-all. Every song here has both intention and decent structure: The addictive ""All That Heaven Allows"" builds itself around a tweaked-out video game synth
column3: yet feels like deeply funky
column4: aqueous lounge music. ""Nuclear Bomb"" is perhaps more Falco than Kraftwerk
column5: but gets its kicks from a giddy rush of glitter punk. ""Save the Ocean"" knocks off Danny Elfman's Pee-wee score in a deliciously demented way
column6: adding a graveyard creep.

column1: There are better songs yet on the record
column2: including ""Emilie Say's""
column3: which showcases Friedlander's vocals nicely; she can wrap a melody around the swirling music in an unexpectedly catchy
column4: chameleonic fashion. The real takeaway is ""catchy
column5: and that this band no longer gets by on feel alone-- just look at highlight ""Ave B""
column6: a slinky late-nighter that will stick in your brain for weeks to come. At a time when anyone with a modem can namecheck and reference weirdos to their heart's content
column7:
La Big Vic are doing the weirdest thing possible for a band of their ilk right now: Playing it straight.

column4: Miles Davis wrote in his autobiography of the live band he led in 1969. With somewhat less panache
column5: Davis completists have pegged the group the Lost Quintet
column6: since
column7: unlike the two longstanding Davis five-pieces that preceded it
column8: this one never made a proper studio recording. All of the members-- saxophonist Wayne Shorter
column9: keyboardist Chick Corea
column10: bassist Dave Holland and drummer Jack DeJohnette-- appear on 1970's landmark Bitches Brew and other scattered sessions from the time
column11: but only as part of larger ensembles; until now
column12: if you wanted to hear them as a stripped-down unit
column13: you had to consult imports
column14: bootlegs and YouTube. This second installment in the Miles Davis Bootleg Series
column15: which follows an excellent 2011 set focusing on the trumpeter's prior working band
column16: gives us three complete Lost Quintet gigs
column17: plus the majority of a fourth
column18: on three CDs and one DVD.

column1: It's a real trove
column2: and not just because this lineup is relatively obscure. In a very clear way
column3: the Lost Quintet is the pivot point between the two main phases of Miles' 40-plus-year career: the acoustic jazz idiom he inhabited
column4: and eventually revolutionized
column5: from the mid-'40s through the late '60s
column6: and the plugged-in ensembles he would lead until his death in 1991. In other words
column7: if you've ever wondered exactly how the dapper jazzman of Kind of Blue morphed into a loudly attired icon in wraparound shades
column8: this set offers some crucial clues. When we last left Miles
column9: on <i>The Bootleg Series
column10: Volume 1
column11: he was leading the world's most advanced and telepathic acoustic jazz group (the so-called Second Great Quintet); by the time of the gigs on Live in Europe 1969
column12: Miles was straddling the fault line. He had already traded acoustic piano for overdriven electric keys and had begun taking rhythmic and textural cues from contemporary funk
column13: but he hadn't yet entered his psychedelic-groove-machine phase in earnest. (For an early taste of the latter
column14: try the 2001 Miles archival release <i><a href=""http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/2197-live-at-the-fillmore-east-march-7-1970-its-about-that-time"" target=""_blank"">Live at the Fillmore East (March 7
column15: 1970): It's About that Time
column16: which features Shorter
column17: Corea
column18: Holland-- who had switched to electric bass in the interim-- and DeJohnette
column19: as well as percussionist Airto Moreira.) Unlike the groups that succeeded it
column20: the Lost Quintet shared a significant portion of its DNA with the acoustic
column21: jazz-centric Miles ensembles that came before.

column1: This is especially apparent on the first two sets here: good-sounding
column2: often-bootlegged performances recorded over successive July nights at the 1969 Juan-les-Pins Jazz Festival in Antibes
column3: France. The scope of these concerts is remarkable. You hear pieces from the yet-unrecorded Bitches Brew (""Spanish Key
column4: ""Miles Runs the Voodoo Down""); a track from the ethereal masterpiece In a Silent Way (""It's About That Time"")
column5: recorded that past February but not yet released; staples of the Second Great Quintet repertoire (including ""Masqualero"" and ""Footprints
column6: both by Shorter
column7: the sole holdover from that band); and themes Miles had favored since the late 50s (""Milestones
column8: ""Round Midnight"")-- all flowing together in the expertly paced suites that were Miles' onstage trademark. But the repertoire is only half of the story; as always with Miles groups
column9: the personnel is the thing. Like the members of the Second Great Quintet
column10: these musicians
column11: aside from the relatively unknown Holland
column12: were already rising or established stars when Miles recruited them. They make for a deadly team
column13: equally at home with low-down groove
column14: in-the-pocket swing and feverish abstraction.

column1: The group displays its raucous intensity right from the start of the first Antibes set. During opener ""Directions
column2: Corea
column3: Holland and DeJohnette send some serious whitewater their boss's way
column4: in the form of a near-chaotic proto-breakbeat. Miles responds with a brief but explosive solo
column5: full of blaring peaks and bravura runs. If drummer Tony Williams was the chief upsetter in the Second Great Quintet-- furnishing near-constant turbulence to the delight of his employer-- the entire rhythm section takes on that role in the Lost Quintet. When Davis isn't playing
column6: they get straight-up Dionysian. The night-two version of ""Miles Runs the Voodoo Down"" starts off as crackling uptempo funk. But following Shorter's solo
column7: Corea and Holland engage in a free-form duel between bleepy keyboard and scratchy bowed bass that rivals Sun Ra's freakiest excursions. Here you can hear Corea-- who has gone on record saying he distrusted the electric piano when Miles first suggested he play it-- forgetting about technique and reveling in an alien sound palette.

column1: The band isn't just about disruption. The versions of familiar pieces like ""Footprints"" and ""Round Midnight
column2: both from from the first Antibes set
column3: feature bashing DeJohnette crescendos and bracingly gritty Shorter solos
column4: but they also demonstrate the band's knack for extraordinarily supple
column5: dynamically controlled swing. A brief Miles/Corea duet on ""I Fall in Love Too Easily
column6: from night two
column7: is another shrewd pace-changer. On <i>The Bootleg Series
column8: Volume 1
column9: Miles and Herbie Hancock introduce this same piece as an unaccompanied duo
column10: but here
column11: Corea's electric piano lends it a newly dreamlike aura. In retrospect
column12: this interlude plays like a stealthy sneak preview of In a Silent Way's proto-ambient brain massage; like the versions of Shorter's ""Sanctuary"" that close each Antibes set
column13: it's part jazz balladry
column14: part immersive soundscape.

column1: The material on disc three
column2: portions of two sets from November 5 in Stockholm
column3: contrasts nicely with the fierce
column4: sprawling Antibes shows. Because of an electric-piano malfunction
column5: Corea plays acoustic piano for most of the first set
column6: a swap that has a major effect on the group dynamic. This performance has its dark
column7: unruly moments
column8: including an early take on the ominous title track of Bitches Brew
column9: recorded that past August but not yet released
column10: but overall
column11: it's a surprisingly tame outing. The version of Shorter's ""Nefertiti"" sounds both elegant and almost quaint
column12: about as close as the Lost Quintet ever came to jazz orthodoxy. The one sample we get of the second Stockholm set offers a tantalizing contrast: a rare take on ""This""
column13: a Corea composition which the pianist had first recorded in May of '69 with a band that included both Holland and DeJohnette. After a brief group theme statement-- with Corea back on electric piano-- the ensemble embarks on a series of atomized improvisations
column14: including a dense Davis/DeJohnette face-off and a pointillist Shorter/Holland/DeJohnette excursion. This single track
column15: possibly the most concentrated example on record of a Miles Davis group playing free jazz
column16: demonstrates how the members of the Lost Quintet spurred the leader toward the avant-garde even as they helped him achieve a deeper engagement with funk and psychedelia.

column1: The DVD
column2: containing a complete Berlin concert from November 7
column3: is essential; the clarity and intimacy of this pristine multicamera document should assure that no one ever again pegs this band as obscure. The in-progress shift in Miles' aesthetic
column4: already apparent in the music
column5: is right there to behold in the men's dress: Whereas the Second Great Quintet always turned up in black tie
column6: the Lost Quintet looks like it's fresh from a Williamsburg vintage shop. (Holland's ensemble—a cow-skin-pattern vest over a purple sweatsuit—is either a facepalmer or a triumph
column7: depending on your tastes.) The band takes a while to warm up here
column8: turning in an unusually subdued ""Directions."" But by a mid-set ""It's About That Time
column9: the feral magic is back; Shorter's brilliantly jittery
column10: speaking-in-tongues soprano solo and a low-volume
column11: high-intensity free-improv duet between Corea and a mallets-wielding DeJohnette make this piece one of the highlights of the entire box set.

column1: Shorter
column2: Corea
column3: Holland and DeJohnette eventually left Miles' band in turn
column4: and Davis began constructing the psych-funk juggernaut heard on records like 1974's aptly titled Dark Magus. As Miles outfitted his trumpet with a wah-wah effect
column5: enlisted a phalanx of guitars and began doubling on organ
column6: the atmosphere thickened and the grooves grew more colossal
column7: but the trumpeter would never again lead a group as thrillingly virtuosic and diabolically mutable as the Lost Quintet. (It's a testament to Miles' eye for talent that Shorter
column8: Corea
column9: Holland and DeJohnette still rank among the most popular and esteemed jazz musicians on earth; Shorter's current working quartet
column10: heard on the new Blue Note release Without a Net
column11: exemplifies a volatility that's directly traceable to the Lost Quintet.) That fact is now duly noted in the official record
column12:
thanks to this set-- a bad motherfucker in its own right.

Alasdair MacLean's unfailingly romantic perspective and vivid imagery alone make for great poetry
column3: and few singers ever achieve as perfect a marriage of content and tone as he did on the Clientele's early records. His voice sounds the way a good memory feels
column4: warm
column5: soft around the edges
column6: lived in
column7: and detailed enough to invite exploration for a while. But those qualities can become a liability for someone trying to live in the present; whenever the Clientele attempted to rock or sound contemporary
column8: he sounded out of his element. With the Clientele on hiatus
column9: his collaboration with Pipas' Lupe Nunez-Fernandez didn't exactly vouch for a change of scenery as the proper remedy; Amor de Días' 2011 debut
column10: Street of the Love of Days
column11: preemptively mitigated expectations with its apologetic presentation
column12: and still managed to underwhelm. Now with The House at Sea legitimizing Amor de Días as a proper band
column13: its predecessor seems a necessary
column14: awkward step in transition. Though The House at Sea still comes off like a travel brochure in audio form
column15: this time MacLean and Nunez-Fernandez at least feel like the people in it rather than those looking at it.

column1: It's a significant improvement on Love of Days
column2: and almost all of it can be chalked up to commitment. Amor de Días' debut was more of a compilation
column3: recorded ""in secret"" over three years with an open-ended personnel

column5: and each of its 12 songs feels finished and fussed over. While still mostly based in decidedly non-rock forms such as bossa nova and English and Spanish pastoral folk
column6: the songs are considerably more defined-- certain parts even come close to rocking
column7: such as Nunez-Fernandez's surprisingly fleet-footed ""Day"" and the frisky
column8: nylon-guitar thrum powering ""In the Winter Sun"". Within this context
column9: a three-chord British Invasion throwback (""Jean's Waving) that could fit on the Clientele's later
column10: more extroverted records has an immediacy that sounds completely out of place on The House at Sea.

column1: More typical are the magic hour lullabies in both native tongues (and even if you haven't taken Spanish since high school
column2: you can follow ""Viento del Mar"" or ""Piedras Rotas"" fairly easily) and they're certainly lovely if not a little lyrically lightweight. And while MacLean has tried to slip spoken word into Clientele albums with varying degrees of success
column3: ""The Sunlit Estate"" and ""Maureen"" are free-form pieces that function better within Amor de Días' looser artistic restrictions. Centerpiece ""Viento del Mar"" hinges on a bold major chord change
column4: and
column5: combined with a sinister
column6: wandering bassline and Nunez-Fernandez's nearly subliminal vocals
column7: it's basically a shoegaze song (something along the lines of Serena-Maneesh) relieved of its distortion and reverb
column8: at least until a coda of surprisingly doomy guitar soloing appears.

column1: That said
column2: even with the bolstered band interplay
column3: every instrument feels like it's being massaged rather than strummed
column4: plucked
column5: or hit-- MacLean's voice barely gets above a whisper
column6: Nunez-Fernandez repeats little more than the titles of ""Day"" and ""In The Winter Sun"" like she's breathing these compositions into life
column7: and
column8: whatever texture you might get from individual cymbal crashes or a guitar distortions
column9: the whole eventually becomes as gritty as a white sand beach. The House at Sea was inspired by time spent in both London and Madrid
column10: and most of the vocals are given to MacLean
column11: but it's still more far more Mediterranean in pace and climate. For the most part
column12: it's ""yacht rock"" in the sense that The House at Sea actually makes you feel like you're on a yacht (or catamaran) as opposed to imagining a coked-out
column13: bearded millionaire in his studio.

column1: Even if Amor de Días stands to become MacLean's main focus instead of a side project
column2: he still gets to play the tourist
column3: enviably relaxed and ultimately giving himself a break from the hard work. This inherently limits the overall effect: Clientele songs distinguished themselves from the scores of other nostalgists through their awareness of place
column4: of seeing things a casual onlooker might not
column5: or they found new ways to express the mundane. The House at Sea begins with a classic MacLean-ism (""The streets in June/ The silver moon/ Like paint on glass"")
column6: and from there onward
column7: he's not an expert on his surroundings
column8: just someone taking it all in. While the best work of the Clientele created worlds
column9: The House at Sea charmingly aspires to being a photo album
column10:
something to inspire your own travels rather than serve as a substitute for them.

column7: the Peaches' bizarro anti-folk

column2: laidback one-offs never amount to much more than just that

column1: In fact

column8: they also seem like two people who've known each other for ages

column10: ""It's kind of like reading your diary out loud to somebody."" It's lucky that she gave Green the key to it.

column1: Yet as good as Green and Shapiro are as foils-- between her vocals once described here as being ""like summer wine"" and his urban cowboy baritone-- it's really Shapiro's show: All the aforementioned songs feature only Shapiro's voice

you're finding yourself wishing they'd just knock off the goddamn charade and kiss already.

Like a lot of stories of scandal
column2: ruin
column3: and the opportunity for redemption
column4: it started with a pretty face. In the spring of 1964
column5: 17-year old Marianne Faithfull walked into a swinging
column6: star-studded London party and landed a record deal without singing a note; Andrew Loog Oldham
column7: the Rolling Stones manager and world-class sleazeball
column8: famously summed up the matter with his usual showbiz aplomb: ""I saw an angel with big tits and signed her."" Within the year
column9: the bookish baroness' daughter was climbing the charts and making the rounds at concert halls and the BBC
column10: thrust into a pop career she didn't much want in the first place. (""For one brief
column11: blissful moment I thought I saw a way out of my pop nightmare
column12: she wrote three decades later in her autobiography
column13: Faithfull
column14: which is every bit as insightful
column15: vivid
column16: and deliciously bonkers as Keith Richards' Life.) Faithfull was a passable vocalist with a folksy
column17: melancholy
column18: relatively generic lilt
column19: but there was a certain vacancy and listlessness about her that suggested she'd not yet become comfortable in her skin. If you watch some of her earliest performances on YouTube
column20: she has a way of making Lana Del Rey look present.

column1: Faithfull started dating Mick Jagger in 1966
column2: and her 60s output is generally only discussed in terms of how it relates to that of the Stones: ""As Tears Go By"" is more famous for being the first song Mick and Keith wrote together than for being Faithfull's debut single. On the personal front
column3: though
column4: the opposite was true: Notoriety had a way of sliding off the boys and sticking to Faithfull. After the infamous Redlands drug bust
column5: the press dubbed her ""Miss X"" and
column6: a bit more personably
column7: ""The Girl in the Fur Rug."" (""SCANTILY CLAD WOMAN AT DRUG PARTY"" screamed one representative headline.) To those closer to the Stones' circle
column8: she was The Muse-- though by her account
column9: her relationship with Jagger was a pretty mutual exchange of ideas
column10: old records
column11: and hallucinogens. Ever the avid reader
column12: a little while prior to the Beggar's Banquet sessions
column13: Faithfull handed him The Master and Margarita and suggested that this Lucifer guy might make for a good character in a song. She wrote the lyrics to ""Sister Morphine""
column14: and cut a shudderingly melancholy version that makes the Stones' take almost seem like a romp. This was maybe the first big
column15: public hint that Miss X knew more about pain and suffering than a lot of people wanted to assume. When she slipped into the coma that almost killed her-- the result of taking 150 Tuinals in a hotel room in Australia-- she had a vision that Brian Jones
column16: just six days in the ground
column17: was beckoning her over a cliff. He leapt; at the last minute she decided to stay. When she opened her eyes in a hospital room six days later
column18: Mick said
column19: ""Marianne
column20: we thought we'd lost you."" In that milky voice that was already starting to curdle
column21: the first thing she said to him was

column1: That's the thing about pretty faces. We'd much prefer to watch them wilt. We don't expect them to belong to the fighters-- the junkies and monks and cockroaches who'll survive every atomic bomb and suicide attempt and outlive us all. And we definitely don't expect them to make songs as gnarled and candid as the ones on Faithfull's finest record
column2: Broken English
column3: but there you go: the best records are all
column4: in some way or another
column5: the ones that blow a mouthful of smoke in the face of expectation. The world that thought it had tsk-tsked Miss X into submission was probably not ready for Broken English in 1979
column6: and even today as it's released in a deluxe edition
column7: it's still raw enough to make you squirm-- the cracked
column8: undead voice of a woman back from exile to make a record about the simple audacity of staying alive.

column1: If you know one thing about Broken English
column2: you probably know that Faithfull was living on the streets right before she made it. And unlike the Mars Bar myth (now thoroughly debunked by Faithfull
column3: Keith Richards
column4: and an honest-to-goodness policeman)
column5: this checks out. Broke
column6: heroin-dependent
column7: and (it seemed) professionally washed up
column8: Faithfull spent the better part of two years living in a roofless pile of rubble in Soho
column9: a bombed-out ruin of the Blitz. She was squatting with her then-husband Ben Brierley (of British punks the Vibrators) and riding the unexpected success of her forlorn ballad
column10: ""Dreamin' My Dreams"" (a dud at home but a surprise hit in politically tumultuous Ireland
column11: where
column13: ""forlorn"" was the mood of the hour) when somebody at her label rather improbably gave her the money to cut another record.

column1: The resulting album feels so intimate and personal that it's easy to overstate its singularity. But Broken English is more than just a portrait of the addict as a middle-aged woman; it captures an entire generation's disillusioned comedown. ""The days of mind-opening drugs were over
column2: Faithfull writes in her autobiography
column3: reflecting on the spiritual climate of the mid-70s. ""The world had tilted. A major change in key had taken place. It was a Mahler symphony whirling madly out of control."" And that's the key in which these songs were written and recorded. Much in the way the Stones did in the late 60s
column4: Broken English taps into a collective consciousness. The new-wave-tinged title track evokes the anxious
column5: prickling paranoia of the Cold War
column6: a chillingly grim cover of ""Working Class Hero"" longs for the counterculture's idealistic faith in individuality
column7: and the excellent ""Brain Drain"" (""Got so much to offer/ But I can't pay the rent/ I can't buy you roses 'cause the money's all spent"") captures the hopelessness of the junkie's lifestyle. A rapidly deteriorating Tim Hardin co-wrote the lyrics on that last one with Faithfull and Brierley on a debauched trip to Antigua. Both implicitly and explicitly
column8: it's a ballad of wasted genius. It's one of the last songs to bear Hardin's name-- he was dead of an overdose a little over a year after the record came out.

column1: After dabbling in baroque pop and country
column2: Faithfull drew fresh inspiration from the Sex Pistols and Brierley's clan in the late 70s
column3: but Broken English is a punk record more in spirit than in sound. (It doesn't sound much like any of her subsequent records either; afterwards
column4: she moved towards the Weill-meets-Tom-Waits-in-a-dank-cabaret sound of the excellent Strange Weather.) Stylistically
column5: Broken English is a fusion of new wave
column6: blues
column7: reggae
column8: and pop
column9: created by a backing band talented enough to genre-hop deftly. Guitarist Barry Reynolds adds a particularly distinct flair to the record; on the incendiary ""Why  D'ya Do It""
column10: his barbed
column11: sneering riff is the perfect match for Faithfull's legendary performance. Easily one of the best songs in her repertoire
column12: ""Why  D'ya Do It"" is also probably the most controversial-- a Heathcote Williams-penned
column13: unfiltered torrent of lovers' rage scattered liberally but purposefully with a few words that still have the power to shock.

column1: Broken English's most affecting moment is Faithfull's spellbinding rendition of Shel Silverstein's ""The Ballad of Lucy Jordan""
column2: a song about a bored housewife dreaming of the exhilarating life and ""thousand lovers"" she never had
column3: slowly going mad. Obviously
column4: it's far from autobiography
column5: but when you know Faithfull's history (a veritable primer on the pitfalls of an exhilarating life)
column6: the subtext becomes almost unbearably poignant. ""Lucy Jordan is me if my life had take a different turn
column7: she has <a href=""http://books.google.co.uk/books?id=7mLhnEEXD9AC&pg=PA237&lpg=PA237&dq=%22Lucy+Jordan+is+me+if+my+life+had+taken+a+different+turn
column8: %22&source=bl&ots=UKr5dOKoFB&sig=PP69iGBPFTUUuU79L4tCUr7HPT4&hl=en&sa=X&ei=99IHUf7KNs6R0QWLoYD4Aw&ved=0CDsQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=%22Lucy%20Jordan%20is%20me%20if%20my%20life%20had%20taken%20a%20different%20turn%2C%22&f=false"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">said. ""It's a song of identification with women who are trapped in that life and the true private horror of the 'good life.'"" But the pain in her fractured voice tells a more complicated story
column9: pointing towards the classic catch-22 that still plagues famous and unfamous women alike: The world will size you up and make you choose one of two roles
column10: Miss X or Lucy Jordan. And the worst of it
column11: Faithfull is saying in this evocative performance
column12: is that the dreamy conjectures about what your life would have been had you chosen differently will not only prove incessant
column13: they might actually drive you crazy.

column1: The bonus material on this deluxe edition of Broken English doesn't add too much to the experience. With only one exception (""Sister Morphine"")
column2: the extra disc is all alternate mixes and extended cuts of the songs that made the record. If anything
column3: the remixes' noodly accoutrements will make you appreciate the record's purposeful minimalism anew. In almost every case
column4: wisely
column5: producer Mark Miller Mundy and engineer Bob Potter let the unvarnished power of Faithfull's voice carry these songs. The deluxe edition also includes the great experimental filmmaker Derek Jarman's early music videos for ""Broken English""
column6: ""Witches Song""
column7: and ""Lucy Jordan""
column8: but if you can make peace with the low quality you could have watched these on YouTube years ago. This particular re-release of Broken English isn't notable because of any new insight it brings to the listening experience
column9: but for the simple fact that it might bring some new fans to an enduringly great record.

column1: Faithfull has been clean for a while now
column2: but she still speaks freely and unapologetically about the experiences that lead her to making this record. Last week I was listening to an interview with her that I assumed was current
column3: done in promotion of the deluxe edition. I didn't realize it was a few years old until she started talking about Amy Winehouse hopefully and in the present tense. ""She's young
column4: she's rich
column5: she feels absolutely immortal
column6: Faithfull said
column7: with obvious empathy. ""They judge her [harshly]... but she's going to get through it all
column8: I know it."" Feeling a little haunted after hearing this
column9: I put on Broken English immediately
column10: and its sheer power and purpose had never felt more obvious. This record documents a particular shade of darkness not everybody lives to describe. Like Faithfull identifying with her opposite in Lucy Jordan
column11: Broken English is an almost otherworldly communion with the other side; it's a record for the Joneses and the Hardins and the Winehouses and all the other voices that the wild horses dragged away before they could say anything this honest about their pain. Aching and defiantly alive
column12:
it still bleeds like it was cut yesterday.
