Of all the 1990s indie and alt.rock bands that have returned from the dead in recent years
column3: has anyone come back as totally as Guided by Voices? Robert Pollard's decision to re-assemble GBV's ""classic"" line-up had obvious nostalgic appeal as a touring unit
column4: though hardcore fans were also delighted by the likeably haphazard bag full of rotten cabbage and cotton candy that was 2012's Let's Go Eat the Factory. After that
column5: the ""for old times sake"" itch was probably scratched for most people
column6: but GBV went ahead anyway and put out two more classically overstuffed LPs
column7: Class Clown Spots a UFO and The Bears for Lunch. Now comes a new EP
column8: Down by the Racetrack
column9: ahead of another LP
column10: English Little League
column11: due later this year.

column1: Robert Pollard releases a shit-load of albums every year-- what else is new? For one thing
column2: this version of GBV was and is a real band
column3: not just backing musicians dotting the galaxy of Pollard's solo projects. The distinction matters: GBV's 2012 trilogy looked and felt like the albums churned out by this line-up in the mid-90s-- albeit with a slightly worse batting average-- with a wealth of spontaneously produced gems and freeform noisy weirdness. This has long been Pollard's formula
column4: though the racket kicked up on those records unmistakably belongs to this specific set of musicians
column5: and not just because there's a Tobin Sprout vocal on every fifth track. (Though that's a big help.) GBV's recent output has an underappreciated craft and logic to it: Even the draggy
column6: thinking-out-loud dead spots suddenly snap into coherence after three listens in ways Pollard's solo work often doesn't.

column1: Anyone familiar with Guided by Voices' vast discography knows what to expect from Down by the Racetrack before hearing it: EPs have been a familiar oasis for GBV in the months (or weeks) that stretch between albums
column2: providing a forum for songs that are too bizarre or extemporaneous even by this band's shaggy-dog standards. And Down by the Racetrack pretty much is that. ""It Travels Faster Through Thin Hair"" is one of those Robert Pollard compositions that sounds like it was written two minutes before they hit the ""record"" button. Pollard's vocal and guitar spend a good 20 seconds trying to find a melody
column3: but once a twangy guitar materializes to act as a guide
column4: he's magically unearthed it
column5: if only for another 20 seconds. ""Pictures of the Man"" sets an atonal 154 guitar riff and ghostly monk chants on a bloody collision course. ""Standing in a Puddle of Flesh"" is the mandated-by-GBV-law Genesis tribute
column6: though the perverse piano riff calls back to ""Always Crush Me"" from Alien Lanes. The title track is the closest thing Racetrack has to a ""Shocker in Gloomtown"" or ""Dusted""
column7: with its magnificent glam-rock riff and Sprout's uncharacteristically commanding vocal.

column1: By virtue of being an EP arriving in the midst of so many other GBV releases
column2: Down by the Racetrack is likely to be overlooked. But for anyone curious about the viability of GBV's revived recording career and unsure of where to begin
column3: Racetrack arguably offers the best introduction. GBV is clearly past the the ""cash-in"" portion of its reunion; Racetrack
column4: like the other recent releases
column5: showcases a band that has fully re-connected with its binge-and-purge creative process
column6: and is back to producing found-object pop and hook-laden doodles at a prodigious clip. Racetrack has all of the mess
column7: melody
column8: magic
column9: and mania of the other records
column10: but in a smaller
column11: more bite-sized
column12:
but nonetheless pleasingly indulgent package.

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/18837/homepage_large.93355134.jpg|A Breathtaking Trip to That Otherside|30973.0|Alexander Spit|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Decon']|2013-01-30 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 17:02:21.617205|"

Who the fuck is Alexander Spit
column2: and why is his name ""Alexander Spit""? These are reasonable questions. Spit
column3: real name Alexander Manzano
column4: is a subterranean sort
column5: and the world hasn't been given many chances to know him. A gaunt
column6: intense
column7: hermetic 25-year old Filipino kid operating on the fringes of the L.A. hip-hop scene
column8: he raps in a pneumatic
column9: plugged-up bleat
column10: and his self-produced music feels emitted from somewhere dank and lightless-- not L.A
column11: in other words
column12: nor the intensely communal North Bay Area in which he was originally raised. A Breathtaking Trip is his first commercial release
column13: and its a curious mixture of West Coast rap signifiers and bad drugs horror core impulses: ""This ain't that Acura
column14: this the Dragula""
column15: he raps on ""Ride"". In other words: He rides
column16: just like any other California rap citizen
column17: he just chooses to do so in a Rob Zombie-piloted dune buggy. His rap name
column18: maybe the most unimaginatively descriptive handle since Black Rob
column19: is the least inspired thing about him.

column1: What immediately separates Spit's first official release from the legions of self-styled outsider auteurs rapping to themselves on Bandcamp is his touch as a producer. A Breathtaking Trip is a sullen
column2: antisocial record
column3: but Spit makes being a loner feel like a positively sensual experience. His bleak
column4: smeary sound draws from the murkier corners of the L.A. beat scene-- it's easy to imagine him rapping over a track by
column5: say
column6: Nosaj Thing-- and the dour gloom of London bass. If there is any connection to Bay Area rap sounds
column7: they poke through submerged: The clicks and pops of ""Death by 27"" sound more at home next to Autechre than E-40
column8: but miles above the track's bottom end
column9: a ghost of a G-funk synth floats. ""Coastal/Hyperion"" bumps like vintage DJ Quik until the synths start glowing like alien spores.

column1: Breathtaking Trip is an immersive listen with lots of small details like this waiting to be noticed. Experienced through a fat pair of headphones
column2: it feels like dunking your head into a dark barrel of water. The stuttering drum roll of ""That's Spit / Space Echoes"" disappears into vapors and traces with nothing but a cavernous
column3: watery dub pulse marking time. ""Artesia"" feeds a house diva vocal snippet through a Cuisinart. Spit often treats his vocals with Witness Protection Program-style processing that might remind Odd Future fans of Tyler
column4: the Creator
column5: but his thick double-time flow
column6: sunk all the way to the ocean floor of the mix
column7: recalls Houston depressive
column8: Trae.

column1: Like a lot of rap's tenacious outsiders
column2: Spit takes a few moments to telegraph his outsized love of the culture: ""I used to freestyle for hours on my way home/ My first beats
column3: they were dialed in on a pay phone
column4: he raps on ""GREAT SCOTT!!!"". His most compelling lyrics are druggier and less concrete
column5: though
column6: flashing in on a striking
column7: retina-singeing image: ""Skyline look like my name in cursive while I'm getting brain
column8: he raps on ""Pulp 2013/Heroin Chic""
column9: while on ""Black Magic on Blue Magic""
column10: he imagines ""clear skies without chemtrails"" and ""skylines without drones.""

column1: Still
column2: Spit's writing doesn't always measure up to the hallucinatory atmosphere of his music-- some of his lines fall flat (""Peep my catalogue
column3: my bars got that glory""). When he enlists some higher-profile guests-- E-40 and Mr. Muthafuckin' Exquire on ""B.N.E.
column4: Action Bronson
column5: playing Russian Roulette
column6: eating sturgeon
column7: and bumping Oakland veteran Joe Blow on ""Artesia""-- they pull too much spotlight too easily. But A Breathtaking Trip to That Otherside is Spit's first full release
column8:
and it hints at some great things. A new weirdo is never unwelcome in rap.

"|17637.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/17637-a-breathtaking-trip-to-that-otherside/|7.2|Jayson Greene

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/18854/homepage_large.ffa8a666.jpg|Tastes the Broom|31023.0|Happy Jawbone Family Band|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Mexican Summer']|2013-01-30 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 17:02:22.284827|"

There's been no shortage of endearingly sloppy
column2: blues-inflected garage rock in recent years
column3: but Brattleboro
column4: Vt.'s Happy Jawbone Family Band uses the template to create its own mythical world. Since 2009
column5: the band has remained blissfully off-grid
column6: recording hundreds of songs over several tapes and full-lengths for similarly homegrown labels like Spooky Town Artifacts
column7: Feeding Tube
column8: and Night People
column9: which makes their next release feel like a move into the spotlight: it's being recorded with Jarvis Taverniere of Woods
column10: and is set for release on Mexican Summer later this year. For context
column11: the label is prepping for the forthcoming LP with this retrospective compilation
column12: which might seem premature if the songs weren't so strong.

column1: The collection opens with ""Now Everybody Rock Like You Got AIDS""
column2: a track from their 2009 album Family Matters-- one of two 40-track cassettes they released that year. The song is an explosive
column3: excessively distorted shout-along that brings to mind the blown-out sound of Siltbreeze acts like Times New Viking and Eat Skull
column4: or the proudly out-of-tune punk rock of Half Japanese. But unlike those bands
column5: Happy Jawbone's members sing with more of a whimsical
column6: childlike disposition
column7: an eerie aesthetic given the title and the chorus. It works as an introduction to the way their songs often juxtapose youthful innocence with dark realities of life and death (according to the band
column8: it was written while members were studying at Naropa University's Jack Kerouac School of Disembodied Poetics and alludes to how ""the ghosts of that epidemic walk freely around the campus""). Continuing the thread is""Fireflies Made Out of Dust""
column9: a crackly
column10: off-kilter gem that sounds like each player is learning the song as they go along
column11: screeching the blues in childish voices: ""You drew an airplane flying through my head/ I might as well be dead.""

column1: The world of Happy Jawbone is shaded by absurdist comedy
column2: especially in the way their songs are are so self-referential
column3: recycling and re-contextualizing their own lyrics
column4: melodies
column5: song titles
column6: and motifs from record to record: fires
column7: broken glass
column8: butter
column9: and bugs
column10: particularly fireflies
column11: are all popular song topics. Halfway through Family Matters
column12: there's a wacky aside in ""The Album So Far...""
column13: which takes the first half of the tape and compacts it into the length of a single track; to date
column14: they've recorded three variations on ""At the Hotel Double Tragedy""-- the version here sounds cartoonish and toy-like.

column1: Happy Jawbone's disturbed take on whimsy and rebellious
column2: youthful spirit recalls lo-fi stables
column3: Elephant 6 and K Records: The alien-sounding ""Martian Santa"" comes from a Christmas album they released in 2011
column4: and brings to mind the way the Music Tapes treat holiday tunes; the record's final song
column5: the six-minute ""Don't Tread on the Museums of Your Youth""
column6: reads like a poetic distillation of all this band's complex ways of dealing with nostalgia and childhood. But Happy Jawbone have their own thing going on
column7: thanks all the same: Like Olympia
column8: Brattleboro is a small town where a regional sound and tiny but fruitful community of experimenters (Blanche Blanche Blanche
column9: the Great Valley
column10: Chris Weisman) exist outside of the big city glare and sheen. On Tastes the Broom
column11: Happy Jawbone Family Band celebrate the value of lo-fi as an act of direct resistance to the toxic gloss of professionalism
column12:
making a persuasive statement in defense of wide-eyed amateurism in the process.

"|17655.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/17655-tastes-the-broom/|7.6|Liz Pelly

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/18793/homepage_large.6f1bfae9.jpg|Soft Opening|30906.0|Pearl Necklace|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Smalltown Supersound']|2013-01-30 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 17:02:22.915792|"

It's probably with good reason that you don't see a lot of features on minimal electronic albums. For music that thrives on subtlety and nuance
column2: too many cooks in the kitchen can often muddle what otherwise requires just clarity and finesse. So it's with skepticism that we approach Brooklyn's Bryce Hackford and Frank Lyon
column3: who record little assemblages of synthesizer
column4: field recordings
column5: and loops
column6: almost all of questionable fidelity
column7: as Pearl Necklace. After hearing the pair's music
column8: Alexis Georgopoulos (better know as electronic composer
column9: Arp) linked the pair up with the revered Norwegian label
column10: Smalltown Supersound. He shows up on almost half of the songs on Pearl Necklace's debut LP
column11: Soft Opening. MGMT vocalist Andrew VanWyngarden drops in on organ for the record's closing track. It's clear that Pearl Necklace aren't particularly interested in playing by the rules
column12: instead opting to pick and choose from samples ranging from obscure and murky to spin-drunk to nearly invisible. Weirdly enough
column13: Soft Opening maintains a sort of oddball consistency in this regard
column14: but is ultimately so aimless
column15: messy
column16: and at times beyond tedious
column17: it hardly matters how many hands were in its pot.

column1: Soft Opening's sketch-like quality practically writes its own ""How many unfathomably stoned 20-somethings does it take to screw in an MPC?"" joke. The eyelid movies Pearl Necklace are trying to conjure may certainly be stranger than any lifeless cinematic fare you're likely to enjoy in the next month
column2: but they often register just as flat and lazily conceived. It quickly becomes apparent that Soft Opening was recorded over the span of a very ""relaxed"" year: These quirky
column3: disjointed little blueprints often begin in the middle of nowhere and end up right back where they started
column4: their heavy reliance on a smattering of barely-there samples fostering an organic vibe
column5: yet certainly not one of this planet. ""Why Toto?"" uses bleary synth stabs like a repurposing of the first contact in Close Encounters of the Third Kind
column6: had said aliens been seriously wasted and spilled space beer into the PA system. Moments like these might clue you into a sense of humor itching under Soft Opening's skin (though coming from a band called Pearl Necklace
column7: humor is kind of relative)
column8: but its foggy construction and dawdling pace just points you back in the direction of weird for weirdness' sake.

column1: If Pearl Necklace are aping any weirdos here
column2: they've made a few wise choices. The fluorescent nacho cheese smear of ""Radio Love"" sounds reminiscent of Ariel Pink
column3: while a handful of tracks owe a good deal to Sun Araw. With a bit more time
column4: care
column5: and ambition
column6: portions of Soft Opening could have really come to life. ""Doorbell"" has a definable Zissou-like charm
column7: but is marred by a mess of clattering distractions that don't afford the song any sort of rhythmic or textural favors. There's a similar likability at work in the groove-forward ""Ah Ah""
column8: but instead of wriggling its way into your brain as intended
column9: the foundationless repetition begins to feel like water torture. These songs hint at a necessary tension
column10: but more often than not
column11: the defining details come off as obstructions.

column1: There's great potential appeal in how shaded and cheekily unaware of themselves these songs are
column2: however. If Arp has inspired anything in these two newcomers
column3: it's the idea that you can still say a great deal using only the simplest of terms. What he forgot to convey was that simple doesn't have to mean half-hearted or uninvested
column4: which is the nagging problem at Soft Opening's center. Maybe Pearl Necklace is slowly defining its own set of motions
column5: but it's hard to deny that they're not just going through them here. As on ""Pearlfriend""
column6: which sounds like a dispatch from the world's loneliest echo-locator
column7:
Pearl Necklace are never far from finding something interesting as a result of their machines' unreliable wirings. But what Soft Opening could really benefit from is a good old fashioned jump start.

"|17600.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/17600-soft-opening/|5.6|Zach Kelly

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/18732/homepage_large.74d6a8c8.jpg|The Flower Lane|27801.0|Ducktails|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Domino']|2013-01-29 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 17:02:24.571919|"

Until recently
column2: Matthew Mondanile seemed to regard Ducktails as the lackadaisical counterpart to his other
column3: better known band
column4: Real Estate. The first two Ducktails LPs were cozy
column5: blithely executed indie rock comfort food that occasionally coalesced into semi-structured songs. With 2011's Ducktails III: Arcade Dynamics
column6: Mondanile tightened up and offered a tuneful (but still slight) precursor to the sublime guitar pop of Real Estate's Days. The Flower Lane is the latest progression for what now resembles a fully fledged group. Mondanile's hasn't tempered the echoes of his other band in Ducktails
column7: but he isn't confined to Real Estate's shadow
column8: either.

column1: The presence of New Jersey power-poppers and Real Estate tourmates Big Troubles helps to give the record a wider musical vocabulary than Mondanile's previous (and mostly solo) Ducktails efforts. After the Days-like cathedral of luminously chiming guitars that heralds the opening track ""Ivy Covered House
column2: Mondanile settles into a warmly melancholy vein of jazzy
column3: fractured pop songs. At times
column4: it's as if he's paying homage to Kaputt and that record's gauche elegance: The soft-rock keyboard accents and head-swimming horns of ""Under Cover"" represent a level of musical sophistication that Mondanile hasn't attempted before on a Ducktails record. The title tracks cuts the blurry
column5: VHS tape-quality of past Ducktails efforts with a rainy day Steely Dan electric piano lick that clarifies and underlines the song's gently serrated hook. The lysergic pop of ""Timothy Shy"" culminates with a fiery guitar solo that burns through Mondanile's normally narcotized façade. Taken together
column6: these subtle yet unmistakable upgrades to Ducktails' gauzy instrumentation immediately command attention
column7: where the records before The Flower Lane were content to lay indifferently outside of it.

column1: Some of the best moments on The Flower Lane occur when Mondanile steps aside and plays musical director for his cast of guest stars. He's especially deft at utilizing female voices
column2: which offer a colorful contrast to his flat
column3: expressionless murmur. ""Sedan Magic"" stumbles over an erratic R&B rhythm on the Mondanile-sung verses
column4: and then zooms to the stratosphere whenever Madeline Follin of Cults takes over on the grabby chorus. Mondanile hands the album's best track
column5: the dreamy love song
column6: ""Letter of Intent""
column7: to Future Shuttle's Jessa Farkas and Big Troubles' Ian Drennan
column8: and the result is a sexy
column9: shy-eyed snuggle jam aided by Oneohtrix Point Never's Daniel Lopatin on synths and his Ford & Lopatin collaborator Joel Ford on bass.

column1: The relatively sumptuous presentation of The Flower Lane successfully separates it from the rest of Ducktails' discography. Unfortunately
column2: a familiar emptiness remains. With Days
column3: Real Estate mined a potent strain of nostalgic ache
column4: giving the songs an emotional thoroughfare that tied the record together into a unified statement. The Flower Lane approaches the musical eloquence of Days
column5: but Mondanile's mind and his soul still don't seem to be in the same place.

column1: Get past the beauty of these songs and what's left is a frustrating lack of substantive sentiment: The gurgly funk of ""Assistant Director"" and the glistening
column2: electro-folk ballad ""Academy Avenue"" speak to Mondanile's ability to churn out easily chewable ear candy. But nothing here lingers
column3: and after a while Mondanile's attachment to the pleasantly ephemeral starts to feel like a dodge. The only lyric that sticks
column4: tellingly
column5:
comes from of a cover of Peter Gutteridge's ""Planet Phrom"": ""I'm moving in a haze all day and I've got a cloudy mind."" Mondanile has cleared his mind on The Flower Lane; now he just needs to open his heart.

"|17538.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/17538-the-flower-lane/|7.1|Steven Hyden

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/18853/homepage_large.a3862a82.jpg|Lost Jewlry|3634.0|Raekwon|['Rap']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Ice H2O']|2013-01-29 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 17:02:25.297762|"

After a universally acclaimed debut album and a lengthy period of career doldrums
column2: Raekwon is enjoying a critical renaissance almost wholly predicated on his decision to play squarely into the expectations of his fans. Only Built 4 Cuban Linx... Pt. 2 and Shaolin Vs. Wu-Tang were a pair of traditionalist correctives that established him as the reigning torchbearer for the kung-fu-and-rare-grooves ethos that vaulted the Wu-Tang Clan into prominence 20 years ago. Rae's latest albums have been stellar
column3: but the spattering of interstitial mixtapes he's released as supplements punctuate just how many swings it takes to score a run like Cuban Linx 2's ""Surgical Gloves"". Rae has described his Lost Jewlry EP
column4: a collection of recent unreleased tracks not being used for his next album
column5: F.I.L.A. (Fly International Luxurious Art)
column6: as having the spirit of Nas' The Lost Tapes. Unlike the Nas compilation
column7: which housed a number of songs very much deserving of placement on the albums that left them behind<i>
column8: Lost Jewlry occasionally feels like a dumpster dive.

column1: A closer parallel from Raekwon' own discography would be Wu-Massacre
column2: his 2010 one-off with Method Man and Ghostface Killah. Wu-Massacre was both hastily conceived and frustratingly short
column3: and Lost Jewlry's brevity is similarly exacerbated by a dearth of fresh ideas. The EP leads with a round of lazily executed mafioso rap boilerplate. On ""Prince of Thieves""
column4: Rae lets go of a clever line about ""Rondos with condos"" but wastes the rest of the song on empty rich guy platitudes
column5: his vocals lagging embarrassingly behind the beat. He changes gears for the ballad ""Hold You Down""
column6: but an emotionally vacant Faith Evans
column7: uncharacteristically standard issue production from Buckwild
column8: and a volley of lyrical clunkers like ""Come here
column9: young lady with the skin of a baby"" and ""No I'm not racial
column10: I'm pro-black” collude to wreck the song. The first 10 of Lost Jewlry's 30 minutes are a total bore.

column1: When Rae applies himself
column2: he's unflappable
column3: though
column4: and Lost Jewlry's mid-section sees a slight return to the pointillist renderings of street hustler narratives that color his finest work. Rae spends much of the remainder of Lost Jewlry chewing through a series of uptempo productions and neoclassicist break beat workouts like a legend doing warm-ups. But the spots where he shines also serve to illuminate the castoff nature of the project. Late in the EP he tries his hand at another song about women with ""86'"" and turns in a wistful verse detailing the rise and fall of an easygoing friends-with-benefits arrangement. It would be a winner if he didn't squander a third of it talking trash over DJ Thoro's plush Mtume loop. What's true of ""86'"" is true of Lost Jewlry as a whole. There's quality material here if you’re willing to sift through the filler.

column1: The accelerated release cycles and constant crop-dusting of new material that are becoming industry norm in hip-hop have created a pace that many artists struggle to keep. It suits some and hinders others. Flooding the market worked to the advantage of a beat-jacking demagogue with nothing to lose like 2002 50 Cent
column2: a midlevel talent suddenly gone supernova like 2006 Lil Wayne
column3: and a dependably consistent workaholic like 2012 Curren$y. But a deliberate
column4: formalist storyteller like Raekwon shouldn't fret over cobbling together mixtapes and EPs to keep his buzz warm between albums
column5:
especially when stopgap releases like this and 2012's Unexpected Victory come out as gossamer and inessential as they do. Lost Jewlry feels so undercooked next to even the slightest of Raekwon's recent album cuts that you wonder why it had to be released at all.

"|17654.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/17654-lost-jewlry/|6.0|Craig Jenkins

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/18757/homepage_large.ee705e38.jpg|General Dome|30394.0|Buke and Gase|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Brassland']|2013-01-29 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 17:02:25.912274|"

Being on the Dessner brothers' label helped Buke and Gase's 2010 debut Riposte get around
column2: but even more intriguing was the appealing story built into the scrambled music. Beyond their much talked-about modified instruments
column3: they forswore looping pedals at a time when everyone was pretty sick of looping pedals
column4: putting emphasis on their creative chops. Their names were Arone and Aron
column5: for god's sake. You couldn't dream up a more tempting lede
column6: and it was covered to death by the time of the transitional Function Falls EP
column7: where ""Gass"" was respelled for phonetic clarity. Their second full-length album
column8: General Dome
column9: feels like a testing ground to see whether Buke and Gase have the aptitude to hold that attention.

column1: They continue to skate their own electric rail between the decorations of prog rock and the cold metallic contours of post-punk. The higher-voiced buke still mainly sings nervy
column2: leaping leads while the snarling gase drives the low end. But some circumstantial changes have had a surprisingly meaningful impact. After Arone Dyer and Aron Sanchez moved from Brooklyn to upstate New York in 2011
column3: Dyer took up motorcycling and replaced her wooden buke with a heavy-duty one made of salvaged automotive steel. Consequently
column4: a new sense of speed and combustion thrums through the music. Majestic opener ""Houdini Crush"" is like a huge engine revving up
column5: then riding wisps of shapely ambient tone. It's intricately structured
column6: with cryptic moods contained in a shuddering shoegaze framework. But it feels like a pop song thanks to Dyer's engaging vocal performance. She can swing limberly between a Karen O yelp and a huskier croon
column7: sounding just like Victoria Legrand when she breathes extra syllables through the word ""inside.""

column1: Most of Buke and Gase's songs are built this way-- incidents and gestures swirling around a theme
column2: above an unstable thud. They're difficult to navigate. Songs peak early to make way for extended elaborations
column3: like the scratchy funk guitar lurching from the jungle rhythms of the title track
column4: mighty and unresolved. It doesn't end; the big gears just catch and whir to a halt as if suddenly unplugged. The same thing happens at the end of ""Hard Times""
column5: where their pointed interplay is suddenly sweetened as the buke echoes the vocal line. That sweetness is at odds with the violence and depravity that flickers discreetly through the lyrics
column6: which are often deformed by Dyer's rubbery enunciation. The imagery can be compelling or perplexing if you focus on it
column7: but the curious silhouette of her voice commands more attention.

column1: Finely wrought moments are plentiful: Check out when Dyer's voice seamlessly rounds off into a gase lead on the explosively bouncy ""Hiccup""
column2: or when the blocky descent of ""Split Like a Lip
column3: No Blood on the Beard"" slips into a dreamy skid
column4: like a car losing traction on ice. But no amount of ingenuity on the duo's part can keep their limited palette from feeling constricted by the end. The bare-bones foot percussion
column5: though resourceful
column6: levels many songs to the same oblivious stomp. The thrilling onward surge of the melodies gradually comes to seem like a search for some vital mortar
column7: a place to alight other than the grungy groove. My ears just get worn out by all the airless staccato
column8: longing for more open chords or smooth continuous tones. But overall
column9: General Dome's rewards are equal to its considerable demands
column10:
proving that there's more to Buke and Gase than a good story.

"|17563.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/17563-general-dome/|7.0|Brian Howe

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/18738/homepage_large.000fff09.jpg|La Busta Gialla|30974.0|Il Sogno del Marinaio|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Clenchedwrench']|2013-01-29 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 17:02:26.498450|"

Mike Watt formed a group called Il Sogno del Marinaio with guitarist Stefano Pilia and drummer Andrea Belfi in 2009
column2: days before the trio set off on a short tour of Italy. Between gigs
column3: the three decamped to the north to record La Busta Gialla
column4: committing to tape the oddly assembled jams and elaborate latticework with which they'd been peppering their otherwise Watt-heavy sets. The quickly constructed La Busta Gialla makes for a rickety listen
column5: teetering
column6: as it does
column7: between tautly composed prog and loosely formed grooves that seem to fall apart as they totter along. What's most impressive about La Busta Gialla is how much proper band-stuff-- how does this one go
column8: who takes which lead
column9: that sort of thing-- these three managed to work out in just a few days. Watt-- Minutemen co-founder
column10: fIREHOSE frontman
column11: human dynamo
column12: bassist extraordinaire
column13: and one-man embodiment of all of punk's highest ideals-- will talk your ear off about music's ability to bring down the boundaries of language
column14: distance
column15: unfamiliarity. And at its best
column16: La Busta Gialla feels like a conversation between three musicians working towards something communal while still feeling each other out.

column1: Like most of the music Watt's made over the years
column2: La Busta Gialla is at its best when it's on the move. Opener ""Zoom"" and immediate follower ""Partisan Song"" are both the album's busiest and best songs; the slightly silly ""Zoom"" plays a Battles-style game of brickbreaker
column3: while ""Partisan"" is all post-rock corrosion. The sound here is in constant flux
column4: passing blithely through section after section
column5: and each move keeps you guessing. Watt's playing-- virtuosic but unflashy
column6: melodically daring but never untethered to the tune-- has filtered down through pretty much all the non-cheesy progressive rock that's come in its wake
column7: echoes of which pop up throughout La Busta Gialla. The eternally ageless Watt has always kept an ear to the ground
column8: so it's a thrill to hear him not only in conversation with these two fine young musicians
column9: but with a lot of the music he's inspired (indirectly or otherwise)
column10: and he plays the stuff with intensity and drive. He's always been willing to set ego aside to benefit the greater good
column11: but here
column12: he seems especially absorbed into the group dynamic; the bass tends to take the melodic lead
column13: but it's rarely the focal point of these songs. The three read each other remarkably well
column14: moving in lockstep
column15: constantly rearranging themselves.

column1: Things take a turn with ""The Tiger Princess"". After a few minutes of snaky bass
column2: Watt sidles in

column6: far-flung talents like Pilia and Belfi just to see how that'd go. At the heart of Watt's legendary raps

column11: making strange records with near-strangers
column12:
forever engaged.

Danilo Plessow is an old soul. The first half of the 26-year old house producer's best-known alias
column3: Motor City Drum Ensemble
column4: is a reference to both his Stuttgart hometown (where the automobile was invented) and Detroit's rich dance music history. (The ""drum ensemble"" part refers to his sizable collection of Roland TR- drum machines.) In interviews
column5: he claims that he doesn't listen to much new music
column6: and despite citing hip-hop as a formative influence
column7: believes that the genre has been creatively stagnant ""since Madlib and J Dilla."" In general
column8: he prefers older sounds
column9: and 2010's Raw Cuts Vol. 1 was testament to that preference. It was an impressively lush collection that included Plessow's series of ""Raw Cuts"" singles from the previous few years
column10: consisting almost entirely of drum machines and vinyl-ripped samples of old soul
column11: jazz
column12: and funk breaks. A reverent synthetic patchwork of the past
column13: Raw Cuts Vol. 1 was as notable for the warm melodic euphoria it exuded as it was for the conceit that birthed the initial run of singles.

column1: As with many producers
column2: Plessow's reconfiguration of dusty sounds relies on a liberal attitude to sampling; In a 2011 interview with Resident Advisor
column3: he described his sampling philosophy as ""take everything
column4: while also expressing a desire to move past that approach. That wish was apparent on that year's ""L.O.V.E."" single
column5: released in tandem with Plessow's eclectic
column6: leg-stretching contribution to !K7's DJ-Kicks mix series. A floor-centric cut tucked within a mix that didn't so much play with the notions of house as it did almost totally jettison the genre
column7: ""L.O.V.E."" mixed sultry vocal samples with wavy synths and a circular bass line provided by Plessow himself. It was a fine taste of what was to come
column8: as MCDE's new EP
column9: Send a Prayer
column10: picks up where ""L.O.V.E."" left off. Its four tracks suggest that Plessow has little intention of completely discarding the warm
column11: crackly thump that defines his winning sound-- but that doesn't mean he's not interested in toying with that sound's confines.

column1: The track that opens the EP's A-side
column2: ""Send a Prayer Pt. 1""
column3: is a neat trick of sorts. At first
column4: it sounds fit for Raw Cuts: A decaying vocal sample moans just below brittle percussion as the backbeat enters without warning
column5: accompanied by warm
column6: bleating tones. The beat picks up
column7: and a jazz break with a broken weathervane saxophone line wanders into the mix
column8: accompanied by background crowd chatter and rattling percussion-- then
column9: the track continues unabated
column10: denying the big payoff that such an intrusion suggests. The payoffs on Raw Cuts Vol. 1 were abundant
column11: a by-product of Plessow's masterful sense of pacing; when the big twist is removed
column12: as it is here
column13: there's little else left but a sense of simmering unease.

column1: ""Send a Prayer Pt. 2"" and the EP's closer
column3: also resemble Raw Cuts' aesthetic. The former's patient
column4: conversational persistence clings so close that it could easily be mistaken for a forgotten cut from that collection
column5: while ""SP 11""'s skipping hi-hat and eardrum-rubbing bass thud sound menacing
column6: with dollops of synth glop adding some saucer-eyed bliss to cut the tension. B-side opener ""The Stranger"" breaks the furthest from the pack; it's also the EP's sole inert moment
column7: a pile of percussive rhythms with no real melodic anchor. The results amount to little more than a showcase for Plessow's ample hardware collection.

column1: It's appropriate that Send a Prayer's weakest moments stray the furthest from Raw Cuts' weathered crate-digging giddiness. While it would be unreasonable to expect that Plessow just creatively jog in place
column2: it's clear that Raw Cuts was the result of someone arriving at an immensely enjoyable sound that sounded relatively fresh
column3: despite its debts to the past. Listening chronologically to the run of non-Raw Cuts singles that saw release between 2007 and 2009
column4: you can hear Plessow starting from somewhere stylistically pro forma within the house genre and slowly finding his own footing
column5: a sound that he could conceivably call his own. Send a Prayer is the first bulk release of new Motor City Drum Ensemble material in nearly three years
column6: and Plessow's stated that he prefers to work at his own pace when it comes to releasing new output. So who knows when we'll hear from him again under this guise
column7: but if this EP is any indication
column8:
his next move will be worth anticipating.

Local Natives' 2010 debut
column4: Gorilla Manor
column5: was fully-formed and immediately pleasing
column6: functioning at a level that lesser acts spend entire careers trying to reach. But it had a certain youthful scrappiness
column7: too. Alongside expansive tracks like ""Shape Shifter"" and ""Wide Eyes""
column8: there were the silly howls that introduced ""Airplanes"" and the shouty breakdown of ""Sun Hands""
column9: both of which brought comparisons to Animal Collective. All told
column10: it was very of-the-moment with influences to match. Guitarist/singer Taylor Rice cited Broken Social Scene in an interview around the time of the album's release
column11: and anyone following along with big-tent indie rock could pick up on other borrowed elements: Grizzly Bear's choirboy sway
column12: the National's starched-shirt seriousness
column13: Fleet Foxes' rolling melodicism. But while the songwriting was strong
column14: you had to wonder if the band would prove to be more than the sum of their influences.

column1: Hummingbird
column2: Local Natives' second album
column3: offers a tricky answer to that question. They're still on the same path-- no fashionable synths or newfound fixation with 1990s R&B here-- but innovation seems beside the point. This is a record of lateral growth
column4: one that finds the band establishing their own place among their contemporaries. Ironically
column5: they've found their sound with the assistance of one of their major forebears: the National's Aaron Dessner performs and contributes songwriting on Hummingbird
column6: and shares production credit with the band while recording with them in his Brooklyn studio. (His brother and bandmate
column7: Bryce
column8: contributed horn arrangements to several songs
column9: too.)

column1: As with member-cum-producers Death Cab for Cutie's Chris Walla and TV on the Radio's Dave Sitek
column2: Dessner's production style isn't terribly distinctive. But he knows how to make things sound good
column3: and there's plenty of richness and depth to these songs. Bassist Andy Hamm left Local Natives in 2011
column4: leaving Local Natives as a quartet; on Hummingbird
column5: Aaron Dessner acts as fifth band member of the group.

column1: In our interview with the band last year
column2: they described the split with Hamm as ""heartbreaking
column3: and it wasn't the only loss suffered following Gorilla Manor's release: lead vocalist Kelcey Ayer's mother passed away last summer. Accordingly
column4: the brightness and boisterousness of Gorilla Manor is mostly absent. Advance track ""Breakers"" is a pulsating rush of drum fills and ""ooh""s that deflates to nearly nothing just as the wordless hook begins to sink in. There are other ominous touches: the tangled vocal ascent of ""You & I""
column5: ""Black Spot""'s closing instrumental tumble
column6: the static laden ""Wooly Mammoth""
column7: one of many cuts that showcases drummer Matt Frazier's knack for creating expressive
column8: overwhelming washes of rhythm. Lyrics convey the anxiety and depressed confusion. Where Gorilla Manor tried to capture the feeling of twentysomething malaise (""Water's in the clouds/ Is my life about to change?/ Who knows?/ Who cares?""); here words are more vivid
column9: conveying scenes of hopelessness and the feeling that everyone you know around you is slowly becoming a stranger.

column1: Lyrically
column2: they're best when they're at their most direct. ""Colombia""'s beautiful swell takes syncopated bass and stately piano and grows into something warm and emotionally cathartic. Vocally
column3: Ayer takes a lilting upper register
column4: leaning into it more and more as his lonely voice turns pleading while addressing his deceased mother: ""If you never felt all of my love/ I pray now you do"". On an album that spans a wide range of emotions
column5: ""Colombia"" is Hummingbird's most affecting moment; it's also one of the best songs the band's ever written.

column1: Although there are a number of fine uptempo songs
column2: Hummingbird's strongest moments are the quiet
column3: elegiac cuts similar to ""Colombia"": the brief
column4: sweetly sung ""Ceilings""
column5: the skyward wails of ""Three Months""
column6: Ayer's simmering solo take on the verses of ""Heavy Feet"". Subtlety is key
column7: and Hummingbird is nothing if not subtle. There's nothing as melodic as ""Airplanes"" or ""World News"" on here
column8: but this isn't a bad thing. With Hummingbird
column9: Local Natives have made a thoughtful
column10:
lovely album with small gestures that provide great rewards.

It would have once been obvious to say that a band's fans made them what they were. Now there's almost something quaint about it

column3: Swifties
column4: and Beliebers
column5: who are as much a marketing tool as the groups being marketed to. Although they get a decent amount of exposure each time they release a record
column6: until now

column8: Heartthrob
column9: is a reference to how we relate to the objects of our affection as teenagers
column10: that obsessive feeling that you live and die by for a few years
column11: and how those crushes usually end up getting replaced by real
column12: mutually loving relationships. Being someone who's liked this band to varying degrees of intensity for a decade
column13: it's easy to interpret the name as the Quins recognizing their own role in their more devoted fans' lives. Doing so at the same time as they decide to make an album with pop impresario Greg Kurstin and dabble in writing for Carly Rae Jepsen might seem a little like selling their cow for a handful of supposedly magic beans.

column1: Some folks have accused the duo of selling out with Heartthrob-- a concise 10 songs
column2: at least half of which could be pop radio singles-- to which I'd argue that accessibility has always been a part of their appeal
column3: in more respects than just working in friendly acoustic
column4: rock
column5: and electro-pop mediums. Surely part of the comfort of their music

column7: is that it doesn't make a big deal of what it's come to represent. It's not like putting on an Ani DiFranco record in your bedroom and the lyrics sparking a parent's ear. One thing they've not been shy about in their songs
column8: however

column10: which pulls it off with aplomb.

column1: The clearest sign that the Quins would follow this path lies in Sainthood's ""Alligator""
column2: an insanely catchy
column3: arid little pop song that had become Sara's trademark. (""Shock to Your System"" and ""How Come You Don't Want Me"" carry on that impulse here.) But it was also a sign of the growing disparity between the twins' respective songwriting styles; Tegan's efforts on that record were stormy emo/power pop blasts
column4: and the two didn't gel to the extent that it seemed fair to wonder whether it made sense for them to continue recording together. The Roxette and Cyndi Lauper-referencing
column5: soaring keyboard pop of Heartthrob is a welcome stylistic reconciliation
column6: if one that sacrifices their sonic weirdness.

column1: Kurstin has taken Tegan and Sara's ability to write a solid refrain (some of their old songs were arguably all refrain) and channeled it into rushing
column2: skyward stadium pop songs where their voices are more upfront
column3: and less tethered to their former prickly structures. ""Closer"" is the killer
column4: starting with Tegan's coy
column5: tightly wound vocal laying out what she's after-- ""All I dream of lately/ Is how to get you underneath me""-- the triumphantly shouted chorus coming off brash and charming
column6: as if she knows she's definitely going to get it. It's a gloriously freeing
column7: retrospective retelling of first infatuations
column8: rewriting the script to articulate what you could only think about furiously back when.

column1: ""Closer""'s trad structure is typical of most of the songs on the record
column2: but ""Now I'm All Messed Up"" breaks through its crackly piano and static whirr of a chorus with piercing
column3: layered pleas: ""Go! Go! Go if you want
column4: I can't stop you!"" It plays like a Wham! ballad repurposed as a glitchy
column5: modern slow jam
column6: which
column7: in case that needs clarifying
column8: is brilliant. The lyrics are a great
column9: tragic portrait of post-split heartbreak-- ""Now I'm all messed up
column10: sick inside wondering where/ Where you're leaving your make-up""-- but the song as a whole never sounds anything less than fully empowering.

column1: On Heartthrob
column2: Tegan and Sara sing about solitude
column3: regret
column4: and self-loathing alongside romance
column5: but most of its 10 songs feel amazing. That's not a sign of cognitive dissonance
column6: but their considerable abilities fusing with those of Kurstin to drag their music out of headphones and into zones of unabashed communal euphoria and delight. The dramatic
column7: ravey swish of ""Goodbye
column8: Goodbye"" and new wavey tick of ""I'm Not Your Hero"" actually deal with the problem of coming across differently to your true self
column9: and the risks you incur to reconcile that gap
column10: whether that means losing someone or admitting that you're lost inside.

column1: Making a relatively conventional sounding pop record-- not an acceptably hip
column2: minimalist one produced by Devonte Hynes or Ariel Rechtshaid-- is a small risk in itself for the duo; for one
column3: if its charms don't chime with sales
column4: I can't imagine Warners keeping on a band whose last album sold 110k. Its misfires are few
column5: if pronounced: On ""Drove Me Wild""
column6: Tegan's voice is pitched up to sound unrecognizable
column7: and the blandness of the music doesn't exactly inspire a wild vocal take-- it sounds like the music on an ad for Ibiza package holidays; ""Love They Say"" dies under slimy 90s production
column8: bland acoustic verses
column9: and a string of clichés about love (""true
column10: ""blind"") that an actual teenager would probably balk at scrawling on a ""Love is..."" notelet.

column1: At its best
column2: however
column3: Heartthrob brings the 32-year old siblings' more adult
column4: romantic touch to a record that roundly avoids turning into any old generic
column5: radio-friendly collection: ""Love like ours is never fixed
column6: Tegan sings on the classic piano pop of ""I Was a Fool"". It's hard to believe you could ever feel differently when you're a teenager crushing so hard you could cry at the injustice of your emotions going unrecognized. One of the strongest ideas Tegan and Sara give anyone who's ever plotted their identity by their music is the potential for change and transformation. For the unconverted
column7:
a temporary suspension of cynicism may be required.

column1: Playing on Wu Tang's ""C.R.E.A.M.""

Up to this point

Few would deny that Dan ""the Automator"" Nakamura makes records sound great. Over a career spanning two decades

column1: Pillowfight is Nakamura's collaboration with singer/songwriter/multi-instrumentalist Emily Wells-- Kid Koala put Nakamura in contact with her after they performed together at a Canadian music festival. He provides the instrumentation

column1: Wells' voice sometimes resembles Sinatra's when she sends it floating up over Nakamura's instrumental bed. Sometimes it sounds a little like a passable
column2: fourth-generation copy of Billie Holiday in blues mode. But for much of the record she deploys a coy
column3: breathy coo that more than anything else sounds like Lana Del Rey stripped of the elegant swoon and old-Hollywood drama that stopped Born to Die just coming off as camp. After years of collaborating with deeply compelling
column4: oddball vocalists like Dr. Octagon and Mike Patton
column5: Nakamura's decision to work with such an unremarkable performer is a disappointment.

column1: The letdowns don't stop there. At this point in his career
column2: Nakamura's biggest liability is his past success. When he first came on the scene
column3: blending hip-hop's muscular percussion and collage-like production techniques with esoteric sounds-- like jazzy swinging-60s bachelor pad pop and a cheekily lowbrow crate-digger attitude-- was novel. But it turned out to be easily reproducible
column4: and since then Nakamura's formula has been copied an untold number of times
column5: and the mainstream pop success of producers who have run with his style (Danger Mouse being the biggest) has inspired even more imitators. At this point
column6: Nakamura's once-sui generis sonic personality has been replicated past the point of cliche.

column1: Nakamura has done little to advance his sound in that time
column2: preferring instead to refine the one he already had. By this point it's been polished smooth enough that you can sit through the entirety of Pillowfight waiting for something unexpected to snag your attention before walking away disappointed 12 songs later. Every sonic element is in its proper place
column3: and none of them misbehaves. The album projects a swanky modernism that the managers of medium-high-end wine bars and lounges might love
column4: but other listeners will find its good manners stifling.

column1: There are a few bright points scattered about. Pillowfight's strongest song
column2: the album-opening ""Used to Think""
column3: has a darkly dramatic atmosphere emphasized by a funereal garage rock organ
column4: ominous strings
column5: and one of the few performances on the record where Wells shows a little edge-- the generic ""you"" that she's singing to resolves into something resembling an actual person. Unfortunately
column6: its meandering structure and the hokey backup vocals on the chorus sink the song. And Kid Koala shows up with his turntables a few times throughout the album to add a much-needed dose of dizzy whimsy.

column1: Ultimately the record's main problem seems to be that Nakamura has simply become too good at being Dan the Automator
column2:
to the point where his recordings have started to sound like a very well executed copy of his past work. Pillowfight is technically flawless but thoroughly unexciting. Sounds great though.

In 2011's Pulitzer-winning novel A Visit From the Goon Squad
column3: Jennifer Egan envisions a future where nearly all communication is conducted in a ruthlessly efficient
column4: text-based pidgin language
column5: made up entirely of abbreviations
column6: punctuation marks
column7: and semaphores. Future more or less raps in a version of this hyper-compressed language and adopts it as his native tongue. ""They need bitches no speaky no INGLO
column8: he squawks on ""Ceelo""
column9: the third track on the Atlanta warbler's latest freebie mixtape
column10: Future Presents FBG: The Movie. If your baseline qualification for good rap is that the rapper's words sit pretty on the page
column11: Future will make you afraid of the future and you'll probably give up before ""Intro""
column12: a series of rambling statements like
column13: ""That yopper on me! Haiti on me!""
column14: is over. ""I don't really freestyle
column15: Future demurred in his latest appearance on Pitchfork.tv's ""Selector"". Thousands of rap traditionalists nodded their heads vehemently in agreement.

column1: But Future is not degrading the conversation-- he's pushing hard on one of rap's remaining frontiers: extreme voice manipulation. On FBG: The Movie
column2: he comes up with some of the most unprecedented noises ever to qualify as mainstream pop music: rodent squeaks
column3: baby gurgles
column4: goat-bleats. His debut album
column5: Pluto
column6: despite its hints and flirtations
column7: wasn't quite as weird or as catchy as advertised; I wanted to have my brain twisted harder
column8: possibly until I yelped. On FBG
column9: Future twists as hard as he can
column10: and as a courtesy
column11: even does the yelping for me.

column1: Mainstream rap's love affair with AutoTune
column2: and with the possibilities of using software designed to discreetly improve voices to blatantly mangle them
column3: has grown more intense with every passing year. But Future's use of it is the most visceral yet. FBG takes what Pluto hinted at to glorious
column4: crazed extremes: On the repetitive hook
column5: ""Who you thank you is?""
column6: on ""Mark Mcquire""
column7: he hardly sounds human. ""Keep On Shinin"" repeats the vocal so many times that the effect becomes hallucinatory. ""Karate Chop"" exaggerates Soulja Boy's stuttering delivery to its logical extreme
column8: so that Future's mangled voice becomes just another firing piston in the cartoon assembly line of Metro Boomin's production.

column1: The production on this. The funereal string section and horns of ""Chosen One""; the senses-obliterating
column2: trance-house breakdown on ""Fo Real""; the organ and pellet-dispenser synth collision on ""Karate Chop""; the Flash Man stage insanity of ""Finessin;"" whatever the fuck is happening to those horns on ""DNA"". Mashing together the martial thud of Lex Luger with the antic 8-bit mischief of Gucci Mane's frequent collaborator Zaytoven
column3: FBG arrives at a sound that is both enormous and oddly giggly
column4: apt to make you either feel invincible or like a visitor to Toon Town
column5: or both.

column1: The unlikeliest aspect of FBG: The Movie's success is its billing: This is nominally a crew mixtape
column2: usually the moment a rapper gets famous enough to allow his less-talented friends to run rampant the booth and ruin the vibe. There are some time-marking verses to sit through here
column3: and the tape is quite long at 24 tracks and and hour plus
column4: but FBG doesn't fit this mold any more than last year's Rich Forever deserved to be considered a free appetizer for the main course. Like Rich Forever
column5: FBG is a narrative-shaping release disguised as a promotional giveaway.

column1: There is one moment of Pluto-style reflective melancholy on FBG called ""Appeal""
column2: but Future doesn't even perform it; instead he deputizes Freeband Gang associate Young Scooter. FBG is Future's victory lap
column3: and he is entirely in crazed-exultation mode. He's everywhere on FBG
column4: like the old Bugs Bunny cartoon in which Bugs plays every baseball position simultaneously
column5: including the chatty catcher. Future has found a blunt-force way to assault rap's boundaries
column6: and on FBG
column7: he's emboldened
column8:
smashing away at everything in his path.

column14: say

As bass music has emerged from the underground in the States
column2: it has
column3: predictably
column4: become warmer
column5: brighter and more accessible. Sure
column6: a key element of Skrillex's appeal is the enormous release that comes with the drop
column7: but it's equally important to have pleasant sounds as contrast. The move toward warmth isn't limited to the most obvious of brostep producers. Flying Lotus isn't soundtracking raves quite yet
column8: but he's certainly shifted towards accessibility
column9: moving from the eerie glitchfest of Los Angeles in 2008
column10: to the settled comfort of last year's Until the Quiet Comes.

column1: Even some of our iciest producers seem vulnerable to this gradual instrumental warming. Take FlyLo's sometime Low End Theory associate
column2: Nosaj Thing. The Los Angeles producer's debut album
column3: Drift
column4: (which came out a year after Los Angeles) was an icy chasm
column5: a shifting cave of sound that seemed as if it could have originated in the coldest reaches of space. But his new album
column6: Home
column7: serves as a kind of twilight to Drift's midnight
column8: elaborating on his sound while taking a welcome turn towards the light.

column1: That's not to say that Nosaj Thing
column2: born Jason Chung
column3: is suddenly making full-fledged pop. The darkness hasn't disappeared entirely. But occasional hints of pop clarity lie trapped just beneath the surface of many tracks on the new album. The shift is surprising given Chung's former penchant for working in huge dark spaces and his origin in the realm of glitch-hop
column4: a subgenre that frequently posits intricacy as its own kind of beauty. But it's not unwelcome
column5: considering the producer has clearly retained his ability to produce the studied soundscapes that made his debut so promising. It's just the sharp edges are now complemented by some soft ones.

column1: The change is particularly obvious when Chung employs vocalists. Blonde Redhead's frontwoman Kazu Makino transforms the plaintive ""Eclipse/Blue"" into a particularly pillowy affair
column2: a torrent of the kind of grey and blue sounds that are described in the lyrics. The Toro Y Moi-featuring ""Try"" and its accompanying ""Prelude"" are downright lovely; a slow tapestry of summoning synths soon gives way to epic fireworks reminiscent of the intro to M83's Hurry Up We're Dreaming. When Chaz Bundick's voice comes in about halfway through ""Try""
column3: his wispy voice blows beautifully through the music
column4: sounding aloft within the mix.

column1: What distinguishes Chung's production from that of M83 is its nuance and its lack of obvious sentimentality. Nearly every track on Home is downtempo
column2: but multiple backbeats help to direct the flow of energy-- doubling down on bass on a song like ""Snap"" makes for a dynamic listen. On the surface
column3: the song resembles something that a bombastic producer like Rustie might make for a peaceful Sunday afternoon
column4: but upon further inspection
column5: it isn't quite as peaceful as it first appears. A close listen reveals a busy world of secondary beats and electronic runs fluttering underneath the mix's outer membrane. ""Glue"" has so many ping-pong echoes and backing beats that it takes a moment to locate the rhythm that's actually moving the track along.

column1: On Drift
column2: melodies existed to accentuate complex beats like these
column3: as on ""Fog""
column4: where chilly synthesizers wove in and out of an asthmatic gasp of a bassline. Even when light broke in on a slow descending bridge
column5: it was still accompanied by that breathless sound
column6: something like Gollum trying to catch his breath in Beijing. The closest comparison on Home is the title track
column7: which opens the album. A synth line moves through a dark chorus of voices until it arrives at a shuddering epicenter that woulnd't have felt out of place on that 2009 album. ""Distance""
column8: too
column9: is somewhat cold-blooded at first
column10: as a brief synth flutter foreshadows an ominous minor key transformation that threatens to dominate when the beat vanishes midway through. But
column11: in a nice microcosm of the album's direction
column12: it uses those minor keys to produce a gorgeous swirling effect that re-ups and reamps when the beat returns.

column1: If any more evidence were needed of the change in Nosaj Thing's sound
column2: album closer ""Light #3""
column3: the third in a trilogy that appears throughout Drift
column4: would serve as proof. Numbers one and two
column5: both of them absolutely stunning tracks in their own right
column6: offer sharpness as beauty
column7: a panoply of cutting sounds choreographed exquisitely. By contrast
column8: the piano that begins the third volume leads in to a gentle mountain of strings and voices
column9: just as beautiful as the first two
column10: but peaceful too
column11: never threatening to overwhelm. Jason Chung may not have put out any music in the last four years
column12: but he appears to have used that time well. Home is an ace of a second album
column13:
one which maintains the most important elements of Chung's painstakingly crafted sound while progressing nicely into a friendlier arena.

Last year's praise of Frank Ocean's Channel Orange scarcely mentioned the album's star utility player
column2: co-producer
column3: and multi-instrumentalist Malay
column4: or the song that Frank didn't write. Channel Orange's ""Fertilizer"" was written by James Fauntleroy
column5: author of American Idol winner Jordin Sparks' triple-platinum ""No Air"" and Rihanna's international chart smash ""Te Amo"". Fauntleroy was featured prominently on Common's The Dreamer/The Believer and G.O.O.D. Music's Cruel Summer as well
column6: but he keeps an impossibly low profile as a solo artist. Lately he's been stepping out as the vocalist of veteran Chicago hip-hop producer No ID's side project Cocaine 80s
column7: which also counts ace hip-hop engineer Rob Kinelski and in-demand session musicians Kevin Randolph and Steve Wyreman among its ranks. The Flower of Life
column8: their fourth in a series of low stakes free EP releases
column9: is an eccentric collection of songs that get over in large part because of Fauntleroy's fantastic voice.

column1: Randolph
column2: Wyreman
column3: and Fauntleroy played house band for No ID's stints as producer-in-residence for Common's The Dreamer/The Believer and Big Sean's Finally Famous in 2011
column4: and The Flower of Life's ""Kuro to Shiro"" and ""Fly Ass Pisces"" both reprise the soulful live band boom bap and full-bodied textural heft of those releases. The former adorns dueling guitar leads and chunky bass with programmed drums and twinkling keyboard ephemera
column5: while the latter sees Wyreman trading ""Kuro to Shiro""'s Thin Lizzy licks for cleaner
column6: jazzier ones as Fauntleroy and Kendrick Lamar associate Jhené Aiko trade sly come-ons and romantic affirmations. Common drops in on both
column7: turning in a pair of capable verses if never quite matching his devastating turn on ""Summer Madness"" from the group's debut
column8: The Pursuit. ""Ground"" is a sprightly pop light grenade built around noodly acoustic guitar
column9: tasteful strings
column10: and a tongue-twisting vocal from Fauntleroy. Cocaine 80s' handle on hip-hop and R&B is effortless
column11: but The Flower of Life is about soldiering beyond comfort zones.

column1: ""The Distant River"" is a stately doo wop number cut from the same cloth as the Fauntleroy-penned ""Get It Over With"" from Rihanna's Unapologetic that showcases his penchant for limber interlocking vocal runs. EP closer ""Lucid"" is just James and an acoustic guitar with groundswells of tremolo guitar ebbing and flowing underfoot. ""The Sun and the Moon"" rides a sedate
column2: psychedelic groove to a washed out coda straight out of the Beta Band's playbook. Later ""Higher Self"" toys with lumbering
column3: angular math rock. The Flower of Life's more experimental passages are largely successful
column4: although ""The Distant River"" leans too close to solo Sting schmaltz for comfort
column5: and ""The Sun and the Moon"" sounds as much like hokey post-grunge as anything else. But James Fauntleroy is the beating heart of this project
column6: and his angelic
column7: multi-tracked vocals carry it through sporadic moments of questionable taste
column8: anchoring The Flower of Life's stylistic hard left turns in an undeniable tunefulness.

column1: Cocaine 80s is a team of hip-hop's best hired guns cutting loose and following the muse down a rabbit hole. The Flower of Life succeeds where it does thanks to the chemistry and genre-busting adventurousness of its players
column2: but the major takeaway here is James Fauntleroy's formidable talent. He can sell a crass come-on like ""You deserve lovin' all day
column3: and you deserve fuckin' all night"" in ""The Sun and the Moon""
column4: and the gallows humor of ""Lucid""'s ""I heard the world could end tomorrow/ Least we won't have to pay the bills"" with the same disarming directness. If he wanted to
column5: Fauntleroy could totally stockpile a handful of hits for himself and parlay his industry connects into a respectable solo career like The-Dream and Frank Ocean did
column6: but if he wants to farm the obvious hits out to artists with greater reach and hang out in the shadows releasing these intermittent blasts of impossibly hooky
column7: subtly experimental R&B
column8:
he's more than welcome to.

Though Wimps' Repeat is slathered in bright
column2: bubbly punk hooks

column4: neurosis
column5: nerves
column6: and depression. The title track's message is simple-- you eat
column7: you sleep
column8: and then you repeat. In the track ""Grump"": ""It's all downhill from here."" The Seattle punk trio use their platform to illustrate the more banal facets of everyday life

column11: if impractical: ""Quit Your Job"" and ""Nap"".

column1: Their messages follow an antagonistic tradition of Seattle punk. Just as the Intelligence recently call-and-response ordered folks to turn off ""that freedom rock
column2: Wimps demand that ""everyone stop having fun right now."" (Drummer Dave Ramm is a former member of the Intelligence.) You can also hear the sonic threads of punk rock's past throughout the album. Their sing-shouting vocals occasionally bring to mind those of belter-in-chief
column3: Corin Tucker
column4: and they deliver each song with buoyant new wave guitars
column5: and of course
column6: a few distortion-laden power chord hooks. With a specific point-of-view and a few catchy songs
column7: guitarist Rachel Ratner
column8: bassist Matt Nyce
column9: and Ramm deliver a strong blueprint for the new Hardly Art offshoot End of Time Records. (Repeat is the label's inaugural release.) And in small bites
column10: it's a fun record delivered with a tinge of cynicism and a familiar hue of West Coast punk. But even with song lengths topping out at 2.5 minutes
column11: Wimps don't really do ""small bites."" It's an album where the songwriting and hooks aren't quite strong enough for these tracks to be as repetitive as they are.

column1: ""Wet Cardboard""
column2: for one
column3: is a clever idea bogged down by repetitive shout-singing. The titular image is used as an analogy for a miserable person's emotional state-- heavy
column4: cold
column5: wet
column6: moldy. And Ratner sounds satisfied about it
column7: as she bitingly shouts
column8: ""You'll never be dry again."" But while it's a clever idea
column9: it's the hardest track on the album to see through. A faster song might be able to sustain three repetitive verses and a bridge
column10: but the tempo drags and the shouted vocals eventually start to grate. Some of their lyrics don't wear well
column11: either. The ""Stop Having Fun"" line ""it's that time of the month for you to shut up"" feels particularly hard to stomach with repeated listens.

column1: But it's a fine line
column2: as the band's repetition and brattiness occasionally work in their favor. ""Nap"" is the album's easy high point. The lyrics encompass Repeat's overall vibe in the simplest terms possible: I don't want to go out or have fun or socialize; I just want to go to sleep. (Or more accurately
column3: ""Naaaaaaaaap!"") Their loud
column4: fast
column5: catchy hook is strong
column6: and it's the song where they economize the most
column7: picking up the tempo and skipping a third verse altogether. Ultimately
column8: a track like this one would sound awesome on the A-side of a 7"". And sometimes
column9: they manage to balance their songs pretty well-- ""Quit Your Job"" packs enough complementary-but-contrasting elements into two minutes to keep the central hook from outstaying its welcome. But those are two examples
column10: and really
column11: their thematic territory
column12: delivery
column13:
and sardonic viewpoint are too samey over 12 tracks.

0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/18744/homepage_large.edcb86ee.jpg|Wolf's Law|28571.0|The Joy Formidable|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Atlantic']|2013-01-24 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 17:02:33.852459|"

The Joy Formidable are attempting to follow a career path that's all but impossible for up-and-coming rock bands to traverse these days. They want to play arenas
column2: and fill those arenas with punishingly loud and hooky guitar riffs and righteous
column3: octopus-arm drum fills that roll over enormous crowds like a monster truck assaulting a line-up of hollowed-out Chevy Malibus. The Joy Formidable have already done this as an opening act for other bands-- most notably Muse during last fall's tour in support of the ridiculous The 2nd Law-- but they burn with headliner envy. It's incredible to see the Joy Formidable take that envy
column4: turn it into pure energy
column5: and shoot it out as a pulverizing Death Star ray in a small club.

column1: The band's 2011 full-length debut The Big Roar is exciting
column2: slickly packaged entertainment more akin to a big-budget action blockbuster like Skyfall than anything currently in vogue in the insular
column3: down-sized world of indie rock. Roar's breakout song ""Whirring"" became a genuine hit on rock radio
column4: and it's a whizz-bang distillation of the Joy Formidable's strengths: Singer Ritzy Bryan's whisper-to-a-scream vocal chops
column5: the collision of instrumental force and melodic finesse
column6: the energetic update of the most muscular forms of 90s shoegaze (specifically Mezcal Head­-era Swervedriver and Ride's ""Leave Them All Behind"")
column7: and an underlying confidence that this music deserves to close out large outdoor festivals around the world.

column1: Looked at more cynically
column2: The Big Roar comes off like it was-- in the words of Pitchfork's Stuart Berman-- ""scientifically engineered to make the Joy Formidable sound like the Biggest Band in the World."" The Big Roar certainly was assembled
column3: not by men in white coats
column4: but by industry people who shepherded the band through years of refining the album's songs. One of Roar's best tracks
column5: ""Austere""
column6: dates back to 2008; other songs appeared on previously released EPs in different versions before given a final polish.

column1: The Joy Formidable's sophomore effort Wolf’s Law arrives without the benefit of multiple rough drafts. And yet Wolf's Law sounds like it's been worked over even more extensively
column2: though not necessarily in a way that makes it more commercial. If anything
column3: Wolf's Law is a weirder
column4: proggier record that explores a wider range of textures and sounds than the relatively monochromatic Roar. The shifting time signatures of the Zeppelinesque ""Cholla"" and the swaggering ""Maw Maw Song""-- which alternates between verses that move stealthily along a rapid metallic pulse and a chorus that stomps about with bombastic insolence-- position the Joy Formidable as the heir to Muse's grandiose arena empire.

column1: Not that the Joy Formidable is as insane as Muse
column2: because no contemporary rock band is as insane as Muse. But they are clearly thinking in bolder and broader terms. The songs that hew closest to the first album’s blueprint-- like ""Tendons"" or the excellent
column3: New Order-like single ""This Ladder is Ours""-- are the most successful
column4: though the penultimate track ""The Hurdle"" shows an improved mastery of rock-song dynamics
column5: building from a mesmerizing strum to an overwhelming
column6: heart-pumping climax. Most Joy Formidable songs start at heart-pumping and turn up the volume from there
column7: but on the delicate ""Silent Treatment""
column8: Bryan is able to convey that same intensity backed only with an acoustic guitar.

column1: It would be an exaggeration to call Wolf's Law the Joy Formidable's ""experimental"" record
column2: but it does stretch (and occasionally overstretch) the band’s formula a bit. The operatic
column3: Days of Future Passed orchestrations of ""The Turnaround"" are a little much
column4: as are the electronic squiggles shot like laser blasts through the surly ""Bats"". Nearly a third of ""Maw Maw Song"" is an extended

column1: No matter the occasional excesses
column2:

The Joy Formidable might not have the most plausible ambitions for a 21st century rock band. But Wolf's Law offers enough thrills to suspend your disbelief.

column5: in the past

column8: ""Fiery the Angels Fell""

column11: and Sweet sings
column12: repeatedly

column1: To hear the implied metal break out onto the surface of the Boduf Songs project is a thrilling moment; it consummates four album's worth of gathering menace. ""Everyone Will Let You Down In the End"" lurches in its final minutes into a La Brea tarpit of down-tuned doom guitars. and is richest and most surprising Boduf release yet.

You hear the arthritic rumble of the train. The 100-ton iron horse clacking at 55 miles per hour through the tunnel to nowhere. Stainless steel cars bombed with balloon letters in bubble gum paint. The F Line
column2: pre-Giuliani

column6: bandits

column1: The doors crumple open and the passengers vanish up half-lit stairwells into the Bridge. There is no Illmatic without the Bridge. Illmatic is the bridge. Queensbridge Houses
column2: the largest projects in America

column5: 000-plus trying to survive. The pissy elevators only stop on every other floor. The neighbors are the rotting East River and the ""Big Alice"" power plant

column1: The Bridge is where Nas was raised. He explained the mentality to The Source in April 1994

column3: it's just life. You can't be no sucker.""

column4: I went to Hell for snuffing Jesus."" He anointed himself the ""street's disciple."" Everyone blessed him as the Golden Child.

column1: His brother Jungle snaps
column2: ""yo
column3: Nas
column4: what the fuck is this bullshit?"" Nas tells him to chill. He's carrying on tradition
column5: defined as: ""When it's real
column6: you do it even without a recording contract."" It's an oath of purity amidst poisons-- something that seems sanctimonious in a post-Puffy world

column1: I lay puzzled as I backtrack to earlier times.
Hip-hop was a teenager when Illmatic dropped. Old enough for biblical foundation

column3: this should only make us sit up and pay attention when a rapper comes along who's not about milking the latest trend and running off with the loot.""

column1: New York street culture was losing its birthright to hip-hop's evolution. Death Row and West Coast gangsta rap dominated the charts and mass media oxygen. Rap-A-Lot was carving up its empire in the South. It was after Vanilla Ice and MC Hammer
column2: and leather-suited rappers wanted that Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles II: Secret of the Ooze money. Big Daddy Kane was firmly in the silken post-Madonna Sex book era. LL Cool J was mugging with a red beret in Toys. Even a young RZA and GZA got bamboozled into goofy New Jack Swing jams by clueless executives. And Nas couldn't get a record deal.

column1: This sounds insane in hindsight. When people start making greatest rapper lists you can't count to five before Nas' name is mentioned. The kid who went to hell for snuffing Jesus has become a sacred cow. Twenty years deep
column2: he's nominated for a Grammy and is in Gap ads with his dad. There was the album with Damian Marley
column3: the feud with Jay-Z
column4: there was Belly. Nas is firmly entrenched in VH1 Special territory. He has crossed over enough without ever making radio hits

column3: Kool G Rap. Translation: great but unsalable. He signed Warren G instead
column4: who went triple platinum in the summer and fall of 1994. Illmatic only sold 330
column5: 000 copies in its first year. It has no ""Regulate"" that can inspire drunken Nate Dogg sing-a-longs
column6: but it is widely regarded as the greatest East Coast rap album ever made. Illmatic is the gold standard that boom-bap connoisseurs refer to in the same way that Baby Boomers talk about Highway 61 Revisited. The evidence they point to when they want to say: this is how good it can be.
