column7: It's Half Time
column8: The World is Yours
column9: Coming Out of Queensbridge
column10: Represent.

column1: A classic album is supposed to change or define its time. Illmatic did both. The Notorious B.I.G. borrowed everything from art ideas to album structure. It was so blatant that Ghostface and Raekwon dedicated an entire skit to mocking it. Jay-Z took a hot Nas line and made a hot song on Reasonable Doubt. If you listen to Sean Carter before Illmatic
column2: the rat-a-tat is straight from Big Daddy Kane. After Nas dropped
column3: Jay-Z suddenly got smooth. Those are just the two most famous appropriations.

column1: No album better reflected the sound and style of New York
column2: 94. The alembic of soul jazz samples
column4: broken nose breaks
column5: and raw rap distilled the Henny
column6: no chaser ideal of boom-bap. The loops rummage through their parent's collection: Donald Byrd
column7: Joe Chambers
column8: Ahmad Jamal
column9: Parliament
column10: Michael Jackson. Nas invites his rolling stone father
column11: Olu Dara to blow the trumpet coda on ""Life's A Bitch"". Jazz-rap fusion had been done well prior
column12: but rarely with such subtlety. Nas didn't need to make the connection explicit-- he allowed you to understand what jazz was like the first time your parents and grandparents heard it.

column1: I pour my Heineken brew to my deceased crew on memory lane.

None of this context has to matter. Illmatic is imprisoned within itself. The power is targeted in the narrow scope of its worldview. There are six desperate and savage blocks and there is nowhere else. Nas captures the feeling of being young and trapped. You see his struggle and you see his ghosts.
The more I listen to Illmatic
column2: the more haunted it feels. When you're younger
column3: it clubs you with its hail of words and the skeletal beauty of its beats. But the older I get
column4: the more it strikes me as a teenaged requiem for those still living. ""Old Soul"" is the sort of stock phrase used by yoga teachers and amateur psychics
column5: but it always fit Nas. He's 20 and prematurely nostalgic
column6: struck by memories of park jams and watching ""CHiPS.""
column7: when Shante dissed the real Roxanne
column8: and how much he misses Mr. Magic.

column1: There is no narrative about Ill Will
column2: but you hear the name over and over. Will was his best friend and first music partner who lived on the 6th floor with turntables and a mic. He was shot to death in Queensbridge over a drunken argument. You don't hear how Nas and his wounded brother Jungle rushed Will to the hospital
column3: got static from emergency room officials
column4: and watched him die. But the sense of grievous loss shadows almost every bar
column5: especially ""Memory Lane"" and ""One Love"".

column1: If you listen to it enough names start to pop out: Fatcat
column2: Alpo
column3: Grand Wizard
column4: Mayo
column5: the foul cop who shot Garcia
column6: Jerome's niece
column7: Little Rob
column8: Herb
column9: Ice
column10: and Bullet. The entirety of ""Represent"". You start to wonder where they are now
column11: or if they are. The album's lone guest AZ
column12: lays it down flat: he's destined to live the dream for all the peeps who never made it.

column1: But Nas uses Illmatic as more than a vehicle to escape. The styles and stories that formed him fuse into something that withstands outdated slang and popular taste: it is a story of a gifted writer born into squalor
column2: trying to claw his way out of the trap. It's somewhere between The Basketball Diaries and Native Son
column3: but Jim Carroll and Richard Wright couldn't rap like Nas.

column1: That's why 19 years later
column2: Get On Down is re-issuing a box set with a vinyl
column3: gold CD
column4: and an ersatz cherry wood case featuring a 48-page book with The Source article that originally crowned him-- even if Illmatic was the archetypal cassette album (along with the purple tape). It's best heard by ignoring the dogma
column5: culture wars
column6: Nas clones
column7: and would-be saviors that have accreted since April of 1994. Who cares whether it's the greatest rap album of all-time or not? It's an example of how great rap can be
column8: but not necessarily the way it should be.

column1: There was no real follow-up to Illmatic because Nas understood that he'd tapped into a moment that could only come once and in one place. This is what things had been building towards. A little over a decade later
column2: Nas claimed that hip-hop was dead
column3:
but this world that was his was already starting to vanish on Illmatic. But you can still summon it from the first rumble of the train. This is what happened when the doors opened.

"|17497.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/17497-illmatic/|10.0|Jeff Weiss

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/18711/homepage_large.0f72fb34.jpg|Christopher|5110.0|The Ruby Suns|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Sub Pop']|2013-01-23 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 17:02:37.766150|"

Ryan McPhun admits within the first minute of the Ruby Suns' new album
column2: Christopher
column3: that he's always falling in love. It's hard to dispute
column4: since he spends the rest of ""Desert of Pop"" enumerating ways to relate the feeling: He's ""like a birthday boy
column5: giddy and excited"" over someone or something that hits him like ""a single malt
column6: pure agave tequila."" The good stuff
column7: y'know? But there's one line that doesn't sit quite right: ""You are [a] cold glass of water in the desert of pop."" I'm almost positive he's referencing pop music
column8: but he does leave open the slightest possibility that it's a reference to soda. It sounds farfetched
column9: but while ""Desert of Pop"" clearly describes being struck dumb by a singer
column10: a song
column11: or a combination of the two
column12: why would McPhun describe pop as an arid wasteland when the spiffy synth hits and hi-NRG dance beats make it abundantly clear that the Ruby Suns want you to view Christopher as their entry into splashy chart pop? Maybe they're not sure either
column13: as Christopher dives in headfirst and just as quickly heads back to the surface.

column1: Perhaps McPhun feels self-conscious about this change of heart
column2: as he confesses about his situation
column3: ""Anyone else would think I'm your cheerleader."" While becoming a pop evangelist relatively late in life can generally be healthy
column4: at least as an acknowledgement that wholly rejecting pop music can be just as narrow-minded as wholly accepting it
column5: it's particularly dangerous in the hands of musicians who haven't really shown much of an ear for it previously. Most often
column6: it just results in enthusiastic overcompensation; you can look to fellow Indie Class of 2008 overachievers Ra Ra Riot neglecting nearly all of their strengths to go electronic on their new LP
column7: Beta Love
column8: and hopefully this can be the last time we ever have to mention POP ETC.

column1: While Christopher undoubtedly comes on strong
column2: the Ruby Suns sound undeniably invigorated here. For one thing
column3: they end up discovering new strengths
column4: as this kind of effusive sound fits McPhun's extroverted (and occasionally cloying) lyrics
column5: and his vocals turn out to be more melodically inclined than he's let on to this point. It also gives the Ruby Suns a sense of direction that was previously missing from the sunny
column6: island-hopping indie pop sampler of Sea Lion and Fight Softly's hesitant purveyance of post-chillwave synth murk. After McPhun's opening devotional
column7: the equally headspun ""In Real Life"" elaborates on a lyric from ""Desert of Pop""-- and its sound as well
column8: resulting in what feels like a smartly constructed medley. Having given himself over
column9: McPhun admits
column10: ""Real life wasn't what I wanted/ What I wanted was a waste of time
column11: opting instead for an untenable existence where you drink the days away
column12: completely free from the worries of money. Far more common than the getaways evoked on Sea Lion
column13: yet the escapism is every bit as intoxicating.

column1: But from there on out
column2: McPhun gets real with us-- in particular
column3: ""Kingfisher Call Me"" shows empathy for a misunderstood friend suffering through what he calls a ""psychological high school."" The balance of Christopher is addressed to people suffering from very specific kinds of teen angst. ""Dramatikk"" resembles the starstruck and spangled balladry of Autre Ne Veut
column4: and consoles a friend experiencing a breakup; as you could probably tell from the title ""Futon Fortress""
column5: its narrator can't even get out of bed but appears to be okay with that. ""Boy"" is a pep talk (""Do you hide in your room/ Away from dad/ To revel in your baseball card collection?"") and also a quasi revenge fantasy
column6: assuring a lonely kid that his foes ""will turn out losers in the end."" It reads embarrassing
column7: but these are the sort of unruly feelings that Capital-P pop helps people understand and even appreciate.

column1: Yet the Ruby Suns quickly lose their nerve and hooks about halfway through Christopher
column2: and it simply becomes a brighter
column3: albeit favorable
column4: take on Fight Softly's mushier innards
column5: only roused by a strange key change during ""Starlight"" and when they bring out the defibrillators for the closer
column6: ""Heart Attack"". The dissonance between the docile synth pop and unbridled urges maxes out on would-be cornerstone ""Jump In"". The title is once again a demonstrative one
column7: as McPhun aspires to live a life free of fears and inhibitions
column8: centering around the lyric
column9: ""When you reach the end of the world/ Don't wanna have no regrets."" By the time it's over
column10: he's asked about your underwear (really)
column11: got involved in a mutual striptease
column12: written a letter to a crush
column13: and sent it without proofreading. Christopher is certainly a welcome call to action from a band who could previously have been cast off as amiable roustabouts. The shame is that
column14: from a musical standpoint
column15:
Christopher is too often a result of Ruby Suns failing to take their own advice.

"|17517.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/17517-christopher/|5.8|Ian Cohen

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/18817/homepage_large.9f67988d.jpg|Goldenheart|30349.0|Dawn Richard|['Pop/R&B']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['self-released']|2013-01-23 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 17:02:38.424072|"

""Get ready for war
column2: Dawn Richard repeatedly intones on the intro to Goldenheart. She takes love very seriously: For Richard
column3: love has been religion
column4: scripture
column5: an all-changing force to be lamented and celebrated at the same time. On her long-awaited second album
column6: it's full-blown warfare. Goldenheart is the culmination of a fruitful few years for the former Danity Kane and Dirty Money singer: She helped to make Diddy's Last Train to Paris fascinating
column7: released one of last year's most stunning R&B records with the Armor On EP
column8: and worked with Israeli house producer Guy Gerber. Since leaving Diddy's watchful eye in 2010
column9: Richard has proven a fiercely independent force in a world dominated by name-dropping and endless collaboration. Goldenheart is the jewel in her crown.

column1: Richard is the kind of artist who believes in statements
column2: so naturally
column3: she uses the album format as a vehicle for a 16-song
column4: hour-plus opus about the trials of relationships. Real stuff: doubt
column5: power struggles
column6: insurmountable obstacles
column7: and hopeless
column8: life-saving devotion. Richard's subjects are simultaneously mundane and grandiose
column9: transcending usual pop fluff and turning her deeply personal subjects into epic tales of battle and salvation. If that sounds like a bit much
column10: well
column11: it is. But Richard has the personality to prop it all up. Her voice is a ghostly wail halfway between a howl and modern R&B melancholy
column12: effortlessly melismatic (check the Bollywood flourishes on ""Return of a Queen"")
column13: and capable of making her complex melodies glisten like an iridescent oil slick. On ""Gleaux""
column14: her processed voice shines as luminous as the sparkling stars the lyrics describe.

column1: Her shimmering vocals are paired with appropriately futuristic-sounding production from close working partner Andrew ""Druski"" Scott: tight and impressive
column2: yet rarely showy. She's always foregrounded
column3: occasionally leaning on the drums for emphasis as on ""Tug of War""
column4: (produced by the Fisticuffs)
column5: but more often using them as a canvas for her holographic paintings. And
column6: as with most R&B of the past half-decade
column7: Goldenheart heavily incorporates dance music
column8: though Richard's restrained aesthetic holds these tracks back from becoming overblown bangers; ""In Your Eyes"" folds in the cyan hues of trance without indulging the genre's excesses
column9: resulting in an unusually smooth house track. Even Richard's inevitable attempt at dubstep strikes gold with ""Pretty Wicked Things""
column10: a pounding industrial foray that literalizes the corruption and deception described in Dawn's lyrics. Though still landing on the more aggro side of the genre
column11: her flirtation with dubstep is more natural than the pop industry's usual taste for the stuff.

column1: Of course
column2: all that ""restraint"" has an effect-- Goldenheart feels about twice as long as it really is. A collection of 16 mostly midtempo tracks is going to turn tepid any way you look at it. Once you learn your way around the record's labyrinthine path
column3: it's an addictive world
column4: but one that you're more likely to pick and choose highlights from than sit all the way through. If you can
column5: however
column6: it's a grand journey through personal trials and tribulations. Relationships and emotions are presented with striking sagacity-- the incredible ""Tug of War"" wraps up the conflicted quest for dominance at the expense of another's power in a strident four minutes. Richard's flair for theatricality is unparalleled
column7: and almost exhausting by the end of the album
column8: with at least three possible elegiac endings: the peaceful ""Ode To You"" and ""Break of Dawn"" both hint towards resolution.

column1: In the intro to ""Warfaire
column2: a hushed Richard mutters ""I fight a battle every day
column3: against discouragement and fear... I must forever be on guard."" It's a little hammy
column4: sure
column5: but her earnest personality both endears and empowers her work. And Goldenheart is definitively
column6: completely her work; no guest stars and no flashy producers
column7: mostly her and Druski crafting her vision. It's not perfect
column8:
but it's closer than you'd expect from someone who just a few years ago was a member of a C-list girl group.

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/18733/homepage_large.14c497bd.jpg|B.M.W. EP|29688.0|Spaceghostpurrp|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['self-released']|2013-01-23 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 17:02:38.978312|"

In a year where rap label brass scrambled to sign buzzy talent
column2: Miami rapper SpaceGhostPurrp ended up in a pretty weird place-- on powerhouse British indie 4AD
column3: folded up into a roster that included Grimes and Purity Ring. He responded with the assured and detailed Mysterious Phonk: The Chronicles of SpaceGhostPurrp
column4: an album that found him inhabiting a smartly chosen array of styles
column5: zoning in on concrete-colored street montages and further articulating his own bleak worldview. The hedonistic
column6: violent lyrical free association that had colored early tapes like Blvcklvnd Rvdix 66.6 (1991) and Nasa the Mixtape was exchanged for more focus
column7: nuance
column8: and space. Around the same time
column9: SGP was also becoming tight with one of 2012's fastest rising rappers
column10: A$AP Rocky
column11: with whom he collaborated to produce frequent A$AP set-opener
column12: ""Pretty Flacko"". SGP is an unconventional
column13: sinisterly-minded MC
column14: to be sure
column15: but he was becoming a small star on his own terms
column16: aligning with folks angled upward
column17: and business blossoming thanks to continued placement and allure of his hypnotic
column18: druggy production.

column1: Soon
column2: Rocky and SpaceGhost's relationship disintegrated-- the reasons why depend on who you ask
column3: but just witness the hardly-veiled menace in Rocky's ""Jodye""-- and SGP returned to his native Florida
column4: re-engaging the music of his emergence with B.M.W.
column5: an EP in name only
column6: clocking in a hair shy of 50 minutes. Though SGP has never never broken too far from the droning
column7: chorus-free stripper anthems of his earliest work
column8: here he retreats fully into the world of his former nome de plume
column9: Muney Jordan
column10: snapping lines like
column11: ""I gotta whole lotta ice/ I'm gonna take you wife"" over rattling
column12: carsick production outfitted with 8-bit blips and samples of women moaning sexually.

column1: Notably absent is the relative clear-mindedness of calculated
column2: dark cult fare thoroughly referenced on Chronicles--  cuts like ""The Black God""
column3: a track (and a visual aesthetic) that wouldn't feel out of place rolled up on an iconic Wu-Tang Clan solo release. While B.M.W. is filled with polished versions of some SpaceGhostPurrp's hallmarks-- the drugged-up soul sample on ""Cum & Git Yuh Some
column4: the venomous chants on ""Rep FLA (Flawda)""-- it's the work of an artist who isn't quite sure what he wants to say or how he wants to say it. The largely unnotable posse Raider Klan don't add much.

column1: SpaceGhostPurrp is a hard guy to figure out and it seems like he's trying to keep it that way. The primer that accompanies the official download-- ""Instructions before listening to this EP : 1. Get yo weed 2. Get yo drank 3. Get yo pillz 4. Get yo coke 5. Get yo bitch 6. Get Phucked up 7. Then blast this shit ""-- jives with whatever message SGP is feeling at the moment; at one point
column2: he raps ""I ain't a hypocrite but I ain't perfect/ There is a higher power / Man I used to be an atheist / Until God made me reminisce / That the faith is the key to self
column3: I keep forgettin' it
column4: but then immediately recedes into his default
column5: desolate objectification. It all adds up to an uneven listen
column6:
to say the least.

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/18747/homepage_large.385da88d.jpg|Fabriclive 67|30976.0|Ben UFO|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Fabric']|2013-01-23 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 17:02:40.388003|"

It seems unnatural to call a musician an innovator when they haven't produced any original music of their own. But 27-year old DJ Ben UFO has done plenty for London's electronic underground just by being a selector. Alongside college friends and Hessle Audio co-founders Pearson Sound and Pangaea
column2: Ben Thomson was an early drum 'n bass turned dubstep enthusiast who encouraged the UK's quietly experimental take on the growing genre. He notes Loefah's ""Horror Show"" as an early influence
column3: and
column4: taking cues from Digital Mystikz
column5: Kode9's Hyperdub imprint
column6: and the newly garage-inflected sounds of a then-anonymous Burial
column7: Hessle Audio became a collective of DJs whose taste weighed as heavily as the quality of their releases.

column1: It's refreshing to see any DJ for that matter being heralded as a tastemaker by taking chances on others. In a time where file-sharing and free releases make vaults of exclusive tracks that much more impressive
column2: Thomson has inadvertently proved that the DJ's worth is one that can still be measured by the amount of trust his audience has put in him. As a result
column3: his induction into Fabric's hall of fame of late night DJ heroes with FabricLive 67 is unsurprising. Hessle has had a residency at the iconic club for years
column4: and his Rinse FM radio slot mirrors those nights via podcast. During those shows
column5: Thomson has championed the importance of actually interacting with his immediate environment-- filling the space of a room
column6: moderating the heaviness of the sound
column7: vibing with those around you-- and brings that same club-culture approach to his sets. There's an obsessive-compulsive tick that inevitably comes in hand; curating a crate
column8: playing a track
column9: assessing its impact
column10: and understanding where to go next.

column1: One can only imagine that his Fabric mix is reflective of those live sets as a result. His strength lies in emulating a club for headphone listening
column2: balancing skirmish
column3: goosebump-inducing drums with techno and garage accents that clatter and echo off of imaginary walls. Although speckled with Hessle releases
column4: the mix relies on visiting corners of the British and American dance underground-- from knocking Croydon dubstep
column5: the grittier side of acid house
column6: Detroit and Chicago favorites
column7: and cross-fusion touches of techno and funky. Mix Mup's ""Dub"" starts things off with a crawling anticipation before launching into the distorted
column8: hi-hat-crunching havoc of L.I.E.S. affiliate Delroy Edwards. Where Pev & Kowton's ""Raw Code"" combines their forces with minimal
column9: unassuming melodies and stripped-down drums
column10: the urgency remains in a tense bassline and carries our own anxieties along with it.

column1: The points of climax here are as disparate in construct as they are emotionally volatile. Mr Fingers' ""I'm Strong"" is a hands-in-the-air deep house epic where the ghostly wailing vocals of Robert Owens is as hypnotic as the chain-gang clank behind Pangaea's ""Release""-- so much so that you can almost hear a chant of ""hey
column2: hey"" in the warped noise sample that pushed the track forward. Blawan's ""And Both His Sons"" excavates the jittery
column3: sinister undertones that stealthily lurk in the mix all along with his rampaging kick-drums and menacing growls. Elsewhere Shackleton chops up the Congolese drums of Kasai Allstars with ""Mukuba Special"" before sucumbing to the bloated
column4: drone-like synth pull of Kyle Hall and Kero's ""Zug Island"".

column1: Thomson's art is in maintaining this wonderfully complex strung-out tension. In a recent interview he explained his selection habits as one that naturally followed in line with the birth of early 4/4 London garage. (In the mid 90s
column2: back-room rave and jungle DJs pitched up New York house records which ultimately led to beginner's 2-step.) Contextualizing older records like Herbert's 1996 gritty deep house banger ""Take Me Back"" or Minimal Man's 1993 acid classic ""Consexual"" with newer tangential stylings (Lowtec's ""Looser""
column3: for example) makes this a process that's both educational and forward-thinking. And while other young UK-based electronic experimentalists like Floating Points make it onto the mix
column4:
Thomson's heavy label love is a reminder that he's constantly one step ahead of the game.

"|17553.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/17553-fabriclive-67/|7.8|Puja Patel

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/18746/homepage_large.0e818946.jpg|We Are the 21st Century Ambassadors of Peace & Magic|30523.0|Foxygen|['Rock']|1.0|0.0|0.0|['Jagjaguwar']|2013-01-22 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 17:02:41.142020|"

Before you play a note
column2: your band begins as a series of decisions: Which bands inspire us? Who do we want to sound like? What are we going to call ourselves? These early triangulations often lead to everything else falling into place: bass lines
column3: vocal affectations
column4: guitar tones
column5: production
column6: album-art style. They say a lot about the band you intend to become. Sam France and Jonathan Rado
column7: a duo from L.A.
column8: decided at some point that they would be called Foxygen. Yes
column9: they were still in high school at the time. But when you pair that name with the unwieldy title We Are The 21st Century Ambassadors of Peace and Magic
column10: you get a certain picture: goofily endearing
column11: kid-brother types
column12: the kind of guys who will probably embarrass you in public if you let them. Which makes the assured and witty We Are that much more surprising.

column1: France and Rado have been playing together for years
column2: and they've apparently spent that time working through their relationships to their record collections. Faced with the terrifying bounty of the rock menu on their 2012 EP Take The Kids Off Broadway
column3: they seemingly shut their eyes and ordered everything at once: The songs stumbled through styles like there was a demented drill-sergeant producer in the background yelling
column4: ""OK now
column5: Memphis soul! Now
column6: when I say
column7: Merseybeat-era Beatles! GO!""

column1: We Are
column2: by contrast
column3: has more poise
column4: rifling with effortless cool through retro-rock quotes and mannerisms-- France's gulps and sobs draw directly from the Mick Jagger of ""Let's Spend the Night Together"" at one moment and channel the thousand-ton boredom of Lou Reed the next. Meandering organ pokes through on ""No Destruction""; flecks of ""Under My Thumb""-style guitars pop up on ""On Blue Mountain"". In the lovely ""San Francisco""
column5: France paints the city as a place where ""the forest meets the bridge
column6: and the grass scent of the Kinks' We Are the Village Green Preservation Society wafts by (even their album title is an echo of that one). Having a great record collection and having some idea what to do with it are two different things
column7: and on We Are The Ambassadors Foxygen have internalized enough of the music they love to start toying with it.

column1: As you spend more time with We Are
column2: you begin to notice some of that playfulness manifesting itself
column3: like the pitched-down vocals counting in the opening of ""On Blue Mountain""
column4: a song that rattles through multiple tempo and key changes without seeming disjointed. The warbly ""Oh Yeah"" can't seem to decide what kind of homage it is
column5: veering between a yearning Captain Fantastic falsetto chorus
column6: Blood Sweat & Tears symphonic soul
column7: and an ""aww-yeah"" breakdown that is a near-direct quote of ""Mr. Big Stuff"". The echoes are blurred further by producer Richard Swift
column8: a talented singer-songwriter with a meticulous ear for period detail. He follows the band's songwriting cues wherever they lead
column9: and Ambassadors seems to be reporting from  three simultaneous decades of rock history.

column1: France
column2: meanwhile
column3: has become a sharp storyteller and lyricist
column4: reeling off lines that feel like insults even if you can't parse them: ""I caught you sipping milkshakes in the parlor of the hotel
column5: he yawns on ""No Destruction""
column6: before delivering the piercingly direct (and already heavily quoted) stinger ""There's no need to be an asshole
column7: you're not in Brooklyn anymore."" On ""Shuggie""
column8: he sighs ""I met your daughter the other day
column9: that was weird/ She had rhinoceros-shaped earrings in her ears
column10: an arresting image that in context evokes an odd sense of sadness. The call-and-response chorus of ""San Francisco""--  ""I left my love in San Francisco/ (That's okay
column11: I was born in L.A.)""-- hits like a joke even if the target isn't clear.

column1: Slipped between the air quotes are proclamations that ring with personal truth: ""We can live on blue mountain like livin' in a sunset/ We can live honestly and true
column2: goes the chorus to ""On Blue Mountain"". On ""Shuggie""
column3: France sings ""If you believe in yourself
column4: you can free your soul."" He sings it in a warbly
column5: affected voice
column6: pulling a face at the sentiment slightly
column7: a trick he repeats at the album's coda
column8: where he keens in an off-key choirboy voice: ""If you believe in love/ Everything you see is love/ So try to be what God wants you to be/ And say that I love you/ Again."" It's one thing to give your band and your album a silly name
column9: and to play dress-up with rock history while tweaking the formula. It's another thing entirely to mean it; the more time you spend with Ambassadors
column10:
the more clearly that commitment and joy comes through.  

"|17552.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/17552-we-are-the-21st-century-ambassadors-of-peace-magic/|8.4|Jayson Greene

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/18510/homepage_large.3b98688c.jpg|Sometimes Good Weather Follows Bad People|651.0|Califone|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|1.0|['Jealous Butcher']|2013-01-22 00:00:00|2012|2016-06-11 17:02:41.714301|"

When Califone first came on the scene in 1998 they were hard to distinguish from the recently defunct Sub Pop band Red Red Meat. Both outfits were led by Chicago scene vet Tim Rutili
column2: both featured emerging producer Brian Deck as a band member and sonic mastermind
column3: both offered broken-down and narcotic spins on blues and folk with evocative titles that played on the gritty imagery of machines (""To Hush a Sick Transmission""
column4: ""Sad Cadillac""). For people who had followed Red Red Meat through the 90s
column5: from their noisy early recordings that put them in league with Royal Trux through their supremely crafted
column6: final two albums that found them in full studio-as-instrument mode
column7: Califone felt very much like an extension of that main band. Eventually
column8: Califone would explore more gentle and song-oriented material as well as delving into pure soundtrack work
column9: and would develop their own idenity-- but during the time of their self-titled 1998 and 2000 EPs
column10: they were pretty much a slightly lower-fi Red Red Meat.

column1: That once-fuzzy line is blurred further on the vinyl reissue of Sometimes Good Weather Follows Bad People
column2: a set that gathers Califone's first two EPs. Both were initially self-titled and issued on small labels (Flydaddy and Road Cone) and they were first gathered together under this title in 2002. So this is in a sense a reissue of a reissue
column3: but this 2xLP edition of Good Weather
column4: in addition to its fine packaging
column5: adds potentially enticing extras on side four: 17 minutes of unreleased Red Red Meat material
column6: culled from their final recording sessions.

column1: The two EPs
column2: spread across the first three sides
column3: still sound great. Rutili and co. were up to something special in the final years of the 20th century. They took sonic inspiration from ancient folk 78s and Jamaican dub
column4: along with songwriting and arrangement inspiration from Tom Waits
column5: and came up with a fresh and affecting music that ranged from ethereal slowcore to blistering noise. In comparison to late Red Red Meat
column6: Califone was a little quieter
column7: a little prettier
column8: and a little wearier. The highlights on the EPs are delicate ballads like the steel drum-inflected ""Silvermine Pictures"" and the gorgeous piano-led ""Electric Fence""
column9: but spikier cuts like ""To Hush a Sick Transmission"" and ""Dock Boggs"" showed how they integrated clangy percussion and electronics into the mix. The rawness of this early material still resonates.

column1: The four new songs on the final side
column2: however
column3: don't transcend ""bonus track"" status. ""Bath Water"" is a winding ballad with a reasonably catchy chorus hook
column4: but it sounds like an ultra-simple and stripped down demo
column5: something laid to tape just to preserve the basics of the song. ""June Rat"" is sung by Tim Hurley and feels like a sketch. The RRM version of ""Pastry Sharp"" is simple
column6: highlighting the strong melody but missing from the atmosphere of Califone's studio version. The full-band take on ""A Horse-Sized Pill"" is the one song that seems like it could fit on a proper Red Red Meat album
column7: though it's very similar to (and is seriously outclassed by) Bunny Gets Paid's ""Rosewood
column8: Stax
column9: Volts and Glitter"".

column1: As bonus material goes
column2: it's all fine
column3: and hardcore RRM/Califone completists (and let's face it
column4: there aren't many of us out there) will appreciate the look at material in its formative stages. But most people will give that fourth side a single play at most. The first three
column5: though
column6: hold up nicely
column7:
capturing one small-scale and deceptively interesting band as it molted and emerged from another.

Ex Cops are a curious signing for Manhattan record store Other Music's new label. Where the shop has developed an international reputation for its expertly curated selection of obscure psychedelia
column2: electronica
column3: cult hero reissues
column4: and other esoterica from around the world
column5: Ex Cops are as traditional an indie-pop act as they come; one that
column6: in the past month alone
column7: has issued faithful covers of both a Paul McCartney holiday standard and a classic Replacements video. But as you delve into the band's debut
column8: True Hallucinations

column1: For the duo of Brian Harding and Amalie Bruun

column3: in the form recently re-popularized by fellow east coasters Wild Nothing
column4: DIIV
column5: and the Pains of Being Pure at Heart. You wouldn't know it from True Hallucinations' opening
column6: ""S&HSXX
column7: a dark
column8: synth-powered instrumental set to a rhythm track sampled from Genesis' mid-'80s hit

column10: that gets the album off to an incongruously icy
column11: ominous beginning. But before long
column12: the sugar-rush swoon of ""Ken"" and ""James"" provide an instant realignment of Ex Cops' aims

column1: Ex Cops become a more interesting
column2: impressive band once they start straying further afield
column3: however
column4: tracing dream pop's evolution through the euphoric
column5: pulse-quickening highs of Feels-era Animal Collective (""Billy Pressly"")
column6: the laser-guided Spiritualized sax surges of ""Jazz & Information""
column7: the locomotive Flying Nun-worthy whirr of ""Broken Chinese Chairz""
column8: and the vintage 4AD flashback that is ""Separator"". (When the latter's beautifully melancholic riff cuts out during the second verse
column9: leaving Harding and Bruun's airy sighs to hang above a brooding bassline
column10: you get a sense of what the Pixies' ""Monkey Gone to Heaven"" might sound like through the space-bound simian's ears.) Meanwhile
column11: the knowingly titled ""Nico Beast"" takes us back to where this strung-out strain of rock 'n' roll all began-- i.e.
column12: the corner of Lexington and 125.

column1: However
column2: more than merely showcase Harding and Bruun's well-cultivated record collections
column3: True Hallucinations is a testament to the duo's unfailingly snappy songcraft and how naturally it can adapt to different forms and settings; even the album's most languorous moment
column4: the moonstruck ballad ""The Millionaire""

column7: androgynous coo; step on tremolo pedal-- but it's an awfully hard one to keep fresh

column9:
True Hallucinations is ultimately a triumph of focus and discipline.

Over the course of three full-length albums
column2: Reading Rainbow has been three distinctly different bands. On 2009's Mystical Participation
column3: founding members (and spouses) Rob Garcia and Sarah Everton ran bubblegum melodies through a grime-filled trench of hiss and reverb; it hardly seemed like a band at all at this point
column4: but rather an extended flirtation conducted over a lo-fi recording deck. On 2010's Prism Eyes
column5: Reading Rainbow suddenly embraced clarity and rock 'n roll assertiveness
column6: pushing against their limitations as a two-piece to make the loudest
column7: poppiest noise possible. On their new record
column8: Yeah Right
column9: Reading Rainbow has made its biggest change-up yet. For starters
column10: they're now known as Bleeding Rainbow. (Apparently the name change was prompted by a disparaging remark from Carrie Brownstein
column11: though that could be embellishment.) More importantly
column12: Bleeding Rainbow has expanded to a quartet
column13: with Everton surrendering the drums to Greg Frantz
column14: and Al Creedon joining Garcia on guitar.

column1: These changes
column2: presumably
column3: were intended to remake Bleeding Rainbow on Yeah Right like Dylan Baldi transformed Cloud Nothings into a hard-hitting post-punk outfit on last year's Attack on Memory
column4: or how the Pains of Being Pure at Heart morphed into a widescreen '90s alt-rock group on 2011's Belong. Like those groups
column5: Reading Rainbow was frequently described as ""twee"" or ""cutesy""-- an image Everton has expressed reservations about in interviews. Based on Yeah Right
column6: Garcia and Everton would rather Bleeding Rainbow be seen as a dark
column7: dreamy shoegaze-infused pop band. You know
column8: cool. Unfortunately
column9: Garcia and Everton aren't very good at being cool
column10: and were better off when they weren't trying to be.

column1: The most disappointing aspect of Yeah Right is how doubling the band's size hasn't made Bleeding Rainbow sound any fuller or more powerful. Frantz's drumming isn't noticeably better than Everton's rudimentary time-keeping
column2: and aside from the occasional would-be psychedelic interlude
column3: Creedon's leads don't add much to the equation. What this line-up has accomplished is giving Bleeding Rainbow a more professional sound
column4: though the dubious likes of the paint-by-numbers MBV homage ""Shades of Eternal Night"" and the corny boy-girl duet ""Inside My Head"" hardly make this seem like a plus. Prism Eyes' fantastic lead-off track ""Wasting Time"" is more anthemic than anything on Yeah Right
column5: and its guileless enthusiasm is sadly missing amid this album's calculated trend-grabs. The handmade quality that made Bleeding Rainbow's first two records so likeable and indelible is absent on Yeah Right; in its place is the serviceable but somewhat generic late 80s/early 90s fuzz pop that's become a default setting for aspirant indie bands.

column1: Strangely
column2: about half of Yeah Right sounds like leftovers from Bleeding Rainbow's former incarnations. These also happen to be the record's best songs. The gutted-out ""Fall Into Your Eyes"" is simultaneously mysterious and innocent
column3: running its hymn-like melody through a buzzsaw of mechanical scrapes and squawks. ""Waking Dream"" is at the opposite end of the sonic spectrum-- its sunny melody and 60s pop bounce conjures the magic of Prism Eyes with a deep
column4: nostalgic pang. ""Pink Ruff"" is another keeper
column5: zipping along on a snappy rhythm guitar riff that approaches the fresh-faced rock this band once specialized in. Yeah Right has its charms
column6:
but they're echoes of a band Bleeding Rainbow used to be under a slightly different name.

When Esben and the Witch released their 2011 debut
column3: Violet Cries

column5: Austra
column6: Chelsea Wolfe)
column7: and
column8: as Jayson Greene concluded in his review of the album
column9: ""the cumulative impact [was] more tepid than bone-chilling."" The Hexagons EP released later that year diluted the debut's hints of darkness even further. But the band's new album

column13: like Warpaint or Wild Beasts.

column3: she sings on the hypnotic ""Shimmering""

column1: That said

column3: ""Despair""
column4: where clawing guitars build to a vicious climax

column9: dissonant guitars riff out to a galloping
column10: near-proggy conclusion.

column7:

We like to think of artists as straining against their limitations
column2: pushing boundaries
column3: confounding expectations
column4: and provoking listeners. This framework makes it easy to underestimate the kind of ambition Chaz Bundick's demonstrated within the context of Toro Y Moi. He's a prolific artist who never comes off like he's in a race with his muse; he subtly expands his range and refines his production skills
column5: but in genres uniformly bereft of bombast or overstatement. Even after 2011's rep-solidifying Underneath the Pine and its equally worthy successor
column6: the Freaking Out EP
column7: many still want to view him as the guy whose earliest singles became definitive documents of a subgenre synonymous with apathy. So Anything in Return can appear like it has Big Third Album things to prove
column8: ambitious in easily understood ways: it's the longest Toro Y Moi album and the loudest as well. It just manages to do those things on Bundick's self-effacing
column9: generous terms. Which shouldn't obscure Anything In Return's accomplishment of being another strong
column10: forward-thinking record from an artist whose grasp never seems to exceed his reach.

column1: Anything in Return serves as a tidy synopsis of everywhere Bundick has taken Toro Y Moi to date. So there's silky R&B
column2: roller-rink pop
column3: bubblegum funk
column4: tasteful chillout music
column5: all unified by a voice that's grown more confident with time. The light touch he applies to his melodies sounds assured rather than meek. The higher BPMs early on make Bundick's peripheral relationship to dance music more overt. He's been on the giving and receiving end of countless remixes and revived his Les Sins project for a partnership with Dan Snaith's Jiaolong label
column6: so he's had plenty of chances to workshop with similarly-minded artists. ""Harm In Change"" is where he shows the results; unlike the introductions from Causers of This or Underneath the Pine
column7: Anything In Return doesn't begin on a wobbly note
column8: rousing itself into shape. The bass drum hits almost immediately
column9: and along with single ""Say That""
column10: ""Harm In Change"" incorporate gestures that would typically have to wait until the inevitable remix make themselves heard: house diva samples serving as punctuation on his own vocal lines
column11: four-on-the-floor beats
column12: modular synth bass
column13: all distinguishing it from the decisively organic Underneath the Pine.

column1: That said
column2: it isn't dance music proper
column3: nor does it aim to be. You might already be hearing it as a potential go-to for rooftops
column4: house parties
column5: or any non-club function
column6: or perhaps as dress-up/go-out music for people who don't relate to ""Suit & Tie"". Anything in Return never feels exclusionary
column7: so the extroversion of the music and the increasingly tony production ensures that any mention of Toro Y Moi as a ""bedroom"" act has to relate to the lyrical concerns only. ""So Many Details"" follows the uptempo introductory duo with a seductive slow grind and cooed lyrics (""This ain't appropriate…I just want to tease your eyes"") that project a polite sort of lasciviousness before unraveling into a hint-dropping
column8: percussive coda. ""Rose Quartz"" consolidates what came before it
column9: two minutes of patient
column10: hands-in-the-air build up before establishing its central juxtaposition of instinctual desires and metaphysical hesitance-- ""Don't let me fall/ 'cause I feel weak.""

column1: As with his previous two LPs
column2: Bundick bookends Anything in Return with the most instantly captivating material
column3: while the middle ultimately establishes the determinative mood. This is where Anything in Return truly differentiates itself. Causers of This took was an immersive experience
column4: aqueous and aquamarine
column5: while the ornate and warm Underneath the Pine painted with pastels; Anything In Return is better described by its shape and body rather than its color. While Toro Y Moi is more or less characterized as portable music
column6: you really should consider a nice subwoofer for this one.

column1: This newfound emphasis on the low-end counters his tendency to let songs drift. This is particularly true on tracks that would otherwise be the most stereotypically chillaxed: ""High Living"" anchors itself with bass that lets the good times roll very
column2: very slowly
column3: ""Studies"" lays nasally funk guitar over an insistent drum break
column4: the champagne-swilling ""Touch"" fizzes but never goes flat. It can actually get a little too lost in its luxury; Anything in Return has more truly great music than any Toro Y Moi album
column5: but at 52 minutes
column6: the overall impact gets dulled. When ""Cake"" pops up as the 10th track<i>
column7: it's by far Bundick's most assertively-sung
column8: and the stickiest as well. It's a revelation for him as an artist
column9: but the startling jolt it provides after the midsection makes you feel like the Anything kicked its feet up for about 10 minutes too long.

column1: Anything in Return could still be called ""lifestyle music"" in the pejorative sense. If you think Toro Y Moi exists solely as a sonic accessory for buying tote bags
column2: this album won't do much to change your mind
column3: largely because it doesn't really want to. But Toro Y Moi's music has a relatable quality that can't be overlooked. The most direct lines tend to be fourth-wall busting mentions of being on tour
column4: having no plans on Friday night
column5: and trying to sort out girl problems
column6: especially when they're freaking out about failing a class and how to explain it to their parents.

column1: While tech-obsessed
column2: sonically omnivorous
column3: and emotionally distracted music typically serves as fodder for ""sound of life today"" thinkpieces
column4: Anything in Return embodies a certain ideal of young adulthood at the pace it's actually lived; of fluidity between creative pursuits and careers
column5: between hanging out and making out. It's tough to say whether Bundick is seeking to make a ""statement"" as Toro Y Moi
column6: no more than any of his peers are seeking to define themselves with a nine-to-five (in fact
column7: his definitive song ""Blessa"" may have been about the futility of just that). But the occasional structure is helpful for an artist constantly plotting his next move. For now
column8:
the musically and emotionally rewarding Anything in Return evokes the feeling of being young with options and in no hurry to figure it all out.

"|17516.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/17516-anything-in-return/|7.9|Ian Cohen

The Brooklyn electro-acoustic duo Mountains have finally landed in a place as vast and awe-inspiring as the landforms they're named after. This is an album that causes you to view everything the band did before a little differently
column2: turning 2011's Air Museum into a transitional piece
column3: a necessary step in the build toward Centralia. Koen Holtkamp and Brendon Anderegg seem to alter their working methods with each passing release
column4: choosing here to separately layer acoustic and electronic instruments
column5: not manipulating the former with the latter. The technical details aren't too important; to pick apart who did what and where would cause Centralia to lose some of its magic. Instead
column6: it's better to just fall into it
column7: letting it wash over you again and again. The actual <a href=""http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Centralia
column8: _Pennsylvania"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">Centralia is a ghost town in Pennsylvania
column9: a place with a population barely in double figures
column10: condemned by a 1962 mine fire that made it largely uninhabitable. It couldn't be less appropriate as a title-- this Centralia is rich with connection
column11: bustling with possibility. It's got life pulsing through it.

column1: This is an album that finds Mountains expanding outward
column2: replacing bungalows with steeples. Brian Howe noted that the duo ""like a big canvas"" in his review of Air Museum
column3: but nothing from that album feels as all-encompassing as their work here. They've added a touch more movement to their music
column4: with the perma-halt they get locked into mostly intact. But those changes in tone are often startling and moving when they appear. It's there in the unexpected rush of noise halfway through ""Propeller""
column5: and in the lulling cello at the close of ""Sand"". Still
column6: nothing resembles traditional song form
column7: with Holtkamp and Anderegg finding strength in great circular drones
column8: ring-shaped synth accents
column9: and ruminative acoustic picking. Mostly it feels like more thought went into this work than prior Mountains records
column10: with the inclination to spread themselves wide birthed through a rigorous attention to detail. There's a strong sense of objective and design
column11: a feeling of being taken somewhere instead of getting deadlocked in one mood
column12: one place.

column1: That sense of creating shifting conditions is a key differentiator between this and any similar works. Centralia is primarily concerned with beauty and contact
column2: creating hypnotic melodies that resonate with meaning as their looped paths uncoil. It's music to get lost in on a certain level
column3: but you can feel pliable human emotions tugging hard on your shoulder throughout. Partly that's due to Mountains improving at integrating their earthy and otherworldly impulses. The acoustic plucking and blocky drones of ""Circular C"" don't feel like they're drawn from separate strains of thought
column4: pushing folk traditions and analog synthesis together as if they were always meant to co-exist. Mountains' guitar work has often resembled Ben Chasny's Six Organs of Admittance output
column5: and that remains a constant here
column6: especially in ""Tilt""
column7: a track that gathers poignancy as it gains momentum. Here
column8: they're as skilled at change as they are at staying lost in time.

column1: It's to Centralia's great credit that its 20-minute centerpiece
column2: ""Propeller""
column3: doesn't completely dwarf everything that comes before and after. ""Propeller"" is huge and masterful
column4: the fullest embodiment of the ""pure phase"" aesthetic Jason Pierce was working toward on the Spiritualized album of the same name. The fact that it's a live recording
column5: albeit one sweetened by a few studio tweaks
column6: is particularly impressive considering the immaculate way all the parts twist around one another. It's here that the possibilities for this music seem boundless. This is music for wide open spaces
column7: full of reach and depth. It's not exactly Mountains' gambit for the big time
column8: but it is the kind of track that could open them up to a wider audience
column9: principally because it takes what they do so well-- repetitive motions executed with ample emotional impact-- and blows it wide open. There are even a few power chords thrown into the following ""Liana""
column10: further emphasizing the maximal strength Mountains have harvested for this release.

column1: Holtkamp and Anderegg's bursts of robustness on Centralia don't quite tell the full story. It's matched by a tenderness that occasionally mirrors the kind of blues Dave Pajo was feeling circa Papa M's Live from a Shark Cage
column2: and a hush that Jason Noble was reaching for in the post-classical outfit
column3: Rachel's. There's a continuity between this and prior Mountains releases
column4: but it's more grandiose than Choral
column5: more focussed than Air Museum. In its longer stretches it's similar to the no-waste ethic of Swans' The Seer
column6: where every tiny detail serves the bigger picture
column7: where nothing in an ostensibly open-ended piece is allowed to drift unattached. Centralia is less severe than The Seer
column8: but it's executed with the same unyielding desire to move and to feel. It's impressive how multi-purpose some of the tracks can be. You can zone out to the one-note drone that ""Sand"" arcs into for a while
column9: only to be yanked somewhere else altogether when a great slide of strings pulls you down. That's the spot Mountains inhabit
column10: in a capacious synchronization of the real and the unreal
column11:
a space they've gloriously matured into.

Over the course of their seven-year career
column2: Ra Ra Riot have

column7: The Orchard

column9: Beta Love

column13: Ra Ra Riot incorporated more keyboards and synthesizers into many of the songs on Beta Love. This new technology-informed attitude represents a necessary change for a band known mostly for one thing.

The keyboards stabbing at Beta Love opener ""Dance With Me"" set the tone for the album's overall harder
column3: faster tempos

column6: tell me why/ I want to read you with this binary mind/ 'Cause if I do/ I'm sure that we'll be complete."" Later
column7: ""Angel
column8: Please"" picks up where that track's hi-NRG left off

column10: intonation
column11: and the use of ""angel"" as romantic epithet (the tambourines and handclaps don't hurt
column12: either). To his credit

column14: even if he strains it to Jemaine Clement levels of absurdity on the R&B-leaning slow jam ""Wilderness"". And Miles takes sexy too far on ""What I Do For U""

column4: the album's haunting high point
column5: provides a template for how Beta Love could have worked. Instead of overcrowding with layers of instrumentation
column6: Ra Ra Riot play off a similarly minimal heartbeat pulse
column7: filling the spaces between with single piano chords as opposed to a continually bursting synthesizers. When they do build to the subtle climaxes
column8: Zeller's violin swells and the finger snaps click into place at precisely the right time. But the moment is lost on the rabid drum fills on follower ""That Much""
column9: which returns to the bombast that relentlessly drives the rest of the album.

column1: It's unclear where Ra Ra Riot will go from here. After some bad tours and the departure of cellist Alexandra Lawn
column2: the brasher tracks on Beta Love come across  as cathartic
column3: as though the band is doing a silly dance or yelling obscenities as a necessary release from a stagnant situation. If that is the case
column4:
then the album's understated moments are a reassuring reminder that Ra Ra Riot still have some of The Rhumb Line in them.

0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/18705/homepage_large.92f93198.jpg|Oak Island|29101.0|Nightlands|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Secretly Canadian']|2013-01-21 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 17:02:46.194403|"

Dave Hartley begins his second album as Nightlands simply enough: ""I'd like to invite you/ For just for a little while/ To a place I used to go/ When I was only 17."" ""Time and Place"" is an offer of comfort and warm nostalgia
column2: almost impossible to be read multiple ways. Yet the manner in which it's actually sung raises a question that goes to the core of songwriting: who exactly is ""I"" here? Hartley's obviously the guy standing in front of a microphone
column3: but he's harmonized at least four layers deep
column4: airbrushing any sort of human impurity that defines ""personal"" expression. And besides
column5: how is this technologically defiled sound indicative of someone's teen years? It's a big-concept
column6: low-budget rendering of the space age sound redolent of any of the movies that came out as an immediate result of Star Wars. If Hartley is indeed 52 years old
column7: he's a young-looking 52. However
column8: let it rush past you like a gust of brisk mountain air once the drums come in
column9: and it's quite lovely.

column1: So it goes on Oak Island
column2: 35 minutes of romantic and robotic soft rock
column3: a crush mixtape for the Uncanny Valley. It doesn't have specific forebears
column4: though recent trends in indie rock at least give it precedent; Gayngs' perverted take on 10cc
column5: Bon Iver's autotuned Hornsby homage ""Beth/Rest
column6: and specifically Destroyer's Kaputt in the use of the delayed trumpets that waft through Hartley's ""So Far So Long"". All of these are examples of stylistic music that uses the studio as a means of reducing human error
column7: or at least achieving some higher level of musicianship while letting the listener know just how much it cost to attempt such feats. Hartley takes it further on Oak Island by just about erasing the idea of it ever being performed by three or four men in a room. It's intentionally android
column8: but not the kind of dystopian man-machine mind-meld explored by
column9: say
column10: Kid A or Silent Shout.

column1: These are mostly love songs
column2: though the juxtapositions of the synthetic
column3: multilayered sonics with the simply worded lyrics of ""You're My Baby"" or ""Born To Love"" turn the record as a whole into a kind of long-form pun about phrases like ""motherboard"" or ""you were made for me""; playing with the idea of our potential to be figuratively programmed into certain roles or romantic desires. As such
column4: while I know full and well that Nightlands is the project of Dave Hartley
column5: bassist of War on Drugs and occasional NBA writer
column6: it's much easier to imagine it as the narrator of Daft Punk's ""Something About Us"" coping with a broken heart.

column1: The album cover can be taken as a pretty good allowance that the listener has free rein to get as fantastical as they want when imagining the physical space occupied by Oak Island. Maybe this will sound great in summer
column2: but I can tell you it's a fantastic accompaniment for winter: so much of the digitally processed and pitch-shifted guitar shimmers like tinsel
column3: the percussion jingles
column4: nylon strings
column5: and dulcimers contribute to a mix that's thick and boozy as eggnog. Even the melodies hint at Yuletide: ""So Far So Long"" and ""Other Peoples Pockets"" have cyclical
column6: massed choruses that sound a lot like caroling.

column1: It could've all turned out to be an insufferable gimmick had Hartley not managed to cover a lot of ground by making odd turns into peripheral genres; ""Born To Love"" is a slow dance on the lido deck
column2: ""I Fell in Love With a Feeling"" boasts a revved-up beat and emotional yearning that puts it within the Springsteen-to-Twin Shadow lineage of pouty motorcycle heroics
column3: while the stacked ELO harmonies and nerdy horns cut against the machismo. It gets even more bizarre towards the end: ""Rolling Down The Hill"" works itself into an Afro-funk frenzy while the stately ""Other Peoples Pockets"" is nearly hymnal. It's played straight and
column4: as such
column5: is paradoxically weirder than what came before.

column1: There are no clues as to why it's called Oak Island and I don't necessarily think Googling it would enrich the experience. Actual trees
column2: let alone the mighty oak
column3: have no place in this landscape. But the ""island"" part I do get; it could be a cult favorite. I can't imagine it becoming anyone's primary influence
column4: and whether the pleasure is solely in the visitation rather than what you can take back with you
column5:
Nightlands have created something that's utterly self-contained.

"|17512.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/17512-oak-island/|7.7|Ian Cohen

column2:
the Army|30481.0|Mike Shiflet|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Under the Spire']|2013-01-21 00:00:00|2012|2016-06-11 17:02:46.793576|"

Abstract music usually involves an element of chance. Even the most precise noise or drone contains moments in which the creator reacts to the creation rather than controlling it. That factor of randomness makes it tough to improve and refine a particular approach
column3: but in the past few years
column4: that's exactly what Mike Shiflet has done. From 2010's Llanos to 2011's Sufferers and Merciless
column5: Shiflet has found new possibilities in his sound by diving deeper into it. In my review of Merciless
column6: I almost called that album his peak
column7: and I'm glad I held out: <i>The Choir
column8: the Army is undoubtedly his best release to date.

column1: Exactly why it's the best is hard to summarize
column2: since there's so much happening in the album's nine rich
column3: ever unfolding tracks. But one standout reason is the way Shiflet's array of tones and techniques-- ambiance
column4: dissonance
column5: melody
column6: repetition-- feel like integral parts of a natural whole. This isn't simply a matter of track sequencing or transitions. It's also the overwhelming sense that every song is guided by a single hand
column7: and every sound plays an equal role. So a blast of static in one piece can feel uncannily similar to a distant bass in another. The resulting cohesion makes<i> The Choir
column8: the Army a kind of wordless story
column9: with each track more like a chapter in a book or a scene in a movie than a song in a collection.

column1: This narrative line is clear from the start. Just compare the first two tracks
column2: the sparse
column3: rattling ""1917"" and the dense
column4: grand ""Zahlentheorie"". On the surface
column5: in the sounds they use and the spaces they fill
column6: the tracks are practically opposites. But the way Shiflet builds them
column7: widening their sonic scope as if he's panning and zooming a camera
column8: they end up feeling like twins. This connective tissue gives him the freedom to trace a wide
column9: diverse path
column10: from the construction-site rattle of ""Attrition"" to the glitchy atmospherics of ""False Flats"" to the trebly whirr of ""Omicron Serenade""
column11: and without ever losing his sense of direction.

column1: It also gives The Choir
column2: the Army an emotional resonance that's not easy to coax from music this abstract. It's there in the shifting grooves of ""Asymptotes""
column3: which morphs random clanging into a kind of evocative noise choir. The warped waves of ""Passenchendale"" are poignantly blurry
column4: echoing the hazy distortion of memory. And there's a hint of Stars of the Lid's stoic longing in the slow-but-tense drift of ""Inching"". Throughout
column5: Shiflet lets his sounds build and arc
column6: never forcing them into shapes or interrupting their flow to grab your attention. In other words
column7: they often feel more like life than art.

column1: Yet the song that I find myself coming back to most is the one with the most obvious artifice. Closer ""Yonder"" offers the most layers of any track
column2: and for the first time you can see the skeleton beneath Shiflet's sonic skin. It's made of tape hiss
column3: rolling static
column4: violin-like creak
column5: and an achingly off-key guitar that adds both creepy aura and nostalgic sadness. But Shiflet's consistent vision gives ""Yonder""'s transparency as much impact as anything on <i>The Choir
column6: the Army. In a way
column7: it represents the album perfectly: varied sounds that achieve a unified goal
column8:
and make you itch to hear them again.

"|17638.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/17638-the-choir-the-army/|7.8|Marc Masters

column3:
'Young Turks']|2013-01-18 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 17:02:47.407509|"

SBTRKT's 2011 self-titled debut was a welcome breakthrough. In a year when bass music was getting further acquainted with the charts on both sides of the Atlantic
column4: SBTRKT found a way to streamline producer Aaron Jerome's clean
column5: rhythmically intricate yet suitably catchy style into a sound that felt distinctly aboveground. And while guest spots from singers like Jessie Ware and Little Dragon's Yukimi Nagano took SBTRKT's compatibility with R&B and indie pop to its logical conclusion
column6: it was the yearning
column7: gentle murmuring of regular collaborator Sampha that proved to be the most characteristic and distinct voice on the record.

column1: In the following year
column2: SBTRKT took his show on the road
column3: and a real sense of showmanship-- elaborate masks
column4: quick shifts from programmed to live percussion
column5: Sampha's presence as a singer and multi-instrumentalist-- made those concerts a sensory-overload experience. That energy's visually borne out in the two videos that come with the LP/DVD version of Live
column6: an album culled from a pair of shows recorded at London venue Shepherds Bush Empire last October. But unfortunately those video excerpts are the closest this set comes to doing justice to what seems like it could've been an exciting series of shows. Because if there's one thing that threatens to ruin the atmosphere of a really tight performance like this
column7: it's a foggy recording
column8: mixing
column9: or mastering job that fails to capture the dynamic pop of SBTRKT's drums
column10: whether programmed or behind the kit.

column1: It's not quite bootleg cameraphone-recording quality
column2: but from the outset of ""Surely"" it's clear something's up-- what should be crisp
column3: resonant snares sound like cardboard
column4: kicks feel mushy
column5: and hi-hats have the weak timbre of rattling chain link fences. It's a shame
column6: because this version takes what was a fairly forgettable bonus 7"" from the LP version of SBTRKT and ups its tempo
column7: using it as a good base to rhythmically improvise some glitchy freeform beats and turning an afterthought into an anthem. Sampha's voice suffers
column8: too-- its strength is in his subtlety
column9: and while he sounds powerful over minimal accompaniment
column10: a lot of nuance is lost when he sings over heavy instrumentation. What should be the most emotional moments on ""Never Never"" and ""Trials of the Past"" give the unfair illusion that he's short of breath and trying to catch up.

column1: Everything else about Live seems almost secondary to the cruddy sound quality
column2: but it'd be a shame to detract from what SBTRKT was going for here. The addition of London's Heritage Orchestra on tracks like ""Trials of the Past"" and ""Go Bang"" isn't your typical class-up-the-joint schmaltz move; the strings really do wring out some additional emotional highs. The version of ""Wildfire"" is deliriously inspired
column3: as SBTRKT takes Nagano's voice and chops it up into a stammering percussive riff
column4: extending one of his signature singles into a high-energy sprawl. And one previously unheard track
column5: the surprisingly techno-indebted ""Migration"" (a segue out of SBTRKT highlight ""Hold On"")
column6:
definitely gives followup-hungry fans something more to look forward to for the next release. This concert album's heart is in the right place. It's too bad that the mics weren't.

As 2013 began
column2: Ty Segall quietly released a 7""-- ""This Time I Got a Reason"" came out on Trouble in Mind under the band name Fuzz. It's his sludgy stoner metal studio project with his friend and frequent collaborator Charles Mootheart
column3: and while the song isn't exactly deep
column4: it's a wholly satisfying nugget of 1970s hard rock. Aside from being yet another notch in his famous prolific streak
column5: it's a natural step for Segall to start the year with a new project. As he explained to Spin
column6: he thrives in the studio. ""I've been on tour for three years straight
column7: basically. It's not my favorite thing; recording is. It's so fun
column8: he said
column9: adding
column10: ""You can get weird."" And throughout his recording career
column11: he's gotten weird time and time again with a revolving door of collaborators: Thee Oh Sees
column12: Sic Alps
column13: White Fence
column14: and most frequently
column15: his old friend Mikal Cronin.

column1: Around 2006
column2: Segall and Cronin started the Laguna Beach garage punk band Epsilons
column3: and since then
column4: they've worked together several times. The duo were both in the short-lived hardcore band Party Fowl
column5: and Cronin has been a member of Segall's touring band for quite a while. Most recently
column6: Cronin's harmonies and bass were an essential contribution to Slaughterhouse. And unsurprisingly
column7: Segall was in the studio to help with Cronin's excellent self-titled debut LP. But as one man comes off his 2012 three-album hot streak while the other just signed to Merge for his second solo record
column8: the weirdness of their 2009 collaborative album Reverse Shark Attack doesn't hold up.

column1: The album's first six tracks are garage songs washed in acid-soaked sonics
column2: and they're ultimately unremarkable when stacked next to the rest of either man's discography. Throughout the album
column3: Segall and Cronin tap into John Dwyer-ian psychedelics
column4: and with pitched-down throaty vocals
column5: the effects feel like a gimmick and cheapens the material. Their more straightforward readings of ""I Wear Black""
column6: for example
column7: are immediately more interesting than the markedly slower studio version. (Evidence: the Daytrotter version.) But when they stick the landing on their more psychedelic tendencies
column8: the results are extremely satisfying. Easily
column9: the best tracks on the album are the final two: Their muddy-but-faithful cover of Pink Floyd's Piper at the Gates of Dawn cut ""Take Up Thy Stethoscope and Walk"" and their 10-minute opus ""Reverse Shark Attack"". The title track switches gears several times
column10: incorporating bubbly psych pop
column11: soft acoustic guitars
column12: a Dick Dale fast-surf outro
column13: and the same sort of slow-burning melodrama you could hear in the Pallbearer album. For a song that jumps around to a few different melodic devices
column14: they're strung together beautifully.

column1: Reverse Shark Attack is a fine example of the downsides to getting weird in the studio. Sometimes
column2: you strike gold. Sometimes
column3: veering into psychedelic territory makes your songs sound unnecessarily cheap. It stands in contrast to Ty's work with the Traditional Fools
column4: who shy away from additional effects and stick to drunken
column5: lo-fi budget rock. In 2008
column6: the trio-- Segall
column7: David Fox
column8: and Andrew Luttrell-- bashed out a series of trashy surf punk songs
column9: four of which are just over one minute long. (That proved to be a troglodyte year for Segall-- he also released his raucous one-man-band debut solo album on Castle Face.) And really
column10: if the sunglasses-clad cheeseburgers on the cover don't already give you a sense of the album's overall vibe
column11: the track titles should: ""Snot Rag""
column12: ""Shredstick""
column13: ""Get Off My Back""
column14: ""Party at My House"".

column1: But here's the thing-- while it's not an ambitious album
column2: every song is solid. Their intention was to create a rock'n'roll party album (from ""Party at My House"": ""Parents comin' home
column3: / Won't you get the fuck out?"")
column4: and with that mission in their sights
column5: they recorded 12 earworm-laden tracks that wouldn't sound out of place at a deranged Frankie and Annette beach party. There's a sped up version of Billy Childish's Thee Headcoats song ""Davey Crockett"" and a fuzzed out version of Redd Kross' ""Kill Someone You Hate"". With speed
column6: volume
column7: great riffs
column8: and a sloppy delivery
column9: they breathe punk rock life into surf.

column1: These two albums are an interesting pair to release at the same time. One's a collection of dumb-but-fun rock'n'roll
column2: the other's a spotty series of tracks that owe more to Beefheart than garage. On their own
column3: these albums could imply that Segall's strengths rest in the loud and fast material. As Hair
column4: Goodbye Bread
column5: and Twins have all proved
column6: that's not the case at all-- he can slow jam with the best of 'em. But early on
column7: he was a master of trash rock
column8:
and The Traditional Fools is 20 minutes of some of his most fun material to date.

0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/18780/homepage_large.a1c23047.jpg|Folarin|10147.0|Wale|['Rap']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Maybach/Warner Bros.']|2013-01-18 00:00:00|2012|2016-06-11 17:02:49.508602|"

After D.C. rapper Wale's major label debut went thud-- not even a Lady Gaga-assisted single could prop it up-- he got lucky. It took a while
column2: though; dropped by Interscope
column3: he was eventually swept into Rick Ross' nascent Maybach Music imprint
column4: a group built to include both intriguing firebrands (Philly's Meek Mill
column5: fishing enthusiast Gunplay) as well as rappers seeking either a consistent identity (Ohio's Stalley
column6: Atlanta's now-invisible Pill) or a fresh start. Wale fell into the latter category
column7: immediately switching his whole style up
column8: transitioning from a rapper who bathed his aesthetic in his hometown's trademark go-go music
column9: wore colorful hats
column10: and dangled Seinfeld ephemera in his recordings to just another above-average rapper miring in bald bitterness
column11: club rap
column12: and feckless crew collaborations. In 2011
column13: Wale put out the well-enough-received Ambition-- a well-balanced digest of his new
column14: more jaded grip on the game-- a record that happened to contain the #1 Billboard Hip-Hop Single ""Lotus Flower Bomb""
column15: probably the highest charting single from last year that no one will admit to liking. In a world where first-disc flameouts often go the way of the Recycle Bin
column16: it could have been worse.

column1: So
column2: in a sense it's exciting to herald Wale's new mixtape
column3: Folarin (his surname)
column4: as his best release since the initial hype-generator The Mixtape About Nothing. That doesn't necessarily mean Wale has completely exorcised his inclination to be a humongous cornball-- the Tiara Thomas-featuring ""Bad"" features some more of that cringe-worthy ""Diced Pineapples""-style poetry-- but Folarin
column5: in its way
column6: approximates something close to being Wale's version of Rich Forever. Like that release
column7: Folarin is long and comes complete with a couple throwaways like ""H20"" (an ode to ""thirst"" and a song built around a sample of bed squeaking)
column8: but it also serves as a platform for some of Wale's most carefree
column9: fun songs. After hearing cuts like the Beat Billionare-produced 2 Chainz collab ""Get Me Doe"" and Chinx Drugz-featuring ""Let a Nigga Know""
column10: you wonder why Wale doesn't just sit back and lob one-liners at visiting guests more often. The list of collaborators on Folarin is a characteristically mixed-bag featuring only one other labelmate-- Diplo
column11: Trinidad James
column12: French Montana
column13: Hit-Boy (as a rapper)
column14: Danny! (as a producer)-- none of it feels like desperate crowdsourcing. Trinidad
column15: in particular
column16: delights in his bellicose blip
column17: and the Diplo/Travis Porter rave-up ""The One Eye Kitten Song"" underlines Folarin's mission of pushing Wale into more lighthearted territory.

column1: Attention Deficit was such an overreach that most folks wrote Wale off; not even a realignment with one of modern rap's biggest stars could fully invigorate the reputation of the one-time Next Big Thing. And
column2: I'm not arguing that Folarin does that-- Wale is still in his own way with syrupy drivel like ""Money Changes""-- but it does find the DC rapper having a better time
column3: generally speaking. He's still the Wale you love or revile
column4: a rapper who almost always lyrically overcooks it (""We out Garfield
column5: we goin' Odie / With rap performance of Forbes got me catchin' up Oprah"")
column6:
but it sounds like he's letting himself off the hook a little bit for his major label false start.

On Reasons to Live
column2: the full-length debut by the Brooklyn punk-rock duo Hilly Eye
column3: singer-guitarist Amy Klein repeatedly returns to images of emotional violence in her lyrics that initially seem like postcards from the edge of an especially awful and parasitic romantic coupling. But Klein
column4: an ex-member of New Jersey rockers Titus Andronicus
column5: tilts her hand just enough to imply that it could also be nation
column6: rather than just a person
column7: that’s left her feeling equal parts enraged and empathetic.

column1: Amid the scuffed-up beauty of dime-store guitars rubbing up against Catherine Tung's brutalized drum kit
column2: Klein seethes about deception in ""American Rail"" with a personal sense of betrayal: ""In my dreams/ I believe all the lies you told me
column3: she sings
column4: in a voice that sounds both confessional and accusatory. On the dreamy travelogue ""Louisville""
column5: she echoes the pleas of a forgotten underclass: ""Don't bring me down/ Higher than the water/ Don’t bring me down/ I don't want to lose my ground."" This neglect explodes into physical abuse on ""Double Dutch""
column6: where Klein spits
column7: ""I can see all the marks that your arms left on me/ I can see what you are.""

column1: Or
column2: you know
column3: Klein could be singing about some asshole she's happy to have rid herself of. Even when she tiptoes precariously close to making A Statement-- like on the album-opening ""Way Back When""
column4: a lilting folk-rock number that alludes to a returning soldier's difficult homecoming-- she always keeps one foot tucked safely in ambiguity. Hilly Eye songs are built on simple
column5: opaque lines that are transformed into stinging slogans; on ""Animal""
column6: the money line is ""All the boys who get beaten up/ all the girls who get beaten down
column7: which Klein delivers as a manic yelp and a churlish taunt over guitars that similarly oscillate alternating shades of pretty and ugly.

column1: Lyrically
column2: Reasons to Live is pitched somewhere between an angry breakup record and an ethereal
column3: post-psychedelic protest screed. Musically
column4: it seems to have been purposely constructed to deny easy satisfaction-- or satisfaction of any kind
column5: really. If the meaning of these songs is difficult to pin down
column6: so is their emotional core. Hilly Eye's primary musical characteristic-- the soft-loud dynamics of Klein and Tung's untrained harmonies and their pummeling
column7: near-amateurish instrumental attack-- is the oldest trick in the indie-rock handbook. The lack of technique gives Reasons to Live an unfinished quality that suggests there's either more depth than there appears to be
column8: or an underlying emptiness deriving from too much feral energy and not enough songwriting.

column1: Given Klein's track record
column2: I'm inclined to believe the former. Hilly Eye's emaciated sound is about as far as you can get from the all-fists-on-deck expansiveness of Titus Andronicus. It seems like a shortcut to something more singular to Klein's own experiences. What's left unresolved on Reasons to Live is what
column3: exactly
column4: Klein has to say about those experiences. It's a record borne of confusion-- though
column5: to its credit
column6: it's about confusion as well. ""I am too young/ I am too old
column7: she sings on ""Almanac""
column8: which meanders aimlessly for a few minutes before magically producing the album's most rousing riff. Klein might still be figuring herself out
column9:
but the identity she seeks is definitely worth finding.
