Alasdair Roberts' musical foundations extend deep into the bedrock of the traditional folk of Scotland and the British Isles. Fuelled by restless curiosity and a scholar's attention to detail
column2: Roberts has long split his attentions between interpretations of traditional material and his own original songs
column3: while often leaving blurry the distinction between the two. On A Wonder Working Stone
column4: his first collection of all original material since 2009's Spoils
column5: the line separating the traditional from the personal is purposefully left fuzzier than ever. Stray bits and pieces from old fiddle tunes and Scottish bagpipe marches are woven tightly with Roberts' thorny lyrics to create elaborate
column6: raucous medleys that can seem almost like a tin-can-and-string phone connection between the past and the present.

column1: A Wonder Working Stone comes on the heels of two albums of traditional material
column2: 2010's Too Long in This Condition and 2012's Urstan
column3: a collection of old Gaelic pieces recorded with Mairi Morrison. By all evidence
column4: the time spent researching and recording those albums stoked Roberts' creative fires as a lyricist. His songs here abound with passing images (""We'll be drinking like masons/ mixing the gunpowder into the wine"") that sound as though they could've been discovered in some half-remembered book of folklore.

column1: Roberts' voice sounds in fine fettle as well
column2: and his reedy
column3: keening brogue is the type of immediately distinctive instrument that is virtually impossible to imagine any listener accidentally mistaking for someone else's. Nevertheless
column4: the ""and Friends"" included on the album cover is there for a reason; this is resolutely a band album. Roberts is joined here by an international host of like-minded talents
column5: with the additions of electric guitarist Ben Reynolds and fiddle player Rafe Fitzpatrick particularly crucial to an overall sound that recalls the early 70s folk-rock fusions of Fairport Convention or Steeleye Span. The album also features the occasional contributions of a horn section and strings from members of the Scottish early music ensemble Concerto Caledonia
column6: but the arrangements are kept loose and casual
column7: sounding at points as though these musicians had just happened upon each other down at their local.

column1: ""Tiny wren under the linden/ pondering in wonder the human conundrum
column2: Roberts sings on ""Wheels of the World/The Human Conundrum""
column3: the album's rambling 9-minute centerpiece. Borrowing strands from Scottish and Irish sources
column4: this piece perhaps best exemplifies Roberts' musical and thematic approach for the album. Nearly every song here is marked by abrupt time changes and eccentric structural shifts that can make them seem almost episodic in nature
column5: with elegiac fiddle solos or raucous sing-a-along choruses bursting in at unexpected angles. These musical mood swings do amply reflect Roberts' tumultuous lyrics
column6: which frequently describe a landscape of lonely boneyards and lurking misery
column7: peopled by such characters as ""the queen of the unseen"" and ""friar of denial.""

column1: Despite these shadows
column2: however
column3: the overall mood is one of celebrating in the face of encroaching doom. (It's telling that the first song here is entitled ""The Merry Wake"".) The album's most rollicking track
column4: ""Scandal and Trance""
column5: might also be its strangest. Cribbing a melody from the traditional ""We Shall Walk Through the Streets of the City""
column6: better known to singing cowboy fans as ""Red River Valley""
column7: Roberts and group turn the track into a woozy and somewhat befuddling hoedown. Yet at song's end
column8: when Roberts and group sing ""Get over your tiny self/ all days will end in joy/ they'll never end in evil"" it serves as a reminder of the communal and participatory nature of the folk traditions that Roberts so celebrates
column9:
and it is not difficult to feel like joining in.

This isn't a new New Order album

column4: expensive sessions that produced 2005's Waiting for the Sirens' Call
column5: New Order recorded a small pile of extra material
column6: the idea being that they'd get a few more songs down after the subsequent tour and call it another album. But they stopped playing together after 2006
column7: then bassist Peter Hook left the band acrimoniously
column8: and the two camps spent a few years bickering at one another. However
column9: since the return of keyboardist Gillian Gilbert
column10: they've been touring again as
column11: effectively
column12: an oldies act-- minus Hook. (Their set lists last year featured
column13: typically
column14: all of two post-1993 songs
column15: and encores from the Joy Division catalogue.)

column1: Now
column2: following extended tussles over mixes and copyright

column3: and they've certainly released a lot of more ragged material in the past. These are densely packed
column4: finely detailed arrangements in New Order's late-80s rock-with-keyboards mode-- much more recognizable as the work of the band that recorded ""Dream Attack"" than the one that recorded ""Fine Time"". Sumner's lyrics are
column5: as usual

column7: and his voice still sounds exactly as clear
column8: earnest

column1: A lot of what made 80s-era New Order special

column3: was their perpetual fascination with body music and the culture around it-- the way they always latched onto the dance music of the moment
column4: from the tail-end of disco to Latin freestyle to acid house
column5: and reworked it in their own idiom. Lost Sirens obviously can't suggest much familiarity with what's going on in dance clubs in 2013
column6: and it doesn't suggest what was going on there when it was recorded close to a decade ago; the clock stopped for their groove sense around the time they first broke up. (""Hellbent"" would sound totally natural mixed out of Primal Scream's Madchester anthem ""Loaded."")

column1: Peter Hook's presence on Lost Sirens is
column2: understandably
column3: somewhat muted-- there are a few of his signature fretless bass solos scattered around the album
column4: but this is very much a guitar-driven
column5: Sumner-centered record. Aside from occasional New Order-y instrumental flourishes

column10: Hook
column11: and Stephen Morris always played together

column13: bickered-over swan song

column1: ""It's been 10 long years since I've been home
column2: begins ""I Told You So""
column3: the one song here reprised from Sirens' Call. (The very different mix here sounds more like a rewrite of ""All Tomorrow's Parties"".) That's a doubly barbed line in this context

Maybe New Order have some more albums in them; maybe with Gilbert back in the fold they'll recast themselves as a singles act again. Maybe not. These remnants of their most recent burst of creative fecundity are a decent way for them to go out
column5: if they are indeed going to be playing the hits to pay the rent from here on out. As an album
column6: Lost Sirens isn't at all an embarrassment: it's a document of a band whose range and reach
column7: rather than power
column8:
are what has been diminished.

Before David Lowery was known as a leading crusader for musicians' rights against the evils of thieving NPR interns
column2: and/or the frontman of fairly popular 90s alt-rock band Cracker
column3: he was the most famous member of semi-famous
column4: 80s indie band Camper Van Beethoven. It's important to point out
column5: because it sometimes seems like the world has forgotten as much. CVB has managed the dubious trick of being influential without being imitated-- they helped to invent the since outmoded term ""college rock
column6: paving the way for much of the music covered by this very website. They're a part of history
column7: but haven't transcended it. Any credible document of American underground rock music must list Camper Van Beethoven in the index
column8: but good luck finding a contemporary band that will namedrop them in interviews.

column1: Since reuniting in 1999 after a nine-year hiatus
column2: Camper Van Beethoven has carved out a decent niche playing live shows for diehards
column3: often touring in tandem with Cracker
column4: whose membership has included Lowery's cohorts in CVB off and on again over the years. The demand for new CVB material outside of that small cult isn't exactly raging
column5: particularly after 2004's decently received New Roman Times. Camper Van Beethoven has not been sought out by a new audience
column6: aside from a curious student or two at the University of Georgia inspired to check out their instructor's discography. And the negative view on La Costa Perdida
column7: the band's first release in eight years
column8: is that it's not a terribly necessary record.

column1: It isn't an ideal starting point for neophytes
column2: anyway. Perdida is more approachable than New Roman Times-- which was a heady concept record about post-9/11 America
column3: far-right militias
column4: Fundamentalist Christian sects
column5: and other assorted detritus floating in the yoke of political extremism-- tying together CVB's zany
column6: chopped-genre sundaes with a thread of sunbaked Northern Californian pleasantries. Hearing these guys play together
column7: presumably huddled in tight and facing a window with a killer view of the ocean
column8: is pretty delightful for much of La Costa Perdida. But the songs themselves aren't all that memorable. The gorgeous country rock of the album-opening ""Come Down The Coast"" comes closest to sticking
column9: even if it veers furthest from the CVB template and toward a full-on homage to Kerosene Hat­-era Cracker. Please
column10: if you have any desire to learn about this group
column11: head straight to 1989's Key Lime Pie and only revisit La Costa Perdida once you've exhausted the rest of the catalog.

column1: If you happen to already love this band
column2: La Costa Perdida warrants a more positive assessment. Maybe contemporary indie-rock isn't flooded with CVB sound-alikes because this happens to be a very difficult band to rip off. Jonathan Segel's vertigo-inducing violin swirls on the fractured English folk of ""Someday Our Love Will Sell Us Out"" could only exist on a CVB record; ditto that for ""Peaches in the Summertime""
column3: a ska-punk-bluegrass ditty that processes its grossly disparate sounds with a straight face and casual flick of the wrist. ""Too High for the Love-In"" shoots Lowery's snarky lyrics through an airy sunshine pop melody that turns sinister during an unexpected acid-rock coda
column4: when Lowery infuses the ""make me a sandwich"" mantra with bizarre malevolence.

column1: Even if La Costa Perdida isn't a great Camper Van Beethoven record
column2: it does illustrate how unique this band still is
column3: 30 years after it formed. And it truly is a kick to hear CVB ply its craft with road-tested assurance and subtly virtuosic musicianship. The bluesy vamp ""You Got to Roll"" doesn't totally work on record
column4: but it should sound great in a concert setting
column5: where the proggy accents of ""Summer Days"" and the ""Euro-Trash Girl""-like epic ""Northern California Girls"" will also likely catch fire. In lieu of having great material
column6:
at least Camper Van Beethoven can count on being itself better than anybody else.

A few months ago
column2: the Brooklyn label Captured Tracks asked how Molly Hamilton would describe her band Widowspeak's second album to someone who's deaf. ""Almanac is like moving into a big old house in the woods with sheets covering all the furniture
column3: and then taking all the sheets off."" The languidly-voiced singer may have been referring to the group's actual experience recording in an old barn in the Hudson River Valley
column4: but the description works on a more intrinsic level as well. The crackling of a fire that begins opener ""Perennials"" burns off the home-recording dust that has been trailing them since their debut October Tape EP
column5: clarifying the song's ringing guitar line and sharpening the indefinable edges of Hamilton's croon. You can practically hear the snap of the sheets as Widowspeak unveil their new sound
column6: expanding upon the hazy
column7: ""Gun Shy""-slinging pop Americana that encouraged them to move from the Pacific Northwest to New York in the first place.

column1: With Widowspeak
column2: Hamilton and guitarist Robert Earl Thomas settled into uncovered ground between Ennio Morricone
column3: Cowboy Junkies
column4: and Neil Young. The interplay between Hamilton's lilting melodies and Thomas' stiff-legged
column5: articulate riffs gave definition to what in lesser hands would just be sepia-toned retrospectives. Songs like the skeletal ""Limbs""
column6: with haunting background vocals crawling through the wreckage of a violin
column7: were refreshingly familiar but also shocking; like a lost photograph of a childhood memory from a different angle. More than their contemporaries and immediate predecessors trafficking in similar themes
column8: Widowspeak were filtering everything through a more self-aware light
column9: perfecting Amanda Petrusich's idea that Instagram makes you to feel ""nostalgic for a time you never actually knew."" (Even Almanac's album cover is a self-proclaimed homage to Wings
column10: Sound of Silence
column11: and the Carpenters LPs
column12: with Hamilton coyly looking up at Thomas in a vintage dress undoubtedly gleaned from an overpriced Williamsburg rack.)

column1: With a traditional framework capable of supporting layers added by co-producers Kevin McMahon and Thomas
column2: on Almanac they further pursue Widowspeak's lines of inquiry into mariachi
column3: spaghetti western soundtracks
column4: and 90s sad-rock
column5: to a certain extent abandoning their original goal to ""hang back as much as possible."" They coalesce the darker elements that hung around Widowspeak like an ether into something more tangible. Growling
column6: they stalk through the album
column7: bringing ""Rhiannon""-like undertones to ""Dyed In the Wool"" and a sense of inevitable malevolence to the psych-leaning ""Locusts"". A new focus on low-range brings out even more of the ""creepy Disney soundtrack folk group""-- Hamilton's original idea for a band called Widow's Peak-- behind the spidery banjo and baroque accordions in ""Thick as Thieves"".

column1: Hamilton's interest in eschatology also influenced the record
column2: which she wanted to record before the forecasted Mayan apocalypse: on the churning ""The Dark Age""
column3: she preaches
column4: ""We have ourselves to blame/ We had our years to play.../ It's getting kind of late/ Don't know what you're waiting for."" It's an electric song
column5: with Thomas' guitar solo bursting to the surface like a churchgoer being released from possession by Hamilton's priest. ""Ballad of the Golden Hour"" turns on another epic shift
column6: segueing seamlessly but suddenly from a slide guitar's anthemic strumming to something more sinister. Before the bridge
column7: Thomas starts climbing up and down the scale with predatory guitar licks until Hamilton slows down the song's verse and rhythm. Her use of indelibly associated phrases like ""as the crow flies
column8: ""as good as gold
column9: and ""long in the teeth"" punctuate the song with almost cinematographic vividness
column10: although it's a pity they come at the expense of subtler lyrical moments elsewhere like the double entendre ""We made the bed/ And built our legs.""

column1: Those moments of instrumental and idiomatic grandeur suggest that Widowspeak is almost mythologizing itself
column2: especially during Almanac's more experimental second half
column3: in which each song renders genre staples so effectively they listen like remastered B-sides. ""Minnewaska"" sways between Hamilton's soothing background sighs and samples of crickets
column4: and she breathes over the ethereal torpidity of ""Storm King"" in the vein of Nancy Sinatra's version of ""Bang Bang (My Baby Shot Me Down)"". Even ""Sore Eyes""
column5: which comes the closest to Widowspeak's tumbleweed romanticism
column6: intimates the band's expanded representation of itself
column7: not unlike a cover. This is Almanac's greatest strength and also its weakness. Widowspeak is moving forward in its evolution as a band with promising conviction
column8: but at this point they're exploring a lot of different paths. Without a singular narrative to tie it all together besides Hamilton's lovely but noncommital exhalations
column9: it's a little too easy to lose interest. Now that the end of the world is behind us
column10: however
column11:
Widowspeak can focus more precisely on how they'd like to be remembered.

Last time we heard from Brokeback
column2: on the 2003 album Looks at the Bird
column3: they sounded positively alien. The band
column4: a long-running side project for Tortoise and Eleventh Dream Day's Douglas McCombs
column5: had stiffened up
column6: sometimes getting lost in a welter of meticulously constructed electronics. But 10 years later
column7: things are markedly different. McCombs has lost bass player and longstanding Brokeback member Noel Kupersmith
column8: and has mostly shed the jazz and electronic leanings of past records under this name. Instead
column9: he's assembled a simple guitar-bass-drums lineup
column10: perhaps deciding he'd reached a point of no return for the post-rock template he partly had a hand in defining. This album unhurriedly shifts through themes-- notably the Duane-Eddy-meets-Morricone feel that's something of a signature for McCombs-- but at its center it's all ragged glory
column11: guys banging out riffs and solos
column12: a clear-cut delve into the rock firmament. You can practically feel the band members blowing the dust off their old plaid shirts and cracking open a six pack. There's nothing ""post"" about it. This is distinctly past rock.

column1: Neil Young's work with Crazy Horse looms large over the all-instrumental Black Rock
column2: with McCombs and his band digging hard into Young's preference for creating greats beds of warm
column3: fuzzy guitar noise. A signifier of Chicago post-rock has always been its tightness
column4: a desire to execute songs with minimal waste

column7: born out of the joy in syphoning his music through a looser framework. Even the backstory behind the album is overly familiar-- it's all diligent weekly practice sessions
column8: working out the kinks in songs through live performances
column9: lucking into an opening slot on a friends' tour (in this case
column10: the Sea and Cake). The only thing missing is a yellowing Rush poster peeling away at the corners on their studio wall.

column1: Prior Brokeback albums could feel desolate-- Field Recordings from the Cook County Water Table is a stark
column2: lonely record-- but here the tendency is toward a much fuller and brighter sound. Occasionally there are nods to the band's past
column3: such as the twangy ""Everywhere Down Here"" from Looks at the Bird
column4: which forms a thread that McCombs picks at again on ""Gold!"" from this album. The moodier side of Brokeback's music criss-crosses with some of McCombs' work elsewhere; ""Gold!"" is even a hark back to the less uptight passages of Tortoise's ""Glass Museum"". It's all much straighter
column5: less fussy than before. There's nothing here as intricate as ""After the Internationals"" from Field Recordings. Instead
column6: there are hints of the dusty trails Calexico have largely made their own (in the twin tracks ""Tonight at Ten"" and ""Tonight at Eleven"")
column7: and twists of neo-noir provided by an often-deployed sea of reverb (""Who is Bozo Texino?""). Mostly it's hard to escape the endless soloing
column8: which weaves a prickly trail through the songs

column1: McCombs has enjoyed a varied career
column2: often altering Brokeback radically with each passing release
column3: so it's not a total surprise to find him bucking his tendency to deliberately work against the conventions of rock. But it's hard not to feel a little disappointed that he couldn't come up with a fresher take on the common tropes he works with here. The closing 11-minute long ""Colossus of Roads"" just sits in place
column4: falling into the trap of sounding like a lot of fun to play
column5: but far less enjoyable to actually sit through. Other Chicago post-rock musicians have veered close to this space before-- Bundy K. Brown's 1996 album Directions In Music
column6: recorded under the name Directions
column7: is an excellent example of how to taper rock excesses into something more palatable. The Black Rock succeeds on occasion
column8: but the weight of McCombs' past is a tough load to bear in situations like this. When you know someone is capable of giving rock a thorough disemboweling
column9:
it's hard not to think of opportunities being squandered when presented with something so forthright.

column4: visceral

column6: perhaps one too many mid-paced laments
column7: and a couple of rounds of roiling tirades. Some welcome breathing space unites the strands; songs stick within a genre at a time
column8: and Higgs' lyrics no longer need Infinite Jest-style footnotes to decode them. If the subject matter sounds like Thom Yorke's dinner table patter

column12: coupled with the most gorgeous
column13: warm rush of a chorus EE have ever written: ""I wanna take you home/ And find some new joy in this autopilot life."" And Higgs' sense of cadence and consonance is strong as ever
column14: backed up by the band's campy
column15: musical theater backing vocals: ""So fast
column16: hence take an arrow from your quiver or we're/ Past tense-- what's a trilobite to anyone?"" he sings on the stuttering ""Kemosabe""
column17: underpinned by Jeremy Pritchard's rude funk bass.

column1: Everything Everything's reputation for abject maximalism overlooks their unexpected ability to craft relatively tender
column2: sad songs; the handful on Man Alive were as delicate but dark as the coiled rainbow on oil's surface. There are similarly unconventional
column3: small-scale ballads on Arc
column4: the best of which is ""Torso of the Week""
column5: whose nervous
column6: mournful verses about the literal and figurative grind of the treadmill eventually burst into a Roman candle of a chorus. ""The House is Dust"" is an atmospheric tale of divorce made ominous by Michael Spearman's cavernous drums; centerpiece ""_Arc_"" is seemingly a structural homage to OK Computer's ""Fitter Happier""
column7: and the best employ of the luscious
column8: Hans Zimmer-y strings that showboat throughout the record. But violins will play sad for any old chump
column9: and beyond the silliness and spark present on Arc
column10: there's a braveness more profound than sticking Beyoncé
column11: Arvo Part
column12: and Mr. Bungle on your influences list and calling it mammy.

column1: It doesn't take an analyst to deduce that the former knottiness of Higgs' lyrics might have been a smokescreen for some ineffable feeling-- for all the words
column2: he didn't often admit to much. Throughout Arc
column3: he's repeatedly crueler to himself than any critic could have been about Man Alive
column4: and sinks beneath the dulled specter of male depression. The juddering
column5: Dustin Wong-like shimmer of ""Choice Mountain"" veils him pondering reincarnation rather than submit to hopelessness; the fraught ""Feet for Hands"" (which opens with the only truly unpleasant sound on the record
column6: a misplaced mandolin intro) asks
column7: ""When you think of me
column8: don't remember this/ Not a slow wane of a blinded man
column9: and the sublime ""Radiant"" counters guitarist Alex Robertshaw's piercing
column10: heart-pounding release with the mournful admission
column11: ""I could make a difference
column12: but I don't.""

column1: Their general sense of drama and vulnerability couched within a pretty masculine idiom-- guitar rock
column2: to be reductive-- brings to mind the way Queen duped a nation into pounding a masculine chest with a feminine fist. The way that Everything Everything play against the macho
column3: aggressive posturing of contemporaries who could care less about caring should be their strongest calling card. ""Don't try to hide it! ... 'Cos it'll have you in the end
column4: Higgs sings in a strong head voice on the final song
column5: the itchy
column6: choral anthem
column7:
""Don't Try"". He should know; Arc is a brilliant lesson in not letting your neuroses become you.

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/18703/homepage_large.9aba8749.jpg|Donuts (45 Box Set)|2248.0|J Dilla|['Rap']|0.0|1.0|1.0|['Stones Throw']|2013-01-16 00:00:00|2006|2016-06-11 17:02:54.115873|"

If the six years since Donuts was released has taught us anything
column2: it's that a great album can be a sort of open-ended puzzle that can be solved from multiple angles. It's become James Yancey's signature production opus
column3: even though the path that led him to it was laid down by a lifetime of collaboration
column4: workshopping
column5: and constant production in the service of other people's voices. It's the last work he created in his lifetime
column6: released the week of his death
column7: and yet it still feels like his music hasn't run out of time yet
column8: whether that's down to periodic dives back into his vaults
column9: or via the artists that've picked up inspiration and run with it to new places. It's a widely praised favorite for so many people
column10: and yet there's something about Donuts that feels like such an intensely personal statement. Even attempting to engage with it objectively
column11: setting aside the direct experience of the man who made it
column12: doesn't entirely break through its mystique.

column1: But as music
column2: the role Donuts occupies is something more than the weight of its rep or impact-- or even the circumstances in which it was created
column3: as hard as it is to separate the idea of the album's sound from the motivation of a prolific creator knowingly constructing his final work. As an album
column4: it just gets deeper the longer you live with it
column5: front-to-back listens revealing emotions and moods that get pulled in every direction: mournful nostalgia
column6: absurd comedy
column7: raucous joy
column8: sinister intensity. There's all kinds of neat little tics and idiosyncrasies
column9: pushing Dilla's early 00s beat-tape experiments and exchanges into compositions that tinker with Thelonious Monk's off-kilter timing and Lee Perry's warped fidelity. The songs on Donuts are like miniature lessons in how to take sample-based music and use it to build elaborate suites out of all those nagging little pieces of songs that stick with you long after you've last listened to them. There's little else in Dilla's catalog quite like it; at points
column10: it sounds like he was busy quickly unlearning everything he'd taught himself just so he could have the experience of relearning it all again one last time.

column1: While Donuts is best experienced as a self-contained album
column2: Stones Throw has gone to the unusual step of reissuing it as a box set of 7"" singles
column3: a format that initially comes across like a boutique novelty at the expense of practicality. If anybody owns a scuffed-up old jukebox and wants to stock it with records that recreate the feeling of recalling jumbled-up memories and mulling over them for a while
column4: then sure
column5: this would work great. And it's hard not to appreciate the symbolism of issuing this album on 7"" records
column6: considering that the hospital bedside setup Yancey used to create a significant portion of Donuts consisted of a SP-303 hooked up to a portable 45 turntable. But is there a reason to chop one of the last 10 years' purest can't-listen-to-just-one-track experiences into pieces
column7: especially when the target audience for this reissue likely already has a version they don't have to keep flipping over?

column1: Well
column2: think of it this way: What's your favorite song on Donuts? Breaking an album like this into its component tracks puts a new viewpoint on a record that's always been easy to see as a whole
column3: and the limitations of three minutes or so per side gives individual moments more weight on their own. The rhythms of the isolated tracks can feel truncated and abrupt in this new context-- without anything to segue into
column4: side-enders like ""Workinonit"" and ""One Eleven"" flip off like a light switch-- but it still fits the suddenness and in medias res editing of the album's handmade
column5: conversational feel. And it only serves to elucidate how much Dilla could do in such a limited amount of space. He could fit a lot of off-beat meter-shifting
column6: loop-upending false starts and jump cuts
column7: subtle slow-build dynamics
column8: and double-back surprises into the little 50-to-80-second vignettes. That's plenty of time to set up expectations
column9: only to twist them around a thousand degrees.

column1: There's also some clever sequencing to the sides that lets new thematic possibilities appear. Of course ""Airworks"" and ""Lightworks"" share a side to themselves
column2: and as consecutive tracks they felt like weird companion pieces in the middle of the original album. On record
column3: that odd pairing-- a hiccupy series of tics drawn from L.V. Johnson's classic Chicago soul
column4: transitioning into a cheerfully odd rework of Raymond Scott's late 50s musique concrete corporate jingles-- forces those two cuts into closer quarters and highlights their shared tendency to loop vocal phrases and backbeats into knots you can't untie. Same goes for ""Two Can Win"" and ""Don't Cry""
column5: which consecutively showcase Yancey's knack for building classic hip-hop beats out of solitary 70s R&B nuggets. The choppy yet lush elegance of ""Dilla Says Go""/""Walkinonit"" and the heartbroken please-stay pleas of ""Hi.""/""Bye."" stand out in isolation
column6: too.

column1: But even without that benefit of new juxtapositions
column2: it's still eye-opening to take each little set of songs as it comes and not sweat getting to the next one
column3: pinpointing the inimitable technique and sample-sourcing scope of Donuts through certain distinct moments. Just pull out ""Geek Down"" and note how Dilla took one of the most recognizable samples in hip-hop
column4: ESG's ""UFO""
column5: and found something surprising and obscure to lay it over: a 2002 7"" retro-funk b-side called ""Charlie's Theme"" released in limited numbers by an incognito Geoff Barrow and Adrian Utley from Portishead. That's in keeping with the other moments where he's clearly working with some well-used building block that every sample-based producer should know their way around-- Mountain's ""Long Red"" (""Stepson of the Clapper""); Malcolm McLaren's ""Buffalo Gals"" (""Workinonit"" and ""The Twister""); the Beastie Boys' ""The New Style"" (""The New"")-- and still finds a way to fit that piece into something uniquely his by drawing from an encyclopedic catalog of under-utilized funk and soul deep cuts. Even the ubiquitous siren he lifted from Mantronix feels like Dilla's sole property now-- maybe because Kurtis never thought to lay it over a mobius-strip revamp of Kool and the Gang album track ""Fruitman"" (""The Diff'rence"") or a tense
column6: staggered piano loop cut from Martha Reeves' mid 70s post-Motown solo debut (""Thunder"").

column1: If you need any extra incentive
column2: the box set packs in some bonus material. There's a medley of tracks that share sources with Donuts instrumentals ""Anti-American Graffiti"" and ""Geek Down""
column3: which were originally slated for MF DOOM and Ghostface showcase ""Sniper Elite & Murder Goons"". The track shows both MCs still in post-Madvillainy/Pretty Toney form
column4: DOOM twisting internal rhymes at a ridiculous clip
column5: Ghost still verbally sprinting like he's coming off ""Run"". And ""Signs""
column6: originally a Fan Club release
column7: tacks on a stand-alone postscript that hints at some of Donuts' brilliance
column8: but mostly just provides a pretty straightforward (if appealing) instrumental break based off a needly organ riff and that old Syl Johnson ""Different Strokes"" grunt. The rarities are enticing
column9: the packaging is immaculate
column10: and the format is intriguing. But above all else
column11: this reissue provides a good excuse to revisit an old favorite in a new light
column12: and in the end it's still a classic no matter how you hear it-- on 45
column13: CD
column14: MP3
column15:
or just running through your head.

If you're the type to dismiss a band out of hand for not doing much to disguise their influences
column2: California X probably aren't for you. The scuzz generated by this Amherst
column3: Mass.
column4: power-trio owes more than a little something to Amherst's other
column5: considerably more famous triad
column6: Dinosaur Jr. The resemblance is
column7: to say the least
column8: striking; once you find out the two bands probably share an alderman
column9: the name California X becomes either a neat bit of misdirection or an acute form of denial. But
column10: if the stompboxed-out mix of run'n'gun hardcore
column11: molasses-thick grunge
column12: and burly classic rock of California X
column13: the band's self-titled debut
column14: isn't far off (geographically or otherwise) from the mess J. Mascis and company have been kicking up off-and-on for some 30 years now
column15: well
column16: consider this: If you could play guitar like J. Mascis
column17:
wouldn't that be a thing you'd want to do all the time?

I'd wager California X frontman Lemmy Gurtowsky would almost be the first to tell you he's no J. Mascis. Allow me to be the second. But the kid's good
column18: and he works the fretboard with much the same low-effort
column19: high-yield fury as his laconic forebear. Like Mascis
column21: but he typically gets more done in three notes than he does in 20. Gurtowsky careens through riff after gnarly riff
column22: yet he's got plenty of control over his abandon
column23: careful not to let things get away from him; grunge-wallop ""Hot Hed"" fades out on a particularly hot-sounding solo and switches in an uncharacteristically delicate piano
column24: and it's like pouring coolant on an overheated engine. Mostly
column29: stopping briefly to catch its breath

column1: So much music that mines the moment indie-rock crashed into grunge drops D
column2: riffs hard
column3: moans something or other
column4: and lets that be that. But Gurtowsky never lets himself lose sight of the song beneath all that sludge. Opener ""Sucker"" begins in distortion and ends in total triumph
column5: its central riff climbing like it's got a flag to plant someplace tall. But it's pushed along by Gurtowsky's impassioned-- if frequently muffled-- vocals
column6: a top-of-the-lungs plea that recalls a more excitable sort of singer than Mr. Mascis
column7: namely Superchunk's Mac McCaughan or Japandroids' Brian King. You can't always make out what Gurtowsky's saying on California X
column8: but even submerged in static
column9: every line's a gasp
column10: exiting his lungs in an all-fired hurry. Just as Gurtowsky wrings a lot of feeling out of a few notes
column11: his singing conveys plenty even when the words get lost in the fray. ""Spider X"" is particularly desperate
column12: and Gurtowsky sings ""I wait for you!"" like a guy who's never wanted to stop waiting so badly in his life. ""Spirit World"" is the kind of pop-punker Wavves would be lucky to call his own; the waterlogged post-grunge of ""Pond Rot"" could be the Toadies' rewrite of ""Under the Sea"". California X can't help but bleed together a bit
column13: what with all the pressing tempos
column14: the muddled vocals
column15: and the constellation of familiar reference points. But there's elation and ennui alike shading in these songs
column16:
two qualities you can't just borrow from another band.

Call it pastiche
column17: call it homage
column18: but whatever you want to call it
column19: California X are guilty on all charges. Does it matter? Well
column21: but there's certainly something to be said for injecting some new feeling into an old formula. As I see it
column22: the big difference between California X and Dinosaur Jr's post-reunion records is one of feeling. The last few Dinosaur LPs have been a nice reminder of what they do well. But
column23: while they're doing a little more than just going through the motions
column24: the fire that drove their early records-- and drove Lou Barlow from the band-- just isn't there like it once was. California X
column27: desperate record that hits you squarely in the gut. It's far from perfect
column28: but it's never less than driven
column29: and that drive gets you past the garbled syllables and any pesky feelings of deja vu. Riffs
column30: you can cop from almost anyplace
column31:
but passion? You have to supply that one yourself. Turns out California X's passion is way louder than their piety.

There's a commonly held belief that divisive art has to be doing something right
column3: but that assumes a confrontational intent on behalf of the artist. As such
column4: it does not account for a record like Free Energy's Love Sign. It's certainly difficult to imagine anyone being lukewarm about it: the Philadelphia band's unyieldingly and unrepentantly shiny
column5: happy jukebox hero-rock either predates or ignores all tenets of punk
column6: and if you hold certain indie ideals sacred
column7: it is likely the antithesis of everything you want out of music. Conversely
column8: you might think those very tenets make a band like Free Energy a necessary counterbalance. So the question gets flipped: when a record that so desperately wants to be universally loved ends up being divisive
column9: is it doing something wrong? Well
column10: the current state of the music industry certainly couldn't support anyone's ambition to be the new Cheap Trick
column11: but Love Sign's belief in the righteousness of its intentionally big
column12: dumb songs being big
column13: dumb and nothing else ultimately sets Free Energy up to fail.

column1: Anachronism should be the least of Free Energy’s concerns: for all of the ""That 70s Band"" affectations that accompanied their occasionally charming and novel 2010 debut Stuck On Nothing
column2: most of Love Sign is actually slick
column3: subcompact power-pop that traces its lineage from the Cars (without the jittery
column4: new wave idiosyncrasies) to Blue Album Weezer (without the emotional reckoning) to Jimmy Eat World (without the generous heart)
column5: and unfortunately
column6: back to latter day Weezer in how it aggressively cops to its own formulism as a preemptive strike against critique. And do they ever love those groovy girls who just want to dance all night. That last part is important: seemingly every other song makes some sort of reference to dancing or shaking it all night
column7: but only one is actually called ""Dance All Night"".

column1: It's a powerful image to conjure
column2: particularly when it has absolutely no currency with what most would consider ""youth music"" in 2013 and could be all the more attractive for it. But in the context of <i>Love Sign
column3: you have to imagine a version of Dazed and Confused that removes any and all references to sex (a lyric about ""making out with your lipstick gloss"" is as close as you get to second base)
column4: drugs
column5: or antiauthoritarian behavior. Which leaves you with basically a five-minute short about getting Aerosmith tickets. The fatal flaw of Love Sign is its failure to realize ""good clean fun"" is a contradiction in youth-oriented rock. If so much of Free Energy's praise thus far has taken to the theoretical-- you could totally hear it coming out of an airbrushed van! These could all be hits in 1975!-- it's because none of it feels inspired by anything resembling a real human interaction.

column1: You don't have to look any further back than Japandroids' Celebration Rock for proof that lyrics don't have to be based in reality to trigger very real and very powerful emotions and that the best antidote to crippling nostalgia is the belief that tonight could really be the best night ever. But Free Energy offer nothing of themselves but the most obvious rhymes possible between the most obviously placed ""whoas"" and ""heys"" in a way that feels borderline insulting to the listener. This carries over to the music as well; for a bunch of self-styled classicists
column2: their depth and appreciation for 70s pop-rock seems to go no further than the exact sounds and signifiers that would be coopted by a commercial for a free credit report
column3: all of which makes John Agnello's plasticine production uncomfortably on-the-nose. It's possible that hearing a cowbell or a harmonized guitar solo or any of the riffs that could pass for slight variations of ""You Ain't Seen Nothin' Yet"" can still trigger a smile. Yet
column4: by pushing these buttons as often as possible
column5: they become nothing more than Spike Jones-style audio gags.

column1: That's not to suggest Free Energy are being cynical or opportunistic on Love Sign; there are much easier ways to achieve stardom in 2013 than to self-release an album of this nature. It is sincere-- the way your drunk uncle sincerely wants to make you laugh when he tells an off-color joke
column2: the way a guy who uses a pickup line at a bar sincerely wants to sleep with you. But when you consider the far more dubious genres privy to salvage jobs as of late
column3: the problem isn't the form so much as the utter void of expression. You think back to similarly minded bands that punctured indie's inflated sense of self and the kitsch quickly gave way to an underlying
column4: unshakeable vision. Sloan had the encyclopedic knowledge and chops to serve as satisfying meta exercise and compete with the power-pop originals
column5: the Darkness juxtaposed the groupie-slaying connotations of their music with incredibly nerdy puns about STDs
column6: masturbation
column7: and RPGs
column8: Junior Senior traded in subversive and very non-subversive sexual politics
column9: Andrew WK didn't make a record so much as a code of ethics. Then again
column10:
Free Energy may have done the same thing; their first album merely took the phrase ""stuck on nothing"" as its title. Love Sign actually lives it.

"|17530.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/17530-love-sign/|3.6|Ian Cohen

Over the past two decades
column2: New Orleans has been as influential and powerful as any city in rap
column3: giving us No Limit
column4: Cash Money
column5: and everything that emanated in their wake. But New Orleans has shifted off to the side recently. Master P
column6: Juvenile
column7: Mystikal
column8: and other assorted characters from those labels have tried to rediscover their careers in the blog era with little success
column9: while you're more likely nowadays to hear about New Orleans in the music of Drake than Lil Wayne. But the most devastating blow to the city's viability came when the prolific Lil Boosie
column10: a Baton Rouge native who nonetheless assumed the crown as New Orleans' hometown hero
column11: went to jail in 2010.

column1: The artists of Trill Ent.
column2: the label that housed Boosie and was responsible for the city's vitality after Wayne moved to Miami
column3: have since lost their relevance-- with one notable exception. Mouse on tha Track is a producer by trade-- he was behind the boards for the label's true pop crossover tracks like ""Wipe Me Down"" and ""Independent""-- but he's turned to rapping recently
column4: maybe out of necessity. His 2011 mixtape Swagga Fresh Freddie was eye-opening for reviving bounce music
column5: long the backbone of the New Orleans rap scene. But Millionaire Dreamzzz
column6: released as 2012 wound down
column7: raises the bar. It displays a Mouse that has come into his own as an MC
column8: reliant less on what he is reviving and more on his own personality.

column1: Swagga Fresh Freddie is still a whippit of delirious fun
column2: but Millionaire Dreamzzz makes it sound quaint. Where Mouse once occupied a role in his music similar to that of classic bounce MCs who would freestyle call-and-response chants over beats
column3: he has now moved closer to crafting actual rap songs. The model is still more or less the same
column4: but Mouse has a noticeable confidence in himself that he didn't have before. On songs off the previous tape like ""Biznezz is Biznezz"" or ""Stupid Like Them Hoes""
column5: it sounded like he was having trouble finding his footing over the jitteriness of beats that spurt every which way
column6: or as if he had chosen vocal takes at random.

column1: But Millionaire Dreamzzz immediately makes it clear that something has changed. On second track ""I'm About It""
column2: Mouse calmly settles into a lithe sing-song flow that turns the track into one three and a half minute hook. On ""Hand Rub""
column3: he flips a meme into a piston-shifting party anthem with multiple choruses that weaves vocal samples into the beat without getting overpowered by them. That track is emblematic of how Mouse has changed with his second tape-- his beats are still bonkers
column4: but now they're in service of something greater than just sounding wild. He is not vying for attention or at odds with his beats-- the Mouse of Millionaire Dreamz has harnessed his greatest asset.

column1: But more than anything he is rounding into a viable solo artist thanks to his growth as a vocalist. Two of the album's best tracks are stuck on the end of what is already a long tape
column2: but they prove more than any tracks that Mouse isn't a one-trick wonder. ""Sip Some Moet"" and ""Millionaire Dreaming"" are basically R&B songs
column3: but they're also logical extensions of what Mouse does throughout the tape. His endlessly catchy playground flow shifts from sing-song to just singing
column4: allowing his songwriting to shine. R&B is not Mouse's endgame
column5:
but the tracks offer that there's still more to come from this unlikely torchbearer.

Perhaps when the time comes to organize 2013 into neat lists

column1: Over the past century
column2: messages have been divided into zeroes and ones for purposes of primitive transmission
column3: encoded secrets
column4: S.O.S. signals; the title of Dutch Uncles' third album
column5: Out of Touch in the Wild

column7: and watching friends succumb to drugs

column9: Dutch Uncles stick to a rigidly pointillist
column10: exacting scheme of glassy
column11: Reichian xylophone and marimba
column12: Talk Talk-y guitar ticks
column13: and choppy Stravinsky-inspired string sections
column14: for a prismatic take on herky-jerky pop that approaches complex situations like a beguiling data visualization.

column1: Out of Touch is far from all head without heart
column2: but singer and pianist Duncan Wallis' primary lyrical and emotional defense mechanism-- and that's the primary position from which he sings-- is to clam up for sake of keeping the peace. ""There's a time to hide everything/ The way that you are
column3: where you've been
column4: he sings at the start of ""Fester""
column5: an ominous sign that even the record's creators might have held it at arms' length. But tiny clues emerge: ""The times I hide behind a smile/ That says you were right/ You were always right
column6: betrays a sardonic acceptance of the futility of trying to argue
column7: while the rigidly rhythmic xylophone tings are undercut with a palpable sense of agitation; like watching someone give an important speech while failing to subtly relieve an itch caused by their suit.

column1: The band have specified the meaning of a few of the songs-- the spinning
column2: baroque ""Godboy"" is about a friend's hopeless death
column3: the wonky funk of ""Bellio"" concerns the first taste of an intense sensation-- but you'd be hard pushed to tell. ""Thematically it's just saying
column4: I'm fucked
column5: I don't know what's going on
column6: Wallis has said
column7: and lines like
column8: ""Never has it been so long since thoughts consoled/ But the reason that came before is gone
column9: from ""Phaedra"" (think Shugo Tokumaru covering Wild Beasts) function like wordy shields protecting an ineffable sensation. The constant tip-toeing around emotion is frustrating
column10: the effect coming off like a message broken in transmission.

column1: However

You can tell a lot about how Christopher Owens is feeling by looking at his hair. Back in 2009
column3: when Girls first emerged
column4: Owens' long
column5: greasy locks seemed to serve a strategic purpose: They formed a thick veil behind which he could seek sanctuary
column6: as he exposed the pain and longing that fuelled attention-seizing early singles like ""Lust for Life"" and ""Hellhole Ratrace"". The mesmerizing qualities of hair certainly weren't lost on Owens

column8: Album
column9: and who used the lead-off track on 2011's follow-up
column10: <a href=""http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/15811-father-son-holy-ghost/"" target=""_blank""><i>Father
column11: Son
column12: Holy Ghost
column13: to reassert his ""dirty hair"" as an outsider status symbol. But Owens treated the more nakedly confessional songs of <i>Father
column14: Son
column15: Holy Ghost as an opportunity to clean up his visage; the tours for that album saw him more comfortably settle into the role of bandleader
column16: facing the crowds and late-night TV-show cameras straight-on through a neatly parted
column17: tidily trimmed coiffure.

column1: So it's rather curious that 0n the cover of his first release since Girls' surprising dissolution
column2: Owens appears to be both ready for his close-up yet eager to use his mangy mane as a barrier. It's but the first of many contradictions that define the equally fascinating and frustrating Lysandre

column1: When an artist opts to release a record under their own name
column2: there's often the implication that songs will be more autobiographical and introspective. But where Girls provided Owens with a vehicle to translate his uniquely fucked-up life experiences into affirming
column3: universal anthems
column4: Lysandre presents very specific details of a particular moment in Owens' life-- complete with names
column5: locations
column6: and copious references to his singer-songwriter vocation-- in a more contrived setting. It's as if he were staging a dramatized meta-musical about his life. On the opening address ""Here We Go""
column7: Owens sings
column8: ""If your heart is broken/ You will find fellowship with me"" as if introducing himself to the audience as a character in his own play
column9: the song's serene
column10: pastoral-folk finger-picking and titular command signaling the dimming of the house lights.

column1: Owens recently admitted to Pitchfork that Lysandre is an album that he just had to get out of his system
column2: presumably to bring proper closure to the romantic relationship that blossoms and flames out (in inverse relation to Owens' ascendant musical career) over the course of the record. Though divided into 11 tracks
column3: Lysandre functions as a single
column4: continuous piece
column5: with a recurring instrumental motif (""Lysandre's Theme"") serving as a thread and reinforcing that sense of feeling haunted by a memory. But if the story of Lysandre is so significant to Owens that it demanded its own song cycle
column6: his musical treatments don't always do the material justice.

column1: On Girls' albums
column2: Owens undercut the sense of despair with moments of levity
column3: but Lysandre overemphasizes the latter quality to the point of undermining the sensitive subject matter. The chirpy flute lines that cut through ""Here We Go"" and the buoyant title track cross the line from classy embellishment to garish distraction
column4: and the disarming portraits of poverty
column5: desperation
column6: and violence that run through ""New York City"" are neutered by an oddly upbeat execution that confuses the Velvet Underground's idea of rock 'n' roll with that of Huey Lewis
column7: thanks to an interminably goofy sax solo that oversells the optimism of starting life anew in the Big Apple. But even those transgressions don't quite prepare you for ""Riviera Rock""
column8: a transitional mid-album ersatz-Santana jam that apparently signifies some unexplained tropical-getaway plot turn
column9: but comes off like a tiki-lounge act's introducing-the-band segment.

column1: Owens is keenly aware of the risks he's taking with Lysandre: Though the insecurities expressed on the winsome ""Love Is in the Ear of the Listener""-- ""What if everybody just thinks I'm a phony/ What if nobody ever gets it?""-- may stem from his early-career stage fright
column2: they're just as trenchant now that he's derailed a much-loved and increasingly popular band to go solo. But the songwriting is rarely a problem on Lysandre: The dolorous acoustic ballads ""A Broken Heart"" and ""Everywhere You Knew"" show that Owens' command of understated devastation remains unparalleled
column3: using simple
column4: seemingly mundane imagery to set unspeakably intimate scenes of awkward first kisses and airport farewells. And the excellent closer ""Part of Me (Lysandre's Epilogue)"" brings this occasionally gaudy album to a refreshingly grounded conclusion
column5: forsaking the baroque flourishes in favour of a Harvest-worthy harmonica refrain and gently rollicking country rhythm. ""You were a part of me/ That part of me is gone
column6: Owens sings with a combination of sadness and relief

column10: Owens emerges from the other side of Lysandre sounding liberated
column11:
and ready to brush that hair out of his eyes once again.

With 3
column2: Retribution Gospel Choir have finally made a record worthy of a Crazy Horse-inspired Midwestern rock band featuring two-thirds of Low. That's not a slam against RGC's previous releases
column3: just that Retribution Gospel Choir
column4: 2
column5: and last year's aggressively minor The Revolution EP were likeable stabs at classic-rock posturing that never really took. For all the sincere affection Alan Sparhawk clearly has for heavy-riffing songs rooted in AOR conventions-- he even dug out a cowbell for The Revolution-- it always seemed more like play-acting than a truly natural guise. There was no question about his desire to write visceral rock songs; what was debatable was whether he was any good at it.

column1: 3 is the ultimate RGC record
column2: and the ultimate departure
column3: composed of just two songs-- recorded live in the studio in one take-- that each run in the neighborhood of 20 minutes. It's a bit of a shock coming after The Revolution
column4: the slickest and hookiest RGC record to date
column5: not to mention the shtickiest. The soft-rock affectations of recent Low records like 2011's C'mon got the funhouse mirror treatment on The Revolution
column6: with RGC verging awkwardly on full-blown power-pop and self-conscious 70s rock cheese. 3 is a wilder
column7: woolier
column8: and yet more coherent beast.

column1: Just when RGC seemed to be turning into a borderline jokey chaser for Sparhawk's more thoughtful work in Low
column2: 3 takes a sharp 180-degree turn toward some of the deepest
column3: most exploratory music he's yet made under the moniker. It satisfies Sparhawk's need to crank up the amps away from Low while at the same time retaining the mastery of atmosphere and subtly evolving soundscapes that distinguishes his better known band. ""Can't Walk Out"" is a fearsome
column4: nearly wordless squall of freeform fury
column5: with Sparhawk oscillating between barely contained chaos and a hard-charging groove that swings between Live at Leeds and A Tribute to Jack Johnson. The point of RGC until now has been about releasing the energy that Low keeps under wraps. But ""Can't Walk Out"" builds a head of steam and turns it in on itself; the tension only increases as Sparhawk's guitar rages over the stormy
column6: thoroughly submerged rhythms supplied by bassist Steve Garrington and drummer Eric Pollard. The final result is a thing of thrilling
column7: terrifying beauty
column8: like a tornado held on the horizon at a safe distance.

column1: The other track
column2: ""Seven""
column3: is relatively catchy
column4: though it goes on for a minute longer. ""Seven"" occasionally wanders back to a pretty folk-rock chorus that's as bleary-eyed as the simple melody that RGC mangles
column5: mends
column6: and mangles again during a sprawling
column7: extemporaneous jam. The wobbly guitar lines that drop into the mix unmistakably belong to special guest star Nels Cline
column8: who exhibits a similar telepathy with Sparhawk that he shares on-stage with Jeff Tweedy in Wilco. For long
column9: wondrous stretches in the back half of ""Seven""
column10: Cline and Sparhawk lock in to form a breathtaking duet of feedback and slow-motion soloing.

column1: The obvious companion to 3 is last year's Neil Young and Crazy Horse double-LP
column2: Psychedelic Pill. Sparhawk certainly isn't afraid to let his songs go on as long as Young does
column3: and his excellent guitar playing is worthy of comparison to one of rock's all-time great sludgy shape-shifters. But 3 also warrants a nod to Low; it's surprising how well the high points of this record line up with Low's strong suits.

column1: The best parts of Low albums often occur in the spaces between the music; few bands are as good about not filling every cubic inch with sound
column2: allowing the listener to settle in and find their own place inside the songs. Retribution Gospel Choir have achieved the same quality on 3; the landscape is thornier
column3: but equally vast
column4: formless
column5: and inviting for ample exploring over multiple listens. Before now
column6: Retribution Gospel Choir records were a little too straight-forward
column7: spilling all of the information they had to offer too quickly. On 3
column8:
they've turned up the noise without spoiling the mystery.

The latest in a long line of Young Jeezy mixtapes opens with the veteran MC feeling ""sick and tired of the bullshit"" being perpetrated by fake rappers and fake gangsters

column5: E-40 has been perfecting a philosophy that Jeezy seems to be coming around to: the best way for an artist now beyond their most marketable years to compete against the hot new things is to simply declare themselves out of their league
column6: and to act and create accordingly.

column1: Not to give the impression that Young Jeezy's shopping for a La-Z-Boy and a spot in a retirement community. While ""RIP""
column2: ""All the Same""
column3: the frictionless
column4: Warren G-produced ""Just Got Word""
column5: and the fantastically nasty Trey Songz-assisted sex jam ""Tonight"" are badass in their own not-giving-a-fuck kind of way

Mystical Weapons is a collaboration between Deerhoof drummer Greg Saunier and Sean Lennon. Lennon has had a solo career since the mid-90s and is
column2: of course
column3: the son of John Lennon and Yoko Ono
column4: but to read the press materials for this project's debut
column5: you wouldn't know that if you didn't already know his name. He's billed as ""Sean Lennon (The Ghost of a Saber Tooth Tiger)
column6: as though his membership in the folky duo he performs in with girlfriend Charlotte Kemp Muhl is the one thing for which he's best known. (For comparison
column7: Saunier is billed as ""Greg Saunier (Deerhoof)."")

column1: Most of the pieces are short-- nearly half are under two minutes-- and they range quite a bit in tone and feel. The most immediately gripping is ""Colony Collapse Disorder""
column2: an airy track with swelling keyboards that sounds a little like it could've been recorded in Germany in 1972. Saunier's drumming brings to mind the lose-the-groove approach of U.S. Maple
column3: backing away every time it approaches a steady pulse. While this piece is moody and highly charged
column4: others are sketchier or outright chaotic. ""Gross Domestic Happiness"" begins agreeably
column5: but by the time you get four minutes in

column7: clattering percussion
column8: and evil synthesizer.

column2: and the most inspired moments are great. The way Saunier at first meets Lennon's weird keyboard phrases in a similar rhythm
column3: then completely changes the emphasis to give the piece a whole different feel on ""Goddess Curlers"" is one good example. This is
column4: ultimately
column5: a record of the moment
column6: though
column7: and not one likely to leave any melodies lingering in your head. Deerhoof fans will have to make a much shorter leap to get into this than fans of Lennon's solo work
column8: but in either case
column9: it's missing the anchors of voice
column10: melody
column11: and songwriting that characterize both discographies. There's plenty to love on Mystical Weapons

column13:

column3: Arbouretum's sophomore album

column5: put a darker
column6: broodier spin on Americana. The album's opening track
column7: ""Signposts and Instruments"" still stands as the Baltimore-based quartet's finest moment-- an ethereal dirge that seems far more otherworldly and bizarre than the its handful of slow-mo power chords should allow for. Delivered in an echo-laden whisper

column9: work-a-day
column10: lovey-dovey-ness
column11: the doom-shrouded folk-moves on Rites of Uncovering had an appeal.

column1: In the years since
column2: the band's struggled to strike a similar compromise between spirit-world imagery and Americana-tinged bar-rock. On their subsequent records
column3: Arbouretum fortified its heavier inclinations. They became a tighter and louder band-- dialing in gritty fuzz tones and extending the free-form freak-outs beyond the 10-minute range-- but as the music's density increased

column1: On Coming Out of the Fog
column2: the band's new album
column3: Arbouretum's eerier inclinations are back in alignment with their amplifiers. As a lyricist
column4: Heumann favors heavy subject matter-- suffering
column5: isolation
column6: mortal man's impossible struggle against natural or supernatural forces-- and he often saturates each line with a mouthful of syllables. ""I've no need of lampreys now nor the funerary ode

column10: Heumann sets a concrete scene-- longing for beach-side serenity-- before slipping into impressionistic language.

column4: barely shifting grooves. On ""World Split Open"" the band rides a single grinding riff for all it's worth

column3: Richard Thompson
column4: and even Western Saharan outfits

Yo La Tengo's classic mid-1990s run (Painful
column2: Electr-o-Pura
column3: and I Can Hear the Heart Beating as One) perfectly embodied the era's collective embrace of the mix-tape-as-courtship-device. These records were sprawling yet intimate
column4: stylistically all over the map yet purposefully constructed. And whether they took the form of earwax-melting noise freakouts or bossa nova lullabies
column5: they always projected the unmistakable
column6: endearing personalities of their makers. But technological changes over the past decade have rendered the mix-tape (or CD-R) an outmoded concept as the shuffled playlist has become the cornerstone of our contemporary listening habits. What was once a unique
column7: painstakingly assembled listening experience has become our default mode.

column1: And true to their quietly contrarian
column2: trend-averse nature
column3: Yo La Tengo have responded to our accelerated
column4: quick-click culture with a more patient approach: Since 2000's And Then Nothing Turned Itself Inside-Out
column5: their albums have mostly favoured calming consistency over unpredictable pastiche
column6: while their more outre interests have been redirected toward side projects (see: the garage-punk goofiness of Condo Fucks) or improvised soundtrack work (2002's The Sounds of the Sounds of Science). And even though their most recent releases have shown a renewed interest in stretching songs past the 10-minute mark
column7: these extended pieces are segregated from the more pop-oriented material on the tracklist
column8: serving as bookends (2006's I Am Not Afraid of You and I Will Beat Your Ass) or shunted off to separate sides of vinyl (2009's Popular Songs).

column1: Fade takes the refinement process one step further
column2: revisiting the brief
column3: breezy-listening forms of Popular Songs' first two sides
column4: but lopping off the backloaded free-form excursions entirely. And at a tight 10 songs and 46 minutes
column5: it's the band's shortest album since 1990's Fakebook. But none of that is to suggest Fade is any more slight than its heftier predecessors. Even as Yo La Tengo lean to their quieter side here
column6: the band's sense of playfulness comes through. Produced by John McEntire
column7: Fade lets you appreciate the complexity of its simplicity. It may trod over some familiar turf-- Georgia Hubley's fuzz-pop standout ""Paddle Forward"" squeezes another drop of blood from ""Sugarcube""-- but the relaxed pacing and pleasing melodies belie just how much action is really going on beneath the serene surfaces.

column1: Truth is
column2: Fade can be every bit as adventurous as the band's most eclectic albums
column3: but applies its myriad layers in more subtle fashion: The opening ""Ohm"" locks into its shuffling
column4: clap-along tabla-funk groove and repetitive
column5: corrosive jangle riff for its full six-minute-plus duration
column6: before gradually thickening the guitar noise and organ drone until the anodyne group-unison vocals transform from monotone to mantra. Centerpiece track ""Stupid Things"" is even more sublime
column7: beginning with some tranquil
column8: exploratory guitar noodling from Ira Kaplan that summons a brushed-snare beat resembling a krautrock skiffle
column9: and sets its chorus aflight on a pillowy bed of strings. And the hazy
column10: soft-focus balladry of ""Two Trains"" is beautifully bent out of shape by a wobbly
column11: dubwise rhythm.

column1: As ever
column2: Kaplan and Georgia Hubley's lyrics assume the form of overheard
column3: one-way conversations between intimates falling in and out of love. And even in Fade's most sanguine moments
column4: there's a sense of unease creeping into Yo La Tengo's little corner of the world. The smooth Motown-by-way-of-Thrill Jockey moves of ""Well You Better"" belie Kaplan's anxious demands (""Baby
column5: make up your mind""); ""Is That Enough"" tries to gloss over its sense of doubt and defeat with cheeky string-section fills
column6: but the distant
column7: distorted guitar line buzzing in the background offers a lingering reminder of the bitterness being suppressed. Fade threatens to become too preoccupied with understated details during its increasingly subdued second act
column8: and yet that sense of restraint just makes the triumphant finale ""Before We Run"" soar all the more gloriously
column9: elevating Hubley's humble melody with a euphoric brass-and-string fanfare. It may not herald another big day coming
column10:
but Fade is a thoroughly immersive dusk-to-dawn soundtrack to a dark night's passing.

Parquet Courts are high as hell and they're not going to take it anymore. Stoned
column3: starving
column4: and maybe just a little bit irritable

column6: they ask co-frontman Austin Brown
column7: who quickly sends Mr. Greenpeace off with a snide-beyond-belief ""for-GET about it"" and a (questionably apropos) reminder that Socrates died in the fucking gutter. Munchie money secure

column1: Parquet cohorts Brown and Andrew Savage-- also of Fergus & Geronimo-- are slackers in an almost classical sense
column2: conjuring up just about every post-collegiate
column3: pre-responsibility
column4: sativa-hoovering tendency you can think of. Their tangent-prone music flits

column7: a knot of Silkworm-inspired guitar tangles and insistent Wire tempos. It's wound tight but fraying at the edges. They're smart but they don't always act it. They could probably play these songs a little better if they wanted to. They're very funny
column8: but not the kind of funny that makes you laugh much. They contradict themselves constantly. They probably wait until the afternoon to shower.

column1: The tension between the sharp rhythms (courtesy of Savage's brother Max) and the ace fretwork is Gold's most reliable thrill; were it not for all this forward motion from the younger Savage
column2: there's just no telling how far afield these songs would drift. Still fresh off Fergus & Geronimo's genre-hopping
column3: indie-skewering Funky Was the State of Affairs
column4: Savage seems considerably looser here: though F&G sometimes hew too closely to constraints of their source material
column5: here he drops the retro studiousness and gets a little weird. Of the pair
column6: though
column7: Brown's the real eccentric; his outburst-riddled material slot in beautifully against Savage's anthems-in-miniature. After a while
column8: you start to see the logic in all all their rambling deflections.

column1: It's not much of a stretch to hear many of of indie rock's recent go-tos-- blurry edged-production
column2: meaning-averse lyrics-- as a form of disaffection. Times are strange
column3: the future's rarely seemed less certain
column4: so it's pretty easy to see the haze surrounding indie rock as a sonic counterpoint to the unfixed nature of
column5: well
column6: everything. Parquet Courts may be potheads but they're not head-in-the-clouds escapists. And
column7: while there's a we're-all-fucked undercurrent running through Light Up Gold's lyric sheet
column8: Parquet Courts aren't about to take it sitting down. Mumbly highlight ""Careers in Combat"" speaks to a fairly uncomfortable reality: there are no more lifeguard jobs or decent gigs left
column9: but hey
column10: the military's always looking for warm bodies. Savage
column11: on ""Yonder is Closer to the Heart""
column12: sees the wadded receipts and spare change piled on his desk as a reminder of the mundane passage of time; later
column13: up to his neck in ""motivation neglect
column14: he unhappily admits ""these days I'm captive in this borrowed time."" Light Up Gold finds Parquet Courts looking to breakout through any available means: intense reflection
column15: resin hits
column16:
or rock'n'roll.

column2:
'Folk/Country']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Polyvinyl']|2013-01-14 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 17:03:03.369808|"

Shugo Tokumaru is one of those rare people who can pile instruments all over each other in a way that makes no sense on paper and then make it come off as the most natural thing in the world. He creates toy-box indie pop with his vast collection of noise makers and a computer
column3: and for all its obvious compositional refinement
column4: it's still a giddy celebration of pop music's potential for mayhem. He's been doing this for a while now
column5: with varying degrees of success
column6: but on In Focus? it all comes together in a beautifully sharp series of Technicolor audio bursts.

column1: This music is hard to place in context without referencing a dozen different things-- it has so many affinities lurking inside of it
column2: from the Beach Boys to French pop in the 60s to 70s Brazilian pop to bedroom IDM
column3: that from moment to moment it will probably remind you of something different. Tokumaru sings entirely in Japanese
column4: which for a non-speaker has the effect of turning his breathy tenor into another instrument
column5: threading its own melodies around the ones carried by the wood flutes and gadgets fluttering in the edges of the mix.

column1: ""Decorate"" has all of that
column2: balancing frenetic verses against a sweeping
column3: harmony-laden chorus-- at first it just sounds like a perfectly constructed indie pop confection
column4: but turn it up a little
column5: and a whole world of little details emerges
column6: from wooden noise makers accenting just the right part of the beat to wood flutes played in different styles depending on the texture that will best complement what's being sung at the moment. The level of thought given to the arrangements on even the shortest
column7: most incidental tracks is astounding. One of the few bands I can think of that's this audibly meticulous is Field Music
column8: but their arrangements are never so colorfully bricolaged.

column1: You can practically hear the kaleidoscope twist to make fresh patterns over the rocketing mid-section of ""Shirase""
column2: as brightly hued instruments tumble into new positions with each passing moment. Though it makes left turns and constantly tweaks its formulas
column3: In Focus? is admirably coherent and cohesive
column4: with each little pile-up of ideas finding its place in the big pile-up of ideas that comprises the album. Tokumaru may not be able to stay in one place for long
column5:
but I'd still say the answer to the question of the title is yes.

Conor O'Brien earned comparisons to the likes of Conor Oberst
column2: Damien Rice
column3: and Glen Hansard on Villagers' 2010 debut Becoming a Jackal
column4: and they were deserved on a musical level: as with Bright Eyes
column5: the Frames
column6: and Rice's solo work
column7: Villagers start with humble folk and build outwards with daunting orchestral arrangements and subtle electronics. Implicit in those comparisons is the assumption of O'Brien as a similarly young old-soul
column8: a world-weary troubadour who lives to fight an eternal struggle: How does one convey the truth to the listener without sounding like a pedant
column9: or worse
column10: a fool? Success is typically achieved in a way that parallels the expansive demeanor of the music: starting with the knowledge that everyone is at the very least an expert on their own experience
column11: and using your own truth to project outwards towards larger ideas. That's where O'Brien breaks rank
column12: as Villagers take the opposite approach on the occasionally charming but mostly frustrating {Awayland}
column13: an album which too often has big ideas and little proof of how he arrived at them.

column1: The charms are there
column2: though. O'Brien's voice is expressive and controlled
column3: hitting every quiver and quaver just right and there's an astringent
column4: citric quality that allows the smallest amount to pierce through. His tone rarely rises above a conversation
column5: yet it always manages to forefront itself no matter how grand the arrangements get behind him. And they certainly are grand
column6: or at least the sound that Mercury Prize nominations were made for
column7: folk-rock earthy and glossy as a gemstone
column8: but grounded in an earnest presentation that counters any temptation to call it ""slick."" He's claimed the influence of film composers such as Lalo Schifrin
column9: which mostly manifests in strings pulling all sorts of dips and derring-do over tense
column10: tight minor chord progressions. (My guess is O'Brien would be disappointed if the two-minute instrumental that bisects {Awayland} was described as anything other than ""cinematic."")

column1: {Awayland} demonstrates admirable range in more traditional formats: ""The Waves"" is genuinely surprising
column2: evolving from Morse code blips to a satisfying
column3: frothy climax of distorted guitars
column4: while ""Nothing Arrived"" situates a pat lyrical resolution (""I waited for something/ and something died/ so I waited for nothing/ and nothing arrived"") amidst easygoing pianos and acoustics like a wordy rendering of Travis ca. 12 Memories. O'Brien does have a knack for melodies that hit squarely
column5: but too much of {Awayland} prides itself in lyrical misdirection that renders his tunefulness an afterthought.

column1: The misappropriated ambition is charming in an undergrad sort of way
column2: and believe me
column3: it will find an audience as long as college kids rubber-stamp indie-folk with poetic pretensions and the authenticity assumed from an Irish accent. O'Brien prefers giving his songs titles and choruses that are declarative (""Judgment Call""
column4: ""Earthly Pleasure""
column5: ""In a Newfoundland You Are Free"") and images that suggest permanence-- trees
column6: waves
column7: and guns as loaded metaphors. And they often come across as trenchant out of context
column8: such as ""The Waves""
column9: which claims ""one man's innocence is another's chance"" in a way that overstates its profundity. Likewise
column10: any one of these fragments from the unconvincingly sinister ""Passing a Message"" could evolve towards an insightful conclusion
column11: but O'Brien structures his stories like Jenga puzzles
column12: a lattice of solid pieces that feel intentionally and ultimately fated to crumble once shared: ""I was carving my name out of a giant sequoia tree/ I was blind to its beauty now it's all I can see/ I learned how to listen to the folks on TV/ They are passing a message that means nothing to me.""

column1: ""The Bell"" is paradoxically the most overt demonstration of the strangely smug tone
column2: an inverse ""Bigmouth Strikes Again"" that tries to find humor out of having nothing new to say. It is also a song about the futility of communication that is five minutes long and features lyrics like ""there is a passenger in every useless word/ can never be twisted or sold/ senator of my skin/ a body of discipline/ must be a million years old."" An extremely kind reading of it would be required to believe lines like the aforementioned are supposed to be self-deprecating
column3: an intentionally purple exaggeration. Especially in light of a confession like ""there's a sleeping dog under this dialog/ obedient only to rhyme/ but if I could beckon her/ if I could find the words/ all they would be is lies
column4: which comes off like more of a boast than apology. To its credit
column5: {Awayland} rarely comes across as false
column6:
but O’Brien's affinity for cleverness over clarity ensures it rarely comes across in any real way.
