Roc Marciano is the butter-smooth pimp
column2: with a melt in your-mouth flow and silky punchlines to match. Action Bronson is the melancholic Albanian foodie with a persistent fear of death and a love for pulp romanticism. Ka is the cold-as-ice gangster veteran from the tough streets of Brownsville. Heems is the internal-rhyme instigator
column3: fiercely proud of who he is
column4: and willing to defend his right to eat at the rap roundtable. The outer borough rap scene is currently filled to the brim with larger-than-life personalities. So what room does that leave for a rapper like Meyhem Lauren
column5: who
column6: despite his linebacker-size and occasional wit
column7: has yet to flesh out a recognizable persona in the midst of the flashy characters that surround him? It leaves him
column8: in a word
column9: forgettable
column10: and in danger of joining the tradition of B and C list New York rappers who were blurrier shadows of their more talented counterparts. (Think of the way a gangster-lite
column11: punchline rapper like Papoose consistently echoed the more charismatic Fabolous).

column1: Lauren's recently released mixtape
column2: Mandatory Brunch Meetings
column3: doesn't do much to rectify the situation. It's a perfectly adequate listen
column4: upgraded by beats by underground heavies like Mike Finito and Harry Fraud. And yet
column5: even with 17 tracks to explore his options
column6: Lauren still seems unable to decide
column7: or unwilling to reveal
column8: exactly who it is he wants to be.

column1: That's not to say that the man they call Laurenovitch is without a personality. It's just that there's no real way to tell
column2: over the course of his overstuffed mixtapes
column3: which character is the true Lauren. Is he a fun-loving behemoth or a raw Queens goon? Is he sensible
column4: an endorser of condoms and money made legally
column5: or totally absurd
column6: always out for a laugh
column7: with a shottie cocked underneath the seat? There are lines on Mandatory Brunch Meetings that indicate all of the above
column8: along with a host of other possible options.

column1: On the Harry Fraud-produced standout
column2: ""10 Dollar Lap Dances""
column3: he's an aggro punchline rapper
column4: a ""raw dealer fly like Blake Griffin over a four-wheeler"" who smashes women like ""negligent pedestrians."" ""Kelly Kapowski""
column5: a should-be nostaligic ode to the Saved by the Bell pinup
column6: finds him in romantic mode
column7: describing the perfect woman in the most generic terms imaginable. And ""Burgundy Guess Jeans"" is all over the place-- on the chorus his ""gun sings
column8: then he's all alliteration
column9: ""provocative
column10: producing pargraphs professionally
column11: and then
column12: suddenly reflective
column13: wishing he ""could put time in a freezer…you only live once on this Earth
column14: gotta explore it."" These consistent switches in subject matter leave you with nothing to latch onto
column15: nothing to render the song memorable without the help of a catchy beat.

column1: To add to his problems
column2: Lauren never really bothers to switch up his flow or tone
column3: consistently rapping in the aggressive half-shout which is the official rap equivalent of a monotone. You would think a song on which the rapper admires a pair of ""Beautiful Areolas"" might actually consist of some admiration
column4: but even an admittedly hilarious line like ""her nipples look like silver dollar pancakes"" is delivered with a nonchalance that dulls what should be a standout bar.

column1: The tape has two significant redeeming qualities-- consistently excellent gritty New York beats and outstanding guest features. Tommy Mas makes strings sing on ""Thousand Dollar Gym Shoes"" while Lauren delivers perhaps his best line of the tape
column2: informing the listener that ""how to be a stupid nigga is the class we skipped."" But Bronson
column3: who guests on the song
column4: outdoes him without even trying
column5: stringing together a couple of phrases that actually make sense consecutively. The end of his verse-- ""selling salmon so my son can eat
column6: I'm trying to have a little taste of this life until I'm underneath""-- gives you a perfect idea of who Bronson is
column7: even if you've never heard him spit a bar before.

column1: The surprise guest of the tape is Gabbie Giftsz
column2: a Brooklyn rapper with the accent of Nicki Minaj and the attitude of Ms. Roq. She's hugely entertaining on ""Silk and Leather Rap""
column3: sing-songing her way through Freddie Krueger comparisons and launching into double-time for some charismatic brag raps. And her ad-hoc shit talking is probably the funniest moment on a tape flooded with ridiculous ad-libs.

column1: Part of Lauren's appeal is his group mentality; this willingness to entertain guests like Bronson
column2: Giftsz
column3: Heems
column4: Hologram
column5: and other rappers on his projects can sometimes make his mixtapes seem more like block parties. This was true on last year's Respect the Fly Shit
column6: on which a South by Southwest hotel room hosted a revolving door of capable rappers. That project flattered perceptions of Lauren by showing him to be a solid player in a vibrant
column7: ascending musical scene. But when the group falls away
column8: and Lauren is forced to make a track stand on its own
column9: he becomes a cipher
column10:
refusing to belong to any kind of definable category. MC can stand for many things but it should never stand for miscellaneous-- Lauren's inability to pick an angle leaves him standing behind the brightest stars in his class.

column1: 0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/18697/homepage_large.0652553d.jpg|Rifts|28187.0|Oneohtrix Point Never|['Experimental']|0.0|1.0|1.0|['Mexican Summer'
column3: said Daniel Lopatin in a 2009 interview with The Wire. His point was it's wrong to reject specific sounds-- in this case
column4: the synth tones used in 1980s new age-- simply out of disdain for the genre they're associated with. In one sense
column5: Lopatin's solo project Oneohtrix Point Never is an ongoing battle against timbral fascism. He's tried to liberate synth sounds from their conventional trappings
column6: placing them in less familiar contexts and coaxing you to hear them in new ways.

column1: This laid-back battle began with Lopatin's first album
column2: 2007's <i>Betrayed in the Octagon
column3: which he called ""a stoned space epic about one really bad day in the life of an astronaut."" His astronaut landed on a strange planet in 2009's Russian Mind and wrote the score to his own death in 2009's Zones Without People. But more interesting than that inscrutable tale was the way that
column4: throughout this trilogy
column5: Lopatin re-imagined synth music for the current era
column6: injecting tension into something normally soft and cheesy. New age got a bad rep because it became too light to resonate
column7: simplifying emotion instead of creating it. But even Lopatin's most beatific arpeggios and most soothing drones avoid sentimentality and easy-listening ambience.

column1: That became clearer when New York noise label No Fun packaged those first three albums together-- along with tracks from smaller-run releases-- into the 2009 double CD Rifts. Listen to one track here or there and it can be tough to hear how lighter moments differ from the saccharine cloud of incidental mood music. But immerse yourself for long stretches
column2: and Rifts sounds more like the hypnotic marathons of Terry Riley than something playing in a store that sells candles and crystals. In that sense
column3: the set was greater than the sum of its original albums. Absorbing all two and a half hours revealed commonalities between Lopatin's disparate constructions-- the kind that aren't apparent when you take OPN in small doses.

column1: The immersion opportunities are even greater on Lopatin's new version of Rifts
column2: issued on his own label Software. This lavish 5xLP/ 3xCD set includes six more tracks from previous releases
column3: stretching it past the three-hour mark. Revisiting Rifts in this expanded (and reordered) form
column4: I've found its stoic sadness even more impressive. Lopatin finds poignancy in wavering tones and rippling notes
column5: conveying a sense of loss mixed with stiff-lipped acceptance. Even the set's one curveball-- an acoustic guitar song called ""I Know It's Taking Pictures From Another Plane (Inside Your Sun)""-- carries this tone
column6: and sounds logical squeezed in between synth-scapes.

column1: The rich moods of Rifts persist in the tracks Lopatin adds to this version. Take the hymn-like despondency in the trebly voices of ""Memory Vague."" Or the slow lurch of ""The Trouble With Being Born""
column2: which sounds like a defeated army returning home
column3: dejected enough to hang their heads but prideful enough to march in step. Such complex sentiments have marked Lopatin's work even as he's moved to the noisier drones of 2010's Returnal and the glitchier loops of 2011's Replica.

column1: So in retrospect
column2: the path OPN has traveled makes sense. But when I first got Betrayed in the Octagon from No Fun in 2007
column3: it was a bit of a shock. At that point the noise underground was still in an <a href=""http://pitchfork.com/features/articles/7702-the-decade-in-noise/"">upswing
column4: and the harsher sounds of Carlos Giffoni's label (and festival) led the charge. There was diversity inside the No Fun umbrella
column5: but nothing there sounded like Betrayed in the Octagon. It turns out that Giffoni and Lopatin were prescient
column6: or at least observant
column7: because soon many other underground artists began mining new age styles.

column1: That trend may be less in vogue a couple of years later
column2: but it survives. Just in the past two months
column3: excellent forays into new age-tinted synth have come from noise-leaning types such as Joseph Raglani
column4: Robert Beatty
column5: and M. Geddes Gengras. All of which makes Rifts look like an important touchstone
column6:
and it should. The way Lopatin discovered fresh ideas inside of a worn-out genre is an inspiring story for the present age.

"|17504.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/17504-rifts/|8.7|Marc Masters

column2: 'Experimental'
column4: a Los Angeles native who records glitchy psychedelia under the name Sun Araw
column5: and the similarly inclined L.A. electronic musician M. Geddes Gengras decamped to Jamaica to record with the legendary roots reggae group the Congos
column6: whose Lee ""Scratch"" Perry-produced 1977 debut Heart of the Congos was one of the best albums to come out of Jamaica at a time when the island was producing an unprecedented amount of incredible music. It was an odd team-up
column7: a bunch of older
column8: very serious musicians collaborating across stylistic and cultural gaps with a couple of punkish young noise dudes
column9: but the resulting record
column10: Icon Give Thank
column11: is a surprisingly organic synthesis of traditional reggae and envelope-pushing electronic experimentation. Now
column12: what was originally presented as a one-off partnership
column13: has spawned a live sequel.

column1: Considering the depth of Stallones and Gengras' electronically manipulated production and the improvisatory feel to the recording
column2: it's unlikely the coalition could have reproduced it accurately live
column3: and this performance captured last June at the Village Underground in London at times only barely resembles their studio collaboration. Which is actually fine-- worrying about making an exact recreation of Icon Give Thank would be antithetical to its free-flowing energy
column4: and would be kind of pointless to boot.

column1: Placed side by side the two recordings make interesting companions. It seems fair to call Icon Give Thank the music of the Congos filtered through their new partners' forward-looking sensibilities. Icon Give Life
column2: on the other hand
column3: sounds more like the Congos hauling Gengras and Stallones back to the late 70s and throwing them and their gear into the anarchic electronics assemblage that comprised Perry's Black Ark Studios.

column1: Backed by a group advertised as the Raw Power Band
column2: the Congos
column3: Stallones
column4: and Gengras make a respectable reggae outfit. The grooves are thick and dense
column5: and frequently display the assertive muscularity that characterized the ""rockers"" reggae that captivated Jamaican audiences around the time that the Congos first formed. The electronic flourishes that gave Icon Give Thank such a unique sound are placed further back in the live mix where they play the same role that Perry's delay-soaked embellishments did in the dubby Heart of the Congos.

column1: Like Icon Give Thank
column2: Icon Give Life wavers between its two musical poles before finding the proper balance. The songs where the spotlight is more directly on the Congos are perfectly enjoyable-- the fine
column3: high voices of founders Roydel ""Ashanti"" Johnson and Cedric Myton haven't aged too noticeably
column4: and the rest of the group and the Raw Power Band cohere nicely
column5: with the proper amount of looseness to feel more like an actual working band than a nostalgic reproduction of one. The parts that are heavier on the noise dudes are less successful. On the record-closing rendition of ""Fisherman""
column6: one of the Congos' signature cuts
column7: Stallones and Gengras' attempts to add dubby texture overwhelms the song itself
column8: and for a minute the project does exactly the worst thing an unlikely collaboration like this can do
column9: which is make the listener question what these musicians are doing together in the first place.

column1: But the two sides meld most seamlessly on ""Thanks and Praise""
column2: one of the songs that the Congos
column3: Stallones
column4: and Gengras composed together. The instrumentation is sparse
column5: with synthesized beeps and whirs bouncing off of hand drums and psychedelically modulated guitar arpeggios. Above this nearly abstract instrumental bed the Congos layer droning vocal parts that are closer to incantation than singing. The song doesn't build any sort of dynamic
column6: it just sort of drifts along
column7: but after two or three of its seven minutes the disparate elements cohere into a vaguely mystical whole
column8:
the group onstage transformed suddenly into an unlikely band of shamanic spirit guides. It's a gorgeous moment that you might wish would never end.

Wu-Tang MC Masta Killa's long-delayed third solo effort began its life as Loyalty & Royalty. Then Loyalty splintered; a guest-heavy disc under that name is promised soon
column3: while the sample-centric

We've gotten pretty used to the oil-and-water relationship between meddling A&Rs with dollar signs in their eyes and rappers who know you can't make money selling records when you have no records to sell. But we're not talking Waka at Warner Brothers here; this is a Masta Killa record on Nature Sounds. You might think reshifting the focus back on the Soul side of things might make for a more taut

column1: With plenty of distended soul samples

column4: GZA-mentored flow

It's difficult to place exactly where Californian musician Tim Gray is trying to position the music he records under his Ethernet alias. On last year's Into the Woods

column9: during a period when he was working night shifts providing technical support for hospital operating rooms. The feeling of being removed from reality burns through the album
column10: as you'd expect from music recorded under such circumstances. At times it feels cut off from humanity altogether
column11: with Gray locked into a deeply contemplative
column12: utterly inward-looking journey.

column1: Opus 2 may be a solitary work

column4: Grouper
column5: and Wolfgang Voigt under his Gas alias have all inhabited similarly desolate places. It's all rolling clouds
column6: amorphous surfaces

column10: but still one that feels like Gray had to forsake everything around him in order to extract its refined grace. There's nothing else here that returns to a similar point
column11: again suggesting that he hasn't quite got around to coloring in the bigger picture for Ethernet. Leaving the project in aesthetic flux is fine
column12: too

column6: sometimes even threatening to overwhelm the track altogether. That's where Opus 2 disconnects from more placid pieces in this field. There's a brittle edge to it
column7: sidling toward unease at times. You can blank out the world to ""Dog Star""
column8: but it doesn't deposit you in a place of rest. Instead
column9: there's a creeping sense of anxiety to it
column10: a feeling of troubled thoughts seeping into the stillness.

column1: There's plenty of similar sentiment spread throughout this record
column2: and acres of room in which to explore it; none of the six tracks dip below the seven-minute mark. But at this point there should be a better idea of the overall direction Gray wants to take Ethernet in. At times
column3: the primitive

column5: but it's too vast a leap from the swirling darkness that gathers around a track like ""Correction"". Of course

column7: one train of thought
column8: one place to dwell in. But there needs to be a firming up of the bridges being built-- if not an overall Ethernet ""sound"" then at least a sense of connections being hammered out to bind Gray's disparate inclinations. Fortunately
column9: Opus 2 ends on a high. The ever-repeating figures of ""Pleroma"" are where the album peaks
column10: in a glassy elegy that sweeps away everything before it with its infinite weight and heightened ambition
column11:
opening up a trail that Gray would be wise to further scrutinize.

column11: Johnson has described himself as the epitome of a hermit

column16: in his words

In the 1990s there were a few artists tucked into out-of-the-way corners of the United States making music defined by its vastness. In Richmond
column2: Va.
column3: were Labradford
column4: whose slow-moving and cinematic pieces showed how much could be wrung from simplicity and repetition. Up in Dearborn
column5: Mich.
column6: Windy Weber and Carl Hultgren were making sensual drone music inspired both by the endless held tones of Lamonte Young and the textural romanticism of 4AD. And down in East Austin
column7: Tex.
column8: there were Adam Wiltzie and Brian McBride
column9: who made druggy and internally-focused drone music as Stars of the Lid.

column1: Stars of the Lid's 1995 debut was called Music for Nitrous Oxide and it had a track called ""Tape Hiss Makes Me Happy""; those two phrases offer a serviceable definition of what SOTL's early music was all about. Working at home and recording on their Yamaha MT-120 and Tascam Portastudio 424
column2: Wiltzie and McBride were patiently mapping a new terrain for experimental music. Along with groups like the previously mentioned Windy & Carl in the United States and UK groups like Flying Saucer Attack and Amp
column3: they were taking the tools of D.I.Y. culture (recording at home
column4: getting the word out through print zines
column5: releasing music on smaller
column6: specialized labels
column7: demonstrating a fondness for cheap and easy cassettes) and using them to make abstract music for deeply immersive listening. Music For Nitrous Oxide mixed metallic drones and feedback with the sounds of strange voices; the effect was something like tuning into two radio stations at once
column8: hearing strange disembodied phrases mixed with weird music that floated across the plains. For their third album
column9: 1997's The Ballasted Orchestra
column10: which has been out of print for some time and has now been reissued on vinyl by Kranky
column11: they did away with the voices and followed their drones to a place where words have no meaning.

column1: The Ballasted Orchestra is four sides of shifting guitar-based drone
column2: with textures that range from thick and menacing to thin and ethereal. For those more familiar with SOTL's work from the last decade (ambient music classics And Their Refinement of the Decline and The Tired Sounds of...) what's most striking about Ballasted is how raw and ragged it sounds
column3: in the best possible way. As the the SOTL project matured
column4: the music grew more pristine
column5: incorporating strings and horns and drawing inspiration from carefully composed music by artists like Arvo Part. In 1997
column6: when these tracks were recorded
column7: Wiltzie and McBride were firmly committed to seeing how much feeling they could wring from guitars and effects pedals.

column1: Turns out it was quite a lot. Some psychedelic drone music seems like it's designed to soundtrack a trip through the cosmos; Stars of the Lid invites you to close your eyes and explore your own mind. And the range of sensations and moods is surprisingly wide. The disorienting ""Sun Drugs"" mixes thin tendrils of wavering drone with trebly guitar notes that feel random like wind chimes. ""Taphead"" is closer to the airy drift of Brian Eno and Daniel Lanois' Apollo while ""Fucked Up (3:57 AM)"" is tensely cinematic
column2: with overlapping chords that are finally interrupted with a cavernous bass that sounds like a tuba blast echoing through an empty gym.

column1: But the highlight and centerpiece is the side-long ""Music for Twin Peaks Episode #30""
column2: which is split into two parts. David Lynch's television series ended its two-season run with episode #29
column3: so the clever title (and Stars of the Lid have always had good ones) affirms that they're using their imaginations to soundtrack a fictional world. And while the work of frequent Lynch collaborator Angelo Badalamenti's work has been an inspiration to Wiltzie and McBride (see ""Mullholland"" on The Tired Sounds of)
column4: at this point the connection was more thematic than sonic. If anything
column5: the piece is more likely to bring to mind the industrial soundscaping of Lynch's sound design partner Alan Splet. But SOTL's speculative soundtrack is absolutely masterful
column6: a drawn-out throb of drone that feels vividly alive. At high volume it taps into the oceanic quality of shoegaze
column7: dissolving boundaries between the listener and the listened-to.

column1: The ""Twin Peaks"" nod helps explain why Stars of the Lid still feel so relevant and why this music
column2: while deeply connected to the wide-open world of 90s tape-based psychedelia
column3:
still feels so current. We'll never stop soundtracking our space and creating virtual worlds. It might happen with a YouTube or an installation but in 1997 there were 4-track tapes recorded by friends in dark rooms that somehow found their way to other people who understood the transmission.

As one of the primary architects of house music's emergence from disco culture
column3: Frankie Knuckles is as an aesthetic visionary and one of the most important figures in the past three decades of pop music. So it's with the utmost respect to Mr. Knuckles that I recommend that if and when you check out this 2xCD DJ mix he produced for the clasically-minded UK label Nocturnal Groove you skip the entire first half hour of the first disc.

column1: That is
column2: unless your tastes in house music run towards overly polished
column3: unaggressive beats that dip into into smooth jazz and contemporary gospel
column4: which is where a lot of this stretch of tracks-- many of them classic cuts given recent reworkings by Knuckles under his Director's Cut alias-- ends up. Some people do like this kind of thing
column5: including house music fans who've stuck with the genre well into middle age
column6: the people responsible for compiling background music for retail outlets
column7: and Germans.

column1: In a way the irritatingly supersmooth portion of the mix
column2: so devoid of any kind of rough edge to snag a listener's attention
column3: is a logical extension of Knuckles' work going back to his earliest days. Even during house music's nascent years he strove to present a smoother
column4: cleaner sonic experience than his contemporaries. While Ron Hardy
column5: one of the other couple of DJs who contributed to house's genesis
column6: used the most advanced technologies of the time-- reel-to-reel tape decks
column7: turntables with pitch controls-- to explore the anarchic possibilities of a new
column8: beat-driven dance music descended from disco
column9: Knuckles used them to isolate and expand disco's most satiny moments into epically glitzy dancefloor fantasias.

column1: That isn't to say they were any less valid than Hardy's sets (or Larry Levan's
column2: or Chip E.'s
column3: or anyone else's at the time)
column4: or that they are any less bumping. Behind all the silkiness is a DJ who wants to jack bodies with the talents to make that happen
column5: and after the overly genteel warm-up
column6: that DJ takes over the mix for two more hours that more than make up for it.

column1: Looking at the lineup of artists on Beyond the Tone Arm you'll see a lot of names from vintage Frankie Knuckles sets that you can find online: Candi Staton
column2: Jamie Principle
column3: Yoko Ono
column4: Lil Louis. The mix is a self-conscious attempt at replicating the type of experience he offered crowds at the Warehouse and the Power Plant in the 80s
column5: the sets that helped establish him as one of the world’s first superstar DJs. And it does a really good job of it.

column1: Listening to the mix
column2: it's easy to see how Knuckles managed to become famous for playing records at nightclubs at a time when that was unheard of. He likes beats that stick close to a discofied four-on-the-floor
column3: but he also likes little rhythmic tics that subliminally nag at the listener in a way you can't help but move to
column4: even if you're just listening to it as background music while web browsing. Take that sturdy rhythmic backbone and add a refined taste for theatrically ecstatic soul-diva vocals and you start to see what it was about Knuckles' approach that allowed him to carve out a place in the mainstream for house music
column5: work that he continued throughout the 90s as the remixer of choice for A-list pop stars like Michael and Janet Jackson.

column1: Those same qualities are being rediscovered by a new wave of dance musicians who have been raiding the 80s and 90s for inspiration now that their extended period of being considered cheesy has expired. Neo-club producers like Brenmar and the current crop of New York disco revival groups have made Knuckles a touchstone in the contemporary dance scene once again
column2: even as EDM acts related (albeit distantly) to Knuckles are filling arenas. Beyond the Tone Arm doesn’t touch on any material from these newer acts
column3: which could be considered a missed opportunity-- I'd be curious to see what he would do with some current sounds
column4: and I'm disappointed that he didn't see fit to include his near-perfect remix of Hercules & Love Affair's ""Blind"". But that's not really the point of this mix. It's one artist's summation of the music he and some like-minded individuals used to alter the course of pop music
column5: and proof that he still knows how to put it together into something suitable to rattling buildings-- not so much resting on his laurels but pulling them out
column6: passing them around
column7:
and showing off how well they still fit.

column3: from cult faves like Phenomena to underrated gems like Lucky McKee]s The Woods. These institutions are typically remote and cloistered

The majority of our most beloved children's stories weren't written with kids' gloves. From Hans Christian Andersen to the Brothers Grimm
column2: the fantastical has always intermingled in equal measure with the terrifying
column3: in ways often more grisly and frank than we remember outside of Angela Carter adaptations. As the former mouthpiece for the now defunct Arab Strap

column4: he's done away with any sort of tinkering

column1: Moffat is clearly still interested in telling stories

column7: tumbling drums (""Drums""). Children mutter phonetic nonsense in lullaby (""Dumbum"")
column8: old recordings of relaxation techniques are layered hypnotically (""Tulpa"")
column9: seagulls shriek in the distance (""Kab 1340""). What's left is more of a jigsaw puzzle that is occasionally stunted due to a lack of fluidity

column11: the music paints strange
column12: tiny pictures where you can see the vintage machinations at work.

column1: Moffat is most consistent in his creations when the focus is centered around string and piano driven pieces. While something like ""Sad Laugh"" might be the best representation of his intent here (it's difficult to discern whether the sounds you're hearing are children laughing or crying)
column2: the most unhurried pieces are the ones that truly stick. With the piercing crescendos of ""The Grief That Does Not Speak"" or the lonely slow waltz of the album's finest piece ""Exits""

column4:
popping physicality of the music-- a sensory experience akin to cracking a leathery old book-- The Island Come True reacts like a lost shadow being reunited with his owner.

They never became a household name and people still think Face to Face or some shitty ""pop punk"" band wrote ""Chesterfield King""
column3: but Jawbreaker were a huge deal for a lot of people. I remember driving from New Brunswick
column4: N.J.
column5: to Philadelphia to bring my girlfriend a promo cassette copy of Dear You
column6: the group's 1995 post-Green Day major label debut. It had arrived a day earlier at the record store where I worked
column7: and I thought she'd want to hear it. I got out of the van
column8: showed it to her; she tossed it on the ground
column9: smashed it under her foot. Around that same time
column10: a guy I knew from local basement shows
column11: came into the record store
column12: pointed to the tattoo of the Jawbreaker logo on his arm
column13: and shook his head. He had tears in his eyes.

column1: This was a band the underground didn't want to lose
column2: at a time when commerce wasn't so closely intertwined with everyday listening experiences. Formed while they were students at NYU
column3: the trio of vocalist/guitarist Blake Schwarzenbach
column4: bassist Chris Bauermeister
column5: and drummer Adam Pfahler relocated to Los Angeles and released their debut
column6: Unfun
column7: in 1990 (it was reissued by Blackball in 2010). Unfun was a good (very fun) record
column8: a solid dose of early 90s emotional
column9: literate punk that established the raw-voiced Schwarzenbach as an underground hero. The band went on the so-called ""Fuck 90"" tour with Econochrist that summer and broke up
column10: but managed to get back together
column11: relocate to San Francisco
column12: and record 1992's Bivouac.

column1: The record found them experimenting
column2: and pushing into deeper
column3: angrier
column4: heavier (and headier) waters. People cite 1994's Steve Albini-helmed 24 Hour Revenge Therapy
column5: which showed up after they played some shows in 1993 with Nirvana
column6: as the group's pre-major label masterpiece. But Bivouac has always held a special place for me. It's their darkest collection
column7: a sprawling
column8: shaggy-dog set that found them transitioning from the cleaner
column9: calmer Unfun to something grittier
column10: wilder
column11: and smarter. Bivouac was a ragged call to arms
column12: 24 Hour Revenge Therapy an ambitious offering within that newer space they'd created.

column1: Bivouac also includes one of their most beloved songs
column2: ""Chesterfield King""
column3: a poppy anthem a lot of people saw themselves in. It was a perfect punk vignette. In just about four minutes Schwarzenbach sets a scene (""We stood in your room and laughed out loud/ Suddenly the laughter died and we were caught in an eye to eye/ We sat on the floor and did we sit close"") as vivid as good fiction. One of his gifts was finding a way to present specific
column4: personal details (""Held your hand and watched TV and traced the little lines along your palms"") and make them feel universal. So
column5: here
column6: when the protagonist cuts out to catch his breath and ends up sharing smokes and thoughts with a toothless woman in a 7-11 parking lot
column7: you sort of remember this happening to you
column8: too.

column1: But it's not all love and lovesickness. From opener ""Shield Your Eyes"" (""There was a sun once/ It lit the whole damn sky/ It kept everything alive"") onward this is an apocalyptic record filled with bigger kinds of searches
column2: depression
column3: and dirt. You get that soul sickness in ""P.S. New York Is Burning""
column4: ""Parabola""'s ""I saw myself in someone else and hated them
column5: and ""Like a Secret""'s request: ""Don't talk me down from here/ Let me fly this kite without a string."" It shows up clearest
column6: and more impressively
column7: in the 10-minute closing title track's search for meaning: ""I'm lonely/ I'm an only/ I learned to put on airs/ I needed them to breathe/ Today I wake up."" Here
column8: Schwarzenbach sets an earth clawing scene (""I dug my fingers in the earth/ I drew pictures of my pain/ They were so pretty"") punctuated by feedback
column9: noise
column10: and the singer's howling of the album title
column11: a shout that hurts and brings down the shelter he's place around himself. It's a call for help
column12: though one that doesn't need to be answered. You get the sense that it's the act itself that mattered most.

column1: Biouvac's 20th Anniversary CD reissue
column2: remastered by John Golden from the original tapes
column3: includes songs from the original studio sessions: ""Ache""
column4: which showd up on 24 Hour Revenge Therapy
column5: and ""Peel It the Fuck Down""
column6: which appeared on the 2002 compilation Etc. Like the original 1992 CD
column7: this version includes the four-songs that appeared on the 1992 Chesterfield King 12"": ""Tour Song""
column8: ""Face Down""
column9: ""You Don't Know""
column10: and ""Pack It Up"". For those who followed the band at the time
column11: those tracks have always felt as much a part of the tracklisting as the 9-song vinyl version. (Fittingly
column12: Blackball has also reissued the 9-song Bivouac and Chesterfield King 12"" on vinyl for the first time in years.)

column1: One of those Chesterfield King tracks
column2: ""Tour Song""
column3: ends with the line: ""<span class=""st"">Every little thing must go wrong."" But
column4: the truth is
column5: despite things not working out exactly as planned
column6: everything did not go wrong. People were angry when Schwarzenbach had painful polyps removed from his vocal chords and were ready to riot when
column7: later
column8: he cleaned up his vocal sound for Dear You. That record didn't sell well enough according to DGC standards
column9: Jawbreaker never became the next Nirvana or Green Day
column10: and in 1996 the group called it quits. But
column11: in retrospect
column12: Dear You was the right record for the band to make. (It's a great album
column13: just not the one you wanted to hear when you were 21 and navigating a close-knit underground that hadn't dealt with this sort of thing firsthand.) So
column14: yeah
column15: Jawbreaker may have grown up before we were ready for them to grow up
column16:
but their music has managed to age especially well. It feels as vital now as it did two decades ago.

The lowly bell might not figure much in the history of minimal techno-- or
column2: indeed
column3: much contemporary music at all-- but it's a percussive instrument that holds much attraction for German producer Hendrik Weber
column4: aka Pantha du Prince. Strip the bells out of ""Lay in a Shimmer"" from the high-benchmark Pantha release Black Noise and it simultaneously loses its twinkly elegance and errs a little too close to humdrum genre fare. Back in 2011 Weber appeared at the Øya Festival in Oslo where he took his obsession up a notch by collaborating with a collection of musicians on a series of bell-oriented tracks under the name Pantha du Prince and the Bell Laboratory. The name neatly tied into Weber's fascination with the instrument and electronic music's past; the original Bell Laboratories were where Max Mathews developed one of the first computer programs to play music back in the 1950s. At Øya the group played a piece titled Elements of Light
column5: the name given to this studio recording of their efforts. There's a lightness to it that belies the literal heaviness at the center of the album-- an instrument named the bell carillon
column6: made up of 50 bronze bells
column7: bearing a combined weight of three tonnes.

column1: This isn't such a great departure for Weber
column2: instead coming across as the logical extension of an idea he's been chasing for a while. There are elements of classic minimalism worked in
column3: as well as a healthy dose of the all-surface moves that were typical of Tortoise's transitionary work on the TNT album. On that record it felt like Tortoise were bridging between the airless electronics they leaned on during Millions Now Living Will Never Die and a space where you could sense them loosening up a little more. It's a feeling this album also taps into. The playing is incredibly tight
column4: but there's a sense of adventure to the whole undertaking
column5: with all the players locked into a common goal. It's an instrumental album with a tinge of narrative
column6: particularly when they venture into mazy 10-minute-plus pieces like ""Particle"" and ""Spectral Split"". Ventures like this often end up feeling like a display of chops
column7: a demonstration of proficiency
column8: an exercise in technical prowess. Elements of Light is mostly the opposite; it feels like those involved were as invested in the transformative power of the music as they were in flexing their not inconsiderable talents.

column1: ""Particle"" is a particularly impressive example of how versatile the bell can be as an instrument
column2: especially when it juxtaposes ominous
column3: church-like clangs with lighter tones that skip and twist across its surface. It's positively giddy at times
column4: never quite ending up where you expect
column5: bringing in familiar beats and swells of bass that anchor it in Weber's world
column6: then constantly pulling rugs out from underneath the listener. To give away too much would spoil the surprises that are crucial to making this album work
column7: but a small glimpse of its magic can be found in the turn into Tom Waits-style pots-and-pans percussion that is unexpectedly teased out during a section of ""Particle"". Moments like that
column8: rendered here as a brief snatch of creative flash
column9: but surely the basis for an entire track in lesser hands
column10: are the points where this album really excels. Occasionally it meanders into cyclical drifting
column11: particularly in shorter tracks like ""Photon""
column12: where the ideas run a little dry. But even that just about works as a contemplative prelude to ""Spectral Split""
column13: serving as a necessary foot-off-the-gas moment before something meatier.

column1: It's in ""Spectral Split"" that Elements of Light flashes through all its tones
column2: from washed out ambience to a momentum borrowed lightly from Steve Reich's Music for 18 Musicians
column3: to the interlinking of classical and electronic textures that Weber so clearly obsesses over. It also demonstrates his astute understanding of how important anticipation is in dance music
column4: with almost half the 17-minute runtime devoted to a slow build that explodes into color when all its spaghetti-like parts are interwoven. That sense of release surfaces sporadically throughout the album and is fundamental to making it work
column5: but it's always delivered with a great degree of control and patience. Sometimes a stiffness emerges in the playing and it feels too mechanical
column6: like a computer trying to figure out the meaning of joy
column7: but even those little moments tie in perfectly with the historic wink in the name of the Bell Laboratory. It's possible that their collected devotion to precision would loosen up more in a live setting
column8: of which more plans are afoot. Here
column9: there's a sense of picking at a strand of inspiration and seeing how it flows toward a form of endgame
column10:
albeit one that still prickles with possibility.

column1: When you think of free jazz featuring dual saxophone soloists

column6: abrasive sounds instead of groovy
column7: mellow ones is no longer fresh news. Here
column8: horns creak
column9: barf
column10: skitter
column11: and spit
column12: but seem perpetually in search of an overriding shape or thought. Anyone looking for the softening melodies of Stetson's solo work will be left clutching at scraps in the multiphonic splatter
column13: such as the the tattered Dixieland drifting through ""Stones That Can Only Be"". To free jazz atheists
column14: the album may sound parodically bad
column15: like carnage in a barnyard full of balloon animals periodically interrupted by chalkboard scribbling. More sympathetic listeners might wonder exactly what doesn't work.

column1: The issue for me is a general top-heaviness that runs from the music's style

column3: to the album's sequence. The first and longest of four tracks
column4: ""Stones That Rest Heavily""

column6: seductive passages and unison surges are hardly able to build any momentum before someone starts screaming through a reed and everything falls apart. More energy is spent than gathered
column7: which makes the music feel slack and enervated
column8: and the necessity to play every which way but normal bottoms out in unbearable goose-honks around the 10-minute mark. Not only does it make for an unwieldy opener
column9: it leaves few new tricks for the rest of the album-- and little energy for us to invest in it.

column1: Most of all
column2: Stones is top-heavy with soloists. Between them
column3: Stetson and Gustafsson make enough noise for five. What's missing is a drive shaft
column4: and Stetson would have been the ideal person to provide it. Steady
column5: powerful torque is what he does best. Who knows why he went off the rails
column6: playing against his own strengths as well as the needs of the music. Perhaps the well-known Arcade Fire sideman and solo auteur felt pressure to adapt to this very jazz context. Perhaps he wanted to show that he can also roam free
column7: contrary to his reputation as a blinkered marathoner. Or maybe it just worked out that way in the moment. Regardless
column8: the result is two musicians chasing each other around like squirrels
column9: playfully yet rather pointlessly
column10: going everywhere to get nowhere. But I can still imagine a tantalizing version of this collaboration where Stetson owns his lane
column11: laying down a winding labyrinth of cool stone
column12: and lets Gustafsson play the snorting
column13: bucking Minotaur
column14:
a role that comes naturally to him.

Implicit in the rise of the local
column2: the handcrafted
column3: and the artisanal is a sense of modesty
column4: that things that were sourced and made locally are to be enjoyed locally. It's in this sense that American Noise

column6: feels like a shot across the bow. An obelisk of a title attached to a bewitching collection of underground dance
column7: experimental
column8: and analog ephemera
column9: American Noise trumpets the breadth and creativity that Ron Morelli's upstart label has championed during its first two-plus years.

column1: You could be forgiven for not having heard of L.I.E.S.. The New York imprint operates quickly and quietly
column2: releasing singles and EPs on limited-run vinyl (but not always)
column3: replete with mysterious stamped labels
column4: some of which are already quite rare. L.I.E.S.'s reach and reputation has outstripped its modest existence
column5: and collector-allure is only a partial explanation. Influential European stores like Berlin's Hardwax have championed the label
column6: and there is a fervor surrounding Morelli & co. that
column7: frankly
column8: few if any American labels have generated in the last decade. To speak plainly
column9: the rise of L.I.E.S. is one of the most significant and encouraging developments in American underground electronic music in years.

column1: Is it deserving of the attention? American Noise will not bash your skull in with newness. The styles it spans will be familiar to followers of electronic and experimental music. The music is held together by a sense of craft and a pervasive menace that ties the music to conjurers like Demdike Stare and Oneohtrix Point Never. What makes L.I.E.S. special
column2: what makes it more than simply another boutique underground label
column3: is its frenetic pace and Morelli's uncanny ability to unearth heretofore unknown producers to place alongside slightly more established names like Maxmillion Dunbar and Xosar (Dutch workaholic Legowelt is the label's weightiest name).

column1: It is an unparalleled collection of fresh talent: for the last two years it's basically been possible to blindly dig the L.I.E.S. crate and unearth something really good. That L.I.E.S. has managed this without tapping into any zeitgeist sound or scene-- the label's offerings span house
column2: electro
column3: kraut
column4: and noise among others-- is all the more impressive. These contributions range from the cauldron-black psychedelia of Jahiliyya Fields to the tipsy motorik of Torn Hawk. House classicist Delroy Edwards and Bookworms-- whose shimmering odyssey ""African Rhythms"" goes toe-to-toe with Daphni's remix of ""Ne Noya"" for the best use of an African vocal sample in a loaded year-- are just two artists who released their first-ever works for L.I.E.S. in 2012. Then there's ""Journey I."" by Unknown Artist
column5: 12 unspooling minutes of pickled funk
column6: possibly the finest example of the intersection between noise and dance music on the label. If there's been little speculation about who the hell these artists are
column7: it's because it's a lot more fun to imagine Morellli having access to some heretofore unknown mine of talent.

column1: It's instructive that one of L.I.E.S.'s best tracks is attributed to an anonymous producer. Central to the popularity of L.I.E.S. is its mythology. There's a secret clubhouse feel to the label
column2: a sense that this is music made and presented the right way
column3: or the old way
column4: or at least in a way that is shielded from the constant deluge of novelty and bullshit that normally accompanies discovering a hot scene. That the music has been so uniformly good-- and that the label has cultivated this feeling naturally-- means this is a fun bonus and not some vague fetishistic moralizing.

column1: Ultimately the only disappointing thing about American Noise is that it can't benefit from the evocative
column2: imagination-stoking intrigue of the label's physical products. It's a 2xCD label compilation
column3: not a message in a bottle. Mixing classics with some fresh productions
column4: though
column5: does give the label's output a sense of uniformity
column6: and helps define ""American noise"" as basically anything that can result from someone sitting down with a synthesizer and a drum machine. It's a big
column7: vague idea that is harnessed by L.I.E.S.'s comparative smallness. So if American Noise pulls the curtain back some
column8: it's only because this music is simply too good not to share
column9: which is presumably the impetus for the label existing in the first place. Come for the unearthed classics
column10:
stay for the next transmission from Morelli's mystic jam generator.

With a name like Secret Circuit
column2: it shouldn't be much of a surprise that the copious amounts of music that L.A.'s Eddie Ruscha
column3: Jr. (yes
column4: he is the progeny of the famed pop artist) has been cranking out in his home studio has not seen that much of California's legendary daylight. Ruscha's previous alternative rock band
column5: Medicine
column6: had spent a decade under-appreciated before getting some due this year with a Captured Tracks-pressed box set. And Ruscha's other notable project
column7: the Laughing Light of Plenty (made with famed UK
column8: SF
column9: and NYC DJ Thomas Bullock)
column10: released one of 2008's Stone Rosiest dance singles
column11: but then released a full-length album that I defy you to find
column12: already deemed ""lost"" even though it dates from 2010. Almost all of Ruscha's music remains secret.

column1: Soon after Medicine achieved mid-level grunge-era success (even landing a cameo in The Crow)
column2: Ruscha bowed out of rock altogether to dabble bedroom-woven electronica being crafted by the likes of Aphex Twin. It's that sort of Selected Ambient Works-worthy playfulness that comes to mind in sampling Tropical Psychedelics
column3: released on England's finely attuned Emotional Response imprint. (Their reissue arm-- Emotional Rescue-- has also had a pretty decent year.) The album also caps Secret Circuit's rather overt 2012
column4: wherein his quirky take on homespun electronic music began to gain more exposure via singles on the Beats in Space label and on Prins Thomas' Internasjonal.

column1: Drawing on music dating back to when Ruscha first left Medicine (a quick scan of Secret Circuit's entry on Discogs reveals over a decade of self-released CDs and cassettes)
column2: this 12-track collection finds the music hard to peg to any particular era or trend. Analog components
column3: modular synthesizers
column4: and dusty drum machines underpin nearly every track. Opener ""White Wish"" has a winsome melody flutter about as a beat ticks underneath
column5: but then a plucked nylon-string figure appears
column6: replaced soon after by a warm'n'fuzzy psych guitar flare-up
column7: before returning to its simple components. The cleverly named ""Afrobotics"" feels both primitive and futuristic
column8: a roiling tom-tom getting topped with multiple layers of spy theme guitar
column9: modular synth gurgles and squalls
column10: even a dash of wordless vocals from Ruscha
column11: the cumulative effect of all these overdubbed tracks never feeling cluttered.

column1: The acoustic guitar foregrounded on ""Moon Life"" and the swirling noise interlude of ""Angel's Eyes"" nod back to 1996's Cosmic Sword #1
column2: while the piano recital-meets-Conrad Schnitzler noise of ""Psouvenirs"" was available on Secret Circuit's 2010 Bandcamp album of the same name (another piano sketch
column3: ""Piano Waltz""
column4: has similar components). You can just make out that clatter and voices of children in the background of the former
column5: suggesting a sketch rendered with the same sense of play. The most taut rhythm tracks appear on ""Winded Up on the Floor"" and ""Lagoland""
column6: the former having the earmarks of early acid tracks while the latter features a buzzing kalimba lick that could come right off of a Congotronics album. Most of the album tracks are mindful to not wear out their welcome
column7: with only three ventures beyond the four-minute mark.

column1: Most of the album's pacing comes at a fugue-like
column2: breezy speed
column3: somewhere between the Balearic sensibilities of a new generation of producers (see the International Feel label and DJ Harvey's Sarcastic Study Masters) as well as the strange sort of punch-drunk exotica evoked by Yellow Magic Orchestra's Haroumi Hosono
column4: with the casual sway of ""Foggy Twilights"" and ""Walkin' on Water"" conjuring island sunsets. Ruscha's curious sensibilities remain intact across Tropical Psychedelics
column5: making the album an idiosyncratic yet satisfying listen. And with a new crop of L.A. producers like Suzanne Kraft
column6: Pacific Horizons
column7: and SFV Acid taking cues from Ruscha's peculiar soundworld
column8:
Secret Circuit may yet become overt.

If nothing else
column2: Greek producer Larry Gus' Silent Congas can serve as an index of where sample-based music is at the beginning of the 21st century: repetitive
column3: simply structured grooves that draw a little on disco
column4: a little on soul
column5: a little on hip-hop
column6: a little on psychedelia
column7: and a little from that ever-expanding territory of outré/foreign-language/exploitation-film obscurities on which tiny reissue labels across the world stake their humble claim. Music built from other music that doesn't so much envision a new world as recreates an old one that only feels
column8: distantly
column9: like it ever existed to begin with.

column1: Silent Congas could be compared to-- or mistaken for-- the work of several other artists. Both here and on 2009's Stitches
column2: Gus does his European takes on J Dilla (""Hutting"") and Madlib (""Circular Obsidian""). On ""Contours Sway""
column3: he is not only the Avalanches in general
column4: but ""Since I Left You"" specifically. Nobody will hear Silent Congas and think
column5: there's that Larry Gus sound! because there isn't a Larry Gus sound.

column1: The music Gus makes is in a sense predicated on anonymity. But when making music from other music
column2: the bar for some sense of authorship is set even higher. He has to make his samples have to say something with him that they couldn't say without him. Here
column3: they seem to say things like ""whoa"" repeatedly-- not a bad message per se
column4: but one that can benefit from complication. Ironically
column5: when Gus sings
column6: he mumbles.

column1: Congas feels like an album that doesn't hit a high mark in part because it seems to have aimed low in the first place. The mystical
column2: jazzy aspects of it allude to a depth that the songs' brief runtimes and basic structures don't make room for-- ""Circular Obsidian""
column3: for example
column4: feels like a two-minute preview for a version of itself that could be 10 times as long. Music like this is essentially a kind of audio collage
column5: and
column6: like collage
column7: Silent Congas has huge potential for strange and revealing juxtapositions between different kinds of sounds
column8:
although it winds up being a friendly place for lots of compatible sounds to mingle rather than anything profound.

0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/18595/homepage_large.286fe472.jpg|Man Chest Hair|0.0|Various Artists|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Finders Keepers']|2013-01-04 00:00:00|2012|2016-06-11 17:03:21.835149|"

There's no need to have been alive in the 70s to be very familiar with 70s hard rock. The music has lived on with enough ubiquity that even if you've never gone near classic rock radio
column2: you've probably heard it over the credits of a TV show
column3: or playing in the supermarket
column4: or on the car stereo of a teenager born in 1996. It's the top-level stuff you'll hear
column5: of course: Zeppelin
column6: Free
column7: Cream
column8: Deep Purple
column9: Van Halen... those bands sold millions of records
column10: but trailing in their wake were hundreds more that would have been happy to sell out a private pressing of 500. Enterprising reissue labels and so-called sharity bloggers have done much to shed light on this music in the last 10 or so years
column11: and it feels as if we'll never run out.

column1: Once you fall into that world
column2: the pull of the rabbit hole seems to increase exponentially. This is an effect surely felt by Andy Votel and Doug Shipton
column3: the compilers of Man Chest Hair
column4: a set whose cheeky title references the English city of Manchester
column5: host to a thriving hard rock scene during the 70s. The two collectors have brought together a rough assortment of tracks documenting the era here
column6: focusing entirely on rock bands of low-to-no commercial fortune. One of the joys of exploring this old music is discovering the incredible diversity of sounds that can exist under a single generic umbrella like hard rock. The groups here range from straightforward boogie outfits to heavy prog
column7: proto-metal
column8: almost-punk
column9: glam
column10: and down-the-middle pop rock acts
column11: with hints of folk and blues as well.

column1: Certainly
column2: the Man Chest Hair title is worth more than a bad pun: nearly every musician heard here was male (JC Heavy's vocalist is the lone exception)
column3: and this stuff was recorded during the wild
column4: shirtless heyday of loud rock and roll
column5: before punk taught people to be ashamed of ambition
column6: or to at least act ashamed of it. No
column7: these bands were aiming for the cheap seats in venues where every seat was cheap
column8: or there were no seats at all. Oscar
column9: a band that also played under the name Royal Variety Show
column10: open the disc with ""Good Lovin' Woman""
column11: which was likely selected to go first because it sounds like some sort of cosmic mean of 70s hard rock. It's got a bit of funk in its step
column12: a lot of crunch in its guitars
column13: ample cowbell
column14: lusty vocals
column15: and free-spirited attitude that roll together almost every quality that put this music on the top of the heap in its original moment.

column1: The biggest highlight for me is ""King Dick II""
column2: by the Way We Live. The song has a great
column3: cycling riff
column4: kicked along by busy but ruthlessly effective drumming
column5: and the lyrics encouraging you to ""practice witchcraft with your friends"" are a pretty hilarious send-up of both hippie ideals and the panicked reaction to them. This band changed its name to Tractor
column6: released a great album
column7: and then settled into the festival circuit
column8: which makes them one of the longer-lived acts on the compilation. By comparison
column9: So On and So Forth hasn't even received the honor of a Rate Your Music entry
column10: though their cover of Cream's ""Sweet Wine"" is quite a bit better than the original. Same goes for the excellently named Urbane Gorilla
column11: whose buzzy sax/guitar riffs on ""Ten Days Gone"" help compensate for the amateurish vocal and turn the song into a thrashing stomper.

column1: Not every song is a winner. Stackwaddy
column2: one of the better-known bands included here
column3: turns in a lumbering
column4: momentumless plodder on ""Hunt the Stag""
column5: and the demo-level quality of other songs doesn't serve the big sounds these groups were aiming for particularly well. These are more than balanced out by the presence of unearthed gems like Grisby Dyke's ""Nebula""
column6: which veers wildly from heavy prog instrumental passages topped by flute
column7: and folk-y
column8: waltz time verses. Likewise
column9: Slipped Disc switches things up a bit with their funky
column10: harmony-flecked ""Come On In""
column11: a song that was clearly pointed toward the charts
column12: even if it stood little chance of hitting them. (Their vocalist also sounds ever so slightly like Robert Wyatt.)

column1: Man Chest Hair occasionally drags
column2: and can't boast more than a handful of tracks that will flip anyone's lid outside of 70s rock enthusiast circles. One does wonder if there were more fully realized gems that got passed over in favor of more obscure
column3: unissued material when this set was being assembled. I'll extend the benefit of the doubt to the compilers and suppose that they picked what they thought best told the story of a city alive with rock and roll during the brief window in which hard rock truly ruled the world
column4:
and the upstart bands that trailed in the wake of Led Zeppelin thought they might be able to secure just a bit of that power for themselves.

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/18682/homepage_large.1f480ea8.jpg|Berberian Sound Studio: Original Motion Picture Soundtrack|473.0|Broadcast|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Warp']|2013-01-03 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 17:03:22.976287|"

Broadcast's output was remarkably meticulous. In their 16 years together as a group
column2: through various lineup changes that saw them ultimately shaved down to the duo of Trish Keenan and James Cargill
column3: they released just four full-length studio albums. There was certainly a decent amount of other work that sprung up in the gaps between those records
column4: but often a protracted silence would settle on the band. It wasn't hard to imagine a permutation of the Broadcast lineup locked away in a studio during those times
column5: agonizing over pink noise settings
column6: crafting a set of lyrics that sat just right with Keenan's detached delivery
column7: mulling over sleeve design with longtime cohort Julian House of the Focus Group. As the world outside sped up they seemed to slow down
column8: getting a little more lost in their own sound with every passing year.

column1: Their final work together before Keenan's sad passing in 2011
column2: the manic cut-and-paste Focus Group collaboration Investigate Witch Cults of the Radio Age
column3: spewed Broadcast out into a disorienting space
column4: deliberately clipping their pop wings. Their live shows from that era further emphasized the feeling
column5: with Keenan and Cargill performing in near darkness
column6: facing one another while hunched over tables laden with equipment
column7: barely even acknowledging the presence of the audience. The sense of retreat from those shows was overpowering
column8: even if it was the natural product of the insular existence the pair seemed to fall into over the course of their career. In the beginning they had easily traceable peers-- labelmates Stereolab
column9: fellow Birmingham bands Plone and Pram-- but by the time of Witch Cults they were mostly out on their own. Even the ""hauntology"" sub-genre felt too parochial for a band that had such potentially limitless scope within its grasp.

column1: It feels appropriate that one of Keenan and Cargill's final works together is a largely instrumental soundtrack to filmmaker Peter Strickland’s 2012 feature Berberian Sound Studio. The film follows a British man who travels to Italy in the 1970s to work on the sound design of a schlocky giallo movie
column2: only to be driven to the point of self-destruction by his own creations. Broadcast are a natural fit for such a project
column3: their working methods clearly mirroring the obsessive
column4: isolationist approach of Strickland's central character. Their music often has a filmy élan to it
column5: bearing traces of composers such as Krzysztof Komeda's work for Roman Polanski and Luboš Fišer's score for Valerie and Her Week of Wonders. It's not clear who did what here-- Keenan and Cargill began working on this project together
column6: with the latter completing the score after Keenan's passing-- but it picks up on the similarly fractured thread sewn throughout Witch Cults
column7: with 39 tracks included
column8: many of them barely making it over the one-minute mark.

column1: That Broadcast were still working deeply in the abstract suggests they were keen to further explore the ideas embedded in that last record. According to Cargill
column2: we may find that out at some point in the future. For now
column3: all we have is this
column4: an album that arches away from Witch Cults in subtle ways
column5: dialling down the self-consciously quirky material that periodically surfaced on that record and bringing a conspicuous feeling of terror closer to the surface. Berberian Sound Studio is all bone-chilling screams
column6: deep red blood spilling across decaying celluloid
column7: knives being raised pointedly in the air. It's the work of people enamored by the common devices of horror
column8: who want to see how pliable that material is so they can find their own entry point into it.

column1: This isn't an album easily broken down into tracks
column2: but the influence of Herk Harvey's sinister organ grind from the classic Carnival of Souls surfaces sporadically (""Beautiful Hair""
column3: ""Treatise"") as do great bursts of menacing analog synth reminiscent of Fabio Frizzi's score for Zombie Flesh Eaters (""Mark of the Devil""
column4: ""Found Scalded
column5: Found Drowned""). Elsewhere
column6: pieces of dialog from the film are regularly worked in
column7: often through creepily whispered female voices reminiscent of a similar trick deployed on Goblin's Suspiria soundtrack (""Monica's Burial""
column8: ""Anima di Cristo""). Occasionally there are even Broadcastian touches-- the keyboard refrain on ""The North Downs Dimension"" is noticeably similar to the one deployed on ""You and Me in Time"" from Tender Buttons. But mostly this is an attempt at subtlety emulating the work of others
column9: of generating chills from an eerie sparseness (the quite beautiful ""Teresa
column10: Lark of Ascension"") or from dense
column11: compact forms (the strident ""The Equestrian Vortex"").

column1: What prevents Berberian Sound Studio from being a genre exercise is the care taken to paper over the cracks
column2: to find some common ground between droney
column3: Popol Vuh-type material (""Valeria’s Burial (Under the Fort)"") and more visceral horror soundtrack work (the positively seething ""The Game's Up""). It's undoubtedly derived from that high level of fastidiousness Keenan and Cargill always applied to their work together
column4: but it also demonstrates what big-picture thinkers they were
column5: able to forge unseen connections between disparate
column6: barely heard musicians. It's what gives an album like this
column7: drawn from so many sources
column8: a recognizable identity of its own
column9:
and it's what gave their ever-evolving career a solid grounding in a world that was recognizably theirs.

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/18681/homepage_large.8236f1da.jpg|Bodily Functions|29142.0|Herbert|['Electronic']|0.0|1.0|1.0|['Accidental']|2013-01-03 00:00:00|2001|2016-06-11 17:03:23.497271|"

Matthew Herbert likes processes
column2: rules
column3: and parameters. He has a manifesto for how he records music-- no sampling other artists
column4: no drum machines
column5: no synths. It sounds mighty ascetic
column6: but the prolific Brit has been responsible for some of the past decade-and-change's most natural-sounding dance music. 1998's Around the House saw him incorporating household sounds; 2001's Bodily Functions moved inward
column7: building songs from samples of the human body. It was easily Herbert's most audacious idea at that point.

column1: Bodily Functions is even more stretch-your-legs-out luxurious than House. The beats don't sound like flatulence
column2: belches
column3: or growling stomachs
column4: but there is something very organic about the record. The drums feel squishy
column5: the rhythms are padded
column6: and everything moves with an elegance that most house could only dream of (no drum machines
column7: remember). ""Leave Me Now"" and ""You Saw It All"" are relatively raucous stompers fashioned from gasping snares and wet rattling
column8: while the very strange ""Foreign Bodies"" is like early Ricardo Villalobos mapped out in human flesh.

column1: It's as much of a jazz album as a house album. Around the House already had plenty of jazz leanings
column2: but this record makes them explicit-- horns that sigh like deep exhales
column3: scrumptious
column4: meaty bass. The album is punctuated by brief meanderings away from house
column5: like the cocktail lounge opener ""You're Unknown to Me"" or the straight-up ""I Know""
column6: which is four and a half minutes of pure jazz vamp with Herbert's own delectable piano work. These pieces serve to open the album up into its inviting
column7: expansive whole.

column1: Bodily Functions also continued Herbert's fruitful collaboration with Dani Siciliano
column2: a smooth singer whose jazzy inflections go well with this album's tasteful house. She's as much the star of Bodily Functions as Herbert is
column3: her pleasantly husky voice inhabiting the album's warm atmosphere. Her calm
column4: gently emotive personality makes tunes like the masterful ""It's Only"" agonizingly ambiguous. She wrings layer upon layer of feeling from the wry kiss-off ""Leave Me Now
column5: commanding ""never call again"" but later asking ""be the friend I never knew."" The lyrics are equally clever
column6: mixing the lexicon of life science (""Foreign Bodies"") with subtle commentary on relationships and interpersonal interactions.

column1: Bodily Functions' supple texturing
column2: smooth demeanor
column3: and pop songcraft have made it timeless
column4: a gem so well-polished you couldn't ever imagine it accumulating scuff marks. So the reissue acts as more of a reminder than a rediscovery
column5: packaged with a second disc that includes compilation track ""Back to the Start"" (which could have easily landed on the album)
column6: as well as a number of period remixes. Highlights include a stunning cover by Jamie Lidell and strong remixes from Matmos and Plaid.

column1: For well-versed Herbert fans
column2: the reissue offers few revelations
column3: though it is nice to have the whole period collected into one package. There are a few new bits
column4: however
column5: including a Dave Aju remix of ""Foreign Bodies"" and two remixes from Pampa boss and consummate weirdo DJ Koze. His take on ""You Saw It All"" capitalizes on the album's odd movements and springy textures
column6: but it's his version of ""It's Only"" that really hits home. Koze's work here is pretty transparent: he hollows out the beat and mixes up the vocal
column7: and then puts a monster bassline underneath
column8: sloping down at a sharp right angle just when you expect the chord progression to ascend.

column1: With Bodily Functions
column2: Herbert made a gorgeous jazz-pop album from recordings of human bodies and a few instruments-- but he also made one of last decade's most important dance albums. An enduring album that still sounds singular
column3:
Bodily Functions floats far above the trend-obsessed nature of dance music.

"|17491.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/17491-bodily-functions/|8.7|Andrew Ryce

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/18685/homepage_large.973705be.jpg|Whiteout EP|30349.0|Dawn Richard|['Pop/R&B']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Our Dawn']|2013-01-03 00:00:00|2012|2016-06-11 17:03:23.991335|"

Dawn Richard's Armor On EP was an album in all but name
column2: offering as fully-realized an artistic vision as you could hope to emerge from any genre. The trickle of new songs to emerge in Armor On's wake-- the manic yet dreamy ""Wild 'n' Young""
column3: the Michael Bay special effects balladry of ""Pretty Wicked Things""
column4: and the luxuriant art-pop of ""'86""
column5: the first single from her forthcoming debut
column6: GoldenHeart-- casts Dawn as less in tune with the big-chested
column7: neck-snapping attitudes of diva R&B and more like a refugee from a flowery sounds of the late-1980's (think Kate Bush circa ""Experiment IV""
column8: or Nona Hendryx's Skin Diver). The promise and the risk of Dawn's next step
column9: then
column10: is whether and how she can keep rewiring her sonic and stylistic organs while still capturing the emotive power of classic R&B songcraft.

column1: Whiteout offers a vision of her potential future. A stopgap for her fans while Dawn finalises a distribution deal for her album
column2: the EP feels like reading a gentle epilogue after having skipped the big climax. This is Dawn in full-on mystic mode
column3: as these four new songs offer variations on a fairly precise idea of ethereal electronic pop. The title track
column4: all sighing harmonies and sonar loops
column5: sees her drift further into pure soundscapes than ever before
column6: but the resulting ""R&B Enya"" effect is more pretty than moving.

column1: Elsewhere
column2: the dusty
column3: tremulous drum & bass pop of ""Miles"" closely resembles a lost cut from Madonna's Ray of Light. Previously
column4: Dawn and producer Druski understood the importance of retaining the kinetic power of the beats they adopted; on Whiteout
column5: the breakbeats are simply deployed as a pasty gloss for the winsome synth burbles and sweet vocal refrains. ""Miles"" still works
column6: but it lays bare her aesthetic a little too openly. The constant potential pitfall of genre tourism is spelled out rather more bluntly on the EP's closer
column7: an ""EDM Remix"" of prior single ""December Sky"" that sounds exactly how you'd expect from reading the title.

column1: Happily
column2: then
column3: the remaining two tracks are prime Dawn Richard
column4: although not in the exact manner to which we've grown accustomed. ""And The Bells"" is a hypnotic
column5: mournful ballad that succeeds by accumulation
column6: minor-key melodies and whirring beats and multi-layered vocals weaving in and out of one another to create a building sense of intensity. ""Wynter"" is even better
column7: an unabashed epic built around gently propulsive dubstep rhythms and gorgeous background sample-stuff oddly reminiscent of defunct Scandinavian balearic outfit Air France
column8: but pushed into stellar territory by the tear-jerking contours of the vocal lines.

column1: Hardly less brave or daring in their sonic wanderings
column2: these two standouts nonetheless confirm that Dawn Richard's curiosity and diligence will always be a good look for her
column3:
but forging an emotional connection remains the heart of her appeal-- no matter how unadventurous a goal it may seem.

King Louie's Drilluminati is the most high profile single-artist mixtape to come out of the Chicago drill scene since it exploded into the mainstream over last summer. It's a weird spot for Louie (or
column2: for now
column3: ""King L
column4: at least until Epic Records sorts out some trademark issues with another artist) to be in
column5: not only because of its the tape's nature
column6: but because at this point he doesn't have much in common artistically with Chief Keef and most of the other rappers he's commonly mentioned alongside.

column1: While Louie was tied in with the drill scene before anyone outside of Chicago even knew it existed
column2: he's never totally fit in with it. For one
column3: at age 24
column4: he's seven years older than Keef
column5: which in this young scene almost counts as a generational gap. But more importantly
column6: while Keef
column7: his Glory Boys crew
column8: and the ever-growing number of rappers imitating them project the image of dead-eyed sociopaths
column9: Louie's always been a hedonist first and a street tough a far-off second--his long-awaited major label debut's been through at least a year's worth of delays

column1: As a mixtape released between a rapper landing a deal and the release of his first ""official"" album
column2: Drilluminati is intended to fulfill several important functions. One is to sustain interest in King L between the signing and the arrival of a retail product
column3: which is increasingly difficult to do. The other is to prove that he's ready to make the jump from the mixtape circuit to a much bigger arena. Kanye West's shout out to Louie in his remix of Keef's ""I Don't Like
column4: which boomed inescapably from car windows and teenagers' cellphones last summer
column5: did the heavy lifting in terms of sustaining interest. But Drilluminati acquits itself nicely in the second respect.

column1: King Louie's been waiting for years to get a chance to establish himself as a rap-world big dog
column2: and on Drilluminati he goes out of his way to invite comparisons with the biggest dog currently running
column3: Rick Ross. The fact that he named the opening track ""Rozay Flow"" makes it unmistakable
column4: but its typically supersized operatic beat by Ross mainstays J.U.S.T.I.C.E. League (who also produced the similarly Ross-ish ""Feeling Like a Billion Bucks"") would have been a pretty serious tip-off by itself. And while his lyrics include a fair share of gun talk (although maybe not so much as to justify the grim
column5: bullet-ridden cover art)
column6: Louie spends significantly more time assuring us of his aptitude for spending money frivolously
column7: something that Ross proven an Olympian talent for.

column1: Louie seems to understand that
column2: if he's going to make Rick Ross-level paper
column3: it won't be by copying Rick Ross' style-- and he doesn't need to
column4: anyway. His flow has the weird anarchic energy that you used to pick up in Ludacris verses and
column5: these days
column6: are more likely to find on something featuring 2 Chainz. He combines that energy with the clipped
column7: gunfire-like enunciation of a Chicago drill rapper-- and when he finds his pocket
column8: it feels like getting on the right beat at the right time is the only thing between him and pop radio.

column1: A few tracks get partway there. ""My Hoes They Do Drugs"" has verses from Pusha T and Juicy J
column2: and DJ Pain 1's slo-mo synth psychedelia bears a squinting resemblance to Juicy's ""Bandz a Make Her Dance""
column3: although its single entendre lyrics are maybe too on the nose even for a pop audience. Louie and producer Hearon Trackz work extremely well together on ""My Niggaz""
column4: as Trackz provides a creepy minimalist beat decorated with blaring
column5: Inception-style brass that Louie comes at with what's probably his strongest performance on the album. Even the requisite bedroom song
column6: ""Bandz Up""
column7: featuring an ostentatious hook from the R&B singer Leek
column8: is surprisingly decent.

column1: Things get even more interesting on two songs in particular. ""2 Pair""
column2: produced by Sonny Digital
column3: takes a giddy synth loop and a rap from Louie at his most compellingly louche
column4: and proceeds to pound it into your head and refuses to let up. The track should make listeners either wild out with abandon or dive for the stereo's off switch. And the previously released ""Val Venis""
column5: with its rotund beat by the gifted Chicago producer C-Sick and an instantly memorable
column6: infinitely enjoyable tongue-tying vocal hook
column7: is something out of an A&R's dream. If anything on Dope & Shrimp matches it
column8:
Louie might just end up as big as he thinks he is.
