column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/18582/homepage_large.e2fed9f4.jpg|Vanquish in Vengeance|30858.0|Incantation|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Listenable']|2013-01-03 00:00:00|2012|2016-06-11 17:03:25.167900|"

It must feel weird to be in Incantation. Imagine how strange it must be to head into the studio to record a new full-length
column2: your first in six years
column3: and carry with you the knowledge that there are dozens of newer bands out there aping the exact same kind of songs you're about to commit to tape. Recording a genre-defining classic like Onward to Golgotha early in your career sets the bar pretty high
column4: after all (following it up with the likes of Mortal Throne of the Nazarene and Diabolical Conquest doesn't help!)
column5: and some of the younger bands who've been wearing their love for those records on their sleeves do a damn good job of trying to recreate them.

column1: While the more talented purveyors of recent old school death metal have taken what was rapidly becoming an exhausting creative desert of a trend and turned it into the new norm
column2: it's still far too easy to shove a mishmash of slow heavy riffs together
column3: bury it under some audio mud
column4: and declare
column5: ""That'll do!"" There are few things more joyless than sitting down to listen to three soulless
column6: monotonous
column7: self-declared old school death metal records in a row
column8: but with bands as diverse as Cruciamentum
column9: Encoffination
column10: Binah
column11: and Antediluvian flying the flag for murky
column12: darkly melodic metal of death
column13: one's got to wonder: does the world really need a new Incantation album? After listening to Vanquish in Vengeance
column14: I'm pleased to report that the answer is a resounding ""Yes.""

column1: Incantation have never been much for tinkering with their sound or approach. The most pronounced difference on this new album lies in the production. On Vanquish in Vengeance
column2: John McEntee and the lads have abandoned their beloved subterranean squall in favor of a brighter
column3: more open approach. This isn't a squeaky-clean
column4: see-yourself-in-the-riffs-shiny Swedish melodeath record; it's still dark and ugly
column5: but it's not what we're accustomed to hearing from the patron saints of muddy guitar tones. Beyond that minor quibble (or asset
column6: depending on how you like your death metal to sound)
column7: the album itself is rock solid.

column1: By now
column2: Incantation don't know how to do anything other than be Incantation
column3: and that's a comforting trait. The macabre
column4: lumbering grooves and aggressive blasts remain intact
column5: as does the hellish din that spews forth from McEntee's tortured throat. Corrupted melodies and a well-oiled rhythm section (anchored by longtime drummer Kyle Severn's murderously precise drumming) keep the songs slithering along smartly.

column1: Incantation are no strangers to the death/doom formula
column2: but in the second act of this performance they really shine a spotlight on the most sluggish end of the spectrum. The first half of the album focuses on the kind of focused
column3: fetid
column4: undeniably evil death metal compositions that we've come to know and love
column5: but title track marks the turning point. Once its twisted chords and churning central riff (lovingly sprinkled with snarling pinch harmonics) fade into ""Profound Loathing""
column6: the tempo shifts
column7: skewing irrevocably towards the lightless depths of doom. The phlegmatic pace of bass-heavy epic ""Profound Loathing"" is a funereal dirge
column8: setting the stage for the latter-era Celtic Frost stomp of ""The Hellions Genesis"" and ""From Hollow Sands"" (whose opening riff is pure Triptykon).

column1: The album closer
column2: ""Legion of Dis
column3: stretches past 11 minutes of disemboweled funeral doom
column4: spiking its portentous riffs with shrieks of feedback and McEntee's rumbling
column5: animalistic growls. It unfolds
column6: brutally slowly and with a hangman's grace
column7: prolonging the end until it peters out
column8: offering a shuddering demise narrated by a choir of piercing
column9: noise
column10: bloodcurdling howls
column11: inaudible ranting
column12: and total sonic collapse. It's a barbaric end to an imposing album. By now
column13: Incantation really don't have anything left to prove
column14: but with this latest release
column15:
have effortlessly set the bar ever higher for those than come after. 

"|17404.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/17404-vanquish-in-vengeance/|7.8|Kim Kelly

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/18698/homepage_large.6b4217c1.jpg|LongLiveA$AP|30007.0|A$AP Rocky|['Rap']|1.0|0.0|0.0|['Polo Grounds / RCA']|2013-01-02 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 17:03:25.838234|"

A few months ago
column2: A$AP Rocky's career seemed mired in purgatory. The 24-year-old Harlem rapper had a spectacular 2011
column3: snagging a still-crazy $3 million deal with RCA based on early buzz and then silencing skeptics with his breakout LiveLoveA$AP mixtape. But throughout 2012
column4: LongLiveA$AP repeatedly failed to materialize. It was slated for July 4th
column5: then September 11th
column6: October 31
column7: and eventually
column8: sometime in December. When the final pushback happened
column9: into the dead zone just after the new year
column10: it began to feel like RCA was attempting to quietly jettison their investment from the corporate hull.

column1: But LongLiveA$AP delivers on and even exceeds the promise of LiveLoveA$AP. Like that mixtape
column2: the album is a triumph of craft and curation
column3: preserving Rocky's immaculate taste while smartly upgrading his sound. A third of the record remains close in style to LiveLoveA$AP while most of the collaborations follow in the steps of last spring's ""Goldie""
column4: which stamped producer Hit-Boy's signature Mini-Boss Musik with a screwed-up hook and gumball-spitting flow that marked it as unmistakably Rocky's. Plenty of rap-industry heavies appear on LongLiveA$AP
column5: and they mix well with Rocky's younger comrades. More importantly
column6: the French-braid gold-teeth kid named after Rakim never cedes the center. For someone often criticized for his lack of depth
column7: A$AP Rocky keeps delivering in the face of skepticism.

column1: Even the most dubious ideas succeed on LongLiveA$AP. For example
column2: A$AP Rocky's team-up with Skrillex
column3: ""Wild for the Night""
column4: bombs your cortex with screaming lasers
column5: stadium-sized reverb
column6: and a reggae-derived organ lope
column7: and the beat feels like being on the receiving end of a perfectly executed Tekken chain combo. It seems like it should be impossible to rap over
column8: but Rocky’s sweat-free double-dutch is an easy fit. Santigold handles the chorus hook on “Hell”
column9: one of two Clams Casino beats on the album
column10: and it feels just as unforced.

column1: A$AP Rocky sounds natural in every setting; along with his command of rhythm and cadence
column2: this is his greatest gift. Whether he's showing off double- and triple-time bounce in the T-Minus-produced ""PMW (All I Really Need)"" or dodging RZA-styled string chops on ""1 Train"" alongside a collision of hot rappers including Action Bronson
column3: Big K.R.I.T.
column4: and Kendrick Lamar
column5: Rocky sounds utterly at home. Even when he stomps through a queasy Odd Future-style battlefield on “Jodye”
column6: he fully owns the mold. That kind of malleability is crucial to pop stardom
column7: and make no mistake
column8: pop stardom is what Rocky's gunning for. His lyrics
column9: a riot of lifestyle brands and other desirables
column10: can feel like standing in front of a closet of prohibitively expensive designer goods: There isn't much to feel unless you consider ""like three million bucks"" a feeling. But besides the Girbaud jeans with hologram straps and reflectors
column11: the Margielas with no laces
column12: the Escada and Balenciaga and Audemars Piguet
column13: there's a lot going on in Rocky's head.

column1: Late-album track ""Suddenly"" bears a co-producing credit from ""Lord Flacko
column2: aka Rocky himself. In it
column3: a drumless vocal sample fights its way to the surface through layers of aquatic muffling
column4: teasing a titanic beat-drop that keeps not arriving. The song is almost all intro: When the beat finally hits
column5: it only lingers for a few bars before disappearing again. Over this master class in tension and release
column6: Rocky summons childhood memories in calm
column7: expansive strokes: ""Everybody have roaches
column8: but our roaches ain't respect us
column9: he cracks
column10: flashing a previously unseen storytelling flair: ""We had cookouts and dirt bikes and dice games and fist fights/ And fish fries and shootouts like one Sig with two rounds/ In one clip
column11: left two down
column12: that's four kids/ But one lived
column13: left three dead but one split/ That one missed
column14: that one snitched."" The song is a forceful reminder of his birthplace and heritage.

column1: Rocky’s New York story has partly been a story of how there is no coherent New York story anymore: Bay Area rappers like the Jacka convincingly channel the gray Queensbridge fatalism of Mobb Deep and Cormega while in Harlem
column2: Rocky soaked up styles happening hundreds of miles away-- Houston screw music
column3: UGK
column4: Bone Thugs. But beneath the 90s-baby trappings
column5: Rocky is a certain breed of Harlem rapper incarnate-- flashy
column6: ambitious
column7: and affably determined to cross over. The flamboyance and singsong rhyme patterns of the Diplomats are an obvious primary color. But reaching further back
column8: to another Harlemite with a deceptively catchy flow
column9: agreeable air
column10: and penchant for colorful clothing
column11: and you find another kindred spirit in Ma$e. Like Ma$e
column12: Rocky tucks steely edges behind a goofy smile. He has the same unerring instinct for balancing pop smarts and street edge and a similar disregard for New York orthodoxy. He’s also consistently dismissed as a lightweight. It's true
column13: Rocky may not be the answer to New York rap's savior complex. But he is undeniably a hit-maker and a major new rap star for a city that sorely needs one. And with LongLiveA$AP
column14:
he's beaten expectations twice.

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/18699/homepage_large.142575fc.jpg|Loosies|0.0|Various Artists|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|"[""Fool's Gold""]"|2013-01-02 00:00:00|2012|2016-06-11 17:03:28.483721|"

By all appearances
column2: Loosies
column3: the latest Fool's Gold compilation
column4: is a state-of-the-label deal that favors the trendier strains of mollied-up club rap. The liner notes play up the hip-hop-for-ravers ideal that founders A-Trak and Nick Catchdubs have been building up for five years
column5: with an emphasis on the notion that there's room for all kinds of approaches-- ""dungeon ciphers
column6: club shit
column7: BBQ basslines
column8: MPC madness
column9: and so on. (This is the label that put out Danny Brown's XXX
column10: so yeah
column11: no kidding.) If you're skeptical about this kind of stuff
column12: this probably won't change your mind; if you're open to it
column13: you've got 22 chances to get your mind blown. Business as usual
column14: right?

column1: But whether or not this label had a hand in upending your own conception of hip-hop orthodoxy
column2: Loosies stands out in its own way. Not just as the summary of a certain boutique-brand view of rap
column3: but a time capsule-worthy rundown of what people argued about and flipped out over in midstream indie-adjacent hip-hop circa 2012. Some people defined their year through Juicy J's inability to say no to ""ratchet pussy""; some through El-P's Scorsese-protagonist urge to find human connections in NYC's more isolated corners. A-Trak pulled them together on the same track
column4: a remix of his ""Piss Test"" that also recruits blunt-force Dipset vet Jim Jones and drugged-out nu-New York phenoms Flatbush Zombies. It's an unlikely alliance
column5: but the point is that they all fit over a beat that proves once and for all that trance synths and trap beats can actually combine into something that could play anywhere.

column1: The other name artists live up to their reps-- good thing
column2: since this comp practically lives and dies by them. Danny Brown's ""Molly Ringwald"" maintains his between-albums profile with an all-in
column3: no-hook tirade with his flow cranked to its most maniacal; AraabMuzik's beat fittingly streamlines the impact of the superclub pastiche that made him a crossover star. Freeway is preposterously grimy over ""Dedicated""'s vintage soul-- at this point
column4: it sounds like he's got a twin-screw supercharger whirring away inside his voicebox. Action Bronson and Party Supplies provide a Blue Chips-worthy one-verse wonder in ""Twin Peugeots""
column5: where Daptonian horns underscore French hot-hatch fetishism
column6: kegel-exercise jokes and NBA Jam-era namedrops en route to Rutger Hauer-inspired lunacy (""Blind Fury/hoppin' out the braille Jeep"") and an outro monologue about how he vacationed with your mom ""on a boogie board doin' all types of stunts."" And while King L's ""Talkin Foolish"" is borderline sociopathic and less capable of converting drill skeptics than ""My Hoes They Do Drugs"" was
column7: at least he seems more interested in channeling his sound through truck speakers instead of Tumblr likes.

column1: That leaves a bunch of up-and-comers and developing cult figures to round out the rest of the collection
column2: and they typically fill one of two roles. The more common one is the contender trying to make headway in an SEO-driven
column3: free-for-all fashion-rap context
column4: staying ephemeral in a safe lane. There's A$AP-shadowing cloud rap (GrandeMarshall's ""Kelly Green"")
column5: revivalism that channels 50 through '95 (Troy Ave's ""Viking"")
column6: one-size-fits-all half-trap delivered with a murmury
column7: bloodshot deadpan (Problems' ""8 Feet Tall"")-- nothing spectacular
column8: but maybe worth keeping an eye on in case their potential pans out. After a while
column9: Loosies becomes monotonous to the point of oppression
column10: in terms of delivery and subject matter: the pussy/liquor/drugs strain of burnout swag is omnipresent
column11: but isn't outrageous enough to rise above blandly arrogant dick-swinging. So the cuts that break the tedium are priceless
column12: like Casey Veggies having goofy fun over boogie funk on ""Sauna""
column13: Gita delivering a razor-tongued ...So Addictive mutation on ""Let That""
column14: and the woozy float of E-40 scion Droop-E's closer ""Mind Gone
column15: which is so far above the clouds it's scraping the exosphere.

column1: A-Trak and Catchdubs probably called this collection Loosies for a reason-- like the bodega cigarettes
column2: the piecemeal approach makes more practical sense than springing for the entire pack. (Then again
column3: they did tack on a 70-minute continuous mix of the compilation as an extra track
column4: so they're leaving all the options open.) Uneven as it is
column5: Loosies does a decent job of scraping up some quality material from some of the most buzzed-about artists
column6: letting a handful of unknowns grab at the spotlight
column7:
and dropping the occasional early-warning breakthrough when you least expect it. You know you've run across a pretty good comp when you gut half the tracks out of its over-stuffed running time and still have a half-hour's worth that holds together as something worthwhile. Not bad for business as usual.

column1: 0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/18678/homepage_large.8b5d2073.jpg|Nayim From The Halfway Line|7725.0|Alexis Taylor|['Rock'
column2: 'Pop/R&B'
column3:
'Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Domino']|2013-01-02 00:00:00|2012|2016-06-11 17:03:28.706352|"

Hot Chip singer and multi-instrumentalist Alexis Taylor appears locked in a constant battle to shake off any form of stasis. He talked of the value in working on musical projects outside his main band during the promo stint for last year's In Our Heads
column4: highlighting how it positively affected the songwriting on that album. Taylor's an enviable musician who gives the impression that he could turn his hand to just about anything if he tried. Even one of his side projects
column5: the low-key collection of musicians who record under the name About Group
column6: have sucked in an impressively broad array of styles over the course of two albums. In 2008 Taylor released Rubbed Out
column7: a full-length solo record grazed by rough production values and
column8: on occasion
column9: a C-86-like slackness to the playing. It felt like he was enjoying the deliberate looseness after spending so long on the tightly wound constructions Hot Chip create
column10: and that feeling of shaking off the slightly stuffy studio creations of his main band has become something of a theme to his work elsewhere. Listen closely enough and you may even hear the sound of Taylor pumping air into the studio through a gigantic set of billows.

column1: Nayim from the Halfway Line is a further progression for Taylor's work away from Hot Chip. There's nothing here as starkly confessional as ""I Love My Home"" from Rubbed Out or his surprisingly fresh take on Paul McCartney's ""Coming Up"" from the same album. Instead
column2: it's Taylor hopping back and forth over the line he's drawn between Hot Chip and his other output. The sense of organization and efficiency that his other band practices is more present here-- it's less demo-y and spontaneous than either Rubbed Out or About Group. None of the four tracks are soccer-themed
column3: but the title is a nod to the Spanish player Nayim
column4: who scored a spectacular goal for Real Zaragoza in the last minute of a match against Arsenal in the 1995 UEFA Cup Winners Cup Final. The ball arcs in the air with just the right weight behind it
column5: Arsenal goalkeeper David Seaman is caught off his line
column6: and Nayim achieves immortality from a moment of rare beauty. There's no obvious link between that incident and the music here
column7: but it does further emphasize Taylor's less earnest approach to the presentation of his non-Hot Chip material.

column1: The title lies in stark contrast to the contents inside. There's a familiarly bookish approach to clubland that pervades throughout
column2: matched to the kind of suffocatingly dense production values that make it feel like everything has been labored over a little too long. That doesn't prevent moments of inspiration from arising
column3: it's just that too often they're dragged down by hackneyed devices such as pitch-shifted vocal passages (""Rhodes Dream"") and small loops left to echo into eternity in an attempt at creating ambience (""Jesus' Birthday""). The sense of departure that resonates throughout his other non-Hot Chip work is strangely absent. ""You Want Me"" even sounds like it could've been a track that didn't make the cut on One Life Stand
column4: although that's not necessarily a bad place to be
column5: especially when Taylor glides into a smooth synth odyssey in its final third. It feels like a step back to the kind of improvisation that lit up his other work away from his main band
column6: momentarily returning to the sense of freedom and release entrenched in those recordings.

column1: The overriding feeling of this EP is one of finding a home for loose ideas that had been hanging around for a while. It's too bad Taylor couldn't find more room for his reedy
column2: utterly soulful vocal passages
column3: such as the ones that briefly light up ""Hot Squash"". He's got the kind of voice that can easily transcend the trite sentimentality that sometimes infects his writing. On ""Hot Squash"" he can even get away with singing: ""Years I've been waiting
column4: waiting too long/ years I've been waiting
column5: now you've gone."" Imbuing lines like that with palpable emotion and setting them to tight pop structures are Taylor's forte
column6: it's just that here they tail off into squawking wah-wah guitar and redundant analog synth bloops
column7: leaving this EP caught somewhere between genuine inspiration and a mess of fumbling in the dark. Similarly
column8: Nayim's titular goal could be argued over as a piece of supreme skill and judgement or a blind hit-and-hope moment. Here
column9:
the latter just about wins out over the former.

"|17488.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/17488-nayim-from-the-halfway-line/|6.3|Nick Neyland

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/18673/homepage_large.fff64c98.jpg|The Paranormal Soul|29894.0|Legowelt|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Clone']|2013-01-02 00:00:00|2012|2016-06-11 17:03:29.658727|"

Hague-based producer Legowelt's Discogs page lists 24 different aliases
column2: not including his recent
column3: productive collaboration with San Francisco's Xosar as Trackman Lafonte and Bonquiqui. Last year
column4: he gave away The Teac Life
column5: an album longer and almost exactly as good as The Paranormal Soul
column6: for free. Danny Wolfers' output is vast
column7: so I'll let him sum it up: ""[P]eople like melodies
column8: so why not make them?"" The album's seamless blend of dance paradigms-- house
column9: techno
column10: electro-- mean that the melodies
column11: which Legowelt draws into orbit out of mostly vintage gear
column12: are on full display.

column1: Despite the commitment to analog equipment
column2: Legowelt doesn't make vintage music. Wolfers' sound is explicitly modern
column3: in that it's not just the product of someone using Juno synthesizers and TR drum machines; it's the product of someone who has developed a time-tested mastery over them
column4: who has benefitted from the learning of others. The Paranormal Soul is so seamless
column5: so clean and wizard-ly that it illuminates the paradox at the center of Legowelt's work. He releases so much material
column6: through so many outlets
column7: that all the negative connotations of machine music start to bubble up: generative
column8: automatic
column9: easy. On the other hand
column10: Legowelt's recordings are masterful
column11: and his arrangements are more complex than those of (many of) his peers. If what Legowelt does is easy
column12: everyone would sound as good as he does.

column1: Legowelt's recordings weren't always this way. At the beginning of the last decade
column2: his tracks were comprised of short
column3: staccato bursts of sound. His lone recording for Germany's Cocoon label
column4: ""Disco Rout""
column5: was a dance hit in 2002. This is
column6: presumably
column7: where Legowelt acquired the ""lo-fi house"" tag that continues to stick to him to this day. It's a red herring now
column8: as Legowelt has grown more skillful
column9: to the point where listening to Soul can be like reading a letter from someone with exquisite penmanship. A long letter: Soul clocks in at over an hour
column10: chock full of five- and six-minute blasts of warm bass and tip-toeing sequencers. It is the other side of the coin that is Legowelt's amazing productivity: he's a shitty self-editor
column11: or at least he has no interest in being a good one.

column1: Tracks like the anthemic ""I Only Move for U"" or the cinematic ""Transformation of the Universe"" would drop like bombs as 12""s
column2: but they get lost in the thicket of synthesizers. The 12 tracks on Soul have similar tempos
column3: tone
column4: and duration; Legowelt pulls off the difficult feat of numbing the listener with quality
column5: of obscuring his personality with his craft. The Teac Life traded on this effect for its hazy
column6: forested atmosphere. Soul is clearer
column7: more of a party album-- see those jackin' vocal samples on ""Clap Yo Hands"" or the acid that bubbles over during ""Voice of Triumph""-- so it can't skate by on obscurity.

column1: And it doesn't
column2: for the most part. If Soul somehow feels like less than the sum of its parts
column3: that doesn't detract that the parts themselves are shiny
column4: sleek little things. Tracks like ""Rave Till Dawn"" and ""Renegade of a New Age"" are fully formed bangers. Legowelt creates limber
column5: beautiful dance music even if he's a little clumsy when it comes to creating limber
column6:
beautiful dance albums. This is probably the price you pay to wrap yourself in craft and process; it's doubtful Legowelt thinks much of it.

"|17483.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/17483-the-paranormal-soul/|6.9|Andrew Gaerig

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/18634/homepage_large.3c4cba6e.jpg|Finding Comfort in Overwhelming Negativity|30885.0|Theologian|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Handmade Birds']|2013-01-02 00:00:00|2012|2016-06-11 17:03:30.263755|"

During the past few years
column2: the intersection of the Venn diagram linking noise
column3: electronica
column4: and heavy metal has been improbably rewarding: From Ben Frost's irascible compositions to Author & Punisher's turbocharged industrial menace
column5: from Tri Angle Records' cadre of crawlers to Vatican Shadow's damaged tumbles
column6: from witch house's pop-bound menace to Demdike Stare's intricate pattern corruption
column7: musicians working as magpies between those sometimes distant forms have made some of the most intriguing records of the still-new decade. The concept of such a mix isn't necessarily new
column8: but it does seem particularly rewarding right now
column9: due in large part to the finesse and subtlety that many such acts are affording the work.

column1: For the last two decades
column2: Lee M. Bartow has hovered near that nexus
column3: making aggressive and often misanthropic noise-cum-industrial as Leech and Navicon Torture Technologies. During the last three years
column4: though
column5: he's worked under the name Theologian
column6: inching closer toward that aforementioned common ground. This year
column7: he's firmly made his claim by releasing the EP Finding Comfort in Overwhelming Negativity and the LP The Chasms of My Heart
column8: records that make his alliances and interests abundantly clear: Beneath a sculpted surface of static and sustained tones
column9: Bartow has added massive beats and
column10: at some turns
column11: veritable (if rarely decipherable) singing. During the EP's ""All I See Is You""
column12: streams of noise wrap around each other in amoeboid motion as the concussive electronics of a drum machine hammer a cacophony into the sounds from below. In the background
column13: Bartow slows and shifts his intonations
column14: suggesting Jónsi Birgisson fracturing a Nitzer Ebb song into pieces only to sing behind the bedlam. ""Abandon All Hope""
column15: which opens Chasms
column16: builds from a distorted whir into an impossibly dense plea
column17: Bartow howling like Jesu's Justin K. Broadrick. Simple
column18: stentorian percussion pounds beneath it all.

column1: The results of Bartow's broadened palette are consistently interesting. Still
column2: after so many years of monolithic noise bludgeons
column3: Bartow is adjusting to the pacing demands of beat-driven music
column4: a handicap that is as pervasive as it is detracting. Indeed
column5: the critical hiccup of Bartow's refreshed approach is his obsequy to longevity. Taken together
column6: Chasms and Comfort clock in at just beyond two hours
column7: creating a gauntlet of self-defeating intensity. Bartow's dynamics consist largely of loud and louder
column8: conditions that make hearing much of his music at once a tad exhausting. The four-track format of Comfort mitigates the problem by creating a rather seamless and immersive environment that
column9: though still quite taxing
column10: provides one obvious entrance and exit. It's possible to think of the slow
column11: grainy lift of opener ""Fighting for Nothing"" as the takeoff and the noise-decay denouement of closer ""In the Moral Leper Colony"" as the landing. Chasms
column12: however
column13: jerks between pieces of four and 15 minutes for more than an hour
column14: with the divisions-- and possible departure gates-- more clearly demarcated. To hear the damaged and deep techno throb of either set’s best piece
column15: ""The Chasms of My Heart""
column16: you'll need to make it through a stack of four eight-minute-plus tracks; the payoff is there
column17: but you'll suffer for it. Given Bartow's past and his tendency for lyrical nihilism
column18: it's possible to interpret that draining structure as some broad eschatological statement. That doesn't make the listening itself any better.

column1: What's more
column2: Bartow tends to striate his textures and parts
column3: stacking them in rather large and simple layers rather than stitching them together like more electronica-oriented counterparts Demdike Stare or Voices from the Lake. That impulse is a vestige of his tenure as a strict noise artist
column4: and it decreases the possibilities of repeat listens. That is
column5: after a couple of passes
column6: you've heard most everything Theologian has to offer

column8: in places
column9: that's quite a bit: Theologian revives the tenacity and force of Bartow's earlier work with unexpected elements. He's still learning how to control those latest additions
column10:
but there's enough here to recommend paying attention to that future pursuit.

Finally Rich is Chief Keef's major-label debut
column2: but truthfully
column3: there's not a whole lot to distinguish it from the free mixtapes he made while on house arrest at his grandmother's place in Chicago's Washington Park neighborhood. Those tapes
column4: first passed around among southside high-schoolers
column5: were what landed the now-17-year-old rapper his Interscope deal
column6: and apart from a few random A&R'ed guest spots
column7: the label appears to have stayed out of his way.

column1: That's a good thing. Chief Keef's music sparked a lot of arguments this year. His youth
column2: his rapid rise
column3: and his association with Chicago's epidemic of gun violence made him 2012’s flashpoint for discussions about what was wrong with hip-hop. But he established a simple sound that proved powerfully effective and addictive
column4: and he also showed that it was a sturdy enough blueprint to support multiple songs. If Waka Flocka Flame woke up tomorrow utterly drained of the will to live
column5: he might sound like Chief Keef -- all the unilateral forward motion and aggression
column6: none of the audible joy. Young Chop's crisp snares and hi-hats mimic Lex Luger's (minus the tricky syncopation) while Keef mutters through a thick wall of processing.

column1: There's nothing to add or subtract to this sound that could substantially improve it. Fellow Chicagoan Kanye West found that out the hard way when his Michigan Avenue makeover of ""I Don't Like"" was given a public dressing-down by Young Chop the day after it hit the web. Finally Rich benefits from some professional tweaks in the mix
column2: but otherwise leaves Keef's sound untouched. And in addition to succeeding on its own terms
column3: it proves that Keef has a lot of potential-- much more than his detractors might have hoped.

column1: Based on a simple four-note earworm
column2: the hook on album opener ""Love Sosa"" has the feel of something sung under the breath
column3: and after hearing it once or twice
column4: you'll probably find yourself doing just that. There's an unquantifiable line separating the maddeningly catchy from the simply maddening
column5: and Keef has a natural knack for walking it. ""Hallelujah""
column6: also produced by Young Chop
column7: is one the album's more involved productions: Its blaring horns gesture towards Waka's ""O Let's Do It"" over Hammond organ licks that feel smuggled out of Houston rap. ""Diamonds"" has a similar feel
column8: with gunfire
column9: horn and string stabs
column10: and a manic carnival-ride synth line all rolling out like evenly spaced 8-bit Donkey Kong barrels.

column1: ""Hate Bein' Sober""
column2: the album’s forthcoming single
column3: is the catchiest moment and perhaps the most pop-focused song Keef’s ever made. It features 50 Cent
column4: who sounds at home for the first time on a pop-rap hit since ""I Get Money"". Out of the handful of big names on Finally Rich
column5: 50's appearance makes the most intuitive sense: Keef built his mystique
column6: in part
column7: on the idea that he was back from the dead
column8: and 50 was the first rapper to overtly sell himself as an unkillable Terminator-like figure. His patented sing-song sloganeering sounds current again here
column9: maybe because Get Rich or Die Tryin' came out when Keef was in elementary school and is part of his basic musical vocabulary.

column1: Speaking of which: Chief Keef isn’t a lyricist. At all. His lyrics on Finally Rich are almost entirely composed of rudimentary gangsta-rap boilerplate
column2: which he treats more like a graffiti bomber than a rapper
column3: tagging his beats with slogans meant for maximum impact and minimal scrutiny. If there’s anything the odd jumble of industry rappers who show up on Finally Rich share
column4: it’s this casual approach to lyrics. French Montana
column5: who pops up on ""Diamonds""
column6: is most famous thus far for literally inventing a word he didn't even say. And Wiz Khalifa fails to make an impression (as usual) when he drops in on ""Hate Bein' Sober"".

column1: Some of the material filling out Finally Rich is already a year old
column2: including the ubiquitous ""I Don't Like"" and another of Keef's earliest YouTube hits
column3: ""3Hunna""
column4: which now sports a Rick Ross feature. The album feels
column5: promisingly
column6: like a progress report on Keef's developing voice rather than a forced ""arrival."" This has downsides
column7: as there are amateurish moments where some intervention might have been welcome: ""No Tomorrow""'s  vocals barely match up with the beat
column8: while ""Laughin to the Bank"" takes a bassy ""HAWH HAWH HAWH"" vocal hook and flogs you into submission with it. It feels specifically designed to make older rap fans massage their temples.

column1: But there are also hints of where Keef’s sound could go next: ""Kay Kay""
column2: produced by K.E. On The Track
column3: is gentle and pretty
column4: built from rolling piano and airy synths. And ""Citgo"" is as close to an uplifting song as Keef’s ever written. Produced by Young Ravisu
column5: it floats on new age synths while Keef sings a warm
column6: sweet melody. The lyrics are still riddled with violence
column7: but the ugliness of the sentiments don't survive the sunlight of song's major key. It's not a redemptive moment
column8: exactly
column9: but it is a transformative one. ""[My sister] thought I was going to be some kind of motherfuckin' screw-up or something
column10: Keef says on the intro to ""Ballin""
column11: in a clip taken from an interview. ""They thought I was going to be like
column12: bad all my life…I gotta job now
column13: I gotta daughter too."" On an album single-mindedly devoted to painting Keef as pitiless and cold
column14:
it’s a brief glint of the dimensions this ruthlessly effective album barely touches on.

column2:
'Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|"[""Fool's Gold""]"|2012-12-14 00:00:00|2012|2016-06-11 17:03:31.533827|"

Alain Macklovitch is a young dude with a musical career that already spans a decade and a half and has gone through several distinct phases. He started out as a baby-faced turntablist savant who won the most prestigious DJ competition in the world before he could legally drive a car. After that came the Sunglasses Is a Must era
column3: where he left the insular world of turntablism for a gig as Kanye's tour DJ
column4: and to figure out how to incorporate his hip-hop-derived skills into the emergent post-indie dance music culture. We are now well into phase three
column5: where he established himself as a legitimate EDM heavyweight with at least one certified rave anthem (""Barbra Streisand""
column6: which he recorded with Armand Van Helden under the name Duck Sauce) under his belt
column7: as well as an eye for talent that's made Fool's Gold
column8: the label he runs with the DJ/producer Nick Catchdubs
column9: one of the most influential indies in the music business.

column1: Phase-three A-Trak is not only the most successful of his incarnations but also by far the funnest. The turntablist scene he came up in has a marked tendency to emphasize technical chops over pleasure
column2: but over the years he's evolved into a full-on hedonist who's not afraid to skirt the line of what some might call cheesiness
column3: and has fully embraced the place in arena-filling quasi-mainstream EDM culture that ""Barbra Streisand"" helped earn him.

column1: After years of near-constant gigging in nearly every shape and size of venue imaginable
column2: Macklovitch has developed a very clear idea of what qualities a song needs to move a crowd
column3: and his new four-song EP is definitely intended to put that knowledge to work producing yet another signature track capable of making tens of thousands of people lose their shit at the same time.

column1: It's possible that either ""Jumbo"" or ""Disco Nap"" could end up being that track. The former
column2: produced with the Swedish EDM supergroup Galantis
column3: has a frenetic
column4: 90s-cyberpunk feel
column5: and enough tweaky rhythmic breakdowns to appeal to an audience predisposed to dubstep. The latter
column6: a collaboration with LA DJ duo Oliver
column7: offers a popping electro-funk groove
column8: acid-house-style buildups
column9: and a vocal hook that pays tribute to the popular and highly recommended practice of getting a nap in before going clubbing.

column1: But odds are it'll be either ""Tuna Melt"" or ""Landline"" that becomes the kind of inescapable song that’ll show up in every set of a multiple-DJ bill without anyone in the crowd complaining. Both are precisely engineered to move bodies
column2: to the point where it almost feels manipulative and unfair
column3: as if you barely have a choice in the matter. Aspiring dance music producers should consider drawing out diagrams for their structures to learn where to add sounds
column4: where to take them away
column5: when to switch the tone of the synth playing the lead melody
column6: and other essential qualities that a rave anthem needs.

column1: ""Landline""
column2: a collaboration with the producer GTA
column3: has several lessons to impart
column4: including how one can manipulate a retro sound like a booming 90s-style synth piano using modern ideas such as the glitchy clusters of notes popular with trap music producers
column5: or where to shift the gears on the tempo from half-time to double-time (and where to shift back)
column6: as well as the potential of a ridiculous sample (in this case of Woody Woodpecker's laugh) to push a song well over the edge of sanity.

column1: ""Tuna Melt"" is as immaculately and meticulously crafted as one of his DMC-winning turntablism sets. There isn't a superfluous sound in its nearly six minute span
column2: nothing-- from the stunningly simple but inescapable main riff to the chopped-up
column3: diva-style female vocal sample-- that doesn't have a clear role in motivating the listener to dance. It has the ruthlessly efficient grace of an Alien xenomorph
column4:
and it doesn't require any chemical assistance to move an EDM fan to a place of total rave bliss. I suspect Macklovich won't have to write another arena-sized anthem for at least a few more years.

When Starkey released Ear Drums and Black Holes back in April 2010
column2: it was still kind of risky for a North American artist to put their weight behind the idea of a dubstep hybrid that incorporated Dirty South production and Auto-Tune vocals alongside more traditional grime and 2-step influences. It just wasn't as risky as it might have been a couple years before: there was already a thick
column3: smothering atmosphere building in the air that made Starkey's eclectic approach seem like a cerebral sort of outlier when it dropped.

column1: Two months later
column2: Sonny Moore posted his electro-dabbler alter ego's debut EP My Name Is Skrillex to MySpace
column3: and by the end of the year the parameters for what constituted a Stateside take on dubstep had drastically shifted to a monolithic wave of WUB WUB SICK DROPZ. When this stuff started filling arenas
column4: the mainstream media decided the development was worth kicking a decade's worth of history to the curb for
column5: and a nuanced
column6: creatively diverse
column7: long-evolving genre was reduced almost overnight into one-dimensional meme fodder by rockist blogs and YouTube joke-mongers. It's enough to turn musical progressives into gate-slamming reactionaries.

column1: To his credit
column2: Starkey's own reaction to all this seems to be more of a brief side eye before getting back to the business of refining his own thing. Ear Drums and Black Holes was entertaining if somewhat uneven
column3: not necessarily quality-wise but in outlook-- a bunch of ideas too good for the singles-plus-filler designation
column4: but with a sprawl that pulled focus away from a real pivotal stylistic center. His new one
column5: Orbits
column6: manages to draw all his influences together into something more consistent
column7: an actual streamlined signature sound that makes perfect sense given the records that preceded it. Like his 2008 Planet Mu debut album Ephemeral Exhibits and most of the singles and EPs that led up to it
column8: he's made this album a one-man operation without collaborative efforts or vocal guest spots. So its idiosyncracies and surprises are all his
column9: and there's a more direct route to getting a grasp on what he's been going for all this time
column10: even if there's still no shortage of cross-genre leaps and well-timed mood swings.

column1: It helps that dubstep is only part of his music's DNA-- enough that it fits under a liberal definition of the genre
column2: but not so much that he's tied down to its preconceived notions. Much of Orbits owes its sound to an engagement with longstanding influences; this is an artist who sounds the way he does because
column3: as a DJ
column4: he knows his way around what makes the foundational likes of Terror Danjah or Plastician tick and translates that through his own filters. But there are also multiple stabs at working with trap and footwork rhythms
column5: whether they're straight-up or salvaged for parts-- largely the latter
column6: twisted out of shape in cuts like the jostling space-Luger overload of ""G V Star (Part 2)"" or the fractured juke of ""Thugs"". There are brief
column7: contemplative ambient interludes (""G V Star (Part 1)"") and moments of Vangelis-style classic-synth grandeur (""Crashing Sphere""). There's even a nod to trance in the closer
column8: ""Distant Star""
column9: that breathtakingly pits that genre's simple chords and 4/4 throb against Starkey's drive to make things more rhythmically and melodically slippery. That track then slams the door with a big shameless stadium-sized dubstep wobble out of nowhere before the fadeout
column10: but it might scan more like a snarky joke instead of a fitting coda if it didn't have a well-thought-out snare-rattle/clap beat bristling underneath.

column1: That whiplash transition isn't a fluke
column2: either-- in almost every track
column3: there's some weird rhythmic structural curveball that upends the typical expectations of buildups and breakdowns and throws in new elements almost as an ambush. Where other songs ratchet up to a huge drop
column4: he pulls the rug out and inverts the equation so elements disperse instead of explode. Here
column5: ramping up to the isolation of an odd little melodic flourish like the ones in ""The Shuttle"" and ""Lzr"" has every bit the resonance as the wig-pushing bass explosions these songs eventually swing back to. And while the slow build from jittery
column6: drumless melodies and vocal samples to a succession of door-kick basslines and starcruiser-liftoff synths in the anthemic ""Command"" is Make The Crowd Go Apeshit 101
column7: it's just as impactful when the speaker-rattling elements dissipate halfway through to let the moody melodic bits breathe again. Because of the way Starkey deploys his moments of hopped-up but measured-out clamor over intricate rhythms that are actually slower than they might first seem
column8: it all works on both the visceral hands-up level you get from big bass blowouts and the slow-ride zone-out level that lets listeners really sink into a beat.

column1: Which is a roundabout way of leading up to the fact that Starkey can get away with all this because his music's so emotionally evocative
column2: even when it's wordless. (That's most of the time
column3: though the judicious usage of his own Auto-Tuned voice on ""Magnet""-- ""frequency is lost/ take one last breath""-- is too haunting to be cloying.) He's skilled at drawing out catharsis and release through those very structures he messes with
column4: where even the most frenetic melodies linger in the mind afterwards; it's best heard in ""Thugs""
column5: which piles bass rattle after percussive fusillade after vocal-sample tic on top of the simple
column6: melancholy melodic figure it opens on but never actually overwhelms it or drowns it out. And he's not afraid to build hooks out of sounds that are annoying the first few times and catchy from there on out
column7: like the weird plink/twang melody on ""G V Star (Part 2)"" that sounds like it's sourced from the foley of a tooth being yanked out in a 50s cartoon. This is some outlandish stuff
column8: to be sure
column9: but in a sense-of-adventure kind of way that feels in keeping with the vague
column10: in-title-only themes of futurism and space travel that Orbits centers around. There are probably more uncharted worlds out there than we think
column11:
and Starkey seems hellbent on finding all of them.

Sigha is a producer without a hook: both his story and his music are so familiar you'll long for a Twitter-sized morsel of discontent or a trendily vapid remix. First
column2: the story. Sigha
column3: London native James Shaw
column4: began making vaguely tech-y dubstep for Hotflush and other labels around the turn of the decade; he has since moved to Berlin and proceeded to make a more traditional form of techno. He runs the nascent Our Circula Sound label. Though he rarely sits down for interviews or offers podcasts
column5: he is not reclusive or secretive

column7: you could do a lot worse.

column1: Sigha's music

column3: is also hookless in a musical sense. He favors the unforgiving
column4: all-rhythm-everything approach of certain second wave Detroit artists as well as the more modern crop of German enthusiasts. Sigha once professed that he finds big melodies distracting
column5: so you can be sure what you're getting throughout Ghosts: linear
column6: mainline drum machines riding roughshod over hissy electronic ephemera. Softness arrives in pill-sized doses
column7: small squiggles of color repeatedly snuffed out by the drums and the haze. Beatless passages tar the beginning
column8: middle
column9: and end of Ghosts
column10: because full-lengths require Art. Sigha's ties to bass music shine through in the tempos
column11: which sit in the 120s. It's big music
column12: meant for big spaces: Ghosts doesn't sound bad on headphones
column13: but it's not any fun
column14: either. Small
column15: personal environments trivialize tracks this rigid. When played loudly
column16: Ghosts commandeers its space. Its synths groan
column17: its drums bulldoze
column18: the whole album intrudes and menaces.

column1: Ghosts is industrial in the most literal sense: the tracks show up
column2: perform
column3: and then exit. There are no hissing valves
column4: no rusty scrapes
column5: no brokedown palaces full of empty assembly lines. Ghosts is too put together for that; it is the modern factory
column6: steam-cleaned every evening
column7: proper safety equipment. Sterility is implied
column8: and when Ghosts errs it errs on the side of order and caution. It is dense and noisy
column9: but it's also conservative
column10: especially because
column11: even for gritty techno
column12: Ghosts is not funky or sexy (don't let the cover fool you). It is pummeling introspection
column13: ""peak time"" interpreted as the point in the evening during which you have most forgotten where you are.

column1: If this were philosophy you would accuse Sigha of asceticism; it's techno
column2: so we just say ""bleak
column3: and ""uncompromising."" There's nothing easy about making music this relentless and impersonal. It is masochism dressed up as genre. (An early Sigha single was named ""I Am Apathy
column4: I Am Submission"".) In open air
column5: Sigha's systems are chaotic and threatening
column6: but they have a habit of choking one another off over the course of an album. Ghosts still proves
column7: though
column8: over and over
column9: that Sigha has a single
column10: awesome skill-- tunneling
column11:
perverse techno.

Wiz Khalifa smokes weed by the acre
column3: but his career thus far has been driven by his own shrewd vision for himself. He is not a rapper's rapper
column4: but he helped push rap into its current fixation with doing drugs instead of selling them and has rightfully reaped the rewards of an entire genre following his lead. He also became a pop star with ease in 2010
column5: sliding into the studio with pop titans like Stargate and Benny Blanco and emerging with a No. 1 single (""Black and Yellow"") that was a pure rap banger and another pop smash (""Roll Up"") that applied his airy
column6: breezy aesthetic to the radio. O.N.I.F.C.
column7: his second major label album
column8: is a resounding misstep
column9: and it's the first sign that Khalifa's unwavering focus may be getting swallowed up by the haze.

column1: Or maybe he couldn't bring himself to care about the fragile nature of crossover success any longer. O.N.I.F.C. will quickly be swept under the rug by anyone but his true diehards
column2: yet Khalifa still had a successful year by displaying his malleability. His Taylor Allderdice mixtape from March was a nice stopgap release
column3: steeped in the same foggy
column4: washed out beats that helped elevate him to fame. Cabin Fever 2
column5: from October
column6: saw Khalifa dipping into L.A.'s ratchet scene to show just how much artists like Iamsu! owe to his own mix of nonsense rapping and soft
column7: blissed-out singing. Both mixtapes were right in his lane
column8: and they predicted the direction Khalifa would take with the album proper.

column1: Khalifa has already more or less disowned his debut
column2: telling his fans that ""creatively [it] wasn't my best work."" That regret is evident on O.N.I.F.C. which tosses a Blanco produced single to the dogs but then retracts further into his vaporized aesthetic. The album kicks off with a suite of tracks that are meant to wash over you
column3: and they are undoubtedly effective-- ""Paperbond"" is steeped in the comforting draft of chillwave while ""Bluffin'""
column4: produced by Drumma Boy no less
column5: borders on balearic. The problem
column6: though
column7: is that both songs would work best as zone-out instrumentals. Khalifa doesn't say anything of note-- ""riding in my ride"" is crushingly emblematic -- and doesn't sound particular good from a technical standpoint. He is there because he has to be
column8: not because he should be.

column1: Everything from there on is just an unending succession of diminishing returns that questions the relevancy of Khalifa's artistic existence. He could-- and just may-- pump music out for the indefinite future that coasts on sound design and little else. Wiz has never exactly spit quotable 16s but his rapping on O.N.I.F.C. suggests ignorance regarding his own distance instead of a conscious desire to roll with the vibes. The album's acronym stands for ""Only Nigga in First Class"" and sports a dour looking photo of Khalifa on the cover
column2: but it's difficult to find any significance in either-- he hints at fatigue
column3: but doesn't illuminate the flipside of stardom in any way.

column1: Maybe the album's most indicative track is ""No Limit""
column2: which is nearly nine and a half minutes long thanks to a three-minute instrumental interlude. It sounds pointless except that the interlude is easily the most enjoyable moment of the record. After a verse from Wiz
column3: the song slips into beachside ambience
column4: ice-rattle drums
column5:
and plaintive pianos. It is legitimately as good as anything Air France ever did. Then Wiz starts rapping again.

column1: Things pick up toward the end. Future also offers the tape's saddest lyric

column3: so we pay for her.""

column9: and my personal favorite

column14:

Earlier this year the excellent British label MIE released a double-vinyl edition of The Dew Line
column2: the 1994 album by Michael Morley's solo project Gate. The reissue was a nice reminder of the peculiar magic Morley conjures with thick guitar
column3: monotone vocals
column4: and the occasional beat. At its best
column5: such as in the two-chord
column6: 12-minute epic ""Have Not""
column7: The Dew Line offered noise-rock slowed to a crawl and coated in syrup
column8: as if Morley recorded it in a codeine-induced haze. Stretching riffs into drones that still maintained a rock thrust

column1: After The Dew Line
column2: Morley has veered mostly toward computer-based music
column3: incorporating samples and even some dance beats. The overall effect of the sound has been similar to that of his early work
column4: mostly due to his mesmerizingly sluggish singing. But certainly some Gate fans must have wondered if he would revisit the heavy-fuzz style that made mid-90s records like <i>The Dew Line
column5: Guitar
column6: and Golden so compelling (and such worthy companions to his work in New Zealand trio the Dead C.)

column1: Damned Revolutions
column2: the first Gate LP since 2010's beat-driven A Republic of Sadness
column3: is a clear return to that sound
column4: and a triumphant one. Triumphant is perhaps an odd word to use for music this subdued and uninterested in hurrying to get anywhere. But Damned Revolutions' slo-mo moans and room-filling guitar are bold
column5: persistent
column6: and once again hypnotic. There's no hesitancy in these two side-long
column7: 19-minute pieces. It's all confident
column8: purposeful time-expansion
column9: with no big moves or flashy changes needed to hold attention.

column1: Which is not to say that nothing happens on Damned Revolutions. It's actually a pretty busy record at times
column2: with Morley cranking out extended guitar noise that rivals his farthest-out explorations in the Dead C. But even those moments stretch time more then they mark it. The tick of the clock seems to fade away as Morley's pieces progress. That approach encourages you to get inside each sound without worrying about when it will end
column3: and to absorb each moment fully rather than anticipate the next one.

column1: The two halves of Damned Revolutions take different angles to achieve this effect. On ""Turned And Glowing Inwardly""
column2: Morley actually does mark time with a sparse
column3: insistent pulse. But the more it marches on
column4: the more it melts into his fog of vocals and guitar. Gradually
column5: its robotic regularly starts to feel surreal and illusively lopsided
column6: as if the woozy sound surrounding it were contagiously throwing it off.

column1: Beats are absent on ""Turning and Towards the Light""
column2: a dark guitar improvisation filled with churning
column3: distant chords. But instead of feeling scary or melodramatic
column4: the track exudes a thorough
column5: almost eerie calm
column6: due to Morley's uncanny ability to stop time in its tracks without devolving into stasis. Though he avoids easy climaxes
column7: the song still creates a kind of catharsis-- one felt more in reflection than action
column8:
more in reverberation than initiation. And it suggests that Morley's achievements on Damned Revolutions might resonate as long as The Dew Line's have-- perhaps even longer.

column3: bassist/vocalist Dylan Desmond and drummer/vocalist Adrian Guerra play patiently

column1: The album opens with a 20 minute journey into despair
column2: ""Bails (of Flesh)""
column3: a track that will likely weed out those who can't handle the unrelentingly downcast feel of the record. The tracks get shorter from there

column2: save for a sample from the Edgar Allen Poe-inspired film The Masque of the Red Death
column3: is a five-minute drumless drone piece
column4: where notes fly off and subsequently wither like Icarus on 33 1/3 RPM. The clean bass is more lonesome and more eerie than the distorted bass that the album's built upon. ""Mask"" seems like the perfect track to incorporate a sudden blast of hisses
column5: feedback
column6: screams-- something to make the listener jolt. It doesn't
column7: and that suspense
column8: like walking over rows of false trap doors
column9: adds to the creepy atmosphere.

column1: Throughout
column2: Guerra's growls are complementary of the genre
column3: and he even throws in a few blackened shrieks on ""Rows (of Endless Waves)"". Desmond's clean vocals
column4: however
column5: are more compelling
column6: taking different shapes throughout the record. His warm
column7: forlorn style carries the latter half of ""Bails (of Flesh)""
column8: turning maudlin doom into perverted praise music. It's not a far stretch to imagine this being played in some church that worships self-destruction
column9: congregants raising their hands up high
column10: arms bleeding from cutting themselves. Desmond gives hails and salutations to the misery
column11: like Om learning of a terminal illness diagnosis.

column1: The previously mentioned ""Rows"" sees Desmond's voice become more delicate
column2: almost crushing under the weight of the music. Frailty is important to the variety of doom Bell Witch explores

column4: adding emphasis without raising his voice. He channels dISEMBOWELMENT's Renato Gallina on ""Longing"" making that track a true successor to the Australian doom-death quartet's 1993 classic Transcendence into the Peripheral. Remember that editorial arguing that metal vocalists are irrelevant? It wasn't entirely without merit
column5: but Desmond challenges that line of thinking. He's got a cleverness and sense of space most vocalists don't possess. His voice is much like the music itself: it reverberates around
column6: as if wandering and looking for a way out of this despair. Open and wide-reaching as it may be

too.

It's impossible to talk about Voodoo without talking about what's happened since Voodoo. Or
column2: more accurately
column3: what hasn't happened since Voodoo. It's been 12 years since D'Angelo released his dirt-encrusted soul opus in the first month of the new millennium
column4: and we have yet to see a follow-up. During those dozen calendar runs
column5: the Virginia-bred singer
column6: songwriter
column7: multi-instrumentalist
column8: and producer has learned to play guitar and spent countless hours in various studios
column9: trying to find his way to the next sound. This time last year
column10: unofficial D'Angelo status updater and kindred spirit/collaborator ?uestlove told me the new album is ""pretty much 97% done."" And this year
column11: D played a number of live shows

column1: He's also been arrested-- for disturbing the peace
column2: marijuana possession
column3: carrying a concealed weapon
column4: and driving under the influence in 2005
column5: and then for offering an undercover NYPD officer $40 for a blowjob in 2010. There were several attempts at rehab. And he's almost died at least once

column7: when I asked ?uestlove how his friend stacks up against the other luminaries he's worked with-- people like Jay-Z and Al Green-- he summed up the D'Angelo dilemma well: ""I consider him a genius beyond words. At the same time
column8: I say to myself
column9: 'How can I scream someone's genius if they hardly have any work to show for it?' Then again
column10: the last work he did was so powerful that it's lasted 10 years.""

column1: At this point
column2: it's easy to forget that Voodoo itself was
column3: for quite awhile
column4: one of those forever-delayed studio myths
column5: too. ""I've been gone so long
column6: just wanna sing my song
column7: D'Angelo sings on ""The Line""
column8: a self-directed pep talk and explanation of his slug-like pace
column9: ""I know you been hearing a lot of things about me."" Voodoo arrived five years behind D's home-recorded bap&B debut
column10: Brown Sugar
column11: and blew through its fair share of release dates before touching down on January 25
column12: 2000. Its arrival came during the twilight of the mega-CD era-- six months after Napster's birth
column13: two years before the iPod-- but its four-year gestation occurred during the halcyon 90s
column14: a time when artists were afforded the chance to tinker for years on end while blazing through bottomless studio budgets. The record topped the Billboard albums chart during its first two weeks out
column15: and looking at 2000's other #1s-- including N'Sync's record-breaking No Strings Attached
column16: Eminem's angsty Marshall Mathers LP
column17: and
column18: uh
column19: Limp Bizkit's Chocolate Starfish and the Hot Dog Flavored Water-- Voodoo stands tall with October's Kid A as a paranoid
column21: and challenging artistic statement that somehow managed to scale the industry.

column1: Riding high off of 1998's The Miseducation of Lauryn Hill
column2: Maxwell's first two LPs
column3: and Erykah Badu's 1997 album Baduizm
column4: the so-called neo-soul movement
column5: which favored earthy 70s production rather than 90s slickness
column6: was reaching an apex in 2000. And Voodoo was positioned as a more down-to-earth alternative to the infinite excess of late-90s hip-hop and R&B. ""[Contemporary R&B]'s a joke
column7: scoffed D'Angelo at the time. ""It's sad-- the people making this shit have turned black music into a club thing."" (For his sake
column8: here's hoping D hasn't flipped on the radio in the last five years.)

column1: While this viewpoint may seem somewhat myopic in our poptimist era
column2: to understand D'Angelo is to understand who he looked to for musical and spiritual guidance: Jimi Hendrix
column3: Sly Stone
column4: George Clinton
column5: Marvin Gaye
column6: Stevie Wonder
column7: Curtis Mayfield
column8: Al Green
column9: Otis Redding
column10: Prince-- supremely gifted artists known for expertly plying their craft. His devotion isn't merely cosmetic or fashionable
column11: though-- by all accounts he's a hardcore music nerd who ""knows every Prince concert's playlist
column12: according to recent GQ profiler Amy Wallace. His love of musical lore is partly why he chose to make Voodoo in Electric Lady Studios
column13: the downtown Manhattan recording space Hendrix built in 1969. Listening to the album
column14: his influences are apparent
column15: but also ingrained in a way that's equal parts reverent and uncanny. Rather than just listening to old Funkadelic or Stevie albums for inspiration
column16: Voodoo was literally born from them; a typical night at Electric Lady would have D
column17: ?uestlove
column18: bassist Pino Palladino
column19: and maybe one or two of their prodigious buddies playing an entire classic soul album through
column20: and then seeing where those jams led them. This went on for years. The result is ineffably natural
column21: the type of live-in-studio sound that requires copious god-given talent-- D'Angelo started playing piano at age 4-- and constant woodshedding to really pull off. There are no shortcuts.

column1: D'Angelo's old-school obsessions extended even further than songwriting inspiration. Voodoo was recorded on 2"" tape-- 120 reels of the stuff were used in total according to engineer Russell Elevado-- and many of the songs' instrumental takes were recorded live without overdubs. Vintage gear was employed. The analog fetishism is ironic considering how
column2: at the time of its release
column3: vinyl had yet to make a resurgence; indeed
column4: this 2xLP reissue is a godsend in that respect
column5: especially for anyone who's considered dropping $100 on eBay for one of the few LPs originally made in 2000. I've been listening to this album since it came out-- my original 74-minute CD-R
column6: burned from a friend
column7: left out the 79-minute album's last song-- and it never gets old
column8: or grating
column9: or tired. While this is obviously largely due to the quality of the songs
column10: it's hard not to think that the warm glow given off by the equipment and recording techniques used to create it factors in as well. Not all music needs to be built to last
column11: but Voodoo was designed and willed and technically optimized to be a testament for the ages; it captures empty space and heartbreak as well as it does rim shots and joy. The grooves deepen. When the news of a bare-bones
column12: no-bonus-tracks vinyl reissue causes palpable excitement 12 years later
column13: it's a rare accomplishment.

column1: But Voodoo is more than a fetish object for analog geeks and old-soul collectors. It's peppered with hip-hop inflections largely informed by the singular work of J Dilla
column2: the record's biggest modern influence. D'Angelo probably had Dilla's beats in mind when he wanted ?uestlove to dirty his impeccable timing to drum like he had just ""drank some moonshine behind a chuckwagon
column3: as ?uest once put it. In GQ
column4: D cited the Detroit producer's 2006 death as the moment he decided to wake up from his booze-and-cocaine fueled lost years. ""I felt like I was going to be next
column5: he said. And when he played this year's Made in America festival in Philadelphia
column6: he stepped out to the strains of obscure Canadian band Motherlode's ""When I Die""
column7: which Dilla flipped on the finale of his last true album
column8: Donuts. The song's hook: ""When I die
column9: I hope to be a better man than you thought I'd be."" Voodoo's element of sampling is crucial and varied as well
column10: whether through flawless interpolations (as on ""Send It On""
column11: which borrows its horn-laden lilt from Kool and the Gang's ""Sea of Tranquility"")
column12: or sly cut-ups (like when DJ Premier drops in a line of Fat Joe's materialistic ""Success"" into the anti-materialism screed ""Devil's Pie"")
column13: or well-chosen covers (the slowed-down brilliance of ""Feel Like Makin' Love""
column14: a #1 for Roberta Flack in 1974).

column1: Given his extensive repertoire of male R&B legends
column2: the fact that D chose Voodoo's only cover to be a song made famous by a woman also seems key. Because another aspect of the album's overall concept involves an embrace of femininity. ""The Aquarian Age is a matriarchal age
column3: and if we are to exist as men in this new world many of us must learn to embrace and nurture that which is feminine with all of our hearts
column4: wrote singer/poet Saul Williams in the record's liner notes. ""But is there any room for artistry in hip hop's decadent man-sion?"" The album's most uncharacteristic moment involves this schism between hip-hop and misogyny and feminism
column5: when guest stars Method Man and Redman drop tone-deaf dick-fluffing broadsides on ""Left and Right"". (Intriguingly
column6: Q-Tip recorded a more thematically appropriate verse for the track
column7: though that version has yet to surface.) But everywhere else
column8: Voodoo exhibits a mature attitude toward women and relationships-- one that doesn't pander
column9: but empathizes
column10: and shows that the then-26-year-old father of two was becoming acquainted with all sides of love.

column1: Voodoo's second half
column2: from ""One Mo' Gin"" through ""Africa""
column3: goes from the depths of despondency
column4: to regret
column5: to carnal ecstasy
column6: to something more spiritual and everlasting. These songs get to the bottom of nothing less than the core of human interaction; what happens when people collide and come together and break apart. And it's all done with the omnipotent knowing of a saint. Nothing is overstated. ""The Root"" is the record's most downtrodden track lyrically
column7: where D'Angelo confesses
column8: ""I feel my soul is empty
column9: my blood is cold and I can't feel my legs/ I need someone to hold me
column10: bring me back to life before I'm dead."" But instead of dour instrumentation
column11: the song's accompanying rhythm is comforting
column12: warm. The whole song leads to a kind of exorcism-- in its final minutes
column13: the singer masterfully layers his own voice on top of itself
column14: vocal lines coming in at every imaginable direction
column15: offering a peek inside his brain. Then it all smooths out
column16: finding comfort in infinity: ""From the Alpha of creation
column17: to the end of all time."" D'Angelo knows these stakes are high but
column18: as he concludes on ""The Line""
column19: ""If I can hold on
column20: I'm sure everything will be alright."" Voodoo is the sound of him holding on; its ensuing silence marks his lost grip.

column1: Details also give Voodoo its timelessness. The album's gentle avoidance of common song structures adds spontaneity; even after hundreds of listens
column2: it's still possible to be surprised. The barely-heard words spoken in intros and outros give things continuity and a voyeuristic quality
column3: like you're hearing it all through a city wall; listen again for the the sweetly awkward conversation with an ex that starts ""One Mo' Gin"" or the way ""Greatdayndamornin'"" is introduced with D'Angelo praising ?uestlove to journalist dream hampton: ""I was like
column4: 'You gonna be my drummer one of these days
column5: '"" gushes D.

column1: The concept of voodoo itself-- as portrayed via the record's voodoo-ceremony photos-- is multi-layered. While probably using voodoo's exaggerated and misrepresented image within modern popular culture to add some mystique and danger
column2: D'Angelo's also likely referencing the religion's African origins
column3: and how it was coveted by uprooted slaves
column4: feared by slave owners
column5: and ignited the Haitian Revolution of 1791. D'Angelo was born the son of a Pentecostal minister
column6: and he was exposed to that religion's closely intertwining relationship between the spiritual and earthly realms: speaking in tongues
column7: divine healing. And music. ""I learned at an early age that what we were doing in the choir was just as important as the preacher
column8: he told GQ. ""The stage is our pulpit
column9: and you can use all of that energy and that music and the lights and the colors and the sound. But you know
column10: you've got to be careful."" Coming out of D's mouth
column11: this is more than hokum-- he believes it and he makes you believe it. There are many ghosts hidden within this record. They're still being drawn out.

column1: Still
column2: many simply know Voodoo for a certain naked music video. The clip for ""Untitled (How Does It Feel)"" is the reason why the album went platinum
column3: and it plays a large part in D's ensuing disappearance. It instantly transformed the singer from a very talented artist to a pin-up. The song was the last track recorded for Voodoo
column4: and it's the most direct thing here
column5: a churning Prince-inspired ballad that bests nearly every actual ballad Prince ever recorded. It's about lust
column6: sure
column7: but it's a two-way street. The way he sings it
column8: ""how does it feel?"" isn't necessarily rhetorical
column9: no matter how much it should be considering the power of the music. And if you look closely
column10: the video isn't just a handsome and muscular guy flexing his pecs. There's a vulnerability in D'Angelo's eyes
column11: an awkwardness that's both endearing and slightly uncomfortable.

column1: ""You've got to realize
column2: he'd never looked like that before in his life
column3: D's trainer Mark Jenkins told Spin in 2008. ""To be somebody who was so introverted
column4: and then
column5: in a matter of three or four months
column6: to be so ripped-- everything was happening so quickly."" The video became a phenomenon and
column7: soon enough
column8: women were standing at the lip of D'Angelo's stage
column9: telling him to take off his clothes. The attention was infuriating to him
column10: and it sent the singer to a dark place-- all that work
column11: all that time blown away by a few sweaty shots of his abdomen. Then again
column12: while he was hesitant
column13: he still shot the video. The unfortunate ordeal causes writer Jason King to conclude
column14: in this reissue's new liner notes: ""For all of Voodoo's claims to realness and authenticity
column15: D'Angelo's imaging
column16: while rooted in promise
column17: had been in some ways a charade
column18: an unsustainable performance of black masculinity gone awry.""

column1: ""I got something I'm seeing; I got a vision
column2: D'Angelo told Time upon Voodoo's release. ""This album is the second step to that vision."" It seems safe to say the prophecy he was speaking about did not entail more than a decade of nothingness
column3: or drug addiction
column4: or shame. Now
column5: it's difficult to say where this vision is leading. Playing an upbeat new funk track called ""Sugar Daddy"" at this year's BET Awards
column6: he looked solid
column7: and his voice sounded fantastic
column8: but it was almost as interesting to watch the cutaway shots-- to see Nicki Minaj staring on
column9: seemingly confused
column10: or Kanye talking to someone during the performance
column11: or Beyonce standing up
column12: loving every second. (BET headlined the clip: ""D'Angelo's Sexiest Performance Ever!"")

column1: There's a big difference between a prodigious
column2: smooth-skinned 26-year-old playing retro-styled music and a 38-year-old doing the same thing. The backwards-looking pose can calcify; by the time Prince was 38
column3: he was well into his symbol phase. That said
column4: D'Angelo is the quintessential old soul. And there's hope in the comebacks of fellow 90s refugees Maxwell and Badu
column5: who both released some of their best work after long layoffs over the last few years. But D'Angelo's inactivity has only helped to inflate Voodoo's myth
column6: though it doesn't need much help. It's frustrating to think about how someone so enamored with the past
column7: who knew his heroes' failures so well
column8: could be doomed to repeat them. It's almost as if he studied them too much
column9: and the same spiritual power that fueled his greatest moment couldn't help but bring him down. Like that's how he thought it was supposed to go. In an interview between ?uestlove and D around the release of Voodoo
column10: the drummer confronted the singer about his idols: ""They all have one thing in common
column11: they were all vanguards
column12:
but 98% of them crashed and burned."" To which D'Angelo responded: ""I think about that all the time.""
