0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/18584/homepage_large.ef7c94db.jpg|Worship is the Cleansing of the Imagination|30851.0|JK Flesh / Prurient|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Hydra Head']|2012-12-12 00:00:00|2012|2016-06-11 17:03:38.565734|"

How and when will you die? That question
column2: of course
column3: has fascinated centuries of thinkers
column4: from philosophers plundering mortality's meaning to laypeople simply hoping to have their affairs in order when life comes to a close. In most cases
column5: the end is unpredictable-- a car crash
column6: a heart attack
column7: a disease that comes on swiftly and decisively. But businesses often sense that doom is inevitable
column8: that accounts receivable are no longer balancing accounts payable in a way that's sustainable. They have the rare choice of how to handle their own demise: They can choose to hide this from their customers and one day simply shutter the doors
column9: or they can choose to throw themselves on the great public pyre
column10: making a show of their mortality and allowing the faithful to plunder their wares another time or two.

column1: In September
column2: Hydra Head Records joined the latter caste: For nearly two decades
column3: Hydra Head has been a fearless syndicate of loud
column4: a label at the vanguard of risky releases paired with adventurous packaging. In 1999
column5: for instance
column6: they released Isis' excellent Sawblade EP-- notably
column7: featuring a cover of Godflesh's ""Streetcleaner""-- on a CD-R affixed to a full-size metallic sawblade
column8: painted red or black. Consistent with Hydra Head founder Aaron Turner's ecumenical vision of heavy
column9: they embraced the grindcore of Agoraphobic Nosebleed
column10: the wretched malevolence of Khanate
column11: the noise purges of Merzbow
column12: the arithmetic bludgeon of the Austerity Program
column13: and the astral wonder of Pyramids
column14: to name a few.

column1: The list of accomplishments is exhausting. It exhausted Hydra Head's funds
column2: too
column3: leading the label to announce the first of two going-out-of-business fire sales in September: Enthusiasts could buy bundles of backstock at incredibly deep discounts
column4: with the hope of paying the bills and finishing the final releases. Two months later
column5: Hydra Head put test pressings
column6: original artwork
column7: and even Turner's Les Paul on sale with the hope of raising enough money to keep the label’s sizable back catalogue in permanent circulation. The willingness of customers to spend $800 on a Torche and Boris 10"" or $180 on an Isis box set became a functional tribute to the label
column8: a way to push it into some future while kowtowing to its expiring glory.

column1: Hydra Head's final (for now) release has much the same effect: A split between Godflesh/Jesu leader Justin K. Broadrick under his new solo moniker
column2: JK Flesh
column3: and prolific electronic noise insurgent Dominick Fernow as Prurient
column4: the six-track Worship is the Cleansing of Imagination serves as a cross-generational cycle between two aggressive sonic explorers. Broadrick's three tracks here are the more concussive
column5: comprising electronic drums massive enough to suggest EBM on steroids and damaged textures occasionally abrasive enough to be classified as power electronics. His opener
column6: ""Fear of Fear""
column7: is a savage and short trip
column8: a cyclone of a beat rumbling through fields of bass and blown-out guitars. Fernow focuses less on a pulse
column9: instead using loops and layers to build a cyclone of sound that he either subsequently pulls apart or simply lets collapse. He leads with ""Chosen Books""
column10: which matches Broadrick's gambit by dogpiling roars and whirs and hums until the frame of the sound system begins to quiver. These are similar but separate paths to the same plane of aggression
column11: an idea that could serve as the retroactive Hydra Head mantra.

column1: The best cuts on either side bear out that idea
column2: too: ""Deceiver"" is Broadrick's most provocative and ambitious cut here. It opens as an industrial dirge
column3: the toll of a church bell stretched into a subterranean groan. That sound cycles throughout the piece
column4: while Broadrick adds and removes layers like a marionette. The hyperkinetic beat occasionally bursts open to douse the track in noisy shrapnel and low-end torture. ""Deceiver"" casts Broadrick as the controller of his past
column5: able to funnel his experiences into these intense five minutes. Worship closes with ""I Understand You""
column6: one of the most strangely beautiful pieces of music in the catalogues of Prurient or Hydra Head. Fernow wrestles simultaneously with disparate sets of impulses
column7: attempting to thread a punishing squelch sustain around a keyboard line that hovers just on the horizon. The din overtakes the melody for a bit
column8: but Fernow eventually pulls both themes back together before letting the keyboard disappear entirely. The noise spreads like ivy on a wall of disappearing ruins.

column1: Both Broadrick and Fernow share the broad musical view implicitly espoused by Hydra Head for the last two decades. Broadrick's oeuvre stretches from the atavistic blast of Napalm Death's debut and the militant stomp of Godflesh to the diaphanous loom of Jesu and the exploratory throb of Techno Animal. In Prurient
column2: Fernow has wrestled with noise and poetry
column3: corrupted beats and rhythm-less roars. He's made black metal in Ash Pool
column4: muted and mutated pop melodies in Vatican Shadow
column5: and gone for full-on dance bombast in Cold Cave. If Hydra Head is indeed done
column6: this is an excellent and appropriate ending for a big-eared label never confined by expectations of its output or intentions. These six tracks provide heaviness in a half-dozen different ways
column7:
a functional and fitting elegy for an imprint that achieved that mission with enviable consistency.

The Game has no dignity
column2: but it certainly hasn't hindered his career
column3: which was built entirely without it
column4: and even predicated on its absence. Dignity's overrated
column5: anyway; if you leveled the accusation at him
column6: he'd probably work it into a rhyme about Blackstreet so he could remind you how much he likes ""No Diggity"". When you've sold 10 million albums abasing yourself at every available opportunity
column7: there's no reason to change course
column8: and on his fifth studio collection
column9: the Game is still happily
column10: busily
column11: thoroughly ethering himself beyond all comprehension: ""I don’t care if Kanye hit it/ I don’t care if Jay hit it/ I’ma eat it up and I’ma lay with it"" he says on the first verse of ""I Remember""
column12: a song that is a bald imitation of Future's ""Same Damn Time""
column13: with Future himself on the hook. Looking away yet? He's just getting started.

column1: Here are some other things the Game says on Jesus Piece: He reminds us on ""Freedom""
column2: again
column3: that Eminem murdered him on The Documentary's ""We Ain't""
column4: as if if wasn't embarrassing enough when he exclaimed it on that very song. He tells us that his iPod is ""shuffling between Common
column5: Jay Electronica
column6: and Bono"" on ""Heaven's Arms"". At one point
column7: he interrupts himself to say ""Hold on
column8: I gotta take Birdman's call
column9: before interpolating audio of a Birdman voicemail. He yells ""Murder is what I do to these Just Blazes
column10: on an album produced entirely without Just Blaze's input. Game's business is making you cringe for him
column11: and business is...well
column12: it remains a business.

column1: Truthfully
column2: it's a little shocking to see another Game product in stores a mere year after The R.E.D. Album
column3: a  project with a development so troubled it redefined the lengths a record label will go to double down on a losing hand. It hit the top of the charts with what felt like a dead-cat-bounce
column4: but here the Game is
column5: seemingly unscathed
column6: with another full platter of his signature blend of desperate-networker hip-hop. He is the rap game Wile E. Coyote; no matter how many times he blows himself to smithereens
column7: he survives to do it again another day.

column1: What presumably keeps him going-- besides
column2: of course
column3: a frightening
column4: ""Walking Dead""-like tenacity-- is that when you scrape away all these irritating quirks
column5: he remains reliably good at cobbling together poppy gangsta-rap songs. He's always boasted excellent
column6: if unadventurous
column7: taste in beats
column8: and he sources some excellent ones on Jesus Piece from SAP
column9: a 22-year-old kid from Delaware whose biggest hits thus far have been Mac Miller's ""Donald Trump"" and Meek Mill's pre-MMG street hit ""In My Bag"". SAP provides the catchy Bone Thugs redux ""Celebration"" and the choir-sampling ""Name Me King""
column10: a song that also has a sharply focused verse from Pusha T. Jake One gives him an infectious early-Kanye-style beat
column11: reminiscent of ""The Glory""
column12: for ""Hallelujah""
column13: and Game makes a very early-Kanye-style song out of it. Longtime collaborators Cool & Dre soak his ruined voice in greyscale synth tones in ""Can't Get Right"" and ""Pray"" and then give him a helium-filled bouncy castle of New Jack Swing vocals on ""All That"".

column1: The album and song titles hint at a sustained religious fascination
column2: but this isn't Game's concept album. Even so
column3: it's more focused than he's been in awhile
column4: and while you couldn't call an album featuring 2Chainz
column5: Rick Ross
column6: Meek Mill
column7: Lil Wayne (twice)
column8: Future
column9: Young Jeezy
column10: Chris Brown
column11: Common
column12: Pusha T
column13: Jamie Foxx
column14: J. Cole
column15: Kendrick Lamar and more ""lean
column16: Jesus Piece is less all-over-the-place than The R.E.D. Album. Except for an embarrassing breakout of ""hanhs"" on the Kanye-sampling title track and his blood-draining Future imitation on ""I Remember""
column17: he mostly keeps a lid on his irritating habit of mimicking other rappers' flows.

column1: The flip side to being prone to saying any fool thing that pops into your head is that you can occasionally be hilarious: on ""Church""
column2: he for some reason kidnaps and attempts to drown a woman before saving her and explaining to her that she was baptized. On ""Can't Get Right""
column3: he continues his long string of overly attached girlfriend messages to Dr. Dre
column4: telling us that after Dre passed him up to work on Kendrick Lamar's record
column5: he had ""nightmares"" that someone shot him. The Game's contract with Interscope is up after this record and something tells me that wherever he goes next
column6: it will be messy to watch
column7: and probably just as entertaining. Seven years into a career that's resembled a slow-motion wreck as often as a highlight reel
column8:
and I remain morbidly fascinated with what will happen to him next.

Musicians tend to recoil at the term ""side project
column2: and with good reason. Calling a band or an album a side project suggests that it's a dabble
column3: a dodge
column4: an exercise that might be fun or instructive for the participants but only of passing interest to the audience. And if you've spent a lot of time (or even just a little) trying to create something
column5: that kind of reduction is pretty annoying. Perhaps that's why these
column6: ahem
column7: ""exploratory enterprises"" seem to be treated with greater seriousness lately. Is Divine Fits a side project? How about Atoms for Peace? Didn't Gnarls Barkley start out as a partnership between artists known for other things
column8: and then become the thing that made Cee-Lo Green and Danger Mouse mainstream stars?

column1: The answers to these questions are: ""Not really
column2: ""more so than Divine Fits but not totally
column3: and ""of course
column4: though it's nothing compared to what The Voice did for Cee-Lo."" Still
column5: even if we agree that side projects being treated with the same respect as ""real"" projects is a good thing
column6: it doesn't mean the term as it was originally intended is necessarily bad. Take San Francisco's Window Twins
column7: a collaboration between Tim Cohen of psych-rockers the Fresh & Onlys and Jon Bernson of the deconstructivist electro-pop group Exray's. Cohen and Bernson have recorded two albums together
column8: including the new Wish
column9: a collection of atmospheric sketches that explore the scuzzy
column10: sinister
column11: and lo-fi fringes of jazzy R&B
column12: and ramshackle folk. It's not a fully realized record or especially immediate
column13: and it's not really intended to be; Wish has the freeform adventurousness of an extemporaneous experiment
column14: where the process is ultimately more important than the finished result. And
column15: if appreciated in this context
column16: it's a fascinating listen.

column1: The album opening ""Two Left Feet"" is easily the most song-like track on Wish
column2: sounding only slightly murkier than the Fresh & Onlys' excellent 2009 album Grey-Eyed Girls. But for the most part
column3: Wish is more about trying out sonic textures than presenting polished compositions
column4: establishing a mood that grows more unsettling as the album progresses. ""The Sky is Back"" is typical of Wish's smudged soulful malevolence
column5: with its skittering beat and bright horn washes. On the glowering ""Others""
column6: a cowpunk gallop clicks along like a clock
column7: which is echoed by Cohen's menacing ""tick tock"" refrain. That paranoia of ""Others""-- echoed by Cohen's insistence that ""there's others in the world
column8: don't forget about that/ you know there's others out there""-- deepens on the creepy ""Good People""
column9: which pairs a despairing lyric (""when good people go away/ where do they go"") with a spare
column10: Massive Attack-like groove.

column1: This is a far cry from the Fresh & Onlys' most recent album
column2: the pretty and poppy Long Slow Dance. If Cohen was repressing his dark side on that record
column3: he indulges it fully with Bernson
column4: and in the process tries out weird sounds that no longer fit with the Fresh & Onlys' more streamlined presentation. About half of the time
column5: the diversions don't coalesce
column6: like on the woozy ""Thunder and Lightning""
column7: which sways uneasily between promising abstraction and unfocused puttering. The bold ""Wine Into Winter""
column8: with its minute-long drum solo and full-on jazz-rock affectations
column9: is better
column10: though mostly as a window into whatever Cohen and Bernson might do with their ""other"" groups. Wish works only intermittently on its own terms
column11: but as a sketchbook for future the Fresh & Onlys and Exray's releases
column12:
it's potentially illuminating.

The Narcissist II is the latest reminder that Dean Blunt thinks about pop music very
column3: very differently than you do. It is the first album for Dean Blunt as a solo artist after several releases with his recording partner Inga Copeland (first as Hype Williams and then as Dean Blunt and Inga Copeland)
column4: though Copeland makes appearances here. A remixed and remastered version of a free
column5: 30-minute ""mixtape"" Blunt dropped in February
column6: The Narcissist II is is the least substantial release in a discography that avoids substance by design. A droopy-eyed
column7: unromantic collage of synthesizers
column8: movie dialogue
column9: and baked vocals
column10: The Narcissist II comments on the ephemerality of modern media consumption by being ephemeral itself.

column1: In particular
column2: The Narcissist II replicates a very specific type of listening: hunching over a laptop
column3: dozens of Chrome tabs open
column4: crawling down a Youtube rabbit hole. You know the drill: locate an obscure track
column5: listen to half of it
column6: click on something ""related"" in the right sidebar
column7: pause it
column8: tab over to a Soundcloud page... tab back. It is consumption via distraction: do this often enough and you'll encounter no end of noisy vinyl rips and shitty covers. This is the best metaphor for The Narcissist II: distant
column9: half-heard clips; novel
column10: obscure
column11: and impossible. The samples blur into the original until The Narcissist II is the noisy rip
column12: the shitty homage.

column1: This is why
column2: during the course of The Narcissist II
column3: at some point nearly everything will seem like a sample. The simple chord riff that beautifies the title track
column4: the Nuggets-y guitar riff that populates ""XXX""
column5: the descending organ that buoys ""caught feelings""-- anything could be pilfered
column6: because it all sounds familiar. And then there are the elements that actually are stolen: a single
column7: guttural ""uhnf!"" from Rick Ross
column8: the melody of Biz Markie's ""Just a Friend"" splayed over ""Are You as Good as I Remember""
column9: ongoing movie dialogue sketching a nasty domestic dispute. (The latter being the first time
column10: perhaps
column11: that the menace and violence in Blunt's music has been made explicit.) At the start of ""Direct Line 2""
column12: the harsh
column13: hot sound of a cell phone placed too close to a speaker crackles; I wince every time
column14: and search for my phone on my desk.

column1: The Narcissist II
column2: though
column3: is better at providing an experience than truly memorable music. This is the salty electro-dub of Excepter minus the forgivable nature of generative music
column4: and the flaky
column5: paper mache edits of Ariel Pink minus any obvious affection for the source material. Blunt
column6: always conversant in hip-hop
column7: actually steps up to the mic on the closer
column8: ""Coroner""
column9: on which he tells you that ""That sweet apple-bottom gonna get candied."" Blunt's delivery is flat
column10: ugly
column11: and devoid of braggadocio; for the first time I consider that his taken surname might not be wholly weed-inspired. This isn't great music just like addled Youtube-ing isn't a great way to experience art. Like a lot of free internet mixtapes
column12: The Narcissist II is compelling but ultimately shallow
column13: and shallow is a fault
column14:
even if that's what Blunt was aiming for. Next tab.

Björk has earned a certain amount of deference. She released a string of masterpieces that redefined
column3: on a grand scale
column4: what a ""pop star"" looks and sounds like and how the avant-garde relates to the mainstream
column5: as well as changing our conception of what makes a voice beautiful. Her earlier albums were so good they warped the light around all that has followed; as visible as Björk has become
column6: she's getting harder and harder to see.

column1: Increasingly
column2: her albums reach us as the eye of a storm of extracurricular activities. With all this diversifying
column3: Björk seems on a ""post pop-stardom public intellectual"" tenure track that brings to mind David Byrne. Starting at around 2007's Volta
column4: her new albums began to feel less like events themselves and more like the musical arm of some broader project. This tendency reached its peak on 2011's Biophilia
column5: an album celebrating the wonders of natural science that was also a series of interactive iPad apps that was also a series of shows at the New York Hall of Science. For me
column6: this was where the signal-to-noise ratio in Björk's work finally
column7: definitively tipped. As a series of ideas
column8: Biophilia was glorious -- fascinating to think about
column9: awe-inspiring in its reach. As an album
column10: it was often turgid
column11: frankly boring
column12: and rarely worth leaving on.

column1: The Biophilia remixes you find on Bastards have been commercially available  in other forms for months; they began trickling out shortly after the album was released in a series of 12-inches
column2: released periodically. Bastards represents a capstone on the Biophilia project
column3: but it is also the end of a dizzying breadcrumb-trail of packaging and repackaging. Pity the hardcore Björk fan; like the lifelong Trent Reznor or Radiohead fan
column4: they are faced with an idol whose musical creativity  is only matched by their ingenuity in dreaming up new ways to separate their faithful from disposable income.

column1: As a standalone product
column2: Bastards feels distressingly unnecessary. But if you didn't want to scoop up these remixes piecemeal and were waiting for a handy package
column3: it is here for you. They occasionally offer new angles from the somewhat-blocky Biophilia material; the album's three most dynamic songs
column4: ""Crystalline""
column5: ""Virus""
column6: and ""Mutual Core""
column7: receive the most attention. Hudson Mohawke gives ""Virus"" a gleaming new coat of paint built from of comet-trails synths and massive synthesized horns; it generates the same stonerish awe that anyone who has ever gaped at a planetarium ceiling will recognize.

column1: Death Grips contribute a pair of remixes
column2: one to ""Sacrifice"" and one to ""Thunderbolt""
column3: both of which send a shot of bad-coke energy skittering through the material. ""Sacrifice""'s margins are filled with mortar-round percussion sounds and sampled snuffling-creature noises
column4: while the glacial church-organ dirge of ""Thunderbolt""
column5: is given a shot of adrenaline through that brings to mind a New Order song hyperventilating. These New Puritans strip all the elements out from underneath Björk's astonishing vocal take and surround her with drizzly bits of bass
column6: piano
column7: and a mournfully chanting vocal ensemble.  Omar Souleyman more or less ditches all the elements that make Björk's songs her own and throws Björk's ""Crystalline"" vocals over a piece of his signature dabke music
column8: transforming it into Syrian New Wave.

column1: The best remixes here remind that Björk's voice remains an endlessly malleable instrument
column2: capable of mapping itself onto nearly any context. But apart from Hudson Mohawke's luminous ""Virus""
column3: there are few revelations wrung from this thin material. In 30 tantalizing seconds Matthew Herbert offers us a breath-caught
column4: ecstatic recasting of ""Sacrifice""
column5: in which the song suddenly feels like an outpouring on the order of ""Joga"". But it disappears just as quickly as it hits
column6:
and Bastards does little to counteract the sensation that latter-day Björk records are more fulfilling to read about than listen to. 

"|17386.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/17386-bastards/|5.2|Jayson Greene

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/18474/homepage_large.18664689.jpg|At The BBC|5185.0|Amy Winehouse|['Pop/R&B']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Universal']|2012-12-11 00:00:00|2012|2016-06-11 17:03:41.182417|"

Everybody wants a new Amy Winehouse album as good as Back to Black. It would be nice if
column2: for instance
column3: it turned out that the British soul revivalist had completed or at least sketched out another jewel of a record during the turbulent last four years of her life. But she didn't: there was her collaboration with Mark Ronson on ""Valerie""
column4: and the new song-and-a-half that turned up on last year's Lioness: Hidden Treasures
column5: which was otherwise stocked with alternate versions
column6: earlier outtakes
column7: and covers. A live album that lived up to what she could do at her best would be welcome
column8: too. But her post-Back to Black gigs were relatively few and
column9: by all accounts
column10: mostly pretty dodgy.

column1: So-- perhaps a set of radio recordings
column2: then? That's something
column3: right? At the BBC cherrypicks 48 minutes' worth of tracks from live-on-stage and live-in-the-studio broadcasts. It adds two otherwise unreleased titles to the Winehouse discography: covers of the standards ""I Should Care"" and ""Lullaby of Birdland""
column4: from the latter of which Winehouse borrowed a bit for her own ""October Song"". And it's sequenced in order of her albums' original release rather than in order of the performances-- all the Frank songs
column5: then all the Back to Black songs
column6: then the other stuff. That covers up for the fact that only two tracks here were recorded in the rocky 2007-2011 period: a blaring ""Just Friends"" and a stripped-down ""Love Is a Losing Game""
column7: both from 2009. It also provides an excuse to lead the album with a 2004 take of ""Know You Now"" that's a marked improvement on the Frank recording.

column1: Winehouse always had a tendency to over sing on stage
column2: though. Especially when she had a big audience to project toward
column3: it was too easy for her to overindulge in the vocal tics-- the slurred consonants
column4: the hyper-articulated melisma
column5: the extravagant ornaments
column6: the imitations of Billie Holiday's timbre-- that she could restrain on her better studio recordings
column7: and it often led her to mangle her own lyrics. (She pronounces the final word of ""F%#k Me Pumps"" here as ""pwuuuups."") The most effective performances here are the most intimate ones
column8: especially on the attached DVD-- an hour-long documentary built around a 22-minute set filmed shortly after the release of Back to Black
column9: just Winehouse
column10: a guitarist and a bassist playing inside a little Irish church.

column1: The versions of Winehouse's repertoire that turn up on At the BBC's audio disc
column2: though
column3: are almost all sloppier than their studio counterparts
column4: and she rarely manages to reveal anything we didn't already know about her songs. And every time she garbles a phrase or pointedly mentions her vices
column5: it's a stinging reminder that she spent the better part of her too-brief career making her audience complicit in her self-destruction. This set isn't devoid of interest
column6: but it's not in any way another great Amy Winehouse album
column7:
or even another good one. We're never going to get that.

"|17295.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/17295-at-the-bbc/|3.1|Douglas Wolk

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/18632/homepage_large.bd6c4b4c.jpg|Life Ain't No Joke|30216.0|Lil Durk|['Rap']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Def Jam']|2012-12-11 00:00:00|2012|2016-06-11 17:03:41.750985|"

Grouping artists into scenes makes it easier for us all to digest
column2: discuss
column3: and categorize music. But of course
column4: there is a downside for the artists in question. Even those in tightly knit communities rarely sound exactly alike or make music about exactly the same thing
column5: or in the exact same way. Chicago's drill scene is no different-- there are artists there
column6: even young ones
column7: making rap music unlike the hollowed-out rattle of Chief Keef and Lil Reese. One of them is Lil Durk
column8: a Chicago teen and GBE associate
column9: who is one of the the city's forgotten figures and who released his second mixtape of the year
column10: Life Ain't No Joke
column11: this fall.

column1: Part of the reason why Durk has been overlooked is because he spent parts of 2012 in prison right as Chicago's rap scene really started to explode. Locally
column2: Durk has long been recognized -- ""L's Anthem""
column3: his single from earlier this year
column4: was one of the biggest songs in the city. But on a national level he lags behind compatriots Chief Keef and Lil Reese
column5: though maybe that's a good thing for Durk
column6: as Keef and Reese remain toxic figures to many. Durk doesn't much sound like either guy; instead
column7: he leans heavily on one under-discussed aspect of drill music: Autotune
column8: and drowning music in it.

column1: People thought Autotune was going to go away (or at least Jay-Z did)
column2: but Future's ascendance has given it as strong a place in contemporary rap as its just about ever had. The Autotune of the drill scene
column3: though
column4: is of a different nature-- its birthplace is in the stoned
column5: aimless warbling of Soulja Boy (one of the earliest non-local Keef collaborators) and Lil Wayne before him. A good portion of Life Ain't No Joke (tracks like ""Ryder"" and ""Days of Our Lives"") finds Durk dunking what would be typical drill music into a vat of Autotune to no real positive outcome-- as an effect used with abandon here it grates without purpose.

column1: Which isn't to say that Durk's Autotune fixation is a complete distraction. ""Molly Girl"" seems like it should be a throwaway track
column2: but instead it's one of the tape's clear highlights. It's one of the few songs where Durk goes full pop
column3: which is surprising considering that his flirtations with singing seem to indicate that he's aiming more for a traditional modern crossover than the rest of his peers. But the track has a deceptively intricate hook that is still plainly enjoyable and it's easy to picture it bubbling up to radio. ""Right Here"" is more of a rap song
column4: but one where Durk's use of Autotune amplifies the song's anthem status instead of detracting from it.

column1: The absolute most promising joint
column2: though
column3: is ""52 Barz (Intro)""
column4: a jittery track that sees Durk rapping for three minutes straight. It has a confessional bent but is enlivened by a gleeful arrogance and unflinching confidence
column5: which is roughly the same formula that has turned Meek Mill into one of rap's most beloved new artists. The song recalls Durk's earlier single ""I Get Paid""
column6: a straight party track whose beat had roots in Chicago footwork but which would slot perfectly next to any Meek banger like ""House Party."" Durk may not turn out to be Meek and he may not even have that kind of art in mind
column7: but it seems like the best case scenario for him would be evolving into the same type of artist.

column1: All that is still in the distance
column2: at least we should hope. Meek
column3: for instance
column4:
was dozens of mixtapes and a handful of years into the game before getting his shot with Rick Ross. Durk has talent-- he has an ear for pop tracks and can spit bars when we wants to. But whether or not he'll be able to figure it all out before the rap game's focus shifts elsewhere is entirely an open question.

"|17441.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/17441-life-aint-no-joke/|6.5|Jordan Sargent

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/18594/homepage_large.95205b0b.jpg|Wild Songs|30865.0|Estasy|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Acéphale']|2012-12-11 00:00:00|2012|2016-06-11 17:03:42.382263|"

Estasy is the project of Emiliano Maggi
column2: an Italian singer/songwriter who has spent the last couple of years releasing low-key CD-Rs and collaborating with artists and filmmakers in Rome. A lot of the time his live performances with other artists
column3: well-documented on YouTube
column4: are set to spooky visuals
column5: and in those that aren't Maggi wears quite frightening masks. Sure
column6: quite a bit of that does sound like the sort of standard gimmickry rife in 2012
column7: but there's something about Emiliano Maggi's music that feels genuinely otherworldly and unusual.

column1: Maggi's vocal plays a starring role in that strangeness on his debut album
column2: Wild Songs. His high-pitched
column3: androgynous sounding voice is technically a coloratura soprano-- most often a range delivered by female opera singers. In opera
column4: the coloratura soprano is characterised not just by the dizzying heights of their top notes
column5: but by their technical agility too. While Maggi seems a way off performing at classical standard
column6: on songs like ""Wonder""
column7: his vocal skips and swoops ornately. Though quite different in some aspects
column8: Maggi's voice also calls to mind the likes of Sigur Rós' Jonsi or new Acéphale label-mate Tom Krell's early releases as How to Dress Well.

column1: The recordings themselves also share something in common with HtDW's ghostly first demos. Maggi's naturalistic takes on Wild Songs are lo-fi and weave in field recordings as part of the scene. Those far-off touches of real atmosphere and places really help ground Wild Songs. Among the strangeness
column2: those moments pull you back to reality: moments like at the end of ""It's a Hard World for Little Things"" when the sound of kindling snapping in a fire slowly fades up in the mix
column3: or the howling pack of dogs that accompany Maggi on ""Kaspar"".

column1: Compared with the sparseness of the rest of Estasy's material
column2: ""Locus Solus"" and ""Wild Wants"" feel almost maximalist. On both tracks
column3: electronic beats help to anchor Maggi's otherwise untethered melodies: the playful beat of the former allows his subtle melodies to feel almost whimsical
column4: but the latter is elevated by drums to become perhaps the most intense moment on the whole record. It feels like a yearning
column5: natural highlight of the set
column6: as multi-tracked vocals swoop around one another with ease and grace.

column1: Wild Songs is an apt title for Estasy's first record. Many of these songs feel like barely captured ideas
column2: almost like happy accidents of rolling tape. Maggi's voice is the star
column3: capable of inspiring genuine strangeness. Its undiluted innateness feels natural among the production's field recording feel. That said
column4: Wild Songs is very rough and ready. At its best it can be utterly startling
column5:
but so far Maggi's Estasy project feels more intriguing than truly beguiling.

"|17416.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/17416-wild-songs/|6.9|Hari Ashurst

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/18557/homepage_large.608d1eea.jpg|Real Colors of the Physical World|10502.0|Raglani|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Editions Mego']|2012-12-11 00:00:00|2012|2016-06-11 17:03:42.932874|"

There's so much happening on Real Colors of the Physical World that absorbing it all might be impossible. In Joseph Raglani's hectic mix
column2: synths ripple in overlapping circles
column3: melodies dive into longer tones
column4: beats morph from pin pricks into plunges
column5: and churning static melts into what sounds like a funk band jamming underwater. His hyperactive sound doesn't just encourage repeat listens-- it makes you wonder if you could ever hear it the same way twice.

column1: Making music sound busy isn't unique
column2: especially when it's electronic; nor is it a guarantee of quality. But even though Raglani's approach has precedents
column3: his knack for mixing and matching sounds
column4: through wavy dissolves
column5: liquefied cuts
column6: and coursing turns
column7: is distinct. In a sense
column8: he's equal parts musician and DJ-- attentive enough to sonic detail that he avoids mere pastiche
column9: but restless enough that his insistence on adding new ideas injects everything with constant energy.

column1: Part of why Real Colors feels so busy is that its first two tracks last over 20 minutes each
column2: and they unfurl like eventful journeys. Apparently portions were designed separately
column3: since the track list includes parenthetical subtitles. Maybe if Raglani had added gaps of silence in between
column4: Real Colors would be easier to digest-- but it wouldn't be as interesting
column5: or as enjoyable. Because as fascinating as the individual passages are
column6: the fissions between them are even more striking.

column1: Examples abound. I'm partial to a section early in opener ""Fog of Interruption"" where a blasting synth crumbles into distant transmissions
column2: then rises from the dead in the form of shiny
column3: laser-like reflections. Even better is a passage in the following track
column4: ""Terrain of Antiquity""
column5: wherein a chaotic mass of lighting-bolt synths slowly turns into a vocoder-like melody that recalls the Residents at their most beatific.

column1: There are echoes of other antecedents throughout
column2: particularly the strain of German experimentation known as Kosmiche Musik. But where Raglani's last widely-distributed release
column3: 2008's Of Sirens Born
column4: felt like a synthesis of his influences
column5: Real Colors bears his own stamp more clearly. That comes across most in its endless pulse
column6: which eternally bubbles and often threatens to burst. His loops feel solid enough to last forever
column7: but never settled or relaxed. Instead
column8: Raglani is always as interested in what his sounds could do next as what they're currently doing.

column1: The final two tracks on Real Colors are significantly shorter-- each lasts just a bit over five minutes-- and less varied than the first two. Where their predecessors were like aural colleges
column2: these pieces are more conventionally song-like. Each begins with an arpeggiated loop that passes through modifications in scale and volume
column3: creating a kind of verse-chorus pattern. ""The Exploded View"" in particular is a bona-fide song
column4: with haunting vocals that follow the synths through cycles of tension and release.

column1: Despite the shift toward contained structure
column2: Raglani makes the second half of the album as restless as its first. Perhaps this is a cleverly-designed after-effect-- once you're immersed in his busy environment
column3: even simple synths can sound ripe with potential. Maybe it's the basic urgency he gives his loops
column4: a skill he's recently honed with Mike Pollard in the excellent duo Bryter Layter. Whatever the reason
column5:
Real Colors of the Physical World demonstrates the beguiling versatility of Joseph Raglani's sound-crafting skills.

"|17378.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/17378-real-colors-of-the-physical-world/|7.7|Marc Masters

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/18473/homepage_large.73cfb6fc.jpg|Vicious Lies and Dangerous Rumors|7749.0|Big Boi|['Rap']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Island Def Jam']|2012-12-10 00:00:00|2012|2016-06-11 17:03:44.540286|"

Big Boi is known for his voracious
column2: omnivorous listening habits and willingness to abandon his most successful musical formulas. Since he's spent the last few years sharing festival stages with indie rock and electronic acts
column3: it makes some sense that he might want to make a record influenced by indie rock and electronic music. So here on his second proper solo album
column4: he's exchanged the deep
column5: dirty funk of 2010's Sir Lucious Left Foot: The Son of Chico Dusty and his half of OutKast's nearly decade-old double solo LP Speakerboxxx/The Love Below for collaborations with artists like Phantogram
column6: Wavves
column7: and Little Dragon.

column1: Vicious Lies and Dangerous Rumors is on the one hand a genre-busting statement of artistic restlessness but it's also a mess. You can try looking at it from a few different angles: as an outgrowth of rap's artsy ambitions
column2: a compilation of indietronic-rap fusion tied together by one voice
column3: or even simply as the new Big Boi record. But each approach carries its own particular set of frustrations when confronted with the 17-track whole.

column1: Some of its weakest moments are actually the ones with the most potential. Teaming up with A$AP Rocky and Phantogram on ""Lines""
column2: for instance
column3: makes good sense on paper. Rocky's among the most successful of the current crop of upstart boundary-pushing rappers and Phantogram (who contribute to three of the album's tracks) have demonstrated an ability to infuse traditional pop structures with a sonically adventurous spirit. But the finished product refuses to cohere into the quasi-ambient electro-pop-rap gestalt the line-up promises. The rappers' verses and Sarah Barthel's breathy
column4: multi-tracked choruses basically stand politely next to each other without interacting in any meaningful way.

column1: Other questionable team-ups fare much worse
column2: like the lineup of Big Boi
column3: pop-rapper B.o.B.
column4: and snotty surf-pop savant Nathan Williams of Wavves on ""Shoes for Running"". The terminally schlocky B.o.B. comes at this potentially challenging collaboration with the same staunchly middle of the road approach he takes to everything
column5: while Williams yelps his way through a hook that would be embarrassingly twee even if it wasn't presented in the context of a rap record. Imagine a weak
column6: more self-consciously indie-fied song from the Judgement Night soundtrack and you're getting there.

column1: The album's saving grace is Big Boi. No matter what setting you place him in
column2: he remains one of the most dextrous
column3: technically capable
column4: and thoroughly entertaining figures in hip-hop. He's still unapologetically lecherous
column5: still styling all over less-smooth fools
column6: still repping for the Dungeon Family and OutKast. (Although the latter trait is starting to seem cruel considering how many people are still holding out hope for a proper sequel to Stankonia and how much more unlikely that possibility seems with every passing year.) He's also still apparently unable to phone in a half-assed verse no matter the circumstances
column7: so at least the flimsiest songs on Vicious Lies still has his performance holding them up
column8: even if there's nothing else helping out.

column1: A few tracks do live up to their potential
column2: and to Big Boi's ambitious vision in general. ""In the A"" brings him together with T.I. and Ludacris over a noisy
column3: chaotic funk beat dripping with wah-wah guitar
column4: siren-like synths
column5: and stripper-pole drums that's got enough of the familiar Big Boi energy to bring its differences into compelling focus. (T.I. and Luda both living up to their habit of delivering their strongest material in cameos on other artists' tracks helps as well.) And the deeply louche ""Raspberries"" upholds Big Boi's reputation for making sex music that sounds like it's being beamed in from several years into the future.

column1: He also clicks with Swedish electro-pop group Little Dragon
column2: who appear on three tracks. ""Descending"" is sweetly sad and atmospheric
column3: with Big Boi and Little Dragon vocalist Yukimi Nagano trading verses over a delicate fingerpicked guitar and a reverb-laden minimalist bit of drum programming straight out of a Prince slow jam. But on ""Higher Res"" and ""Thom Pettie""-- maybe the best cut on the album-- the group shows a surprising facility for producing the kind of booming
column4: nasty beats that suit Big Boi the best. Out of the lengthy list of collaborators on the disappointing Vicious Lies
column5:
they're the only ones he should hit up the next time he goes in to record.

"|17294.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/17294-vicious-lies-and-dangerous-rumors/|6.1|Miles Raymer

column1: 0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/18607/homepage_large.65bd19b6.jpg|Lucifer in Dub|29484.0|Peaking Lights|['Rock'
column2:
'Experimental']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Mexican Summer']|2012-12-10 00:00:00|2012|2016-06-11 17:03:45.088063|"

Given their fondness for rhythmic repetition
column3: reverberating vocals
column4: watery ambience
column5: and analog synths
column6: matrimonial L.A. neo-psych duo Peaking Lights are about as close as you can get to a dub act without actually being a dub act. But where the band's 2012 release
column7: Lucifer
column8: saw that island influence fused into other strains of cosmic head-trip music (60s psychedelia
column9: Krautrock
column10: shoegaze)
column11: this follow-up companion piece serves to make the implicit explicit. No false advertising here: Lucifer in Dub does exactly what it says it's going to do
column12: with Aaron Coyes re-engineering Indra Dunis' dreamy pop melodies into echo-plexed incantations while greatly amplifying the percussive clatter we imagined to be percolating beneath the hypnotic haze. But this remix album proves so faithful to its antecedent that it verges on the redundant.

column1: Featuring cheekily titled revisions of six Lucifer songs (while forsaking the album's brief bookend tracks)
column2: Lucifer in Dub is more a protraction of its predecessor than a radical reworking. Had the band continued to ride out the tropical grooves of originals ""Cosmic Tides""
column3: ""Live Love""
column4: or ""Midnight (In the Valley of Shadows)"" for another seven minutes
column5: the songs probably would've naturally mutated into what we hear on their equivalents
column6: ""Cosmic Dub""
column7: ""Live Dub""
column8: and ""Midnight Dub""
column9: which closely resemble their respective source tracks in both feel and form
column10: albeit with added textural freakiness and a more aggressive energy bleeding into the productions. But beyond these gradual
column11: subtle enhancements
column12: Lucifer in Dub doesn't afford us much opportunity to see these songs in a new light-- it essentially renders what was already a trippy
column13: amorphous album slightly more trippy and amorphous. Really
column14: the closest this set comes to going off the hook is when the ""Beautiful Son"" redux (""Beautiful Dub"") announces itself with the now antiquated
column15: staccato tone of a phone that needs to be placed back on its receiver.

column1: The musical exploitation of household items is a common dub device
column2: but on Lucifer in Dub
column3: the aforementioned phone effect or the doorbell ringing throughout ""Lo Dub High Dub"" provide a novel means for Coyes and Dunis to obliquely reference the theme of domestic bliss that runs through Lucifer. A little more of that abstract logic could've gone a long way in making Lucifer in Dub a more distinct
column4: stand-alone piece. As it stands
column5: the ideal way to experience this record is to make a playlist pairing off its tracks with their original counterparts
column6: so that each Lucifer song essentially dissolves into its own distended
column7: dubbed-out coda. In its most transfixing moments
column8: Lucifer emitted the sort of soothing
column9: mesmerizing sound that you wish could go on forever-- at the very least
column10:
Lucifer in Dub affords us a few more minutes in the service of that ideal.

"|17429.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/17429-lucifer-in-dub/|6.6|Stuart Berman

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/18608/homepage_large.3e999a79.jpg|The Jazz Workshop Concerts 1964–65|13106.0|Charles Mingus|['Jazz']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Mosaic']|2012-12-10 00:00:00|2012|2016-06-11 17:03:45.728812|"

In one sense
column2: The Jazz Workshop Concerts 1964–65
column3: a limited-edition seven-disc box set
column4: reiterates a well-established fact: The sextet that Charles Mingus took on tour in 1964 belongs on the short list of all-time-great jazz groups. The bassist/leader was the mastermind
column5: but the star was Eric Dolphy
column6: a virtuosic
column7: modernist-minded improviser on saxophone
column8: bass clarinet
column9: and flute
column10: who was mere months from death due to undiagnosed diabetes at the time of the shows documented here. Collectors know this band well
column11: through various live recordings made in the spring of 64
column12: including a film of the April 12th Oslo show and an exemplary 2007 double-CD set
column13: Cornell 1964. The first four discs of The Jazz Workshop Concerts-- which compiles five good-to-great-sounding full-show recordings from Mingus's personal archive
column14: three never before issued in their entirety-- present two more shows from this run: April 4 at Town Hall in New York (excerpted on a 1964 LP issued by Mingus's Jazz Workshop label) and April 10 at the Concertgebouw in Amsterdam (released on a limited-edition French LP in 1985). Like every showing by the 64 Mingus sextet
column15: these are outstanding performances
column16: but whether you're craving additional versions of a familiar set list depends entirely on your level of fandom. (Mosaic
column17: the label behind The Jazz Workshop Concerts
column18: is a hallowed name among jazz completists; full disclosure: I contributed liner notes to a 2010 Mosaic box focused on avant-garde innovator Henry Threadgill.)

column1: But this set
column2: a commemoration of Mingus's 90th birthday anniversary this past April
column3: also contains assorted other treasures
column4: at least one of which-- a performance from May 1965
column5: less than half of which originally came out on a rare Mingus-released LP called My Favorite Quintet-- feels like its own landmark. It's hard to beat the '64 band
column6: but during the year and a half following Dolphy's death
column7: Mingus didn't let that tragedy slow him down. We hear him here at consecutive Monterey Jazz Festivals (September '64 and '65) and at the May '65 show
column8: presenting ambitious
column9: socially engaged
column10: composer-centric sets. One of The Jazz Workshop Concerts' key pleasures is contrasting the familiar fireworks of the '64 working band with the fascinating odds and ends that follow.

column1: This set is not Mingus 101. If you don't own staples such as Mingus Ah Um
column2: Charles Mingus Presents Charles Mingus
column3: and The Black Saint and the Sinner Lady
column4: The Jazz Workshop Concerts will likely be too specific for your needs. But for listeners interested in taking a long
column5: hard look at a prolific and tumultuous period in this great composer's life
column6: it's well worth the plunge.

column1: Hearing the '64 sextet material found here
column2: it's hard not to focus on the tragedy of Dolphy's impending demise. The multi-instrumental marvel was on an incredible roll that year
column3: having found time to record his own magnum opus
column4: Out to Lunch!
column5: and appear on Point of Departure
column6: a masterpiece by the enigmatic pianist Andrew Hill
column7: amid his commitments to Mingus. But The Jazz Workshop Concerts affords the chance to reassess this lopsided view of the band. It was an incredibly deep group
column8: with each of the other musicians providing a unique texture: the hard-bop brawn of tenor saxist Clifford Jordan
column9: the gentle lyricism of trumpeter Johnny Coles
column10: the prismatic
column11: good-humored splendor of pianist Jaki Byard
column12: the devilishly mutable pulse of drummer Dannie Richmond
column13: and Mingus's own nimble majesty on bass.

column1: Mingus' spring '64 setlists
column2: favoring elastic forms with tons of solo space
column3: seem designed to flatter his sidemen. This is especially evident on the 21-minute Amsterdam version of the Charlie Parker tribute ""Parkeriana""
column4: during which Mingus yanks the rhythm section out from under each soloist in turn. Byard uses his break to bust into one of his patented stride-style jaunts
column5: sounding like an overdriven player piano. Later
column6: Dolphy swoops and yelps in the foreground as Jordan and Coles calmly quote the melody of the Dizzy Gillespie–Frank Paparelli bebop classic ""A Night in Tunisia""
column7: which Mingus had played with Parker and Gillespie at a famed 1953 gig at Toronto's Massey Hall. Moments such as this illustrate one of Mingus's chief imperatives as a bandleader: Honor the past but interrogate it
column8: juxtapose it with the sound of now.

column1: If ""Parkeriana"" and other fixtures of the '64 sets favor a loose
column2: jammy feel
column3: the centerpiece of these shows
column4: ""Meditations on Integration
column5: aims for a very different mood. The Jazz Workshop Concerts features three versions of this sprawling suite
column6: but the one to focus on is the 27-minute Town Hall rendition. This performance
column7: which Mingus dubbed ""Praying with Eric"" on its initial release
column8: is straight-up phenomenal. It isn't just the highlight of the box; it's one of the crown jewels in the Mingus discography. The piece reflected Mingus's appropriately grim view of the contemporary African-American condition-- the only difference between the situation in the South and the Holocaust
column9: Mingus tells the Town Hall audience
column10: being that ""they don't have gas chambers and hot stoves to cook us in yet""-- and that gravity is on full display in the music. Like The Black Saint and the Sinner Lady
column11: it's a programmatic compositional triumph that transcends genre.

column1: Heard after this staggering statement
column2: the '64 Monterey Jazz Festival performance on disc 5
column3: which earned rave reviews at the time
column4: feels comparatively tame. Recorded three months after Dolphy's death
column5: it finds Mingus
column6: Byard
column7: and Richmond regrouping in the company of an alternate frontline-- altoist Charles McPherson
column8: tenorist John Handy and trumpeter Lonnie Hillyer-- and running through familiar material: a medley of pieces by Mingus's idol
column9: Duke Ellington
column10: and ""Orange Was the Color of Her Dress
column11: Then Blue Silk""
column12: a mainstay of the prior sextet's repertoire. There's also a quasi-orchestral version of ""Meditations on Integration"" here
column13: which augments the core band with extra reeds and brass
column14: but even with the added manpower
column15: it can't muster the soul-shaking drama of the Town Hall rendition.

column1: Fortunately
column2: the 1965 material on The Jazz Workshop Concerts-- the My Favorite Quintet performance
column3: also with McPherson and Hillyer
column4: and a brass-heavy octet appearance at that year's Monterey festival-- finds Mingus making conscious forward strides. Old standbys show up in these sets but several of the works are rarities
column5: either duplicated only on a 2006 archival release
column6: At UCLA 1965
column7: or exclusive to this box. ""They Trespass the Land of the Sacred Sioux"" affords a vivid look at the underrated McPherson
column8: who took on the daunting task of replacing Dolphy in the alto-sax role. McPherson plays beautifully on this episodic elegy
column9: soloing first in tandem with flugelhorn player Jimmy Owens and then
column10: at Mingus's urging (""Alto! Alto!"")
column11: alone. He hints at his predecessor's keening urgency
column12: while sanding down the spiky edges and adding a touch of old-school romance.

column1: As strong as the September '65 Monterey performance is
column2: My Favorite Quintet (split between discs six and seven) is better. Recorded in Minneapolis in May of '65
column3: this great-sounding document shows how the McPherson/Hillyer group carved out its own identity
column4: distinct from the Dolphy/Jordan/Coles band. The opening track
column5: a long
column6: leisurely rendition of ""So Long Eric""
column7: finds Mingus
column8: Richmond and Byard having a blast prodding Hillyer with dropouts
column9: crescendos
column10: and head-spinning tempo changes
column11: as McPherson contributes big-band-style riffs in the background. The remainder of the concert covers a ton of ground. There's a charmingly retro take on the 1934 standard ""Cocktails for Two""
column12: where McPherson nods to the signature vibrato of New Orleans jazz great Sidney Bechet; an unsettling spoken-word protest piece (""A Lonely Day in Selma
column13: Alabama
column14: which segues into the timeless ""Freedom""); a gem of a Mingus piano solo
column15: harking back to the 1963 LP Mingus Plays Piano; a consummately relaxed ""Themeless Blues"" that starts with a slapsticky Mingus/Hillyer duet; and a super-tight sprint through ""Copa City Titty
column16: which appears on other Mingus records as ""O.P.""-- a nod to the bassist Oscar Pettiford. (Mingus helpfully informs the audience that ""titty"" was once slang for ""gig
column17: and has ""nothing to do with mammaries."")

column1: The stage banter is mostly priceless. Near the end of the show
column2: Mingus asks the audience to boycott his high-profile releases on Columbia
column3: Atlantic
column4: and Impulse
column5: labels which he claims have failed to pay him ample royalties. (He okays RCA Victor exclusively
column6: quipping
column7: ""I imagine
column8: because they make enough money with the atomic bomb
column9: that they don't have to worry about cheating jazz musicians."") Introducing ""Bird Preamble
column10: another Charlie Parker tribute
column11: Mingus takes a shot at the then-thriving free-jazz movement: ""This is to sum up an era that some people think they have summed up
column12: [because] they call themselves 'avant-garde.' And I've found that the avant-garde cannot play Bird yet."" As an illustration of the Mingus temperament
column13: both musical and philosophical
column14: the Minneapolis recording is essential.

column1: A hotly contested and sometimes borderline-farcical election year feels like a good time to revisit Charles Mingus' work. He sought to entertain without pandering
column2: to educate without preaching
column3: to mingle the past and present of his art form in alchemical ways. The Jazz Workshop Concerts 1964–65 is too focused to serve as a Mingus primer
column4: but it does illustrate these core facets of his aesthetic by zeroing in on a key transitional phase. Just as importantly
column5: it memorializes late
column6: great radicals such as Eric Dolphy and Jaki Byard
column7: while drawing attention to Charles McPherson
column8:
an undervalued veteran still with us. Spend good time with these seven discs and Mingus's multifarious genius snaps into crisp focus.

Container's Ren Schofield makes techno
column2: but he doesn't make techno like Carl Craig
column3: Richie Hawtin
column4: or Marcel Dettman. Instead
column5: he's one of a growing number of noise and experimental artists to discover that loud
column6: hirsute
column7: pulsing beats are a potent way to disorient listeners. Those beats
column8: mixed with a noisenik's abandon
column9: can unearth sound-worlds trad-y producers miss. For instance

column13: features an obscene
column14: high-pitch frequency that sounds a lot like a bird's chirp. Carl Craig never disturbs my dog.

column1: Schofield's part of a sonic dialogue that includes American labels like Future Times
column2: Spectrum Spools
column3: and L.I.E.S. (Long Island Electrical System) that help bridge the gap between noise and dance. Combine that with a renewed interest in analog gear and performance by a generation of European DJs-- Blawan

column1: The pictures in the article linked above
column2: coupled with LP
column3: manage to say something that hundreds of frankly not-that-different-in-the-grand-scheme-of-things records from Berlin and London don't: that techno can be sloppy
column4: unordered
column5: punk
column6: and
column7: above all
column8: casual. That it can have fuck-all to do with geometry and design and clubbing until 8 a.m. the next morning. (Schofield's live sets are reportedly short
column9: intense
column10: and shrill.) Precious
column11: homey metaphors are too easy to apply to LP
column12: so take your pick: lumpy mashed potatoes
column13: a wobbly stool
column14: an askance picture frame.

column1: The best part about LP
column2: though
column3: is that it isn't precious at all. It's wily and sharp and thoughtfully brief. Schofield doesn't bother too much with traditional melodies and basslines
column4: but he's more orderly than peers like Frak (true weirdos) or Pete Swanson (a nihilist in comparison). ""Perforate"" actually sounds quite a bit like Drexciya
column5: both in its curt
column6: iridescent palpitations and its blank-stare vocal repetitions: ""Per/for/ate...Per/for/ate."" Schofield uses up 80% of applicable adjectives just naming his songs: ""Dissolve""
column7: ""Rattler""
column8: ""Dripping"". They're tags that any techno beginner would think up: succinct
column9: memorable
column10: and descriptive. The tracks build
column11: but not for too long
column12: and avoid snowballing into big noisy messes. The exception is the closing track
column13: ""Refract""
column14: which unleashes a spanking
column15: double-time rhythmic blast that will absolutely cane your speakers.

column1: Schofield
column2: of course
column3: is not really exploring frequencies or structures heretofore unknown to techno. Above all else
column4: Schofield offers an outsider's perspective
column5: and it's one he's not afraid to lean on in deference to a genre's monolithic history. LP is efficient
column6: prickly
column7: and noticeable
column8: or not much like modern techno at all. That he is operating like this at the same time many others are is a boon
column9: for us
column10:
so long as he keeps his blinders on.

The Brighton-based Cold Pumas didn't play their first live shows until a year after they formed in Exeter in 2008
column4: and between then and now
column5: they've released just three of their own singles in addition to two splits-- one with Male Bonding
column6: the other with Women
column7: Fair Ohs
column8: and Friendo-- and toured to a moderate degree. It's not that they're unambitious: Over those four years
column9: frontman Dan Reeves and brothers Oliver and Patrick Fisher have worked on mastering and refining the seam of fluid but bristling
column10: colorless post-punk they share with Women
column11: which manifests on their debut album
column12: Persistent Malaise. But while perfecting the kind of jam that could bowl along forever with scree and smoke in its wake
column13: things outside the band inevitably fell apart.

column1: In an interview with the band Sauna Youth
column2: Patrick confessed that ""the lyrical directness of our album unfortunately follows the thematic focus of Bon Iver's debut (minus the cabin)."" Fisher's intense heartbreak called for more thorough lyrical treatment than the shallow vagaries he had lent to their past work. On Persistent Malaise
column3: his lines are meticulously structured
column4: excavating old times so that he might torture himself by staring clean at them. ""Our past seems angled to support what has bloomed/ But pillow talk
column5: it should not be exhumed/ For what I whispered
column6: I would never recoup/ I'm not so bitter
column7: just a crystalline loop
column8: he yelps on ""Fog Cutter""
column9: over a thick
column10: smoggy riff that's perpetually climbing peaks
column11: sounding at its best like a Cryptograms offcut.

column1: The album toes the line between tension and ambience
column2: exploring the strain inherent in stasis. The siren-like guitar interplay of ""Sherry Island"" is overshot with a near-euphoric wave of warm drone
column3: while Fisher's lyrics chronicle a Halloween party where the guests' obfuscating masks only serve to make him realize how distant he was from them in the first place. ""Variety Lights"" is the album's only instrumental
column4: ticking between dank and trebly like two hypnotic shades of an animated .gif. On ""This Modernist Crown""
column5: Fisher is subject to several layers of emotional and physical paralysis-- ""I wake up tired for still I'm dreaming of you""-- as a warped
column6: queasy cloud of feedback gives way to  the record's only guitar solo
column7: and a rare bout of smashing
column8: all-out aggression.

column1: While emotional inertia forms the backbone of Persistent Malaise
column2: Cold Pumas' debut is also a testament to honing one's craft before presenting it to the world. Its sureness and subtlety say more than a few gauche early pullquotes
column3: and although Cold Pumas undoubtedly won't sound the same forever
column4:
their commitment to consistency has already served them admirably.

Steven Ellison
column2: aka Flying Lotus
column3: is an obsessive
column4: opinionated hip-hop fan who's never quite sure how his own music fits in. As he explained to Pitchfork last year
column5: ""I feel like I'm hip-hop's fucking weird step-child and they don't want to see me."" When talking about Lil Wayne in an earlier interview
column6: he asked for some impromptu A&R help: ""I just want to get on a mixtape… You know him? Hook it up
column7: man!"" Later
column8: Big Sean's state-of-the-art
column9: big-money solo record inspired him to tweet
column10: ""Oh rap.. You used to be such a beautiful bitch
column11: now look at you.. Look at you!"" Poor guy couldn't even get it together with a relatively accessible dude like <a href=""http://pitchfork.com/artists/29179-tyler-the-creator/"">Tyler
column12: the Creator and he lives in the same city: ""I don't know what it is
column13: but they ain't fucking kicking my door down."" His candor has been refreshing and also frustrating: This isn't some chump using Soundcloud comments to drop links to his beat tapes. What's stopping him from actually making a Flying Lotus hip-hop record?

column1: In a sense
column2: we still don't know. The previously anonymous rap entity Captain Murphy has since been revealed as Steven Ellison
column3: but the project doesn't extend the aesthetic of Flying Lotus albums into the rap realm. Instead
column4: it's lowbrow
column5: heavy-lidded
column6: and charmingly giddy about its love for all things Wu-Tang
column7: Odd Future
column8: and Stones Throw. If you can get past the fact that it doesn't change the game or even try to

column1: While Captain Murphy will be seen as a side project
column2: it still feels like the product of a FlyLo-level work ethic. But the process is inverted: Los Angeles
column3: Cosmogramma and Until the Quiet Comes each constitute 45 or so minutes of impossibly dense music delivered as a single piece meant to be consumed in one sitting. Duality is far more even-keeled and is presented as a sum of easily segmented
column4: constituent parts. The deluxe mixtape changes artwork with every track
column5: enhancing its interactive
column6: Viewfinder-like feel.

column1: Ellison handles the majority of the production
column2: along with Brainfeeder associates like Teebs and Samiyam
column3: who forego the astral jazz and to dig in the same crates where Madlib and Dilla got their fingers dusty. If a sample sounded a little too vigorous for beanbag chair repose
column4: it didn't make the cut. Everything's subsumed under such a thick cloud of weed smoke that even higher profile guests like Just Blaze and Earl Sweatshirt simply take their rightful place in the puff-puff-pass procedure.

column1: Much of Duality's initial intrigue lies in Ellison's rapping; you can't help wondering what he sounds like and what he's going to rap about now that he's finally decided to take the mic. It's filled with morally casual lines like ""It's getting real late now
column2: delivery DiGiorno/ Either fuck a fat bitch or I'mma settle for this porno"" and couplets that conflate blowjob jokes with ""Dragonball Z"" references like a latter day Bobby Digital.

column1: This aspect gave credence to the persistent rumor that Captain Murphy was actually Tyler
column2: the Creator going incognito in his laziest publicity stunt yet (yes
column3: even more so than Young Nigga). And yes
column4: the most common vocal filter Ellison employs makes him sound almost exactly like Tyler. It's particularly apparent when Ellison stammers through multi-syllable thickets of softcore shock tactics such as ""Bitches love it when I'm fuckin' rough and stuff/ Hate to see me drunk walkin' like I'm Snuffleufagus
column5: and ""Captain known to choke a blonde/ Does she like it?/ No doubt even though she cryin'/ Oh wow
column6: simmer down I only kinda mean it.""

column1: But with hindsight
column2: you can certainly see Ellison leaving a breadcrumb trail to his true identity. On ""Children of the Atom""
column3: he snarls ""Two Grammys on my wishlist/ I blame it on my fans
column4: a likely nod at his rant against being shut out for Cosmogramma. One of his introductory tracks
column5: ""Between Friends""
column6: ends with a slightly-skewed Brainfeeder shout-out
column7: and on ""The Killing Joke""
column8: he boasts ""Labels tryin' to sign me/ Speculating my identity/ Good luck
column9: you'll never find me."" This is one of the most respected beatmakers and label heads out there

column1: While the relentlessly active pitch-shifting and stereo panning is meant to render Ellison as some kind of hallucinogenic voice projection
column2: Duality proves that he's the best rapper on his own label. Check the motormouthed
column3: Busta Rhymes-style onomatopoeia on ""Mighty Morphin Foreskin"" or ""Drive Thru""
column4: which seems modeled after Das Racist's loopy ""People Are Strange"". His voice is constantly in motion and the lyrics are subtly rife with clever wordplay
column5: incidental sound effects
column6: and bawdy jokes. In fact
column7: it's only when conventionally personified Brainfeeder rappers like Jeremiah Jae and Azizi Gibson show up that Duality feels pedestrian.

column1: That is
column2: unless you think a very good weed-rap tape is pedestrian by default. Ellison's work as Flying Lotus tends to inspire lofty comparisons-- Aphex Twin
column3: Dilla and of course
column4: his own Coltrane lineage. So anything under that name that doesn't feel like a statement will register as a lesser work. But what about the Flying Lotus who performs live with a bottle of Jameson and a laptop full of TNGHT
column5: Waka Flocka Flame
column6: and Schoolboy Q bangers? This isn't FlyLo's long-threatened Dirty South beat tape and it's probably not something that will make Kanye West reach out to him. But make no mistake

this record is fun in a way that Flying Lotus records choose not to be and satisfying in a way that most of his peers' fail to be.

Jim Jarmusch's films often give life's bit-part players a central role. There's Eddie from Stranger Than Paradise
column2: played by former Sonic Youth drummer Richard Edson
column3: whose weatherworn existence revolved around placing bets at the dog track. Ghost Dog deposited an ice cream salesman played by Isaach De Bankolé as the best friend of the titular character. The musical choices for Jarmusch's films
column4: so often pivotal to the action
column5: reflect his decision to cast Hollywood stars alongside relative unknowns. The Broken Flowers soundtrack featured contributions from Mulatu Astatke
column6: Marvin Gaye
column7: and Sleep. His forthcoming vampire feature
column8: Only Lovers Left Alive
column9: will pull another musician out of the shadows
column10: with Dutch lutist Jozef Van Wissem providing music for the film. The Mystery of Heaven is the pair's third musical collaboration this year
column11: following Concerning the Entrance Into Eternity (on Important) and Apokatastasis (on Van Wissem's own Incunabulum label).

column1: The story of how this duo met
column2: in a chance meeting on a New York City street
column3: where Van Wissem pushed a CD into Jarmusch's hand
column4: feels like it was pulled directly from one of the director's movies. The music they make together retains certain tenets of those films
column5: too. There's a strong sense of magic and mystery
column6: all delivered with a beautiful simplicity. If you strip away the stylistic heft of Jarmusch's films
column7: there are often deceptively basic human emotions underpinning the narrative
column8: albeit ones revealed through the eyes of emotionally damaged individuals. The tracks on The Mystery of Heaven reach down to the same spot
column9: as told through Van Wissem's forlorn lute playing and Jarmusch's feedback-addled guitar parts. Their only diversion is to employ actress (and Only Lovers star) Tilda Swinton to provide a stern spoken word passage over ""The More She Burns the More Beautifully She Glows"".

column1: Much of this record is a gentle advance on the ideas of Concerning the Entrance Into Eternity
column2: with Jarmusch again taking a back seat to Van Wissem's lead. It's a meditative piece
column3: and one that passes naturally from bristly
column4: repetitive motifs (""Flowing Light of the Godhead"") to more subdued material (""The Mystery of Heaven""). Even when they reach peak noise
column5: about two thirds of the way through ""Flowing Light""
column6: it's more hypnotic than aggressive. This is material with a firmly contemplative edge to it
column7: casting a spell only broken with the occasional fluffed note or lapse into accidental dissonance. There's a definite sense that this was recorded live and with little practice beforehand. The title track feels sloppy and aimless at times
column8: perhaps deliberately so. But this is music that benefits from a certain amount of discipline
column9: such as the feral splendor of ""The More She Burns""
column10: where the pair sync up perfectly following Swinton's wonderfully haughty vocal.

column1: The fact that Jarmusch worked on this album with an actress and musician involved in his next movie makes this feel like an important step toward that project. There's even a filmic feel to some of the work here
column2: particularly in the two versions of ""Etimasia""
column3: which echo with a lonely
column4: lovelorn ambiance. It makes sense that Jarmusch would want to break away from music that could superficially resemble ""soundtrack"" work
column5: and he mostly has achieved that on his various collaborations with Van Wissem. But the versions of ""Etimasia"" on The Mystery of Heaven shift closer to a place in which he's become more comfortable since his nascent musical efforts in the no wave scene. It's one of stark
column6: pensive thought
column7: populated by characters who don't make connections easily
column8: whose attempts to make sense of the world are largely a solitary pursuit. At its best
column9: this music feeds into a similar sentiment
column10:
pushing close to the kind of deep introspection at the heart of Jarmusch's films.

At first blush
column2: the Rosebuds covering the entirety of Sade's 1992 LP Love Deluxe may seem baffling. ""What's next?""
column3: one might ask. ""Mates of State perform Anita Baker's Rapture?"" Anyone who's followed the Rosebuds' career for the past decade knows that there's a bit more logic to such an idea

column1: This much is obvious: no one else can be Sade. Over the past decade

column3: the band's sumptuous
column4: smooth music shows no signs of wear

Perhaps the greatest compliment to pay the Rosebuds' cover of Love Deluxe is that it's not necessary to have any familiarity with the original to enjoy its remake-- Howard knows his limits
