Girls Aloud are as huge a pop act as the UK has seen in the past decade
column3: yet they've never so much as dented the American charts. Cheryl Cole
column4: Sarah Harding
column5: Nadine Coyle
column6: Nicola Roberts
column7: and Kimberley Walsh were put together on the reality show Popstars: The Rivals in 2002
column8: and they proceeded to score 20 consecutive British Top 10 singles over the next seven years. That series of hits may well be their legacy
column9: despite the fact that they've reunited for four new songs on this retrospective
column10: their second greatest hits compilation to date.

column1: The most obvious comparison for Girls Aloud is
column2: of course
column3: Spice Girls: cheerful! Euro! girl-power-y! But it might be a little more accurate to compare them to the mid-60s-era Supremes
column4: a group whose presence is all about charm and restraint
column5: and whose behind-the-scenes powerhouse is a brilliantly original writing and production team. In roughly the same way that the Supremes of the period from ""Where Did Our Love Go"" to ""Reflections"" were the vocal adjuncts to Holland-Dozier-Holland
column6: Girls Aloud are basically the most prominent performing associates of Xenomania
column7: the UK song-factory collective centered on Brian Higgins.

column1: Xenomania has cranked out dozens of European hits over the past 15 years
column2: for acts like Pet Shop Boys
column3: Sugababes
column4: and Kylie Minogue. They don't exactly have a signature sound
column5: although they do have a signature songwriting style
column6: which seems to consist of writing a lot of songs
column7: then chopping them up into pieces
column8: keeping the catchiest parts
column9: and seeing which ones can be sutured together into new songs. The best Xenomania songs tend to come off like miraculously coordinated mini-suites; the second-rank ones sound more like ""Stars on 45""-style medleys.

column1: Girls Aloud
column2: as it happens
column3: got a lot of the best ones. The utterly wonderful ""Biology"" starts with a Chicago electric blues riff
column4: of all things; that gets supplanted by a string of increasingly amazing Eurotechno melodies
column5: the last of which-- the nominal chorus
column6: which finally shows up two minutes in-- somehow transforms itself straight back into the blues riff again. ""Biology"" also features one of the proud Britishisms that are all over their records: ""We're gonna cause a conTROversy
column7: Coyle wails. ""The Loving Kind""
column8: which Pet Shop Boys co-wrote with Xenomania
column9: pulls off another one by rhyming its title with ""disinclined.""

column1: As you might expect
column2: Xenomania grab hooks wherever they can find them
column3: and another other way of listening to Girls Aloud's hits is to try to catch all the allusions to the past 50 years' worth of pop as they whizz by. ""Love Machine""-- no relation to either the Miracles' or Morning Musume's respective hits called ""Love Machine""-- borrows its groove from the Smiths' ""Rusholme Ruffians""
column4: its chorus melody from the Beatles' ""Baby You're a Rich Man""
column5: and a stray lyric from Frankie Goes to Hollywood's ""Two Tribes""
column6: for starters. It also contains one of their funniest lines: ""We're gift-wrapped kitty cats/ We're only turning into tigers when we gotta fight back.""

column1: The big difference between the 00s-style song machine and that of the 60s is that-- at least for Xenomania's strain of pop-- it's no longer important to make a song's lyrics sketch out a narrative or emotional state. Xenomania's cut-and-paste method often means that Girls Aloud's lyrics
column2: as smoothly as they scan
column3: are vestigial or incoherent. Compare ""No Good Advice"" with the Supremes' song on a similar theme of parental warnings
column4: ""You Can't Hurry Love""
column5: and stray lines that don't really belong start to poke out of the Girls Aloud record: ""I don't need no special fix to anesthetize me""? ""I dig the music that I'm making
column6: baby
column7: and I'll break it into your brain""?

column1: That's a quibble
column2: though. The broader fault of Ten is that it isn't the ABBA Gold-caliber wonder that Girls Aloud deserves as a greatest hits collection. The group's pointless covers of the Pretenders' ""I'll Stand By You"" and the Pointer Sisters' ""Jump"" were big British hits
column3: but they already sound more dated than anything else here. Then there are the new songs
column4: only two of them Xenomania-written. The group's comeback single
column5: ""Something New""
column6: is a game approximation of the Girls Aloud of seven years ago. But the others just drag the album down-- ""Beautiful Cause You Love Me""
column7: in particular
column8: belongs on the same icky-valentine shelf as James Blunt's ""You're Beautiful"".

column1: Momentum is everything for this kind of pop act
column2: and the fact that the one-year break Girls Aloud announced in 2009 turned into three years off suggests that the group isn't the top priority for its members (or for Xenomania) any more. Four of them have embarked on solo careers to varying degrees of success (and Harding's debut album is due in 2013). They may have a second wave in them
column3: perhaps an equivalent of the Supremes' ""Stoned Love""
column4: ""Nathan Jones""
column5: ""Floy Joy"" era. The virtue of Girls Aloud's best songs
column6: though
column7: is that the next part is always even better than the one you're listening to until
column8: suddenly
column9:
they're over.

Very rarely is there a great deal at stake for a band releasing their debut EP
column2: and after a cursory once-over of Brooklyn by-way-of Los Angeles duo Starred
column3: you probably wouldn't disagree. Last summer
column4: Liza Thorn and Matthew Koshak released ""No Good""
column5: a dusty slow-burner that reveled in its own negative space
column6: hanging in mid-air with a mix of wonder and fear that was easy to see potential in. Never minding their handle
column7: the old Mazzy Star comparisons still came easily
column8: but thanks to some lucky timing
column9: ""No Good"" managed to fill a more immediate void. Right as the song began to prick up ears
column10: Christopher Owens-- frontman of San Francisco's madly beloved Girls-- announced that he'd be leaving his band behind. So while Starred's brokenhearted curiosity regarding the darker corners of pop had the Girls comparisons coming easily
column11: too
column12: there was more connecting the two acts than many realized.

column1: Before there was a Girls
column2: there was Curls
column3: which consisted of then-lovers Owens and Thorn. Though both the band and the relationship didn't last
column4: the pair had clearly rubbed off on each other. ""Lust For Life""
column5: one of the most notable indie pop songs from the past couple years and Owens' first real songwriting credit
column6: was written about Thorn-- suntan
column7: pizza
column8: bottle of wine and all. Now with their Prison to Prison EP
column9: Starred find themselves in a position to win over some of those dejected Girls' fans
column10: and interested parties are most certainly paying attention.

column1: And well they should be. Prison to Prison is a satisfying
column2: intriguing batch of songs that are far more engaging than the simple parts they're made of would suggest. Melancholic and druggy and often surprisingly straightforward
column3: Starred are capable of evoking the same kind of vulnerability that made much of Girls' music so compelling
column4: but in noticeably different ways. Prison to Prison offers both lullabied acoustics that impart a desolate country feel
column5: countoured by spurts of post-punk and psych-rock to create music that by all accounts should float right past you
column6: but instead registers as surprisingly urgent. The results are often a little mixed
column7: but almost always attention-grabbing in some capacity.

column1: Single ""LA Drugs"" and ""Committee"" sit right in the middle of the EP
column2: and function as the most stylistically even-handed pieces. Both hover in ways that could read as anchor-less or simply unspectacular
column3: but are always grounded by the off-putting hum of an organ or a jag of lightning scorched guitar (techniques that feel spiritually akin to EMA's Past Life Martyred Saints
column4: though employed not quite as effectively). Even with the wattage cranked up a few notches
column5: like on the sleazy-pretty ""Sure Bet""
column6: there's still a balance at work that sidesteps some obvious pitfalls (in this case
column7: an easy Kills rip-off) and offers something more dynamic.

column1: Bookends ""Call From Paris"" and ""Light"" highlight yet another one of Starred's strengths. A few years ago
column2: a video surfaced of Courtney Love in a hotel room
column3: singing a cover of ""Unsatisfied"" while to putting her make-up on in the mirror. Accompanied by only an acoustic guitar
column4: it's both obviously unhinged and unexpectedly kind of great. Despite being far more carefully crafted and purposefully pretty
column5: it's hard not to hear some of that rendition in these two tracks. Over the course of six songs
column6: Thorn's vocals range from muttered to hushed to honeyed
column7: but it's on ""Call From Paris"" and ""Light"" that these tiny resemblances to Love become a little more clear. ""It's everything you do
column8: making all of these lies true
column9: she sings on ""Paris"" with a bit of a rasp
column10: placing a subtle snarl on the word ""lies."" ""Light"" is even more contextually telling
column11: as she sings
column12: ""Someone in my light
column13: and he's taking it all."" It's not hard to venture a guess at who that's pointed at
column14: ripe with shades of betrayal and delusion and bitterness that feel all but too familiarly lipstick-smeared.

column1: So suffice it to say that Prison to Prison is a pretty scatterbrained affair in spite of these songs' relatively streamlined structures. But unlike other bands-in-progress
column2: Starred make their varied hat-donnings an asset. Instead of wading into these cloudy pools too deeply
column3: Thorn and Koshak highlight the disparate parts of their musical personalities instead
column4: making pretty music sound frequently maddened and elegantly defeated. Yet it goes without saying that they're at their best when everything falls into place
column5: and you're able to peek into a potentially brighter near-future. That preview comes in the form of ""Cemetery""
column6: a song that's warm and desperate in a way that recalls a folky
column7: aqueous take on ""Just Like Honey"". Still
column8: Starred are in the process of trying to figure exactly who they want to be
column9: and that's perfectly fine. With songs as good as some of the ones on Prison to Prison are
column10:
they've earned themselves a little time.

You can't keep a good narrative down: chillwave has been a reliable punchline the last couple of years even though most of its biggest targets have refused to cooperate. Toro Y Moi
column3: Neon Indian
column4: and Washed Out have all established themselves as career artists and made their 2011 LPs count in a major way
column5: while their aesthetic bled into hip-hop by way of Clams Casino and cloud rap. Even genre godfather Ariel Pink is developing a new legacy by releasing some of the best songs of his life. It seems like only Memory Tapes
column6: aka Dayve Hawk
column7: failed to rise to the occasion
column8: following up the excellent Seek Magic with Player Piano
column9: a collection of wan indie rock that seemed like an attempt to backdoor a revival of his previous trad-alt band Hail Social.

column1: But then again
column2: as a 30-something father and music industry vet
column3: he was an outlier among the Urban Outfitters set to begin with. And if there's any silver lining to Player Piano
column4: it's that the prolific and hermetic Hawk is free to do whatever the hell he wants without expectations. Last year
column5: he hinted at a batch of Black Sabbath-esque dirges. Which is certainly intriguing and also about a billion miles away from the meandering pop of Grace/Confusion.

column1: The most immediately striking aspect of Memory Tapes' third proper LP is the tracklisting: It's only six songs long and the shortest cut is just shy of five minutes; nominal lead single ""Sheila"" clocks in at about eight and a half. This seems daunting until you remember Seek Magic had only eight songs and
column2: besides his unquestionable peak ""Bicycle""
column3: its strengths lay in lengthier dance-leaning numbers like ""Stop Talking"" and ""Graphics"". So Grace/Confusion is certainly not the pop record Player Piano was. Here
column4: Hawk employs a watercolor palette to his benefit: Despite its unnerving chorus
column5: ""I watch you sleep
column6: the first half of ""Neighborhood Watch"" is given to the sounds of bleary sunrises
column7: loosely strummed acoustics
column8: and distant harmonies. Likewise
column9: the brisk and perky ""Thru the Field"" is ""Bicycle""-gone-Tour de France
column10: while the first half of ""Sheila"" unifies two prominent artistic memes by sounding like Tango in the Night dubbed onto VHS. That constitutes about half of Grace/Confusion
column11: likely the ""grace"" part.

column1: Hawke has called this record ""messier"" than his previous work. But with the exception of the strikingly distorted coda of ""Neighborhood Watch"" (maybe that's where the Sabbath fix went?)
column2: most of Grace/Confusion pads out past four minutes by establishing a foothold before softly pivoting towards a far less interesting destination. And the immersion demanded by Grace/Confusion is undermined by Hawk's drizzly production; as an avid remixer
column3: you'd hope he would be more accommodating to some outside input or at least an upgrade in gear. The same tones and textures that worked for ""Bicycle"" or ""Plain Material"" are unnecessarily restrictive in a format that requires more depth and dynamic range. And while it casts a nice spell during the earliest hours when your day is either beginning or ending
column4: lifestyle depending
column5: it's ultimately interrupted by Hawk's proclivity for chintzy sound effects; the second half of ""Thru the Field"" trails off into a wheedling
column6: harmonized guitar solo; ""Neighborhood Watch"" breaks its tense grind with overeager synth lines
column7: and Hawk bisects ""Sheila"" with a garish laser beam like some sort of supervillain ploy.

column1: While Grace/Confusion may lean too heavily on Hawk's production
column2: it's a hair better than Player Piano. But it's hard to call it an ""improvement"" or ""progression"" considering it's hardly outside the scope of what Memory Tapes has done so far. In a sense his artistic trajectory seems to be working in reverse-- Seek Magic feels like it should be the culmination of what he's done separately on Player Piano and now Grace/Confusion
column3: not the starting point. So it's hard to take Hawk at his word as he once again claims that his next record will sound nothing like Grace/Confusion; without some true commitment to a sonic reconfiguration
column4:
his gift/curse is that it'll probably still sound like something he's already done.

Saint Etienne's first album in seven years
column4: this year's Words and Music by Saint Etienne
column5: is pop music of and about loving pop music. In a less direct way

column8: 1993's So Tough
column9: and 1994's Tiger Bay combine a connoisseur's stylish adventurousness with a true fan's endearingly quaint romanticism. Whether 1960s girl groups
column10: 90s Euro-house

column12: Saint Etienne aren't ones to let shiny prettiness go to waste.

column1: The last two entries in Saint Etienne's four-year deluxe series make for one hell of a victory lap. Casino Classics
column2: an update of a 1996 remix collection
column3: and Lipslide
column4: singer Sarah Cracknell's 1997 solo debut
column5: are both far more than the afterthoughts such phrases might suggest. Each vividly represent Saint Etienne's far-flung interests-- their cosmopolitan
column6: dance-oriented side and their more domestic
column7: Burt Bacharach-leaning side-- though not necessarily the one you might think. Most importantly
column8: diehard Saint Etienne fans who've already picked up all of the other reissues have no reason to stop here
column9: and curious newcomers shouldn't have to feel daunted
column10: either.

column1: Casino Classics would be notable for historical reasons alone
column2: but happily its top-notch remixers-- and top-notch remix material-- still easily hold their own in this post-EDM era. As a group whose first single
column3: and first hit
column4: converted Neil Young's ""Only Love Can Break Your Heart"" into dubby Eurodisco
column5: Saint Etienne have never been strangers to the dance realm
column6: and the original 2xCD
column7: 3xLP release was both stacked and prescient. The Chemical Brothers' distinctively block-rocking take on Tiger Bay's krautrock-sleek standout ""Like a Motorway""
column8: for instance

column1: The complete reissue
column2: including two limited-edition bonus discs
column3: adds more than 30 tracks to the original
column4: though nothing from this year's Words and Music. As unwieldy as this approach is for listening all the way through

column8: and its glitchy

column10: but they're enveloping glimpses of an artist who hadn't yet released Selected Ambient Works Volume II. Broadcast's eerily cinematic ""Angel"" remix came out before the English outfit's first Warp compilation.

column1: Among the new additions
column2: DJ Tiësto's remix of ""Action
column3: originally from 2002's Finisterre
column4: captures the song's return-to-the-clubs feeling-- and also captures Tiësto before he started raking in a reported $22 million annually. And Richard X's reworking of ""Method of Modern Love""
column5: the only all-new song from Saint Etienne's 2009 best-of compilation London Conversations and one he produced and co-wrote only amps up his subject's ur-pop pleasures
column6: something like his wonderful remix of Cassie's recent ""King of Hearts"". When you throw in a couple of the preexisting comp's standout tracks
column7: such as a breathtaking reworking of Tiger Bay Eurodisco-mainliner ""He's on the Phone"" by Motiv 8 (who did an excellent remix of Spice Girl's ""Wannabe"" around the same time) and Andrew Weatherall's dub-exploring revamp of ""Only Love Can Break Your Heart""
column8: it's instructive that so much of what might seem like a leftfield digression for Saint Etienne also underscores their pop charms.

column1: Cracknell's solo Lipslide might seem like the opposite of a remix album
column2: but it winningly isn't so different after all. Like the remixers
column3: Cracknell is making Saint Etienne's songs her own
column4: though unlike them she does so in a style that's not unlike the group's usual approach. After all
column5: she didn't sing on Saint Etienne's first singles
column6: and in a trio with the former music journalists Bob Stanley and Pete Wiggs
column7: her role must've been easy for a sometimes chauvinistic critical establishment to discount unfairly. Recorded between her main outfit's masterful electro-folk hybrid Tiger Bay and 1998's Swedish indie pop-indebted Good Humor
column8: Lipslide asserts Cracknell's rockist bona fides in the least rockist way possible: She co-writes every song
column9: but they're are unabashedly soft and quotidian
column10: decked out in synths and strings rather than muscular guitars or middlebrow approximations of depth. It's the supposedly interchangeable vocalist reaffirming that the supposedly interchangeable is what really matters anyway.

column1: The 2xCD deluxe edition might surprise some US listeners by mainly restoring the alternate
column2: UK tracklist for the main disc; while a couple of the US-only tracks
column3: such as ""Aussie Soap Girl""
column4: find their way to the bonus disc

column8: a hybrid of contemporary synth-pop and swinging London mod in the finest Saint Etienne mold

column10: friends who got engaged-- in a conversation with a heartbroken friend

column12: and ""Can't Stop Now"" is Dusty Springfield-ish ""daydreaming that love is cool""-- basically the blueprint for later London indie-poppers Lucky Soul.

column1: Even here
column2: though
column3: the triphoppy ""Goldie""
column4: lithe electro-disco strutter ""Taxi""
column5: or Madonna-buoyant synth-gospel ultimatum ""If You Leave Me"" could almost as easily fit on the other new Etienne-related reissue. Lipslide's bonus material is more varied
column6: including a couple of demos and more acoustic-leaning tracks-- among them a previously unreleased team-up with Liverpool group Shack on their song ""Miles Apart""
column7: which is elegant in a strummier way. The album doesn't completely follow the UK tracklist
column8: either
column9: as the baggier UK album version of ""Home"" makes a welcome appearance on the bonus disc. Saint Etienne fans

column11: are used to trawling through an overly complicated discography
column12: and they do so because the rewards continue to be worth the search.

column1: Saint Etienne's reissues series wraps up as their stance
column2: consciously or not
column3: appears to be gaining an increasing hold in the indie firmament. Take Elite Gymnastics' James Brooks
column4: who has said he's trying to ""rebuild my own canon where Joy Division or Radiohead doesn't matter but Tori Amos or Sarah McLachlan or the Spice Girls or George Michael or Des'ree or the Romeo + Juliet soundtrack do matter."" Or the likes of CFCF and LOL Boys

column11:
as ever (with all the requisite postmodern provisos): Only love can break your heart.

as ever (with all the requisite postmodern provisos): Only love can break your heart.

column9: as on the excellent ""What That Was""

These songs have the expressive power of confessions
column5: or handwritten letters. Take the melodic and mesmerizing opening track
column6: <a href=""http://pitchfork.com/reviews/tracks/14531-turns-turns-turns/"" target=""_blank"">""Turns
column7: Turns
column8: Turns""

column1: A lot of this comes from the fact that Welsh (who also once twirled knobs in now defunct electro-dreamers Pop Winds) is now embracing his inner frontman. He and Otto both used to man an assortment of samplers

column9:
a handwritten invitation into Majical Cloudz' dream world.

In spring of 2011

column6: rubbing up against a bell-like synth and yearning
column7: overlapping vocals

column1: ""Need Someone"" appears again here on the duo's debut

column3: though

column1: For much of the record

There might well be sincerity to Santucci's wounded lyrics but he never moves beyond scab-picking toward the kind of emotional payoff that great break-up records all share. Stubborn Heart is like the friend who
column6: six months after a break-up
column7: has grown a beard
column8: put on a few pounds
column9: and is no fun at all to have a conversation with. There's no sense of journey to the romantic trauma and across a full hour's running time
column10: the wallowing becomes monotonous. Fortunately
column11: Santucci's voice can sound fairly unique and carries enough characterstic yearning that he doesn't need to over emote.

column1: There are a couple of moments of promise
column2: but they're stuck at the front: ""Penetrate"" starts the record off well
column3: contrasting laid-back vocals with busy rhythms to good effect. Its shimmering
column4: spacious chorus is easily the prettiest moment on Stubborn Heart
column5: too. ""Better Than This"" also works a succinct chorus hook nicely
column6: its central lyric
column7: ""I can do better
column8: you can do better
column9: we can do so much better than this"" teetering between feeling acerbic and comforting.

column1: Stubborn Heart is frustrating because the band can do so much better. There's not a lot of light to be found on this record-- the beats are heavy legged and much of the action happens in the miasmic low-end. It all sounds so serious without any real reason for it. You wish they'd snap out of the funk because when they do
column2: Stubborn Heart are capable of making sly
column3:
futuristic pop music with real potential. There's not much of it to be found here.

Writing about Von in 2012 seems wrong: For some a footnote and others a foundation
column2: the San Francisco group earns the distinction of being one of America's first black metal bands. Especially in a field that favors merchandise and memorabilia
column3: they're also incredibly under-documented
column4: with a pair of atavistic EPs followed more than a decade later by a compilation collecting those early works and a live set captured in San Francisco in 1991. Still
column5: the band's reputation supersedes their relative commercial obscurity: Their early demos are clear forebears of the current United States black metal scene
column6: with Von's uniform pugnacity helping set the stage for a later caste of norm-breakers. It also didn't hurt that Burzum's Varg Vikernes wore a long-sleeve Von shirt while on trial for the murder of Mayhem’s Øystein Aarseth.

column2: both as the wave of legacy acts reforming surged along and as coverage of United States black metal began reached the mainstream media
column3: Von reunited. They played London’s Armageddon Fest with Watain
column4: the corpsepaint Swedes who'd taken one of their tunes as a name
column5: and released a three-song 7"" of reworked older tunes. In a subsequent interview
column6: cofounders Venien and Goat seemed amicable enough
column7: saying ""being in action feels exhilarating
column8: my friend"" and describing the second leg of their career as fortuitous happenstance. ""Goat and I got back in touch and decided to discuss matters and it sort of started at that point
column9: Venien told Vladimir Petković. ""It really had to make sense to both Goat and I
column10: and it just worked out to be something we were comfortable with.""

column1: The demand for mutual comfort didn't last very long: Though Venien said that there was no full-length in the works only two years ago
column2: Von has returned again with its full-length debut
column3: Satanic Blood-- and
column4: importantly
column5: without Goat. Satanic Blood is the name of the band’s most infamous demo tape
column6: and this LP's 17 tracks consist largely of reworked archival material; you'll find original versions of almost every tune on Satanic Blood Angel
column7: a 2003 Nuclear War Now! compilation. Goat sang those songs then
column8: but Venien sings them now. He's not an especially great vocalist
column9: but his barely decipherable grunts lend themselves to the quartet's dense roil. His singing doesn't lead the band so much as fit within it
column10: the functional wedge between Von's constant blast beats and repetition-as-a-lifestyle riffs.

column1: Venien's move hasn't necessarily been a popular one
column2: invoking ire on online forums by raising the question of what exactly Von is and who it belongs to
column3: but it works: Satanic Blood is a grueling
column4: sloppy mass of low-fidelity
column5: high-energy metal that gets by on enthusiasm and vigor. Von roars through the title cut
column6: multi-tracked vocals forming a militia of demons around a band that races toward the end. This quartet’s take at ""Devil Pig"" is a hilariously direct Von gem about a porcine in pentagrams. The band treats the tune's simple guitar lead and militant rhythmic approach as though they were edicts to be exalted. No matter the authenticity objections of those playing
column7: the tune is a triumphant 150-second jaunt in the dark. Von's truncated take on ""Goat Christ"" moves with grindcore speed
column8: while Venien chants with the joined force of hardcore and death metal. Von give new oomph to an old standard.

column1: Still
column2: Satanic Blood falters when Venien pushes away from sheer propulsion. Tedious instrumental ""Veadtuck"" aims to evidence the band’s instrumental chops and stylistic prescience but fails on both counts. Mostly
column3: it stalls the mountain of momentum created by the first four tracks. This is the sign and sound of a band-- or part of a band
column4: as it were-- who finally got around to recording an LP after a quarter-century. ""Dissection InHuman""
column5: meanwhile
column6: storms at the start
column7: its messy riff buried within serrated vocals and ceaseless drums. Toward the middle
column8: Venian drops into a ghoulish lurk
column9: letting wind howl around the microphones as the band fecklessly tries to recreate a moonlit ritual. It's as scary as grocery store Halloween decorations; luckily
column10: they lift above the murk one more time
column11: ending the song on one of the record's most convincing black metal bursts. The new ""Jesus Stain"" pummels without apology for most of its four minutes
column12: but it falters at the end when the band switches to stop-time
column13: breaking up the motion like they're auditioning to be the Who. Given the factions that Satanic Blood created
column14: it's tempting to wish for a little progression here
column15: for the addition of some unforeseen flourishes. But Von only sounds convincing when they sound mawkishly simple
column16: too; most everything else comes across as forced. Venien mostly understands that.

column1: The line between perpetuating a legacy and publicly shaming it is a daunting and unpredictable one. In forms that emerged to lash back at the powers that be
column2: whether that be indie rock or heavy metal
column3: simple cash grabs or quick attempts to reiterate a reputation are nauseating reminders of art's function as simple commodity. Already playing some small club shows
column4: if Venien trots this bastardized Von onto the metal festival circuits
column5: that's likely the judgment that awaits his return-- an entitled old guy trying to cash in on inspirational youthful activity. But I'd be lying if I said I despised the band that made Satanic Blood in 2012. They delight in their own shambles
column6: racing off into euphoric
column7:
energetic madness like teenagers catching on to an outlandish sound.

Billy Corgan hasn't done a very good job speaking on his own behalf over the past decade
column2: so let me feed him a line from the Greek philosopher Pittacus that would make a much better case for his legacy: ""The measure of a man is what he does with power."" In 1995
column3: nearly every other band at Smashing Pumpkins' level was in some way turning its back on its audience: Pearl Jam had started their principled retreat from the spotlight; U2 and R.E.M. were deep within their stagiest
column4: most ironic phases and making their least satisfying music to date; Rivers Cuomo was well on his way towards making Pinkerton; Metallica discovered nail polish; and
column5: of course
column6: Kurt Cobain gave up on life itself. On a much smaller level
column7: even Corgan's eternal rival Steve Malkmus had just released Wowee Zowee
column8: a record whose sloppy sprawl was taken by Rolling Stone as proof that ""Pavement are simply afraid to succeed.""

column1: Given this mid-decade valley
column2: it's understandable that the 2xCD Mellon Collie and the Infinite Sadness would be sneered at as self-indulgent. The Smashing Pumpkins hadn't made their appearance at Hullabalooza yet
column3: so many were unaware the band had a sense of humor. Still
column4: their reputation was played for laughs. But Mellon Collie and the Infinite Sadness turned out to be one of the most generous records of the decade. During a time when rock heroes were hard to come by
column5: Smashing Pumpkins took it upon themselves to make a record that only teenagers could love and for many it was the only one they needed.

column1: I suppose it's worth mentioning I was 15 when Mellon Collie came out and I would've told you at the time it was my favorite album ever made. Finally
column2: I thought
column3: here was our White Album
column4: Physical Graffiti
column5: or The Wall
column6: but we could watch its legend being constructed in real time without all the received wisdom. It's true
column7: a double album reeks of 70s-style excess that tries to edify its creators. It was meant as Smashing Pumpkins' monument to itself. But in the case of Mellon Collie
column8: it was the only format that could contain the songwriting streak Corgan was going through at the time. Anything shorter would've done his fans a disservice.

column1: This is not an exaggeration. Cull the 14 best tracks from the concurrently recorded The Aeroplane Flies High singles collection and you either have the fourth best Smashing Pumpkins album (behind the perpetually underrated Adore
column2: ahead of Pisces Iscariot) or a strong third disc that would've made Mellon Collie the greatest triple-LP ever made. What becomes more obvious with time is that Mellon Collie
column3: unlike its most common comparison The Wall
column4: has no conceptual framework. There is no plot
column5: almost no filler
column6: and the organization of its two discs is iffy at best: The second song on the seemingly chronological first disc Dawn to Dusk is ""Tonight
column7: Tonight""
column8: while disc two
column9: Twilight to Starlight
column10: contains all of the ugliest metal songs. So Mellon Collie is a Smashing Pumpkins record that just so happens to be 28 songs in length
column11: stunning in both its stylistic range and overall excellence.

column1: This is perhaps the only Smashing Pumpkins record where they acted like an actual band rather than Corgan and his resentful charges. It's hard to pinpoint where the influence of James Iha or D'Arcy came into play (not so with the phenomenal drumming of Jimmy Chamberlin)
column2: but with the oversight of producers Flood and Alan Moulder
column3: Mellon Collie was developed through protracted jam sessions and personal interplay. Siamese Dream
column4: for all of its symphonic grandeur
column5: was a fairly standard rock album and a solitary one-- nearly all of the guitar and bass parts were rumored to have been performed by Corgan himself. Meanwhile
column6: Mellon Collie indulges in styles more associated with hermetic artists-- ornate chamber-pop (""Cupid De Locke"")
column7: mumbly acoustic confessionals (""Stumbleine"")
column8: and synthesized nocturnes (mostly everything after ""X.Y.U.""). And it does so while feeling like the work of four people in a room.

column1: Mellon Collie's remarkable breadth is the best indication of Corgan's ability to let loose. You could pick five songs at random and still end up with a diverse batch of singles that would make a case for Smashing Pumpkins being the most stylistically malleable multi-platinum act of the 90s. Maybe it wouldn't sell as many copies
column2: but picture an alternate universe where heavy rotation met the joyous
column3: mechanized grind of ""Love""
column4: ""In the Arms of Sleep""'s unabashed antiquated romanticism
column5: the Prince-like electro-ballad ""Beautiful""
column6: ""Muzzle""'s stadium-status affirmations
column7: or the throttling metal of ""Bodies"".

column1: The ubiquity of the five songs that did become singles overshadows just how idiosyncratic and distinct they were in the scope of 1995. Has there been anything like ""Tonight
column2: Tonight"" since? Orchestral strings typically signify weepy balladry or compositional pretension in rock music
column3: not wonderful
column4: lovestruck propulsion. While ""Tonight
column5: Tonight"" is now inseparable from its Le Voyage dans la lune-inspired video
column6: that the music existed without its guidance only stresses the Pumpkins' sonic creativity. ""Thirty-Three"" was the final and least heralded of the singles-- where on alt-rock radio was there room for a slowpoke
column7: time-signature shifting country song with phased slide guitars and shuffling drum machines?

column1: ""Zero"" and ""Bullet With Butterfly Wings"" are the ones that riled up the older folks and
column2: yes
column3: the lyrics are pissy and juvenile and fairly embarrassing. That said
column4: they're far more interesting from a sonic perspective than they're often given credit for. They're the songs where Flood's digitized production fits better than the saturated
column5: analog warmth Butch Vig lent to Siamese Dream. They're basically new wave performed as pop-metal.

column1: And of course
column2: there's ""1979""
column3: the one everybody can agree on. On a record that reveled in 70s prog and pomp without being restricted to it
column4: it sounds futuristic. And while just as youth-obsessed as everything else here
column5: it's one of the few times where high school sounds like something that can be remembered fondly. Corgan loves to stress how it was the last song to make the record
column6: and while its chorus does have an effortless charge embodying the ""urgency of now
column7: it's the only Mellon Collie song that functions best as nostalgia. That reading is no doubt abetted by another fantastic video
column8: but while ""1979"" is an unimpeachable song
column9: the rush to praise it as an outlier does its surroundings a tremendous disservice. While Mellon Collie is the realization of all Billy Corgan's ambitions
column10: most of the criticisms surround the lyrics for not being as personal as those on the tortured Siamese Dream. It's this way by design.

column1: The terms ""sad machines"" and ""teen machines"" are interchangeably used during ""Here Is No Why""
column2: a pep talk to the outwardly sullen mopes who Corgan urges to break free of either and ascend like its heroic guitar solo. ""Bullet With Butterfly Wings"" is notorious for its chorus
column3: but teen angst doesn't fight fair; you need some seriously heavy ammo to resist it. The mudslide of distortion that ushers in its bridge leads towards two minutes of the most viscerally exciting music that Smashing Pumpkins produced. Then immediately after
column4: the mournful ""To Forgive"" devastates with a personal detail that gives Corgan credibility in all of this: ""And I remember my birthdays/ Empty party afternoons."" This is the kind of youthful
column5: inexplicable emotional whiplash that can result in an immolating hatebomb called ""Fuck You (An Ode to No One)"" being followed by a giddy proclamation that ""love solves everything."" It's clearly not a mature way of dealing with life
column6: but that's only a problem if you somehow believe Mellon Collie isn't meant as rock 'n' roll fantasy. When Corgan declares ""I know that I was meant for this world"" during ""Muzzle""
column7: it's your happy ending.

column1: So
column2: yes
column3: most people who have developed a meaningful relationship with Mellon Collie did so in their youth. The question is whether you can get anything new from this in 2012. As with all of the Smashing Pumpkins reissues
column4: Mellon Collie is giving: the Deluxe boxed set justifies its sticker shock by containing ""re-imagined cover art

column6: which is everything you'd imagine and thensome. There are an extra 64 tracks and only a few of them appeared on The Aeroplane Flies High
column7: though most of these inclusions are demos or alternate takes
column8: the sort of thing that should only be listened to multiple times by people who are being paid to do so
column9: i.e.
column10: music critics and Flood.

column1: But there is a way of hearing the same album differently as you refract it through your own experiences. ""Thru the Eyes of Ruby"" is rumored to have contained 70 guitar tracks; it's a wedding vow punctuated by Corgan snarling ""youth is wasted on the young."" This isn't meant to negate the intent of the 90 minutes that preceded it
column2: it's a reminder of how Mellon Collie can communicate different things to someone who's 30 as opposed to 15. Revisiting it can feel like leafing through a high school yearbook-- not necessarily your own
column3: just somebody's. And there's solace in how
column4: for all of the navel-gazing that went on
column5: the ridiculousness of it all somehow escapes you. What you wore
column6: how you spoke
column7: what you felt not so much seeming normal as just the way it is. You look at each person
column8: thinking that they might hope to achieve the self-actualization promised by ""Muzzle""
column9: to lose themselves in another person in the manner described by ""Beautiful"" or ""In the Arms of Sleep""
column10: or to embrace their own awkwardness as a rallying cry like ""We Only Come Out at Night"". Those events were all right around the corner
column11: as they are for just about anybody growing up

column14: Tonight""

column8: Tonight""

The newly released CD of demos that became Sharon Van Etten's third record

column1: Demos is the bonus half of a reissue of Tramp

column3: and this week
column4: played her biggest ever U.K. gig (2
column5: 000 capacity) and got announced as the main support for Nick Cave and the Bad Seeds' 2013 U.S. tour. All timeliness aside
column6: though
column7: Demos reveals the most when compared to an album that's nearly four years old.

column1: One of the nicest impromptu presents anyone ever gave to me was a CDR of Sharon Van Etten's home recordings
column2: bought at an early British gig. The unmarked
column3: home-burned CD came inside a piece of folded brown parcel paper
column4: held together with black tape
column5: decorated with a square of colorful wrapping. Inside it is another brown sheet covered in splodgy typewriter text: two sides of blocks of lyrics without punctuation or paragraphing
column6: followed by a handwritten note apologizing for the noise on the recordings
column7: a request for feedback
column8: and an old email address. Most of the songs are on Van Etten's debut album proper
column9: the acoustic Because I Was in Love
column10: where they weren't exactly beefed up
column11: but at least there were no trains rumbling past the studio window to intrude on proceedings.

column1: Home Recordings was done in Sharon's then-basement
column2: and her voice is often so quiet that even the atmosphere picked up by the microphone overpowers her. These recordings were made at a time when Van Etten's confidence was low
column3: when she didn't have as many champions-- TV on the Radio's Kyp Malone initially encouraged her to play shows after she'd moved back to the north-east after escaping her ex-boyfriend-- when she was probably able to personally express her gratitude and hand change over to every person that bought their handmade copy of the CD at those early shows. A different kind of human interaction made Tramp-- a large ensemble affair produced by the National's Aaron Dessner
column4: starring members of his band
column5: and the Walkmen
column6: Beirut
column7: Wye Oak
column8: the Antlers among others-- but the sense of solitude is just as important to Demos.

column1: Tramp was named as a nod to Van Etten's homelessness during the making of her third album
column2: and Demos' liner notes-- in that same blobby typewriter font-- draw a map from the backstage area at a Warsaw show to a Bushwick basement
column3: friends' places in Fort Greene
column4: her parents' house in New Jersey
column5: Tokyo
column6: producer Aaron Dessner's Brooklyn studio
column7: and her bedroom. The carefully produced package features a droopy self-portrait on the front
column8: a half-homage to those of Leonard Cohen
column9: perhaps. (""Leonard"" on Tramp was named for his influence; the cover of that record had Van Etten emulating John Cale's close-up portrait from Fear.) A note from Van Etten inside the Demos package was written from the first solo holiday she ever took
column10: to Cancun in summer 2011 while recording Tramp
column11: and ruminations on the comfort of aloneness (rather than loneliness) pepper the diary excerpts within the liner notes
column12: where she also explains each song's origin. Some are as old as the music on Home Recordings
column13: but only saw life on Tramp due to their author's hesitation to reveal a certain side of herself until that point.

column1: She calls ""Serpents"" ""really aggressive
column2: and the lyrics here differ from the album in that it's Van Etten (or her character) who has thrown a bowl at someone at the start
column3: and it ends with her raggedly challenging a knife with the threat
column4: ""Well
column5: I've got a gun""-- unlikely
column6: of course
column7: but an unfettered expression of frustration
column8: vengeance
column9: and self-protection against emotional abuse. Van Etten originally worried that ""In Line""
column10: one of Tramp's most affecting songs
column11: was too much of a ""dirge
column12: but Dessner encouraged her to give it a go. The demo is one of the lesser formed songs here
column13: where she beats at an acoustic's sloppy strings while feeling around the vocal melody; ""the world was shitty then"" is one of the only audible phrases.

column1: These demos appear in various states of finish
column2: with Van Etten often either feeling out the space where words will eventually go
column3: or extemporizing with a total lack of self-consciousness
column4: her streams of thought sometimes revealing more than the polished Tramp eventually would. You sometimes read bands talking in interviews about how even when they're playing the same songs at gigs each night
column5: doing so takes them back to the exact point where they first wrote them: bullshit. ""Joke or a Lie"" is shorter than its Tramp equivalent
column6: but there's a gulf between every lingered-over line; her liner notes reveal that this song was written after ""a lover gave up"" on her
column7: recorded while ""chain smoking in my bedroom and letting the smoke rise between strums."" She sings at full volume
column8: a small reclamation of power in the face of desertion.

column1: Home Recordings was intended as an invitation-- the show itself-- whereas Demos is the curtain reveal
column2: dipping its toes into uglier palettes
column3: marked by the gloom and clank of recording in confined spaces on primitive equipment. Stripping Tramp back to its most basic form demonstrates how Van Etten's approach to songwriting has changed. Home Recordings follows mellifluous folky structures with the guide of an acoustic guitar
column4: but that tradition has disappeared from Van Etten's more recent writing; there's less ornate fingerpicking
column5: and more monotone strumming that propels her rough lyrics along with a tense
column6: anxious pace. There's no playing the singer-songwriter
column7: as Matthew Murphy alluded to in his review of Because I Was in Love; she's now beholden to letting what she wants to say dictate the shape rather than the other way around.

column1: By and large
column2: Demos contains very little that would surprise anyone familiar with Tramp
column3: but there's more to this collection than marveling at how funny ""Magic Chords"" sounds with a rinky-dink drum machine instead of that snare purr
column4: or the way ""I'm Wrong"" unfolds when stripped of the shimmering production parade with which it marches outward. As well as lifting the curtain on Tramp
column5: releasing Demos feels like an act of dispossession masquerading as a modest recognition of appreciation. In 2012
column6: Van Etten has released more music in one year than ever before-- there have been singles
column7: b-sides
column8: a song for ""Boardwalk Empire""
column9: a Christmas duet with Rufus Wainwright
column10: a strange
column11: ""Twin Peaks""-indebted four-song collection called Psychajealous that you got if you bought Tramp at London's Rough Trade. A certain swathe of people know about Sharon Van Etten
column12: and a decent proportion of them know the much-cited
column13:
boyfriend-related situation that inspired a lot of her music and has dominated much of the conversation around it. Demos feels like a final act of blood-letting. Whatever comes next will be a fresh body.

Tiga
column3: better known for his tastemaking and mixing skills than his productions
column4: has one really important skill: He makes niche scenes feel populist. He did this most memorably in 2003
column5: when his DJ-Kicks mix made the booming electroclash scene play like a big party instead of a bunch of pissy punk rockers with sequencers. Since then he's released a trunk-full of singles and remixes
column6: along with two artist albums notable mostly for their goofy insouciance. Less visibly
column7: he's stewarded the shockingly productive Turbo Recordings
column8: a label that
column9: if it hasn't quite predicted every major trend in dance music during the last half-decade
column10: has at least been on the cusp
column11: from Chromeo's 80s revivalism to Azari & III's pilfering of Chicago house to the label's more recent focus on the gritty end of tech house. His record as a taste barometer is flawless.

column1: Befitting his label's recent direction
column2: Tiga's Non Stop mix for Pias/Different Recordings focuses on pug-nosed
column3: gritty dance. Tiga weaves them into a broader pop context that includes nonchalant indie-electro (Kindness' magnificent Mats' cover
column4: ""Swingin' Party"") and contemporary pop-rap-- his Tyga-refactoring ""Track City Bitch"" is clever and annoying. These are sore thumbs
column5: obvious ones from an artist who has snatched in for reworking ""Sunglasses at Night"" and ""Hot in Here""
column6: but they're hardly all that's on offer. Non Stop shines when it marries the rambunctiousness of recent Turbo mainstays such as Clouds and Duke Dumont with everything from abstract indie (Actress' Panda Bear remix) to noise-punk tirades (Factory Floor) and analogue purism (the hotly tipped Blawan and Locked Groove).

column1: It's those Turbo artists that Non Stop really cradles
column2: all this infrastructure that makes Duke Dumont's ""Street Walker"" the type of track casual fans could pick out of a lineup; that makes Clouds' stomping ""Those Cracks in Your Face
column3: Do They Hurt?"" sound playful. He's not offering these tracks in context: he's removing them from it
column4: from an all-house
column5: all-techno world in which they might seem gray
column6: or rote
column7: or merely good. There is a level of whimsy here not available in a standard Fabric or DJ-Kicks offering. That whimsy can serve as a gateway
column8: and that's really valuable.

column1: Non Stop is an alloy so primly tailored to every conceivable dance music trend that it's worth wondering if Tiga has a cool nephew or a bug planted in a Hardwax buyer's laptop. The real explanation-- that Tiga is an exceptionally tuned-in connoiseur-- is less exciting
column2: but it doesn't subtract from the casual mixology of Non Stop. Tiga's Turbo label has expertly shifted its focus over the years
column3: but his mixing remains an all-Tiga affair
column4: expertly unfocused
column5:
still hanging streamers and balloons in unlikely places.

0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/18643/homepage_large.9ba7e4b4.jpg|Greatest of Deceivers|30890.0|NIDINGR|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Indie']|2012-12-05 00:00:00|2012|2016-06-11 17:03:57.794902|"

For a musical style designed with the express purpose of aggressively alienating the majority of listeners that might encounter it
column2: black metal has proven to be exceedingly amenable to mixing with other genres. In recent years it's gained influence in the underground metal world
column3: and in the process of expanding has spawned a number of hybrid offspring
column4: from relatively predictable combinations like blackened death metal and blackened crust punk to such unexpected variants as black-metal-influenced industrial music and the accurately named subgenre black 'n' roll.

column1: Greatest of Deceivers
column2: the fourth album by Borre
column3: Norway's Nidingr since 1996
column4: the group takes a black metal approach to a lengthy list of influences. The group's mastermind
column5: Morten Iversen
column6: better known as Teloch
column7: has been involved in the Scandinavian black metal scene since the prime of its second wave when it was ruled by a hardline orthodoxy that didn't allow for much in the way of crossover
column8: and when a lot of other metal scenes didn't want much to do with it in return.

column1: Despite his involvement with such classically-minded groups as Mayhem
column2: Gorgoroth
column4: and Ov Hell
column5: Iversen's got an especially broad sonic vision. Greatest of Deceivers is a dense and complex mass made up of songs that themselves generally have more discrete movements than you can count on one hand. Some of them offer blackened takes on full-throttle death metal and crust punk. Others offer complicated leads and tricky time signatures that hint at mathcore and sometimes even at a particularly gnarly interpretation of jazz. Occasionally the group cuts back the aggression sharply and coasts into near-ambiance. In terms of compositional ambition the songs are closer to the labyrinthine post-rock and post-hardcore bands of the mid to late 90s than the savagely straightforward black metal outfits that were operating around the same time.

column1: This complexity is a double edged sword. On the one hand there is something about listening to a finely tuned band rip through such daunting compositions with machine-like precision that is very easy to enjoy in the same way as watching Olympic-level sports or other human skill refined to a point far out of the reach of the average person. There's also just a surfeit of material to digest
column2: and having it come at you at such a rapid rate can be satisfyingly overwhelming. Black metal's had symphonic ambitions since it first took root in Norway
column3: and Nidingr's baroque works often feel like the a group reaching to live up to them and succeeding.

column1: But the problem with extreme partsiness
column2: as many of the aforementioned post-rock and post-hardcore bands have demonstrated
column3: is that the more parts you add to a song the greater the likelihood that one or more is going to be a clunker
column4: and on Greatest of Deceivers the clunkers come at a distractingly steady pace. The tricky mathcore bits are technically impressive
column5: but when they pop up in the middle of a blistering bit of truly wicked death metal it can ruin the mood. The group's also less adept at spacey textural playing than the fast-and-complicated stuff
column6: and the quasi-ambient excursions can be stiff and vaguely awkward.

column1: The frustrating part is that when the band dials down their ambition and plays it straight on the mid-album highlights ""The Balances"" and ""Vim Patior""
column2: they're untouchable
column3: with the perfect ratio of brutality to finesse. Iversen and his longtime creative partner Damien ""Blargh"" <span>Hammeren both favor thick
column4: crunchy guitar tones over the traditional tinny black metal attack
column5: and on pummelling tracks like ""The Balances"" they cleverly fit together just a couple of guitar parts to make a gestalt that sounds very big and very evil
column6: with hooky riffs snuck into the mix almost subliminally. It feels wrong to fault a bunch of musicians for being ambitious and wanting to challenge themselves and their audience
column7:
but when a band is so good at playing it straight and simple it's hard to argue that they even need to.

column1: 0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/18504/homepage_large.58eefb3c.jpg|Turn on the Bright Lights: The Tenth Anniversary Edition|2112.0|Interpol|['Rock'
column3: the story of Interpol's 2002 full-length debut Turn on the Bright Lights is almost annoyingly of its place and time: four guys meet in New York
column4: start a band
column5: make tightly-wound indie rock jams that sound great at your favorite mid-gentrification Williamsburg bar
column6: sign to a renowned independent label
column7: and the rest is history. But the early-aughts New York of Turn on the Bright Lights is not the young
column8: vibrant
column9: and impossibly cool place of cultural myth. It is a darker and more complicated place
column10: fraught with disappointment and disconnection. It is a crushingly real place
column11: rendered in such vivid emotional detail that it rings true even to those who have never set foot in the city. This stellar 10th Anniversary reissue documents the process by which a handful of pretty-good songs became a truly great album
column12: making it painfully and unequivocally clear that Turn on the Bright Lights is the sum of its players
column13: not its influences.

column1: In retrospect
column2: 2002 may have been the very year that we stopped talking about how music sounds
column3: and started talking about what other music it sounds like. ""Interpol sounds like Joy Division"" was one of the first critical observations to turn into a full-fledged meme. In the intervening years
column4: other bands have sounded a whole lot more like Joy Division
column5: and the comparison now feels like just that: a comparison. While Joy Division could channel enormous amounts of energy through Ian Curtis's intense delivery
column6: Interpol pulled off a real magic trick by constructing a framework complex and dynamic enough to bring singer Paul Banks' inscrutable deadpan to life. Banks's words can be downright laughable on paper
column7: and are often sung as if WRITTEN OUT IN ALL CAPS WITH NO PUNCTUATION. But from this insistent
column8: exaggerated blankness
column9: the band coaxed a genuinely unnerving sense of alienation and melancholy. These songs are packed with a staggering amount of rhythmic and melodic tension
column10: sometimes amplifying minuscule expressive nuances in Banks's voice
column11: and sometimes drawing attention to their disconcerting absence.

column1: Each individual member of the band has his own role in piecing this puzzle together. Drummer Sam Fogarino is the perfect anchor for Carlos Dengler's busy
column2: melodic bass lines
column3: keeping the rhythm section forceful and grounded. Guitarist Daniel Kessler is the album's unsung hero
column4: expanding the band's dynamic range by oscillating between wide
column5: monolithic chords and narrow
column6: winding leads. The album's second single ""NYC"" achieves two unlikely successes pioneered by Matador labelmates Chavez: structuring a ballad around loud
column7: steady drums and withholding all bass guitar until the chorus. ""The New"" slips a disco bass line under a morass of swirling
column8: detuned guitars. There are a lot of things about Turn on the Bright Lights that should not work
column9: and would not work were they not so carefully thought through and artfully implemented.

column1: Three batches of demo recordings are far and away the most interesting bonus materials on this extensive reissue
column2: as they show just how close the album came to not working. The first three-song demo
column3: recorded in 1998 and featuring album cuts ""PDA"" and ""Roland""
column4: comes off as an unremarkable practice tape by a band with lots of good ideas but insufficient energy and chemistry to pull them all together. The second three-song demo
column5: recorded at Brooklyn's Rare Book Room in 1999
column6: is more worked over with decidedly mixed results; there are some jarringly tacky too-loud keyboards here
column7: and a sing-spoken interlude that can't help but bring to mind Crazy Town's ""Butterfly"". Somewhat ironically
column8: it is only the third and final four-song demo
column9: recorded at the band's practice space
column10: where Interpol stops sounding like four guys in a practice space tentatively running through busy rock songs. Much of this can be credited to Fogarino
column11: who joined the band between their second and third tapes and brought with him a rhythmic confidence and swagger that provided the crucial missing piece of Interpol's singular sound.

column1: This progression of demo recordings documents not only the evolution of the band's playing
column2: but also their increasing attention to texture and ambiance. As the group grew more confident
column3: the gritty sonics of their demos became less incidental to the songs they were making
column4: and more a part of the songs themselves. Producer Peter Katis did an amazing job of preserving and amplifying this rawness
column5: and the band themselves crucially revisited many elements of their demos to better suit their evolving capabilities. The slight changes that Fogarino made to the kick pattern at the beginning of ""PDA"" completely make the song's signature introduction
column6: taking it from ""oh
column7: there's a drumbeat"" to ""OH
column8: there's THAT drumbeat."" Banks gave his lyrics a thorough tune-up before the recording the album
column9: excising his most rhythmically formless lines and shoring up the critical interplay between his voice and the rest of the band.

column1: The extensive liner notes here are as much about the city in which Interpol operated as the band itself. It's certainly interesting
column2: especially for those who are up on their New York City indie rock landmarks. And while the photographs included here do a good job of documenting the physical locations where this album was born
column3: the album itself conveys the setting in a deeper way. Suggesting that this album is simply a product of its time and place is no less naive than suggesting that anyone who has ever been in love could easily write
column4: arrange and record an amazing love song. There were a lot of good bands in New York in 2002
column5:
but only one band made this record.

"|17324.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/17324-turn-on-the-bright-lights-the-tenth-anniversary-edition/|9.5|Matt LeMay

Alicia Keys' fifth studio album opens the same way each one of her previous albums does: with a short
column2: pensive piano piece. The quiet ""De Novo Adagio"" is meant to set the stage for the drama to come
column3: but it handily accomplishes two other things as well. First
column4: it reminds listeners that Keys is a classically trained musician
column5: that she graduated from Professional Performing Arts School and studied at Columbia University. Her studies no longer determine her sound the way they once did
column6: but a moment like this reminds you she's a serious artist.

column1: Second: ""De Novo Adagio""
column2: which translates loosely to ""Adagio Again""
column3: signals that Girl on Fire is an album about rebirth and renewal. That girl on fire is a phoenix
column4: and to demonstrate that point
column5: ""Adagio"" segues seamlessly into ""Brand New Me""
column6: a slow-burning declaration of independence co-written with Scottish singer-songwriter Emeli Sandé. Keys excels at this kind of self-esteem anthem
column7: but this one feels a little too familiar-- an old way of introducing her new self. That song is followed by the Jamie xx-produced ""When It's All Over""
column8: and it's perhaps a sign that I'm listening to too much Taylor Swift that I naturally wondered what had happened in Keys' personal life to warrant a record so heavy on break-up songs. Then I remembered that it doesn't matter: Keys has retooled and reinvented herself
column9: however subtly and slightly
column10: on every album
column11: so it makes sense that she would use romantic tragedy as the engine for transformation.

column1: Four albums about rebirth
column2: however
column3: can become a bit predictable
column4: if not an outright drag. Neither ""Brand New Me"" nor ""When It's Over"" does much that Keys hasn't done in the past
column5: but then she drops ""New Day""
column6: a heavy banger that actually feels brand new. With her sharp eh-eh-eh-ehs and slightly accented delivery
column7: she sounds like she's channeling Rihanna without the regrettable drama that has sadly infected the ""Umbrella"" singer's most recent efforts. In a way this is exactly the kind of song we wish Rihanna were singing: something strong and forceful and self-assertive
column8: something that writes the happy ending we want for our pop stars. Keys throws herself into the song; her voice quavering during the rawer moments
column9: as though the notes are well within her range but the emotions are not.

column1: A collaboration with Swizz Beatz (Keys' husband) and Dr. Dre
column2: ""New Day"" has a transformative effect within the album
column3: whose middle is as strong as any sequence of songs Keys has recorded. After a rough start lyrically (""She's just a girl and she's on fire"")
column4: the title track features Keys' most powerful vocals and a too-brief cameo from Nicki Minaj
column5: who sounds like she's just getting started before her verse comes to an end. ""Fire We Make""
column6: her duet with Maxwell
column7: is an old-fashioned slow jam that doesn't have a whole lot of actual song to it and honestly doesn't need it. Instead
column8: it's an excuse for vocal and sexual fireworks from two of r&b's strongest singers
column9: with Keys' bold voice evocatively contrasting Maxwell's softer
column10: slightly hoarse delivery.

column1: Keys has always chosen her collaborators well
column2: and even when she's working with the ultimate alpha males (Kanye West on The Diary of Alicia Keys
column3: John Mayer on As I Am)
column4: she never lets anyone elbow her out of the spotlight. Still
column5: the announcement that she was doing a song with Bruno Mars and the Smeezingtons
column6: the team responsible for Cee Lo Green's ""Fuck You"" and Mars' own ""Grenade""
column7: was enough to arch some eyebrows. They're pop throwbacks
column8: but they throw back to a completely different pop era than Keys evokes
column9: and does anyone want to see this woman
column10: who seems to draw inspiration from Aretha and Pam Grier equally
column11: show up at the sockhop? Surprisingly
column12: ""Tears Always Win"" manages to split the difference between Keys and Mars
column13: and the retro flourishes-- the shuffling drumbeat
column14: the doo wop backing vocals-- reinforce rather than distract from the pain in Keys' vocals and lyrics. With its bedroom setting and emotional insomnia
column15: the song comes across like a sequel to ""Try Sleeping with a Broken Heart""
column16: holding its own against one of Key's finest moments.

column1: After that comes ""Not Even the King""
column2: which features just Keys and her piano. It's a respectable ballad
column3: albeit a bit too devoted to its own metaphor
column4: and it's refreshing to hear her in such a spare setting. But it also brings the album back down to earth
column5: stalling the momentum she'd established. Following the rhythmically and grammatically awkwardly ""Limitedless""
column6: a pair of fine ballads
column7: ""One Thing"" and ""101""
column8: sound good on their own but dour as back-to-back closers. The latter culminates in a loud coda that's among the heaviest passages Keys has recorded
column9: full of shouted hallelujahs and some startlingly violent beats. It's a risky move
column10: about as far from the pensive notes of ""De Novo Adagio"" as Keys could get
column11: but she doesn’t pull it off. Far too bombastic to be especially cathartic
column12: ""101"" makes for a gently unsatisfying conclusion to an otherwise assured album. It never quite lives up to its theme of rebirth
column13: but especially given the range and power she's showed in the past
column14:
it doesn't really need to.

0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/18637/homepage_large.ad154416.jpg|Wu-Block|30685.0|Wu-Block|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['E1']|2012-12-04 00:00:00|2012|2016-06-11 17:03:59.652442|"

You don't tune into a D-Block and Ghostface Killah collaborative project expecting surprises
column2: so here's the good news: There are absolutely none on Wu-Block. Neither Ghost nor the LOX have switched up their style in over a decade
column3: which makes listening to Wu-Block feel a little like watching a late-period Woody Allen film; before anyone opens their mouth
column4: you already know exactly how everyone will sound
column5: what they will talk about
column6: what the surroundings will look like. If you're drawn to Wu-Block
column7: it's probably at least in part for the way it promises
column8: for 50 minutes or so
column9: to shut the door on surprises.

column1: Luckily
column2: it's coming out
column3: as all Ghostface-related projects do
column4: right before the holiday season
column5: a moment when we're all a little fonder of hoary old institutions and a little more susceptible to nostalgia. Ghost and D-Block are mascots of an unchanging NYC
column6: as reliable as a  beloved slice joint. But there's a blurry line where ""reliable"" fades into ""stagnant
column7: and mileage will vary for rap fans where Wu-Block falls. (Me
column8: I still can't quite shake the memory that one of these guys
column9: Ghost
column10: was one of the most constantly surprising to ever do it.)

column1: The tone is established from the opening seconds: The first song is called “Crack Spot Stories"". It opens with the sound of Raekwon
column2: Jadakiss
column3: Ghost
column4: and Sheek arguing over who has the remote
column5: and the production is a faded soul loop. Sheek Louch nails the project's slightly-too-comfy vibe in one line: ""Fiends at the door
column6: I'm too lazy to let 'em in/ Turkey sandwich
column7: barbecue chips
column8: ESPN."" Ghost is ""chillin' in his robe
column9: while Raekwon is sitting with his ""leg back
column10: examining choices."" The scene is less crack-spot than man-cave
column11: a bunch of grouchy old guys cracking each other up with the door closed to the outside world.

column1: All of them sound great
column2: though
column3: and it's nice to hear them settle comfortably into their roles as older heads. Ghost is still finding vivid notes within his coke-sniffing kingpin fantasy persona
column4: which is more than a decade old. ""If I sneeze
column5: the left side of my nose might rip
column6: he yelps on ""Comin For Ya Head"". In that same verse
column7: he gives us some home potency remedies (""You eat seal meat
column8: dick stay up for a fuckin' week"") and takes us to ""a brutal rap battle in Zaire."" On ""Take Notice""
column9: he says ""I do hood yoga/ I pull muscles counting money
column10: need a new shoulder
column11: and in a club-scene verse on ""Pull Tha Cars Out""
column12: he shows off his still-sharp flair for imagery: ""A baby ghost appeared from the blunt smoke/ It lingered through her hair and set into her clothes.""

column1: Neither Sheek Louch nor Styles P ever had golden ages like Ghost's to live up to: They've been endearing knuckleheads pretty much since Day One
column2: and they're as enjoyable
column3: more or less
column4: as always. Sheek Louch's ""winded touch-football participant"" flow tends to make his dumb jokes hit harder than they should (see ""My chain lower than your GPA
column5: from ""Take Notice"")
column6: but they make his unintentionally funny lines even funnier: ""My bars is prenatal!"" he yells on ""Comin For Ya Head"". Styles P has always flowed like steel shavings (one of the most quotable lines of his career is still ""I don't give a fuck who you are/ So fuck who you are"")
column7: and his best line here is when he sneers  the line ""probably in the crib getting high watching Fargo"" with a fierceness all out of proportion to the act of watching the movie Fargo.

column1: There are other familiar faces
column2: too: Cappadonna
column3: yelling about a girl with a ""thunder butt"" on ""Pour Tha  Martini""; GZA working out an over-labored ""life-as-car"" metaphor on ""Drivin Round""
column4: a song that also features a lightly crooning Erykah Badu. Raekwon sounds amazing
column5: always
column6: but his cadences and slang have budged so little over the years that everything he says has started to sound the same
column7: giving his lines a ""pull-string Raekwon"" feel: ""Sit back
column8: laughin' with a stack and a clapper."" See? You know exactly how that sounds.

column1: But again
column2: that familiarity is the point of Wu-Block. Everyone on the album sounds engaged and happy to be in the room. There are a handful of goofy skits
column3: and a lot of hilarious cross-chatter in the album's margins: after  the song ""All in Together"" ends
column4: they stick around to make fun of people who wear fake jewelry. On ""Take Notice""
column5: Ghost yells about the cold he has
column6: acting grumpy and pulling the covers around him in the booth. ""He's tellin' me to throw onions and garlic in my socks-- I ain’t with all that! Hand me some TheraFlu
column7: some NyQuil or something."" Small joys
column8: but real ones that give Wu-Block a rap Statler-and-Waldorf feel. The conversation has long since passed these guys by
column9: so they're having their own. You can visit whenever you like
column10:
but close the door on your way out.

0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/18564/homepage_large.d52aca79.jpg|Night Has a Thousand Screams|29264.0|Umberto|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Rock Action']|2012-12-04 00:00:00|2012|2016-06-11 17:04:00.248994|"

Pieces is a slasher horror feature from 1982 that revolves around a serial killer who tries to construct a jigsaw puzzle from human body parts. The idea of bastardizing existing forms appears to hold great appeal for Kansas City musician Matt Hill
column2: who records schlocky instrumental fare indebted to a broad range of Z-grade giallo peddlers under the Umberto name. His prior work
column3: of which the deathly Not Not Fun LP Prophecy of the Black Widow was a highlight
column4: provided
column5: in Hill's own words
column6: ""soundtracks to films that don't exist"". There still isn't a bona fide soundtrack that bears the Umberto name
column7: but he took one step closer to realizing that dream by performing the music on Night Has a Thousand Screams to a screening of Pieces at the Glasgow Music and Film Festival earlier this year. Mogwai's Stuart Braithwaite was in attendance at the screening
column8: and subsequently offered to release the music on his Rock Action imprint. The results are a fractional advance on what came before
column9: with the blood running a little thicker and brighter than prior Umberto releases.

column1: To draw on an analogy from the film work to which Hill is so clearly enthralled
column2: Night of a Thousand Screams is like picking up a copy of Buddy Giovinazzo's masterfully frayed Combat Shock after gorging on the base slice and dice chills of the Friday the 13th series. Prophecy's opening cut
column3: ""Temple Room""
column4: was a piece of Claudio Simonetti worship that was both a little too in awe of its source and lacking in the necessary tools to make it ooze under your skin. In short
column5: it felt like a tinny replica cowering in the wake of a far bolder creation. Goblin's work was purposefully big
column6: with every power chord designed to hammer into your chest. It's no wonder Justice found so much much fertile territory to mine from the band's output on Audio
column7: Video
column8: Disco. Hill has wisely chosen not to match Simonetti at his game here
column9: instead edging toward the low rent chills of Italian soundtrack master Fabio Frizzi
column10: in particular his superior City of the Living Dead score.

column1: The influence of Frizzi is primarily manifested in the choral work
column2: presumably lifted from Hill's sample library. It's a great sweep of male humming that resurfaces at pertinent points in the record
column3: reaching a maximal crescendo during the appropriately named final track
column4: ""End Credits"". Night Has a Thousand Screams is structured around subtly repeating motifs like that
column5: subtly bringing back small keyboard parts to mirror the way a horror film will often return to its central theme song. At its worst it borders on a barely palatable mesh of kitsch and homage
column6: such as the cheap Ghost Box knock-off ""Paralyzed"". It's when Hill reaches into purposefully more restrained areas that the album picks up its eerie glow. ""The Puzzle"" is a brief
column7: beatless passage full of cold vapors; ""The Pool"" is even better
column8: combining thudding keys with further choral enhancements that briefly make it sound like a lost Lamberto Bava score composed by Popol Vuh.

column1: Similar moments of inspiration arise sporadically on Night Has a Thousand Screams
column2: but the overall feel is often tugged down by Hill's tendency to lapse into genre exercises. He creates his own world through work like ""The Waterbed""
column3: which succeeds by melding sparse
column4: hissy textures with a sudden jolt into a stiffly mechanized final third full of siren wails. In a market flooded with electronic acts reaching toward horror soundtrack work to fulfill their ""dark"" remit
column5: it often feels like supply is far outweighing demand
column6: making it hard to stand out from the pack. Hill's work is steadily gaining its own hue
column7:
and this album is a step toward a recognizable Umberto sound that won't instantly be tagged with all the influences he so adores. It's interesting that he's had a minor breakthrough by having some visual stimulus to compose around. A fully-fledged soundtrack assignment might push him even harder to create his own recognizable strain of musical terror.
