column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/18561/homepage_large.86dbbb44.jpg|...And Don't Deliver Us From Evil|30848.0|Forgotten Tomb|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Agonia']|2012-12-04 00:00:00|2012|2016-06-11 17:04:01.495657|"

I'm slightly ashamed to say that
column2: until earlier this year
column3: I'd more or less written off Italy's Forgotten Tomb as a gothy clone of the Swedish black metallers Shining. It took seeing a spellbinding live performance in Germany and the arrival of their latest album to convince me I was wrong. From there
column4: I delved into their back catalog. Their earlier material generally stays the course of straightforward depressive black metal-- it doesn't get much grimmer than an Ildjarn tribute album-- but somewhere around 2007's Negative Megalomania
column5: the band's sound began to shift
column6: and a more dynamic
column7: even rock-based approach took over. That's not to say Forgotten Tomb pulled a Darkthrone and started aping Manilla Road
column8: but there was a definite spring in their step that hadn't been there previously. They carried that frosty bounce through to their next couple records
column9: and now
column10: on …And Don't Deliver Us From Evil
column11: they've hit their groove.

column1: Opener ""Deprived""
column2: kicks off as full-bore black 'n' roll banger that sinks into gloomier territory halfway through then switches into post-metal mode for the remaining two minutes of shiny acoustic chords and punchy drums that merrily trip along Shoegaze Alley. And that's just the first song. There's a lot of genre blending going on here; lines blur almost faster than they register
column3: and Forgotten Tomb have clearly got goldish-caliber attention spans on some of these tunes. The title track begins as atmospheric black metal as narrated by Attila Csihar's hoarsest of croaks then dips back into languid black 'n' roll swing. ""Cold Summer"" offers a slow
column4: menacing shadow of their former suicidal sound
column5: while ""Let's Torture Each Other"" is a catchy
column6: perverted love song for shut-ins. ""Love Me Like You'd Love the Death"" is Type O Negative gothic that sees vocalist Herr Morbid abusing his vocal chords over slow
column7: slithering blackness with doomy underpinnings. The clean
column8: hollow vocals on ""Adrift"" are even more reminiscent of Type O's Peter Steele. ""Nullifying Tomorrow"" ends the album on a sad Katatonia-esque note-- echoes of the Swedish sadsacks can be found throughout the record
column9: as moody rock and atmospheric black metal battle for dominance (doom and goth put up a good fight
column10: but are ultimate quashed by melodic chords and desperate growls).

column1: Forgotten Tomb are an interesting band
column2: and one that refuses to fall into any of the neat little boxes we writers have spent so many decades getting cozy for them. They remind me of a more melancholy and less aggressive Faustcoven
column3: or a more evolved Shining (far from a clone
column4: they've released the record that Kvarforth & Co. should've done ages ago). Their willingness to explore sounds and draw in influences from outside the approved spectrum for black metal has resulted in one hell of a good record
column5: one that continues to grow with every listen. Their roots still show from time to time
column6: but it's become apparent that Forgotten Tomb have outgrown their depressive shackles and
column7: unlike many of their peers
column8:
embraced evolution.

0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/18566/homepage_large.01f06f8f.jpg|Bish Bosch|4636.0|Scott Walker|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['4AD']|2012-12-03 00:00:00|2012|2016-06-11 17:04:02.290968|"

Bish Bosch starts with 30 seconds of what sounds like a jackhammer and ends with a funereal rendition of ""Jingle Bells"" for solo xylophone. In-between
column2: there are tense silences
column3: horror-movie strings
column4: and 20-minute songs without verses or choruses. At the center of it all is an old man wailing about cutting off his own balls and feeding them to someone. The man seems to think this is some kind of opera. He is Scott Walker
column5: and he puts the situation to us like this: ""I've severed my reeking gonads/ Fed them to your shrunken face.""

column1: ""Gonads"" and ""sever"" are good indications of the vocabulary and subject matter at work here. Like Walker's last two albums-- 1995's Tilt and 2006's The Drift-- Bish Bosch is austere
column2: high-minded music about a dirty world where people always seem to be getting castrated or mutilated by something or another. It features drums and guitars and other passing references to rock music
column3: but its deepest roots are in the dissonant
column4: turn-of-the century compositions by Stravinsky
column5: Schoenberg
column6: Webern
column7: and Berg-- music that divided its early audiences between applause
column8: hissing
column9: and laughter. More than anything Walker's latter-day albums sound like a parody of what people probably think of when they think of ""avant-garde."" No scene captures them better than video footage taken during the recording of The Drift
column10: in which Walker-- a friendly looking man in a baseball hat-- instructs a percussionist on exactly how he would like him to punch a side of beef.

column1: The story of Walker's career is a strange and amazing one. He grew up in Ohio but spent most of his life in England and Europe. He was cover-boy famous by his early 20s and a has-been by 30. Between 1967 and 1969 he released a series of orchestral pop albums whose stories about Joseph Stalin and childhood prostitution contrasted-- sometimes beautifully
column2: sometimes just cynically-- with their high-gloss arrangements. No man has ever sung the word ""gonorrhea"" with more poise.

column1: Between the 1970s and 1990s
column2: he effectively disappeared
column3: putting out a few sub-mediocre country albums
column4: a few new songs with his former group the Walker Brothers (including ""The Electrician""
column5: which is really the starting point for the music he's making now)
column6: and 1984's Climate of Hunter. The output of his unexpected second act-- Tilt
column7: The Drift
column8: and now Bish Bosch-- have taken 20 years to record. Scarcity creates demand-- this is basic economics. With an artist like Walker
column9: though
column10: long waiting times between albums serve mostly to reinforce the idea that he is careful and deliberate
column11: and in turn
column12: the idea that his music is not just product
column13: but that purest of things which cannot be rushed: Art.

column1: Besides the appropriately exhausting 20-minute sweep of ""SDSS14+13B (Zercon
column2: A Flagpole Sitter)""
column3: the best songs on Bish Bosch-- ""'See You Don't Bump His Head'""
column4: ""Corps De Blah""
column5: and ""Epizootics!""-- are also the most immediate. Walker's approach here
column6: especially compared to Tilt and The Drift
column7: is almost cartoonish: Big
column8: bouncy saxophones
column9: bright trumpet fanfares and
column10: on ""Corps""
column11: what sounds like a small dog barking. These songs work for one simple reason: In the midst of all Walker's void-courting experimentation
column12: they give listeners something vaguely familiar to hang on to.

column1: Here and there
column2: the contrast between the brainy and the base is so deliberate it sounds like pandering. When Walker sings “If shit were music
column3: you'd be a brass band!"" on ""Zercon""
column4: for example
column5: he's probably trying to remind people that this is all supposed to be on some level funny
column6: which makes it instantly less funny-- not to mention less tragic-- than the Walker who sang lines like ""I've become a giant
column7: I fill every street/ I dwarf the rooftops
column8: I hunchback the moon
column9: stars dance at my feet"" in a song about an overworked husband whose only liberation in life comes from whores.

column1: As much as it can sound like it stands alone
column2: Bish Bosch is part of a tradition of music that tried to find new ways to articulate that same old misery. Wagner operas
column3: Mahler symphonies
column4: the brutal cabaret of Jacques Brel (who Walker covered extensively in the 1960s)
column5: David Bowie
column6: Diamanda Galás
column7: the aggressive anti-music of no wave
column8: even early Swans: this is music that doesn't sound exactly like Scott Walker but makes Walker's bleakness and theatricality sound that much more familiar. Bish Bosch is difficult music that was intended to sound difficult and be enjoyed primarily by people who enjoy difficult experiences. The irony is that it is difficult in conventional ways.

column1: Walker's career has always been surrounded with the whispery
column2: romantic myth of genius
column3: and we need myths like that-- myths about people who seem to forge their own path into the wilderness of their art
column4: slowly and alone. The danger is to pretend that the music exists somewhere above us
column5: or
column6: like a carnival ride
column7: is something we have to be This Smart to understand.

column1: Like the movie director David Lynch
column2: Walker is an artist that people-- fans and non-fans-- seem bent on ""getting
column3: as though there was anything to ""get"" in the first place. Let's pretend there isn't. Let's pretend that when Walker tells a ""you're so fat"" joke halfway through ""Zercon""
column4: it's not a metaphor for anything
column5: but an insult about fat people.

column1: A few minutes later
column2: he breaks down and starts screaming
column3: ""Did you ever throw your own mother's food back at her? Did you ever tell her 'Take this junk away'? What kind of an unnatural son would do that to his own mother?"" Let's pretend that the moment has nothing to do with 5th-century Moorish history or the astronomy behind brown dwarf stars. Let's pretend it's simpler than that. Behind all its obscure references and theatrics
column4:
Bish Bosch is a catalog of basic human cruelty-- a subject no footnote could ever make any easier to understand.

"|17387.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/17387-bish-bosch/|8.0|Mike Powell

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/18647/homepage_large.005d9129.jpg|Super Ultra|29761.0|Charli XCX|['Pop/R&B']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['self-released']|2012-12-03 00:00:00|2012|2016-06-11 17:04:03.014207|"

British electro pop singer Charli XCX's embrace of the mixtape makes perfect sense: It fits her association with dance music acts (a genre that's well suited to the format)
column2: her obvious debt to M.I.A. (who released her debut mixtape Piracy Funds Terrorism all the way back in 2004)
column3: and the importance of a rebellious
column4: anti-authoritarian streak to her overall image. The free mixtape's direct line of communication from artist to listener
column5: unimpeded by A&R execs
column6: and the anarchic
column7: genre-smashing creative approach that it engenders feel very compatible with the times
column8: and with XCX's internet-mashing creative hybrids. Super Ultra is the second one she's released this year
column9: after spring's Heartbreaks and Earthquakes
column10: and it's an interesting experiment
column11: if far from flawless.

column1: The eight-track EP opens on a low note-- probably its lowest-- with a track featuring internet personality Brooke Candy
column2: who is best known for appearing in Grimes' music video for ""Genesis"" and has a sideline in being a terrible rapper. The beat has a pleasing blunted feel and a catchy hook driven by a funky keyboard riff
column3: but Candy's contribution sounds like the female half of a discarded turn-of-the-millennium Ja Rule duet
column4: down to the outdated slang and submissive-chick role she plays in her lyrics. With her nasal voice and awkwardly-fitting accent she comes off like the female Mickey Avalon who
column5: much like Mickey Avalon
column6: no-one who actually likes rap music could possibly enjoy in any unironic way. ""Heatwave"" offers a convincing recreation of a brand of 80s electroclash that's been redone a vast number of times since the genre's heyday
column7: while the droopy ""Moments in Love"" suggests that Charli might be better off with a supervisory eye looking over her shoulder. (If there wasn't one-- the presence of a link to Atlantic's UK division at the bottom of the page that homes Super Ultra suggests that it's not entirely free of label ties.)

column1: But there are a few bright moments on Super Ultra. ""Velvet Dreaming (Luv)"" is spacey and ravey in a way that bears more than a passing resemblance to the Orb's ""Little Fluffy Clouds""
column2: and the ecstatic synthesizer crescendo accompanied by an extended sample of dialogue from True Romance that pops up 30 seconds in would likely have gotten it the axe if she'd tried placing it on an album for a label. The same goes for ""Glow""
column3: which has a beat that sounds like Clams Casino and a weary
column4: dissipated vocal that doesn't fit the established outlines of a pop star personality.

column1: And then there's the record-closing ""Forgiveness""
column2: which is legitimately gorgeous and weird. It begins as a plaintive piano ballad before waves of strings and drums sweep over and it transforms into a minor-key dirge. It's awash in vocal effects that suggest some sort of emotional breakdown
column3: along with an insistent cowbell that somehow feels vaguely maniacal and menacing in the context of everything that's going on. Charli's vocals show off all of her star-worthy talents
column4: but the lyrics go deeper than self-doubt
column5: all the way down to self-loathing and a raw
column6: unembellished portrait of a dark psychic space. After listening a dozen times I realized that it most reminded me of of Montreal's epic meltdown ""The Past is a Grotesque Animal"". ""Forgiveness"" is a fascinatingly strange song
column7: and who knows if it would have made it onto Super Ultra if it had been intended to shift units on a pop star level. In any case
column8:
it's a compelling argument for letting these kind of pop stars off the leash.

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/18635/homepage_large.c424d6b4.jpg|Black Mamba|29847.0|Cut Hands|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Susan Lawly']|2012-12-03 00:00:00|2012|2016-06-11 17:04:03.720581|"

Working in an accessible realm may be the only true shock left for artists who have spent lengthy careers operating as provocateurs. The sheer amount of time William Bennett spent terrorizing audiences as part of the long-running noise outfit Whitehouse suggested he would be the last person to land in such a place. But
column2: as the 2011 album by his self-styled ""afro-noise"" project Cut Hands demonstrated
column3: even someone with a fondness for calling songs ""I'm Comin' Up Your Ass"" is capable of growing old with a certain amount of grace. Afro Noise I wasn't exactly commercial-- Bennett won't be bothering the Top 40 any time soon-- but anyone expecting to hear a saw-toothed desecration of the African music he was citing as a key influence was left empty handed. On Black Mamba
column4: which follows the lead of its predecessor by tying together a collection of new and previously released material
column5: those rough edges are flattened out even further.

column1: The major factor that ties the Cut Hands material to Bennett's work in Whitehouse is in his fondness for the straightforward. There's a sledgehammer-like simplicity to his other band's bludgeoning. Here
column2: nothing splinters off in an unexpected direction
column3: or ends up in a place radically different from whence it came. The standout cut is the title track
column4: possibly the most groove-oriented work Bennett has ever released
column5: where cacophonic beats are driven through carefully plotted tempo changes. There isn't much more to it other than a series of looped drum sounds going to war with one another
column6: but it's an exhausting and exhilarating ride
column7: and one that fully delivers on the promise of the similarly inclined ""Stabbers Conspiracy"" from the prior Cut Hands album. That we don’t get to return to the feel of ""Black Mamba"" is a shame
column8: although after years of working in Whitehouse's one-mode world it's perhaps unsurprising to see Bennett taking the chance to stretch out.

column1: A theme that binds both Cut Hands records
column2: and sweeps back to Whitehouse's 2007 album Racket (which bore a barely perceptible African influence)
column3: is a series of tracks that bear the name ""Nzambi"". Here
column4: ""Nzambi la Ngonde"" and ""Nzambi la Muini"" consist of washy ambient passages
column5: with both edging away from prickly beginnings by picking up a glassy texture reminiscent of Oneohtrix Point Never. The album oscillates between that kind of rudderless drifting and more layered
column6: beat-oriented work. Occasionally it's a little too basic. ""No Spare No Soul"" spends too long with a beat echoing in place before Bennett dumps a batch of digital discord onto its second half. ""Brown-Brown"" is better
column7: subtly building off a fidgety sound source that resembles someone hammering a rhythm out on a skeletal rib cage.

column1: The bulk of Black Mamba is positioned in a more equable place than the album that preceded it
column2: although it might be better received now that Bennett's fans have had more time to adjust to this mindset. Still
column3: a track like ""54 Needles"" may come as a shock
column4: especially as it's hard not to reach for an adjective like ""cloying"" when trying to describe it. Whitehouse may be many things
column5: but sentimental certainly isn't one of them. At this point it's better to look at Cut Hands as an entity unto itself that occasionally bears scars torn from a previous life. Tellingly
column6: Black Mamba becomes more robust when Bennett slings one of those hooks into the sound. It's there in the seething pessimism that pours out of ""Erzulie D'en Tort"" and it's there in the blackout beats that stack up unremittingly on the title track. Cut Hands may find Bennett in surprise user-friendly mode
column7:
but it succeeds most often when he gives up the fight against familiar feelings of tension and confrontation.

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/18589/homepage_large.f1063789.jpg|On Triple Beams|6917.0|Tyvek|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['In the Red']|2012-12-03 00:00:00|2012|2016-06-11 17:04:03.934113|"

Tyvek are a Detroit band
column2: which is definitely a point of pride for them. In interviews
column3: they talk about the city not just as a place where they derive inspiration or play shows
column4: but as a place where the community is obligated to fill a vital role. ""I feel like in other cities there might be more of a separation from the different crews or different scenes
column5: whereas in Detroit people are supporting each other just by default so they have something to do on a Saturday night
column6: frontman Kevin Boyer said. ""It's definitely a survivor kind of city."" In the past
column7: something like ""survivalism"" made itself apparent in the band's near-hardcore aggression
column8: especially on their 2010 album Nothing Fits. That's still present for On Triple Beams
column9: but in a key moment
column10: they soften somewhat to deliver a unifying anthem for Detroit's punks
column11: nerds
column12: and audiophiles fighting for something to do on Saturday night.

column1: That anthem is ""Wayne County Roads""
column2: which takes its name from <a href=""http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wayne_County
column3: _Michigan"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">the greater Detroit area. The song's title is chanted in response to the line
column4: ""Can you explain to me just how we get home?"" It's a song not about the sort of ""white flight"" city desertion from the history books
column5: but about recent
column6: specific young people ditching the city for other places. ""Friends that I hold so dear
column7: it's sad to report/ Not hardly one soul around to defend the fort."" It's a depressing notion
column8: but the title is chanted as a sort of rallying cry-- there are fewer soldiers around
column9: but that's all the more reason to fucking do something.

column1: Appropriately
column2: the song comes right after a track called ""City of a Dream""
column3: which discusses the recent efforts to ""rebuild"" Detroit. Boyer's view of the current situation is cynical
column4: though he sings it over a cheerful progression: ""City of a dream
column5: but it's just a lie/ You can write about it in the Sunday Times."" But aside from the standard bitterness seemingly directed at politicians and the media
column6: there are glimpses at real life in the city
column7: like working at Temple Bar or the movie theater. If the allusions to the big picture make On Triple Beams feel contemporary or significant
column8: it's the descriptions of ""Midwest Basements"" and the MOCAD namedrop that make it feel special.

column1: And since it's Tyvek we're talking about here
column2: most of the tracks emanate urgency in nearly every respect. The guitars are buzzy and loud
column3: the rhythms are quick
column4: the drums crash
column5: the lyrics are densely packed into a short span of time
column6: and Boyer spits them out with punk rock confidence. His words are often eloquent
column7: but sometimes
column8: shit's just too frustrating for poetry. On ""Little Richard""
column9: he sings about not being able to afford rent or heat
column10: which eventually leads to
column11: ""Click clack click clack click clack FUCK/ We've got a live one
column12: we've got a live one!"" It's a simple
column13: understandable descent into nonsensical anger.

column1: More often than not
column2: tackling current events on a punk record can end with corny and terrible results. But Boyer and Tyvek succeed because they don't set out to make a condescending
column3: chastising political record. Yes
column4: they allude to the current state of Detroit
column5: but they also reference what sound like personal details from their own lives: friends moving out of town
column6: sleeping in Midwestern basements
column7: getting drunk
column8: forcing the band into the van by 3pm
column9: working tomorrow with Steve
column10: etc. It's not a romantic view of Detroit at all
column11: but idealism has never been Tyvek's thing. Do they offer a great reason to come to town and support the local scene? Hell no. But that's not what they're trying to do. With their urgent
column12: sometimes aggressive
column13: sometimes anthemic delivery
column14:
they show us Detroit from their vantage point.

Considered on image alone
column2: Dragged into Sunlight might be the most fascinating new recruit within extreme metal for the better part of the last decade. Like bank robbers on a job or mercenaries on a mission
column3: the British quartet appears uniformly in balaclavas; the holes in the fabric are invitations of intrigue about the minds
column4: lives and pasts of the four anonymous members. And when they play live
column5: the musicians turn their backs on the audience
column6: closing themselves to the house to again invoke wonder about just what they’re doing. Those conditions certainly aren't new for heavy metal
column7: a genre replete with one-man bands
column8: figure-obscuring robes
column9: and pioneers who've still never performed in public. Coupled
column10: however
column11: with Dragged into Sunlight's forthright willingness to not only tour but also discuss its intentions and influences and irritations with the world
column12: they do create a strangely magnetic allure
column13: conjuring the idea of a band allegiant to its name-- a dark figure
column14: reluctantly forced into public view to share its grim view of the world. ""Our inspiration is very much a natural creation
column15: spurred from months
column16: if not years
column17: of frustrated murderous intent
column18: the band told Metallomusikum last year. ""Imagine each micro-social interaction stuffed into one massive wrecking ball. Every time someone pissed you off and you wanted to tear their jaw off
column19: concealed
column20: building and ready to burst at any moment."" Who else would you rather rage with?

column1: This public chiaroscuro seems to be one reason that Dragged into Sunlight's second LP
column2: Widowmaker
column3: has been so righteously anticipated: Here is a band
column4: after all
column5: of purported but unnamed extreme metal veterans
column6: willing to take potshots at most anyone in interviews and back it with their own agitated magpie music. Indeed
column7: 2009's Hatred for Mankind offered a potent recombination of death metal
column8: black metal
column9: shocking samples
column10: and relentless production. On the memorably named ""Lashed to the Grinder and Stoned to Death""
column11: for example
column12: Dragged into Sunlight plunged through hideous doom depths only to reemerge with both speed and vigor
column13: a four-piece thrashing as one against the world. In interviews
column14: Dragged into Sunlight griped about the metal community's ever-growing mold of stylistic conformity; on tape
column15: they seemed capable of more than complaints
column16: a band capable of actually sounding
column17: well
column18: new.

column1: Widowmaker suffers from that sensation. Due to factors like other jobs
column2: other bands
column3: and the 300-mile geographical spread between the members
column4: Dragged into Sunlight has been working on Widowmaker-- a three-part
column5: 40-minute suite intended as one piece of music-- for three years. Both the process and ambition show as seams here
column6: meaning that these 40 minutes sound like a cycle through influences and an unrealized aspiration to unite them under one release. Late last year
column7: talking to Decibel about the just-finished record
column8: the band rolled through a list of Widowmaker touchstones-- ""It's doom-- there are influences from Eyehategod
column9: Grief-- but then there's some thrashier elements
column10: and there's a bit of High on Fire
column11: Trap Them
column12: even Om in there
column13: too."" Those components are all clearly identifiable here
column14: from Part Three's down-tuned downturn to Part Two's sudden circle pit initiation. For the first 15 minutes
column15: Dragged into Sunlight even does its best Godspeed
column16: weaving a somber guitar around whispers of stately violin
column17: down-the-abyss traces of noise
column18: and recordings of serial killers talking about the rewards of their work. It's an interesting piece
column19: but when it ends
column20: Dragged into Sunlight flips a switch of convenience by plowing instantly into the howls and wallops of death metal. That's the net effect of Widowmaker
column21: an album that finds Dragged into Sunlight working through strong parts of doom or thrash
column22: noise or drone but never actually welding them into one. Widowmaker is named for
column23: as the band told The Quietus
column24: a heartache that ""builds and builds and your heart is basically exploding."" But the album itself is more akin to vertigo
column25: with the stylistic disconnects and sudden switches making the record as a whole forgettable at best and vexing at worst.

column1: Widowmaker isn't without its rewards: Toward the end of the three-part suite
column2: the band repeatedly cycles through near-silence (a lugubrious field recording from the Czech Republic's Bone Church circles like a sinister breeze) and the record's most furious bursts. Despite Dragged into Sunlight's insistence on being identified as one unit
column3: these moments offer some of the album’s most motivated and moving performances. A skittering drum solo
column4: for instance
column5: lifts the whole band through a drone and into a phosphorescent surge; during another relatively calm pass
column6: the guitar’s tone and patience are enviable
column7: the slowly rising riff setting a paradoxically grim but inviting scene. And in Part Two
column8: they dart around a serial killer's ramblings
column9: spotlighting the unease as he talks about himself as a mass murderer. These bursts renew Hatred for Mankind's promise of fresh invective.

column1: But by and large
column2: Widowmaker hoists Dragged into Sunlight with their own petard
column3: turning that once-welcome eclecticism and adventurousness into the weapon that disrupts the payoff. It's not that these 40 minutes are too extreme or overly dependent on too many ideas; it's that Dragged into Sunlight haven't found out how to synthesize their best impulses and broad ambitions into a whole. The parts generally work
column4: but they rarely work together. And from a band that insists upon the collective identity mattering much more than the constituent parts
column5: that's an outcome equivalent to
column6: as they might put it
column7:
""frustrated murderous intent.""

Listening to Massive Attack's debut album
column2: Blue Lines
column3: 21 years after its initial release is like reading an old William Gibson novel that describes the then-near future
column4: which is now the present
column5: with unsettling precision. Nearly every song offers a sound currently in use in music's taste-making leading edge. Robert ""3D"" Del Naja's chopped-up vocals on the album-opening ""Safe From Harm"" sound freakishly like the chorus to Kanye et al's ""Mercy"" (even if Ye actually lifted it from DJ Screw
column6: who was developing his idiosyncratic style 5
column7: 000 miles away from Bristol
column8: England at almost the exact same time Massive were recording Blue Lines). The chunky
column9: palm-muted guitar riff on ""One Love"" is almost identical to the one on ""Ahh Shit"" from Jeremih's brilliant Late Nights with Jeremih. The subzero space-reggae beat to ""Five Man Army"" could easily be a highlight of any number of fashionable rappers' mixtapes.

column1: When Del Najas
column2: Grant ""Daddy G"" Marshall
column3: and Andrew ""Mushroom"" Vowles were recording Blue Lines
column4: the sub-genre called trip-hop hadn't been invented. But at its heart
column5: Blue Lines is a hip-hop record
column6: although one marbled with streaks of soul
column7: dub
column8: dance music
column9: and psychedelic rock. The fact that its primary audience in America was made up largely of ravers and alternative rockers doesn't change that. And their accomplishments stand out even further next to what was happening elsewhere in the hip-hop world at the time. Straight Outta Compton
column10: It Takes a Nation of Millions to Hold Us Back
column11: Paul's Boutique
column12: and 3 Feet High and Rising were all still just a few of years old in 1991
column13: and so was the idea of beatmaking as an art unto itself. The blocky rhythms and minimal arrangements that defined rap's identity in the 1980s were just starting to be replaced by the deep
column14: organic textures that would define its 90s
column15: and Blue Lines was at the forefront.

column1: When Massive Attack first arrived
column2: hip-hop in the UK was still figuring itself out. For years the scene there
column3: such as it was
column4: focused mainly on reproducing trends that had already fallen out of fashion by the time they made it across the Atlantic. That lack of identity was probably an asset for Massive Attack. They didn't have to compete against their contemporaries to see who could sample which Jimmy Castor Bunch break first
column5: or worry about conforming to any outsider whose preconceptions about hip-hop authenticity might not include prog-rock samples or a lush chill-out anthem like ""Unfinished Sympathy"". Another asset was Neneh Cherry
column6: whose Raw Like Sushi
column7: which Del Naja and Vowles worked on
column8: provided a genre-bending inspiration for Blue Lines
column9: as well as a bankroll to record it. (Cherry even paid the group a salary and let them turn her kid's bedroom into an impromptu studio.)

column1: In fact
column2: those Raw Like Sushi credits (Vowles' for programming
column3: Del Naja's for co-writing ""Manchild"") were the only real music-industry bona fides any of the principal contributors to Blue Lines had going into it
column4: aside from vocalists Shara Nelson and roots reggae veteran Horace Andy. But somehow the group realized a remarkable and seamless sonic identity. That's clear from the arresting opener ""Safe From Harm""
column5: which spins an aggressive drumbeat
column6: Del Naja's rap
column7: Nelson's soulful vocals
column8: and a mist of sustained minor-key synths around an intimidatingly muscular bass loop. From that moment
column9: every major part of the Massive Attack profile is already present
column10: from the collaging of genres to the spacious
column11: nocturnal sonic environment to the heavy dose of paranoia that permeates it all.

column1: They spend the rest of the album exploring variations on these themes. ""One Love
column2: with Andy on vocals
column3: has a digital dancehall feel
column4: a creepy-funky electric piano riff
column5: and a scratched sample of a blaring horn section that predates Pharoahe Monch's ""Simon Says"" by almost a decade. ""Daydreaming""
column6: with its scratchy breakbeat drums
column7: is more directly hip-hop than most of the rest of the album
column8: but the layers of atmospheric synthesizers and Tricky's felonious near-whisper make it clear that Massive Attack was up to something entirely different from what every other rap producer at the time was doing.

column1: Blue Lines brought producers around to its unique vision. By the time Massive released Protection three years later
column2: the group's renegade approach had been copied enough times to become a full-on movement. They'd go on to produce their masterpiece
column3: Mezzanine
column4: a couple of years after
column5: but by then the project had already started to splinter. Tricky split from the collective after Protection to follow his own solo vision
column6: while the core trio behind it would eventually burn out acrimoniously
column7: with Vowles and then Marshall leaving Del Naja to produce increasingly less rewarding music under the group's name. Meanwhile
column8: trip-hop in general had its edges polished off by genteel musicians who transformed it into soundtracks for fashionable hotel lobbies.

column1: Still
column2: that doesn't change the fact that Blue Lines was a startling record when it came out
column3: and it remains one now. For this reissue it received a new mix and a new mastering job straight from the original tapes. It's available as a CD
column4: in digital form in standard and high fidelity formats
column5: and as a set of two LPs and a DVD of high resolution audio files. There aren't any bonus tracks
column6: and aside from a reproduction promo poster in the vinyl edition there aren't any add-ons either. Frankly they'd just be a distraction from the underlying theme that becomes clear once you get absorbed into the music
column7: which is that Blue Lines is still Blue Lines
column8:
and most of the world is still trying to catch up to it. 

"|17384.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/17384-blue-lines-remastered-box-set/|9.0|Miles Raymer

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/18507/homepage_large.d4518a91.jpg|Instrumental Tourist|1917.0|Tim Hecker|['Experimental']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Software']|2012-11-30 00:00:00|2012|2016-06-11 17:04:05.705802|"

In the world of instrumental electronic music
column2: you're nothing without your own sound. Without vocals and without an instrument that you can manipulate with your body
column3: it's harder to insert ""you"" into the music. And harder still to have that ""you"" be so thoroughly ""you"" that listeners pick up on it and can identify you from your sonics alone. Both Tim Hecker and Daniel Lopatin (better known as Oneohtrix Point Never) have gotten there. Each has his own aesthetic and you can hear them inside of it. Hecker's is more immediately identifiable. Since 2001's Haunt Me
column4: Haunt Me
column5: Do It Again
column6: he's created a run of good-to-amazing albums that are typically built on static and shifting drones
column7: number-crunching music that is also intensely physical and tactile. Lopatin's approach is comparatively playful and also more steeped in appropriation
column8: as he finds ways to incorporate the cast-off music of the past and make something that is both affecting and very much of this moment. When listening to a record by either Hecker or Lopatin
column9: you get a strong sense of the minds and sensibilities behind the music.

column1: Hecker and Lopatin admire each other's work and move in some of the same circles. Earlier this year
column2: at Lopatin's urging
column3: they got together to experiment. Crucially
column4: they were actually in the same room together for the project
column5: sharing sketches and creating new music in real time. When so much music is being made by sharing files online
column6: the fact that they actually played together and improvised is unusual and gives the album a unique quality. Here and there you can hear artifacts from the sessions
column7: like the ""Are you ready? We're recording..."" voices very quietly at the opening of ""Vaccination (for Thomas Mann)""
column8: which reinforce the air of spontaneity. One precedent for this sort of project comes from artists both producers admire
column9: the collaborations between Christian Fennesz
column10: Jim O'Rourke
column11: and Peter Rehberg under the name Fenn O'Berg. But while those collaborations could be dense and heavily abstract
column12: Instrumental Tourist is an easy listen
column13: loaded with billowy atmosphere and discernible melody.

column1: It's almost eerie in how you can hear the melding of two sounds. On tracks like ""Intrusions""
column2: ""Grey Geisha""
column3: and ""Vaccination No. 2""
column4: Hecker's blown-out digital shoegaze forms the basis of the tracks while Lopatin adds quasi global accents on top. On tracks like ""Vaccination (for Thomas Mann)"" and ""Racist Drone""
column5: Lopatin's thinner new age tones dominate and the accents are Hecker's. The overall mood drifts from lightly narcotic bliss to mild tension and then back again
column6: but the album hangs together. The way these things usually work
column7: it's unlikely that every ""Hecker-like"" sound comes from him and vice-versa. But it's uncanny how much these tracks sound like two guys jamming and bringing their individual voices into a shared context.

column1: For someone deeply attuned to these guys' careers
column2: listening for their individual contributions is both fun and slightly distracting. They sound good together and the meshing of their sounds is seamless
column3: but both are known more for meticulously crafted tracks honed over long periods of time
column4: and albums that string tracks together in a coherent way. Instrumental Tourist
column5: while listenable
column6: doesn't hide its more sketch-driven beginnings. It's an album more about process; you feel like you are hearing something at the moment of creation and
column7: relative to the recent full-lengths these two have made on their own
column8: there's less of a pull to return to the music and see how it all works. It's also
column9: at 55 minutes
column10: on the long side
column11: and there aren't quite enough ideas being batted back and forth to justify the length. But it's an enjoyable detour
column12:
one that affirms how well these producers have honed their approaches to sound.

column1: 0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/18505/homepage_large.f3169b73.jpg|From the Vaults
column3: especially for active bands
column4: rarity compilations seem like fading vestiges of an antiquated industry. When most every gig seems to work its way onto YouTube
column5: and when unreleased tracks act as fresh bait for legal downloads
column6: one expects that most groups aren’t sitting on enough fully formed but unheard songs to necessitate such stopgaps. The internet demands its content like grist for the mill
column7: so that quality often succumbs to quantity. An unearthed demo
column8: an alternate take

column11: why not put them to use?

column1: That idea

column4: recorded by Southern metal bushwhackers Kylesa between 2005 and 2012-- seems so refreshing. Recorded in the studio of co-founder Phillip Cope

column6: with tones both enormous and exploratory and vocals both large and enthusiastic. Many of these songs have been released before in some limited format

column1: In fact

column3: for instance

column5: Cope and Laura Pleasants trading lead vocals and textural harmonies like they're going to Halloween as Mates of State. Kylesa and Torche once got mentioned in the same Southern metal trend pieces
column6: more as a result of geographic proximity than sound. Here
column7: though
column8: Kylesa one-ups the bubblegum tenacity of their Miami counterparts with twisted sonics pirouetting around an unfailing hook. Meanwhile
column9: the lopsided structure and antiphonal clash of the guitars and howls during ""Inverse"" afford Kylesa a Godflesh-like urgency; but Kylesa's two-drummer configuration enables around-the-beat flourishes
column10: rewiring the robot back into a righteous rock band.

column1: Kylesa smartly handles this mix of material like an album
column2: with the turgid lurk of the collection's one ""new"" track ""End Truth"" bisecting the blessed pop-metal of ""Paranoid Tempo"" and the hardcore-baiting rage of ""Bottom Line II"". Just as Kylesa have employed slow-building gambits
column3: moody interludes
column4: and closing instrumentals on their proper LPs
column5: they open with a pensive full-band jam
column6: insert a minute-long atmospheric recess
column7: and end with a fairly incredible ""Drum Jam"" that variably suggests Steve Reich
column8: the Grateful Dead
column9: the Rolling Stones
column10: and Dennis Chambers. Though the choice to sequester the set's only covers (a malevolent
column11: marrow-scraping take on Buzzov-en's ""Drained"" and an ascendant version of Pink Floyd's ""Set the Controls for the Heart of the Sun"") might seem like an obvious concession to typical odds-and-sods formats
column12: the pair actually ends From the Vaults on notes both awesome and telling: Though Kylesa is rooted in the viscous Southern metal that Buzzov-en has made so aggressively for decades
column13: they are fascinating because they've extended beyond those roots
column14: adding psychedelic and industrial and pop influences to their music en masse. These covers trace that lineage
column15: forming a progressive arrow that parallels the investigative nature of Kylesa's music. From the Vaults
column16: then
column17: provides context and content.

column1: Kylesa has never been a casual band: During the last decade
column2: they've survived the death of a member
column3: multiple shifts in label alliances
column4: and that moment a few years back when people romantically spoke about Savannah and the swampy South like the new Seattle. Despite it all
column5: they've become the rare act that seems both tied to the sound of their geography and inherently interested in expanding it
column6: too. Their commitment to those ends are epitomized by From the Vaults
column7: a collection that shows a band that's spent the last seven years building a bulkhead of interesting music that extends beyond proper LPs. This set
column8: after all
column9: beneficently takes the subtitle Vol. 1
column10:
an appendage that can hopefully be interpreted not only as a sign that Kylesa continues to work on new material but also that similar scraps remain in the stable.

column3: and clear
column4: the songs are often discombobulated and repetitive. Songs that go on for seven or eight minutes in order to heighten excitement simply drag when there isn't much excitement to be had. That isn't to say that the music isn't technically good or at least precise. The best track here
column5: ""Morir Soñando""
column6: is a funky head-nodder
column7: powered by a springy baseline and trance-inducing verses on which Ruiz
column8: along with back-up vocalists Jaiko Suzuki and Sokhna Mabin
column9: chants about a romantic dream of love
column10: paradise
column11: and a land beyond. It's a dusky nighttime romp with enough thematic development to distract from relative musical stasis.

column1: But too often
column2: tracks slide by without supplying anything to fasten on to. Opener ""Ascension"" starts energetically with a heel-kicking synths but after about a minute it loses steam and
column3: for the next four minutes
column4: it drags. Those streamlined synths turn dirty and become a focal point but there's never anything that makes the song feel alive. Ditto for ""Paradise""
column5: which
column6: with its dial-tone staccato
column7: continuously fools the listener into false climax without capitalizing on the energy that it builds throughout.

column1: The worst sin that the group commits is indulgence. The two minute-long outro on ""Crossing"" is particularly aggravating
column2: using an idea similar to ""Dueling Banjos"" while scrapping any novelty or amusement. These missteps are surprising because the Crystal Ark
column3: while most potent as a live outfit
column4: are capable of sounding great in the studio. Last year's single ""Touch"" was a great example of lithe disco-funk
column5: which incorporated Russom's signature repetition while slowly building momentum. And a pair of singles from 2010
column6: ""The Tangible Presence of the Miraculous"" and ""The City Never Sleeps""
column7: found the right balance between rigidity and raucousness.

column1: Those singles' descendants can be found in the last two tracks on The Crystal Ark. ""Rain""
column2: the shortest song on the album
column3: makes great use of the group's leads
column4: as Russom and Ruiz guide pulsing funk and ribbon synths into a sexy
column5: naturalistic chorus. And on ""Silver Cord"" Ruiz finds a particular phrasing that provides a backbone for the urgency of her backup singers. ""Vibrations they rise and fall
column6: she chants
column7: before the beat drops out from under her and she's left alone
column8:
isolated in a dark room but singing with confidence that belies the tension in the music. On these two tracks form rises to match function and they provide a helpful counterpoint to their shapeless antecedents. The Crystal Ark's best tracks that work are the ones that actually exude some spirit in their mission to move bodies.

0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/18653/homepage_large.c562f573.jpg|The Allah-Las|30907.0|Allah-Las|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Innovative Leisure']|2012-11-30 00:00:00|2012|2016-06-11 17:04:07.447783|"

Garage rock
column2: even at its rowdiest
column3: is inherently lonely music. It exists outside of time
column4: allergic to trends and suspicious of new technologies
column5: which makes it ideal for loners who feel alienated from culture. Garage rock also sounds solitary. If it is recorded correctly-- which is to say
column6: if it feels like the audio was captured haphazardly by an amateur engineer in 1966-- this music will be alive and sloppy but also a little removed
column7: particularly the vocals. You know a garage-rock band has done its homework if the lead singer can affect a Jagger-esque whine that comes off somewhat anesthetized
column8: like he can't quite bring himself to commit fully to the song or life in general.

column1: You can't accuse Los Angeles quartet Allah-Las of not doing its homework. Three of the four members met while working at one of the country's great record stores
column2: Amoeba on Sunset Boulevard
column3: where they spent countless hours studying up on the vintage sounds that compose their affectingly melancholy self-titled debut. The band formed in 2008
column4: and worked for several years painstakingly assembling the songs on Allah-Las
column5: first releasing the vinyl single
column6: ""Catamaran""/""Long Journey""
column7: in 2011 and following up with two singles in 2012. All of these songs
column8: plus the eight other tracks that make up Allah-Las
column9: were produced by Nick Waterhouse
column10: a fine L.A. singer-songwriter whose 2012 LP Time's All Gone is a spirited and record-geek friendly collection of raucous 50s-style R&B thrashers.

column1: Waterhouse's production aesthetic involves a lot of tubes and analog equipment and ""natural"" sounds. The idea is to give the appearance of a band bashing out a record in a matter of minutes
column2: but the reality of the process is far more deliberate and meticulous. ""The whole lo-fi
column3: DIY has its own appeal
column4: and there are lots of bands we like that can make that work for them
column5: Allah-Las bassist Spencer Dunham told the L.A. Weekly in 2011. ""But for us to make the sound that we really want
column6: we work a lot better in a studio setting with $3
column7: 000 microphones from 1953.""

column1: This means Allah-Las are even lonelier than the average garage-rock band
column2: obsessively constructing jangly
column3: seemingly simple mid-tempo pop songs in the studio like they're building grand pocket symphonies. The success of Allah-Las is that it doesn't seem like it was strained over; instead
column4: it sounds like an effortlessly wistful batch of starry-eyed
column5: minor-key beauties that gently ruminate on the usual young-guy subjects: sex
column6: freedom
column7: the ways the former can interfere with the latter and vice versa. The album's prettiest song
column8: the Felt-like ""Vis-à-Vis""
column9: looks back on a failed relationship with a mix of regret and fatalistic acceptance: ""Some things can't be undone/ but that doesn't mean it was all just a waste of time
column10: bassist Spencer Dunham says
column11: sounding unknowingly innocent.

column1: The darker vibes lurking inside ""Sandy""
column2: with its ""too close to the sun"" imagery
column3: finally curdle on the album-closing ""Long Journey""
column4: Allah-Las' most aggressive track with its tough guitar jabs and springy bassline. After stating his intention ""to find a love that'll stay
column5: drummer Matt Correia fantasizes about ""heading down by the river to kill your daddy tonight/ and by the break of day
column6: you know that we’ll be out of sight."" It sounds like a line borrowed from an old blues tune
column7: though much of the yearning for escape on Allah-Las is derived from the beach. (Most of the guys in this band surf.) The seductive groove of ""Catamaran"" has a strong pull
column8: but the instrumental ""Sacred Sands"" shows where the band's heart really is. Like so many garage-rock questers before them
column9: Allah-Las are ultimately preoccupied with sound above all else. So long as there are 12-string guitars
column10: four-piece drumkits
column11: and lots and lots of reverb
column12:
the rest of the world can go away.

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/18555/homepage_large.f644b2fc.jpg|Desertshore/The Final Report|30901.0|X-TG|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Industrial']|2012-11-29 00:00:00|2012|2016-06-11 17:04:07.963000|"

Some bands employ what could be termed as an ""antagonizer
column2: a random element thrown into the frame to cause willful destruction. Einar Örn fulfilled such a role for the Sugarcubes
column3: providing mazy spoken word rants that butted up against Björk's singular tone. Throbbing Gristle were a band of four antagonizers
column4: an unlikely amalgam of headstrong individuals who somehow found space to work together. Their history is well documented and doesn't need repeating here. This is about an end
column5: not a beginning. Just as the origins of TG make for fascinating reading
column6: so too do the final days of the band. This release
column7: containing a full album cover of Nico's 1970 record
column8: Desertshore
column9: plus an album of new material titled The Final Report
column10: doesn't bear the Throbbing Gristle name. It revolves around original members Peter ""Sleazy"" Christopherson
column11: Chris Carter
column12: and Cosey Fanni Tutti
column13: who performed as X-TG after Genesis P-Orridge suddenly quit Throbbing Gristle during a seemingly-fruitful reunion. X-TG's shelf-life was short-- Sleazy passed away in November 2010 after the trio played just two shows under the name.

column1: P-Orridge's departure is still causing acrimony between the band members
column2: including a recent Twitter spat between h/er and Carter. Five years ago
column3: when things were more harmonious
column4: the group staged an ambitious summer residency at the ICA in London comprised of six two-hour sessions based around Desertshore
column5: the results of which were to be used on their interpretation of Nico's record. P-Orridge provided vocals on the songs
column6: and the raw materials were even released as a 12-disc CD-R set. The idea of covering the Nico album belonged to Sleazy
column7: who passed away shortly after P-Orridge left the band in 2010. It's hard to imagine the conflicting emotions Carter and Tutti must have gone through when finalizing this project
column8: although the fact that it's born out of chaos and animosity feels fitting. But this is no last snarl of anger. It's a relatively sedate affair compared to the broader body of TG work
column9: a contemplative pair of albums that feel like an extended goodbye note
column10: executed with the kind of careful thought required when handling precious materials left behind by a friend.

column1: The problem of how to fill the P-Orridge void on Desertshore was solved by bringing in a series of guest vocalists
column2: including Antony Hegarty
column3: Marc Almond
column4: and Blixa Bargeld. Wildcard contributions come from porn star turned musician/actress Sasha Grey and filmmaker Gaspar Noé
column5: with Tutti filling out the vocal duties on two tracks. The idea of using guest vocalists originated with Sleazy
column6: whose typically obtuse selection of singers included singer-songwriter Jake Thackray and famed children's TV animator Oliver Postgate. Here
column7: we get a series of artists sticking firmly to their strengths. Bargeld gets closest to the spirit of Nico
column8: curling a nicotine-stained vocal around ""Mutterlein"" that transforms it from muted drama into a whirl of waltz-time color. The overall tone for the piece is set by Antony
column9: who casts an astonishing sweep of vocal darkness over ""Janitor of Lunacy""
column10: all set to reverent electronics and horns that snake up in the mix toward the song's close. Antony
column11: like the rest of the cast
column12: wisely chooses not to stick too close to the source material.

column1: There's little in Desertshore that sounds like TG or Sleazy's work in Coil. Instead this is a one-off strain of inspiration
column2: similar to the excellent Carter Tutti Void project. Sometimes it dips into torch song territory
column3: such as on Almond's stirring take on ""The Falconer"". At other times there's light pouring in
column4: with Tutti's two vocal turns alternating between strident (""All That Is My Own"") and pillowy (""My Only Child""). Carefully tweaked beats and electronics run throughout
column5: providing the album with a crisp aesthetic bedrock. Occasional growls of analog synth feel like a sharp reminder this is three members of TG thrashing around on a short leash. But fundamentally there's a feeling of respect
column6: a sense of bringing to life a vision from someone who couldn't be around to complete it. Diehard fans may not be looking for that kind of sentiment from a band that staked its reputation on anything but respect
column7: but looping Desertshore back to the noisier side of the group would have been a shift into a redundant cul-de-sac. What binds the work of Sleazy
column8: Carter
column9: and Tutti
column10: plus many of the guest vocalists
column11: is a sense of forward momentum
column12: of leaving the past behind.

column1: The Final Report is a less essential document
column2: consisting of a series of tracks the three members worked on prior to Sleazy's death. There's incredible depth and detail to the arrangements
column3: with deathly chills pumped through the sparse material (""Breach"") and a choking sense of claustrophobia packed into more layered work (""Stasis""). Nothing feels quite complete
column4: and perhaps that's the point. ""Um Dum Dom"" drifts into a fog of spooky ambience and just stays there
column5: its low vocal moans effectively ripping tiny holes in the surface at all the right spots. At times it feels like there's something missing
column6: and it's certainly tempting to wonder how The Final Report would feel with P-Orridge's involvement. It's when they move out of the somber mood pieces that The Final Report gains an unusual shape of its own. ""In Accord"" is full of peculiarly contorted electronics that feel like they're deteriorating at the hands of the players in real time. Even better is ""Gordian Knot""
column7: a track full of vocal manipulations that positively glower.

column1: Where Desertshore and The Final Report connect is through a fascination with reaching the point where beauty gets tangled up with ugliness. It's something that ran through Nico's career from start to finish
column2: where fashion model looks slowly sagged into heroin addiction
column3: where a rare kind of musical talent faded pitifully into the shadows. By tapping into that feeling Sleazy was unwittingly creating what would be a poignant final chapter to his own career
column4: a slightly madcap idea that gathers more emotional gravitas than he ever intended. We shouldn't search too hard for meaning in his choice of final statement; this is someone who could flit between directing Van Halen videos and making records as affecting as Coil's Musick to Play in the Dark albums. But Carter/Tutti have done great justice to his idea here
column5: rounding off the concept by filling this album with a sense of loss that sinks into its core. In the documentary Nico Icon
column6: Nico's aunt described her as ""dreaming and boundless
column7:
seeing something that wasn't really there."" Desertshore effortlessly taps into that feeling.

Any way you slice it
column2: French Montana is poised to end 2012 as one of the year's hottest rappers. (See ""Pop That""
column3: <a href=""http://www.nytimes.com/2012/07/15/magazine/lady-mondegreen-and-the-miracle-of-misheard-song-lyrics.html?_r=2&pagewanted=all"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">the etymology of ""fanute
column4: ""Stay Schemin'""
column5: sharing his ""Versace silk swag"" with the offices of GQ.) But I still have no idea what a great French Montana song sounds like. Don't get me wrong
column6: I'm responsible for more than a few of the 25 million YouTube views granted to ""Pop That"". But much like his mentor Max B
column7: French Montana's qualities as a rapper-- a marble-mouthed
column8: sing-song flow that toggles between clear-eyed observation and heavy-lidded confession-- hardly translate on paper or in a boardroom. At this point he has more record deals than actual records
column9: so the question remains: ""What do you do with this guy?"" Mac & Cheese 3 is French Montana's most high-profile mixtape to date and proof that no one else really seems to know the answer.

column1: Or
column2: that the answer is ""everything."" The roster of Mac & Cheese 3 is astounding on multiple levels
column3: the first of which is that it would be utterly absurd even on a record that needed to justify the $9.99 expenditure. It might be the most heavily A&R'ed mixtape ever made. There really is no precedent for this mumble-goes-mainstream sort of blockbuster
column4: at least not until the Duplass brothers get to direct the next Die Hard movie or something. What really stands out above all is how it assumes that French Montana is either the most malleable rapper alive or that he simply does not matter.

column1: Witness him trading bars with past-their-prime NYC rappers like Fat Joe
column2: Prodigy
column3: and Fabolous
column4: who says ""teach me how to Douglas"" on ""Dance Move""
column5: an event that should not go undocumented. Or
column6: maybe he's more of a XXL Freshman 10 type
column7: so here's some Mac Miller
column8: Tyga
column9: and Wale features! Or
column10: hey
column11: we're getting the Bad Boy band back together! Not quite
column12: Diddy and Ma$e show up separately and the latter appears promising to bring you ""soup and orange juice if you’re really sick"" on a track that borders on condoning sexual assault (""Grownups""). Another event that should not go undocumented. Or maybe French is a Slip-N-Slide rapper! Rick Ross would've shown up regardless
column13: but Trina ends up stealing the show on ""Tic Toc""
column14: partly because she contributes an awesome verse
column15: partly because she adds contrast to a mixtape whose depressing sexual politics suggests that ""Pop That""'s views on women were its biggest selling point.

column1: ""Ocho Cinco"" sets the tone in terms of its features and its deadening misogyny. The second track on Mac & Cheese 3 features the following: perpetually ignored NYC mixtape space-filler Red Café
column2: Everlast/Yelawolf hybrid MGK
column3: Chief Keef producer Young Chop
column4: and Diddy
column5: who has apparently signed several of these guys. What exactly could unify this crew? Here's the group chant of a hook: ""Told that bitch give me head
column6: Ocho Cinco!"" I mean
column7: I've heard worse and having seen just enough <a href=""http://abcnews.go.com/GMA/video/chad-ochocinco-johnson-wife-evelyn-lozada-interview-head-butt-arrested-charge-17141399"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">SportsCenter and <i>Real Housewives of Atlanta
column8: I get the joke. It's still a joke that uses an episode of domestic violence as a means of demanding oral sex. ""Ocho Cinco"" is then followed by a skit which is 30 seconds of minor variations on threats to ""beat my baby moms up"" for listening to a French Montana tape. Needless to say
column9: it's played for laughs.

column1: Weirdly
column2: through all of this
column3: French remains kinda likeable if not remotely admirable. For all of its repulsiveness
column4: ""Pop That"" felt more like the talk of a high school locker room than a conversation between high rollers in bottle service and
column5: at its best
column6: Mac & Cheese 3 retains that giddy vulgarity. Though he's obviously a spiritual descendent of Max B
column7: I tend to hear Gucci Mane in how his slack delivery can obscure his clever wordplay or Noreaga in that his generally knucklehead demeanor can make the occasional but very real instances of resonance feel like they've been created against their own will.

column1: And you have to at least appreciate the wealth of production here. Harry Fraud gave French his first solo hit (""Shot Caller"") and is something of a kindred spirit in that he's a similarly hot name without an identifiable ""trick."" On Mac & Cheese 3
column2: his uptempo
column3: soul-infused beats prove to be complementary
column4: utilizing recognizable samples ranging from Florence & the Machine (""Intro"") to the original source material of Jay-Z's ""D'evils"" (""State of Mind"") and Ice Cube's ""Today Was a Good Day"" (""Triple Double""). But once again
column5: overzealous matchmaking sinks Mac & Cheese; access to a couple of Young Chop beats would be an unquestionable coup for French Montana if he actually sounded at home on them. As is
column6: it's strange to hear a grown man following what were likely instructions to sound as much like Chief Keef as possible
column7: and the only real difference between ""Love Sosa"" and ""Devil Want My Soul"" is that the latter is a minute and a half longer.

column1: And trust
column2: Mac & Cheese 3 did not need any sort of extra padding. If its fantasy football approach to team building is a remnant of the cash-flush late 90s
column3: its CD-maxing length is as well
column4: yet Mac & Cheese 3 never settles into a groove. French Montana simply blends in and is only as entertaining as his surroundings. When J. Cole turns up with a surprisingly slick verse and Rick Ross demands that his kids see him buried like a pharaoh
column5: ""Diamonds"" makes the ridiculous enterprise seem worthwhile. When immeasurably duller guys like Ace Hood and Chinx Drugs and Mac Miller show up
column6: Mac & Cheese 3 feels like it might never end. Even after spending more than an hour with a French Montana mixtape
column7: you get no closer to figuring out what to do with him. It's appropriate he's so closely associated with a made up word-- like ""fanute"" French remains ill-defined
column8:
and you sorta just know when it's being used correctly.

Indie-classical composer Nico Muhly's pieces feel like a series of archly posed questions. In their formal inventiveness
column2: love of blank space
column3: and haiku-like neatness
column4: they arouse the part of your brain that suspects it's being outsmarted. Even if you're rarely shaken listening to Muhly
column5: you're usually intrigued: To feel your intellect being playfully
column6: patiently tested
column7: as if he is circling your mind and kicking its tires
column8: can be a wonderfully maddening experience.

column1: His Drones
column2: initially spread across three EPs and collected here as a full-length
column3: toys with the notion of drone in a way that fits Muhly's ""cat meets yarn ball"" sensibility. Writing about the pieces for his blog
column4: Muhly mentions ""singing along with one's vacuum cleaner
column5: or…the subtle but constant humming found in most dwelling-places"" and writes
column6: ""We surround ourselves with constant noise
column7: and the Drones pieces are an attempt to honor these drones and stylize them."" He expanded on this idea in a July blog post: ""The process of idling at the airport
column8: taxiing
column9: and taking off (to say nothing of the flight itself) is a series of changing drones. Idling
column10: for instance
column11: is a constant c#
column12: with an ever-changing top note: f#
column13: e#
column14: or e.""

column1: Like many of Muhly's compositional ideas
column2: this one suggests a quizzical interest in music that lives in our most arid cultural spaces; his 2008 album Mothertongue began with a recitation of all the street addresses he has called home. Muhly seems at home in this world
column3: and part of the enjoyment of Drones is in how it seems to observe
column4: from Muhly’s serene remove
column5: how others are not. Drones & Piano sets a hard-charging staccato piano line against a soft unchanging hum of piano and violin
column6: evoking someone pacing in an airless space -- the aisles of the taxiing plane
column7: maybe
column8: that Muhly is busy analyzing chordal structures on.

column1: Drones & Viola and Drones & Violin are slight modifications of this scenario; the three pieces seem to sit inside of each other like Chinese boxes. The lulling
column2: fluttering drones
column3: played on piano and violin
column4: smooth over the outbursts of the solo instruments the way a humming dryer might quiet a colicky baby. There are moments of fierce urgency
column5: like the one in ""Part II: Material in a Handsome Stack"" where Nadia Sirota's sinewy viola rises and lets out a feral cry. You can feel the bow hairs gripping and pulling the strings out of place
column6: but the moment's drama dissolves back into the soft thrum. Even Bruce Brubaker's seething
column7: pacing piano line on Drones & Piano seems to have settled back grumbling into its seat for takeoff by the end. Mundanity has a muffling effect.

column1: What Muhly might think of this situation isn't clear
column2: exactly. Are we being smothered and sedated by all this ambient noise? Does it isolate us from our deeper feelings the way thick plate glass separates prisoners from their visitors? His pieces never step in to comment
column3: and Muhly's not the type to insert himself. He is an observer
column4: humming his observations to himself beneath the constantly changing root note of his vacuum cleaner
column5: and maybe he's suggesting we do the same. We're not getting rid of all this extraneous noise
column6:
so we might as well sing along to it.

You don't so much throw on a Nadja album as dunk your head in one; the smoggy haze of fuzz and scuzz that permeates the Berlin-based doom-gaze duo's albums is so relentless and all-consuming that
column4: after a while
column5: it starts to feel as comforting and commonplace as oxygen. But something remarkable happens at the beginning of Nadja's new album
column6: and that is: nothing at all. In place of the impenetrable wall of noise that usually greets you on their many recordings
column7: there's just the quiet murmur of Leah Buckareff's bass
column8: the tick-tock tap of a cymbal
column9: and a complete absence of Aidan Baker's effects-pedal onslaught-- by Nadja standards
column10: this is the equivalent of cutting an Unplugged session.

column1: Of course
column2: this sense of serenity lasts for just 60 seconds
column3: upon which that barren bassline is amplified into the tsunami-sized sludge of ""One Sense Alone"". But by offering that tentative tease
column4: and unleasing the noise in more controlled spurts
column5: Nadja offer a glimpse of something not always discernible on their previous records: their immense sense of scale. Nadja's capacity for heaviness has never been in doubt
column6: but Dagdrøm lets you really feel the weight of it all. And it's a heft measured not just by volume
column7: but by how long it takes to dissipate
column8: each shock of distortion lingering like the tingles in a sleeping foot being shaken awake.

column1: The greater definition heard on Dagdrøm is a logical extension of Nadja's 2009 covers album
column2: When I See the Sun Always Shines on TV
column3: though the dread-ridden vibe in effect here is informed much more by their stalking take on Slayer's ""Dead Skin Mask"" than their hazy-heady drift through Elliott Smith's ""Needle in the Hay"". And for that you can thank the recruitment of the Jesus Lizard's Mac McNeilly
column4: the kind of drummer you'd be foolish to bury under too much dreamy drone. McNeilly (who also appeared on the intensely prolific Baker's recent solo double album
column5: The Spectrum of Distraction) doesn't try to destablize Nadja's signature slow-motion sway; in Lizardian terms
column6: his default mode here is more ""Monkey Trick"" than ""Boilermaker"". But McNeilly's martial
column7: militaristic hits lend Nadja a noticeably more threatening momentum. And they provide a predatory percussive complement to Baker's mostly obscured delivery
column8: which here sounds less informed by My Bloody Valentine's vaporous vocals than the ominous mutterings of Slint's Brian McMahan. If Touch & Go Records had gotten in on the doom-metal game back in 1991
column9: it would've sounded a lot like this.

column1: Dagdrøm contains four tracks that average 11 minutes each
column2: and though they're presented as discrete pieces
column3: each is similar in mood and execution
column4: and each plays off the one before it as a variation on the same foreboding theme. ""Falling Out of Your Head"" effectively chops the riff of ""One Sense Alone"" in half and doubles the tension
column5: leading a Spiderland-stark lurch to an accelerated
column6: increasingly punishing climax; the title track immediately resumes the in-the-red onslaught
column7: but gradually winds down
column8: reducing its once-imposing refrain to expose the tranquil melody underpinning it. It's followed by the closing ""Space Time & Absence""
column9: a song that likewise showcases Nadja's sonic extremities
column10: but on an evermore epic scale: McNeilly's galloping
column11: tribal beat propels the song into a gargantuan groove
column12: before yielding to a hushed
column13: drawn-out comedown that keeps threatening to erupt once again
column14:
like a horror-movie villain that just won't stay dead. And therein lies the key to Dagdrøm's daunting mystique: You're never really sure if what you're hearing is the calm before the storm or the storm before the calm.

When London label Hemlock started in 2008
column2: the term ""dubstep"" meant something different than it does now: There was no such thing as Skrillex or Taylor Swift songs with vaguely dubstep-influenced choruses. Dubstep was not used to market cereal. The music had started out as another step in a continuum leading from Jamaican reggae through British techno; the most mainstream versions of it now function more or less like arena rock
column3: with hot guitar solos replaced by <a href=""http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YTS6CKuZ4kg&feature=related"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">""heavy
column4: dirty
column5: filthy"" bass drops. This isn't a eulogy for what dubstep was or a criticism of what it became
column6: just a statement of fact: times change
column7: things trend
column8: and what was once essentially just a genre of underground dance music having awkward brushes with popular culture is now a brightly colored Hot Topic t-shirt declaring
column9: finally
column10: SEX
column11: DRUGS & DUBSTEP.

column1: The role labels like Hemlock played in this transformation is pretty negligible. Even before dubstep's more widescale commercialization
column2: they represented a boutique alternative whose releases were more diverse and usually less immediate than more iconically dubstep artists like Digital Mystikz
column3: folding in house
column4: electro
column5: minimal and other sounds from outside the sphere.

column1: The label's cofounder
column2: Jack Dunning-- who records as Untold-- makes violent
column3: corrosive little sound sculptures that resemble people trying desperately to catch their breath or the clang-on-clang of demolition sites. In a quote that stands as one of my favorite statements of artistic purpose
column4: he once told Resident Advisor that
column5: ""I want to make people screwface
column6: shout
column7: dance weird."" Hemlock put out James Blake's phenomenally great first single and remix
column8: which sound like gospel if gospel were designed to terrify you instead of make you feel safe; they've also put out singles by magpies like Ramadanman and Fantastic Mr. Fox.

column1: Presented as an hour-long Untold mix with a few new
column2: unmixed extras tacked on
column3: Hemlock Recordings Chapter One tries to tell a story of the label as it stands now. Almost 20 minutes of the mix is new material
column4: including the tacked-on songs. ""The tracks I play these days are basically house or electro
column5: but made by producers who came through dubstep
column6: Dunning said in an interview last year. ""People are writing stuff that sounds like minimal techno
column7: grime
column8: juke etc
column9: but it has a twist
column10: an edge that carries through some of the trademarks of the original dubstep sound-- sub bass
column11: darkness
column12: space and unpredictability.""

column1: As evidence of his own argument
column2: Dunning's mix moves in roughly chronological order
column3: from the label's stuttering
column4: lopsided first singles to its firm
column5: house-influenced recent output. The change isn't just rhythmic
column6: either: Hemlock's early tracks sounded hard
column7: flat and airless
column8: like the music had been vacuum-packed
column9: while a lot of the mid-mix material-- especially Guy Andrew's ""Resistivity"" and Sei A's ""Hyphen""-- sounds like its playing from inside a fog bank. (For a visual metaphor
column10: try a Piet Mondrian next to a Gerhardt Richter.)

column1: For a celebration of the past
column2: it's a progressive and unsentimental attitude to take
column3: but Dunning has always seemed like an admirably progressive and unsentimental artist-- he knows that all these familiar oldies were once new
column4: too. But the format has its drawbacks. Some of the best older tracks have clever
column5: winding structures that make them more interesting as start-to-finish pieces of music than raw materials to chop up and use in a mix. There's also something a little inbred about hearing an hour of tracks coming from the same place
column6: even when a third of them are new. More than anything
column7: the mix just seems like a formality-- the thing that techno labels do because other techno labels do it.

column1: What it reveals about Hemlock is
column2: again
column3: what Dunning wants it to reveal: They never had a single exclusive sound to begin with. The affiliations between the artists here have less to do with dubstep and more to do with a misfit love of nasty sounds probably best exemplified by Dunning himself. He has said that his own pseudo-scientifically titled Change in a Dynamic Environment EPs from this year were attempts to use dance music's tendency toward short releases to capture small shifts in personal style
column4: as well as evidence of his almost compulsive predisposition toward the new.

column1: There's something sentimental about a commemorative release for a label that has only been around for four years. At least with Dunning you can take comfort in the knowledge that if they ever do this again
column2: the sound will have changed just as much
column3:
if not more.

When you put the needle to Bikini Kill's newly reissued self-titled EP

column17: 'Hey! You at home! You can make a record too!'"" Bikini Kill is purposefully
column18: defiantly
