column2: Bikini Kill's legend is more widely known than their music. The spirit of riot grrrl is manifesting not so much in bands but in extra-musical phenomena influenced by the movement's ideas: from the rebel girls running the feminist teen webzine Rookie to the collective of Russian revolutionaries who plucked two pieces of the Bikini Kill lexicon and dubbed themselves Pussy Riot. So the release of the first EP on Bikini Kill Records (an imprint formed to reissue the band's discography) feels like an auspiciously timed opportunity to remember something that's come to feel
column3: oddly
column4: almost secondary to their story: Bikini Kill wrote great punk songs. Tobi Vail's drumming managed to sound both wildly anarchic and assertively tight; Kathi Wilcox's bass gave even their hardest songs an elastic
column5: low-end pogo-ability. Billy Karren pivoted between sludge-coated surf riffs and piercing dissonance. And then there was Hanna
column6: sassing
column7: seething
column8: and spitting the band's cumulative passion like hot bile.

column1: Commemorative reissues of classic punk records present certain ideological challenges. Should a band that sticks a $200+ price tag on a box set of previously released material be banned from speaking about the evils of capitalism? Can liner notes explain why a certain album is great without discouraging the listener from coming to his or her own conclusions? Is it possible to glorify the past without shortchanging the future? Well
column2: aging punks
column3: take note: the reissue of Bikini Kill elegantly avoids these pitfalls. It provides context (a zine-style insert featuring photos
column4: collages
column5: and recent interviews with MacKaye and Bratmobile's Molly Neuman) but doesn't stifle you with nostalgia. It pokes fun at the scenester's eternal refrain of ""I was there"" (one interview's gently mocking subtitle: ""Bikini Kill
column6: You Really Had To Be There…"")
column7: and it's ticketed at the reasonable price of just 2 and 2/5 Fugazi shows (not adjusted for inflation). It's an uncommonly inviting reissue
column8: letting the songs sound not like museum pieces but living documents. Somehow
column9: this music still sounds throbbingly present tense
column10: which levels the exclusiveness of nostalgia.

column1: Bikini Kill touches on themes they'd continue to explore over the next half-decade. ""Liar"" draws a direct line between capitalism and forms of social oppression (""You profit from the lie"")
column2: ""Carnival"" extols the virtues and radical possibilities of seemingly trashy pleasures (""It's by the Lacey Mall! That's where you'll find me
column3: yeah!"")
column4: and the opening manifesto ""Double Dare Ya"" manages to cram everything Bikini Kill stood for into two minutes and 41 gloriously abrasive seconds. ""Hey girlfriennnnnnd
column5: Hanna begins
column6: ""I gotta proposition
column7: goes something like this! Dare you to do what you want! Dare you to be who you will! Dare you to cry right out loud!"" It's one of their definitive songs: an explosive collision between didacticism and dynamism
column8: a Bill of Rights you can mosh to.

column3: she's Biafra
column4: she's a drill sergeant and a (not-so) conscientious objector
column5: she's artist and (on the incendiary and dryly funny ""Thurston Hearts the Who"") critic
column6: victim and abuser; she's your dad
column7: your mom
column8: your little brother
column9: and your big sister all trapped (or liberated) inside one body.

column1: The elasticity of voice in a Bikini Kill song is visceral
column2: cathartic
column3: and occasionally even comic. But it's also inherently political. Shortly before forming Bikini Kill
column4: Hanna was working at a domestic violence shelter where she'd founded a discussion group for teen girls. This experience had a huge impact on her songwriting. In Sara Marcus's riot grrrl history Girls to the Front
column5: she says that these were the girls she was initially writing for
column6: screaming out other women's pent-up silence. So the vocal theatrics Hanna delivers on the earliest Bikini Kill songs are sometimes declarations of resistance (during the chorus of the blistering ""Suck My Left One""
column7: she voices a girl hurling the title phrase at her sexually abusive father like she's re-enacting a scene from The Exorcist)
column8: but they also find her exercising her freedom
column9: acting on the challenge she issues in the first song: Dare you to be who you will!

column1: ""Women make natural anarchists and revolutionaries because they've always been second-class citizens
column2: having to claw their way out
column3: Kim Gordon said in a recent interview. She was reflecting on the trial of Pussy Riot
column4: who cite Bikini Kill as a major influence
column5: but she might as well have been summing up the spirit of Bikini Kill's earliest recordings. They'd go on to make better records (The Singles remains Bikini Kill's defining document)

column7: this EP does the same for something that deserves just as much credit: their music. In its grooves
column8: still
column9:
you hear the revolution.

About 12 years ago
column2: I made a forlorn pilgrimage to a Bad Brains reunion show at a small venue in upstate New York that sat in the middle of a mini-mall. On the three-hour van ride there
column3: I struggled mightily against my own unreasonable expectations. I had missed my chance by about 20 years to witness the Bad Brains of my imagination-- the ones you see immortalized in this iconic Glen Friedman photo
column4: for instance-- perform live. Those guys no longer existed
column5: and hadn't since the second Reagan administration. I was late by two decades. This was probably going to go poorly.

column1: It did so
column2: more than I could ever have imagined. Lead singer H.R. wandered onstage several uncomfortable minutes after his bandmates had taken their place. He conducted the band with limp hands in a way that seemed to be directly mocking them. He stopped frequently to look up at the venue's squat ceiling to seemingly address Jah. Bassist Darryl Jenifer fixed a thousand-yard stare to the back of the venue and played dutifully. The only member who seemed to enjoying himself was guitarist Dr. Know
column3: who shredded joyfully through the solos in ""Let Me Help"" and ""Re-Ignition"". The set leaned heavily on the bleary reggae that absolutely no one in the audience had come to hear and after perfunctory run-throughs of two or three hardcore classics
column4: H.R. thanked Jah
column5: thanked us
column6: and they left. Filing out crestfallen

column8: he said plaintively.

column1: This is the unique curse that sometimes visits legendary bands who have the audacity to stay together
column2: or even worse
column3: keep recording
column4: once their legend has crystallized. Bad Brains’ thunderclap fusion of hardcore

column12: name changes
column13: and more-- can only feel like denouement. The mere fact of their survival into a third decade is surprising; the band I saw in 2000 seemed minutes away from gratefully quitting each other's company forever. But the band stubbornly persists.

On ""Popcorn"" he does a routine that feels far too close to Anthony Kiedis circa ""Funky Monks"". He bursts out out into his wild scatting on ""We Belong Together"". Into the Future is the most interesting Bad Brains reunion album in part because it allows H.R. to be as weird as he likes.

The band has also found a way to sneak the sweetness of melody back into their music

column9: and ""Fun"" are more memorable songs than anything on Build a Nation. ""We Belong Together"" is probably the best full-throttle punk-metal song they've written since ""Soul Craft"". They seem to be enjoying each other

column1: H.R.'s lyrics have never been celebrated for their coherence or profundity

It's been a good year for rapper-producer Le1f. His Greedhead-inscribed Dark York mixtape was one of the most talked-about avant-rap releases. He was in the right place at the right time to get swept up in the wave of trend pieces about the number of queer rappers emerging out of New York City. And the video for his skronking booty-clap anthem ""Wut"" became an unlikely Internet meme thanks in large part to his formidable twerking skills and repertoire of anime power-up poses. If we've learned anything about Le1f during all this
column2: it's that he has an aversion to being pinned down or pigeonholed. So it shouldn't come as a surprise then that the Liquid EP
column3: his followup to Dark York

column7: Part 2.

column1: With its hypnotic polyrhythmic beat and metallic clangs
column2: the second cut
column3: ""Buoy""

Two-thirds of the way through what sounds like a chattering synthesizer shows up

column7: right now

The DMC World DJ Championships are likely the most impressive DJing event that you've never heard of-- pulling up video of this year's competition exposes you to kinetic jockeys putting on the kind of showy digital performances that keep AraabMuzik selling out concerts. The annual competition
column2: which allows for individual and group bouts

column1: DJ Final

column1: It's this combination-- a hugely efficient technical sensibility superseded by a pop playfulness that makes Cashmere Cat such an effective producer. His debut EP Mirror Maru is comprised of four tracks of colorful

Without the percussion it would be easy to get mired in temperate noise. ""Secrets + Lies"" doesn't rely on any kind of simple loop or repetition

When we heard from Solange Knowles four years ago
column3: she was a major-label signee trying to find her footing on a conceptual and vintage-sounding album called SoL-Angel and the Hadley Street Dreams. Then she split with Interscope and resurfaced on the indie circuit
column4: carting Jay-Z and her sister Beyoncé to Grizzly Bear concerts on the Williamsburg waterfront and offering up a cover of Dirty Projectors' ""Stillness Is the Move"". At cynical first glance
column5: it seemed like Knowles was simply backtracking and rebranding
column6: hoping to claim some available indie turf. But this fall
column7: she released ""Losing You""
column8: a gleaming and spirited new song that transcended the labels she'd been assigned. Released via Terrible
column9: the label co-owned by Chris Taylor of Grizzly Bear
column10: the sly single hinted at the possibilities open to an artist who eschews a traditional model of pop stardom. True
column11: the EP that follows
column12: delivers on the fresh promise of ""Losing You"" and marks the sound of a singer hitting a graceful stride
column13: in her own time and on her own terms.

column1: Producers and songwriters in the pop world sometimes lurk in the background
column2: leaving the vocalist to be the face of the project. But Solange upends that model by presenting Devonté Hynes
column3: her co-songwriter and True’s main producer
column4: as a full-fledged partner. His name is credited prominently and he appears hand-in-hand with Solange at listening parties and in press photos. And True
column5: a thematically consistent whole
column6: sounds like the product of a lovingly forged artistic bond. The EP shares DNA with Hynes' solo outlet Blood Orange. Like the best bits of his 2011 album Coastal Grooves
column7: it feeds on humble but compulsively listenable tunes that reference the silken grooves of late-80s pop. But Hynes thrives in a supporting role. ""If there's a better voice [than mine] suited to a song-- I usually have a female voice in my head
column8: anyway-- then I would rather her sing it
column9: he told me during an interview earlier this year. ""It makes me happier.""

column1: Hynes has met an ideal female vocal muse in Solange
column2: who executes each cut with simple grace and yearning naïveté. These songs often reconcile girlish optimism with worldly wisdom as though the two are one and the same. ""Maybe I lost you
column3: but I was not done having my fun/ Played around with your heart
column4: now I'm playing around in the dark
column5: she apologizes on ""Lovers in the Parking Lot"". And on “Bad Girls”
column6: she captures the uneasiness of waking up in last night's smeared makeup and feeling unmoored: ""I look down on you
column7: so deep down I know that we're the same/ It's stupid thinking that you would want to come play my game
column8: she sings
column9:
ending the EP over a twinkle worthy of a closing scene in an early John Hughes film.

Like much of True
column10: it's the sound of a complicated slow dance during a night's dwindling last minutes
column11: fueled by pounding hearts and racing minds. The record never builds to a huge chorus; instead
column12: its hooks bubble up quietly and quickly
column13: then dissipate as the songs return to their downbeat simmer. Hynes tinkers with non-traditional structures
column14: letting the tunes meander in and out of grooves
column15: but while this occasionally causes True to fall slack (""Look Good With Trouble"")
column16: it’s a largely effective approach.

column1: True also benefits from its unorthodox length: At seven songs
column2: it's fuller than most EPs
column3: yet too short to be considered an album-album. Somehow
column4: it works. Why add filler just to call it an album? It's another example of Knowles and Hynes forgoing conventional wisdom and doing things their own way. Seven songs can be the perfect length; a collection of accessible and authentic pop can come out on an indie label; you can reshape the typical producer/songwriter/pop star model; you can create unassuming music that still sounds like a big deal. And ultimately
column5: for Solange
column6:
you can retrace your steps and find yourself somewhere entirely new.

Mogwai made their name on a simple formula: be very quiet
column2: and then
column3: without warning
column4: be sadistically loud. But very early on
column5: the group showed they weren't especially precious about their practice. Their 1997 full-length debut
column6: Young Team
column7: was quickly followed by Kicking a Dead Pig
column8: wherein Young Team's tracks were subjected to sonic surgery by a cast of noted studio scientists that included Kevin Shields
column9: Alec Empire
column10: and µ-Ziq. At the time
column11: it hardly seemed odd that the most undanceable band in all of Scotland would welcome the opportunity for a beat-based rethink. After all
column12: in the wake of the late-90s electronica boom
column13: remix albums had effectively replaced live albums as the default cash-cow-milking measure for rock bands (as acknowledged by the collection's piss-take of a title)
column14: and the ample negative space in the band's music presents producers with a large canvass to color in. But despite its impressive cast and elaborate double-CD presentation
column15: Dead Pig ultimately sounded like random attempts at applying Mogwai's metallic noise to the darker strains of electronic music of the era (drill and bass
column16: digital hardcore)

column1: Fourteen years later

column3: A Wrenched Virile Lore
column4: arrives as a more cohesive work

column6: alternate-universe reimgination of Mogwai's 2011 release
column7: Hardcore Will Never Die But You Will. Despite its severe title
column8: Hardcore counts as the band’s most blissful and texturally rich to date. Hardcore's sound provides producers with more jumping-off points than the band's mountainous art-rock would normally allow. If Kicking a Dead Pig was mostly about giving Mogwai's atomic guitar eruptions a mechanized makeover
column9: A Wrenched Virile Lore repositions the songs' central melodies in more splendorous surroundings. In the hands of Justin K. Broadrick
column10: the post-punky krautrock of ""George Square Thatcher Death Party"" becomes the sort of gently ascendant
column11: anthemic opener that you could imagine blaring out of a stadium to kick-off an Olympics ceremony; Pittsburgh prog-rockers Zombi hear the mournful piano refrain of ""Letters to the Metro"" as the basis for a glorious
column12: strobe-lit Trans Europe Express flashback. Or in some cases
column13: the material is stripped down to its essence: Glaswegian troubador R.M. Hubbert re-routes the motorik pulse of ""Mexican Grand Prix"" off the speedway into the backwoods and transforms it into a hushed
column14: Jose Gonzalez-like acoustic hymn
column15: while San Fran neo-goth upstarts the Soft Moon scuff away the surface sheen of ""San Pedro"" to expose the seething menace lurking underneath. However
column16: there are limits to this approach: Umberto's distended
column17: ambient distillation of ""Too Raging to Cheers"" simmers down this already serene track to the point of rendering it inconsequential.

column1: Like Hardcore
column2: A Wrenched Virile Lore features 10 tracks
column3: though it only references eight of the originals. However
column4: even the mixes that draw from the same songs are different enough in approach and sequenced in such a way that the reappearances feel like purposeful reprises: Klad Hest's drum and bass-rattled redux of ""Rano Pano"" finds its sobering aftershock in Tim Hecker's haunted and damaged revision
column5: while Cylob's cloying synth-pop take on Hardcore's opener ""White Noise""-- which fills in the original's instrumental melody with lyrics sung through a vocoder-- is redeemed by UK composer Robert Hampson's 13-minute soft-focus dissolve of the same track. Renamed ""La Mort Blanche""
column6: its appearance provides both a full-circle completion of this record (by book-ending it with mixes by former Godflesh members) while serving as a re-entry point back into Hardcore by reintroducing the source song's main motifs and widescreen vantage. But more than just inspire a renewed appreciation for Hardcore
column7: A Wrenched Virile Lore potentially provides Mogwai with new avenues to explore now that they're well into their second decade
column8:
and perhaps instill a greater confidence in the idea that their identity can remain intact even in the absence of their usual skull-crushing squall.

James Ferraro's work is usually about layers
column2: both in its dense sound and in the multiple meanings behind that sound. Some of his early releases were so murky and obscure that it was tough to sort through it all and glean his intentions. Yet when his music got ostensibly clearer and more accessible on last year's Far Side Virtual
column3: the layers only seemed to get denser.

column1: Sonically
column2: Ferraro eschewed his standard blurry sheen. But by lifting generic sounds from ads
column3: apps
column4: and other modern technological ubiquities
column5: he pumped up the levels of irony and cultural commentary. And despite the surface clarity
column6: the music was still dense-- it turns out listening to a month’s worth of smartphone alerts and Skype chimes in one 45-minute chunk isn't easy. Far Side Virtual became Ferraro's most discussed and divisive effort
column7: landing on year-end best-of lists as often as it got dismissed as a joke.

column1: All this continuing chatter made what Ferraro might do next fun to imagine but hard to guess. Subsequent quick-hit mix tapes under the names Bebetune$ and Bodyguard mined hip-hop and R&B
column2: and both could have been meant as parody (or just afterthought). But Ferraro more recently expressed a desire to shed all the layers. ""You can contrive it to a point where it gets too heady
column3: he told Dazed a few months ago. ""I'm not always trying to be hyper-conceptual. That's inherently who I am
column4: but I enjoy making music for people to listen to.""

column1: He's followed through on that sentiment with Sushi
column2: which is truly his most accessible album to date. Though smartly crafted and often referential to other music
column3: it's relatively concept-free
column4: with little in the way of ironic jabs or culture-jamming commentary. Perhaps there are jokes happening here that I'm not catching (and titles like ""SO N2U"" and ""Condom"" aren’t exactly serious). But to me Sushi sounds mostly like well-made
column5: engaging electronic instrumental music
column6: the best of which rivals that of any current producer.

column1: What makes it engaging is its playfulness. Ferraro's loops often feel cartoonish-- not in the sense of caricature
column2: but in the way snippets of voices and smatterings of sound effects add unpredictable humor. At best
column3: like the whirring ""Jump Shot Earth"" or the chirping ""Flamboyant""
column4: he conjures a smoother
column5: more soulful version of Black Dice. That smoothness can get cheesy
column6: but it's a sincere kind of cheesy rather than a winking one. And more often he's restrained and reflective
column7: echoing Flying Lotus' laid-back atmospheres
column8: albeit with less emotional weight than Steven Ellison is capable of.

column1: That is perhaps where Sushi suffers a bit-- on the whole
column2: it's more entertaining than resonant. Cynics might blame Ferraro's self-described ""hyper-conceptual"" nature
column3: and assume he's mocking the idea that referential
column4: artificially-constructed music can be moving. But I give Ferraro and his rather exhaustive track record more credit than that. In many ways he's a dedicated craftsman
column5: and the elegant way he develops his pieces that creates its own kind of emotion.

column1: Besides
column2: some tracks here are genuinely affecting. The chiming lope of ""Jet Skis & Sushi"" suggests technology fusing with humanity
column3: and the closing song's wavy tones and ponging accents are oddly wistful
column4: despite the fact that it's titled ""Bootycall"". Those moments suggest what Ferraro has begun on Sushi could deliver deeper rewards
column5:
if this mercurial artist sees fit to continue down this earnest path.

column3: in turn

For all the talk about how iPods and Megaupload have exponentially advanced listener curiosity
column3: post-punk and rap have long coexisted in the collections of anyone who simply likes great music. Still
column4: those two genres have rarely mixed in the time since-- you could point to off-the-grid acts like Dälek
column5: while Clipse's Hell Hath No Fury has as much clangor
column6: negative space
column7: and nihilism as <i>Metal Box
column8: but the influence of post-punk on hip-hop has been mostly relegated to the theoretical realm. At least until now. Memphis rapper Cities Aviv definitely displayed an iconoclastic streak on 2011's Digital Lows
column9: in which serious Three 6 Mafia homage and a straight-up ""People Are People"" sample found equal footing. On Black Pleasure
column10: he goes all in with one of the first rap albums that sounds it's angling for a deal with Pendu Sounds or Captured Tracks. It's bold and possibly forward thinking. What's less certain is whether he actually made a good record.

column1: He does have the voice for it. While an adept wordsmith
column2: Aviv's vocals have a stiff and shouty cadence. At the outset
column3: it's surprisingly effective. The militant kick drums that power ""Forever"" are the domain of no-fi coldwave revivalists like the Soft Moon and Black Marble
column4: while Aviv's vocals are initially lost in impenetrable
column5: well-bottom reverb. By the time he emerges to rap clearly intelligible words
column6: you mostly catch the punchline where his insecurities have him ""hanging like I'm Ian Curtis."" It's something of a ""shock tactic
column7: not so much in its allusion to a man's suicide
column8: but one that can be cynically viewed as an easy ""in"" for indie listeners. But you can't really doubt his commitment
column9: as later on he and his girlfriend are making love to Joy Division and Psychic TV
column10: while porn star Mary Carey and Debbie Harry also get namechecked in succession.

column1: Fortunately
column2: Black Pleasure isn't a half hour of Cities Aviv trying to score cred points; there's plenty of material here that would fit within the confines of the searching and introspective Digital Lows were it not for the severity of the production. Aviv remains a relatable and personable rapper who's mostly falling in or out of love during Black Pleasure
column3: while taking stock of his own situation and those of his peers. The most instantly ear-turning quotables come to the fore on ""Simulation""
column4: which takes shots at e-rappers (""you thuggin' but you only sendin' shots over Gmail"") and pretty much all internet-based interaction (""with 30
column5: 000 user names which is the real you?"") over distended production from Green Ova Undergrounds associate L.W.H..

column1: ""Simulation"" is one of the few tracks where the words take precedence
column2: and that's a problem. It isn't about the compatibility of Cities Aviv's influences so much as the actual mix
column3: the way Black Pleasure sounds coming out of speakers and headphones. Nearly every production tactic that makes Black Pleasure so distinct ends up working against the strengths of its creator. The blown-out reverb and aluminum aftertaste won't be too unfamiliar
column4: but while most rock bands using these tricks consider lyrics to be a non-entity or the vocals another sonic layer
column5: Cities Aviv is a talented rapper who conceivably wants his words to be heard. The moaning sample that punctuates every bar of ""Escorts"" completely dominates the sonic field and the lack of definition on ""Remynd"" makes the appearance of Maria Minerva a complete non-event. Perhaps it's meant more as a consumptive
column6: textural experience than as a beats and rhymes record
column7: but if that's the case
column8: Black Pleasure forfeits its main selling point; so much of the production relies on the acidic
column9: warping qualities of distortion that without Cities Aviv's instructions on how he wants Black Pleasure to be heard
column10: you could just as easily assume he was catching up with chillwave or cloud-rap.

column1: At the very least
column2: you have to admit there isn't anyone else making music like this right now
column3: but it's debatable whether Cities Aviv is in his own lane here because others consciously chose to avoid it. And while there's no such thing as a ""free"" mixtape
column4: since time and creativity are limited resources
column5: you could argue that unlike
column6: say
column7: 808s and Heartbreak or even Rebirth
column8: this lacks the stakes of Cities Aviv putting his money where his mouth is. Maybe thats the real issue with Black Pleasure-- it feels more laudable for its ethics and process than the actual product; even if it isn't felt
column9: it can certainly be discussed
column10:
and talking points are probably more valuable than actual hits at this point in Cites Aviv's trajectory. But I'm more interested in hearing what Cities Aviv is capable of when he doesn't surround himself in so much figurative and literal noise.

Gerry Read is just 20 years old. But it would be wrong to call him ""precocious"" or an ""upstart""; for the most part
column2: the British producer stays quiet and releases tracks. His relative anonymity-- press photos obscure his face; if he's on Twitter it's a really good disguise-- and steady release schedule have a lot more in common with the old Chicago and Detroit heads than the current generation of UK producers. In rare interviews
column3: he is intimidatingly well adjusted: When asked if he'd always listened to house music
column4: he declined and then added
column5: ""I think people feel they have to say they've always been into loads of old shit though
column6: as if having all these influences makes you look like you know what you're doing.""

column1: Read makes his tracks quickly
column2: without much editing and without much gear. He claims not to dance at clubs (he does DJ)
column3: though his scruffy
column4: noisy tracks don't necessarily lend themselves to home listening. This is the digital generation's answer to secluded
column5: auteur behavior. You won't hear ""Crawl"" in a hair salon; it takes several spins to realize how much his debut album
column6: Jummy
column7: distracts
column8: and how this is one of its best qualities. On Jummy
column9: Read reveals a dedication to haze and clutter mostly absent on his early singles
column10: and it provides a necessary counterpoint to his Spartan loops. Where most producers have to avoid jam-packing their tracks
column11: Read struggles with adding enough material. Because on some level
column12: presumably
column13: he could just listen to the choppy vocal loop on ""Let's Make it Deeper"" forever.

column1: Read is one of the few producers confident or careless enough to slap a genre name on his productions-- house-- so let's use that. But this is art-house
column2: and Read spends Jummy exploring how the idioms of that genre can be suffocated and then
column3: at the last minute
column4: let up to gasp for air. He lacks Theo Parrish's brilliant ear for sound design (most do)
column5: but shares his hermit-like impulses and
column6: increasingly
column7: Parrish's abstractions of jazz and blues music. To put it another way
column8: Jummy sounds like what Moodymann's Black Mahogani series might've sounded like if it had access to FruityLoops and Rapidshare.

column1: Jummy is built mostly from samples
column2: mixing big
column3: wet drum sounds-- Read records them from his own kit-- with short
column4: cloudy bursts of Rhodes piano and mumbled half-syllables. Throughout
column5: the drums are bright and musical
column6: the melodies stoned and irritable. Fans of Motor City Drum Ensemble or Flying Lotus will find common ground here
column7: but Read is more obtuse than the former and less free-spirited than the latter. Despite the prevalence of samples
column8: Jummy never feel like a collage. It's more ordered. Deducing Read's track architecture is simple-- he does his work in eight bars or less-- and that can make his music seem simple; like staring at a great pattern
column9: it's best to let the simplicity wash over you and to let the geometry tickle your brain.

column1: Tickle it will
column2: too
column3: because Jummy refuses to fade into the background. Credit the aggressive samples or the distinct friction created when Read pushes those drums against them. Jummy closes with ""Sidecar""
column4: a ghostly
column5: pale piece that that screams ""album closer!"" Its formless
column6: dim neon proposes that Read has bigger ideas for an R&B hook than a great house track. But right now
column7: Read is full of great
column8:
idiosyncratic house tracks and Jummy is packed with them.

Both words in Eternal Tapestry's name say something about their music
column2: but it's the first that's key. This Portland band's expansive psych rock sounds like it could go on forever
column3: and most of their releases have in fact been culled from longer
column4: open-ended improvisations. The way they slowly build these jams-- adding parts
column5: increasing volume
column6: and cresting in unison-- you get the feeling they're always playing
column7: and their records are just glimpses of an endless stream.

column1: For A World Out of Time
column2: Eternal Tapestry's second full-length of 2012
column3: the band took a less long-form approach. Instead of jamming endlessly and picking sections from the results
column4: they recorded the album
column5: according to press materials
column6: ""as a whole."" This presumably means they performed one set of focused
column7: purposeful sessions
column8: but it doesn't mean there's a one-to-one ratio between what was laid to tape and what's included. In fact
column9: this is the band's most collage-oriented release
column10: offering varied sounds fused with hard cuts
column11: cross-fades
column12: and even outdoorsy ambience.

column1: Still
column2: there's more efficiency and clarity on A World Out of Time than any previous Eternal Tapestry album. While each song could pass for a portion of a larger jam
column3: they all get to the point rapidly. Well
column4: almost all of them-- opener ""When I Was in Your Mind"" is 12-plus minutes of wandering guitar jangle. But after that
column5: every track is pretty concise-- most last less than five minutes and none go over seven. Remarkably
column6: this brevity comes with little loss of space or freedom. That's probably because the group has so much experience at playing for longer. The chemistry they've built over all those sessions makes them able to step on the gas quickly and naturally
column7: which is why they can make a four-minute song sound as wide-open as a half-hour excursion.

column1: My favorite example is ""The Weird Stone""
column2: a masterpiece of slow-burning
column3: perfectly-overlapping guitars
column4: all driven by Jed Bindeman's limber drumming
column5: which combines garage primacy with jazz-like flexibility. In a flash
column6: the band evokes numerous psych-jam forefathers-- I hear the Grateful Dead
column7: Hawkwind
column8: and the under-sung Japanese band Marble Sheep and the Run Down Sun's Children-- while adding accents and textures that avoid outright mimicry.

column1: Some might find that last claim debatable. Admittedly
column2: Eternal Tapestry rely on well-worn psych moves
column3: some of which verge on cliché. One song
column4: ""Apocalypse Troll""
column5: cops a riff so familiar it must have inhabited multiple classic rock songs before. Another
column6: closer ""Sand Into Rain""
column7: sounds like a slowed-down tribute to Donovan's ""Hurdy Gurdy Man"". Eternal Tapestry embraces other tropes common to this kind of music as well-- at least four songs share titles with sci-fi and fantasy tomes by the likes of Isaac Asimov and Harlan Ellison.

column1: But to me the band's commitment to diving deep into psych-rock tradition actually helps them stand out. Their unapologetic sound isn't an opportunistic gloss on the past
column2: but rather a full-on exploration that enhances and moves history forward. Sometimes a group this versed in a genre
column3: this able to tap its depths
column4: is best equipped to further it. Judging by <i>A World Out of Time
column5:
Eternal Tapestry's well won't run dry anytime soon.

column11: though.

The early Dinosaur Jr. were defined by two qualities: volume and volatility. The stewing bitterness between guitar-slinging introvert J. Mascis and bass-pounding extrovert Lou Barlow resulted in some of the most frazzled and ferocious music of 1980s indie rock. The acrimony was so deep-seated that
column2: even after Barlow's exit in 1989
column3: he went about writing spiteful songs about his ex-bandmate like Taylor Swift writes about ex-boyfriends.

column1: But the first official live document of Dinosaur Jr.'s original-- and following their 2005 reunion
column2: now current-- line-up bears little evidence of the band's eardrum-rupturing
column3: tension-fuelled reputation. Sounding like a crud-encrusted cassette that's been left to decay under the driver seat of your dad's Oldsmobile for the past two decades
column4: Chocomel Daze is less a showcase of a legendary power trio touring behind their heaviest
column5: most incendiary album (1987's You’re Living All Over Me
column6: whose 25th anniversary this set is meant to commemorate) than a reminder of the seventh-generation Dictaphone bootlegs fans had to satisfy themselves with back in the days before we could dial up last night’s show on YouTube.

column1: Recorded before a small crowd in the Dutch town of Nijmegen
column2: Chocomel Daze wears its flaws proudly (the first minute of the opening ""Severed Lips"" is actually muffled to the point of indecipherability)
column3: leaving in all the awkward between-song pauses and background chatter that threatens to overpower the main attraction. The setlist is divided evenly between 1985's self-titled album and You're Living All Over Me
column4: with the band aggressively attacking tracks from the former
column5: while seemingly still getting a handle on material from the latter. (Mascis hits the wrong notes on the crunchy chorus riff of ""The Lung"".) But even with gnarlier takes on ""Does It Float"" and ""Gargoyle""
column6: there's really no reason to reach for these versions over their studio-album counterparts. Aside from Mascis' phaser-pedal flourishes and occasionally hammy vocal tics (he sounds suitably repulsed during ""Repulsion"")
column7: what you get are simply more slack
column8: sloppier
column9: and shoddily recorded renditions that don't come close to inciting the equilibrium-imbalance that normally results from being in the room while this band plays. And lord knows
column10: you're not going to get much in the way of interesting
column11: memorable stage banter from this crew
column12: beyond Barlow's brief shout-out to the titular Dutch brand of chocolate milk.

column1: If there had to be a Dinosaur Jr. live album released this year
column2: fans would've undoubtedly been better served by a hi-fi recording of this fall's I Bet on Sky tour. Not only are Dinosaur Jr. a much tighter unit in their friendly 40s than they were in their testy 20s
column3: but their current setlist contains some genuine revelations that better justify the canonization: a full-torque flashback to their pre-Dinosaur hardcore band Deep Wound; Barlow-bruised versions of Dino's more polished 90s-era MTV hits; and a searing ""Forget the Swan"" that gets stretched out to ""Like a Hurricane"" levels of grandeur. Had Mascis and Barlow never reconciled
column4: there might be a greater historical value to Chocomel Daze as a portrait of the band's formative phase. But
column5: as it stands
column6:
why stare at a faded Polaroid when you can still go experience the real deal?

column3: Roc Marciano threatens to ""push your afro back to 76... those were some good years
column4: baby."" He was born in 1978. It's not the first time the Long Island rapper has ignored the calendar year. After spending the 2000s in the major label hinterlands as a forgotten member of Flipmode Squad
column5: he went Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind on that entire decade with the release of 2010's Marcberg. On that album

column7: equally informed by the pimp posture of the 70s and the crack epidemic of the 80s. He remains in that zone today
column8: but two years later
column9: surrounded by rugged New York rap from artists like Mr. Muthafuckin' eXquire
column10: Action Bronson
column11: Heems
column12: El-P
column13: and the Pro Era crew (not to mention Nas' overtly nostalgic Life is Good)
column14: he sounds like less of an anachronism. Fortunately

column1: In setting and sound
column2: Reloaded is most certainly a ""New York"" album. The beats are steeped in classic blaxploitation funk and understated menace
column3: but the occasional glimpse of light and organic groove offers more entry points than the unrelentingly grim Marcberg. And where Marcberg simply filled a void
column4: Reloaded can create demand among rap fans who look beyond the five boroughs. Roc's voice is more confident and distinctive and
column5: more importantly
column6: he's stepped up his lyrics. They've become something wholly his own as opposed to a clear stylistic descendent of anyone else. He's at a point that we see every few years where a rapper manages to accumulate the escape velocity to transcend the strictures of regionalism and become something that can be embraced by anyone who simply loves the possibilities that hip-hop lyricism allows for. It's ""gangsta rap"" in form alone
column7: still presented as songs with hooks and structure
column8: but the main pursuit is making the English language bend to their will: see Prodigy in 2000
column9: DipSet in 2003
column10: Clipse in 2005
column11: Wayne in 2007
column12: Gucci Mane in 2009
column13: or Rick Ross in 2010. Or
column14: it's ""lyrical"" hip-hop for people who don't necessarily think that term has to be the tool of the ""good guys.""

column1: Roc Marciano pulls pretty much one trick over and over again throughout Reloaded
column2: but it's an awesome one-- managing to stack one multisyllabic rhyme after another in a way that still makes narrative sense
column3: without ever devolving into empty Scribble Jam showmanship. As a result
column4: Reloaded is 100% quotable. Marciano's first few bars on ""Tek to a Mack"" basically sums it up: ""I'm back for the crown
column5: baby/ In the Avi' that's brown like gravy/ Style's wavy
column6: lazy eye Tracy McGrady/ Deliver like an 80-pound baby."" ""Pistolier"" is another astounding example of Marciano's limitless facility with gun talk: ""diamond choker
column7: we bonded at the Ponderosa/ Islamic culture put the copper in the toaster/ Pot smoker drive the Rover with the silent motor/ Mama I'm vulgar my persona got the fly aroma."" Even better is how Roc is realizing the inherent comedy in all of this absurd wordplay. Closer ""The Man"" is something closer to straight punchline stand-up
column8: as Roc comes up with the best NBA namedrops in recent memory over DOOM-style soul cheese (""sniff the Chris Mullin off the envelope
column9: ""the 4-4's chrome with the long nose
column10: call it Ginobili""). Did you enjoy any of those? Great
column11: because the whole album is pretty much that all the time
column12: thrilling and incredibly nerdy
column13:
like watching the best Street Fighter II player in town rule the local arcade.

Based on the above
column14: Reloaded should be something of a minor classic. But if you still consider hip-hop to be a triangulation of beats
column15: rhymes
column16: and life
column17: it's the last of the three that ultimately limits its ceiling. Quite simply
column18: nothing happens on Reloaded. At all. That's something of an overstatement
column19: obviously: Most of the time
column20: Roc and his associates will plot on your demise and execute it with ease
column21: at which point they will have their way with your woman and celebrate over top-shelf liquor. Then they'll probably buy more guns. That's the plot of nearly every single track on Reloaded. Yet none of this seems to be happening in the present tense and it's easy to imagine Roc rapping the entirety of Reloaded from a podium
column22: like it's simply a 55-minute lecture on wordplay. There's an almost wholesale dearth of storytelling and aside from the still rather vague encomium of ""Thug's Prayer
column24:
not a single personal detail.

But Reloaded's narrow brand of lyrical genius is so captivating on a second-by-second basis that these criticisms feel misplaced or even irrelevant. Though his appeal runs deep
column25: Roc Marciano is a specialist and the flipside of the consensus praise granted to universal
column27: and ambitious hip hop records like <a href=""http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/17253-good-kid-maad-city/"" target=""_blank""><i>Good Kid
column28: m.A.A.d. City or My Beautiful Dark Twisted Fantasy is that specialists tend to get underrated or overlooked. A rapper doesn't have to be everything to everyone

column32:
it really doesn't get any better than Reloaded.

column4: early-90s rap and Cam'ron equally
column5: seem like a zeitgeist rap group in some sense
column6: and in that they have an untapped power waiting to be harnessed. There is also an obvious level of talent: Wiki's ability to rap well from a technical perspective almost works against him
column7: but it's still a dazzling skill that could one day be put to good use.

column1: There are also the beats on the album
column2: cooked up by producers Sporting Life and Ramon. They are built from the ground up with hard boom-bap drums
column3: but they attack with an aggressiveness and noise that sprouts from the group's roots in hardcore and punk. There is no dissonance
column4: though
column5: no skronk; they are beats made to be rapped over
column6: but without a nod to the lived-in warmth and old crackle of typical 90s-revival productions.

column1: ""To every mother with a stroller
column2: eyeing me when I roll up/ Know your kid's gonna be just like me when he grows up
column3: Wiki raps on ""Pretty Picture"" and in many cases it's probably be true. But Ratking are a group that are a very long way away from turning that into a rallying cry
column4: from not just embodying disaffected teen rebels but speaking for them. Being able to really connect with that fanbase-- the one that turned the Beastie Boys
column5: Eminem and Odd Future into heroes-- doesn't come easily
column6:
and it can't be papered over with a nice flow.

"|17352.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/17352-wiki93-ep/|5.8|Jordan Sargent

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/18592/homepage_large.7ae2c9fd.jpg|Quarter Turns Over a Living Line|30862.0|Raime|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Blackest Ever Black']|2012-11-21 00:00:00|2012|2016-06-11 17:04:22.157778|"

There isn't an easy entrance point into the music of Raime
column2: the London-based duo signed to the appropriately named Blackest Ever Black label. At times it feels like Joe Andrews and Tom Halstead are purposefully erecting barriers around their work
column3: desperate to keep listeners at a certain distance. This isn't an inclusive experience. It doesn't even tap into post-club comedown chills
column4: although it comes close at times. Instead
column5: the seven tracks here have the cold ripple of alienation and abandon pulsing through them. It feels like the soundtrack of a lonely night out
column6: of someone standing by themselves in the corner of a club
column7: examining a flyer for the umpteenth time
column8: studying their phone just because it's there. The early run of 12"" singles by the pair occasionally felt like austere classroom exercises
column9: with Andrews and Halstead racing to the bottom just because they could. Quarter Turns Over a Living Line peels open that sound
column10: flushing some much-needed air through the pipes.

column1: At times Raime's work feels like a logical endpoint for dubstep
column2: a natural dead zone where all that rumination can come to an uneasy rest. But it also resembles work that's skipped the past decade or so altogether. Andrews and Halstead are self-confessed fans of jungle
column3: and it's easy to trace the 1990s peaks of chilly post-industrial outfits like Pan Sonic
column4: Autechre
column5: and Zoviet*France here. Occasionally Raime's approach is reminiscent of post-rock
column6: especially in their fascination with a bloodless form of machine noise
column7: but also in their use of ambiguously wordy titles. One of their earlier releases contained a track titled ""We Must Hunt Under the Wreckage of Many Systems"". Much like the early Tortoise releases
column8: Raime don't give you any easy answers
column9: instead scattering a trail of malleable clues and ideas for the listener to get lost in and interpret as they see fit.

column1: There's a sense of discovery to Quarter Turns Over a Living Line
column2: with Andrews and Halstead unveiling the slow evolution of their sound over its 40-minute runtime. One of the earliest tracks is a version of ""This Foundry"" (retitled ""The Last Foundry"") from a prior release
column3: which is tightly bound up in the kind of itchy oppression of John Carpenter's Assault on Precinct 13 soundtrack. At times it feels like someone struggling for a last gasp of air after having a plastic bag wrapped tightly around their head
column4: such as on the oppressive grind of ""Soil and Colts"". But the astringency subtly releases in unexpected ways as the album progresses
column5: especially when the use of non-electronic instruments is pushed up in the mix. It's like witnessing Andrews and Halstead subtly chinking cracks of light into their sound
column6: giving it a quality that lifts it above notionally ""dark"" works such as their rather hollow earlier output.

column1: That lightness of touch is most apparent in the closing two tracks
column2: ""Your Cast Will Tire"" and ""The Dimming of Road and Rights"". Here
column3: the sound of scraping guitar strings and violins come to the fore
column4: adding touches of despondency and sadness that drag Raime away from their tendency to dwell a little too hard in a pool of bitter (and
column5: on occasion
column6: emotionally barren) brooding. Those elements are still present
column7: but here Andrews and Halstead find a way to capture that knife-edge turn from rage into melancholy. ""The Dimming of Road and Rights"" plays out like an uneasy passage of time during an inconclusive argument
column8: with both sides settled into an apprehensive truce
column9: unable to find common ground
column10: half expecting the other person to explode into anger at any second. It feels like Raime revealing a little more of themselves than they intended to when this project was initially conceived
column11:
a necessary and inevitable expression of connectivity that arises from spending so long depicting the solitary.

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/18631/homepage_large.5d1dbdf3.jpg|OFF/ON|30881.0|Forma|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Spectrum Spools']|2012-11-21 00:00:00|2012|2016-06-11 17:04:22.711478|"

The Brooklyn trio FORMA's 2011 self-titled debut was a dream pop record that felt very much in tune with electronic world's continued embrace of new age textures. Presented with a wide-eyed
column2: almost precious demeanor
column3: FORMA was curious and cosmic
column4: though not terribly dynamic: Mark Dwinell
column5: Sophie Lam
column6: and George Bennett came off as intrepid sonic pioneers
column7: gently forming otherworldly landscapes in ways that were effective
column8: if too timid
column9: in their simplicity. Looking at the Mars-like terrain on the album's cover
column10: it wasn't hard to see where FORMA's collective head was
column11: but it also didn't suggest there was much life to be found out there. A year later
column12: FORMA return with OFF/ON
column13: promising a darker spin on their sound. The cover-- a fluorescent slash of magma spilling down a black basaltic rock face-- suggests OFF/ON's planet has generated potentially dangerous readings. And while the most engaging moments foster a sense of unease
column14: or more typically a false sense of security
column15: OFF/ON never deviates from FORMA's designated path: it mimicks a crisper
column16: slightly more realized version of its predecessor.

column1: FORMA pull off some neat tricks over the course of these 46 minutes
column2: none of which just any average cosmonaut with an arsenal of analog machines could easily do. Clearly there's a vested interest in the early electronic thrummings coming out of Germany in the late 70s and early 80s
column3: as some of their own equipment dates back to around that time. So it's to be expected that the sounds FORMA are using are naturally fairly sterile and cold. But instead of trying to replicate those moods and atmospheres
column4: FORMA approach their music with a sense of warmth and wonder
column5: manipulating and balancing the familiar to create tracks the signify discovery
column6: rebirth
column7: and exploration. ""FORMA306C"" feels like a krautrock muscle relaxer
column8: swaying back and forth like tipsy ocean liner
column9: while ""FORMA286B"" boasts an array of dizzily playful components that practically orbit around your head.

column1: FORMA aren't necessarily forthcoming with their secrets
column2: concealing or downplaying the most interesting elements with a shaded and understated approach that invites you to either simply sink in or tune out. But underneath the surface-- and upon close
column3: repeated listens-- the details begin to emerge. It's clear that there's something nefarious going on in opener ""OFF""
column4: thanks to those telling
column5: Carpenter-like nightmare arpeggiations
column6: but more nuanced tracks like ""FORMA278"" benefit from slight drops in barometric pressure that add a dimension of disquietude to what could otherwise be described as music better suited to accompany an episode of ""NOVA."" An even better example is closer ""FORMA315""
column7: an uncharacteristically beat-driven piece that is not only daydream-y but slightly scared and remorseful.

column1: The only real problem is that in the event that you can't give OFF/ON your full
column2: undivided attention
column3: colors begin to blur and the music slips into the background. Taking into consideration the way that FORMA serialize their song titles with seemingly meaningless numbers
column4: OFF/ON can feel like a smattering of random entries plucked from larger catalog
column5: one that's ever-expanding and dictated by an algorithm that mutates only ever so slightly from sample to sample. In this light
column6: the attention to detail-- on the part of both the listener and the producer-- is all the more important
column7: especially when the risk of things becoming repetitive and interchangeable runs this high.

column1: But at its core
column2: OFF/ON is a solid record that thrives on the idea of possibility and hedged optimism. Listening for a first time
column3: it's hard not to draw parallels between OFF/ON and daredevil Felix Baumgartner's record breaking space jump last month. As it ran live
column4: major news outlets cut away from his video feed in case the unthinkable were to happen. For some
column5: the suspense was unbearable
column6: but for others
column7: the fact that everything had been so carefully planned and meticulously ordered
column8: the chance that this human rocket would accidentally drill himself into the earth's crust seemed surprisingly slim. Instead
column9: you were left blind to a sense of possibility and wonder that
column10: in your own head
column11:
was all the more vivid and rewarding than the actual footage could ever be.

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/18614/homepage_large.0332258e.jpg|The Velvet Underground & Nico 45th Anniversary [Super Deluxe]|4469.0|The Velvet Underground|['Rock']|0.0|1.0|0.0|['Polydor']|2012-11-20 00:00:00|2012|2016-06-11 17:04:24.535890|"

Forty-five years after its release
column2: everything that was supposed to have made The Velvet Underground & Nico special has been nearly eradicated by its own legend. The most dangerous record of 1967 has been absorbed into the establishment rock canon; the paradoxical fame it earned from its hilariously terrible sales figures in its early years has been negated by reissue after deluxe-edition reissue; and its transgressive kinky-druggy menace has been smothered by the embrace of millions of overly precious Wes Anderson acolytes. Is a limited-edition ""super deluxe"" six-disc box set really going to help restore any of the ineffable outsider cool that it's lost over the years? Actually
column3: yeah
column4: it is.

column1: The new super deluxe edition of TVU&N consists of a new stereo remaster of the album
column2: a new mono remaster (both taken from the original tapes)
column3: a disc of alternate versions and mixes of the songs
column4: a disc of practice sessions recorded at Andy Warhol's Factory
column5: a live recording from around the time the album was recorded (spread across two discs)
column6: and a remaster of Nico's solo debut
column7: Chelsea Girl
column8: which the Velvets performed on. So aside from the 45 minutes of Chelsea Girl
column9: you've got five hours of essentially the same 11 songs presented over and over in various levels of audio fidelity. On paper it may seem indulgent
column10: but listening through the entire massive collection of material results in a sharper-edged portrait of the group than there's ever been
column11: with all of the danger filled back in.

column1: First there's the album proper. The remastering process was handled by Bill Levenson
column2: who's been working on Velvets material since the mid-80s rarities collections VU and Another VU
column3: and who oversaw the 1995 Peel Slowly and See box set that collected all of the group's studio recordings. Levenson knows the material well enough to keep from making it sound too clean. The amp hiss
column4: tape saturation
column5: and overall grit that made TVU&N leap out from the scores of mannered psychedelic rock albums released around the same time is still firmly in place; it's just that the grit sounds better.

column1: The stereo mix breathes in a way that the album never has before. As incredible as it sounds
column2: though
column3: the mono version on the second disc provides the set's first moment of serious revelation: It doesn't breathe at all. In fact
column4: with every throbbing bassline and squalling viola set dead center
column5: the mix is suffocating. The transformative effect it has on the songs is unreal. Lou-fronted rockers like ""I'm Waiting for the Man"" and ""Run
column6: Run
column7: Run"" leap out from the speakers with an aggression that other versions lack. ""All Tomorrow's Parties""
column8: ""Venus in Furs""
column9: and ""The Black Angel's Death Song"" are oppressively noisy
column10: but pleasurably so. It's a sensual sensory overload that underlines just how successful the group was at the music-as-S&M game it was playing with listeners.

column1: Disc four is even rawer
column2: and removes the last bit of remaining studio refinement to expose the Velvets' primal proto-punk heart. The first half is a reproduction of the one-of-a-kind acetate discovered by a record collector in a New York City street sale in 2002-- and sold on eBay a few years later for over $25
column3: 000-- that contained the first version of the album that the band delivered to Columbia Records (and which the label rejected). Some of the tracks would end up on the version of album that Verve issued after taming them down during another round of mixing; others were re-recorded entirely. Compared to the familiar finished version the material sounds unhinged. Moe Tucker's rudimentary drumming on an alternate version of ""Heroin"" is primitive to the extreme
column4: while the original mix of ""Femme Fatale"" place a bizarre falsetto backing vocal from one of the male members high enough in the mix to put a listener on edge. And since the audio's taken straight from a beat-up acetate the whole fantastic mess is covered in crackles and hiss.

column1: The rest of disc four is pulled from a taped rehearsal at the Factory a few months before the Scepter sessions
column2: previously available in bootleg form. Parts of it are more interesting than listenable
column3: like the band dicking around while Lou Reed patiently attempts to explain the lyrics to ""Venus in Furs"" to Nico. Other parts are jaw-dropping
column4: like a version of ""Run
column5: Run
column6: Run"" that quickly turns itself inside out and transforms into a frenetic
column7: semi-improvised Bo Diddley impression that's denser and heavier than almost anything else in the Velvets' catalog and can demand repeat plays back to back.

column1: What makes moments like this
column2: and the set in general
column3: so compelling is that you get a picture of the group as a living
column4: breathing band
column5: separate from the performances that would be frozen in time and started on a long march to iconhood a little over a year later. For a minute-- or sometimes for 12-- you get a sense of what they really were
column6: which is just another garage outfit hopped up on pills and playing rock'n'roll music so hard that it starts flinging off parts. The difference is that their garage was the Factory
column7: and that they were willing to ride it far closer to fully falling apart than anyone else.

column1: That's the image that sustains the final two discs
column2: which together comprise a bootlegged live set from Columbus
column3: Ohio's Valleydale Ballroom in November
column5: four months or so before TVU&N was released. While someone-- maybe a devoted fan of the Factory scene-- yells out Nico's name when she introduces ""All Tomorrow's Parties""
column6: you get the very clear idea that very few people in the crowd know who the Velvet Underground are
column7: or like what they're playing. You can hear maybe two or three members of the audience clap after the opener ""Melody Laughter""
column8: a 28-minute jam that's mostly noisy drone with a brief pop coda at the end. After a feedback-filled scorched-earth rendition of ""Black Angel's Death Song""
column9: Lou Reed snarls at the audience
column10: ""If it's too loud for you
column11: you move back.""

column1: A few months later
column2: right after the release of The Velvet Underground & Nico
column3: the group would convene to record parts of Nico's Chelsea Girl
column4: which is a fine baroque folk-pop album
column5: but nothing approaching that first record. The three other LPs the group recorded before Reed left the band almost four years after that show were great in their own rights
column6: but paled in comparison to TVU&N. Listening to the live recording and hearing the silences between the songs
column7: though
column8: it's easy to imagine a roomful of people being pummeled by this strange
column9: intimidating noise
column10: and seeking safety in the back of the room
column11: completely unaware that the band they're being assaulted by was at that moment (and for not much longer)
column12:
the best in the world.

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/18533/homepage_large.b3a137fc.jpg|Movement|30806.0|Holly Herndon|['Experimental']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Rvng Intl.']|2012-11-20 00:00:00|2012|2016-06-11 17:04:25.095902|"

In a recent interview with the British magazine FACT
column2: Holly Herndon refuted the trope that electronic music is the stuff of impersonal and inhuman androids. The Tennessee native bought into that narrative herself while living in the electronic hub of Berlin
column3: where
column4: though she played with a band named Electrocute
column5: she began taking contrabass lessons. Her hope was that if she could master a ""real instrument
column6: she might
column7: one day
column8: be taken seriously as a composer. But after returning stateside to study at the electronic sanctum of California's Mills College
column9: she realized that her laptop-- a web of code and a fountain of sound-- could make music as personal
column10: intimate
column11: and important as that of any ensemble. ""This is actually the most interesting instrument for me
column12: she told FACT. ""I also think that it's the most personal instrument that the world has ever seen.""

column1: Many people might balk at that idea
column2: that a computer is somehow a more personal instrument than the customary acoustic toolset of music. After all
column3: how can a box of wires
column4: circuits
column5: and chips connected to a screen and controlled by fingers be more individual than a guitar
column6: with its strings simply pressed by fingers
column7: or
column8: better yet
column9: the human voice
column10: the sound of someone simply singing? But
column11: to an extent
column12: computers are forever malleable
column13: able to be programmed and reprogrammed to fit needs and whims and
column14: in turn
column15: to alter those old modes of expression in ways that they couldn't do themselves. On her proper full-length debut Movement
column16: the California-based composer uses her crystalline voice as a chief input for her laptop
column17: ultimately arriving at a poignant nexus of electronic accessibility and experimentation that owes as much to her academic forebears as her club contemporaries. It's a record with the rare capacity to turn cynics who might scoff at the idea of laptops-as-intimate-instruments into believers.

column1: It seems overly convenient and coincidental to compare Herndon's Movement to Laurel Halo's Quarantine. Here are
column2: after all
column3: two American women releasing records in the same year that weave their respective voices into intricate electronic music that sits at the borders of pop
column4: dance
column5: and more esoteric forms. The links are reductive enough to be insulting. But both Movement and Quarantine are bold records
column6: dependent upon a multiplicity of voices from one source to press against borders of populist versus experimental media-- or
column7: better yet
column8: to unite them. At times
column9: both Halo and Herndon seem like would-be popular sirens
column10: ready to deliver hooks to the radio; at other points
column11: however
column12: they seem destined for careers of gigs in small art spaces or extended fellowships at universities. But at their best
column13: they seem like both and neither
column14: composers and thinkers unafraid to elide convention
column15: circumvent categorization and arrive
column16: fully formed
column17: at an intersection of things often thought to be mutually exclusive.

column1: Movement's humanity stems in part from its variety of moods. At times overtly playful and slyly sexual
column2: decidedly monastic and obviously extroverted
column3: these seven pieces skip between feelings with a true-to-life mercurialness and unpredictability. Herndon's sonics are impressive; see the subdural bass moans of opener ""Terminal"" or the careful
column4: Oval-like slices of ""Control And"" for proof. But she never betrays the soul of her music for the sound of it. During ""Breathe""
column5: for instance
column6: Herndon takes a series of deep breaths and scrambles the patterns of inhalation and exhalation. She splits the actions across the channels
column7: conjuring an unlikely choir of dissonance and consonance. Sonically
column8: it's impressive enough
column9: but emotionally
column10: it portrays the struggle to rise above the world's din
column11: to stay centered in a bustle of hyperactivity. It's electronic Zen: Herndon successfully links an electroacoustic premise to a pragmatic observation.

column1: Especially considering that this is her first LP
column2: Herndon's ability to steer music that's simultaneously complex and approachable is astounding: ""Fade""
column3: for instance
column4: should lure fans of the Knife with its iterative keyboards and sticky arctic hook
column5: but the structure-- or
column6: more specifically
column7: the way Herndon handles the beat in relation to her voice-- is a marvel all its own. Herndon frames the rhythm with her voice
column8: syllables darting between its cracks like water washing through rivulets. But that's just the most superficial layer of Herndon's voice. Underneath the hook
column9: samples of her singing crisscross beneath the beat
column10: supplying counterrhythms and serving like little magnets that draw the listener deeper into the song with each pass. It's a perfect interface of machine and user and of intricate composition with irrepressible songcraft. Likewise
column11: though the noisy 64-second track ""Interlude"" might seem ostracizing at first
column12: it plays out like a miniature video game of voices. Herndon manipulates her own tone into blips and volleys that clash with one another in their own electronic Mortal Kombat. It's quixotic
column13: a dose of levity in a field not known for it.

column1: ""Dilato""
column2: the brilliant closer
column3: is the only track that doesn't key on Herndon’s voice. Instead
column4: she samples and stretches the patient intonations of classical baritone Bruce Rameker
column5: pulling his syllables until they turn into a brooding
column6: wordless chorus. The piece is Movement's most unapologetically academic; it treats speech with such force that it recalls Alvin Lucier's I Am Sitting in a Room
column7: in which the composer repeatedly played back and recorded a tape of himself reading text in a room until his speech hummed into howling oblivion. But listen closely for Herndon's own voice
column8: which joins Rameker's most notably just before the three-minute mark. She harmonizes with him for a moment
column9: singing one syllable with an operatic grandeur. It's over in an instant
column10: but it's enough to reiterate Herndon's symbiotic thesis and to make ""Dilato"" feel like much more than a rote exercise in bending one person's voice into phantasmagorias.

column1: Appropriately named
column2: Movement feels like a progression and challenge from one of the year's most exciting new voices
column3: producers
column4: and composers. It's an invitation by example to move in several circles at once and emerge with something that’s brazen
column5: fresh
column6:
and entirely individual.

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/18429/homepage_large.afb11fd6.jpg|Wild Water Kingdom|29388.0|Heems|['Rap']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Greedhead']|2012-11-20 00:00:00|2012|2016-06-11 17:04:25.774361|"

The Fader has a regular feature called ""The Things I Carry"" in which artists share what's in their pockets. A recent subject was Himanshu Suri
column2: better known as Heems of Das Racist
column3: the divisive
column4: allusive
column5: and pop culture savvy rap trio. Heems
column6: along with the usual pocket regulars (keys
column7: wallet) and an elephant totem from his girlfriend
column8: was carrying a $30
column9: 000 check from Kmart
column10: given to him in exchange for the rights to the Das Racist song ""Girl"" for use in a layaway commercial.

column1: When I saw that check
column2: I was annoyed. But while complaints about materialism in rap are common
column3: it's easy to forget that rappers are character-creators
column4: to whom flashiness is a way to promote an artistic brand. If I'm OK with other rappers' excess
column5: why wasn't I willing to understand Heems from within the same context? Because of the way he looks
column6: or where he went to school? At its best
column7: Heems' music raises these sorts of questions
column8: challenging the assumptions and double standards of rap fan groupthink. The question that has to be asked now that he's been playing these tricks for a couple years is simple: Can this philosophy make for compelling music?

column1: In short
column2: yes. His new mixtape Wild Water Kingdom is the most substantial solo project full-length associated with Das Racist to date
column3: because it merges the academic underpinnings of Heems' ideas with thoroughly listenable rap music. Though he's still not the best rapper (his refusal to abide by traditional rhyme schemes will be frustrating to purists) he's made great strides here and is helped along by a NYC underground producer showcase.

column1: Those beats
column2: unfortunately
column3: are forced to sustain the album's first quarter. Heems comes out swinging on ""Cowabunga Gnarly""
column4: a banger from producer-of-the-year candidate Harry Fraud
column5: but quickly loses steam
column6: and resorts to his lazy reference overdrive
column7: a trick which lost its novelty a couple years ago. Claiming
column8: right after you declare your appreciation Junot Diaz
column9: that you're ""as smart as three SAT's
column10: is fine
column11: I guess
column12: but the facts are unrelated. And the Crookers-produced ""Third Thing"" has a great singalong hook
column13: but there's way too much nonsense in the amateurish verses.

column1: Luckily
column2: things do take a turn for the better. Around the halfway point of the title track
column3: another Harry Fraud production (this one replete with gorgeous sitar strings)
column4: Heems decides to turns it on. ""Freedom
column5: put the heat up
column6: who scheming for cheese/ believe in them please/ they need us to reach/ a piece with the place/ that's filled with the trees."" These lines are rapped more fiercely and quickly than anything before
column7: and they refer back to the family that Heems reps throughout the song
column8: and the tape. And for the fans of the old Das Racist shtick
column9: there's still an absurd Princess Diana line nestled a couple of bars later.

column1: It used to be hard to tell if Heems wanted to be a rapper or if he wanted to make people who love rap angry. That's mostly gone now. This guy wants it
column2: and his earnestness occasionally boils over
column3: to the point of sappiness. Not sure if anyone realized that collaborator Safe sounds a lot like Dave Matthews
column4: but the resemblance
column5: and the resulting campfire vibe is enough to kill the otherwise tolerable ""Medium Green Eyes"".

column1: More often
column2: this newfound ability to speak plainly is a huge advantage for Heems. ""Deepak Choppa""
column3: one of the best offerings here
column4: is politically aware and seems truly angry
column5: rather than bitter or sarcastic. ""You know that we could send you back/ at any given time/ it ain't like money that you stack/ money for a lawyer/ that's the money that you lack
column6: he raps from the perspective of an immigration agent
column7: before transitioning into a different flow. On the second half of the song
column8: he takes on race
column9: repping his New York roots and his family and asking that you test his credentials: ""I ain't black/ I ain't white/ I can't rap/ I can't write/ I ain't strapped/ I could fight."" This isn't a sneer
column10: it's a challenge.

column1: In rap purist communities
column2: the inability of some blog rappers to rap well is a well-documented gripe. Hearing a song like ""Tell Me""
column3: in which two of the most disparaged targets wile out out over a huge beat from Earth 2's version of Just Blaze (producer Mike Finito)
column4: is some kind of head turner. Haters are still going to hate lines like Gambino's ""Rush Limballin while I'm listening to tUne-yarDs"" or Heems' spitting ""Chamomile tea that we pour with splash."" But those listeners will have to ask themselves-- would they hate these lines if they were coming from sources like Dipset
column5: Roc Marciano
column6: or Action Bronson?

column1: Of course
column2: those are the kinds of questions Heems has always provoked. Now that he's rapping well
column3: that purpose is free to slide into focus. On Wild Water Kingdom
column4: it's hard to argue with the beats. For the most part
column5: it's hard to argue with the raps. You're going to have to ask yourself
column6: if this guy is still bothering you
column7: what exactly is it that you don't like? Because if it's the way he looks
column8: or the references he's making
column9:
congratulations: you're now that guy who's too conservative to listen to rap music.

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/18593/homepage_large.02c0ad74.jpg|Jessica Pratt|30852.0|Jessica Pratt|['Folk/Country']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Birth']|2012-11-20 00:00:00|2012|2016-06-11 17:04:26.256425|"

The mid-aughts freak-folk moment found artists and fans blurring the boundaries between past and present and seeking out kindred spirits across time
column2: which made it an abundant season for folk reissues. Linda Perhacs' Parallelograms
column3: Karen Dalton's In My Own Time
column4: and Sibylle Baier's Colour Green
column5: to name just a few
column6: all got their long-delayed
column7: much-deserved days in record store windows. And now
column8: after an unhurried half-decade gestation period
column9: 2012 felt like the year we started to hear the debut records from some of the young artists who scooped those reissues up.

column1: One such record is Missouri native Angel Olsen's excellent debut LP Half Way Home. Her songs are struck through with poetic macabre (""I thought this time last year I'd be dead/ It's quite strange the thoughts that pop into your head"") and showcase a tortured
column2: warbling croon that sounds like Vashti Bunyan leading a seance to commune with Roy Orbison. San Francisco's Jessica Pratt calls upon similar influences but makes music that feels like a counterpoint to Olsen's. As with Baier
column3: the simplicity and affectlessness of Pratt's tranquil tunes are precisely what make them so hypnotic. Anyone who appreciated the general idea behind The Milk-Eyed Mender but couldn't quite make peace with Joanna Newsom's divisive vocal quirks (or her love of obtuse
column4: 10-dollar-and-change vocab words) might feel more at home in the plaintive
column5: unadorned warmth of Pratt's debut LP.

column1: Pratt is a young songwriter with a decidedly old soul and a voice that balances spry sweetness with husky grit. ""Night Faces"" has a weathered
column2: world-weary vibe as she sings of shedding ""a million tears trying to dig myself out all these years
column3: while ""Half Twain the Jesse"" moves with an air of childlike curiosity. The songs themselves also feel lodged in some liminal realm between past and present
column4: devoid of references that might place them in a historical moment. But their sepia tone never feels like a cheap gimmick; words like ""brethren
column5: ""twain
column6: and ""bushel"" roll off Pratt's tongue so naturally that you quickly become enveloped in the record's self-contained grammar. The effect is cumulative
column7: lulling the listener into a tranquil
column8: meditative space somewhere outside the interruptions of the modern world.

column1: Pratt and her acoustic guitar are mostly unaccompanied
column2: and there are occasional imperfections-- buzzing strings
column3: the faint crack of her voice-- that add to its atmosphere of unvarnished intimacy. Her chord progressions are neither neat resolutions nor mournful elegies
column4: which is to say that her songs traverse that vast
column5: somewhat under-explored territory between happy and sad (except for ""Titles Under Pressure""
column6: which revolves around a hook that goes ""The next time
column7: I'm stayin' away from this place/ I cannot make more mistakes""; that one's a heartbreaker.) Even when Pratt sings a line like ""All the lights in my life are fading"" on ""Streets of Mine""
column8: there's a bright
column9: resilient note or two that belie how dismal it looks on paper.

column1: The last song on the album is a dim
column2: crackling
column3: live-recorded track called ""Dreams""
column4: on which she's joined by a man whose voice sounds like a cross between Phil Elvrum and Fred Neil. It's subdued enough to keep the vibe enact
column5: but his sudden presence reinforces what a quiet
column6: private and secluded place Pratt's self-titled debut has been. Listeners who prefer their folk flashier or wrapped around memorable
column7: poppy hooks might find Pratt's approach meandering or bland. But those with a more patient ear will find her a worthy and quietly distinct heir of Baier
column8: Bunyan
column9: and Dalton's homespun sound. ""There was a time before us
column10: she  murmurs on the lovely ""Bushel Hyde""
column11: sounding like she's perhaps found a way to travel back there herself
column12:
picking up some of her forebears' weathered wisdom and weaving it into her own worldview.
