column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/18395/homepage_large.8efaa022.jpg|We Don't Even Live Here|3484.0|P.O.S.|['Rap']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Rhymesayers']|2012-11-20 00:00:00|2012|2016-06-11 17:04:26.743912|"

The title of Stefon Alexander's fourth LP as P.O.S. conveys a self-deprecation and sense of displacement that reminds me of the last time I saw him perform live. Unfortunately
column2: due to <a href=""http://pitchfork.com/news/48287-pos-cancels-tour/"">recent health complications
column3: it could be the last time I see him live for a while. He was added to the 2010 Coachella lineup only days before the festival took place and he was quite literally the first person to perform that weekend
column4: arriving to a sparsely-filled tent of curious foreigners and confused onlookers who almost certainly assumed they were supposed to see P.O.D. He acknowledged the obstacles
column5: embraced the opportunity
column6: and absolutely rocked that show-- he undoubtedly earned some fans in that half hour. Making the best out of a shitty situation is likewise a prevalent theme in P.O.S.' latest record of clenched-fist
column7: politicized
column8: and proudly Midwestern hip-hop. The problem is that the strangely smug We Don't Even Live Here feels more like P.O.S. preaching to the converted than attempting to make a believer out of anyone
column9: lacking any palpable resistance necessary to justify the constant underdog pose.

column1: To his credit
column2: P.O.S. ensures We Don’t Even Live Here at least sounds celebratory. It features production from the likes of both Lazerbeak and Boys Noize that goes heavy on squelchy electro-funk
column3: you get a Justin Vernon cameo on ""Where We Land""
column4: while ""Wanted/Wasted"" and ""They Can't Come"" are near disco-sample rap
column5: at least not that far off from something that could appear on a 97 Bad Boy record. For the most part
column6: the aggro-punk abrasion of 2009's Never Better is jettisoned
column7: but most of it is either overtly rock (the 5 Hour Energy-pounding opener ""Bumper"") or implicitly rock
column8: the drums always knocking and often taking the tone of real snares and kicks. It could just as easily please a Rock The Bells purist as it could a Warped Tour onlooker. #47 debut on Billboard aside
column9: no one would consider it pop-rap
column10: yet there are catchy hooks throughout
column11: even if their clunky verbiage make them difficult to actually sing along with.

column1: But it's not really a crossover of any sort since the appeal of We Don't Even Live Here essentially comes down to whether or not you're already marching with P.O.S. The vast majority of the record is rendered from the perspective of ""we"" or ""they
column2: where ""we"" constitutes the Doomtree collective and anyone who has even some semblance of anger about the state of hip-hop or the economy. ""They"" are classic strawmen-- commercial rappers who are liars by definition
column3: shady politicians
column4: and anyone who has doubted Doomtree. So while We Don't Even Live Here is cerebral
column5: not much of it stands up to intelligent debate
column6: often vague and heavy-handed at the same time. The biggest problem manifests in a track like ""Fuck Your Stuff""
column7: where a group chant promises that they'll be ""scuffin' up your Nikes
column8: spittin' on your whip."" It's a weirdly dated image that's the first of many signs that P.O.S. has some kind of awareness of the mainstream. But other than brief mentions of OWS and terribly forced namedrops of Anonymous and Christopher Hitchens
column9: you're left wondering about the last time he meaningfully engaged with it. Subliminals are thrown at the likes of ""All I Do Is Win""
column10: ""Stunt 101""
column11: ""Diamonds from Sierra Leone""
column12: ""Run This Town""
column13: and for fuck's sake
column14: J-Kwon.

column1: As a response
column2: do you mention Jay-Z's involvement in the 2012 election
column3: or Kanye's benefit concerts
column4: or Diddy's ""Vote or Die"" campaign
column5: or that Young Jeezy made the definitive Barack Obama track? It hardly seems worth it
column6: since P.O.S.'s reaction on ""Wanted/Wasted"" is the following: ""black president
column7: hooray for history/ but that shit's still totally pretend."" What's ""that shit
column8: and how is it ""totally pretend""? He leaves it at that
column9: and ""Fuck Your Stuff"" is simply more food for thought filled with empty calories: ""fuck dumbin' it down/ spit ice
column10: skip jewelry/ Molotov cocktails on me like accessories."" ""Accessory"" being a key term since P.O.S.' platform of revolution is so depersonalized-- ""they on some nonsense/ we on some non-stop
column11: ""kickin' out your DJ
column12: ""this world's got a whole lot of locked doors/ we decided not to live here anymore""-- the homemade explosives and other instruments of mayhem mentioned throughout are rendered as much of a bauble and signifier as one of ""their"" luxury cars. Hell
column13: the title of ""Lock-Picks
column14: Knives
column15: Bricks
column16: and Bats"" might as well be <a href=""http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dTR7yvONCV8"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">""Beamer
column17: Benz
column18: or Bentley"".

column1: There can always stand to be more socially engaged musicians in any genre
column2: but hip-hop has proven to be bountiful if imperfect on that end in 2012. You could hear the lived-in experience on Killer Mike's R.A.P. Music
column3: a record which balances blanket statements with tough questions. El-P's Cancer for Cure conflated sci-fi with poli-sci. The Coup filtered absurdist humor through itchy new wave. Death Grips might not be saying a whole lot that's intelligible
column4: but it sure as hell makes you want to smash something. Even the abhorrently violent hip-hop coming from Chicago can trigger real discussion as a necessary reflection of its environment. Ironically
column5: We Don't Even Live Here creates a world where P.O.S. is all too welcome. You'll never go broke playing yourself up as the solution or alternative to the perceived mindlessness of pop radio
column6: but it doesn't matter if you're going to the club to get drunk or simply reading post-election commentary that confirms whatever beliefs you held beforehand: They're both forms of escapism
column7:
and We Don't Even Live Here just doesn't seem aware of how content it really is.

"|17214.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/17214-we-dont-even-live-here/|5.7|Ian Cohen

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/18243/homepage_large.06fc9f79.jpg|The Disintegration Loops|302.0|William Basinski|['Experimental']|0.0|1.0|0.0|['Temporary Residence']|2012-11-19 00:00:00|2012|2016-06-11 17:04:27.262939|"

In the early part of the last decade
column2: William Basinski's The Disintegration Loops was the sort of music you passed around. Once you heard it
column3: you wanted to tell somebody about it. There was obviously the sound itself
column4: so hypnotic that it was immediately understood as a classic of ambient music. But there was more to it.

column1: The Disintegration Loops arrived with a story that was beautiful and heartbreaking in its own right. It's been repeated so many times that Basinski himself has grown weary of telling it: in the 1980s
column2: he constructed a series of tape loops consisting of processed snatches of music captured from an easy listening station. When going through his archives in 2001
column3: he decided to digitize the decades-old loops to preserve them. He started a loop on his digital recorder and left it running
column4: and when he returned a short while later
column5: he noticed that the tape was gradually crumbling as it played. The fine coating of magnetized metal was slivering off
column6: and the music was decaying slightly with each pass through the spindle. Astonished
column7: Basinski repeated the process with other loops and obtained similar results.

column1: Shortly after Basinski digitized his loops came the September 11 attacks. From the roof of his space in Brooklyn
column2: he put a video camera on a tripod and captured the final hour of daylight on that day
column3: pointing the camera at a smoldering lower Manhattan. On September 12
column4: he cued the first of his newly created sound pieces and listened to it while watching the footage. The impossibly melancholy music
column5: the gradual fade
column6: and the images of ruin: the project suddenly had a sense of purpose. It would become an elegy for that day. Stills from the video were used for the covers of the CDs
column7: and eventually
column8: the hour-long visual with sound was released on DVD. The video is included with the four volumes of the music and two new live pieces in this lavish and impressive box set.

column1: The beauty of the music is not easy to explain. There are plenty of pieces that work in a similar way-- the beat-less drone pieces of Gas
column2: a few of Gavin Bryars' most heartrending works
column3: the experiments in memory by the Caretaker-- but it's hard to quantify this music's special pull. Each of the nine pieces on the original four volumes has its own character
column4: yet all are related and function like variations on a theme. ""Dlp 1.1""
column5: marked by a plaintive horn sound
column6: has the air of a dejected fanfare
column7: a meditation on death and loss (it was this loop that was paired with the 9/11 video). ""Dlp 2.1"" is more of a metallic drone
column8: filled with anxiety and encroaching dread. The source material on ""Dlp 4"" sounds like a soundtrack to an educational film
column9: not terribly far from the warble of an early Boards of Canada interlude
column10: but the chaotic ripples of distortion make it seem even more uneasy. ""Dlp 3"" feels like a snippet from an impossibly lush and shimmering Debussy piece stretched to infinity and then lowered into an acid bath. The moods and textures of these pieces are all different but they become more powerful in relation to one another.

column1: There's an irony to the four volumes of The Disintegration Loops appearing here on vinyl for the first time
column2: since the defiantly analog origin of the music is central to its appeal. Even 10 years later
column3: the internet is generally a poor space for contemplating the end; there are few digital metaphors for the process of dying. With Basinski's pieces
column4: the metaphor couldn't be more simple. This music reminds us of how everything eventually falls apart and returns to dust. We're listening to music as it disappears in front of us. Hearing the music on vinyl
column5: with its inherent imperfections
column6: and imagining the records changing over time
column7: lends another layer of poignancy.

column1: Given the central idea behind the project
column2: the length of the individual tracks is important. The first
column4: is just over an hour long
column5: and its source only lasts a few seconds. To listen to the entire piece is to hear that segment many hundreds of times
column6: and the progression from ""music"" to silence happens incrementally with each play. But the loops don't fade linearly. It often takes a few minutes for the obvious cracks to appear
column7: and then the tumble toward the void speeds up at the end
column8: presumably because the cumulative runs against the tape head had loosened even the bits of tape that were still hanging on. The process is so gradual it focuses attention in unique way; I find myself examining each new cycle to discover what is left and what has vanished.

column1: It's possible to use this music in the quintessential ambient sense
column2: allowing it to play in the background while doing something else. The sound is uniform and drone-like
column3: so you can adjust the volume and not worry about it intruding. But there is something uncanny about the emotion embedded in this music. It never feels neutral
column4: so it's hard for me to just have it playing in the background. Part of that is what I know of how it was made
column5: and part of that is the nature of the loops themselves. Basinski has a rare feel for mood and texture. The sounds on their own are haunting
column6: and Basinski has a wonderful ear for how a loop can work
column7: how to capture these bits of incidental music in a place where there's just a hint of tension that is never released.

column1: One unexpected twist in The Disintegration Loops story is that some of the work was later performed. New music ensembles have charted the progression and decay of the pieces and scored them for a live setting
column2: and recordings from two shows are included in this box set. (One of the performances is by the ensemble Alter Ego
column3: who partnered with Gavin Bryars and Philip Jeck in 2007 to record a new version of Bryars' ""The Sinking of the Titanic"". The presence of Alter Ego reinforces the thematic and emotional connection between the two pieces.)

column1: I was skeptical of these live versions at first
column2: but over time they made more sense. They bring a different quality to the experience and offer a subtle twist. The key to live recordings lies in the rests. Little by little
column3: the players have to insert a bit more silence into the piece and hold that silence as they cycle through the same phrase. And there's something especially tense and uneasy about hearing this happen in a moment with live performers. It also makes it difficult for the audience to know exactly when the piece has ended
column4: and when it finally does
column5: they explode with applause and
column6: presumably
column7: relief.

column1: I've owned many box sets and this is possibly the most gorgeous and substantial one I've ever seen. There are CD and vinyl versions of all the music; the vinyl is heavy
column2: and the pressings are very well done. There's a book that has liner notes from Antony Hegarty
column3: David Tibet
column4: Basinski himself
column5: and others. But most of the book consists of blown-up frames from the video piece. It's almost like a flip book
column6: as each new shot brings us a little closer to darkness. For me
column7: it functions like a more tolerable version of the video piece
column8: which
column9: even after all this time
column10: I still have trouble watching. I respect it and understand that it might work very differently for someone who was there
column11: but it's still difficult for me to watch footage of burning Manhattan in an ""art"" context.

column1: It's been said that box sets are tombstones
column2: but this one feels like a living and breathing thing. And there's an irony in that too. The obvious observation about The Disintegration Loops is that it's about death
column3: but of course
column4: life gives death meaning. A couple of days ago I was listening to ""Dlp 4"" while riding the subway to work. For the track's early half
column5: I was gripped by the sublime beauty of the repeating music and I was lost in my own world completely. But then as it started to break apart and silence took over I started to become aware of what was around me. I could hear the engines
column6: the rattle of the tracks
column7: and the voices of people in the subway car. The music had me thinking about the biggest questions-- why we are here and how we exist and what it all means. And then as the last crackle faded and the music was no more
column8:
I took in my surroundings and looked around at the faces and I was right there with everybody and we were alive. 

"|17064.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/17064-the-disintegration-loops/|10.0|Mark Richardson

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/18554/homepage_large.ea9946f4.jpg|Rare Chandeliers|29708.0|Action Bronson|['Rap']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Vice']|2012-11-19 00:00:00|2012|2016-06-11 17:04:27.922702|"

Action Bronson and the Alchemist are an obvious pairing. Both revive and tweak classic New York rap
column2: and are expertly good at doing so. Some things just make sense
column3: and this is one of those things -- or at least you'd think it would be. On paper
column4: their collaborative mixtape Rare Chandeliers should have no trouble living up to its expectations
column5: but in practice it reveals cracks in Bronson's highly tailored aesthetic.

column1: Bronson's profile has ballooned this year thanks to Blue Chips
column2: his March mixtape with producer Party Supplies. It's funny now to think that just a year ago
column3: it seemed like Bronson would never be able to shake those Ghostface comparisons. But on Blue Chips he fleshed out his own character
column4: one that acts like Tony Soprano
column5: travels like James Bond
column6: and eats like Frank Bruni. Bronson's world is a carefully constructed fantasy
column7: but he has both the deep imagination and wicked humor required to make the persona as engrossing as it is singular. It is no surprise that in the past year
column8: Bronson has found a kindred spirt in Riff Raff
column9: rap's foremost ridiculous yet rewarding character.

column1: Blue Chips was Bronson's breakout
column2: but if there's one thing that Rare Chandeliers makes clear
column3: it's that Party Supplies' production had a crucial hand in why that album was a clear step up. The Alchemist's beats on Rare Chandeliers are perfectly good
column4: but they do little to amplify Bronson's character. Blue Chips was sourced using samples ripped straight from YouTube and the slapdash
column5: madcap production almost imagined Bronson as the star of his own blaxploitation film
column6: which is what the cover of Rare Chandeliers aims to evoke. It was also the perfect fit for a rapper who spits punchlines as they come -- the track ""5 Minute Beats 1 Take Raps"" served as the album's unofficial motto. In spirit (though not quite sound)
column7: the production was an outgrowth of the two's deliriously fun ""Contemporary Man
column8: a one-off song where Bronson freestyled over a succession of 80s pop hits.

column1: Five-minute beats isn't the Alchemist's style
column2: and the precision here too often zaps Bronson's character of its color
column3: in turn sapping the music of fun. There has always been a nastiness to Bronson-- especially towards women-- and that unfortunately gets played up on <i>Rare Chandeliers
column4: an album that is both darker and more stately in tone. The Bronson here is one who lurks in shadows
column5: alleys
column6: and cigar lounges and possesses little of the awareness of others displayed on Blue Chips joints like ""Hookers at the Point"" or ""Thug Love Story 2012"". The line between jokester and asshole is a blurry one
column7: and on a track like ""Demolition Man""
column8: you get the sense that maybe Bronson is starting to believe his own illusion.

column1: There are times
column2: though
column3: when the duo strike gold; unsurprisingly
column4: it's when they loosen things up and play with structure. ""Randy the Musical"" flips through three beats in four minutes
column5: all of which feel like they were played by a live band. ""Eggs on the Third Floor"" likewise switches halfway through into a mimed cypher
column6: which is essentially the ideal setting for Bronson's style of rapping. That's not to say that every Bronson song needs to be pull the rug out from under itself after 90 seconds
column7: but that he's at his best and when his beats pump him with energy. Unfortunately
column8: that doesn't happen enough here.

column1: Of course
column2: there are also songs like ""The Symbol"" or ""Modern Day Revelations""
column3: where the very simple formula of ""great beat plus great rapping"" spits out enjoyable results. Relying on that formula shouldn't be a problem in of itself
column4: but that easy repetition can soon offer diminishing returns. It is the same path that made one Curren$y EP indistinguishable from the next.

column1: Rare Chandeliers offered itself as genius meeting of minds
column2: and the album's core quality speaks precisely to the level of talent involved. But there is more to Bronson as an artist than merely matching him up with a stylistically similar producer
column3: and Rare Chandeliers makes that clear. It knocks
column4: yes
column5:
but it's more instructive than anything.

Ian MacKaye
column3: America's Angriest Teenager
column4: is now 50 years old. He and Amy Farina
column5: his partner in the Evens
column6: have a four-year-old son. It's been six years since the previous Evens album. Fugazi played their final show to date 10 years ago this month. Anyone waiting for that explosive band to resume operations should not be holding their breath: MacKaye is presently no more (and no less) the guy who sang ""Bed for the Scraping"" than that guy was the one who sang ""Straight Edge.""

column1: One fascinating thing about MacKaye is that
column2: for someone with a reputation as a world-class control freak
column3: he's always been extraordinarily good at collaboration. Now he's half of a two-person partnership
column4: in music as well as life
column5: and drummer/singer Farina continues to be as much of a presence in their third album's songs as he is. They trade off lines
column6: interject harmonies or commentary
column7: rarely sing alone for more than a few seconds. (Her lyrics tend to be abstract and impressionistic
column8: his concrete and argumentative.) Farina is a very precise but unusual drummer-- in the Evens
column9: as with her earlier tenure backing up Lois Maffeo
column10: she tends to play really hard in half-time
column11: or to deliberately avoid the downbeat. So a lot of the beatkeeping role in this band belongs to MacKaye's baritone guitar; he'll often strum at twice Farina's tempo
column12: or hold down a pulse on a single note while she plays around him.

column1: The Evens can work their way up to fury when they need to: on ""Wanted Criminals""
column2: the closest thing to an old-fashioned Fugazi rave-up here
column3: they alternate an assaultive riff with MacKaye's ruthless sketch of the surveillance state. (""Jails in search of prisoners
column4: goes the refrain. Middle-age softness has crept into his enunciation
column5: but not his politics.) Mostly
column6: though
column7: they let negative space do their work for them. They're not just quiet
column8: they're demonstrating their command of their power by not throwing it around.

column1: As careful as they are to avoid repeating themselves
column2: you don't spend as many decades in music as the Evens have without having a sense of history's weight. MacKaye is also the guy who wrote ""Look Back and Laugh"" and ""Salad Days"" before he was 22 years old
column3: and there are nods to the lesser-known crannies of independent rock's past scattered all over The Odds. The pinpoint bop-bop-bops and fluttering-handed guitar part of ""This Other Thing"" seem to be a tribute to another Washington
column4: D.C.-area duo
column5: Jenny Toomey and Mark Robinson's early-90s project Grenadine; the ringing bridge riff in ""Warble Factor"" is straight out of the Mission of Burma playbook.

column1: The only time they actually sound like cranky old folks is ""Competing with the Till""
column2: a song about playing at a bar that didn't treat them as the true artistes they are. The boss complains that they're soundchecking while ""money's standing outside""; eventually
column3: MacKaye realizes that ""to him
column4: all the people coming to the show were just there to pay his rent."" The song's partly redeemed by goofy lounge-lizard piano playing and the Evens' gift for phrasemaking-- ""our audience is your clientele""-- but they might also acknowledge that they have a clientele of their own.

column1: MacKaye once made a big point of being a kid
column2: and now he's demonstrably not one in any way. But he's also always made a big point of moving forward and evolving
column3: and of not being a careerist. The Odds is
column4: in every way
column5:
the product of scaling down operations rather than of giving up or throwing the fans a nostalgia trip. It's fair to say that the Evens have set their target low and close; you could also call that intimacy.

In September 2011
column2: El Perro del Mar posted the song  ""What Do You Expect"" online. Comprising a collage of samples over a minimal beat
column3: it was a protest track released shortly after the London riots. Considering that Sarah Assbring was better known for chronicling romantic relations over those between social classes
column4: it was jarring to hear her deploy samples like ""The police are not listening to them-- what do you expect?"" Toward the end
column5: in her characteristic sullen murmur
column6: she delivers the lines
column7: ""Never grow tired of this pale
column8: pale fire."" It's a bit vague to be inflammatory on its own
column9: but in context
column10: it bore a certain poignancy.

column1: ""What Do You Expect"" hasn't ended up on the LP she named Pale Fire
column2: and Assbring has backed off from politics since then
column3: focusing instead on the dueling forces that have preoccupied her since her debut
column4: 2005's Look! It's El Perro Del Mar. ""In this world
column5: you think you have no reason to believe in love or in anything much
column6: she said of the title. ""Then one day
column7: when you least expect it
column8: a light appears on the far horizon...It's the pale fire. The promise of love and hope-- all consuming and elusive.""

column1: A slight cop-out? Sure
column2: though no one was expecting an album of fiery protest songs from one of Sweden's most reliable portrayers of romance and whimsy. What twists the knife is that Assbring has said that Pale Fire was inspired by the 90s music she used to love-- namely house and trip hop. The idea of a dance album from El Perro Del Mar is tantalizing: tears on the floor and a thick
column3: moody fog in the air
column4: as apt for dancing as for watching shadows. The extended version of Pale Fire's centerpiece
column5: ""Walk On By""
column6: goes so far as to include a whopping
column7: very noticeable sample from Massive Attack's ""Unfinished Sympathy""
column8: but disappointingly
column9: Assbring's dalliances with the politicized movement and with the bold
column10: era-defining chime of house are reduced to wan dilutions of the original inspirational source material.

column1: Set those intentions aside
column2: though
column3: and Assbring at least stays true to the hushedly sensual vibe with which she's made her name. The title track punches in with a flurry of horns which fade to a tentative murmur and a resigned dance breakdown better made for moping than any frenetic movement. A synth zips its way around ""Home is to Feel Like That""
column4: and its beat is initially as giddy as its first words: ""I just had to see you
column5: I just had to see you."" But those words quickly veer south and become a farewell
column6: something that characterizes Pale Fire. Each mention of love is followed by an annulment
column7: and the closest thing to a straightforward declaration of intent
column8: ""I Was a Boy""
column9: is a delicate husk that's about as appropriate to carry the themes of a love song as is a requiem.

column1: But most requiems aren't this easy to move to
column2: and Pale Fire fortunately picks up the pace from time to time. ""I Carry the Fire"" is house inhabited by ghosts
column3: and ""To the Beat of a Dying World"" clings tight to a steady
column4: propulsive drone. ""Hold Off the Dawn"" comes off like an intensely loud synthpop track heard through layers of gossamer that slowly envelop the song. Somewhere in the mix are lasers
column5: stuttering pianos
column6: and skips of percussion
column7: but picking them out isn't easy. Nothing's exactly immediate -- but that's hardly a surprise either. Pale Fire doesn't command your attention so much as wait patiently until it drifts into your view and then goes away. Assbring's said as much about the concept of love over the years; on Pale Fire
column8:
it sounds just as much like her stance on music.

0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/18537/homepage_large.7a274717.jpg|Sequitur|29955.0|Steve Hauschildt|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Kranky']|2012-11-19 00:00:00|2012|2016-06-11 17:04:29.906709|"

Blacklight posters. Telescopes. Stacks of VHS tapes. A grainy video of a comet traveling across the pitch black expanse of space. If Emeralds
column2: the Cleveland-born synth and guitar three piece
column3: are known for anything
column4: it's their ability to take empty nostalgia and flip it into deep introspection. It's a skill that speaks to their musical prowess as much as it does their sincere love of things that many people would initially write off as ironic.

column1: As solo artists
column2: each member has taken their love of ephemera and abstract ideas in different directions. John Elliott went cosmic
column3: making music that sounds like it was conceived on a space shuttle
column4: while Mark McGuire's burrowed further into his guitar
column5: creating gorgeous ripples of dusky sunlight-tinged music that sounds like the work of a band instead of one guy. Steve Hauschildt
column6: on the other hand
column7: is steadily molding soft drone
column8: spa-ready new age
column9: and breathy keys into something that isn't quite dance music
column10: but isn't fully ambient either. On Sequitur
column11: his second album for Kranky in two years
column12: he manages to make the jump into intellectual electronics without losing the playfulness that made him appealing in the first place.

column1: The most immediately noticeable aspect of the record is that Hauschildt is now singing. Sort of. His vocals are masked by a vocoder
column2: rendered borderline indecipherable. This isn't an accident. In the press release for the record
column3: Hauschildt explains that he wants to make an album that uses technology as a way of expressing androgyny. By mixing male and female tones
column4: he's arrived at a vocal sound that isn't exactly either. It's a heavy concept to broach
column5: especially when he could just as easily carry on without explaining it at all
column6: but Sequitur is an album for thinking to above anything else.

column1: Across eight tracks
column2: he combines layers of glittering synth with smooth washes of mechanical hum. There are moments when this stuff fades too far into the background
column3: like in the pretty but overly repetitive ""Vegas Mode""
column4: which is technically accomplished but lacks heft. ""Kept""
column5: the most explicitly ambient piece on the record
column6: demands attention due to its gummy web of textured keys that pulse with vitality. If ""Vegas Mode"" is Hauschildt straddling multiple genres and not really pulling it off
column7: then ""Kept"" shows that maybe he would be better served tackling one thing at a time. Which is not to say that Sequitur is a bad album. More than anything
column8: it's a hint at what Hauschildt's capable of.

column1: Today
column2: you could walk into just about any remaining record store and pick up a wide array of deluxe reissues of long haired dudes from previous decades messing with synthesizers they wanted nothing more than to understand. It's great that they exist. Those records are often mind bogglingly ahead of their time
column3: and are a clear influence on a new crop of electronic music obsessives
column4: but they often feel like curiosities-- as if the end result was just experimenting with the equipment rather than using it to make fully formed pieces.

column1: With the academic concept behind Sequitur
column2: Hauschildt initially seems like he's part of that school
column3: but when the album reaches closer ""Steep Decline""
column4: everything's overwhelmingly human. On that track
column5: cavernous drums boom across a tangle of triumphant keys
column6: and it sounds like Hauschildt's attempting to drag emotion from a sterile soundscape. He'll certainly make better records
column7: yes
column8:
but right now Sequitur feels like a step forward for a genre that could happily stay the same forever.

Of all the grunge bands that went multi-platinum in the 1990s
column3: Soundgarden pulled it off with the least amount of drama or fall-out. No antagonistic relationships with the media
column4: no publicized addictions
column5: no scandals
column6: no suicides. Their legacy is instead one of hard work
column7: perseverance
column8: and pragmatism; after all
column9: Soundgarden had already embraced the benefits of signing to a major label several years before Kurt Cobain had developed a self-loathing attitude about doing the same. Even the band's dissolution in 1997 was less of a bombshell than a simple product of boredom with the biz.

column1: So it follows that the band's recent reunion has a par-for-the-course
column2: procedural air: Soundgarden are back together and making new music because
column3: well
column4: that's what dormant alt-rock institutions are supposed to do now
column5: right? Even the band's would-be comeback coronation
column6: King Animal's ""Been Away Too Long""
column7: is less a statement of celebration than obligation
column8: the titular declaration undercut by Chris Cornell's admission that ""I never really wanted to stay.""

column1: Still
column2: the return of Soundgarden is something to get excited about
column3: if only because it momentarily delays the release of another Cornell solo album. And fortunately
column4: the singer's interim attempts to reinvent himself -- as a Jeff Buckley-esque crooner
column5: Timbaland's favorite mobile-phone pitchman
column6: and wet-blanket warbler for a squandered hard-rock supergroup opportunity-- have little bearing on the outcome of King Animal. However
column7: your enthusiasm for this album will ultimately depend on how often you return to 1996's Down on the Upside
column8: an album that scored the band another platinum disc to hang in their bathrooms but felt like a holding pattern after the impressive four-album progression charted from 1988's sludgy Ultramega OK to 1994's steely Superunknown.

column1: On the latter album
column2: Soundgarden got their formula of muscular hard rock
column3: brooding
column4: psychedelic power ballads
column5: and acoustic mysticism down to an exact science
column6: and Upside simply repeated those same moves to slightly diminished returns. (Consider how the surreal
column7: bad-trip Beatleisms of Superunknown's ""Black Hole Sun"" got processed into the melodramatic and obvious ""Blow Up the Outside World."") Now
column8: imagine that same formula rehashed and diluted even more and you've got King Animal.

column1: The result is all the more disappointing given a strong start that showcases the band's regained command of rhythm and ballast. ""Non-State Actor"" grooves menacingly like a funkier ""Spoonman""
column2: while the album's hands-down standout
column3: ""By Crooked Steps""
column4: reminds us that Soundgarden is at its best when making Ben Shepherd and Matt Cameron's stuttering time signatures
column5: Kim Thayil's contorted riffage
column6: and Cornell's glass-shattering wail sound like perfectly natural FM-radio fodder.

column1: From there
column2: the band simmer down into moodier
column3: mid-tempo realms-- minus the skyscraping
column4: MTV-baiting hooks that once allowed them to mellow out without boring the mosh pit. And after a while
column5: you get the sense that Soundgarden are checking boxes off on a list: ""Bones of Birds"" is the ""Black Hole""-sized psychedelic centerpiece that boasts an affective
column6: downcast riff from Thayil
column7: but is bogged down by an undercooked
column8: overwrought chorus. And there are two attempts -- back-to-back
column9: no less -- at a congenial
column10: acoustic-strummed exercise a la ""Burden in My Hand"" (""Black Saturday"" and ""Halfway There"")
column11: but without the anthemic refrains to put them over the top. Likewise
column12: the rare excursions outside their classic-rockin' comfort zone lead to dead ends
column13: as when the dubby outro on ""Worse Dreams"" shoots for trippy
column14: free-form chaos but winds up an aimless
column15: uneventful mess. The autopilot nature of King Animal's second half is perfectly summed up by the repeated chain-gang chant of the closing ""Rowing"": ""Don't know where I'm going/ I just keep on rowing/ I just keep on pulling/ Gotta row.""

column1: King Animal makes for a respectable display of Soundgarden's proficiency
column2: but lacks their once-imposing majesty. Listening to the record
column3: it's easy to forget what a disorienting
column4: brutalizing effect songs like ""Rusty Cage"" and ""Jesus Christ Pose"" had on the early-90s rock landscape
column5: even after Nirvana had nudged post-hardcore-schooled noise to the right of the dial. And in the decade and a half that Soundgarden were out of commission
column6: there have been many art-metal aspirants-- from the Deftones and Queens of the Stone Age to Mastodon and Boris-- who've aimed for a similar balance of brains and brawn. The best hope for King Animal was that Soundgarden would be inspired enough by their spiritual successors to want to outdo them
column7: and set a new benchmark for ambitious aggression. Instead
column8:
the group's first album since 1996 just sounds like the one they would've churned out in 1998.

Early this year when I interviewed Michael Quattlebaum
column3: the New York poet and performance artist who raps as Mykki Blanco
column4: he explained: ""I would rather be famous like Insane Clown Posse than like A$AP Rocky"". He spoke of his childhood adoration of Eminem and his preferred ""shock-rock"" tactics in approaching art and rap music-- an ideology that synced up nicely with the sinister
column5: hallucinatory handful of Mykki Blanco tracks that had been posted on SoundCloud. But shocking listeners is a tall order in 2012

So it follows that Cosmic Angel: Illuminati Prince/ss

column4: Gatekeeper
column5: and Sinden offer up a broad

column3: hissing: ""Eighteen/ Mykki Blanco
column4: teenage dream/ Homecoming queen
column5: stroking woodies/ Toy Story/Denying me the black card?/ Oh
column6: now it's statutory"" like she's at a poetry reading hosted in a grimy underworld. It's that sort of psychedelic
column7: stream-of-consciousness flow looped through cartoonishly girly vocal filters that brought Mykki Blanco character to life initially
column8: the character she described as having ""two sides: cute and criminally insane."" When both personas bubble out of Blanco in fierce equal measure in a verse

column1: Where Cosmic Angel: The Illuminati Prince/ss falls short is in the bloated middle ground between club and camp. There are a handful of downbeat tracks here that meander aimlessly
column2: and some of the mixtape is rickety

""You think I was a mink the way these dogs was sniffin'/ You'd think my name was Homer Simpson  to these Peter Griffins/ They hangin' off my angry word/ Damn these fucking Angry Birds""-- a raw reminder of how thrilling her character can be at its unfiltered peak.

column2: 'Experimental'
column4: Chicago improviser Kevin Drumm began to gather up all its darkest strands in one corroded braid. His starting point was an electric guitar
column5: laid clinically on a slab
column6: and dissected in neat
column7: quiet strokes. Over the next 15 years and counting
column8: he grew louder
column9: bolder
column10: and more ambitious
column11: drawing in aspects of black metal
column12: harsh noise
column13: drone
column14: concrete music
column15: and free electronics. His music rose to a peak of vigor without sacrificing its subtlety-- no matter how unruly it got
column16: the greater forces of Drumm's instincts stayed in control. His discography deepened at a dizzying pace
column17: and certain solo works emerged as big statements amid the collaborations and incidental excursions.

column1: One such statement was the screaming wall of mouths of Sheer Hellish Miasma
column2: a refreshingly on-the-nose title in a field that often preferred to wreath its mischief in loftier concepts. Drumm offered other worthwhile releases in the ensuing decade
column3: but Relief might be his next milestone. If pure volatility is the most exciting thing about noise
column4: it's also the biggest hurdle for people who reasonably expect music to be made of continuous patterns. Returning to Editions Mego with this single 36-minute track
column5: Drumm unites the best of both worlds. As on <i>Miasma
column6: he wrestles a great deal of hectic squirming into an impregnable monument that crumbles and crumbles without getting smaller. Gradations of mood
column7: color
column8: and weight fluctutate chaotically
column9: but a tense arch of cyclic melody lends form.

column1: The substance of the music is a dense but porous array of throaty roars
column2: eerie baying
column3: hissing static
column4: rogue frequencies
column5: tactile shudders
column6: and other instabilities
column7: oozing over and through each other. Ubiquitous high-frequency interference rises and falls
column8: governing the intensity of the piece at any given moment. But even during its most violent passages
column9: Relief is more entrancing than overwhelming
column10: at least after you sink through its abrasive exterior and get used to its lulling depths. The energy coursing through the convulsive medium is slow
column11: periodic
column12: wave-like; smoothing the spatter into a blur. Sonority exerts a powerful presence
column13: shining off the textures in prismatic overtones and turning inside them like a warped screw.

column1: It can be hard to describe what distinguishes a really good noise record from an average one
column2: but Drumm makes it easy for us. The question that all improvisers have to answer is whether something you play once can be worth listening to more than once. Experience and forethought ease the answer toward yes
column3: and Drumm has both at his command. Throughout Relief
column4: we hear a mind making choices in the moment
column5: rather than just letting sound make its own. Stray frequencies or timbres sometimes spring free
column6: taking on the character of cries for help
column7: only to be swiftly tamped back down into the swirling mass. A noise record called Relief courts easy jokes about what happens when you turn it off
column8: but it's funny-- when the storm clears and silence descends again
column9: heavier than before
column10: the strongest lingering impression isn't of random violence
column11:
but of the hauntingly measured motif drifting at the bottom of it all.

Lust for Youth feels neither lustful nor particularly youthful: The work of one Swedish guy holding down two or three notes on a Casio and declaiming tonelessly
column4: like he's straining to make himself heard over a supermarket PA system

column9: scenery-chewing

column1: His name is Hannes Norrvide

column3: and some of the songs are so defaced by fuzz that they're barely legible. If you were scanning a car radio and landed on a station that sounded like ""We Planted A Seed""

column14: collaborations and side-projects

column4: covers
column5: interludes

column1: The most and least notable tracks on Temporal close its two respective discs: Recorded in 2001 before the band made its move from Massachusetts to Los Angeles

column2: the jarring and dynamic Wavering Radiant highlight. It seems intended as a bittersweet farewell

column4: ""20 Minutes/40 Years"" sounds mostly like a reminder of Days of the New's moment in the late 90s alt-rock sun. More saliently

column1: Elsewhere
column2: the offerings range from ignorable to interesting: This practice-space version of ""Wills Dissolve"" sounds exactly like what it is

column9: previously issued in 2008. Instead of circumscribing Isis' power
column10: Dimuzio enhances it by adding instrumental layers that recreate the band's sudden surges

column1: But in the end
column2: and in an era of download link wormholes and streaming YouTube content

column4: it exhumes too few buried-but-necessary takes and does little to illuminate what Isis did
column5: why they did it

column7: most of all

Since Lukid is signed to Actress' Werkdiscs label

column8: go
column9: she answers the sound-shapes the figure emits. And then two-thirds of the way through there's a bass drop that pounds the chest like heartbreak. Elsewhere

column1: ""The Life of the Mind"" is the quiet heart of the record

Silver & Gold
column2: Sufjan Stevens' holiday-themed follow-up to 2006's 42-song-long Songs for Christmas collection
column3: stretches 59 tracks across nearly three hours. The box set includes a fold-it-yourself paper star ornament. And stickers. Also: temporary tattoos and a poster. There's an 80-page booklet
column4: too. All of which may make you think: ""Wow
column5: Sufjan is really
column6: really
column7: really fucking obsessed with Christmas."" And you would be correct. But his fixation isn't born of pure peppermint joy or the eternal spite of not finding that Power Wheels under the tree as a toddler. It's more complicated than that. About a third of the tracks here are Sufjan originals
column8: and the music ranges from reverent
column9: to intergalactic
column10: to angelic
column11: to positively looney. The stickers and tattoos include a skeleton/soldier throwing a bomb
column12: a panda in a Christmas sweater holding a human skull
column13: and a chainsaw-wielding snowman. The crowded poster shows a half-alien/half-human breastfeeding her alien offspring
column14: a sea monster
column15: a robot owl
column16: a cigarette-smoking baby with a lobster claw for a hand
column17: and Jesus on the phone with a caption next to him that reads
column18: ""DAD!"" And along with lyrics and chords and insanely cut-and-pasted family photos and a hard drive's worth of outre fonts
column19: the booklet features an essay from a pastor that concludes thusly: ""Advent is ultimately about death. The end is near. You are going to die. Happy Holidays.""

column1: The entire project is an excavation into Sufjan's conflicted Christmas heart. He also penned two essays for the booklet
column2: and both are filled with some of the most critical seasonal tidings you're ever likely to hear. In the first
column3: which reads like a tortured self-justification for the project itself
column4: he observes that the yearly economy-boosting hoopla reduces us to ""that clammy
column5: pre-pubescent Christmas wish-list spoiled brat kid of our insatiable childhood
column6: throwing an empirical fit on Santa's lap
column7: faced with the hard-candy facts of reality
column8: knowing for certain we will never really get what we want for Christmas
column9: or in life
column10: for that matter."" And in the second
column11: he dives deep into the history and hypocrisy of Christmas trees specifically
column12: concluding that: ""The Christmas tree has become nothing more than a symbol of environmental bondage
column13: illustrating all the negligent ways in which man has taken possession of the world in order to destroy it. [...] In a word
column14: the Christmas tree is our bitch."" Um
column15: joy to the world?

column1: Of course
column2: Sufjan's uniquely bizarre feelings toward all things merry is a boon for the rest of us
column3: who naturally have the same kind of anxieties and phobias about the holidays
column4: but lack the vast musical talent and/or OCD graphic design skills to make it really count. Because while he's extremely wary of the idea of putting a Christmas box set out just in time for the trampling Black Friday hordes
column5: he's no less susceptible to wintertime whimsy than anyone else. ""Christmas is what you make of it
column6: he writes
column7: in one of the more level-headed booklet passages
column8: ""and its songs reflect mystery and magic as expertly as they clatter and clang with the most audacious and rambunctious intonations of irreverence.""

column1: Like Songs for Christmas
column2: which boxed EPs recorded for friends and family each year from 2001-2006
column3: Silver & Gold has another five discs that span songs from 2006-2010
column4: with some additional tune-ups laid down over the last couple of years. Essentially
column5: it's an extremely over-the-top scrapbook
column6: detailing the musical phases
column7: friends
column8: and feelings coursing through Sufjan's world each year. But unlike the meticulously pleasant Songs for Christmas
column9: which more or less sounds exactly like what a casual fan (or detractor) might expect a Sufjan Stevens Christmas box set to sound like
column10: the music inside Silver & Gold can be as downright strange as its accompanying accessories.

column1: Recorded with the National's Dessner brothers a year and a half after the release of Illinois
column2: 2006's Gloria is the most traditionally Sufjan-y thing here. With its careful guitar picking
column3: pristine choir
column4: and overall sense of in-the-lines tastefulness
column5: it's the disc least likely to offend grandmothers on Christmas Day. Gloria also has two of the collection's finest originals with ""The Midnight Clear"" and ""Carol of St. Benjamin the Bearded One""
column6: both of which could sneak onto Illinois without much complaint. ""I will delight in this
column7: sings Sufjan
column8: sincerely backing up his own faith
column9: before a choir quietly comes back
column10: ""Though you may doubt it.""

column1: I Am Santa's Helper is the wooliest of the bunch
column2: and also the worst. It's got the most tracks at 23
column3: but many are just two-minute fragments
column4: bits of solo piano
column5: or goofball jamming. It still lasts 45 minutes
column6: and by the mid-way point
column7: Sufjan and his buddies' ramshackle racket goes from endearing to annoying. It was recorded right around the premiere of his ambitious BQE project
column8: which could explain the tossed-off-ness. Still
column9: it's instructive of this songwriter's musical narrative; it sounds lost
column10: searching for something new and settling on something half-baked.

column1: Christmas Infinity Voyage is where things get interesting. These songs were originally recorded at the end of 2008
column2: a relatively quiet time for Sufjan
column3: and they reveal an artist in transition. A version of this disc made it online that Christmas
column4: showing Sufjan toying with new electronic textures. That leaked release was intriguing
column5: but ultimately unsure (Sufjan himself calls it ""poorly realized"" in the Silver & Gold booklet). So he took the same songs and largely re-recorded them over the last two years
column6: using the technical know-how he built up while working on 2010's radical and brilliant The Age of Adz. So
column7: of all the material here
column8: Infinity Voyage comes closest to that album's mechanized sheen. There's a roboticized ""Do You Hear What I Hear?"" that lasts nearly 10 minutes
column9: eventually spiraling gloriously out of control with Sufjan repeating ""do you feel what I feel?"" with enough vocal processing slathered over his voice to make T-Pain blush. There's a brief and bubbly cover of Prince's ""Alphabet St."" that recalls Beck's white-boy funk circa Midnite Vultures-- it makes little sense within the context of a Christmas album
column10: but only a fool would protest. This is the disc most likely to confuse the hell out of your grandmother.

column1: Infinity Voyage also boasts the set's strongest originals. ""Christmas in the Room"" is Silver & Gold's best bet at some sort of bizarro new standard
column2: as it combines Sufjan's old-school acoustic balladry with some subtle new-school electronics. It's about finding Christmas-- and all its joy and sorrow-- in another person: ""No travel plans
column3: no shopping malls/ No candy canes or Santa Claus/ For as the day of rest draws near/ It's just the two of us this year."" Meanwhile
column4: ""The Child With the Star on His Head"" uses the birth of Christ to try to transcend the little things that make up modern human existence
column5: things like ""dictionaries
column6: ""calendars
column7: ""television
column8: ""fathers
column9: and ""consequences."" But those pillars can't really be looked past
column10: and Sufjan knows this. So he stops singing for the final 10 minutes of the quarter-hour track
column11: and instead lets a stream-of-consciousness experimental guitar/synth/who-knows-what solos do the heavy lifting. Somehow
column12: these cracked sounds do the job
column13: rendering a smashed beauty that's almost impossible to translate with words. Here
column14: Sufjan is no longer lost
column15: and it's all too easy to get blissfully disoriented by the cacophony.

column1: The final two discs
column2: Let It Snow and Christmas Unicorn
column3: ride out the momentum of Infinity Voyage
column4: though they're not quite as out-there. Both find Sufjan continuing to experiment with synthetic sounds
column5: though mostly as accents rather than the focus. ""I'll Be Home for Christmas"" gets an especially dreamy revamp
column6: with Sufjan sounding like a quivering ghost looking down on the season's festivities. And ""Let It Snow! Let It Snow! Let It Snow!"" is given a minor-chord makeover
column7: ultimately hinting at what a Radiohead Christmas album might sound like. The entire marathon ends strong with a couple of moody ruminators-- ""Happy Karma Christmas"" and ""Justice Delivers Its Death""-- and a blowout finale with the 13-minute ""Christmas Unicorn"". Turns out Sufjan-- with his highly weary yet hopelessly complicit take on the holidays-- is the unicorn
column8: and he suspects he's not alone. ""I know you're just like me
column9: he sings
column10: before pied-piper flutes lead us to an electro freak-out that perfectly morphs into ""Love Will Tear Us Apart"". Within this latest mistletoe'n'holly universe Sufjan has created
column11: the Joy Division classic makes exactly as much sense as ""We Need a Little Christmas""; the Christmas spirit is a fractured one
column12: and reveling in its inherent contradictions is the only way to get through it with your soul intact.

column1: In the Silver & Gold essay by Pastor Thomas Vito Aiuto
column2: he explains how the birth of Christ and Christianity helped to transfer humanity's overall narrative from cyclical to linear. That is
column3: whereas time was an ""empty medium"" before
column4: Christianity brought with it ideas of a great birth and a great death-- the apocalypse. It's intense stuff
column5: but it's also transferable to today's Christmas which
column6: for a 37-year-old like Sufjan or anyone who suddenly finds themselves giving more gifts than they receive
column7: can be about ends: of innocence
column8: of youth
column9: of blind joy. But still
column10: with his annual winter music-making ritual and his refusal to totally give into the more cynical aspects of the holidays-- he decided to release all of his originals here as Public Domain-- Sufjan is taking things back to the days of cycles
column11: in a way. His songwriting no longer hews to story-like structures; he's more and more prone to extended outros that find musical answers through repetition. Talking about the Greco-Roman world
column12: Aiuto writes
column13: ""Abstraction was for them the vehicle of truth and salvation."" One listen to the frenzied and free final minutes of ""The Child With the Star on His Head""
column14:
and it's clear-- Sufjan sounds closer to that gospel than ever.

Something about A List of the Burning Mountains makes me want to describe it as Oneida getting back to basics. The problem is I'm not sure exactly what ""basics"" would mean in the context of the Brooklyn band's vast sonic universe. Through a dozen albums in 15 years
column3: they've covered a daunting amount of territory
column4: darting between rock
column5: noise
column6: psych
column7: drone
column8: electronics
column9: and minimalism. Their most recent project
column10: the Thank Your Parents trilogy
column11: was their most sprawling. It began with the kraut/Boredoms super-jam of 2008's Preteen Weaponry
column12: swerved into the all-encompassing 2009 triple-LP Rated O (an even more accomplished statement than their 2002 masterpiece Each One Teach One)
column13: and ended last year with one of their most abstract releases
column14: Absolute II.

column1: So maybe there's no ""basic"" Oneida sound
column2: and if so
column3: that's part of what's made them such an interesting and unpredictable band. Their sonic shape-shifting continues on this vinyl-only offering
column4: A List of the Burning Mountains. But compared to its conceptual predecessors
column5: the album feels simple and frill-free. It consists of two side-long tracks
column6: both sharing a name with the album. And it sounds uncalculated and uncontrived
column7: as if Oneida's just playing whatever they feel like playing at the moment. The result is high-level improvised rock
column8: infused with the assurance and proficiency that comes from 15 years of making so much varied music.

column1: It's also infused with the expert drumming of Kid Millions
column2: who this time out sounds like the band's unofficial leader. My guess is that every member had an equal
column3: unspoken say in how this jam evolved
column4: but Millions' busy beats are like wind blowing Oneida's clouds of noise and drone. When his playing is weighty and grounded
column5: full of kick-drum drilling
column6: his comrades dole out denser sounds; when his beats are more regular
column7: the mix swerves toward rock riffs; and when he gets airier and more impulsive
column8: the guitars lighten and the atmosphere expands. The band fuses these sections seamlessly; you don't really notice that they've made a shift until long after that shift actually began.

column1: The peaks on A List of the Burning Mountains come when Oneida connects the dots so deftly that the differences between their individual contributions is nearly unnoticeable. My favorite instance comes about halfway through side two
column2: when grinding feedback
column3: swaths of electronic drone
column4: and a churning low end all melt into one undulating ocean. Similar passages occur throughout-- take a dark section during side one that evokes Sunn O)))-style drone-metal
column5: or the album's close
column6: a free jazz sprint morphed into the echo of a symphony. But I have to admit I had to scan back through to remember those sections
column7: because there's a unity to this album that's bigger and more indefinable than what individual moments can capture.

column1: The impression I keep coming back to is how basic A List of the Burning Mountains is. As big and bold as it can sound
column2: there's little here that's especially flashy or blatantly attention-seeking. The band never really gets into any obvious repetitions or motifs
column3: content to run where they want to run and drift where they want to drift. Paradoxically
column4:
this understated approach means the album might be best appreciated by those most familiar with the band's specific internal language. But I can't imagine anyone checking out A List of the Burning Mountains and coming away unimpressed.

School of Seven Bells' 2012 LP Ghostory was loosely structured around the character Lafaye
column2: who finds herself consistently confronted by ghosts
column3: but not of the ""boo!"" variety. For singer/lyricist Alejandra Deheza
column4: ghosts represent the very real emotions that arise from deeply personal past events-- particularly those that aren't blessed with a sense of closure-- and which manifest themselves bodily as stress
column5: or a general sense of unease. Not anything near the leap forward that 2010's Disconnect from Desire
column6: was from 2008's Alpinisms
column7: Ghostory was more Deheza and Ben Curtis doubling down on the group's foundational conceit: a meditative confrontation with the shackles of guilt-- what Depeche Mode called ""a halo in reverse.""

column1: From its title alone
column2: it's tempting to view the 5 track tour EP Put Your Sad Down as a too-literal evocation of Ghostory's conceit-- like the highly-regarded therapist going all in and aiming for the top of the self-help bestseller chart. Indeed
column3: Sad's title track is the most outlandish thing they've ever done: a nearly 13-minute excursion into Miami Vice-style synth thumps and the monasterial echo of Violator
column4: that takes an off-ramp into a lengthy drone section halfway through before reprising the central theme. ""All I wanna do/ Is make you forget/ Forget that you feel so bad
column5: Deheza chants
column6: echoing the mystical empathy that suffuses all of SVIIB's music
column7: but with a fervor more in line with the euphoria of disco-style escapism. When she suggests ""tonight
column8: just feel with your body
column9: however
column10: it's less a suggestion to give in to unfettered eros than to heed a personal fulfillment mantra.

column1: In essence
column2: it's the perfect lead track for a tour EP
column3: a release genre that typically collects castaways and one-offs as a reward to fans who come out to live dates. There are some orphans on Sad
column4: though tracks like ""Secret Days"" and ""Faded Heart"" merge Deheza's trademark yearning with production that respectively recall the earthy circa 2008 Brooklyn syncopations of Alpinisms and a more outré version of Disconnect's take on 90s club music. A dream-pop update of Silver Apples' hypnotic proto-electro track ""Lovefingers"" would certainly stick out on the band's carefully drawn LPs
column5: but in an interstitial context
column6: the song affectionately traces a direct line back to one of the preeminent pioneers of SVIIB's own sound. Particularly with the departure of Deheza's twin Claudia from the group before the release of Ghostory
column7:
SVIIB has gone through some significant changes over the past year. Perhaps this release is their own way of dispensing with some lingering ghosts before moving on to something new.

The Bay area rapper DaVinci tells us The MOEna Lisa represents the third installment of a trilogy: 2010's The Day the Turf Stood Still found him squinting critically at the gentrification spreading through his home neighborhood of San Francisco's Fillmore district; last year's Feast or Famine EP mourned for his lost culture; and this album's positioned as his acceptance. Or so goes the narrative: To say that this thematic arc is mostly out of dog's range of hearing
column2: and that all three releases resemble each other more than they do not
column3: isn't a knock on DaVinci. He is a phenomenally consistent artist
column4: and his releases resemble each other in all the best ways.

column1: Very little changes in DaVinci's style
column2: by design. His voice is flat and dry
column3: sounding like Yo Gotti but less raspy. He doesn't modulate his voice much
column4: preferring to let his writing do the inflection for him. He is a resolutely serious pen-and-pad ghetto reporter
column5: a East Coast-hearted rapper through and through. Bay Area rap has been working through an intriguing obsession with NYC's grey-toned boom-bap heyday: That music felt traditional and timeless even as it was being made
column6: and you have to assume this is what appeals to DaVinci. Like Freddie Gibbs
column7: who pops up on The MOEna Lisa and instantly feels like a kindred spirit
column8: DaVinci treats ""gangsta music"" as something to present and then to get out of the way of. To elaborate on it
column9: vandalize it
column10: or make it his own would be heresy.

column1: All of this makes DaVinci sound about as exciting as a bowl of shredded wheat and water. Subtlety is a murderous selling point: You might as well trumpet the font and spacing of a book. But small details
column2: lovingly fussed over
column3: do matter
column4: and the longer you spend in DaVinci’s fine-grained world
column5: the further you sink into it. He's an incremental-progress artist
column6: and there's progress to observe on The MOEna Lisa. His taste in beats is growing more flamboyant-- those beats seem to be rubbing off on his po-faced style. ""Champion"" chops a flashy piano strut similar to ""Otis"" and tosses in a sampled gospel choir and children’s voices to boot. ""My Connect""
column7: which loops a helium-filled vocal whine around a thunderous slap
column8: resembles the cartoon-colored Bay Area rap of DaVinci's peers.

column1: If there's anywhere you can actually feel the narrative arc DaVinci has claimed for these albums
column2: it's in the sense that on The MOEna Lisa
column3: he's at least momentarily let got of whatever was gnawing him internally and allowed himself a few laughs
column4: even put a few of them on the record. He's still better writing about misery rather than fun or women: Here's a fiercely packed line from the Gibbs featuring ""MYOB"": ""Big brother shot up
column5: sister's always knocked up/ Big homey's locked up and my poppa still ain't popped up."" On ""Extraordinary""
column6: by contrast
column7: he offers the profoundly uninviting sex talk ""I'm gonna renovate the coochie/ rip down walls
column8: which is so disgusting that it took me out of the song to ponder questions: Will there be ventilation masks? Asbestos testing? (And
column9: for what it's worth
column10: most women probably don't enjoy having their vaginas compared to condemned buildings.)

column1: You can hear the flip side of forehead-slappers like that
column2: though
column3: on songs like ""Nothin Finna Stop Me""
column4: which is full of goofy similes and boasting-- his money comes quick ""like virgin sex
column5: if he ""had a bag full of fucks I couldn't give one."" The song is relaxed
column6: something DaVinci's never once been
column7: and for fans of his music
column8: it is all the more satisfying for feeling hard-won. This sense of stakes
column9: impossible to quantify or explain
column10: is what compels you to stick around with DaVinci. It's there in the music
column11: and it's a worthy substitute for flair or formal innovation. He doesn't tweak gangsta rap because it probably helped save his life
column12:
and he likes it straight. On The MOEna Lisa it remains as lovingly served as you can get it anywhere these days.

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/18530/homepage_large.2754ddaf.jpg|Nebula Dance|30824.0|Ital Tek|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Planet Mu']|2012-11-14 00:00:00|2012|2016-06-11 17:04:41.753193|"

Brighton producer Alan Myson is frequently referred to as a dubstep musician
column2: even in his own promotional materials. This made sense in 2007 when he was releasing early Ital Tek singles like ""Blood Line""
column3: a track that had more of an aggressive horror-movie-soundtrack atmosphere than most dubstep of the time
column4: but still fit the general outlines of the form. These days
column5: though
column6: it's an inaccurate
column7: not to mention unimaginative
column8: way to describe an artist who over course of an armful of releases the past five years has become impressively adept at shrugging off the constraints of genre identification.

column1: Myson's stylistic slipperiness has reached a peak on his third full-length
column2: Nebula Dance. He bends his sonic profile to fit enough disparate subgenres for the record to resemble a respectably broad survey of the dance music world circa 2012
column3: or at least the parts that appeal to its more cerebral
column4: less hedonistic citizens. You get a drum'n'bass cut here
column5: a dip into footwork there
column6: all with little to no indication of party-hard moombahton and trap.

column1: It's to Myson's credit that he never comes off like a dilettante in the process. For one he seems to runderstand the source material he's working from. Not only can he grasp what makes a footwork beat read as a footwork beat
column2: but he gets what it is about footwork beats that makes people want to listen to them in the first place. And maybe more significantly
column3: he isn't afraid to mess with the forms he's exploring
column4: which makes the whole project seem like a musician at play in a stylistic sandbox rather than one dissecting them with clinical detachment
column5: a mood that's sunk more than a few artists' attempts to jump genre barriers.

column1: For instance the titular opening cut
column2: with its 142 BPM tempo and deep sub-bass dives
column3: is obviously intended to be Myson's take on drum'n'bass. But the beat steers clear of obvious references to the ""Amen"" break that underpinned the vast majority of first wave d'n'b
column4: replacing it with intricately plotted drum programming full of backwards samples that give it the feeling of a rhythm coiling around itself. When the song takes a breath halfway through and introduces a hint of hip-hop
column5: it starts to sound a little like 2step and a little like the chilly dubstep Myson made his name on-- in other words a couple of nods toward drum'n'bass' descendents
column6: which might come off as a little too clever if it didn't progress so organically.

column1: His handling of footwork music-- whose influence is most clearly felt on ""Dusk Beat""
column2: but which permeates a good chunk of the record-- is equally deft. Up until this point
column3: most attempts by musicians from outside the original Chicago scene to emulate the style have been sunk by an overly exacting approach to reproducing the sounds of producers like DJ Rashad and DJ Spinn (both labelmates of Myson's on Planet Mu)
column4: combined with the serious hurdle of not having access to actual footwork dancers (whose highly specific demands have been the biggest influence on the form). Purists might take issue with Myson softening the style's edges and aiming it more toward the boutique headphones crowd than dancers working on their dribbles
column5: skates
column6: and ghosts
column7: but the airy
column8: R&B-tinged feel he brings to a sound that can be oppressively claustrophobic is crafty. And more importantly it simply works.

column1: For all of the stylistic hopscotch being played
column2: the individual songs on Nebula Dance cohere into an impressively solid whole. During his time as Ital Tek
column3:
Myson has developed a sonic identity that's proven more than capable of whatever formal experiments he uses it for. The difficulty listeners might have figuring out where to shelve it is a small price to pay for the results.

If you checked out completely in 2011

column5: assuming you are willing to take it as a single piece. Which isn't easy: in spite of Tesfaye's diaphanous voice and the lush production

column7: with tempos that slow to a codeine drip for five minutes or more. But Trilogy as a whole sets up a narrative that was previously only implied.

column1: House of Balloons is the ""fun"" part of the story
column2: though that's a relative term. It has the only Weeknd songs you might play at a celebration
column3: and the only point where the illicit behavior feels alluring. On House
column4: the Weeknd introduce an aesthetic that
column5: over the course of the rest of the three tapes
column6: gradually evolves into something deeper and less based in traditional songcraft. It's a continuation of the purple-tinted R&B and hip-hop hybrid forged by The-Dream and Drake
column7: with eye-of-the-quiet storm assurance of Sade and Aaliyah and industrial and trip-hop touches that range from Nine Inch Nails to Tricky. But the Weeknd show a flair for melody that allows every richly atmospheric song on House to stand on its own
column8: boasting strong (and sometimes borrowed) hooks that embrace repetition without feeling manipulative. The cyclical choruses of ""What You Need""
column9: ""The Morning""
column10: and ""High For This"" in particular are both immediately striking and subtly ingratiating
column11: overtures to pop radio that operate outside of it.

column1: Those borrowed hooks mean that House of Balloons is the part of Trilogy most affected by the remaster. If you can't catch how the guitars hit a little harder and the drums have a bit more pop on ""High For This""
column2: you'll definitely notice how the sample from Aaliyah's ""Rock the Boat"" has been wiped from ""What You Need"". If I had to choose
column3: I prefer the original House of Balloons for its spontaneity
column4: but it's kind of like familiarizing yourself with your partner after they get a new haircut; it's just different for a while
column5: and if you want
column6: you can always go back.

column1: Thursday is exactly the kind of ""difficult"" second record you'd expect from the Weeknd had they disappeared for two years and holed up in the studio as a reaction to House's success. But it came just a few months after. It's more ambitious in its way
column2: incorporating influences far from the R&B mainstream and generally just sounding like it has something to prove.

column1: The title is a loaded metaphor; Thursday is a day for the most dedicated partiers
column2: the one that separates a lost weekend from a week full of blackouts. Accordingly
column3: the album is an hour-long exploration of people acknowledging a point of no return. What had been seductive has become menacing. Outside of Drake's guest verse on ""The Zone""
column4: there's not much indication that the songs take place in a club of any sort. The pleasure on House of Balloons felt consensual; here
column5: it feels codependent.

column1: Echoes of Silence benefits considerably from the Trilogy context and now seems on equal footing with House of Balloons and Thursday. As Juicy J helpfully reminds us out of nowhere at the end of ""Same Old Song""
column2: Echoes was released near Christmas
column3: a refractory period between the publication of year-end lists and the turn of the calendar. It's easy to overlook new music that drops at that point
column4: especially in this case
column5: where the lack of immediate hooks suggests that it could have been a rush job.

column1: But get familiar with Echoes' aims and you can hear its value. For one
column2: the lyrical and thematic callbacks make clear that Echoes was meant to interact with what preceded it
column3: to serve as an epilogue and appendix in addition to a denouement. More importantly
column4: it's easier to tune into the final third's resounding depression after having been tenderized by the preceding two hours. It's a morning-after record for a night that never ended
column5: where people have to go into their day shift with no sleep
column6: where club stars still live with parents and the parents find drugs in the laundry. And it's where people who only hours before were perfectly fine to snort their life away simply cannot fucking stand to be around each other for another minute.

column1: But the arresting music redeems that potentially alienating emotional view. ""Montreal"" boasts a frigid and concise hurt as well as a pop sensibility that went missing from the previous half hour
column2: ""Outside"" incorporates intriguing Eastern overtones
column3: and ""The Fall"" integrates Clams Casino's brand of beautifully wasted hip-hop
column4: which ascended in parallel to the Weeknd throughout 2011.

column1: On House's ""The Party and the After Party
column2: Tefsaye sings
column3: ""They don't want my love/ They just want my potential."" In the context of Trilogy's progression
column4: it's the first crack in his callous exterior
column5: revealing a lifelong studio nerd with possibly years worth of grudges (""I don't play/ Unless it's keys and I play all day
column6: he claims on ""Loft Music""). He makes repeated mentions of ""potential
column7: and being ""next
column8: fixating on those particular words like he's holding onto something a girl told him in 7th grade. If you turn your ear right
column9: Trilogy is the most in-depth exploration of male sexual neuroses this side of Pinkerton.

column1: ""You never thought I'd go this far
column2: Tesfaye sings on ""Same Old Song"". That line could be a reference to marathon drug use or the progressive demoralization of his narrator
column3: which bottoms out amidst the pall of gang rape coursing through the very uncomfortable ""Initiation"". The inclusion of Michael Jackson's venomous ""Dirty Diana"" on Echoes (renamed ""D.D."") is perfect in this context
column4: retaining the original's deplorable depiction of predatory groupies as the feminine norm. Tesfaye's narrator celebrates his own irresistibility and embraces the poisonous justifications of victimhood.

column1: Just as perfect is the closing title track
column2: which finds Tesfaye alone in a quiet room
column3: letting the past reverberate
column4: hitting bottom because he simply stops digging. It's the point where the Weeknd's 2011 stops and it's a perfect way to end things. At least it was; on Trilogy
column5: it's followed by ""Till Dawn (Here Comes The Sun)"". Like all of the new songs
column6: it's strong enough on its own but arbitrary in terms of sequencing and has only minimal relation to the LP it was included on.

column1: This is some of the best music of the young decade; judging by its already pervasive influence
column2: it's safe to say Trilogy (or at least House of Balloons) will be one of those records that will be viewed as a turning point when we look at the 2010s as a whole. Some of it's up to demographics. Artists of Tesfaye's age had formative years where Timbaland
column3: the Neptunes
column4: Missy Elliott
column5: D'Angelo
column6: and Aaliyah were at the peak of their powers. And given the ""new rock revolution"" early in the 2000's
column7: which created nothing new at all
column8: it stands to reason that many who came of age in that era don't hear rock as a progressive form. You can sense the shift when talking to new bands. And of course
column9: for those who have some indie rock inclinations
column10: Beach House and Siouxsie samples don't hurt.

column1: Ultimately
column2: the Weeknd's music creates a world. In it
column3: people acknowledge their humanity as expressed by their desires to fuck
column4: to get high
column5: to resent one another
column6: to hurt
column7: to not care about tomorrow. That's a lot for a single artist to take on. ""You'll wanna be high for this
column8: Tesfaye memorably sings within the first minute. Trilogy's triumph is in how it makes its three hours feel necessary to fully embrace it all
column9:
to acknowledge its existence inside ourselves and to vicariously live through it as art.

Through his Caldo Verde label

column3: but also various collections of live tracks
column4: alternate takes

column6: and covers. Most find their way to listeners via bonus discs or free-with-purchase offerings
column7: and by now seemingly every song he has ever written is well documented at each stage of its life: rough demo
column8: studio recording
column9: and live performance. And yet
column10: despite releasing only a handful of proper albums
column11: Kozelek's archives are apparently inexhaustible. It appears to be a sound business model

column1: This 2xCD soundtrack to Kozelek's documentary
