column1: This busy release schedule arguably serves a function beyond simply generating product and profit: It allows Kozelek to insist that a song changes essentially from one night to the next and that such external factors as location
column2: venue
column3: and audience define a song as fundamentally as lyrics and melody. In that regard
column4: there is new material on On Tour
column5: even if the tracklist overlaps with every other Kozelek release. And yet
column6: the set comes across as quietly and curiously anticlimactic
column7: if only because he has hit this retrospective vein so many times in the past. However
column8: we've never actually heard Kozelek do a soundtrack before. This might present some artists an opportunity to either reconsider what they do or rethink the whole concept of what a soundtrack can do
column9: but On Tour comes across as haphazard and
column10: worse
column11: conceptually staid.

column1: There is something intrinsically cinematic about Kozelek's music
column2: especially the material on Admiral Fell Promises
column3: which was defined by the fine filigrees of guitar
column4: the low thrum of the nylon strings
column5: the subtle grain in his voice
column6: and the delicate evocations of his lyrics. Some of the older material
column7: such as ""Void (Live in Sweden)"" and ""Like the River (Live in Spain)""
column8: are enlivened by his flamenco-style guitar playing
column9: while others
column10: such as ""Lucky Man (Hotel Performance)"" take on a new intimacy thanks to the relatively lo-fi quality of the recordings. It's clear Kozelek is an able
column11: agile picker and a gracefully understated interpreter
column12: but that's not necessarily a revelation.

column1: The music is not the problem here; the problem is the way the music's been repackaged. And that includes the timing of this release. The film debuted last fall
column2: long before Sun Kil Moon's most recent album Among the Leaves surfaced
column3: a collection that actually proves a much more bracing enumeration of the gains and losses of a life spent on the road
column4: in the studio
column5: and at the label. It's as though Kozelek threw caution to the wind and started writing about what lay immediately in front of him: overeager fanboys
column6: VD
column7: broken relationships
column8: a bad back. The frankness and forthrightness with which he addressed such matters allowed for a sneaky humor rarely heard on his albums
column9: and the considerable length of Among the Leaves-- 17 tracks at about 70 minutes­­
column10: plus a bonus disc
column11: of course-- seemed to be its grimmest joke: After more than two decades in the music business
column12: Kozelek has become the old man rambling on and on and on
column13: to the point where fewer and fewer people are listening. Among the Leaves
column14: while far from perfect
column15: still represents a new chapter for Kozelek
column16: one that finds him trying out new approaches and new attitudes that throw his entire catalog into sharp relief while revealing new facets of his veteran persona. He has two February releases-- a live album and a covers collection-- that ought to expound on Leaves. In the meantime
column17:
how can On Tour be anything but an enormous step backwards?

The most distinct and memorable voice heard on Ital's Hive Mind was a shredded and reassembled Lady Gaga coolly stammering the titular
column2: ""Born This Way""-sourced refrain of ""Doesn't Matter (If You Love Him)"" over grimy downtempo funk-house. The most distinct and memorable voice heard on Dream On
column3: meanwhile
column4: is the one that opens ""What a Mess"": the flange-distorted pleads of a choked-up woman at a 2009 town hall meeting
column5: asking Oklahoma Senator Tom Coburn what he could do to help her uninsured husband after he suffered a traumatic brain injury. Coburn's response-- that citizens have to rely on community instead of government for help-- is multitracked and reverbed into oblivion before being smothered by a dense organ chord and crumbled apart by skittering hi-hats.

column1: It's a willfully bizarre sample for a producer to slot into a postmodern house track
column2: even one that rides on a tension between minimalism and abrasion. But it's also one of Daniel Martin-McCormick's clearest signals yet that he's got a certain dedication to finding the potential for repulsion in a traditionally euphoric and physical strain of music. Just how ugly Dream On gets is a matter of degrees-- most of it isn't as up-front as that opening to ""What a Mess""
column3: and when it does manifest it's usually more in the form of a creeping dissonance or a slow build to something intriguingly grotesque. This album exploits the fine line between repetition as groove and repetition as unnerving tic

column1: Opening track ""Despot"" is as close as things get to the spaced-out momentum of its predecessor album's brightest moments. But even its straightforwardly dense backbeat is in the service of a pulse that feels more like tension than release

column6: deeply submerged melodic touches sets up a lush space-- but that only makes things more disorienting when he brings in a succession of high-pitched
column7: intermittent buzzing whirs that resemble pitched-up F1 race cars.

column1: But Ital never loses the plot
column2: even when it seems like throwing off casual dancefloor vibes is part of the point. The way ""Enrique"" starts splitting at the seams
column3: choppy intonations of firing-up jet engine whirs crackling through the edges

column5: following up the knife-edge snares
column6: organ growls
column7: and panic-attack layered vocals of ""What a Mess"" with a spacious deep house atmosphere that only gets more high-spirited when the noisy bits seep in-- that buzzsaw drone might as well be a chorus of angels. Ital's sense of abrasion and his notion of groove are both finely tuned
column8:
so it's all for the best when they work in parallel.

column1: Fortunately

column6: and they all stretch further
column7: morphing together patterns with a more graded progression. Still
column8: this is bold

Crystal Castles seem to operate in a perpetual state of confrontation
column4: conflict
column5: and stress. That works in their favor as they face a new and strange set of challenges on their third album: Their brand of dark electro has proven so influential in recent years that it's put them in danger of sounding normal in 2012. Their first two records were explosive
column6: unpredictable
column7: and found them living on borrowed time
column8: trying to outlast the blog-house fad that spawned their earliest singles and outstrip a run of bad publicity caused by early copyright disputes and cancelled gigs. ""The world is a dystopia where victims don't get justice and corruption prevails
column9: Alice Glass recently vented. ""I'm one step away from being a vigilante to protect people and bring justice to the people I love."" Indeed
column10: her lyrics on the fiercely aggressive (III) take on a newfound importance

column1: Though the duo claims to have overhauled their recording process for (III)

column3: the album couldn't be mistaken for the work of anyone else. It retains Ethan Kath's trademark staggered synths and Glass' acute wail still pierces through thick reverb. The music now conveys a sense of unease somewhere between waiting for the drugs to kick in and wanting to leave the club as soon as possible. As promised
column4: it is unyieldingly ""bleak."" Even the catchy songs are filtered through a forbidding darkness. ""Pale Flesh"" exhumes witch house for just long enough to beat it at its own game

column1: While not as immediately striking as either Crystal Castles (I or II)
column2: the streamlined sound allows more maneuverability and subtle variety in the actual songwriting. Crystal Castles songs could once be split into two camps
column3: the ""pretty"" ones and the ""aggressive"" ones; (III) is the duo's most focused record
column4: and the fact that it avoids assaults like ""Doe Deer"" or ""Alice Practice"" demonstrates an alluring confidence. Even the all-texture tracks (""Telepath""
column5: ""Insulin"") are more driven by rhythm than abrasion; they contribute to the overall flow rather than hijacking it.

column1: Insularity is nothing new for Crystal Castles
column2: as both of their self-titled records existed in a sort of personal airlock. Shortly after the release of Crystal Castles (II)
column3: they re-cast its cover of Platinum Blonde's ""Not in Love"" with Robert Smith on lead vocals
column4: resulting in their most successful single to date
column5: but it had the unintended effect of making the emotional illegibility of their own version more apparent. At the end of the tightly coiled ""Kerosene""
column6: Glass reveals a desire to connect
column7: breathing a promise of equal menace and love: ""I'll protect you from all the things I've seen."" Glass' lyrics are often addressed to children facing horrors they can't quite process or future atrocities they can't imagine-- references to blood
column8: wounds
column9: antiseptics
column10: and soil are frequent
column11: as well as a warning to ""sell your bones for ivory.""

column1: So how is this popular
column2: exactly? Fair question. Pop music is often considered to be synonymous with escapism
column3: but it can also be cathartic
column4: and many records this year have shared (III)'s apocalyptic bent. Albums by Swans and Godspeed You! Black Emperor view 2012 in the Mayan sense
column5: predicting a form of divine retribution that will be cataclysmic but also possibly awesome. And while the typical goth jokes came easy when ""Affection"" dropped on Halloween
column6: look at it in the context of being just another day: the New York Marathon planned to go on despite the destruction of Hurricane Sandy
column7: the cover of the latest Sports Illustrated featured a story surveying the ""resilience"" of the Penn State football team a year after the Jerry Sandusky scandal erupted
column8: and we were in the homestretch of an American presidential election that actually fostered the discussion of what constitutes ""legitimate rape."" Whether you listen to Crystal Castles or not
column9: this is a time of confrontation
column10: conflict
column11: and stress
column12: and the success of (III) is how it brings you close enough to the evil that men do to be shocked
column13: repulsed
column14:
and affected by it.

Even when Robert Pollard was exploring new extremes in amateur home-recording
column5: hyper-prolific songwriting
column6: and Budweiser consumption in the 1990s
column7: he was always picky about which of the thousands of songs he wrote was officially issued under the Guided by Voices name. From their 1986 formation through to the b(r)and's dissolution in 2004
column8: Guided by Voices proper released an average of one full-length album per year. That's a brisk clip for most acts
column9: but a relative coffee drip when you consider the song overflow Pollard continues to divert to his exponentially increasing array of solo and side projects. So his decision last year to revive Guided by Voices with its ""classic"" 1992-96-era line-up suggested a return not just to the band's ramshackle roots
column10: but their old quality-control standards as well.

column1: The band's actual post-reunion strategy tells a different story. Pollard and co. were already well into their mid-30s when the band first emerged in the early 90s. Now
column2: two decades on
column3: they seem determined to make the most of this second wind and release as much music as possible while they can still physically withstand the scissor kicks and windmills. The Bears for Lunch is their third album of 2012
column4: following January's comeback Let's Go Eat the Factory and June's Class Clown Spots a UFO. And like its immediate predecessors
column5: The Bears effectively picks up where this line-up left off with 1996's Under the Bushes Under the Stars
column6: mediating between the band's formative lo-fi lunacy and their desire for a more streamlined sound.

column1: But if all this new GBV material faithfully approximates the form and fidelity of the band's signature works
column2: its impact has been diminished by a lack of context or conceptual vision. Back in the mid-90s
column3: each new GBV album played out like a game of ""will they or won't they"": would Pollard and his trusty foil Tobin Sprout limit their morsels of melody to 60-second spurts
column4: or would they allow the songs to flourish into alternate-universe power-pop classics? And despite their randomized appearances
column5: those album sequences were always carefully considered
column6: where even the seemingly throwaway tracks were strategically stitched into the crazy-quilt patchwork. But by mostly settling into the Under the Bushes mid-fi comfort zone
column7: the band's 2012 albums mostly just sound like one Guided by Voices song after another-- some exceptional
column8: some forgettable. That's hardly a bum deal for long-time fans
column9: but there's little sense of the organizing principles that made those early albums eminently replayable and rewarding.

column1: The Bears for Lunch
column2: however
column3: is the most consistent of this year's trifecta. It may not boast an instant
column4: indeliable earworm like Class Clown's ""Keep It Motion"" or Factory's ""Doughnut for a Snowman""
column5: but there are no buzzkill duds like ""The Big Hat and Toy Show"" either. And
column6: of the three
column7: it's the album that most faithfully approximates the tumbling
column8: track-to-track momentum of the band's mid-90s masterworks
column9: with off-the-cuff oddities like the gruff busker ditty ""Have a Jug"" and the absurdist chant ""Finger Gang"" effectively setting up more dignified
column10: resonant turns like ""Hangover Child"" and ""The Challenge Is Much More"".

column1: As per GBV tradition
column2: Pollard's lyrical concerns mostly orbit around aviation
column3: medieval folklore
column4: and boys of various preternatural abilities. So the greatest revelations here come when Pollard seemingly takes stock of his own mortality
column5: as on the sleazily suggestive love song ""She Lives in an Airport"" (""she makes it quicker and competition thicker/ designed to spark up a real weak ticker"") or on ""The Military School Dance Dismissal""
column6: which sounds like Pollard crooning a Hunky Dory piano ballad in some Dayton dive at the age of 85. Sprout
column7: for his part
column8: responds to Pollard's ever-changing whims by keeping his feet firmly planted in Rubber Soul
column9: contributing The Bears' most richly melodious songs in the folksy ""Waking Up the Stars"" and ""Waving at Airplanes"" (the latter of which is no less poignant for pinching its acoustic fanfare from Bad Company's ""Feel Like Makin' Love"").

column1: Taken together
column2: GBV's three releases this year plot an alternate late-90s course for the band
column3: one which in Pollard stuck with his basement buds and never hooked up with Cobra Verde for 1997's muscular Mag Earwhig!
column4: never signed to TVT
column5: and never asked for Ric Ocasek's phone number. This GBV would've simply continued to crank out album after album of pleasingly wobbly indie rock
column6: gradually refining their craft and reining in their eccentricities but stopping short of realizing their hi-fi arena rock potential.

column1: Still
column2: as The Bears' late-album progression gets tripped up by the one-note discord of ""Tree Fly Jet"" and ""Amorphous Surprise""
column3: you can't help but think the band's re-emergence would be that much more dramatic if they had pared down their three 2012 releases into one record stacked with the best songs from each; surely
column4: no O.G. GBV fan would've felt cheated by receiving ""only"" a single
column5: no-filler album from a line-up they never thought they'd see in action again. After all
column6:
Guided by Voices' 1994 critical breakthrough Bee Thousand was as much a triumph of judicious pruning as quality songcraft; the most important takeaway from this year is that Guided by Voices can still produce enough of the latter to allow for the luxury of the former.

column2: the Toledo

column1: At the Down-Turned Jagged Rim of the Sky

column3: is on the one hand just another Jessica Bailiff album

column10: delivery
column11: and fuzz.

column1: But throughout At the Down-Turned Jagged Rim of the Sky
column2: Bailiff's music resists easy summary. The opening ""Your Ghost Is Not Enough"" is a strong meditation on the tensions and feelings of long-distance relationships
column3: and two songs later

column1: That all this was done in a home studio by Bailiff is no surprise-- that's part of her approach from the start
column2: even as she's maintained her other musical efforts and day-to-day life. Bailiff not only resists whatever a trend might be in favor of her own instincts
column3: she is also not afraid to go big in a way that neither apes modern mega-production nor just relies on a laptop patch to approximate it. There are
column4: always
column5: other routes
column6: and she knows how to find them here.

column1: A strong example comes near the end of the record with ""Goodnight"". Initially
column2: a solo piano traces a melodic loop over humming drone
column3: with Bailiff's vocals coming in as a gentle sway back and forth. It all sounds like a ballad
column4: though a line like ""It makes me sick"" suggests something else at work: At nearly two minutes into the track that something else happens
column5: as big guitars and drums emerge. They're buried just enough into the mix-- a suppressed anger and roar-- that the song feels like it's about to fully snap a tether. The extra organ that appears after three minutes adds further intensity
column6: an unafraid embrace of the overpowering
column7: while isolated strings emerge at the end. A lullaby this isn't.

column1: There's a clear sense of arrangement and precision throughout. Often there's no overt variation or change in a song
column2: but when subtle changes do emerge after careful listening
column3: you get a sense of how her understated touch creates a strong impact. Bringing scope and space to a more intimate level
column4: the miniature epic ""This is Real"" demonstrates the virtues of the slow build and Bailiff's careful placement: repeated keyboard parts are matched by guitars
column5: then voices take the place of the guitars as new guitars are added into the background. It feels like sweeping exultance
column6: a sigh
column7: and the title's reach for something grounded.

column1: That the album ends on the gentler note of the easygoing pop jam ""Firefly"" seems apt: Down-Turned is an album that starts in two different worlds
column2: explores a range of possibilities
column3: and ends brightly. It sounds exactly like what a fan of Bailiff would hope for
column4:
while offering something new and distinct. And it's proof that she knows her own particular path is the best one to follow.

He then went on to compare the proceedings to when early 20th-century spiritual teacher George Ivanovich Gurdjieff had his hummings turned into piano music by composer and spiritual devotee Thomas de Hartmann.

column10: the never-pressed 45 label art that also appears in that befuddling PDF. At other moments

column1: Most of the second half of the album emphasizes this mysterious creator's piano meditations

column8: from photos of a Moog synthesizer to instructions for installing an underwater loudspeaker to a 1973 article published in The New Englander titled ""Business Tries Meditating""
column9:
surmising that the ""Maharishi makes sense in board room."" Which may be the most sensible statement here.

Joni Mitchell once called fame ""a glamorous misunderstanding."" As America's finest living Canadian songwriter (tied with Neil Young)
column2: few musicians have understood its nature so well. In the 1960s and 70s
column3: Mitchell was Mary Magdalene to Dylan's folk-rock messiah
column4: making music that was bittersweet and relatable
column5: carrying what Dylan begat even further. Her work helped birth a new idiom that was personal and poetic
column6: creating a new space for songs that made artistic statements
column7: unbound by cliché and tradition. Such was the strength of her music that Mitchell's lyrics didn't have to make sense. But they did
column8: particularly to women.

column1: Mitchell's first 10 studio albums
column2: cut during an 11-year span
column3: have been gathered in this import box set. During this run
column4: Mitchell charted one of the most solid career arcs in contemporary music that then detoured into one of the strangest
column5: following her muse into places that very nearly cost her career and exhausted her fanbase's patience. Throughout
column6: she was confident and unrepentant in her vision
column7: in an era where that kind of ego was unbefitting a woman
column8: even if she did have the gold albums and Grammys™ to back it up.

column1: This is a basic set-- no frills
column2: just all the albums' original layouts reproduced in envelope sleeves
column3: the fonts so tiny only mice could read them. There are no extras
column4: outtakes or re-anythinged. But taking these 10 records in a row
column5: chronologically
column6: it is a striking reminder no single artist has had a run like Joni (even her acolyte Prince only got to seven albums before he started to fall off). Mitchell was pop's first female auteur
column7: an innovator of singular talent
column8: whose influence was vast
column9: immediate (see: Led Zeppelin's ""Going to California"") and long lasting (Joanna Newsom
column10: St. Vincent
column11: Taylor Swift's kiss'n'tell cottage industry).

column1: Mitchell was ""discovered"" c. 1968 when ex-Byrd David Crosby pulled up in a sailboat outside the Florida club she was playing and took her to L.A. At the time
column2: folk was out of fashion yet Mitchell managed to pull down an unprecedented major label deal for a girl and her guitar: total and complete artistic freedom
column3: with the caveat that Crosby would produce her first album. It was rare for a woman to be writing and recording her own material at the time
column4: let alone to be an unaccompanied solo act. Though Mitchell's debut
column5: Song to a Seagull
column6: was a heavy precedent for the era it's a harder listen now
column7: the fin de siècle earth-mama lyrics playing strange against the stilted
column8: formal musical settings. The delicate album suffers under Crosby's intrusive production; Mitchell would self-produce from then on.

column1: Clouds (1969) is the introduction to Mitchell's real deal
column2: shaking folk tradition and giving off a little humor and spirit. The album sounds casual. Lyrically
column3: she was transitioning from the era's de facto hippie sensualism (colors! the weather! vibes!) to the classically prosodic style (Keats! Cohen!) she'd become known for. The album's biggest signs of life are two of her most famous songs-- the kicky ""Chelsea Morning""
column4: which is about as straightforward as Mitchell ever got
column5: and ""Both Sides Now"". Though she'd known burden and heartache plenty by her still-tender age (she'd borne a child alone and in secret after dropping out of art school and married singer Chuck Mitchell in order to make a family; he changed his mind a month later and she put the baby up for adoption) she sounds a bit too young and chipper to be singing about disillusionment. Still
column6: Clouds was a landmark
column7: and she landed a Grammy for Best Folk Performance.

column1: Ladies of the Canyon from 1970 is Mitchell's most accessible album and it introduces her earnest folk-pop style. Her voice is newly elastic and expressive
column2: and it's the first record where she sounds like she might actually be fun to hang out with. Ladies also features her generation-defining ""Woodstock""
column3: ""The Circle Game"" (Mitchell's answer back to Neil Young's nostalgic ""Sugar Mountain"")
column4: and her blustery gentrification sing-along
column5: ""Big Yellow Taxi"". All were hippie-era sing-along staples; it hardly bears remarking that these songs are some of Mitchell's corniest.

column1: The genius of Ladies is often circumscribed by Mitchell's proximity to CSNY; the vocal arrangement and production invariably propped to Crosby's influence
column2: ""Woodstock"" supposedly inspired by Nash's recounting of the event (she wrote it before he'd even returned from the festival). If Ladies does bear the mark of CSNY
column3: it's to the album's detriment. The fruits of the Nash/Mitchell romance-- his gee-whiz domestic ode
column4: ""Our House"" and Ladies' ""Willy""-- are saccharine at best. Their subsequent break up would inspire much more potent work-- Neil Young's ""Only Love Can Break Your Heart"" and Mitchell's follow-up.

column1: About that follow-up: 1971's Blue is possibly the most gutting break-up album ever made. After Mitchell's relationship with Nash dissolved
column2: she headed to Europe to lose the tether of her fame
column3: eventually taking exile in a cave on the Greek island Crete. The trip would inspire the how-Joni-got-her-groove-back ditties ""Carey"" and ""California"". The album is suffused with melancholy for all that is missing: her daughter (""Little Green"")
column4: innocence (""The Last Time I Saw Richard"")
column5: and connection (""All I Want""). Mitchell bleeds diffidence and highlights it with spare notes plucked out on her Appalachian dulcimer. While her pals Neil Young
column6: Leonard Cohen
column7: and Laura Nyro were also pushing the singer-songwriter genre forward
column8: none of them managed to stride the distance that Mitchell did here in a single album.

column1: ""Will you take me as I am/ Strung out on another man?"" Mitchell pleads on ""California"". She was (in)famously strung out on other talents that were as mercurial as hers
column2: fueling constant speculation as to whether this song was about Leonard Cohen
column3: or that one about James Taylor or Nash or that puerile heartbreaker Jackson Browne. The year Mitchell issued Blue
column4: an album that would be a landmark in any artist's career
column5: Rolling Stone named her ""Old Lady of the Year
column6: a dismissal effectively saying her import was as a girlfriend or muse to the men around her more than as an artist in her own right. Worse still
column7: they called her ""Queen of El Lay
column8: and offered a diagram of her supposed affairs and conquests. She'd made the best album of her career and in exchange she got slut-shamed in the biggest music magazine in America.

column1: Mitchell retired to her homestead in Canada and returned sounding confident for 1972's For the Roses. Up until Roses she'd kept things minimal
column2: here she stacked multi-tracks of impossible vocals harmonies
column3: mimicking a horn section (""Let the Wind Carry Me"") or interpolating and dueling with jazzer sideman Tom Scott's riffing woodwinds. Mitchell's vocals
column4: fluttering unpredictably and with stunning control between the bottom of her range and the top of her crystalline contralto
column5: were given a new stop; her heavy smoking had given her a heretofore non-existent midrange. There's really no singing along with Roses--  which is a fabulous fuck-you for a pop artist.

column1: Though part of the reason that she'd retired from performing in 1969 was to avoid the default of writing about the myopic rock'n'roll life
column2: Roses' standout track
column3: ""Blonde in the Bleachers""
column4: shows that she may have understood it better than any of the boys; it is one of the best songs ever written about the rules and (gender) roles of the road. ""It seems like you've got to give up/ Such a piece of your soul /When you give up the chase
column5: she sings
column6: about finding identity and meaning in who you fuck. Freedom is an evergreen subject for Mitchell
column7: but ""Blonde in the Bleachers"" gets beyond the thrill in partaking of what-- or
column8: rather
column9: who-- is offered up
column10: backstage. The quiet story here is the ebbing power of a woman once she's been conquered.

column1: Though Mitchell was criticized for not making blatantly feminist or political (read: sloganeering) albums
column2: her work was always tacitly so. Her songs spotlight the unspoken roles of women (""Barandgrill"")
column3: who they were unrelated to men; she gave them names and precise details. There is hardly a more feminist topic than striving for a freedom that life and love has never allowed you. On ""Woman of Heart and Mind""
column4: it's hard to tell whether she is mocking herself or the man she is singing to (or both): ""Push your papers/ Win your medals/ Fuck your strangers/ Don't it leave you on the empty side /I'm looking for affection and respect."" On Roses
column5: Mitchell sounds like a woman who's had enough of everyone else's shit
column6: an attitude that certainly put her in line with the libbers.

column1: Her 1974 commercial break-out
column2: Court and Spark
column3: found her backed by first-call jazz session cats L.A. Express. It was her official severance from folk music. Court is her most pop album and gave her three chart hits
column4: going gold five weeks after its release. Mitchell's production features heavy and sudden multi-tracked swells of her voice that spike melodies like a choir of accusing angels and mimic strings and horns. Her arrangement on ""Down to You"" (aided by Express bandleader Tom Scott) is stunning in its complexity
column5: yet it never shakes you; it is still utterly a pop song.

column1: Now six albums deep on the topic of love and loss
column2: Court has a marked cynicism. It's a grown up album about arriving at the intractable issues of adult love. ""Help Me""
column3: which was Mitchell's only top 10 hit
column4: is reluctant about romance; she's ""hoping for the future/ And worrying about the past."" The refrain is pocked by the dawnlight realizations of that post-free love era: ""We love our lovin'/ But not like we love our freedom."" For the largeness of her band (which included Joe Sample of the Crusaders
column5: and Larry Carlton
column6: soon to be of every memorable Steely Dan guitar solo) they are nimble throughout; their finesse suited her own.

column1: To explain how and what happened next in Mitchell's career-- how much her The Hissing of Summer Lawns was viewed as not a stylistic departure but a betrayal-- we must first look at the run up. While promoting Court
column2: what could easily be defined as the commercial and artistic high-water mark of her career
column3: Mitchell went to go see Dylan's Rolling Thunder Revue tour and wound up joining. At the time
column4: she was a peer of Dylan
column5: commercially and as a songwriter
column6: she was also tight with tour member Robbie Robertson of the Band. She had a song in the Billboard Top 10-- and she was opening. When Mitchell recounts this in later interviews
column7: she talks about how being on the tour was a matter of constantly having to subvert her ego to the men around her.

column1: At this same time
column2: many of her peers were headed further toward the mainstream
column3: towards syncopation
column4: towards rock
column5: towards retro revivalism. Mitchell saw there was not much of a place for her amongst the new talents and the Peter Pan-ing crew she came up with
column6: as a woman in her early 30s
column7: and she saw jazz as a genre that would allow her to age gracefully and expand as an artist-- and so there she went. She was trying to find or develop a place to belong.

column1: Through all of this she arrived at Hissing of Summer Lawns.
The 1975 album marks Mitchell's official departure from the mainstream
column2: her embarking upon her jazzbo journey. It's the album of an artist absolutely assured of herself
column3: and it's addressed to anyone who might not consider her a serious musician
column4: who believed all she could do was confess her heartache. Though it doesn't have the rhapsodic rep as Blue
column5: it's unquestionably one of Mitchell's finest albums
column6: and it is certainly her most timeless.

column1: It opens easy enough with ""In France They Kiss on Main Street""-- a soft
column2: linear move from Court. What follows is jarring if you were expecting more of the same: ""The Jungle Line"" runs over a distorting sample of the Royal Drummers of Burundi tribal pounding and chanting. Mitchell going from husky to her enunciation so precise about ""the mathematic circuits of the modern nights
column3: the long
column4: low whirring of a Moog running the melody line under Mitchell's acoustic strumming. The rest of the record is dark
column5: tense
column6: and lilts unapologetically toward something softer and more ornate than jazz fusion (no more than the later Steely Dan records it predated) with Mitchell singing observationally
column7: about the place of women in the world
column8: about the trade-offs they make for power and freedom.

column1: Mitchell and women of her generation had been brought up with the idea that marriage to a man who took care of them would fulfill them entirely and that ambitions beyond that were frivolous. The album is a reckoning reflective of culture at the time; Hissing is an album of women trying to find their real selves in a world that had groomed them for quiet obeisance to men. On ""Harry's House"" Mitchell sings of a curdling domestic scene
column2: of wives who ""paper the walls to keep their gut reactions hid."" The song dovetails into the standard ""Centerpiece""
column3: which she sings in a voice not her own
column4: playacting with this ultra-feminine throwback voice
column5: creating a critical distance when she sings the lines: ""I'm building all my dreams around you/ Our happiness will never cease/ 'Cause nothing's any good without you/ Baby you're my centerpiece."" And on the subtlety devastating ""Sweet Bird""
column6: she sings of women wielding power through beauty and youth
column7: and what is lost and gained in that bargaining: ""Power ideals and beauty/ Fading in everyone's hand"" and ""Calendars of our lives/ Circled with compromise.""

column1: Mitchell had never made a record that wasn't bigger than the one before and was shocked that her fans and many critics saw her new sound as an abandonment and misguided move
column2: respectively. Reviewers chastised her for her ego. While the album went gold and brought her a Grammy nod
column3: as her 1974 live album Miles of Aisles attests (a wonky fiasco
column4: skip it) there were still plenty of people shouting for ""Big Yellow Taxi"". But that Joni didn't live here anymore. Hissing was proof. The era of Mitchell doing no wrong was over and if her audience couldn't hang
column5: she wasn't about to do anything to reel them back in.

column1: The two albums that followed are where Mitchell went off the grid. Hejira
column2: from 1976
column3: was written while driving alone from Maine to L.A. and is a meditation on the value and melancholy of being alone
column4: her guitar imitating the rhythms and expanse of the road. In spots it's as emotionally bare as Blue. It's a real grown woman album and may not make tremendous sense to anyone under 30.

column1: Musically
column2: Mitchell says she was trying to see how far she could get from traditional rhythm; the songs are long and lovely
column3: burbling and unspooling. Whether or not you feel this era of Mitchell is unfairly maligned depends on how you feel about Jaco Pastorious and his fretless bass and its many
column4: many notes fardling way up high in the mix. His playing lends a darkly cinematic feeling to the album
column5: but in the decades since his trademark sound and style have been taken to such unpleasant extremes by jam and light jazz bands
column6: it's understandable to experience a visceral revulsion.

column1: Inspired by the rhythms of Brazilian music
column2: Mitchell issued the experimental double-album Don Juan's Reckless Daughter in '77. Her experiments went further than just musical; she appears in brownface and an afro wig as a man on the cover. Less commented on is her in ""injun"" costume on the back
column3: palm raised
column4: a bubble above her head reads ""How!"" (Her cringe-inducing arguments about it later on included statements about how she has a ""black man's soul""). The album is solidly jazz-fusion
column5: indulgent in length with still plenty of Jaco-dominance. But! there is reward in the album's centerpiece
column6: if you can make it that far: The 16-minute ""Paprika Plains"" is a freakout of a song suite
column7: inspired in part by a conversation with prickly ol' Bob Dylan. Even if you cannot abide by the album
column8: we must be grateful for it
column9: as it is Bjork's #1 favorite album and source of inspiration. The last piece in the box
column10: Mingus
column11: her 1979 collaboration with Charles Mingus before his death makes her seem like the jazz dilettante that people accused her of being. The ultimate result doesn't serve either of their legacies particularly well.

column1: Though Mitchell's weird escapade through pop doesn't end where the box set does
column2: she never recaptured the thread of popular imagination. Her 80s albums
column3: like many of her hippie-era peers'
column4: were overbearing and scolding and featured awkward embraces of technology. She retired for long stretches to focus on her painting. Her last good record was 2000's Both Sides Now
column5: where
column6: her range ravaged by decades of smoking
column7:
she sings the definitive version of the titular song that launched her career and finally sounds like she's seen enough to know.

Joni Mitchell once called fame ""a glamorous misunderstanding."" As America's finest living Canadian songwriter (tied with Neil Young)
column2: few musicians have understood its nature so well. In the 1960s and 70s
column3: Mitchell was Mary Magdalene to Dylan's folk-rock messiah
column4: making music that was bittersweet and relatable
column5: carrying what Dylan begat even further. Her work helped birth a new idiom that was personal and poetic
column6: creating a new space for songs that made artistic statements
column7: unbound by cliché and tradition. Such was the strength of her music that Mitchell's lyrics didn't have to make sense. But they did
column8: particularly to women.

column1: Mitchell's first 10 studio albums
column2: cut during an 11-year span
column3: have been gathered in this import box set. During this run
column4: Mitchell charted one of the most solid career arcs in contemporary music that then detoured into one of the strangest
column5: following her muse into places that very nearly cost her career and exhausted her fanbase's patience. Throughout
column6: she was confident and unrepentant in her vision
column7: in an era where that kind of ego was unbefitting a woman
column8: even if she did have the gold albums and Grammys™ to back it up.

column1: This is a basic set-- no frills
column2: just all the albums' original layouts reproduced in envelope sleeves
column3: the fonts so tiny only mice could read them. There are no extras
column4: outtakes or re-anythinged. But taking these 10 records in a row
column5: chronologically
column6: it is a striking reminder no single artist has had a run like Joni (even her acolyte Prince only got to seven albums before he started to fall off). Mitchell was pop's first female auteur
column7: an innovator of singular talent
column8: whose influence was vast
column9: immediate (see: Led Zeppelin's ""Going to California"") and long lasting (Joanna Newsom
column10: St. Vincent
column11: Taylor Swift's kiss'n'tell cottage industry).

column1: Mitchell was ""discovered"" c. 1968 when ex-Byrd David Crosby pulled up in a sailboat outside the Florida club she was playing and took her to L.A. At the time
column2: folk was out of fashion yet Mitchell managed to pull down an unprecedented major label deal for a girl and her guitar: total and complete artistic freedom
column3: with the caveat that Crosby would produce her first album. It was rare for a woman to be writing and recording her own material at the time
column4: let alone to be an unaccompanied solo act. Though Mitchell's debut
column5: Song to a Seagull
column6: was a heavy precedent for the era it's a harder listen now
column7: the fin de siècle earth-mama lyrics playing strange against the stilted
column8: formal musical settings. The delicate album suffers under Crosby's intrusive production; Mitchell would self-produce from then on.

column1: Clouds (1969) is the introduction to Mitchell's real deal
column2: shaking folk tradition and giving off a little humor and spirit. The album sounds casual. Lyrically
column3: she was transitioning from the era's de facto hippie sensualism (colors! the weather! vibes!) to the classically prosodic style (Keats! Cohen!) she'd become known for. The album's biggest signs of life are two of her most famous songs-- the kicky ""Chelsea Morning""
column4: which is about as straightforward as Mitchell ever got
column5: and ""Both Sides Now"". Though she'd known burden and heartache plenty by her still-tender age (she'd borne a child alone and in secret after dropping out of art school and married singer Chuck Mitchell in order to make a family; he changed his mind a month later and she put the baby up for adoption) she sounds a bit too young and chipper to be singing about disillusionment. Still
column6: Clouds was a landmark
column7: and she landed a Grammy for Best Folk Performance.

column1: Ladies of the Canyon from 1970 is Mitchell's most accessible album and it introduces her earnest folk-pop style. Her voice is newly elastic and expressive
column2: and it's the first record where she sounds like she might actually be fun to hang out with. Ladies also features her generation-defining ""Woodstock""
column3: ""The Circle Game"" (Mitchell's answer back to Neil Young's nostalgic ""Sugar Mountain"")
column4: and her blustery gentrification sing-along
column5: ""Big Yellow Taxi"". All were hippie-era sing-along staples; it hardly bears remarking that these songs are some of Mitchell's corniest.

column1: The genius of Ladies is often circumscribed by Mitchell's proximity to CSNY; the vocal arrangement and production invariably propped to Crosby's influence
column2: ""Woodstock"" supposedly inspired by Nash's recounting of the event (she wrote it before he'd even returned from the festival). If Ladies does bear the mark of CSNY
column3: it's to the album's detriment. The fruits of the Nash/Mitchell romance-- his gee-whiz domestic ode
column4: ""Our House"" and Ladies' ""Willy""-- are saccharine at best. Their subsequent break up would inspire much more potent work-- Neil Young's ""Only Love Can Break Your Heart"" and Mitchell's follow-up.

column1: About that follow-up: 1971's Blue is possibly the most gutting break-up album ever made. After Mitchell's relationship with Nash dissolved
column2: she headed to Europe to lose the tether of her fame
column3: eventually taking exile in a cave on the Greek island Crete. The trip would inspire the how-Joni-got-her-groove-back ditties ""Carey"" and ""California"". The album is suffused with melancholy for all that is missing: her daughter (""Little Green"")
column4: innocence (""The Last Time I Saw Richard"")
column5: and connection (""All I Want""). Mitchell bleeds diffidence and highlights it with spare notes plucked out on her Appalachian dulcimer. While her pals Neil Young
column6: Leonard Cohen
column7: and Laura Nyro were also pushing the singer-songwriter genre forward
column8: none of them managed to stride the distance that Mitchell did here in a single album.

column1: ""Will you take me as I am/ Strung out on another man?"" Mitchell pleads on ""California"". She was (in)famously strung out on other talents that were as mercurial as hers

column6: a dismissal effectively saying her import was as a girlfriend or muse to the men around her more than as an artist in her own right. Worse still

column3: she was transitioning from the era's de facto hippie sensualism (colors! the weather! vibes!) to the classically prosodic style (Keats! Cohen!) she'd become known for. The album's biggest signs of life are two of her most famous songs-- the kicky ""Chelsea Morning""
column4: which is about as straightforward as Mitchell ever got
column5: and ""Both Sides Now"". Though she'd known burden and heartache plenty by her still-tender age (she'd borne a child alone and in secret after dropping out of art school and married singer Chuck Mitchell in order to make a family; he changed his mind a month later and she put the baby up for adoption) she sounds a bit too young and chipper to be singing about disillusionment. Still
column6: Clouds was a landmark
column7: and she landed a Grammy for Best Folk Performance.

column1: Ladies of the Canyon from 1970 is Mitchell's most accessible album and it introduces her earnest folk-pop style. Her voice is newly elastic and expressive
column2: and it's the first record where she sounds like she might actually be fun to hang out with. Ladies also features her generation-defining ""Woodstock""
column3: ""The Circle Game"" (Mitchell's answer back to Neil Young's nostalgic ""Sugar Mountain"")
column4: and her blustery gentrification sing-along
column5: ""Big Yellow Taxi"". All were hippie-era sing-along staples; it hardly bears remarking that these songs are some of Mitchell's corniest.

column1: The genius of Ladies is often circumscribed by Mitchell's proximity to CSNY; the vocal arrangement and production invariably propped to Crosby's influence
column2: ""Woodstock"" supposedly inspired by Nash's recounting of the event (she wrote it before he'd even returned from the festival). If Ladies does bear the mark of CSNY
column3: it's to the album's detriment. The fruits of the Nash/Mitchell romance-- his gee-whiz domestic ode
column4: ""Our House"" and Ladies' ""Willy""-- are saccharine at best. Their subsequent break up would inspire much more potent work-- Neil Young's ""Only Love Can Break Your Heart"" and Mitchell's follow-up.

column1: About that follow-up: 1971's Blue is possibly the most gutting break-up album ever made. After Mitchell's relationship with Nash dissolved
column2: she headed to Europe to lose the tether of her fame
column3: eventually taking exile in a cave on the Greek island Crete. The trip would inspire the how-Joni-got-her-groove-back ditties ""Carey"" and ""California"". The album is suffused with melancholy for all that is missing: her daughter (""Little Green"")
column4: innocence (""The Last Time I Saw Richard"")
column5: and connection (""All I Want""). Mitchell bleeds diffidence and highlights it with spare notes plucked out on her Appalachian dulcimer. While her pals Neil Young
column6: Leonard Cohen
column7: and Laura Nyro were also pushing the singer-songwriter genre forward
column8: none of them managed to stride the distance that Mitchell did here in a single album.

column1: ""Will you take me as I am/ Strung out on another man?"" Mitchell pleads on ""California"". She was (in)famously strung out on other talents that were as mercurial as hers
column2: fueling constant speculation as to whether this song was about Leonard Cohen
column3: or that one about James Taylor or Nash or that puerile heartbreaker Jackson Browne. The year Mitchell issued Blue
column4: an album that would be a landmark in any artist's career
column5: Rolling Stone named her ""Old Lady of the Year
column6: a dismissal effectively saying her import was as a girlfriend or muse to the men around her more than as an artist in her own right. Worse still
column7: they called her ""Queen of El Lay
column8: and offered a diagram of her supposed affairs and conquests. She'd made the best album of her career and in exchange she got slut-shamed in the biggest music magazine in America.

column1: Mitchell retired to her homestead in Canada and returned sounding confident for 1972's For the Roses. Up until Roses she'd kept things minimal
column2: here she stacked multi-tracks of impossible vocals harmonies
column3: mimicking a horn section (""Let the Wind Carry Me"") or interpolating and dueling with jazzer sideman Tom Scott's riffing woodwinds. Mitchell's vocals
column4: fluttering unpredictably and with stunning control between the bottom of her range and the top of her crystalline contralto
column5: were given a new stop; her heavy smoking had given her a heretofore non-existent midrange. There's really no singing along with Roses--  which is a fabulous fuck-you for a pop artist.

column1: Though part of the reason that she'd retired from performing in 1969 was to avoid the default of writing about the myopic rock'n'roll life
column2: Roses' standout track
column3: ""Blonde in the Bleachers""
column4: shows that she may have understood it better than any of the boys; it is one of the best songs ever written about the rules and (gender) roles of the road. ""It seems like you've got to give up/ Such a piece of your soul /When you give up the chase
column5: she sings
column6: about finding identity and meaning in who you fuck. Freedom is an evergreen subject for Mitchell
column7: but ""Blonde in the Bleachers"" gets beyond the thrill in partaking of what-- or
column8: rather
column9: who-- is offered up
column10: backstage. The quiet story here is the ebbing power of a woman once she's been conquered.

column1: Though Mitchell was criticized for not making blatantly feminist or political (read: sloganeering) albums
column2: her work was always tacitly so. Her songs spotlight the unspoken roles of women (""Barandgrill"")
column3: who they were unrelated to men; she gave them names and precise details. There is hardly a more feminist topic than striving for a freedom that life and love has never allowed you. On ""Woman of Heart and Mind""
column4: it's hard to tell whether she is mocking herself or the man she is singing to (or both): ""Push your papers/ Win your medals/ Fuck your strangers/ Don't it leave you on the empty side /I'm looking for affection and respect."" On Roses
column5: Mitchell sounds like a woman who's had enough of everyone else's shit
column6: an attitude that certainly put her in line with the libbers.

column1: Her 1974 commercial break-out
column2: Court and Spark
column3: found her backed by first-call jazz session cats L.A. Express. It was her official severance from folk music. Court is her most pop album and gave her three chart hits
column4: going gold five weeks after its release. Mitchell's production features heavy and sudden multi-tracked swells of her voice that spike melodies like a choir of accusing angels and mimic strings and horns. Her arrangement on ""Down to You"" (aided by Express bandleader Tom Scott) is stunning in its complexity
column5: yet it never shakes you; it is still utterly a pop song.

column1: Now six albums deep on the topic of love and loss
column2: Court has a marked cynicism. It's a grown up album about arriving at the intractable issues of adult love. ""Help Me""
column3: which was Mitchell's only top 10 hit
column4: is reluctant about romance; she's ""hoping for the future/ And worrying about the past."" The refrain is pocked by the dawnlight realizations of that post-free love era: ""We love our lovin'/ But not like we love our freedom."" For the largeness of her band (which included Joe Sample of the Crusaders
column5: and Larry Carlton
column6: soon to be of every memorable Steely Dan guitar solo) they are nimble throughout; their finesse suited her own.

column1: To explain how and what happened next in Mitchell's career-- how much her The Hissing of Summer Lawns was viewed as not a stylistic departure but a betrayal-- we must first look at the run up. While promoting Court
column2: what could easily be defined as the commercial and artistic high-water mark of her career
column3: Mitchell went to go see Dylan's Rolling Thunder Revue tour and wound up joining. At the time
column4: she was a peer of Dylan
column5: commercially and as a songwriter
column6: she was also tight with tour member Robbie Robertson of the Band. She had a song in the Billboard Top 10-- and she was opening. When Mitchell recounts this in later interviews
column7: she talks about how being on the tour was a matter of constantly having to subvert her ego to the men around her.

column1: At this same time
column2: many of her peers were headed further toward the mainstream
column3: towards syncopation
column4: towards rock
column5: towards retro revivalism. Mitchell saw there was not much of a place for her amongst the new talents and the Peter Pan-ing crew she came up with
column6: as a woman in her early 30s
column7: and she saw jazz as a genre that would allow her to age gracefully and expand as an artist-- and so there she went. She was trying to find or develop a place to belong.

column1: Through all of this she arrived at Hissing of Summer Lawns.
The 1975 album marks Mitchell's official departure from the mainstream
column2: her embarking upon her jazzbo journey. It's the album of an artist absolutely assured of herself
column3: and it's addressed to anyone who might not consider her a serious musician
column4: who believed all she could do was confess her heartache. Though it doesn't have the rhapsodic rep as Blue
column5: it's unquestionably one of Mitchell's finest albums
column6: and it is certainly her most timeless.

column1: It opens easy enough with ""In France They Kiss on Main Street""-- a soft
column2: linear move from Court. What follows is jarring if you were expecting more of the same: ""The Jungle Line"" runs over a distorting sample of the Royal Drummers of Burundi tribal pounding and chanting. Mitchell going from husky to her enunciation so precise about ""the mathematic circuits of the modern nights
column3: the long
column4: low whirring of a Moog running the melody line under Mitchell's acoustic strumming. The rest of the record is dark
column5: tense
column6: and lilts unapologetically toward something softer and more ornate than jazz fusion (no more than the later Steely Dan records it predated) with Mitchell singing observationally
column7: about the place of women in the world
column8: about the trade-offs they make for power and freedom.

column1: Mitchell and women of her generation had been brought up with the idea that marriage to a man who took care of them would fulfill them entirely and that ambitions beyond that were frivolous. The album is a reckoning reflective of culture at the time; Hissing is an album of women trying to find their real selves in a world that had groomed them for quiet obeisance to men. On ""Harry's House"" Mitchell sings of a curdling domestic scene
column2: of wives who ""paper the walls to keep their gut reactions hid."" The song dovetails into the standard ""Centerpiece""
column3: which she sings in a voice not her own
column4: playacting with this ultra-feminine throwback voice
column5: creating a critical distance when she sings the lines: ""I'm building all my dreams around you/ Our happiness will never cease/ 'Cause nothing's any good without you/ Baby you're my centerpiece."" And on the subtlety devastating ""Sweet Bird""
column6: she sings of women wielding power through beauty and youth
column7: and what is lost and gained in that bargaining: ""Power ideals and beauty/ Fading in everyone's hand"" and ""Calendars of our lives/ Circled with compromise.""

column1: Mitchell had never made a record that wasn't bigger than the one before and was shocked that her fans and many critics saw her new sound as an abandonment and misguided move
column2: respectively. Reviewers chastised her for her ego. While the album went gold and brought her a Grammy nod
column3: as her 1974 live album Miles of Aisles attests (a wonky fiasco
column4: skip it) there were still plenty of people shouting for ""Big Yellow Taxi"". But that Joni didn't live here anymore. Hissing was proof. The era of Mitchell doing no wrong was over and if her audience couldn't hang
column5: she wasn't about to do anything to reel them back in.

column1: The two albums that followed are where Mitchell went off the grid. Hejira
column2: from 1976
column3: was written while driving alone from Maine to L.A. and is a meditation on the value and melancholy of being alone
column4: her guitar imitating the rhythms and expanse of the road. In spots it's as emotionally bare as Blue. It's a real grown woman album and may not make tremendous sense to anyone under 30.

column1: Musically
column2: Mitchell says she was trying to see how far she could get from traditional rhythm; the songs are long and lovely
column3: burbling and unspooling. Whether or not you feel this era of Mitchell is unfairly maligned depends on how you feel about Jaco Pastorious and his fretless bass and its many
column4: many notes fardling way up high in the mix. His playing lends a darkly cinematic feeling to the album
column5: but in the decades since his trademark sound and style have been taken to such unpleasant extremes by jam and light jazz bands
column6: it's understandable to experience a visceral revulsion.

column1: Inspired by the rhythms of Brazilian music
column2: Mitchell issued the experimental double-album Don Juan's Reckless Daughter in '77. Her experiments went further than just musical; she appears in brownface and an afro wig as a man on the cover. Less commented on is her in ""injun"" costume on the back
column3: palm raised
column4: a bubble above her head reads ""How!"" (Her cringe-inducing arguments about it later on included statements about how she has a ""black man's soul""). The album is solidly jazz-fusion
column5: indulgent in length with still plenty of Jaco-dominance. But! there is reward in the album's centerpiece
column6: if you can make it that far: The 16-minute ""Paprika Plains"" is a freakout of a song suite
column7: inspired in part by a conversation with prickly ol' Bob Dylan. Even if you cannot abide by the album
column8: we must be grateful for it
column9: as it is Bjork's #1 favorite album and source of inspiration. The last piece in the box
column10: Mingus
column11: her 1979 collaboration with Charles Mingus before his death makes her seem like the jazz dilettante that people accused her of being. The ultimate result doesn't serve either of their legacies particularly well.

column1: Though Mitchell's weird escapade through pop doesn't end where the box set does
column2: she never recaptured the thread of popular imagination. Her 80s albums
column3: like many of her hippie-era peers'
column4: were overbearing and scolding and featured awkward embraces of technology. She retired for long stretches to focus on her painting. Her last good record was 2000's Both Sides Now
column5: where
column6: her range ravaged by decades of smoking
column7:
she sings the definitive version of the titular song that launched her career and finally sounds like she's seen enough to know.

3|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/18617/homepage_large.4d7c00ab.jpg|Ladies of the Canyon|6841.0|Joni Mitchell|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|1.0|['Rhino']|2012-11-09 00:00:00|1970|2016-06-11 17:04:48.568165|"

Joni Mitchell once called fame ""a glamorous misunderstanding."" As America's finest living Canadian songwriter (tied with Neil Young)
column2: few musicians have understood its nature so well. In the 1960s and 70s
column3: Mitchell was Mary Magdalene to Dylan's folk-rock messiah
column4: making music that was bittersweet and relatable
column5: carrying what Dylan begat even further. Her work helped birth a new idiom that was personal and poetic
column6: creating a new space for songs that made artistic statements
column7: unbound by cliché and tradition. Such was the strength of her music that Mitchell's lyrics didn't have to make sense. But they did
column8: particularly to women.

column1: Mitchell's first 10 studio albums
column2: cut during an 11-year span
column3: have been gathered in this import box set. During this run
column4: Mitchell charted one of the most solid career arcs in contemporary music that then detoured into one of the strangest
column5: following her muse into places that very nearly cost her career and exhausted her fanbase's patience. Throughout
column6: she was confident and unrepentant in her vision
column7: in an era where that kind of ego was unbefitting a woman
column8: even if she did have the gold albums and Grammys™ to back it up.

column1: This is a basic set-- no frills
column2: just all the albums' original layouts reproduced in envelope sleeves
column3: the fonts so tiny only mice could read them. There are no extras
column4: outtakes or re-anythinged. But taking these 10 records in a row
column5: chronologically
column6: it is a striking reminder no single artist has had a run like Joni (even her acolyte Prince only got to seven albums before he started to fall off). Mitchell was pop's first female auteur
column7: an innovator of singular talent
column8: whose influence was vast
column9: immediate (see: Led Zeppelin's ""Going to California"") and long lasting (Joanna Newsom
column10: St. Vincent
column11: Taylor Swift's kiss'n'tell cottage industry).

column4: let alone to be an unaccompanied solo act. Though Mitchell's debut

column1: Mitchell was ""discovered"" c. 1968 when ex-Byrd David Crosby pulled up in a sailboat outside the Florida club she was playing and took her to L.A. At the time

column5: Song to a Seagull

column8: formal musical settings. The delicate album suffers under Crosby's intrusive production; Mitchell would self-produce from then on.

column1: Clouds (1969) is the introduction to Mitchell's real deal
column2: shaking folk tradition and giving off a little humor and spirit. The album sounds casual. Lyrically
column3: she was transitioning from the era's de facto hippie sensualism (colors! the weather! vibes!) to the classically prosodic style (Keats! Cohen!) she'd become known for. The album's biggest signs of life are two of her most famous songs-- the kicky ""Chelsea Morning""
column4: which is about as straightforward as Mitchell ever got
column5: and ""Both Sides Now"". Though she'd known burden and heartache plenty by her still-tender age (she'd borne a child alone and in secret after dropping out of art school and married singer Chuck Mitchell in order to make a family; he changed his mind a month later and she put the baby up for adoption) she sounds a bit too young and chipper to be singing about disillusionment. Still
column6: Clouds was a landmark
column7: and she landed a Grammy for Best Folk Performance.

column1: Ladies of the Canyon from 1970 is Mitchell's most accessible album and it introduces her earnest folk-pop style. Her voice is newly elastic and expressive
column2: and it's the first record where she sounds like she might actually be fun to hang out with. Ladies also features her generation-defining ""Woodstock""
column3: ""The Circle Game"" (Mitchell's answer back to Neil Young's nostalgic ""Sugar Mountain"")
column4: and her blustery gentrification sing-along
column5: ""Big Yellow Taxi"". All were hippie-era sing-along staples; it hardly bears remarking that these songs are some of Mitchell's corniest.

column1: The genius of Ladies is often circumscribed by Mitchell's proximity to CSNY; the vocal arrangement and production invariably propped to Crosby's influence
column2: ""Woodstock"" supposedly inspired by Nash's recounting of the event (she wrote it before he'd even returned from the festival). If Ladies does bear the mark of CSNY
column3: it's to the album's detriment. The fruits of the Nash/Mitchell romance-- his gee-whiz domestic ode
column4: ""Our House"" and Ladies' ""Willy""-- are saccharine at best. Their subsequent break up would inspire much more potent work-- Neil Young's ""Only Love Can Break Your Heart"" and Mitchell's follow-up.

column1: About that follow-up: 1971's Blue is possibly the most gutting break-up album ever made. After Mitchell's relationship with Nash dissolved
column2: she headed to Europe to lose the tether of her fame
column3: eventually taking exile in a cave on the Greek island Crete. The trip would inspire the how-Joni-got-her-groove-back ditties ""Carey"" and ""California"". The album is suffused with melancholy for all that is missing: her daughter (""Little Green"")
column4: innocence (""The Last Time I Saw Richard"")
column5: and connection (""All I Want""). Mitchell bleeds diffidence and highlights it with spare notes plucked out on her Appalachian dulcimer. While her pals Neil Young
column6: Leonard Cohen
column7: and Laura Nyro were also pushing the singer-songwriter genre forward
column8: none of them managed to stride the distance that Mitchell did here in a single album.

column1: ""Will you take me as I am/ Strung out on another man?"" Mitchell pleads on ""California"". She was (in)famously strung out on other talents that were as mercurial as hers
column2: fueling constant speculation as to whether this song was about Leonard Cohen
column3: or that one about James Taylor or Nash or that puerile heartbreaker Jackson Browne. The year Mitchell issued Blue
column4: an album that would be a landmark in any artist's career
column5: Rolling Stone named her ""Old Lady of the Year
column6: a dismissal effectively saying her import was as a girlfriend or muse to the men around her more than as an artist in her own right. Worse still
column7: they called her ""Queen of El Lay
column8: and offered a diagram of her supposed affairs and conquests. She'd made the best album of her career and in exchange she got slut-shamed in the biggest music magazine in America.

column1: Mitchell retired to her homestead in Canada and returned sounding confident for 1972's For the Roses. Up until Roses she'd kept things minimal
column2: here she stacked multi-tracks of impossible vocals harmonies
column3: mimicking a horn section (""Let the Wind Carry Me"") or interpolating and dueling with jazzer sideman Tom Scott's riffing woodwinds. Mitchell's vocals
column4: fluttering unpredictably and with stunning control between the bottom of her range and the top of her crystalline contralto
column5: were given a new stop; her heavy smoking had given her a heretofore non-existent midrange. There's really no singing along with Roses--  which is a fabulous fuck-you for a pop artist.

column1: Though part of the reason that she'd retired from performing in 1969 was to avoid the default of writing about the myopic rock'n'roll life
column2: Roses' standout track
column3: ""Blonde in the Bleachers""
column4: shows that she may have understood it better than any of the boys; it is one of the best songs ever written about the rules and (gender) roles of the road. ""It seems like you've got to give up/ Such a piece of your soul /When you give up the chase
column5: she sings
column6: about finding identity and meaning in who you fuck. Freedom is an evergreen subject for Mitchell
column7: but ""Blonde in the Bleachers"" gets beyond the thrill in partaking of what-- or
column8: rather
column9: who-- is offered up
column10: backstage. The quiet story here is the ebbing power of a woman once she's been conquered.

column1: Though Mitchell was criticized for not making blatantly feminist or political (read: sloganeering) albums
column2: her work was always tacitly so. Her songs spotlight the unspoken roles of women (""Barandgrill"")
column3: who they were unrelated to men; she gave them names and precise details. There is hardly a more feminist topic than striving for a freedom that life and love has never allowed you. On ""Woman of Heart and Mind""
column4: it's hard to tell whether she is mocking herself or the man she is singing to (or both): ""Push your papers/ Win your medals/ Fuck your strangers/ Don't it leave you on the empty side /I'm looking for affection and respect."" On Roses
column5: Mitchell sounds like a woman who's had enough of everyone else's shit
column6: an attitude that certainly put her in line with the libbers.

column1: Her 1974 commercial break-out
column2: Court and Spark
column3: found her backed by first-call jazz session cats L.A. Express. It was her official severance from folk music. Court is her most pop album and gave her three chart hits
column4: going gold five weeks after its release. Mitchell's production features heavy and sudden multi-tracked swells of her voice that spike melodies like a choir of accusing angels and mimic strings and horns. Her arrangement on ""Down to You"" (aided by Express bandleader Tom Scott) is stunning in its complexity
column5: yet it never shakes you; it is still utterly a pop song.

column1: Now six albums deep on the topic of love and loss
column2: Court has a marked cynicism. It's a grown up album about arriving at the intractable issues of adult love. ""Help Me""
column3: which was Mitchell's only top 10 hit
column4: is reluctant about romance; she's ""hoping for the future/ And worrying about the past."" The refrain is pocked by the dawnlight realizations of that post-free love era: ""We love our lovin'/ But not like we love our freedom."" For the largeness of her band (which included Joe Sample of the Crusaders
column5: and Larry Carlton
column6: soon to be of every memorable Steely Dan guitar solo) they are nimble throughout; their finesse suited her own.

column1: To explain how and what happened next in Mitchell's career-- how much her The Hissing of Summer Lawns was viewed as not a stylistic departure but a betrayal-- we must first look at the run up. While promoting Court
column2: what could easily be defined as the commercial and artistic high-water mark of her career
column3: Mitchell went to go see Dylan's Rolling Thunder Revue tour and wound up joining. At the time
column4: she was a peer of Dylan
column5: commercially and as a songwriter
column6: she was also tight with tour member Robbie Robertson of the Band. She had a song in the Billboard Top 10-- and she was opening. When Mitchell recounts this in later interviews
column7: she talks about how being on the tour was a matter of constantly having to subvert her ego to the men around her.

column1: At this same time
column2: many of her peers were headed further toward the mainstream
column3: towards syncopation
column4: towards rock
column5: towards retro revivalism. Mitchell saw there was not much of a place for her amongst the new talents and the Peter Pan-ing crew she came up with
column6: as a woman in her early 30s
column7: and she saw jazz as a genre that would allow her to age gracefully and expand as an artist-- and so there she went. She was trying to find or develop a place to belong.

column1: Through all of this she arrived at Hissing of Summer Lawns.
The 1975 album marks Mitchell's official departure from the mainstream
column2: her embarking upon her jazzbo journey. It's the album of an artist absolutely assured of herself
column3: and it's addressed to anyone who might not consider her a serious musician
column4: who believed all she could do was confess her heartache. Though it doesn't have the rhapsodic rep as Blue
column5: it's unquestionably one of Mitchell's finest albums
column6: and it is certainly her most timeless.

column1: It opens easy enough with ""In France They Kiss on Main Street""-- a soft
column2: linear move from Court. What follows is jarring if you were expecting more of the same: ""The Jungle Line"" runs over a distorting sample of the Royal Drummers of Burundi tribal pounding and chanting. Mitchell going from husky to her enunciation so precise about ""the mathematic circuits of the modern nights
column3: the long
column4: low whirring of a Moog running the melody line under Mitchell's acoustic strumming. The rest of the record is dark
column5: tense
column6: and lilts unapologetically toward something softer and more ornate than jazz fusion (no more than the later Steely Dan records it predated) with Mitchell singing observationally
column7: about the place of women in the world
column8: about the trade-offs they make for power and freedom.

column1: Mitchell and women of her generation had been brought up with the idea that marriage to a man who took care of them would fulfill them entirely and that ambitions beyond that were frivolous. The album is a reckoning reflective of culture at the time; Hissing is an album of women trying to find their real selves in a world that had groomed them for quiet obeisance to men. On ""Harry's House"" Mitchell sings of a curdling domestic scene
column2: of wives who ""paper the walls to keep their gut reactions hid."" The song dovetails into the standard ""Centerpiece""
column3: which she sings in a voice not her own
column4: playacting with this ultra-feminine throwback voice
column5: creating a critical distance when she sings the lines: ""I'm building all my dreams around you/ Our happiness will never cease/ 'Cause nothing's any good without you/ Baby you're my centerpiece."" And on the subtlety devastating ""Sweet Bird""
column6: she sings of women wielding power through beauty and youth
column7: and what is lost and gained in that bargaining: ""Power ideals and beauty/ Fading in everyone's hand"" and ""Calendars of our lives/ Circled with compromise.""

column1: Mitchell had never made a record that wasn't bigger than the one before and was shocked that her fans and many critics saw her new sound as an abandonment and misguided move
column2: respectively. Reviewers chastised her for her ego. While the album went gold and brought her a Grammy nod
column3: as her 1974 live album Miles of Aisles attests (a wonky fiasco
column4: skip it) there were still plenty of people shouting for ""Big Yellow Taxi"". But that Joni didn't live here anymore. Hissing was proof. The era of Mitchell doing no wrong was over and if her audience couldn't hang
column5: she wasn't about to do anything to reel them back in.

column1: The two albums that followed are where Mitchell went off the grid. Hejira
column2: from 1976
column3: was written while driving alone from Maine to L.A. and is a meditation on the value and melancholy of being alone
column4: her guitar imitating the rhythms and expanse of the road. In spots it's as emotionally bare as Blue. It's a real grown woman album and may not make tremendous sense to anyone under 30.

column1: Musically
column2: Mitchell says she was trying to see how far she could get from traditional rhythm; the songs are long and lovely
column3: burbling and unspooling. Whether or not you feel this era of Mitchell is unfairly maligned depends on how you feel about Jaco Pastorious and his fretless bass and its many
column4: many notes fardling way up high in the mix. His playing lends a darkly cinematic feeling to the album
column5: but in the decades since his trademark sound and style have been taken to such unpleasant extremes by jam and light jazz bands
column6: it's understandable to experience a visceral revulsion.

column1: Inspired by the rhythms of Brazilian music
column2: Mitchell issued the experimental double-album Don Juan's Reckless Daughter in '77. Her experiments went further than just musical; she appears in brownface and an afro wig as a man on the cover. Less commented on is her in ""injun"" costume on the back
column3: palm raised
column4: a bubble above her head reads ""How!"" (Her cringe-inducing arguments about it later on included statements about how she has a ""black man's soul""). The album is solidly jazz-fusion
