column2: her embarking upon her jazzbo journey. It's the album of an artist absolutely assured of herself
column3: and it's addressed to anyone who might not consider her a serious musician
column4: who believed all she could do was confess her heartache. Though it doesn't have the rhapsodic rep as Blue
column5: it's unquestionably one of Mitchell's finest albums
column6: and it is certainly her most timeless.

column1: It opens easy enough with ""In France They Kiss on Main Street""-- a soft
column2: linear move from Court. What follows is jarring if you were expecting more of the same: ""The Jungle Line"" runs over a distorting sample of the Royal Drummers of Burundi tribal pounding and chanting. Mitchell going from husky to her enunciation so precise about ""the mathematic circuits of the modern nights
column3: the long
column4: low whirring of a Moog running the melody line under Mitchell's acoustic strumming. The rest of the record is dark
column5: tense
column6: and lilts unapologetically toward something softer and more ornate than jazz fusion (no more than the later Steely Dan records it predated) with Mitchell singing observationally
column7: about the place of women in the world
column8: about the trade-offs they make for power and freedom.

column1: Mitchell and women of her generation had been brought up with the idea that marriage to a man who took care of them would fulfill them entirely and that ambitions beyond that were frivolous. The album is a reckoning reflective of culture at the time; Hissing is an album of women trying to find their real selves in a world that had groomed them for quiet obeisance to men. On ""Harry's House"" Mitchell sings of a curdling domestic scene
column2: of wives who ""paper the walls to keep their gut reactions hid."" The song dovetails into the standard ""Centerpiece""
column3: which she sings in a voice not her own
column4: playacting with this ultra-feminine throwback voice
column5: creating a critical distance when she sings the lines: ""I'm building all my dreams around you/ Our happiness will never cease/ 'Cause nothing's any good without you/ Baby you're my centerpiece."" And on the subtlety devastating ""Sweet Bird""
column6: she sings of women wielding power through beauty and youth
column7: and what is lost and gained in that bargaining: ""Power ideals and beauty/ Fading in everyone's hand"" and ""Calendars of our lives/ Circled with compromise.""

column1: Mitchell had never made a record that wasn't bigger than the one before and was shocked that her fans and many critics saw her new sound as an abandonment and misguided move
column2: respectively. Reviewers chastised her for her ego. While the album went gold and brought her a Grammy nod
column3: as her 1974 live album Miles of Aisles attests (a wonky fiasco
column4: skip it) there were still plenty of people shouting for ""Big Yellow Taxi"". But that Joni didn't live here anymore. Hissing was proof. The era of Mitchell doing no wrong was over and if her audience couldn't hang
column5: she wasn't about to do anything to reel them back in.

column1: The two albums that followed are where Mitchell went off the grid. Hejira
column2: from 1976
column3: was written while driving alone from Maine to L.A. and is a meditation on the value and melancholy of being alone
column4: her guitar imitating the rhythms and expanse of the road. In spots it's as emotionally bare as Blue. It's a real grown woman album and may not make tremendous sense to anyone under 30.

column1: Musically
column2: Mitchell says she was trying to see how far she could get from traditional rhythm; the songs are long and lovely
column3: burbling and unspooling. Whether or not you feel this era of Mitchell is unfairly maligned depends on how you feel about Jaco Pastorious and his fretless bass and its many
column4: many notes fardling way up high in the mix. His playing lends a darkly cinematic feeling to the album
column5: but in the decades since his trademark sound and style have been taken to such unpleasant extremes by jam and light jazz bands
column6: it's understandable to experience a visceral revulsion.

column1: Inspired by the rhythms of Brazilian music
column2: Mitchell issued the experimental double-album Don Juan's Reckless Daughter in '77. Her experiments went further than just musical; she appears in brownface and an afro wig as a man on the cover. Less commented on is her in ""injun"" costume on the back
column3: palm raised
column4: a bubble above her head reads ""How!"" (Her cringe-inducing arguments about it later on included statements about how she has a ""black man's soul""). The album is solidly jazz-fusion
column5: indulgent in length with still plenty of Jaco-dominance. But! there is reward in the album's centerpiece
column6: if you can make it that far: The 16-minute ""Paprika Plains"" is a freakout of a song suite
column7: inspired in part by a conversation with prickly ol' Bob Dylan. Even if you cannot abide by the album
column8: we must be grateful for it
column9: as it is Bjork's #1 favorite album and source of inspiration. The last piece in the box
column10: Mingus
column11: her 1979 collaboration with Charles Mingus before his death makes her seem like the jazz dilettante that people accused her of being. The ultimate result doesn't serve either of their legacies particularly well.

column1: Though Mitchell's weird escapade through pop doesn't end where the box set does
column2: she never recaptured the thread of popular imagination. Her 80s albums
column3: like many of her hippie-era peers'
column4: were overbearing and scolding and featured awkward embraces of technology. She retired for long stretches to focus on her painting. Her last good record was 2000's Both Sides Now
column5: where
column6: her range ravaged by decades of smoking
column7:
she sings the definitive version of the titular song that launched her career and finally sounds like she's seen enough to know.

Joni Mitchell once called fame ""a glamorous misunderstanding."" As America's finest living Canadian songwriter (tied with Neil Young)
column2: few musicians have understood its nature so well. In the 1960s and 70s
column3: Mitchell was Mary Magdalene to Dylan's folk-rock messiah
column4: making music that was bittersweet and relatable
column5: carrying what Dylan begat even further. Her work helped birth a new idiom that was personal and poetic
column6: creating a new space for songs that made artistic statements
column7: unbound by cliché and tradition. Such was the strength of her music that Mitchell's lyrics didn't have to make sense. But they did
column8: particularly to women.

column1: Mitchell's first 10 studio albums
column2: cut during an 11-year span
column3: have been gathered in this import box set. During this run
column4: Mitchell charted one of the most solid career arcs in contemporary music that then detoured into one of the strangest
column5: following her muse into places that very nearly cost her career and exhausted her fanbase's patience. Throughout
column6: she was confident and unrepentant in her vision
column7: in an era where that kind of ego was unbefitting a woman
column8: even if she did have the gold albums and Grammys™ to back it up.

column1: This is a basic set-- no frills
column2: just all the albums' original layouts reproduced in envelope sleeves
column3: the fonts so tiny only mice could read them. There are no extras
column4: outtakes or re-anythinged. But taking these 10 records in a row
column5: chronologically
column6: it is a striking reminder no single artist has had a run like Joni (even her acolyte Prince only got to seven albums before he started to fall off). Mitchell was pop's first female auteur
column7: an innovator of singular talent
column8: whose influence was vast
column9: immediate (see: Led Zeppelin's ""Going to California"") and long lasting (Joanna Newsom
column10: St. Vincent
column11: Taylor Swift's kiss'n'tell cottage industry).

column1: Mitchell was ""discovered"" c. 1968 when ex-Byrd David Crosby pulled up in a sailboat outside the Florida club she was playing and took her to L.A. At the time
column2: folk was out of fashion yet Mitchell managed to pull down an unprecedented major label deal for a girl and her guitar: total and complete artistic freedom
column3: with the caveat that Crosby would produce her first album. It was rare for a woman to be writing and recording her own material at the time
column4: let alone to be an unaccompanied solo act. Though Mitchell's debut
column5: Song to a Seagull
column6: was a heavy precedent for the era it's a harder listen now
column7: the fin de siècle earth-mama lyrics playing strange against the stilted
column8: formal musical settings. The delicate album suffers under Crosby's intrusive production; Mitchell would self-produce from then on.

column1: Clouds (1969) is the introduction to Mitchell's real deal
column2: shaking folk tradition and giving off a little humor and spirit. The album sounds casual. Lyrically
column3: she was transitioning from the era's de facto hippie sensualism (colors! the weather! vibes!) to the classically prosodic style (Keats! Cohen!) she'd become known for. The album's biggest signs of life are two of her most famous songs-- the kicky ""Chelsea Morning""
column4: which is about as straightforward as Mitchell ever got
column5: and ""Both Sides Now"". Though she'd known burden and heartache plenty by her still-tender age (she'd borne a child alone and in secret after dropping out of art school and married singer Chuck Mitchell in order to make a family; he changed his mind a month later and she put the baby up for adoption) she sounds a bit too young and chipper to be singing about disillusionment. Still
column6: Clouds was a landmark
column7: and she landed a Grammy for Best Folk Performance.

column1: Ladies of the Canyon from 1970 is Mitchell's most accessible album and it introduces her earnest folk-pop style. Her voice is newly elastic and expressive
column2: and it's the first record where she sounds like she might actually be fun to hang out with. Ladies also features her generation-defining ""Woodstock""
column3: ""The Circle Game"" (Mitchell's answer back to Neil Young's nostalgic ""Sugar Mountain"")
column4: and her blustery gentrification sing-along
column5: ""Big Yellow Taxi"". All were hippie-era sing-along staples; it hardly bears remarking that these songs are some of Mitchell's corniest.

column1: The genius of Ladies is often circumscribed by Mitchell's proximity to CSNY; the vocal arrangement and production invariably propped to Crosby's influence
column2: ""Woodstock"" supposedly inspired by Nash's recounting of the event (she wrote it before he'd even returned from the festival). If Ladies does bear the mark of CSNY
column3: it's to the album's detriment. The fruits of the Nash/Mitchell romance-- his gee-whiz domestic ode
column4: ""Our House"" and Ladies' ""Willy""-- are saccharine at best. Their subsequent break up would inspire much more potent work-- Neil Young's ""Only Love Can Break Your Heart"" and Mitchell's follow-up.

column1: About that follow-up: 1971's Blue is possibly the most gutting break-up album ever made. After Mitchell's relationship with Nash dissolved
column2: she headed to Europe to lose the tether of her fame
column3: eventually taking exile in a cave on the Greek island Crete. The trip would inspire the how-Joni-got-her-groove-back ditties ""Carey"" and ""California"". The album is suffused with melancholy for all that is missing: her daughter (""Little Green"")
column4: innocence (""The Last Time I Saw Richard"")
column5: and connection (""All I Want""). Mitchell bleeds diffidence and highlights it with spare notes plucked out on her Appalachian dulcimer. While her pals Neil Young
column6: Leonard Cohen
column7: and Laura Nyro were also pushing the singer-songwriter genre forward
column8: none of them managed to stride the distance that Mitchell did here in a single album.

column1: ""Will you take me as I am/ Strung out on another man?"" Mitchell pleads on ""California"". She was (in)famously strung out on other talents that were as mercurial as hers
column2: fueling constant speculation as to whether this song was about Leonard Cohen
column3: or that one about James Taylor or Nash or that puerile heartbreaker Jackson Browne. The year Mitchell issued Blue
column4: an album that would be a landmark in any artist's career
column5: Rolling Stone named her ""Old Lady of the Year
column6: a dismissal effectively saying her import was as a girlfriend or muse to the men around her more than as an artist in her own right. Worse still
column7: they called her ""Queen of El Lay
column8: and offered a diagram of her supposed affairs and conquests. She'd made the best album of her career and in exchange she got slut-shamed in the biggest music magazine in America.

column1: Mitchell retired to her homestead in Canada and returned sounding confident for 1972's For the Roses. Up until Roses she'd kept things minimal
column2: here she stacked multi-tracks of impossible vocals harmonies
column3: mimicking a horn section (""Let the Wind Carry Me"") or interpolating and dueling with jazzer sideman Tom Scott's riffing woodwinds. Mitchell's vocals
column4: fluttering unpredictably and with stunning control between the bottom of her range and the top of her crystalline contralto
column5: were given a new stop; her heavy smoking had given her a heretofore non-existent midrange. There's really no singing along with Roses--  which is a fabulous fuck-you for a pop artist.

column1: Though part of the reason that she'd retired from performing in 1969 was to avoid the default of writing about the myopic rock'n'roll life
column2: Roses' standout track
column3: ""Blonde in the Bleachers""
column4: shows that she may have understood it better than any of the boys; it is one of the best songs ever written about the rules and (gender) roles of the road. ""It seems like you've got to give up/ Such a piece of your soul /When you give up the chase
column5: she sings
column6: about finding identity and meaning in who you fuck. Freedom is an evergreen subject for Mitchell
column7: but ""Blonde in the Bleachers"" gets beyond the thrill in partaking of what-- or
column8: rather
column9: who-- is offered up
column10: backstage. The quiet story here is the ebbing power of a woman once she's been conquered.

column1: Though Mitchell was criticized for not making blatantly feminist or political (read: sloganeering) albums
column2: her work was always tacitly so. Her songs spotlight the unspoken roles of women (""Barandgrill"")
column3: who they were unrelated to men; she gave them names and precise details. There is hardly a more feminist topic than striving for a freedom that life and love has never allowed you. On ""Woman of Heart and Mind""
column4: it's hard to tell whether she is mocking herself or the man she is singing to (or both): ""Push your papers/ Win your medals/ Fuck your strangers/ Don't it leave you on the empty side /I'm looking for affection and respect."" On Roses
column5: Mitchell sounds like a woman who's had enough of everyone else's shit
column6: an attitude that certainly put her in line with the libbers.

column1: Her 1974 commercial break-out
column2: Court and Spark
column3: found her backed by first-call jazz session cats L.A. Express. It was her official severance from folk music. Court is her most pop album and gave her three chart hits
column4: going gold five weeks after its release. Mitchell's production features heavy and sudden multi-tracked swells of her voice that spike melodies like a choir of accusing angels and mimic strings and horns. Her arrangement on ""Down to You"" (aided by Express bandleader Tom Scott) is stunning in its complexity
column5: yet it never shakes you; it is still utterly a pop song.

column1: Now six albums deep on the topic of love and loss
column2: Court has a marked cynicism. It's a grown up album about arriving at the intractable issues of adult love. ""Help Me""
column3: which was Mitchell's only top 10 hit
column4: is reluctant about romance; she's ""hoping for the future/ And worrying about the past."" The refrain is pocked by the dawnlight realizations of that post-free love era: ""We love our lovin'/ But not like we love our freedom."" For the largeness of her band (which included Joe Sample of the Crusaders
column5: and Larry Carlton
column6: soon to be of every memorable Steely Dan guitar solo) they are nimble throughout; their finesse suited her own.

column4: she was a peer of Dylan
column5: commercially and as a songwriter
column6: she was also tight with tour member Robbie Robertson of the Band. She had a song in the Billboard Top 10-- and she was opening. When Mitchell recounts this in later interviews
column7: she talks about how being on the tour was a matter of constantly having to subvert her ego to the men around her.

column1: Her 1974 commercial break-out
column2: Court and Spark
column3: found her backed by first-call jazz session cats L.A. Express. It was her official severance from folk music. Court is her most pop album and gave her three chart hits

Mitchell's production features heavy and sudden multi-tracked swells of her voice that spike melodies like a choir of accusing angels and mimic strings and horns. Her arrangement on ""Down to You"" (aided by Express bandleader Tom Scott) is stunning in its complexity
column5: yet it never shakes you; it is still utterly a pop song.

column1: Now six albums deep on the topic of love and loss
column2: Court has a marked cynicism. It's a grown up album about arriving at the intractable issues of adult love. ""Help Me""
column3: which was Mitchell's only top 10 hit
column4: is reluctant about romance; she's ""hoping for the future/ And worrying about the past."" The refrain is pocked by the dawnlight realizations of that post-free love era: ""We love our lovin'/ But not like we love our freedom."" For the largeness of her band (which included Joe Sample of the Crusaders
column5: and Larry Carlton
column6: soon to be of every memorable Steely Dan guitar solo) they are nimble throughout; their finesse suited her own.

column1: To explain how and what happened next in Mitchell's career-- how much her The Hissing of Summer Lawns was viewed as not a stylistic departure but a betrayal-- we must first look at the run up. While promoting Court
column2: what could easily be defined as the commercial and artistic high-water mark of her career
column3: Mitchell went to go see Dylan's Rolling Thunder Revue tour and wound up joining. At the time
column4: she was a peer of Dylan
column5: commercially and as a songwriter
column6: she was also tight with tour member Robbie Robertson of the Band. She had a song in the Billboard Top 10-- and she was opening. When Mitchell recounts this in later interviews
column7: she talks about how being on the tour was a matter of constantly having to subvert her ego to the men around her.

column1: At this same time
column2: many of her peers were headed further toward the mainstream
column3: towards syncopation
column4: towards rock
column5: towards retro revivalism. Mitchell saw there was not much of a place for her amongst the new talents and the Peter Pan-ing crew she came up with
column6: as a woman in her early 30s
column7: and she saw jazz as a genre that would allow her to age gracefully and expand as an artist-- and so there she went. She was trying to find or develop a place to belong.

column1: Through all of this she arrived at Hissing of Summer Lawns.
The 1975 album marks Mitchell's official departure from the mainstream
column2: her embarking upon her jazzbo journey. It's the album of an artist absolutely assured of herself
column3: and it's addressed to anyone who might not consider her a serious musician
column4: who believed all she could do was confess her heartache. Though it doesn't have the rhapsodic rep as Blue
column5: it's unquestionably one of Mitchell's finest albums
column6: and it is certainly her most timeless.

column1: It opens easy enough with ""In France They Kiss on Main Street""-- a soft
column2: linear move from Court. What follows is jarring if you were expecting more of the same: ""The Jungle Line"" runs over a distorting sample of the Royal Drummers of Burundi tribal pounding and chanting. Mitchell going from husky to her enunciation so precise about ""the mathematic circuits of the modern nights
column3: the long
column4: low whirring of a Moog running the melody line under Mitchell's acoustic strumming. The rest of the record is dark
column5: tense
column6: and lilts unapologetically toward something softer and more ornate than jazz fusion (no more than the later Steely Dan records it predated) with Mitchell singing observationally
column7: about the place of women in the world
column8: about the trade-offs they make for power and freedom.

column1: Mitchell and women of her generation had been brought up with the idea that marriage to a man who took care of them would fulfill them entirely and that ambitions beyond that were frivolous. The album is a reckoning reflective of culture at the time; Hissing is an album of women trying to find their real selves in a world that had groomed them for quiet obeisance to men. On ""Harry's House"" Mitchell sings of a curdling domestic scene
column2: of wives who ""paper the walls to keep their gut reactions hid."" The song dovetails into the standard ""Centerpiece""
column3: which she sings in a voice not her own
column4: playacting with this ultra-feminine throwback voice
column5: creating a critical distance when she sings the lines: ""I'm building all my dreams around you/ Our happiness will never cease/ 'Cause nothing's any good without you/ Baby you're my centerpiece."" And on the subtlety devastating ""Sweet Bird""
column6: she sings of women wielding power through beauty and youth
column7: and what is lost and gained in that bargaining: ""Power ideals and beauty/ Fading in everyone's hand"" and ""Calendars of our lives/ Circled with compromise.""

column1: Mitchell had never made a record that wasn't bigger than the one before and was shocked that her fans and many critics saw her new sound as an abandonment and misguided move
column2: respectively. Reviewers chastised her for her ego. While the album went gold and brought her a Grammy nod
column3: as her 1974 live album Miles of Aisles attests (a wonky fiasco
column4: skip it) there were still plenty of people shouting for ""Big Yellow Taxi"". But that Joni didn't live here anymore. Hissing was proof. The era of Mitchell doing no wrong was over and if her audience couldn't hang
column5: she wasn't about to do anything to reel them back in.

column1: The two albums that followed are where Mitchell went off the grid. Hejira
column2: from 1976
column3: was written while driving alone from Maine to L.A. and is a meditation on the value and melancholy of being alone
column4: her guitar imitating the rhythms and expanse of the road. In spots it's as emotionally bare as Blue. It's a real grown woman album and may not make tremendous sense to anyone under 30.

column1: Musically
column2: Mitchell says she was trying to see how far she could get from traditional rhythm; the songs are long and lovely
column3: burbling and unspooling. Whether or not you feel this era of Mitchell is unfairly maligned depends on how you feel about Jaco Pastorious and his fretless bass and its many
column4: many notes fardling way up high in the mix. His playing lends a darkly cinematic feeling to the album
column5: but in the decades since his trademark sound and style have been taken to such unpleasant extremes by jam and light jazz bands
column6: it's understandable to experience a visceral revulsion.

column1: Inspired by the rhythms of Brazilian music
column2: Mitchell issued the experimental double-album Don Juan's Reckless Daughter in '77. Her experiments went further than just musical; she appears in brownface and an afro wig as a man on the cover. Less commented on is her in ""injun"" costume on the back
column3: palm raised
column4: a bubble above her head reads ""How!"" (Her cringe-inducing arguments about it later on included statements about how she has a ""black man's soul""). The album is solidly jazz-fusion
column5: indulgent in length with still plenty of Jaco-dominance. But! there is reward in the album's centerpiece
column6: if you can make it that far: The 16-minute ""Paprika Plains"" is a freakout of a song suite
column7: inspired in part by a conversation with prickly ol' Bob Dylan. Even if you cannot abide by the album
column8: we must be grateful for it
column9: as it is Bjork's #1 favorite album and source of inspiration. The last piece in the box
column10: Mingus
column11: her 1979 collaboration with Charles Mingus before his death makes her seem like the jazz dilettante that people accused her of being. The ultimate result doesn't serve either of their legacies particularly well.

column1: Though Mitchell's weird escapade through pop doesn't end where the box set does
column2: she never recaptured the thread of popular imagination. Her 80s albums
column3: like many of her hippie-era peers'
column4: were overbearing and scolding and featured awkward embraces of technology. She retired for long stretches to focus on her painting. Her last good record was 2000's Both Sides Now
column5: where
column6: her range ravaged by decades of smoking
column7:
she sings the definitive version of the titular song that launched her career and finally sounds like she's seen enough to know.

column2: few musicians have understood its nature so well. In the 1960s and 70s

column4: making music that was bittersweet and relatable

column6: creating a new space for songs that made artistic statements

column8: particularly to women.

column1: Mitchell's first 10 studio albums
column2: cut during an 11-year span
column3: have been gathered in this import box set. During this run
column4: Mitchell charted one of the most solid career arcs in contemporary music that then detoured into one of the strangest
column5: following her muse into places that very nearly cost her career and exhausted her fanbase's patience. Throughout
column6: she was confident and unrepentant in her vision
column7: in an era where that kind of ego was unbefitting a woman

column1: This is a basic set-- no frills

column1: Mitchell was ""discovered"" c. 1968 when ex-Byrd David Crosby pulled up in a sailboat outside the Florida club she was playing and took her to L.A. At the time
column2: folk was out of fashion yet Mitchell managed to pull down an unprecedented major label deal for a girl and her guitar: total and complete artistic freedom
column3: with the caveat that Crosby would produce her first album. It was rare for a woman to be writing and recording her own material at the time
column4: let alone to be an unaccompanied solo act. Though Mitchell's debut

column6: was a heavy precedent for the era it's a harder listen now
column7: the fin de siècle earth-mama lyrics playing strange against the stilted
column8: formal musical settings. The delicate album suffers under Crosby's intrusive production; Mitchell would self-produce from then on.

column1: Clouds (1969) is the introduction to Mitchell's real deal
column2: shaking folk tradition and giving off a little humor and spirit. The album sounds casual. Lyrically
column3: she was transitioning from the era's de facto hippie sensualism (colors! the weather! vibes!) to the classically prosodic style (Keats! Cohen!) she'd become known for. The album's biggest signs of life are two of her most famous songs-- the kicky ""Chelsea Morning""
column4: which is about as straightforward as Mitchell ever got
column5: and ""Both Sides Now"". Though she'd known burden and heartache plenty by her still-tender age (she'd borne a child alone and in secret after dropping out of art school and married singer Chuck Mitchell in order to make a family; he changed his mind a month later and she put the baby up for adoption) she sounds a bit too young and chipper to be singing about disillusionment. Still
column6: Clouds was a landmark
column7: and she landed a Grammy for Best Folk Performance.

column1: Ladies of the Canyon from 1970 is Mitchell's most accessible album and it introduces her earnest folk-pop style. Her voice is newly elastic and expressive
column2: and it's the first record where she sounds like she might actually be fun to hang out with. Ladies also features her generation-defining ""Woodstock""
column3: ""The Circle Game"" (Mitchell's answer back to Neil Young's nostalgic ""Sugar Mountain"")
column4: and her blustery gentrification sing-along

column1: The genius of Ladies is often circumscribed by Mitchell's proximity to CSNY; the vocal arrangement and production invariably propped to Crosby's influence

column3: it's to the album's detriment. The fruits of the Nash/Mitchell romance-- his gee-whiz domestic ode
column4: ""Our House"" and Ladies' ""Willy""-- are saccharine at best. Their subsequent break up would inspire much more potent work-- Neil Young's ""Only Love Can Break Your Heart"" and Mitchell's follow-up.

column4: innocence (""The Last Time I Saw Richard"")
column5: and connection (""All I Want""). Mitchell bleeds diffidence and highlights it with spare notes plucked out on her Appalachian dulcimer. While her pals Neil Young
column6: Leonard Cohen
column7: and Laura Nyro were also pushing the singer-songwriter genre forward

column4: fluttering unpredictably and with stunning control between the bottom of her range and the top of her crystalline contralto
column5: were given a new stop; her heavy smoking had given her a heretofore non-existent midrange. There's really no singing along with Roses--  which is a fabulous fuck-you for a pop artist.

column6: about finding identity and meaning in who you fuck. Freedom is an evergreen subject for Mitchell

column8: rather
column9: who-- is offered up
column10: backstage. The quiet story here is the ebbing power of a woman once she's been conquered.

column1: Though Mitchell was criticized for not making blatantly feminist or political (read: sloganeering) albums
column2: her work was always tacitly so. Her songs spotlight the unspoken roles of women (""Barandgrill"")
column3: who they were unrelated to men; she gave them names and precise details. There is hardly a more feminist topic than striving for a freedom that life and love has never allowed you. On ""Woman of Heart and Mind""
column4: it's hard to tell whether she is mocking herself or the man she is singing to (or both): ""Push your papers/ Win your medals/ Fuck your strangers/ Don't it leave you on the empty side /I'm looking for affection and respect."" On Roses
column5: Mitchell sounds like a woman who's had enough of everyone else's shit
column6: an attitude that certainly put her in line with the libbers.

column1: Her 1974 commercial break-out
column2: Court and Spark
column3: found her backed by first-call jazz session cats L.A. Express. It was her official severance from folk music. Court is her most pop album and gave her three chart hits
column4: going gold five weeks after its release. Mitchell's production features heavy and sudden multi-tracked swells of her voice that spike melodies like a choir of accusing angels and mimic strings and horns. Her arrangement on ""Down to You"" (aided by Express bandleader Tom Scott) is stunning in its complexity
column5: yet it never shakes you; it is still utterly a pop song.

column1: Now six albums deep on the topic of love and loss
column2: Court has a marked cynicism. It's a grown up album about arriving at the intractable issues of adult love. ""Help Me""
column3: which was Mitchell's only top 10 hit
column4: is reluctant about romance; she's ""hoping for the future/ And worrying about the past."" The refrain is pocked by the dawnlight realizations of that post-free love era: ""We love our lovin'/ But not like we love our freedom."" For the largeness of her band (which included Joe Sample of the Crusaders
column5: and Larry Carlton
column6: soon to be of every memorable Steely Dan guitar solo) they are nimble throughout; their finesse suited her own.

column1: To explain how and what happened next in Mitchell's career-- how much her The Hissing of Summer Lawns was viewed as not a stylistic departure but a betrayal-- we must first look at the run up. While promoting Court
column2: what could easily be defined as the commercial and artistic high-water mark of her career
column3: Mitchell went to go see Dylan's Rolling Thunder Revue tour and wound up joining. At the time
column4: she was a peer of Dylan
column5: commercially and as a songwriter
column6: she was also tight with tour member Robbie Robertson of the Band. She had a song in the Billboard Top 10-- and she was opening. When Mitchell recounts this in later interviews
column7: she talks about how being on the tour was a matter of constantly having to subvert her ego to the men around her.

column1: At this same time
column2: many of her peers were headed further toward the mainstream
column3: towards syncopation
column4: towards rock
column5: towards retro revivalism. Mitchell saw there was not much of a place for her amongst the new talents and the Peter Pan-ing crew she came up with
column6: as a woman in her early 30s
column7: and she saw jazz as a genre that would allow her to age gracefully and expand as an artist-- and so there she went. She was trying to find or develop a place to belong.

column1: Through all of this she arrived at Hissing of Summer Lawns.
The 1975 album marks Mitchell's official departure from the mainstream
column2: her embarking upon her jazzbo journey. It's the album of an artist absolutely assured of herself
column3: and it's addressed to anyone who might not consider her a serious musician
column4: who believed all she could do was confess her heartache. Though it doesn't have the rhapsodic rep as Blue
column5: it's unquestionably one of Mitchell's finest albums
column6: and it is certainly her most timeless.

column1: It opens easy enough with ""In France They Kiss on Main Street""-- a soft
column2: linear move from Court. What follows is jarring if you were expecting more of the same: ""The Jungle Line"" runs over a distorting sample of the Royal Drummers of Burundi tribal pounding and chanting. Mitchell going from husky to her enunciation so precise about ""the mathematic circuits of the modern nights
column3: the long
column4: low whirring of a Moog running the melody line under Mitchell's acoustic strumming. The rest of the record is dark
column5: tense
column6: and lilts unapologetically toward something softer and more ornate than jazz fusion (no more than the later Steely Dan records it predated) with Mitchell singing observationally
column7: about the place of women in the world
column8: about the trade-offs they make for power and freedom.

column1: Mitchell and women of her generation had been brought up with the idea that marriage to a man who took care of them would fulfill them entirely and that ambitions beyond that were frivolous. The album is a reckoning reflective of culture at the time; Hissing is an album of women trying to find their real selves in a world that had groomed them for quiet obeisance to men. On ""Harry's House"" Mitchell sings of a curdling domestic scene
column2: of wives who ""paper the walls to keep their gut reactions hid."" The song dovetails into the standard ""Centerpiece""
column3: which she sings in a voice not her own
column4: playacting with this ultra-feminine throwback voice
column5: creating a critical distance when she sings the lines: ""I'm building all my dreams around you/ Our happiness will never cease/ 'Cause nothing's any good without you/ Baby you're my centerpiece."" And on the subtlety devastating ""Sweet Bird""
column6: she sings of women wielding power through beauty and youth
column7: and what is lost and gained in that bargaining: ""Power ideals and beauty/ Fading in everyone's hand"" and ""Calendars of our lives/ Circled with compromise.""

column1: Mitchell had never made a record that wasn't bigger than the one before and was shocked that her fans and many critics saw her new sound as an abandonment and misguided move
column2: respectively. Reviewers chastised her for her ego. While the album went gold and brought her a Grammy nod
column3: as her 1974 live album Miles of Aisles attests (a wonky fiasco
column4: skip it) there were still plenty of people shouting for ""Big Yellow Taxi"". But that Joni didn't live here anymore. Hissing was proof. The era of Mitchell doing no wrong was over and if her audience couldn't hang
column5: she wasn't about to do anything to reel them back in.

column1: The two albums that followed are where Mitchell went off the grid. Hejira
column2: from 1976
column3: was written while driving alone from Maine to L.A. and is a meditation on the value and melancholy of being alone
column4: her guitar imitating the rhythms and expanse of the road. In spots it's as emotionally bare as Blue. It's a real grown woman album and may not make tremendous sense to anyone under 30.

column1: Musically
column2: Mitchell says she was trying to see how far she could get from traditional rhythm; the songs are long and lovely
column3: burbling and unspooling. Whether or not you feel this era of Mitchell is unfairly maligned depends on how you feel about Jaco Pastorious and his fretless bass and its many
column4: many notes fardling way up high in the mix. His playing lends a darkly cinematic feeling to the album
column5: but in the decades since his trademark sound and style have been taken to such unpleasant extremes by jam and light jazz bands
column6: it's understandable to experience a visceral revulsion.

column1: Inspired by the rhythms of Brazilian music
column2: Mitchell issued the experimental double-album Don Juan's Reckless Daughter in '77. Her experiments went further than just musical; she appears in brownface and an afro wig as a man on the cover. Less commented on is her in ""injun"" costume on the back
column3: palm raised
column4: a bubble above her head reads ""How!"" (Her cringe-inducing arguments about it later on included statements about how she has a ""black man's soul""). The album is solidly jazz-fusion
column5: indulgent in length with still plenty of Jaco-dominance. But! there is reward in the album's centerpiece
column6: if you can make it that far: The 16-minute ""Paprika Plains"" is a freakout of a song suite
column7: inspired in part by a conversation with prickly ol' Bob Dylan. Even if you cannot abide by the album
column8: we must be grateful for it
column9: as it is Bjork's #1 favorite album and source of inspiration. The last piece in the box
column10: Mingus
column11: her 1979 collaboration with Charles Mingus before his death makes her seem like the jazz dilettante that people accused her of being. The ultimate result doesn't serve either of their legacies particularly well.

column1: Though Mitchell's weird escapade through pop doesn't end where the box set does
column2: she never recaptured the thread of popular imagination. Her 80s albums
column3: like many of her hippie-era peers'
column4: were overbearing and scolding and featured awkward embraces of technology. She retired for long stretches to focus on her painting. Her last good record was 2000's Both Sides Now
column5: where
column6: her range ravaged by decades of smoking
column7:
she sings the definitive version of the titular song that launched her career and finally sounds like she's seen enough to know.

column2: few musicians have understood its nature so well. In the 1960s and 70s

column3: palm raised
column4: a bubble above her head reads ""How!"" (Her cringe-inducing arguments about it later on included statements about how she has a ""black man's soul""). The album is solidly jazz-fusion
column5: indulgent in length with still plenty of Jaco-dominance. But! there is reward in the album's centerpiece
column6: if you can make it that far: The 16-minute ""Paprika Plains"" is a freakout of a song suite
column7: inspired in part by a conversation with prickly ol' Bob Dylan. Even if you cannot abide by the album

column10: Mingus
column11: her 1979 collaboration with Charles Mingus before his death makes her seem like the jazz dilettante that people accused her of being. The ultimate result doesn't serve either of their legacies particularly well.

column1: Though Mitchell's weird escapade through pop doesn't end where the box set does
column2: she never recaptured the thread of popular imagination. Her 80s albums
column3: like many of her hippie-era peers'
column4: were overbearing and scolding and featured awkward embraces of technology. She retired for long stretches to focus on her painting. Her last good record was 2000's Both Sides Now
column5: where
column6: her range ravaged by decades of smoking
column7:
she sings the definitive version of the titular song that launched her career and finally sounds like she's seen enough to know.

Sisters Taraka and Nimai Larson-- anchors of the new-age revival project Prince Rama-- are no strangers to mixing make believe and music. From their background as Hare Krishnas to far-out live shows that often verge on performance art to conducting ""group exorcisms disguised as VHS workouts

column10: channeling the ghosts of each one to perform the various songs."" This premise includes a new wave band
column11: a Hindi-pop act
column12: and a desert psych group
column13: all complete with  fictional bios and names like the Metaphysixxx
column14: Nu Fighters
column15: and I.M.M.O.R.T.A.L.I.F.E.

column1: Now

column5: Prince Rama have curated an enjoyable pop experience that both works independently of its concept and pays greater dividends the more you play along. Still reluctant to completely disavow their roots-- layers of summersaulting drums
column6: new-age synths
column7: and melodies steeped in Eastern musics all remain-- Prince Rama have placed the importance of movement
column8: hooks
column9: and accessibility above all else. Take the excellent ""No Way Back"" (an interpretation of the single by the imaginary motorcycle band/ murderous graverobbers Nu Fighters)
column10: which takes the pair's mythic
column11: seance-y vibes and refracts them through the mirroball
column12: complete with acid-washed guitar squeals and a strangely sinister
column13: wind-in-your-face feeling of freedom. Whether it's the ABBA worship of ""We Will Fallin Love Again"" or the wink to New Order on the clubby
column14: pulsating <a href=""http://pitchfork.com/reviews/tracks/14340-those-who-live-for-love-will-live-forever/"" target=""_blank"">""Those Who Live For Love Will Live Forever""
column15: the nods are often subtle

column1: The lack of humor and self-awareness in Prince Rama's music has always been a stumbling block

column3: phony band press shots to the those backstories (the blurbs regarding the Metaphysixxx and I.M.M.O.R.T.A.L.I.F.E. are wonderfully stupid)
column4: the Larsons seem in on a joke that was frequently pointed only at them
column5: and the reversal is endearing. The newfound carefree attitude suits nicely: While the oddly ""Creep""-ish
column6: frat boy dub of ""Welcome to the Now Age"" or the Ariel Pink Goes Bollywood feel of ""Radhamadhava"" might not make for a great songs
column7: they don't make for boring ones
column8: either.

column1: End of the World still isn't quite as fun as it could be

column3: but often don't embrace the potential of the genre-bending fun that's in front of them. Not to mention that pretty much every track on the record could've greatly benefitted from a high-definition mix instead of the slightly muffled one they've ended up going with here. Still

column6:
and for an act like Prince Rama-- whose own skewed sense of reality was once a deterrent-- it's an idea that's realized on End of the World in the form of a compliment.

Before there was metal

column5: endlessly soloing guitars of Nilsson and Jonathan Ramm. The anger is even more palpable on ""An Industry of Murder""
column6: a death march that sounds like ""Black Sabbath"" played in double-time

column8: howling
column9: ""The unholy alliance

column11: when greed has set your path.""

column1: Bands like Graveyard will always be susceptible to accusations of nostalgia

column5: as in blues
column6: act as signposts that must be respected

column8:
at some point you're obliged to eventually bring it all back home.

column1: All the courage in the world

column14: well

really. You can't bob your head to it; you can't learn anything from it. This is music that fails at everything it tries to do.

Because the producer is such a talented chameleon-- evoking with the 34 tracks here a whole range of his fellows-- the album ends up functioning as a sort of survey course: every piece
column8: based on its distinct construction and influences

column1: As a hip-hop instrumentalist
column2: Riggins hews most closely to the Dilla format
column3: taking miniaturized loops and samples and scrambling them together to come up with the eminently digestible sketches now immortalized as ""donuts."" This approach frequently yields tracks that sound time-stamped by certain periods of Dilla's progression

""Double Trouble"" evokes Dilla most strongly; its woodwind flourishes and tonal progressions may as well have been produced by Jay Dee's ghost.

column1: But Riggins is more than just a convincing Dilla clone. The producer's interest in exotic instrumentation also recalls some of Madlib's more far-flung forays. ""Moogy Foog It"" (think Beat Konducta in India)
column2: ""Esperanza"" (which incorporates a trilling flute)
column3: ""Africa""
column4: and ""Back in Brazil"" are spread throughout the album

column3: though aptly titled with its gladiator ululation

column6: the anxiety-inducing ""Because""

column5: may not be a great movie. But I don't think making a great movie was his goal. It seems more likely RZA wanted to make an awesome movie

column1: The accompanying soundtrack boasts several things the movie lacks: continuity
column2: professional editing

column4: but it never strives to be awesome. And for a RZA project
column5: that means it can't be great either.

column1: The conservative streak of Iron Fists is understandable on two levels: For one
column2: it's RZA's first of what may be many big-money Hollywood projects. And he's recently gone on record saying the Wu could achieve one final triumph

column9: blaxploitation sonic blueprint that runs parallel to the movie's grindhouse aesthetic and allows for simmering soul pieces from Corinne Bailey Rae and the Revelations as well an appositely chipper Japanese pop song to sit alongside M.O.P. and Freddie Gibbs.

column3: cosmic energy to become a human weapon
column4: but most of the songs here seem to identify with the Blacksmith's day job. ""Black Out"" features M.O.P.
column5: Ghostface
column6: and Pharoahe Monch in a grouping that surely excites on name alone as does the Raekwon
column7: Ghost

column10: you wish they'd provide something more animated and celebratory.

column1: Opener ""Baddest Man Alive"" aims for that territory

column3: which is still a fairly simple concept: rap over a slower Black Keys song. It's enjoyable hearing RZA using his serious voice while not taking himself so seriously
column4: something akin to Bobby Digital rebranding himself as a Saturday morning cartoon (though he'd have to do away with lyrics like ""I date rape Beauty right in front of the Beast."") Otherwise
column5: RZA looks outside his Clan to channel the film's base desires. Kanye West's ""White Dress"" is an outlier; though co-produced by RZA

His technically-obsessed hardhead raps come off like a less off-kilter Masta Killa or a gullier Black Knights rather than the consummate gangsta rap loner guise he's made a career on. I'm at a loss to explain where Wiz Khalifa fits into all of this

serving as a muse whose inspiration is perhaps too prevalent on the movie and not enough on the soundtrack.

Hans-Peter Lindstrøm is not one for concise statements: The Norwegian space-disco producer once put out an album with a 30-minute lead track and then followed that release with a 45-minute cover of ""Little Drummer Boy"". But now comes the comparatively modest Smalhans
column2: Lindstrøm's second release in 2012 following this past winter's Six Cups of Rebel. The latter was a wildly experimental record from an artist known for subtle shifts

column6: cosmic dance that maintains an earthy humanity.

column1: Occasionally

Plenty of words have been used to describe the scene-defining UK dance music of Leeds-based Hessle Audio label. ""Funny"" has not been one of them. Yet there it is

column3: imploring via sample

column6: ""Work It""
column7: and it's funny because a UK dance artist sampling Missy Elliott and Timabland-- or really any early-aughts US hip-hop-- could not be construed as being ""ahead of the game."" For a while

column1: Kevin McAuley
column2: aka Pangaea

column1: It is the only thing that takes him out of the running. Pangaea's debut album
column2: by all measures except McAuley's own
column3: is a wily and undefinable example of progressive underground dance music. His best work imagines a world in which UK garage mates with the scraped-knee utility of 1990s techno instead of sinking into the city-low hues of dubstep. It's a beguiling mix
column4: one that marries the syncopated rhythmic template and radio-bait of garage with chilly
column5: alien textures.

column1: More than any Hessle production before it
column2: Release is singular
column3: almost standoffish. There are no DJ tools here
column4: very little grist for the Rinse FM mill. This is McAuley stepping outside his comfort zone because he-- and indeed the entire Hessle crew-- has built a reputation on providing not only forward-thinking dance music
column5: but forward-thinking dance music that plays nicely with its UK club peers. Release stays sour and pugnacious throughout its eight tracks. There are nods to classic UK dubstep-- the yawning pulses that dominate the second half of the title track
column6: the stoned tempo of ""Middleman""-- but its McAuley's devotion to briney tectures and anti-climaxes that define Release. This is techno-as-worldview
column7: a struggle with machines
column8: not dystopian but properly pessimistic.

column1: McAuley fancies cut-up vocals like many of his peers
column2: but he doesn't shade them into darkness like
column3: say
column4: Burial; he forces them through a meat grinder
column5: and they come out the other side pink and compressed. Nowhere more so than on the final track
column6: ""High""
column7: a beatless horrorshow that juxtaposes warm electronic pulses with mangled vocals. This brutal treatment goes on for more than seven minutes-- the longest track on the album. The sample appears to be from an old club track

column1: While Pangaea and Hessle's peers have resorted to mealy
column2: house-music gruel (Hotflush) and thinly veiled populism (Hyperdub)

column4: self-conscious antagonism of the purest variety. It's newness by necessity. (And it's no shock that among all the artists featured in Resident Advisor's Machine Love series

column6: the place where his dexterity and rankle can be best put to use. Release is leaden and brute
column7:
and Pangaea has never been the type to carry anchors. Be glad McAuley leaves them lying around for us.

column5: there's rarely a chance for rest or

column15: crisscrossing layers of serrated vocals and clean-singing harmonies suggesting metalcore as swallowed by the abyss. During ""In Coelo Quies

column1: 0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/18470/homepage_large.9d6f36dd.jpg|Free Reign|779.0|Clinic|['Rock'
column2: 'Experimental'
column4: Clinic have left their surgical masks on longer than KISS initially kept on their make-up
column5: and this rigid visual motif makes it easy to overlook the Liverpool art-rock quartet's evolution. We've grown accustomed to conflating an artist's musical progression with their changing appearances-- like when they go through a beardo phase
column6: or get ill-advised new-wave haircuts
column7: or start wearing guyliner. But Clinic always look like Clinic
column8: which reinforces the idea that they always sound like Clinic. Even when the band embraced soft-pop melody and open-hearted lyricism on 2010's knowingly titled Bubblegum
column9: it seemed to only amplify this band's inherent
column10: ineffable strangeness.

column1: Those masks aren't just a gimmicky extension of Clinic's name; they're also a visual manifestation of the band's meticulous approach
column2: as they've taken a scalpel to music from the 1960s and 70s-- the Monks
column3: Sparks
column4: Joe Meek
column5: krautrock-- and stitched their favorite bits into new
column6: mutant forms. But compared to the concise structures of their six previous albums
column7: on Free Reign
column8: the band behaves less like surgeons and more like scientists who favor exploration and patience. The game plan this time is to switch their analog synths to the ""Suicide"" setting and see where the drones take them.

column1: The more open-ended ethos also extends to the band's choice of mixer: Daniel Lopatin aka Oneohtrix Point Never. Lopatin's avant-electronic soundscaping has little in common with Clinic's compact collage-rock
column2: but his influence seems less about sound than spirit. Clinic show a greater willingness to let these songs unfurl according to their own logic and pace: The slow-percolating opener
column3: ""Misty""
column4: doesn't reveal its chiming
column5: churchly Spiritualized-like keyboard hook until a good two minutes in
column6: which is usually the point when Clinic are wrapping a song up. It's also the first of four songs here to crack the five-minute mark
column7: heretofore uncharted territory in the Clinic canon.

column1: But as Free Reign shows
column2: when Clinic take their time
column3: they can build up a bewitching groove. The album's twin highlights
column4: ""Miss You"" and ""You""
column5: are similarly titled
column6: similarly structured
column7: and similarly libidinous exercises in disco-Can decadence; while a touch too slow for dancefloor traction
column8: they both get impressively freakier and funkier the longer they stretch out. ""Seamless Boogie Woofie BBC2 10"" works the same trick in more abbreviated form
column9: while proving that even a chorus of ""you're beautiful"" can sound creepily sinister when coming from ever-enigmatic vocalist Ade Blackburn.

column1: But if Free Reign posits Clinic as unlikely heirs to the LCD Soundsystem legacy of post-punky electro-rock
column2: it also reveals the mess they made along the way. ""See Saw"" practically kills the album's momentum before it even gets going
column3: with a maddeningly repetitious caveman stomp that sounds like a practice-space goof. ""Cosmic Radiation"" and ""Sun and the Moon"" meanwhile
column4: offer glimpses of Clinic as jam band
column5: with Blackburn's omnipresent melodica squawking over the former's aimless
column6: wah-wah'ed jazz-funk rhythm
column7: while the latter's loose blues ramble imagines the late-era Doors gone dub.

column1: But in between Free Reign's two extremes-- of taut groove and directionless doodle-- Clinic also add to their deepening catalog of disarmingly affecting ballads with ""For the Season""
column2: a wistful whisper of a song that inspires scenes of slow dances in empty ballrooms. It may be the most atypical track here
column3: but on an album that so doggedly documents the process of experimentation
column4:
it's a welcome moment where Clinic can let down the mask and enjoy a breather.

It isn't until the 20th and final song on Gucci Mane's third mixtape of the year
column2: Trap God
column3: that you run into a verse based around Gucci making car noises with his mouth. This may seem like an insignificant detail
column4: but in Gucci terms
column5: this marks a major evolutionary event. Facial tattoos notwithstanding
column6: he's cautious and conservative when it comes to change
column7: and it takes a few spins through Trap God before the differences between it and past records come into focus. But once they do
column8: they cohere into a portrait of an artist in the midst of an aesthetic metamorphosis.

column1: Gucci isn't prone to the kind of daring innovations that have made Kanye the rap-game Apple Inc.
column2: a market-dominating behemoth who drops a zeitgeist-altering product about once a year. He's more like a niche company that builds devices for hardcore gamers
column3: and offers a larger selection of goods that differ from each other only incrementally
column4: but which aim at satisfying the needs of a more specialist crowd.

column1: And if anything
column2: Gucci's been almost too consistently good at delivering. Ever since he first started getting attention on a national scale in 2009
column3: during an especially prolific period where he put out eight LPs' worth of material in a 12-month span
column4: he could be counted on to release albums
column5: mixtapes
column6: and guest verses at such a blinding rate and that so reliably hit all of the marks his audience has come to expect-- the car noises
column7: the ""s'Gucci"" ad libs
column8: the good-but-not-incredible lyrics peppered with the requisite number of punchlines-- that they tend to blur together.

column1: Trap God has the lyrics and the punchline frequency (as well as the nasally congested
column2: marble-mouthed flow)
column3: but it's short on the trademark Gucci vocal tics. In fact
column4: sometimes it seems like there isn't enough Gucci in general-- not counting the brief ""Intro""
column5: there are only four tracks that don't feature a guest rapper or singer
column6: and three of them come in the back half of the record. And on some of the tracks he doesn't feel completely present
column7: an effect that's exacerbated when he teams up with Meek Mill
column8: Rick Ross
column9: and his former protégé Waka Flocka Flame
column10: three artists with outsize personalities who are currently at the top of their respective games. And the tracks where he comes out unambiguously on top-- including the handful alongside newly signed 1017 Brick Squad second-stringer Young Scooter-- the matchups feel lopsided.

column1: The bright side is that Trap God's best songs are among the best in Gucci's catalog. Probably not coincidentally they also tend to be the ones where Gucci challenges himself the most. On the chiptune-inflected ""Suckaz"" (produced by Shawty Redd) and ""Act Up"" (produced by T-Pain
column2: who also provides a killer vocal on the chorus)
column3: he sounds energetic and loose
column4: hovering weightlessly over the beat. And when he squares off with Waka Flocka and internet mixtape sensation Kirko Bangz on the 808 Mafia-produced ode to no-strings-attached sex
column5: ""Fawk Something""
column6: he comes through with a remarkably profane verse that includes a brief and totally hilarious swing at impersonating a dancehall rapper.

column1: When Gucci puts his mind to writing a chorus these days
column2: he's coming up with better stuff than he ever has before. ""Rolly Up"" may have the most irritatingly unshakeable hook this side of Jibbs' ""Chain Hang Low""
column3: but the back-to-back cuts ""Money Habits"" and ""Crazy"" are spiked with eccentrically catchy
column4: off-key candy pop passages that suggest he might be the spiritual heir to Ol' Dirty Bastard at his karaoke-crooner best. Still
column5: while Gucci Mane's recently been stuck in a particularly enjoyable rut
column6: a rut is still a rut. It's good to see him start to pull himself out of it
column7: even if it's slow going
column8:
inch by inch.

Much of the current wave of aggressive
column3: pop-oriented dance music can be traced to 2005. That year
column4: Madonna's late-career foray into Eurodance

column6: while French Touch veteran Alan Braxe attracted indie types to glittery hedonism with his stellar singles comp The Upper Cuts. Meanwhile
column7: the teeth-grinding one-two French electro-punch of Justice's antagonistic Waters of Nazareth 12"" and Daft Punk's oft-maligned Human After All now sound strangely prescient.

column1: Vitalic
column2: real name Pascal Arbez
column3: fit in with those last two artists in the middle of the last decade. Four years after releasing the stacked Poney EP
column4: he dropped OK Cowboy
column5: a dizzying collection of loopy
column6: buzzy electro that would work for any 2010s HARD Fest attendee. If that album was a series of bright
column7: loud firecrackers
column8: then 2009's Flashmob resembled a slow-burning candle
column9: as it found the French producer adding shades of sultry disco to his palette. It was a fine album
column10: but the low-key aesthetic and lack of big singles lessened its impact.

column1: Three years later
column2: we have Rave Age

column4: and the record looks toward past glories
column5: too. Rave Age's first two singles
column6: ""No More Sleep"" and ""Stamina""
column7: bring to mind OK Cowboy's more audacious moments

column1: The streamlined vocal cuts don't all work
column2: but at least Arbez seems engaged on them. The gritty ""La Mort Sur Le Dance Floor"" features a snotty performance from French singer Rebeka Warrior that should be avoided as long as Crystal Castles are going
column3: but ""Under Your Sun"" fares better thanks to airy
column4: hollow production and a perfectly competent high-register touch from fellow countrywoman Owlle. The standout from the pop cuts is ""Fade Away""
column5: featuring an arena-scale tender take from Shitdisco's Joe Reeves. It works in part because it's the most straightforwardly gorgeous thing on the record
column6: but for me the real appeal is how its structure parallels Saint Etienne's head-in-the-clouds remix of the Drums' ""Forever and Ever Amen"".

column1: And that's the album's biggest problem: Rave Age makes you wish you were listening to other songs. The closer you listen to the wobbly hip-hop textures
column2: overly-busy techno
column3: and generic dark ambience
column4: the less the album needs to exist. Maximalism has frequently been Arbez's thing-- it's the quality that made him rise to some sort of prominence to begin with. But on Rave Age
column5:
he does too much of everything and sounds mostly like a whole lot of nothing.
